00:00:12.434 --> 00:00:13.585
I do two things:

00:00:13.609 --> 00:00:15.727
I design mobile computers
and I study brains.

00:00:15.751 --> 00:00:18.681
Today's talk is about brains
and -- (Audience member cheers)

00:00:18.705 --> 00:00:20.522
Yay! I have a brain fan out there.

00:00:20.546 --> 00:00:23.693
(Laughter)

00:00:23.717 --> 00:00:25.272
If I could have my first slide,

00:00:25.296 --> 00:00:28.145
you'll see the title of my talk
and my two affiliations.

00:00:28.169 --> 00:00:31.637
So what I'm going to talk about is why
we don't have a good brain theory,

00:00:31.661 --> 00:00:33.938
why it is important
that we should develop one

00:00:33.962 --> 00:00:35.445
and what we can do about it.

00:00:35.469 --> 00:00:37.293
I'll try to do all that in 20 minutes.

00:00:37.317 --> 00:00:38.468
I have two affiliations.

00:00:38.492 --> 00:00:41.024
Most of you know me
from my Palm and Handspring days,

00:00:41.048 --> 00:00:43.731
but I also run a nonprofit
scientific research institute

00:00:43.755 --> 00:00:46.387
called the Redwood Neuroscience
Institute in Menlo Park.

00:00:46.411 --> 00:00:49.799
We study theoretical neuroscience
and how the neocortex works.

00:00:49.823 --> 00:00:51.421
I'm going to talk all about that.

00:00:51.445 --> 00:00:54.190
I have one slide on my other life,
the computer life,

00:00:54.214 --> 00:00:55.515
and that's this slide here.

00:00:55.539 --> 00:00:58.807
These are some of the products
I've worked on over the last 20 years,

00:00:58.831 --> 00:01:00.673
starting from the very original laptop

00:01:00.697 --> 00:01:02.484
to some of the first tablet computers

00:01:02.508 --> 00:01:04.806
and so on, ending up
most recently with the Treo,

00:01:04.830 --> 00:01:06.362
and we're continuing to do this.

00:01:06.386 --> 00:01:08.687
I've done this because
I believe mobile computing

00:01:08.711 --> 00:01:10.435
is the future of personal computing,

00:01:10.459 --> 00:01:12.913
and I'm trying to make
the world a little bit better

00:01:12.937 --> 00:01:14.233
by working on these things.

00:01:14.257 --> 00:01:16.131
But this was, I admit, all an accident.

00:01:16.155 --> 00:01:18.463
I really didn't want to do
any of these products.

00:01:18.487 --> 00:01:19.869
Very early in my career

00:01:19.893 --> 00:01:22.583
I decided I was not going to be
in the computer industry.

00:01:22.607 --> 00:01:24.328
Before that, I just have to tell you

00:01:24.352 --> 00:01:27.460
about this picture of Graffiti
I picked off the web the other day.

00:01:27.484 --> 00:01:30.737
I was looking for a picture for Graffiti
that'll text input language.

00:01:30.761 --> 00:01:34.450
I found a website dedicated to teachers
who want to make script-writing things

00:01:34.474 --> 00:01:36.148
across the top of their blackboard,

00:01:36.172 --> 00:01:39.005
and they had added Graffiti to it,
and I'm sorry about that.

00:01:39.029 --> 00:01:41.276
(Laughter)

00:01:41.300 --> 00:01:42.600
So what happened was,

00:01:42.624 --> 00:01:47.523
when I was young and got out
of engineering school at Cornell in '79,

00:01:47.547 --> 00:01:50.734
I went to work for Intel
and was in the computer industry,

00:01:50.758 --> 00:01:54.160
and three months into that,
I fell in love with something else.

00:01:54.184 --> 00:01:57.228
I said, "I made
the wrong career choice here,"

00:01:57.252 --> 00:01:59.491
and I fell in love with brains.

00:01:59.515 --> 00:02:01.048
This is not a real brain.

00:02:01.072 --> 00:02:03.791
This is a picture of one, a line drawing.

00:02:03.815 --> 00:02:05.934
And I don't remember
exactly how it happened,

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:09.473
but I have one recollection,
which was pretty strong in my mind.

00:02:09.497 --> 00:02:11.107
In September of 1979,

00:02:11.131 --> 00:02:14.495
Scientific American came out
with a single-topic issue about the brain.

00:02:14.519 --> 00:02:16.457
It was one of their best issues ever.

00:02:16.481 --> 00:02:19.428
They talked about the neuron,
development, disease, vision

00:02:19.452 --> 00:02:22.048
and all the things you might want
to know about brains.

00:02:22.072 --> 00:02:23.574
It was really quite impressive.

00:02:23.598 --> 00:02:26.370
One might've had the impression
we knew a lot about brains.

00:02:26.394 --> 00:02:30.589
But the last article in that issue
was written by Francis Crick of DNA fame.

00:02:30.613 --> 00:02:33.637
Today is, I think, the 50th anniversary
of the discovery of DNA.

00:02:33.661 --> 00:02:36.736
And he wrote a story basically saying,
this is all well and good,

00:02:36.760 --> 00:02:39.503
but you know, we don't know
diddly squat about brains,

00:02:39.527 --> 00:02:41.266
and no one has a clue how they work,

00:02:41.290 --> 00:02:43.156
so don't believe what anyone tells you.

00:02:43.180 --> 00:02:45.345
This is a quote
from that article, he says:

00:02:45.369 --> 00:02:49.662
"What is conspicuously lacking" --
he's a very proper British gentleman --

00:02:49.686 --> 00:02:52.516
"What is conspicuously lacking
is a broad framework of ideas

00:02:52.540 --> 00:02:54.892
in which to interpret
these different approaches."

00:02:54.916 --> 00:02:56.884
I thought the word "framework" was great.

00:02:56.908 --> 00:02:58.725
He didn't say we didn't have a theory.

00:02:58.749 --> 00:03:01.474
He says we don't even know
how to begin to think about it.

00:03:01.498 --> 00:03:02.990
We don't even have a framework.

00:03:03.014 --> 00:03:06.064
We are in the pre-paradigm days,
if you want to use Thomas Kuhn.

00:03:06.088 --> 00:03:07.427
So I fell in love with this.

00:03:07.451 --> 00:03:11.026
I said, look: We have all this knowledge
about brains -- how hard can it be?

00:03:11.050 --> 00:03:14.488
It's something we can work on
in my lifetime; I could make a difference.

00:03:14.512 --> 00:03:18.131
So I tried to get out of the computer
business, into the brain business.

00:03:18.155 --> 00:03:20.159
First, I went to MIT,
the AI lab was there.

00:03:20.183 --> 00:03:22.578
I said, I want to build
intelligent machines too,

00:03:22.602 --> 00:03:25.119
but I want to study how brains work first.

00:03:25.143 --> 00:03:27.449
And they said, "Oh, you
don't need to do that.

00:03:27.473 --> 00:03:29.863
You're just going to program
computers, that's all.

00:03:29.887 --> 00:03:31.850
I said, you really ought to study brains.

00:03:31.874 --> 00:03:33.306
They said, "No, you're wrong."

00:03:33.330 --> 00:03:35.576
I said, "No, you're wrong,"
and I didn't get in.

00:03:35.600 --> 00:03:36.678
(Laughter)

00:03:36.702 --> 00:03:38.857
I was a little disappointed --
pretty young --

00:03:38.881 --> 00:03:40.817
but I went back again a few years later,

00:03:40.841 --> 00:03:43.200
this time in California,
and I went to Berkeley.

00:03:43.224 --> 00:03:45.654
And I said, I'll go
in from the biological side.

00:03:45.678 --> 00:03:48.767
So I got in the PhD program in biophysics.

00:03:48.791 --> 00:03:52.201
I was like, I'm studying brains now.
Well, I want to study theory.

00:03:52.225 --> 00:03:54.494
They said, "You can't
study theory about brains.

00:03:54.518 --> 00:03:56.513
You can't get funded for that.

00:03:56.537 --> 00:03:58.692
And as a graduate student,
you can't do that."

00:03:58.716 --> 00:03:59.934
So I said, oh my gosh.

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:03.113
I was depressed; I said, but I can
make a difference in this field.

00:04:03.137 --> 00:04:05.145
I went back in the computer industry

00:04:05.169 --> 00:04:07.274
and said, I'll have to work
here for a while.

00:04:07.298 --> 00:04:09.691
That's when I designed
all those computer products.

00:04:09.715 --> 00:04:11.016
(Laughter)

00:04:11.040 --> 00:04:13.934
I said, I want to do this
for four years, make some money,

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:17.934
I was having a family,
and I would mature a bit,

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:20.774
and maybe the business
of neuroscience would mature a bit.

00:04:20.798 --> 00:04:23.799
Well, it took longer than four years.
It's been about 16 years.

00:04:23.823 --> 00:04:26.539
But I'm doing it now,
and I'm going to tell you about it.

00:04:26.563 --> 00:04:28.849
So why should we have a good brain theory?

00:04:28.873 --> 00:04:31.975
Well, there's lots of reasons
people do science.

00:04:31.999 --> 00:04:34.916
The most basic one is,
people like to know things.

00:04:34.940 --> 00:04:37.135
We're curious, and we go out
and get knowledge.

00:04:37.159 --> 00:04:39.025
Why do we study ants? It's interesting.

00:04:39.049 --> 00:04:42.515
Maybe we'll learn something useful,
but it's interesting and fascinating.

00:04:42.539 --> 00:04:44.596
But sometimes a science
has other attributes

00:04:44.620 --> 00:04:46.449
which makes it really interesting.

00:04:46.473 --> 00:04:49.100
Sometimes a science will tell
something about ourselves;

00:04:49.124 --> 00:04:50.348
it'll tell us who we are.

00:04:50.372 --> 00:04:53.124
Evolution did this
and Copernicus did this,

00:04:53.148 --> 00:04:55.482
where we have a new
understanding of who we are.

00:04:55.506 --> 00:04:58.934
And after all, we are our brains.
My brain is talking to your brain.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:00.988
Our bodies are hanging along for the ride,

00:05:01.012 --> 00:05:02.837
but my brain is talking to your brain.

00:05:02.861 --> 00:05:06.109
And if we want to understand
who we are and how we feel and perceive,

00:05:06.133 --> 00:05:07.524
we need to understand brains.

00:05:07.548 --> 00:05:11.332
Another thing is sometimes science leads
to big societal benefits, technologies,

00:05:11.356 --> 00:05:12.647
or businesses or whatever.

00:05:12.671 --> 00:05:15.549
This is one, too, because
when we understand how brains work,

00:05:15.573 --> 00:05:17.637
we'll be able to build
intelligent machines.

00:05:17.661 --> 00:05:19.359
That's a good thing on the whole,

00:05:19.383 --> 00:05:21.241
with tremendous benefits to society,

00:05:21.265 --> 00:05:22.934
just like a fundamental technology.

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:25.808
So why don't we have
a good theory of brains?

00:05:25.832 --> 00:05:28.000
People have been working
on it for 100 years.

00:05:28.024 --> 00:05:30.743
Let's first take a look
at what normal science looks like.

00:05:30.767 --> 00:05:31.954
This is normal science.

00:05:31.978 --> 00:05:36.052
Normal science is a nice balance
between theory and experimentalists.

00:05:36.076 --> 00:05:38.767
The theorist guy says,
"I think this is what's going on,"

00:05:38.791 --> 00:05:40.752
the experimentalist says, "You're wrong."

00:05:40.776 --> 00:05:43.780
It goes back and forth,
this works in physics, this in geology.

00:05:43.804 --> 00:05:46.813
But if this is normal science,
what does neuroscience look like?

00:05:46.837 --> 00:05:48.632
This is what neuroscience looks like.

00:05:48.656 --> 00:05:50.098
We have this mountain of data,

00:05:50.122 --> 00:05:52.192
which is anatomy, physiology and behavior.

00:05:52.216 --> 00:05:55.410
You can't imagine how much detail
we know about brains.

00:05:55.434 --> 00:05:59.026
There were 28,000 people who went
to the neuroscience conference this year,

00:05:59.050 --> 00:06:01.413
and every one of them
is doing research in brains.

00:06:01.437 --> 00:06:03.131
A lot of data, but no theory.

00:06:03.155 --> 00:06:05.155
There's a little wimpy box on top there.

00:06:05.179 --> 00:06:08.561
And theory has not played a role
in any sort of grand way

00:06:08.585 --> 00:06:10.014
in the neurosciences.

00:06:10.038 --> 00:06:11.278
And it's a real shame.

00:06:11.302 --> 00:06:12.693
Now, why has this come about?

00:06:12.717 --> 00:06:15.705
If you ask neuroscientists
why is this the state of affairs,

00:06:15.729 --> 00:06:16.975
first, they'll admit it.

00:06:16.999 --> 00:06:18.484
But if you ask them, they say,

00:06:18.508 --> 00:06:21.240
there's various reasons
we don't have a good brain theory.

00:06:21.264 --> 00:06:23.233
Some say we still don't have enough data,

00:06:23.257 --> 00:06:26.316
we need more information,
there's all these things we don't know.

00:06:26.340 --> 00:06:29.181
Well, I just told you there's data
coming out of your ears.

00:06:29.205 --> 00:06:32.369
We have so much information,
we don't even know how to organize it.

00:06:32.393 --> 00:06:33.831
What good is more going to do?

00:06:33.855 --> 00:06:37.303
Maybe we'll be lucky and discover
some magic thing, but I don't think so.

00:06:37.327 --> 00:06:40.300
This is a symptom of the fact
that we just don't have a theory.

00:06:40.324 --> 00:06:42.934
We don't need more data,
we need a good theory.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.756
Another one is sometimes people say,

00:06:44.780 --> 00:06:47.934
"Brains are so complex,
it'll take another 50 years."

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:51.312
I even think Chris said something
like this yesterday, something like,

00:06:51.336 --> 00:06:53.963
it's one of the most complicated
things in the universe.

00:06:53.987 --> 00:06:56.777
That's not true -- you're more
complicated than your brain.

00:06:56.801 --> 00:06:57.952
You've got a brain.

00:06:57.976 --> 00:07:00.126
And although the brain
looks very complicated,

00:07:00.150 --> 00:07:02.486
things look complicated
until you understand them.

00:07:02.510 --> 00:07:03.845
That's always been the case.

00:07:03.869 --> 00:07:07.112
So we can say, my neocortex,
the part of the brain I'm interested in,

00:07:07.136 --> 00:07:08.288
has 30 billion cells.

00:07:08.312 --> 00:07:10.744
But, you know what?
It's very, very regular.

00:07:10.768 --> 00:07:14.162
In fact, it looks like it's the same thing
repeated over and over again.

00:07:14.186 --> 00:07:16.722
It's not as complex as it looks.
That's not the issue.

00:07:16.746 --> 00:07:19.033
Some people say,
brains can't understand brains.

00:07:19.057 --> 00:07:21.045
Very Zen-like. Woo.

00:07:21.069 --> 00:07:23.257
(Laughter)

00:07:23.281 --> 00:07:26.140
You know, it sounds good, but why?
I mean, what's the point?

00:07:26.164 --> 00:07:28.733
It's just a bunch of cells.
You understand your liver.

00:07:28.757 --> 00:07:30.734
It's got a lot of cells in it too, right?

00:07:30.758 --> 00:07:33.252
So, you know, I don't think
there's anything to that.

00:07:33.276 --> 00:07:35.388
And finally, some people say,

00:07:35.412 --> 00:07:38.395
"I don't feel like a bunch
of cells -- I'm conscious.

00:07:38.419 --> 00:07:40.488
I've got this experience,
I'm in the world.

00:07:40.512 --> 00:07:42.422
I can't be just a bunch of cells."

00:07:42.446 --> 00:07:45.669
Well, people used to believe
there was a life force to be living,

00:07:45.693 --> 00:07:48.102
and we now know
that's really not true at all.

00:07:48.126 --> 00:07:50.024
And there's really no evidence,

00:07:50.048 --> 00:07:53.422
other than that people just disbelieve
that cells can do what they do.

00:07:53.446 --> 00:07:56.487
So some people have fallen
into the pit of metaphysical dualism,

00:07:56.511 --> 00:07:59.241
some really smart people, too,
but we can reject all that.

00:07:59.265 --> 00:08:02.160
(Laughter)

00:08:02.184 --> 00:08:03.925
No, there's something else,

00:08:03.949 --> 00:08:05.934
something really fundamental, and it is:

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.409
another reason why we don't have
a good brain theory

00:08:08.433 --> 00:08:13.968
is because we have an intuitive,
strongly held but incorrect assumption

00:08:13.992 --> 00:08:16.104
that has prevented us
from seeing the answer.

00:08:16.128 --> 00:08:19.916
There's something we believe that just,
it's obvious, but it's wrong.

00:08:19.940 --> 00:08:23.506
Now, there's a history of this in science
and before I tell you what it is,

00:08:23.530 --> 00:08:25.829
I'll tell you about the history
of it in science.

00:08:25.853 --> 00:08:27.763
Look at other scientific revolutions --

00:08:27.787 --> 00:08:29.666
the solar system, that's Copernicus,

00:08:29.690 --> 00:08:32.509
Darwin's evolution,
and tectonic plates, that's Wegener.

00:08:33.017 --> 00:08:35.312
They all have a lot in common
with brain science.

00:08:35.336 --> 00:08:38.002
First, they had a lot
of unexplained data. A lot of it.

00:08:38.026 --> 00:08:40.820
But it got more manageable
once they had a theory.

00:08:40.844 --> 00:08:43.651
The best minds were stumped --
really smart people.

00:08:43.675 --> 00:08:45.679
We're not smarter now than they were then;

00:08:45.703 --> 00:08:48.230
it just turns out it's really
hard to think of things,

00:08:48.254 --> 00:08:50.930
but once you've thought of them,
it's easy to understand.

00:08:50.954 --> 00:08:53.060
My daughters understood
these three theories,

00:08:53.084 --> 00:08:55.602
in their basic framework, in kindergarten.

00:08:55.626 --> 00:08:58.892
It's not that hard --
here's the apple, here's the orange,

00:08:58.916 --> 00:09:00.934
the Earth goes around, that kind of stuff.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:03.544
Another thing is the answer
was there all along,

00:09:03.568 --> 00:09:06.347
but we kind of ignored it
because of this obvious thing.

00:09:06.371 --> 00:09:09.221
It was an intuitive,
strongly held belief that was wrong.

00:09:09.245 --> 00:09:10.935
In the case of the solar system,

00:09:10.959 --> 00:09:12.719
the idea that the Earth is spinning,

00:09:12.743 --> 00:09:14.934
the surface is going
a thousand miles an hour,

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:18.207
and it's going through the solar system
at a million miles an hour --

00:09:18.231 --> 00:09:20.707
this is lunacy; we all know
the Earth isn't moving.

00:09:20.731 --> 00:09:23.608
Do you feel like you're moving
a thousand miles an hour?

00:09:23.632 --> 00:09:26.551
If you said Earth was spinning
around in space and was huge --

00:09:26.575 --> 00:09:29.166
they would lock you up,
that's what they did back then.

00:09:29.190 --> 00:09:32.465
So it was intuitive and obvious.
Now, what about evolution?

00:09:32.489 --> 00:09:33.643
Evolution, same thing.

00:09:33.667 --> 00:09:36.747
We taught our kids the Bible says
God created all these species,

00:09:36.771 --> 00:09:39.914
cats are cats; dogs are dogs;
people are people; plants are plants;

00:09:39.938 --> 00:09:41.179
they don't change.

00:09:41.203 --> 00:09:43.852
Noah put them on the ark
in that order, blah, blah.

00:09:43.876 --> 00:09:47.271
The fact is, if you believe in evolution,
we all have a common ancestor.

00:09:47.295 --> 00:09:50.577
We all have a common ancestor
with the plant in the lobby!

00:09:50.601 --> 00:09:54.287
This is what evolution tells us.
And it's true. It's kind of unbelievable.

00:09:54.311 --> 00:09:56.868
And the same thing about tectonic plates.

00:09:56.892 --> 00:09:58.614
All the mountains and the continents

00:09:58.638 --> 00:10:00.982
are kind of floating around
on top of the Earth.

00:10:01.006 --> 00:10:02.252
It doesn't make any sense.

00:10:02.276 --> 00:10:06.877
So what is the intuitive,
but incorrect assumption,

00:10:06.901 --> 00:10:08.868
that's kept us from understanding brains?

00:10:08.892 --> 00:10:12.185
I'll tell you. It'll seem obvious
that it's correct. That's the point.

00:10:12.209 --> 00:10:15.643
Then I'll make an argument why
you're incorrect on the other assumption.

00:10:15.667 --> 00:10:17.349
The intuitive but obvious thing is:

00:10:17.373 --> 00:10:19.687
somehow, intelligence
is defined by behavior;

00:10:19.711 --> 00:10:22.061
we're intelligent
because of how we do things

00:10:22.085 --> 00:10:23.657
and how we behave intelligently.

00:10:23.681 --> 00:10:25.560
And I'm going to tell you that's wrong.

00:10:25.584 --> 00:10:27.715
Intelligence is defined by prediction.

00:10:27.739 --> 00:10:30.154
I'm going to work you
through this in a few slides,

00:10:30.178 --> 00:10:32.272
and give you an example
of what this means.

00:10:32.296 --> 00:10:33.597
Here's a system.

00:10:33.621 --> 00:10:36.529
Engineers and scientists
like to look at systems like this.

00:10:36.553 --> 00:10:39.716
They say, we have a thing in a box.
We have its inputs and outputs.

00:10:39.740 --> 00:10:42.980
The AI people said, the thing in the box
is a programmable computer,

00:10:43.004 --> 00:10:44.683
because it's equivalent to a brain.

00:10:44.707 --> 00:10:48.213
We'll feed it some inputs and get it
to do something, have some behavior.

00:10:48.237 --> 00:10:51.059
Alan Turing defined the Turing test,
which essentially says,

00:10:51.083 --> 00:10:54.636
we'll know if something's intelligent
if it behaves identical to a human --

00:10:54.660 --> 00:10:56.766
a behavioral metric
of what intelligence is

00:10:56.790 --> 00:10:58.934
that has stuck in our minds
for a long time.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:01.350
Reality, though --
I call it real intelligence.

00:11:01.374 --> 00:11:03.549
Real intelligence
is built on something else.

00:11:03.573 --> 00:11:06.787
We experience the world
through a sequence of patterns,

00:11:06.811 --> 00:11:08.960
and we store them, and we recall them.

00:11:08.984 --> 00:11:11.529
When we recall them,
we match them up against reality,

00:11:11.553 --> 00:11:13.804
and we're making predictions all the time.

00:11:13.828 --> 00:11:16.786
It's an internal metric;
there's an internal metric about us,

00:11:16.810 --> 00:11:20.152
saying, do we understand the world,
am I making predictions, and so on.

00:11:20.176 --> 00:11:23.178
You're all being intelligent now,
but you're not doing anything.

00:11:23.202 --> 00:11:26.204
Maybe you're scratching yourself,
but you're not doing anything.

00:11:26.228 --> 00:11:29.384
But you're being intelligent;
you're understanding what I'm saying.

00:11:29.408 --> 00:11:31.703
Because you're intelligent
and you speak English,

00:11:31.727 --> 00:11:33.478
you know the word at the end of this

00:11:33.502 --> 00:11:34.661
sentence.

00:11:34.685 --> 00:11:37.837
The word came to you;
you make these predictions all the time.

00:11:37.861 --> 00:11:39.560
What I'm saying is,

00:11:39.584 --> 00:11:42.215
the internal prediction
is the output in the neocortex,

00:11:42.239 --> 00:11:44.780
and somehow, prediction
leads to intelligent behavior.

00:11:44.804 --> 00:11:45.955
Here's how that happens:

00:11:45.979 --> 00:11:47.934
Let's start with a non-intelligent brain.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:50.967
I'll argue a non-intelligent brain,
we'll call it an old brain.

00:11:50.991 --> 00:11:53.862
And we'll say it's
a non-mammal, like a reptile,

00:11:53.886 --> 00:11:55.871
say, an alligator; we have an alligator.

00:11:55.895 --> 00:11:59.266
And the alligator has
some very sophisticated senses.

00:11:59.290 --> 00:12:02.496
It's got good eyes and ears
and touch senses and so on,

00:12:02.520 --> 00:12:03.989
a mouth and a nose.

00:12:04.013 --> 00:12:06.004
It has very complex behavior.

00:12:06.028 --> 00:12:09.934
It can run and hide. It has fears
and emotions. It can eat you.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:13.548
It can attack.
It can do all kinds of stuff.

00:12:14.151 --> 00:12:17.007
But we don't consider
the alligator very intelligent,

00:12:17.031 --> 00:12:18.707
not in a human sort of way.

00:12:18.731 --> 00:12:21.087
But it has all this complex
behavior already.

00:12:21.468 --> 00:12:23.269
Now in evolution, what happened?

00:12:23.293 --> 00:12:25.678
First thing that happened
in evolution with mammals

00:12:25.702 --> 00:12:28.233
is we started to develop a thing
called the neocortex.

00:12:28.257 --> 00:12:32.050
I'm going to represent the neocortex
by this box on top of the old brain.

00:12:32.074 --> 00:12:35.427
Neocortex means "new layer."
It's a new layer on top of your brain.

00:12:35.451 --> 00:12:37.794
It's the wrinkly thing
on the top of your head

00:12:37.818 --> 00:12:40.902
that got wrinkly because it got shoved
in there and doesn't fit.

00:12:40.926 --> 00:12:41.934
(Laughter)

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.200
Literally, it's about the size
of a table napkin

00:12:44.224 --> 00:12:45.798
and doesn't fit, so it's wrinkly.

00:12:45.822 --> 00:12:47.567
Now, look at how I've drawn this.

00:12:47.591 --> 00:12:48.977
The old brain is still there.

00:12:49.001 --> 00:12:52.656
You still have that alligator brain.
You do. It's your emotional brain.

00:12:52.680 --> 00:12:55.410
It's all those gut reactions you have.

00:12:55.434 --> 00:12:58.704
On top of it, we have this memory system
called the neocortex.

00:12:58.728 --> 00:13:03.022
And the memory system is sitting
over the sensory part of the brain.

00:13:03.046 --> 00:13:06.101
So as the sensory input
comes in and feeds from the old brain,

00:13:06.125 --> 00:13:08.279
it also goes up into the neocortex.

00:13:08.303 --> 00:13:10.216
And the neocortex is just memorizing.

00:13:10.240 --> 00:13:13.801
It's sitting there saying, I'm going
to memorize all the things going on:

00:13:13.825 --> 00:13:16.844
where I've been, people I've seen,
things I've heard, and so on.

00:13:16.868 --> 00:13:20.230
And in the future, when it sees
something similar to that again,

00:13:20.254 --> 00:13:22.889
in a similar environment,
or the exact same environment,

00:13:22.913 --> 00:13:26.468
it'll start playing it back:
"Oh, I've been here before,"

00:13:26.492 --> 00:13:28.856
and when you were here before,
this happened next.

00:13:28.880 --> 00:13:30.606
It allows you to predict the future.

00:13:30.630 --> 00:13:34.026
It literally feeds back
the signals into your brain;

00:13:34.050 --> 00:13:36.315
they'll let you see
what's going to happen next,

00:13:36.339 --> 00:13:38.934
will let you hear the word
"sentence" before I said it.

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:42.143
And it's this feeding
back into the old brain

00:13:42.167 --> 00:13:44.744
that will allow you to make
more intelligent decisions.

00:13:44.768 --> 00:13:48.257
This is the most important slide
of my talk, so I'll dwell on it a little.

00:13:48.281 --> 00:13:51.856
And all the time you say,
"Oh, I can predict things,"

00:13:51.880 --> 00:13:55.240
so if you're a rat and you go
through a maze, and you learn the maze,

00:13:55.264 --> 00:13:57.703
next time you're in one,
you have the same behavior.

00:13:57.727 --> 00:14:00.718
But suddenly, you're smarter;
you say, "I recognize this maze,

00:14:00.742 --> 00:14:04.284
I know which way to go; I've been here
before; I can envision the future."

00:14:04.308 --> 00:14:05.476
That's what it's doing.

00:14:05.500 --> 00:14:08.340
This is true for all mammals --

00:14:08.364 --> 00:14:10.395
in humans, it got a lot worse.

00:14:10.419 --> 00:14:13.006
Humans actually developed
the front of the neocortex,

00:14:13.030 --> 00:14:15.251
called the anterior part of the neocortex.

00:14:15.275 --> 00:14:16.713
And nature did a little trick.

00:14:16.737 --> 00:14:19.424
It copied the posterior,
the back part, which is sensory,

00:14:19.448 --> 00:14:20.599
and put it in the front.

00:14:20.623 --> 00:14:23.103
Humans uniquely have
the same mechanism on the front,

00:14:23.127 --> 00:14:24.681
but we use it for motor control.

00:14:24.705 --> 00:14:28.286
So we're now able to do very sophisticated
motor planning, things like that.

00:14:28.310 --> 00:14:31.436
I don't have time to explain,
but to understand how a brain works,

00:14:31.460 --> 00:14:34.997
you have to understand how the first part
of the mammalian neocortex works,

00:14:35.021 --> 00:14:37.314
how it is we store patterns
and make predictions.

00:14:37.338 --> 00:14:39.526
Let me give you
a few examples of predictions.

00:14:39.550 --> 00:14:41.226
I already said the word "sentence."

00:14:41.250 --> 00:14:44.456
In music, if you've heard a song before,

00:14:44.480 --> 00:14:47.389
when you hear it, the next note
pops into your head already --

00:14:47.413 --> 00:14:48.564
you anticipate it.

00:14:48.588 --> 00:14:51.942
With an album, at the end of a song,
the next song pops into your head.

00:14:51.966 --> 00:14:54.271
It happens all the time,
you make predictions.

00:14:54.295 --> 00:14:57.334
I have this thing called
the "altered door" thought experiment.

00:14:57.358 --> 00:15:00.187
It says, you have a door at home;

00:15:00.211 --> 00:15:01.966
when you're here, I'm changing it --

00:15:01.990 --> 00:15:05.186
I've got a guy back at your house
right now, moving the door around,

00:15:05.210 --> 00:15:06.979
moving your doorknob over two inches.

00:15:07.003 --> 00:15:10.587
When you go home tonight, you'll put
your hand out, reach for the doorknob,

00:15:10.611 --> 00:15:12.125
notice it's in the wrong spot

00:15:12.149 --> 00:15:13.836
and go, "Whoa, something happened."

00:15:13.860 --> 00:15:15.961
It may take a second,
but something happened.

00:15:15.985 --> 00:15:17.988
I can change your doorknob
in other ways --

00:15:18.012 --> 00:15:21.253
make it larger, smaller, change
its brass to silver, make it a lever,

00:15:21.277 --> 00:15:23.853
I can change the door;
put colors on, put windows in.

00:15:23.877 --> 00:15:26.028
I can change a thousand things
about your door

00:15:26.052 --> 00:15:28.060
and in the two seconds
you take to open it,

00:15:28.084 --> 00:15:29.806
you'll notice something has changed.

00:15:29.830 --> 00:15:32.414
Now, the engineering approach,
the AI approach to this,

00:15:32.438 --> 00:15:35.113
is to build a door database
with all the door attributes.

00:15:35.137 --> 00:15:37.956
And as you go up to the door,
we check them off one at time:

00:15:37.980 --> 00:15:39.326
door, door, color ...

00:15:39.350 --> 00:15:41.450
We don't do that.
Your brain doesn't do that.

00:15:41.474 --> 00:15:44.014
Your brain is making
constant predictions all the time

00:15:44.038 --> 00:15:46.072
about what will happen
in your environment.

00:15:46.096 --> 00:15:48.842
As I put my hand on this table,
I expect to feel it stop.

00:15:48.866 --> 00:15:51.885
When I walk, every step,
if I missed it by an eighth of an inch,

00:15:51.909 --> 00:15:53.442
I'll know something has changed.

00:15:53.466 --> 00:15:56.286
You're constantly making predictions
about your environment.

00:15:56.310 --> 00:15:57.903
I'll talk about vision, briefly.

00:15:57.927 --> 00:15:59.310
This is a picture of a woman.

00:15:59.334 --> 00:16:02.824
When we look at people, our eyes saccade
over two to three times a second.

00:16:02.848 --> 00:16:05.377
We're not aware of it,
but our eyes are always moving.

00:16:05.401 --> 00:16:08.836
When we look at a face, we typically
go from eye to eye to nose to mouth.

00:16:08.860 --> 00:16:10.729
When your eye moves from eye to eye,

00:16:10.753 --> 00:16:12.911
if there was something
else there like a nose,

00:16:12.935 --> 00:16:16.481
you'd see a nose where an eye
is supposed to be and go, "Oh, shit!"

00:16:16.505 --> 00:16:17.901
(Laughter)

00:16:17.925 --> 00:16:20.034
"There's something wrong
about this person."

00:16:20.058 --> 00:16:22.063
That's because you're making a prediction.

00:16:22.087 --> 00:16:25.526
It's not like you just look over and say,
"What am I seeing? A nose? OK."

00:16:25.550 --> 00:16:28.184
No, you have an expectation
of what you're going to see.

00:16:28.208 --> 00:16:29.359
Every single moment.

00:16:29.383 --> 00:16:32.012
And finally, let's think
about how we test intelligence.

00:16:32.036 --> 00:16:35.117
We test it by prediction:
What is the next word in this ...?

00:16:35.141 --> 00:16:38.768
This is to this as this is to this.
What is the next number in this sentence?

00:16:38.792 --> 00:16:41.482
Here's three visions of an object.
What's the fourth one?

00:16:41.506 --> 00:16:44.010
That's how we test it.
It's all about prediction.

00:16:44.531 --> 00:16:46.725
So what is the recipe for brain theory?

00:16:47.177 --> 00:16:49.543
First of all, we have to have
the right framework.

00:16:49.567 --> 00:16:51.480
And the framework is a memory framework,

00:16:51.504 --> 00:16:53.528
not a computational or behavior framework,

00:16:53.552 --> 00:16:54.715
it's a memory framework.

00:16:54.739 --> 00:16:57.362
How do you store and recall
these sequences of patterns?

00:16:57.386 --> 00:16:58.828
It's spatiotemporal patterns.

00:16:58.852 --> 00:17:01.861
Then, if in that framework,
you take a bunch of theoreticians --

00:17:01.885 --> 00:17:04.131
biologists generally
are not good theoreticians.

00:17:04.155 --> 00:17:07.684
Not always, but generally, there's not
a good history of theory in biology.

00:17:07.708 --> 00:17:10.282
I've found the best people
to work with are physicists,

00:17:10.306 --> 00:17:11.689
engineers and mathematicians,

00:17:11.713 --> 00:17:13.409
who tend to think algorithmically.

00:17:13.433 --> 00:17:16.697
Then they have to learn
the anatomy and the physiology.

00:17:16.721 --> 00:17:21.217
You have to make these theories
very realistic in anatomical terms.

00:17:21.241 --> 00:17:24.006
Anyone who tells you their theory
about how the brain works

00:17:24.030 --> 00:17:26.127
and doesn't tell you exactly
how it's working

00:17:26.151 --> 00:17:27.454
and how the wiring works --

00:17:27.478 --> 00:17:28.745
it's not a theory.

00:17:28.769 --> 00:17:31.602
And that's what we do
at the Redwood Neuroscience Institute.

00:17:31.626 --> 00:17:34.934
I'd love to tell you we're making
fantastic progress in this thing,

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:38.620
and I expect to be back on this stage
sometime in the not too distant future,

00:17:38.644 --> 00:17:39.808
to tell you about it.

00:17:39.832 --> 00:17:42.426
I'm really excited;
this is not going to take 50 years.

00:17:42.450 --> 00:17:44.028
What will brain theory look like?

00:17:44.052 --> 00:17:46.107
First of all, it's going
to be about memory.

00:17:46.131 --> 00:17:48.953
Not like computer memory --
not at all like computer memory.

00:17:48.977 --> 00:17:50.128
It's very different.

00:17:50.152 --> 00:17:52.409
It's a memory of very
high-dimensional patterns,

00:17:52.433 --> 00:17:54.395
like the things that come from your eyes.

00:17:54.419 --> 00:17:55.856
It's also memory of sequences:

00:17:55.880 --> 00:17:58.610
you cannot learn or recall anything
outside of a sequence.

00:17:58.634 --> 00:18:01.471
A song must be heard
in sequence over time,

00:18:01.495 --> 00:18:03.846
and you must play it back
in sequence over time.

00:18:03.870 --> 00:18:06.319
And these sequences
are auto-associatively recalled,

00:18:06.343 --> 00:18:09.216
so if I see something, I hear something,
it reminds me of it,

00:18:09.240 --> 00:18:10.773
and it plays back automatically.

00:18:10.797 --> 00:18:12.091
It's an automatic playback.

00:18:12.115 --> 00:18:14.663
And prediction of future inputs
is the desired output.

00:18:14.687 --> 00:18:17.307
And as I said, the theory
must be biologically accurate,

00:18:17.331 --> 00:18:19.815
it must be testable
and you must be able to build it.

00:18:19.839 --> 00:18:22.050
If you don't build it,
you don't understand it.

00:18:22.074 --> 00:18:23.606
One more slide.

00:18:23.630 --> 00:18:25.939
What is this going to result in?

00:18:25.963 --> 00:18:28.311
Are we going to really build
intelligent machines?

00:18:28.335 --> 00:18:32.133
Absolutely. And it's going to be
different than people think.

00:18:32.466 --> 00:18:34.858
No doubt that it's going
to happen, in my mind.

00:18:34.882 --> 00:18:37.998
First of all, we're going to build
this stuff out of silicon.

00:18:38.022 --> 00:18:40.934
The same techniques we use to build
silicon computer memories,

00:18:40.958 --> 00:18:42.109
we can use here.

00:18:42.133 --> 00:18:44.242
But they're very different
types of memories.

00:18:44.266 --> 00:18:46.289
And we'll attach
these memories to sensors,

00:18:46.313 --> 00:18:49.090
and the sensors will experience
real-live, real-world data,

00:18:49.114 --> 00:18:50.866
and learn about their environment.

00:18:50.890 --> 00:18:54.335
Now, it's very unlikely the first things
you'll see are like robots.

00:18:54.359 --> 00:18:56.934
Not that robots aren't useful;
people can build robots.

00:18:56.958 --> 00:19:00.725
But the robotics part is the hardest part.
That's old brain. That's really hard.

00:19:00.749 --> 00:19:02.756
The new brain is easier
than the old brain.

00:19:02.780 --> 00:19:05.862
So first we'll do things
that don't require a lot of robotics.

00:19:05.886 --> 00:19:08.065
So you're not going to see C-3PO.

00:19:08.089 --> 00:19:10.574
You're going to see things
more like intelligent cars

00:19:10.598 --> 00:19:13.406
that really understand
what traffic is, what driving is

00:19:13.430 --> 00:19:16.708
and have learned that cars
with the blinkers on for half a minute

00:19:16.732 --> 00:19:18.306
probably aren't going to turn.

00:19:18.330 --> 00:19:19.621
(Laughter)

00:19:19.645 --> 00:19:21.709
We can also do intelligent
security systems.

00:19:21.733 --> 00:19:25.306
Anytime we're basically using our brain
but not doing a lot of mechanics --

00:19:25.330 --> 00:19:27.389
those are the things
that will happen first.

00:19:27.413 --> 00:19:29.233
But ultimately, the world's the limit.

00:19:29.257 --> 00:19:30.989
I don't know how this will turn out.

00:19:31.013 --> 00:19:33.604
I know a lot of people who invented
the microprocessor.

00:19:33.628 --> 00:19:35.792
And if you talk to them,

00:19:35.816 --> 00:19:38.391
they knew what they were doing
was really significant,

00:19:38.415 --> 00:19:40.915
but they didn't really know
what was going to happen.

00:19:40.939 --> 00:19:43.707
They couldn't anticipate
cell phones and the Internet

00:19:43.731 --> 00:19:45.466
and all this kind of stuff.

00:19:45.490 --> 00:19:48.111
They just knew like,
"We're going to build calculators

00:19:48.135 --> 00:19:49.575
and traffic-light controllers.

00:19:49.599 --> 00:19:50.898
But it's going to be big!"

00:19:50.922 --> 00:19:53.263
In the same way, brain science
and these memories

00:19:53.287 --> 00:19:55.512
are going to be a very
fundamental technology,

00:19:55.536 --> 00:19:58.978
and it will lead to unbelievable changes
in the next 100 years.

00:19:59.002 --> 00:20:02.407
And I'm most excited about
how we're going to use them in science.

00:20:02.431 --> 00:20:05.268
So I think that's all my time -- I'm over,

00:20:05.292 --> 00:20:07.569
and I'm going to end my talk right there.

title: Swim with the giant sunfish
transcript: I'd like to start tonight by something completely different, asking you to join me by stepping off the land and jumping into the open ocean for a moment. 90 percent of the living space on the planet is in the open ocean, and it's where life — the title of our seminar tonight — it's where life began. And it's a lively and a lovely place, but we're rapidly changing the oceans with our — not only with our overfishing, our irresponsible fishing, our adding of pollutants like fertilizer from our cropland, but also, most recently, with climate change, and Steve Schneider, I'm sure, will be going into greater detail on this. Now, as we continue to tinker with the oceans, more and more reports are predicting that the kinds of seas that we're creating will be conducive to low-energy type of animals, like jellyfish and bacteria. And this might be the kind of seas we're headed for.Now jellyfish are strangely hypnotic and beautiful, and you'll see lots of gorgeous ones at the aquarium on Friday, but they sting like hell, and jellyfish sushi and sashimi is just not going to fill you up. About 100 grams of jellyfish equals four calories. So it may be good for the waistline, but it probably won't keep you satiated for very long. And a sea that's just filled and teeming with jellyfish isn't very good for all the other creatures that live in the oceans, that is, unless you eat jellyfish. And this is this voracious predator launching a sneak attack on this poor little unsuspecting jellyfish there, a by-the-wind sailor. And that predator is the giant ocean sunfish, the Mola mola, whose primary prey are jellyfish.This animal is in "The Guinness World Book of Records" for being the world's heaviest bony fish. It reaches up to almost 5,000 pounds — on a diet of jellyfish, primarily. And I think it's kind of a nice little cosmological convergence here that the Mola mola — its common name is sunfish — that its favorite food is the moon jelly. So it's kind of nice, the sun and the moon getting together this way, even if one is eating the other. Now this is typically how you see sunfish, this is where they get their common name. They like to sunbathe, can't blame them. They just lay out on the surface of the sea and most people think they're sick or lazy, but that's a typical behavior, they lie out and bask on the surface.Their other name, Mola mola, is — it sounds Hawaiian, but it's actually Latin for millstone, and that's attributable to their roundish, very bizarre, cut-off shape. It's as if, as they were growing, they just forgot the tail part. And that's actually what drew me to the Mola in the first place, was this terribly bizarre shape. You know, you look at sharks, and they're streamlined, and they're sleek, and you look at tuna, and they're like torpedoes — they just give away their agenda. They're about migration and strength, and then you look at the sunfish.(Laughter)And this is just so elegantly mysterious, it's just — it really kind of holds its cards a lot tighter than say, a tuna. So I was just intrigued with what — you know, what is this animal's story? Well, as with anything in biology, nothing really makes sense except in the light of evolution. The Mola's no exception. They appeared shortly after the dinosaurs disappeared, 65 million years ago, at a time when whales still had legs, and they come from a rebellious little puffer fish faction — oblige me a little Kipling-esque storytelling here. Of course evolution is somewhat random, and you know, about 55 million years ago there was this rebellious little puffer fish faction that said, oh, the heck with the coral reefs — we're going to head to the high seas. And lots of generations, lots of tweaking and torquing, and we turn our puffer into the Mola. You know, if you give Mother Nature enough time, that is what she will produce.They look — maybe they look kind of prehistoric and unfinished, abridged perhaps, but in fact, in fact they are the — they vie for the top position of the most evolutionarily-derived fish in the sea, right up there with flat fish. They're — every single thing about that fish has been changed. And in terms of fishes — fishes appeared 500 million years ago, and they're pretty modern, just 50 million years ago, so — so interestingly, they give away their ancestry as they develop. They start as little eggs, and they're in "The Guinness World Book of Records" again for having the most number of eggs of any vertebrate on the planet. A single four-foot female had 300 million eggs, can carry 300 million eggs in her ovaries — imagine — and they get to be over 10 feet long. Imagine what a 10 foot one has. And from that little egg, they pass through this spiky little porcupine fish stage, reminiscent of their ancestry, and develop — this is their little adolescent stage. They school as adolescents, and become behemoth loners as adults. That's a little diver up there in the corner.They're in "The Guinness World Book of Records" again for being the vertebrate growth champion of the world. From their little hatching size of their egg, into their little larval stage till they reach adulthood, they put on 600 million times an increase in weight. 600 million. Now imagine if you gave birth to a little baby, and you had to feed this thing. That would mean that your child, you would expect it to gain the weight of six Titanics. Now I don't know how you'd feed a child like that but — we don't know how fast the Molas grow in the wild, but captive growth studies at the Monterey Bay Aquarium — one of the first places to have them in captivity — they had one that gained 800 lbs in 14 months. I said, now, that's a true American.(Laughter)(Applause)So being a loner is a great thing, especially in today's seas, because schooling used to be salvation for fishes, but it's suicide for fishes now. But unfortunately Molas, even though they don't school, they still get caught in nets as by-catch. If we're going to save the world from total jellyfish domination, then we've got to figure out what the jellyfish predators — how they live their lives, like the Mola. And unfortunately, they make up a large portion of the California by-catch — up to 26 percent of the drift net. And in the Mediterranean, in the swordfish net fisheries, they make up up to 90 percent. So we've got to figure out how they're living their lives. And how do you do that? How do you do that with an animal — very few places in the world. This is an open ocean creature. It knows no boundaries — it doesn't go to land.How do you get insight? How do you seduce an open ocean creature like that to spill its secrets? Well, there's some great new technology that has just recently become available, and it's just a boon for getting insight into open ocean animals. And it's pictured right here, that little tag up there. That little tag can record temperature, depth and light intensity, which is correlated with time, and from that we can get locations. And it can record this data for up to two years, and keep it in that tag, release at a pre-programmed time, float to the surface, upload all that data, that whole travelogue, to satellite, which relays it directly to our computers, and we've got that whole dataset. And we didn't even have — we just had to tag the animal and then we went home and you know, sat at our desks. So the great thing about the Mola is that when we put the tag on them — if you look up here — that's streaming off, that's right where we put the tag. And it just so happens that's a parasite hanging off the Mola.Molas are infamous for carrying tons of parasites. They're just parasite hotels; even their parasites have parasites. I think Donne wrote a poem about that. But they have 40 genera of parasites, and so we figured just one more parasite won't be too much of a problem. And they happen to be a very good vehicle for carrying oceanographic equipment. They don't seem to mind, so far. So what are we trying to find out? We're focusing on the Pacific. We're tagging on the California coast, and we're tagging over in Taiwan and Japan. And we're interested in how these animals are using the currents, using temperature, using the open ocean, to live their lives. We'd love to tag in Monterey. Monterey is one of the few places in the world where Molas come in large numbers. Not this time of year — it's more around October.And we'd love to tag here — this is an aerial shot of Monterey — but unfortunately, the Molas here end up looking like this because another one of our locals really likes Molas but in the wrong way. The California sea lion takes the Molas as soon as they come into the bay, rips off their fins, fashions them into the ultimate Frisbee, Mola style, and then tosses them back and forth. And I'm not exaggerating, it is just — and sometimes they don't eat them, it's just spiteful. And you know, the locals think it's terrible behavior, it's just horrible watching this happen, day after day. The poor little Molas coming in, getting ripped to shreds, so we head down south, to San Diego. Not so many California sea lions down there. And the Molas there, you can find them with a spotter plane very easily, and they like to hang out under floating rafts of kelp. And under those kelps — this is why the Molas come there because it's spa time for the Molas there. As soon as they get under those rafts of kelp, the exfoliating cleaner fish come. And they come and give the Molas — you can see they strike this funny little position that says, "I'm not threatening, but I need a massage."(Laughter)And they'll put their fins out and their eyes go in the back of their head, and the fish come up and they just clean, clean, clean — because the Molas, you know, there's just a smorgasbord of parasites. And it's also a great place to go down south because the water's warmer, and the Molas are kind of friendly down there. I mean what other kind of fish, if you approach it right, will say, "Okay, scratch me right there." You truly can swim up to a Mola — they're very gentle — and if you approach them right, you can give them a scratch and they enjoy it. So we've also tagged one part of the Pacific; we've gone over to another part of the Pacific, and we've tagged in Taiwan, and we tagged in Japan. And over in these places, the Molas are caught in set nets that line these countries. And they're not thrown back as by-catch, they're eaten. We were served a nine-course meal of Mola after we tagged. Well, not the one we tagged! And everything from the kidney, to the testes, to the back bone, to the fin muscle to — I think that ís pretty much the whole fish — is eaten.So the hardest part of tagging, now, is after you put that tag on, you have to wait, months. And you're just wondering, oh, I hope the fish is safe, I hope, I hope it's going to be able to actually live its life out during the course that the tag is recording. The tags cost 3500 dollars each, and then satellite time is another 500 dollars, so you're like, oh, I hope the tag is okay. And so the waiting is really the hardest part. I'm going to show you our latest dataset. And it hasn't been published, so it's totally privy information just for TED. And in showing you this, you know, when we're looking at this data, we're thinking, oh do these animals, do they cross the equator? Do they go from one side of the Pacific to the other? And we found that they kind of are homebodies. They're not big migrators. This is their track: we deployed the tag off of Tokyo, and the Mola in one month kind of got into the Kuroshio Current off of Japan and foraged there. And after four months, went up, you know, off of the north part of Japan. And that's kind of their home range. Now that's important, though, because if there's a lot of fishing pressure, that population doesn't get replenished. So that's a very important piece of data.But also what's important is that they're not slacker, lazy fish. They're super industrious. And this is a day in the life of a Mola, and if we — they're up and down, and up and down, and up and down, and up and up and down, up to 40 times a day. As the sun comes up, you see in the blue, they start their dive. Down — and as the sun gets brighter they go a little deeper, little deeper. They plumb the depths down to 600 meters, in temperatures to one degree centigrade, and this is why you see them on the surface — it's so cold down there. They've got to come up, warm, get that solar power, and then plunge back into the depths, and go up and down and up and down. And they're hitting a layer down there; it's called the deep scattering layer — which a whole variety of food's in that layer. So rather than just being some sunbathing slacker, they're really very industrious fish that dance this wild dance between the surface and the bottom and through temperature.We see the same pattern — now with these tags we're seeing a similar pattern for swordfishes, manta rays, tunas, a real three-dimensional play. This is part of a much larger program called the Census of Marine Life, where they're going to be tagging all over the world and the Mola's going to enter into that. And what's exciting — you all travel, and you know the best thing about traveling is to be able to find the locals, and to find the great places by getting the local knowledge. Well now with the Census of Marine Life, we'll be able to sidle up to all the locals and explore 90 percent of our living space, with local knowledge. It's never — it's really never been a more exciting, or a vital time, to be a biologist.Which brings me to my last point, and what I think is kind of the most fun. I set up a website because I was getting so many questions about Molas and sunfish. And so I just figured I'd have the questions answered, and I'd be able to thank my funders, like National Geographic and Lindbergh. But people would write into the site with all sorts of, all sorts of stories about these animals and wanting to help me get samples for genetic analysis. And what I found most exciting is that everyone had a shared — a shared love and an interest in the oceans. I was getting reports from Catholic nuns, Jewish Rabbis, Muslims, Christians — everybody writing in, united by their love of life. And to me that — I don't think I could say it any better than the immortal Bard himself: "One touch of nature makes the whole world kin." And sure, it may be just one big old silly fish, but it's helping. If it's helping to unite the world, I think it's definitely the fish of the future.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:16.958
but it's suicide for fishes now.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
But unfortunately Molas, even though they don't school,

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
they still get caught in nets as by-catch.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:25.958
If we're going to save the world from total jellyfish domination,

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
then we've got to figure out what the jellyfish predators --

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
how they live their lives, like the Mola.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:34.958
And unfortunately, they make up a large portion of the California by-catch --

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
up to 26 percent of the drift net.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:41.958
And in the Mediterranean, in the swordfish net fisheries,

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
they make up up to 90 percent.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:48.958
So we've got to figure out how they're living their lives.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
And how do you do that?

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.958
How do you do that with an animal -- very few places in the world.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:57.958
This is an open ocean creature. It knows no boundaries -- it doesn't go to land.

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:59.958
How do you get insight?

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:04.958
How do you seduce an open ocean creature like that to spill its secrets?

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:07.958
Well, there's some great new technology

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
that has just recently become available,

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:13.958
and it's just a boon for getting insight into open ocean animals.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:17.958
And it's pictured right here, that little tag up there.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:22.958
That little tag can record temperature, depth and light intensity,

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:26.958
which is correlated with time, and from that we can get locations.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:30.958
And it can record this data for up to two years,

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:34.958
and keep it in that tag, release at a pre-programmed time,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:38.958
float to the surface, upload all that data, that whole travelogue,

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:41.958
to satellite, which relays it directly to our computers,

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:45.958
and we've got that whole dataset. And we didn't even have --

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:49.958
we just had to tag the animal and then we went home and you know, sat at our desks.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
So the great thing about the Mola

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:55.958
is that when we put the tag on them -- if you look up here --

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
that's streaming off, that's right where we put the tag.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:01.958
And it just so happens that's a parasite hanging off the Mola.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
Molas are infamous for carrying tons of parasites.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:08.958
They're just parasite hotels; even their parasites have parasites.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
I think Donne wrote a poem about that.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
But they have 40 genera of parasites,

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:17.958
and so we figured just one more parasite won't be too much of a problem.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:22.958
And they happen to be a very good vehicle for carrying oceanographic equipment.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
They don't seem to mind, so far.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:29.958
So what are we trying to find out? We're focusing on the Pacific.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:33.958
We're tagging on the California coast, and we're tagging over in Taiwan and Japan.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:36.958
And we're interested in how these animals are using the currents,

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:42.958
using temperature, using the open ocean, to live their lives.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
We'd love to tag in Monterey.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:48.958
Monterey is one of the few places in the world where Molas come in large numbers.

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
Not this time of year -- it's more around October.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
And we'd love to tag here -- this is an aerial shot of Monterey --

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:58.958
but unfortunately, the Molas here end up looking like this

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:02.958
because another one of our locals really likes Molas but in the wrong way.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:06.958
The California sea lion takes the Molas as soon as they come into the bay,

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:11.958
rips off their fins, fashions them into the ultimate Frisbee, Mola style,

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
and then tosses them back and forth.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
And I'm not exaggerating, it is just --

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:19.958
and sometimes they don't eat them, it's just spiteful.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:24.958
And you know, the locals think it's terrible behavior,

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:29.958
it's just horrible watching this happen, day after day.

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:32.958
The poor little Molas coming in, getting ripped to shreds,

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:36.958
so we head down south, to San Diego.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
Not so many California sea lions down there.

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:41.958
And the Molas there, you can find them with a spotter plane very easily,

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:44.958
and they like to hang out under floating rafts of kelp.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.958
And under those kelps -- this is why the Molas come there

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:51.958
because it's spa time for the Molas there.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:55.958
As soon as they get under those rafts of kelp, the exfoliating cleaner fish come.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
And they come and give the Molas --

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:00.958
you can see they strike this funny little position that says,

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
"I'm not threatening, but I need a massage."

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:06.958
(Laughter)

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:10.958
And they'll put their fins out and their eyes go in the back of their head,

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:14.958
and the fish come up and they just clean, clean, clean --

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:18.958
because the Molas, you know, there's just a smorgasbord of parasites.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
And it's also a great place to go down south

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:24.958
because the water's warmer, and the Molas are kind of friendly down there.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
I mean what other kind of fish, if you approach it right,

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
will say, "Okay, scratch me right there."

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
You truly can swim up to a Mola -- they're very gentle --

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:36.958
and if you approach them right, you can give them a scratch and they enjoy it.

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
So we've also tagged one part of the Pacific;

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
we've gone over to another part of the Pacific,

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
and we've tagged in Taiwan, and we tagged in Japan.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:51.958
And over in these places, the Molas are caught in set nets that line these countries.

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:54.958
And they're not thrown back as by-catch, they're eaten.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:58.958
We were served a nine-course meal of Mola after we tagged.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
Well, not the one we tagged!

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:05.958
And everything from the kidney, to the testes, to the back bone,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:12.958
to the fin muscle to -- I think that ís pretty much the whole fish -- is eaten.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:22.958
So the hardest part of tagging, now, is

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:27.958
after you put that tag on, you have to wait, months.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:31.958
And you're just wondering, oh, I hope the fish is safe,

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:35.958
I hope, I hope it's going to be able to actually live its life out

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:38.958
during the course that the tag is recording.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:44.958
The tags cost 3500 dollars each, and then satellite time is another 500 dollars,

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:47.958
so you're like, oh, I hope the tag is okay.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
And so the waiting is really the hardest part.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
I'm going to show you our latest dataset.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:57.958
And it hasn't been published, so it's totally privy information just for TED.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:01.958
And in showing you this, you know, when we're looking at this data,

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.958
we're thinking, oh do these animals, do they cross the equator?

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
Do they go from one side of the Pacific to the other?

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:10.958
And we found that they kind of are homebodies.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
They're not big migrators. This is their track:

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:17.958
we deployed the tag off of Tokyo, and the Mola in one month

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:22.958
kind of got into the Kuroshio Current off of Japan and foraged there.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:26.958
And after four months, went up, you know, off of the north part of Japan.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
And that's kind of their home range.

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:32.958
Now that's important, though, because if there's a lot of fishing pressure,

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.958
that population doesn't get replenished.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
So that's a very important piece of data.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:43.958
But also what's important is that they're not slacker, lazy fish.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:45.958
They're super industrious.

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:48.958
And this is a day in the life of a Mola, and if we --

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:52.958
they're up and down, and up and down, and up and down, and up

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
and up and down, up to 40 times a day.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:59.958
As the sun comes up, you see in the blue, they start their dive.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:03.958
Down -- and as the sun gets brighter they go a little deeper, little deeper.

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:09.958
They plumb the depths down to 600 meters, in temperatures to one degree centigrade,

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:13.958
and this is why you see them on the surface -- it's so cold down there.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
They've got to come up, warm, get that solar power,

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:18.958
and then plunge back into the depths, and go up and down and up and down.

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:21.958
And they're hitting a layer down there; it's called the deep scattering layer --

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:26.958
which a whole variety of food's in that layer.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:30.958
So rather than just being some sunbathing slacker,

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:33.958
they're really very industrious fish that dance this wild dance

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:38.958
between the surface and the bottom and through temperature.

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:41.958
We see the same pattern -- now with these tags

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:45.958
we're seeing a similar pattern for swordfishes, manta rays, tunas,

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:48.958
a real three-dimensional play.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:53.958
This is part of a much larger program called the Census of Marine Life,

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:56.958
where they're going to be tagging all over the world

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
and the Mola's going to enter into that.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
And what's exciting -- you all travel, and you know

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:04.958
the best thing about traveling is to be able to find the locals,

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
and to find the great places by getting the local knowledge.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:11.958
Well now with the Census of Marine Life, we'll be able to sidle up to all the locals

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:16.958
and explore 90 percent of our living space, with local knowledge.

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:22.958
It's never -- it's really never been a more exciting, or a vital time, to be a biologist.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:26.958
Which brings me to my last point, and what I think is kind of the most fun.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:34.958
I set up a website because I was getting so many questions about Molas and sunfish.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:38.958
And so I just figured I'd have the questions answered,

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:42.958
and I'd be able to thank my funders, like National Geographic and Lindbergh.

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:46.958
But people would write into the site with all sorts of,

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:49.958
all sorts of stories about these animals

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:53.958
and wanting to help me get samples for genetic analysis.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:16:00.958
And what I found most exciting is that everyone had a shared --

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:03.958
a shared love and an interest in the oceans.

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:07.958
I was getting reports from Catholic nuns,

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:12.958
Jewish Rabbis, Muslims, Christians -- everybody writing in,

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:16.958
united by their love of life.

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:22.958
And to me that -- I don't think I could say it any better than the immortal Bard himself:

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:26.958
"One touch of nature makes the whole world kin."

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:30.958
And sure, it may be just one big old silly fish, but it's helping.

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:34.958
If it's helping to unite the world, I think it's definitely the fish of the future.

title: How PhotoSynth can connect the world's images
transcript: What I'm going to show you first, as quickly as I can, is some foundational work, some new technology that we brought to Microsoft as part of an acquisition almost exactly a year ago. This is Seadragon, and it's an environment in which you can either locally or remotely interact with vast amounts of visual data.We're looking at many, many gigabytes of digital photos here and kind of seamlessly and continuously zooming in, panning through it, rearranging it in any way we want. And it doesn't matter how much information we're looking at, how big these collections are or how big the images are. Most of them are ordinary digital camera photos, but this one, for example, is a scan from the Library of Congress, and it's in the 300 megapixel range. It doesn't make any difference because the only thing that ought to limit the performance of a system like this one is the number of pixels on your screen at any given moment. It's also very flexible architecture. This is an entire book, so this is an example of non-image data. This is "Bleak House" by Dickens. Every column is a chapter. To prove to you that it's really text, and not an image, we can do something like so, to really show that this is a real representation of the text; it's not a picture. Maybe this is an artificial way to read an e-book. I wouldn't recommend it.This is a more realistic case, an issue of The Guardian. Every large image is the beginning of a section. And this really gives you the joy and the good experience of reading the real paper version of a magazine or a newspaper, which is an inherently multi-scale kind of medium. We've done something with the corner of this particular issue of The Guardian. We've made up a fake ad that's very high resolution — much higher than in an ordinary ad — and we've embedded extra content. If you want to see the features of this car, you can see it here. Or other models, or even technical specifications. And this really gets at some of these ideas about really doing away with those limits on screen real estate. We hope that this means no more pop-ups and other rubbish like that — shouldn't be necessary.Of course, mapping is one of those obvious applications for a technology like this. And this one I really won't spend any time on, except to say that we have things to contribute to this field as well. But those are all the roads in the U.S. superimposed on top of a NASA geospatial image. So let's pull up, now, something else. This is actually live on the Web now; you can go check it out.This is a project called Photosynth, which marries two different technologies. One of them is Seadragon and the other is some very beautiful computer-vision research done by Noah Snavely, a graduate student at the University of Washington, co-advised by Steve Seitz at U.W. and Rick Szeliski at Microsoft Research. A very nice collaboration. And so this is live on the Web. It's powered by Seadragon. You can see that when we do these sorts of views, where we can dive through images and have this kind of multi-resolution experience.But the spatial arrangement of the images here is actually meaningful. The computer vision algorithms have registered these images together so that they correspond to the real space in which these shots — all taken near Grassi Lakes in the Canadian Rockies — all these shots were taken. So you see elements here of stabilized slide-show or panoramic imaging, and these things have all been related spatially. I'm not sure if I have time to show you any other environments. Some are much more spatial. I would like to jump straight to one of Noah's original data-sets — this is from an early prototype that we first got working this summer — to show you what I think is really the punch line behind the Photosynth technology, It's not necessarily so apparent from looking at the environments we've put up on the website. We had to worry about the lawyers and so on.This is a reconstruction of Notre Dame Cathedral that was done entirely computationally from images scraped from Flickr. You just type Notre Dame into Flickr, and you get some pictures of guys in T-shirts, and of the campus and so on. And each of these orange cones represents an image that was discovered to belong to this model. And so these are all Flickr images, and they've all been related spatially in this way. We can just navigate in this very simple way.(Applause)(Applause ends)You know, I never thought that I'd end up working at Microsoft. It's very gratifying to have this kind of reception here.(Laughter)I guess you can see this is lots of different types of cameras: it's everything from cell-phone cameras to professional SLRs, quite a large number of them, stitched together in this environment. If I can find some of the sort of weird ones — So many of them are occluded by faces, and so on. Somewhere in here there is actually a series of photographs — here we go. This is actually a poster of Notre Dame that registered correctly. We can dive in from the poster to a physical view of this environment.What the point here really is is that we can do things with the social environment. This is now taking data from everybody — from the entire collective memory, visually, of what the Earth looks like — and link all of that together. Those photos become linked, and they make something emergent that's greater than the sum of the parts. You have a model that emerges of the entire Earth. Think of this as the long tail to Stephen Lawler's Virtual Earth work. And this is something that grows in complexity as people use it, and whose benefits become greater to the users as they use it. Their own photos are getting tagged with meta-data that somebody else entered. If somebody bothered to tag all of these saints and say who they all are, then my photo of Notre Dame Cathedral suddenly gets enriched with all of that data, and I can use it as an entry point to dive into that space, into that meta-verse, using everybody else's photos, and do a kind of a cross-modal and cross-user social experience that way. And of course, a by-product of all of that is immensely rich virtual models of every interesting part of the Earth, collected not just from overhead flights and from satellite images and so on, but from the collective memory.Thank you so much.(Applause)(Applause ends)Chris Anderson: Do I understand this right? What your software is going to allow, is that at some point, really within the next few years, all the pictures that are shared by anyone across the world are going to link together?BAA: Yes. What this is really doing is discovering, creating hyperlinks, if you will, between images. It's doing that based on the content inside the images. And that gets really exciting when you think about the richness of the semantic information a lot of images have. Like when you do a web search for images, you type in phrases, and the text on the web page is carrying a lot of information about what that picture is of. What if that picture links to all of your pictures? The amount of semantic interconnection and richness that comes out of that is really huge. It's a classic network effect.CA: Truly incredible. Congratulations.
