00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:17.958
for tissues and for organs themselves.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:23.958
So today's reality is that if we get sick,

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:26.958
the message is we will treat your symptoms,

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:28.958
and you need to adjust to a new way of life.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
I would pose to you that tomorrow --

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
and when tomorrow is we could debate,

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:35.958
but it's within the foreseeable future --

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:38.958
we will talk about regenerative rehabilitation.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:40.958
There's a limb prosthetic up here,

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:43.958
similar actually one on the soldier

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
that's come back from Iraq.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:49.958
There are 370 soldiers that have come back from Iraq that have lost limbs.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:52.958
Imagine if instead of facing that, they could actually

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
face the regeneration of that limb.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:55.958
It's a wild concept.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:08:00.958
I'll show you where we are at the moment in working towards that concept.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
But it's applicable, again, to every organ system.

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:04.958
How can we do that?

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:08.958
The way to do that is to develop a conversation with the body.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
We need to learn to speak the body's language.

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:16.958
And to switch on processes that we knew how to do when we were a fetus.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:21.958
A mammalian fetus, if it loses a limb during the first trimester of pregnancy,

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
will re-grow that limb.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:29.958
So our DNA has the capacity to do these kinds of wound-healing mechanisms.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
It's a natural process,

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
but it is lost as we age.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:38.958
In a child, before the age of about six months,

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
if they lose their fingertip in an accident,

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
they'll re-grow their fingertip.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
By the time they're five, they won't be able to do that anymore.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
So to engage in that conversation with the body,

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
we need to speak the body's language.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:54.958
And there are certain tools in our toolbox that allow us to do this today.

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:58.958
I'm going to give you an example of three of these tools

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:00.958
through which to converse with the body.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
The first is cellular therapies.

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:06.958
Clearly, we heal ourselves in a natural process,

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:09.958
using cells to do most of the work.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:11.958
Therefore, if we can find the right cells

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:14.958
and implant them in the body, they may do the healing.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
Secondly, we can use materials.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
We heard yesterday about the importance of new materials.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
If we can invent materials, design materials,

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:26.958
or extract materials from a natural environment,

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:30.958
then we might be able to have those materials induce the body to heal itself.

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.958
And finally, we may be able to use smart devices

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:37.958
that will offload the work of the body and allow it to heal.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
I'm going to show you an example of each of these,

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
and I'm going to start with materials.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
Steve Badylak -- who's at the University of Pittsburgh --

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
about a decade ago had a remarkable idea.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:51.958
And that idea was that the small intestine of a pig,

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:53.958
if you threw away all the cells,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:58.958
and if you did that in a way that allowed it to remain biologically active,

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:01.958
may contain all of the necessary factors and signals

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
that would signal the body to heal itself.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
And he asked a very important question.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:06.958
He asked the question,

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
if I take that material, which is a natural material

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
that usually induces healing in the small intestine,

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:16.958
and I place it somewhere else on a person's body,

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:19.958
would it give a tissue-specific response,

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:22.958
or would it make small intestine if I tried to make a new ear?

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:28.958
I wouldn't be telling you this story if it weren't compelling.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
The picture I'm about to show you

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
is a compelling picture.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
(Laughter)

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
However, for those of you that are even the slightest bit squeamish --

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:40.958
even though you may not like to admit it in front of your friends --

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:43.958
the lights are down. This is a good time to look at your feet,

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:47.958
check your Blackberry, do anything other than look at the screen.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:51.958
(Laughter)

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:55.958
What I'm about to show you is a diabetic ulcer.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
And although -- it's good to laugh before we look at this.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
This is the reality of diabetes.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.958
I think a lot of times we hear about diabetics, diabetic ulcers,

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:08.958
we just don't connect the ulcer with the eventual treatment,

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
which is amputation, if you can't heal it.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:13.958
So I'm going to put the slide up now. It won't be up for long.

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:16.958
This is a diabetic ulcer. It's tragic.

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
The treatment for this is amputation.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:22.958
This is an older lady. She has cancer of the liver as well as diabetes,

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:26.958
and has decided to die with what' s left of her body intact.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:32.958
And this lady decided, after a year of attempted treatment of that ulcer,

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
that she would try this new therapy that Steve invented.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
That's what the wound looked like 11 weeks later.

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:41.958
That material contained only natural signals.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:46.958
And that material induced the body to switch back on a healing response

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:48.958
that it didn't have before.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:51.958
There's going to be a couple more distressing slides for those of you --

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
I'll let you know when you can look again.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:56.958
This is a horse. The horse is not in pain.

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
If the horse was in pain, I wouldn't show you this slide.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
The horse just has another nostril that's developed

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
because of a riding accident.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:04.958
Just a few weeks after treatment --

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:07.958
in this case, taking that material, turning it into a gel,

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:11.958
and packing that area, and then repeating the treatment a few times --

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
and the horse heals up.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
And if you took an ultrasound of that area, it would look great.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
Here's a dolphin where the fin's been re-attached.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:21.958
There are now 400,000 patients around the world

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:24.958
who have used that material to heal their wounds.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
Could you regenerate a limb?

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:31.958
DARPA just gave Steve 15 million dollars to lead an eight-institution project

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:34.958
to begin the process of asking that question.

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
And I'll show you the 15 million dollar picture.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:40.958
This is a 78 year-old man who's lost the end of his fingertip.

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:44.958
Remember that I mentioned before the children who lose their fingertips.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
After treatment that's what it looks like.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:49.958
This is happening today.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
This is clinically relevant today.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:55.958
There are materials that do this. Here are the heart patches.

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
But could you go a little further?

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
Could you, say, instead of using material,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
can I take some cells along with the material,

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
and remove a damaged piece of tissue,

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:06.958
put a bio-degradable material on there?

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:09.958
You can see here a little bit of heart muscle beating in a dish.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:14.958
This was done by Teruo Okano at Tokyo Women's Hospital.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
He can actually grow beating tissue in a dish.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
He chills the dish, it changes its properties

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
and he peels it right out of the dish.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:22.958
It's the coolest stuff.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
Now I'm going to show you cell-based regeneration.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
And what I'm going to show you here

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:31.958
is stem cells being removed from the hip of a patient.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:34.958
Again, if you're squeamish, you don't want to watch.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:35.958
But this one's kind of cool.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:41.958
So this is a bypass operation, just like what Al Gore had,

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:42.958
with a difference.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:45.958
In this case, at the end of the bypass operation,

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:47.958
you're going to see the stem cells from the patient

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
that were removed at the beginning of the procedure

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:52.958
being injected directly into the heart of the patient.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
And I'm standing up here because at one point

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
I'm going to show you just how early this technology is.

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.958
Here go the stem cells, right into the beating heart of the patient.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:02.958
And if you look really carefully,

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:04.958
it's going to be right around this point

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
you'll actually see a back-flush.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
You see the cells coming back out.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
We need all sorts of new technology, new devices,

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:15.958
to get the cells to the right place at the right time.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:19.958
Just a little bit of data, a tiny bit of data.

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
This was a randomized trial.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:24.958
At this time this was an N of 20. Now there's an N of about 100.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
Basically, if you take an extremely sick patient

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
and you give them a bypass, they get a little bit better.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
If you give them stem cells as well as their bypass,

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:35.958
for these particular patients, they became asymptomatic.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
These are now two years out.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:42.958
The coolest thing would be is if you could diagnose the disease early,

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:46.958
and prevent the onset of the disease to a bad state.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:50.958
This is the same procedure, but now done minimally invasively,

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:53.958
with only three holes in the body where they're taking the heart

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:57.958
and simply injecting stem cells through a laparoscopic procedure.

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:58.958
There go the cells.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
We don't have time to go into all of those details,

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
but basically, that works too.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:06.958
You can take patients who are less sick,

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:10.958
and bring them back to an almost asymptomatic state

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
through that kind of therapy.

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:16.958
Here's another example of stem-cell therapy that isn't quite clinical yet,

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:18.958
but I think very soon will be.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
This is the work of Kacey Marra from Pittsburgh,

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
along with a number of colleagues around the world.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:25.958
They've decided that liposuction fluid,

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:28.958
which -- in the United States, we have a lot of liposuction fluid.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:29.958
(Laughter)

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
It's a great source of stem cells.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
Stem cells are packed in that liposuction fluid.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:37.958
So you could go in, you could get your tummy-tuck.

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:39.958
Out comes the liposuction fluid,

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:43.958
and in this case, the stem cells are isolated and turned into neurons.

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:45.958
All done in the lab.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
And I think fairly soon, you will see patients being treated

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:52.958
with their own fat-derived, or adipose-derived, stem cells.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:55.958
I talked before about the use of devices

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:58.958
to dramatically change the way we treat disease.

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.958
Here's just one example before I close up.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:02.958
This is equally tragic.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.958
We have a very abiding and heartbreaking partnership

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:09.958
with our colleagues at the Institute for Surgical Research in the US Army,

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:14.958
who have to treat the now 11,000 kids that have come back from Iraq.

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:16.958
Many of those patients are very severely burned.

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
And if there's anything that's been learned about burn,

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:20.958
it's that we don't know how to treat it.

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:22.958
Everything that is done to treat burn --

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:24.958
basically we do a sodding approach.

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:27.958
We make something over here,

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
and then we transplant it onto the site of the wound,

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:31.958
and we try and get the two to take.

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:35.958
In this case here, a new, wearable bio-reactor has been designed --

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:38.958
it should be tested clinically later this year at ISR --

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:40.958
by Joerg Gerlach in Pittsburgh.

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:43.958
And that bio-reactor will lay down in the wound bed.

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:46.958
The gun that you see there sprays cells.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:49.958
That's going to spray cells over that area.

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:52.958
The reactor will serve to fertilize the environment,

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:55.958
deliver other things as well at the same time,

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:58.958
and therefore we will seed that lawn,

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:00.958
as opposed to try the sodding approach.

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:02.958
It's a completely different way of doing it.

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:06.958
So my 18 minutes is up.

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:08.958
So let me finish up with some good news,

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:10.958
and maybe a little bit of bad news.

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:14.958
The good news is that this is happening today.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:16.958
It's very powerful work.

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:18.958
Clearly the images kind of get that across.

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:21.958
It's incredibly difficult because it's highly inter-disciplinary.

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:25.958
Almost every field of science engineering and clinical practice

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:28.958
is involved in trying to get this to happen.

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:31.958
A number of governments, and a number of regions,

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:34.958
have recognized that this is a new way to treat disease.

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:36.958
The Japanese government were perhaps the first,

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:39.958
when they decided to invest first 3 billion,

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:42.958
later another 2 billion in this field.

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:43.958
It's no coincidence.

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:46.958
Japan is the oldest country on earth in terms of its average age.

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:50.958
They need this to work or their health system dies.

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:54.958
So they're putting a lot of strategic investment focused in this area.

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:57.958
The European Union, same thing.

00:17:57.958 --> 00:17:59.958
China, the same thing.

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:01.958
China just launched a national tissue-engineering center.

00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:05.958
The first year budget was 250 million US dollars.

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:09.958
In the United States we've had a somewhat different approach.

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:12.958
(Laughter)

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:16.958
Oh, for Al Gore to come and be in the real world as president.

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:17.958
We've had a different approach.

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:21.958
And the approach has basically been to just sort of fund things as they come along.

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:24.958
But there's been no strategic investment

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:30.958
to bring all of the necessary things to bear and focus them in a careful way.

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:33.958
And I'm going to finish up with a quote, maybe a little cheap shot,

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:37.958
at the director of the NIH, who's a very charming man.

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:41.958
Myself and Jay Vacanti from Harvard

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:46.958
went to visit with him and a number of his directors of his institute

00:18:46.958 --> 00:18:48.958
just a few months ago,

00:18:49.958 --> 00:18:54.958
to try and convince him that it was time to take just a little piece

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:58.958
of that 27.5 billion dollars that he's going to get next year

00:18:58.958 --> 00:19:03.958
and focus it, in a strategic way, to make sure we can accelerate the pace

00:19:03.958 --> 00:19:05.958
at which these things get to patients.

00:19:06.958 --> 00:19:08.958
And at the end of a very testy meeting,

00:19:08.958 --> 00:19:10.958
what the NIH director said was,

00:19:10.958 --> 00:19:12.958
"Your vision is larger than our appetite."

00:19:12.958 --> 00:19:16.958
I'd like to close by saying that no one's going to change our vision,

00:19:16.958 --> 00:19:18.958
but together we can change his appetite.

00:19:18.958 --> 00:19:19.958
Thank you.

title: The Web's secret stories
transcript: So I really consider myself a storyteller. But I don't really tell stories in the usual way, in the sense that I don't usually tell my own stories. Instead, I'm really interested in building tools that allow large numbers of other people to tell their stories, people all around the world. I do this because I think that people actually have a lot in common. I think people are very similar, but I also think that we have trouble seeing that.You know, as I look around the world I see a lot of gaps, and I think we all see a lot of gaps. And we define ourselves by our gaps. There's language gaps, there's ethnicity and racial gaps, there's age gaps, there's gender gaps, there's sexuality gaps, there's wealth and money gaps, there's education gaps, there's also religious gaps. You know, we have all these gaps and I think we like our gaps because they make us feel like we identify with something, some smaller community. But I think that actually, despite our gaps, we really have a lot in common. And I think one thing we have in common is a very deep need to express ourselves. I think this is a very old human desire. It's nothing new.But the thing about self-expression is that there's traditionally been this imbalance between the desire that we have to express ourselves and the number of sympathetic friends who are willing to stand around and listen.(Laughter)This, also, is nothing new. Since the dawn of human history, we've tried to rectify this imbalance by making art, writing poems, singing songs, scripting editorials and sending them in to a newspaper, gossiping with friends. This is nothing new.What's new is that in the last several years a lot of these very traditional physical human activities, these acts of self-expression, have been moving onto the Internet. And as that's happened, people have been leaving behind footprints, footprints that tell stories of their moments of self-expression. And so what I do is, I write computer programs that study very large sets of these footprints, and then try to draw conclusions about the people who left them — what they feel, what they think, what's different in the world today than usual, these sorts of questions.One project that explores these ideas, which was made about a year ago, is a piece called We Feel Fine. This is a piece that every two or three minutes scans the world's newly-posted blog entries for occurrences of the phrases "I feel" or "I am feeling." And when it finds one of those phrases, it grabs the sentence up to the period, and then automatically tries to deduce the age, gender and geographical location of the person that wrote that sentence. Then, knowing the geographical location and the time, we can also then figure out the weather when that person wrote the sentence. All of this information is saved in a database that collects about 20,000 feelings a day. It's been running for about a year and a half. It's reached about seven-and-a-half million human feelings now. And I'll show you a glimpse of how this information is then visualized. So this is We Feel Fine.What you see here is a madly swarming mass of particles, each of which represents a single human feeling that was stated in the last few hours. The color of each particle corresponds to the type of feeling inside — so that happy, positive feelings are brightly colored. And sad, negative feelings are darkly colored. The diameter of each dot represents the length of the sentence inside, so that the large dots contain large sentences, and the small dots contain small sentences. Any dot can be clicked and expanded. And we see here, "I would just feel so much better if I could curl up in his arms right now and feel his affection for me in the embrace of his body and the tenderness of his lips." So it gets pretty hot and steamy sometimes in the world of human emotions. And all of these are stated by people: "I know that objectively it really doesn't mean much, but after spending so many years as a small fish in a big pond, it's nice to feel bigger again."The dots exhibit human qualities. They kind of have their own physics, and they swarm wildly around, kind of exploring the world of life. And then they also exhibit curiosity. You can see a few of them are swarming around the cursor right now. You can see some other ones are swarming around the bottom left corner of the screen around six words. Those six words represent the six movements of We Feel Fine. We're currently seeing Madness. There's also Murmurs, Montage, Mobs, Metrics and Mounds. And I'll walk you through a few of those now. Murmurs causes all of the feelings to fly to the ceiling. And then, one by one, in reverse chronological order, they excuse themselves, entering the scrolling list of feelings. "I feel a bit better now."(Laughter)"I feel confused and unsure of what the hell I want to do." "I feel gypped out of something awesome here." "I feel so free; I feel so good." "I feel like I'm in this fog of depression that I can't get out of." And you can click any of these to go out and visit the blog from which it was collected. And in that way, you can connect with the authors of these statements if you feel some degree of empathy.The next movement is called Montage. Montage causes all of the feelings that contain photographs to become extracted and display themselves in a grid. This grid is then said to represent the picture of the world's feelings in the last few hours, if you will. Each of these can be clicked and we can blow it up. We see, "I just feel like I'm not going to have fun if it's not the both of us." That was from someone in Michigan. We see, "I feel like I have been at a computer all day."(Laughter)These are automatically constructed using the found objects: "I think I feel a little full."The next movement is called mobs. Mobs provides different statistical breakdowns of the population of the world's feelings in the last few hours. We see that "better" is the most frequent feeling right now, followed by "good," "bad," "guilty," "right," "down," "sick" and so on. We can also get a gender breakdown. And we see that women are slightly more prolific talking about their emotions in the last few hours than men. We can do an age breakdown, which gives us a histogram of the world's emotional distribution by age. We see people in their twenties are the most prolific, followed by teenagers, and then people in their thirties, and it dies out very quickly from there. In weather, the feelings assume the physical characteristics of the weather that they represent, so that the ones collected on a sunny day swirl around as if they're part of the sun. The cloudy ones float along as if they're on a breeze. The rainy ones fall down as if they're in a rainstorm, and the snowy ones kind of flutter to the ground.Finally, location causes the feelings to move to their positions on a world map showing the geographical distribution of feelings. Metrics provides more numerical views on the data. We see that the world is feeling "used" at 3.3 times the normal level right now.(Laughter)They're feeling "warm" at 2.9 times the normal level, and so on. Other views are also available. Here are gender, age, weather, location.The final movement is called Mounds. It's a bit different from the others. Mounds visualizes the entire dataset as large, gelatinous blobs which kind of jiggle. And if I hold down my cursor, they do a little dance. We see "better" is the most frequent feeling, followed by "bad." And then if I go over here, the list begins to scroll, and there are actually thousands of feelings that have been collected. You can see the little pink cursor moving along, representing our position. Here we see people that feel "slipping," "nauseous," "responsible."There's also a search capability, if you're interested in finding out about a certain population. For instance, you could find women who feel "addicted" in their 20s when it was cloudy in Bangladesh.(Laughter)But I'll spare you that. So here are some of my favorite montages that have been collected: "I feel so much of my dad alive in me that there isn't even room for me." "I feel very lonely." "I need to be in some backwoods redneck town so that I can feel beautiful." "I feel invisible to you." "I wouldn't hide it if society didn't make me feel like I needed to." "I feel in love with Carolyn." "I feel so naughty." "I feel these weirdoes are actually an asset to college life."(Laughter)"I love how I feel today."So as you can see, We Feel Fine uses a technique that I call "passive observation." What I mean by that is that it passively observes people as they live their lives. It scans the world's blogs and looks at what people are writing, and these people don't know they're being watched or interviewed. And because of that, you end up getting very honest, candid, sincere responses that are often very moving. And this is a technique that I usually prefer in my work because people don't know they're being interviewed. They're just living life, and they end up just acting like that.Another technique is directly questioning people. And this is a technique that I explored in a different project, the Yahoo! Time Capsule, which was designed to take a fingerprint of the world in 2006. It was divided into ten very simple themes — love, anger, sadness and so on — each of which contained a single, very open-ended question put to the world: What do you love? What makes you angry? What makes you sad? What do you believe in? And so on. The time capsule was available for one month online, translated into 10 languages, and this is what it looked like. It's a spinning globe, the surface of which is entirely composed of the pictures and words and drawings of people that submitted to the time capsule. The ten themes radiate out and orbit the time capsule. You can sift through this data and see what people have submitted. This is in response to, What's beautiful? "Miss World."There are two modes to the time capsule. There's One World, which presents the spinning globe, and Many Voices, which splits the data out into film strips and lets you sift through them one by one. So this project was punctuated by a really amazing event, which was held in the desert outside Albuquerque in New Mexico at the Jemez Pueblo, where for three consecutive nights, the contents of the capsule were projected onto the sides of the ancient Red Rock Canyon walls, which stand about 200 feet tall. It was really incredible. And we also projected the contents of the time capsule as binary code using a 35-watt laser into outer space. You can see the orange line leaving the desert floor at about a 45 degree angle there. This was amazing because the first night I looked at all this information and really started seeing the gaps that I talked about earlier — the differences in age, gender and wealth and so on.But, you know, as I looked at this more and more and more, and saw these images go across the rocks, I realized I was seeing the same archetypal events depicted again and again and again. You know: weddings, births, funerals, the first car, the first kiss, the first camel or horse — depending on the culture. And it was really moving. And this picture here was taken the final night from a distant cliff about two miles away, where the contents of the capsule were being beamed into space. And there was something very moving about all of this human expression being shot off into the night sky.And it started to make me think a lot about the night sky, and how humans have always used the night sky to project their great stories. You know, as a child in Vermont, on a farm where I grew up, I would often look up into the dark sky and see the three star belt of Orion, the Hunter. And as an adult, I've been more aware of the great Greek myths playing out in the sky overhead every night. You know, Orion facing the roaring bull. Perseus flying to the rescue of Andromeda. Zeus battling Chronos for control of Mount Olympus. I mean, these are the great tales of the Greeks.And it caused me to wonder about our world today. And it caused me to wonder specifically, if we could make new constellations today, what would those look like? What would those be? If we could make new pictures in the sky, what would we draw? What are the great stories of today?And those are the questions that inspired my new project, which is debuting here today at TED. Nobody's seen this yet, publicly. It's called Universe: Revealing Our Modern Mythology. And it uses this metaphor of an interactive night sky. So, it's my great pleasure now to show this to you.So, Universe will open here. And you'll see that it leads with a shifting star field, and there's an Aurora Borealis in the background, kind of morphing with color. The color of the Aurora Borealis can be controlled using this single bar of color at the bottom, and we'll put it down here to red. So you see this kind of — these stars moving along.Now, these aren't just little points of light, little pixels. Each of those stars actually represents a specific event in the real world — a quote that was stated by somebody, an image, a news story, a person, a company. You know, some kind of heroic personality. And you might notice that as the cursor begins to touch some of these stars, that shapes begin to emerge. We see here there's a little man walking along, or maybe a woman. And we see here a photograph with a head. You can start to see words emerging here. And those are the constellations of today. And I can turn them all on, and you can see them moving across the sky now.This is the universe of 2007, the last two months. The data from this is global news coverage from thousands of news sources around the world. It's using the API of a really great company that I work with in New York, actually, called Daylife. And it's kind of the zeitgeist view at this level of the world's current mythology over the last couple of months.So we can see where it's emerging here, like President Ford, Iraq, Bush. And we can actually isolate just the words — I call them secrets — and we can cause them to form an alphabetical list. And we see Anna Nicole Smith playing a big role recently. President Ford — this is Gerald Ford's funeral. We can actually click anything in Universe and have it become the center of the universe, and everything else will enter its orbit. So, we'll click Ford, and now that becomes the center. And the things that relate to Ford enter its orbit and swirl around it.We can isolate just the photographs, and we now see those. We can click on one of those and have the photograph be the center of the universe. Now the things that relate to it are swirling around. We can click on this and we see this iconic image of Betty Ford kissing her husband's coffin.In Universe, there's kind of no end. It just goes infinitely, and you can just kind of click on stuff. This is a photographic representation, called Snapshots. But we can actually be more specific in defining our universe. So, if we want to, let's check out what Bill Clinton's universe looks like. And let's see, in the past week, what he's been up to. So now, we have a new universe, which is just constrained to all things Bill Clinton. We can have his constellations emerge here. We can pull out his secrets, and we see that it has a lot to do with candidates, Hillary, presidential, Barack Obama. We can see the stories that Bill Clinton is taking part in right now. Any of those can be opened up. So we see Obama and the Clintons meet in Alabama. You can see that this is an important story; there are a lot of things in its orbit. If we open this up, we get different perspectives on this story. You can click any of those to go out and read the article at the source. This one's from Al Jazeera.We can also see the superstars. These would be the people that are kind of the looming heroes and heroines in the universe of Bill Clinton. So there's Bill Clinton, Hillary, Iraq, George Bush, Barack Obama, Scooter Libby — these are kind of the people of Bill Clinton. We can also see a world map, so this shows us the geographic reach of Bill Clinton in the last week or so. We can see he's been focused in America because he's been campaigning, probably, but a little bit of action over here in the Middle East. And then we can also see a timeline. So we see that he was a bit quiet on Saturday, but he was back to work on Sunday morning, and actually been tapering off since then this week.And it's not limited to just people or dates, but we can actually put in concepts also. So if I put in climate change for all of 2006, we'll see what that universe looks like. Here we have our star field. Here we have our shapes. Here we have our secrets. So we see again, climate change is large: Nairobi, global conference, environmental. And there are also quotes that you can see, if you're interested in reading about quotes on climate change. You know, this is really an infinite thing.The superstars of climate change in 2006: United States, Britain, China. You know, these are the towering countries that kind of define this concept. So this is a piece that demands exploration.This will be online in several days, probably next Tuesday. And you'll all be able to use it and kind of explore what your own personal mythology might be. You'll notice that in Daylife — rather, in Universe — it supports both the notion of a global mythology, which is represented by something as broad as, say, 2007, and also a personal mythology. As you search for the things that are important to you in your world, and then see what the constellations of those might look like.So it's been a pleasure. Thank you very much.(Applause)

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:15.958
So I really consider myself a storyteller.

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:19.958
But I don't really tell stories in the usual way,

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:22.958
in the sense that I don't usually tell my own stories.

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:25.958
Instead, I'm really interested in building tools that allow

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:29.958
large numbers of other people to tell their stories,

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:30.958
people all around the world.

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:35.958
I do this because I think that people actually have a lot in common.

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:36.958
I think people are very similar,

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:39.958
but I also think that we have trouble seeing that.

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:43.958
You know, as I look around the world I see a lot of gaps,

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:44.958
and I think we all see a lot of gaps.

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:47.958
And we define ourselves by our gaps.

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:49.958
There's language gaps,

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:54.958
there's ethnicity and racial gaps, there's age gaps,

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:59.958
there's gender gaps, there's sexuality gaps,

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:03.958
there's wealth and money gaps, there's education gaps,

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:06.958
there's also religious gaps.

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:08.958
You know, we have all these gaps and I think we like our gaps

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:11.958
because they make us feel like we identify with something,

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:12.958
some smaller community.

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:14.958
But I think that actually, despite our gaps,

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:16.958
we really have a lot in common.

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:20.958
And I think one thing we have in common is a very deep need

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:22.958
to express ourselves.

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:27.958
I think this is a very old human desire. It's nothing new.

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:29.958
But the thing about self-expression

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:31.958
is that there's traditionally been this imbalance

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.958
between the desire that we have to express ourselves

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
and the number of sympathetic friends

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:38.958
who are willing to stand around and listen.

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:39.958
(Laughter)

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:42.958
This, also, is nothing new.

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:45.958
Since the dawn of human history, we've tried to rectify this imbalance

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:49.958
by making art, writing poems, singing songs,

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:52.958
scripting editorials and sending them in to a newspaper,

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:54.958
gossiping with friends. This is nothing new.

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:56.958
What's new is that in the last several years

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:59.958
a lot of these very traditional physical human activities,

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:01.958
these acts of self-expression, have been moving onto the Internet.

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:05.958
And as that's happened, people have been leaving behind footprints,

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:09.958
footprints that tell stories of their moments of self-expression.

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:13.958
And so what I do is, I write computer programs

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:16.958
that study very large sets of these footprints,

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:19.958
and then try to draw conclusions about the people who left them --

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:21.958
what they feel, what they think,

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.958
what's different in the world today than usual,

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:26.958
these sorts of questions.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:28.958
One project that explores these ideas,

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:30.958
which was made about a year ago,

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:31.958
is a piece called We Feel Fine.

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:34.958
This is a piece that every two or three minutes

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
scans the world's newly-posted blog entries

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:41.958
for occurrences of the phrases "I feel" or "I am feeling."

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:42.958
And when it finds one of those phrases,

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:44.958
it grabs the sentence up to the period,

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:47.958
and then automatically tries to deduce the age, gender

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:50.958
and geographical location of the person that wrote that sentence.

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:53.958
Then, knowing the geographical location and the time,

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:54.958
we can also then figure out the weather

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:56.958
when that person wrote the sentence.

00:02:57.958 --> 00:02:59.958
All of this information is saved in a database

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:01.958
that collects about 20,000 feelings a day.

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:03.958
It's been running for about a year and a half.

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:06.958
It's reached about seven-and-a-half million human feelings now.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:07.958
And I'll show you a glimpse

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:12.958
of how this information is then visualized. So this is We Feel Fine.

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:17.958
What you see here is a madly swarming mass of particles,

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
each of which represents a single human feeling

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
that was stated in the last few hours.

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:25.958
The color of each particle corresponds to the type of feeling inside --

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.958
so that happy, positive feelings are brightly colored.

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
And sad, negative feelings are darkly colored.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:32.958
The diameter of each dot

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:34.958
represents the length of the sentence inside,

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:36.958
so that the large dots contain large sentences,

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:38.958
and the small dots contain small sentences.

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:41.958
Any dot can be clicked and expanded. And we see here,

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:43.958
"I would just feel so much better

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:46.958
if I could curl up in his arms right now and feel his affection for me

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:49.958
in the embrace of his body and the tenderness of his lips."

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:51.958
So it gets pretty hot and steamy sometimes

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:53.958
in the world of human emotions.

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:56.958
And all of these are stated by people:

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:58.958
"I know that objectively it really doesn't mean much,

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:01.958
but after spending so many years as a small fish in a big pond,

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:03.958
it's nice to feel bigger again."

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:06.958
The dots exhibit human qualities. They kind of have their own physics,

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:10.958
and they swarm wildly around, kind of exploring the world of life.

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:12.958
And then they also exhibit curiosity.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:15.958
You can see a few of them are swarming around the cursor right now.

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:16.958
You can see some other ones

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:18.958
are swarming around the bottom left corner of the screen

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:22.958
around six words. Those six words represent the six movements

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:25.958
of We Feel Fine. We're currently seeing Madness.

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:29.958
There's also Murmurs, Montage, Mobs, Metrics and Mounds.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:31.958
And I'll walk you through a few of those now.

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:34.958
Murmurs causes all of the feelings to fly to the ceiling.

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:37.958
And then, one by one, in reverse chronological order,

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.958
they excuse themselves, entering the scrolling list of feelings.

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:43.958
"I feel a bit better now."

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
(Laughter)

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:48.958
"I feel confused and unsure of what the hell I want to do."

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
"I feel gypped out of something awesome here."

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:53.958
"I feel so free; I feel so good."

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:57.958
"I feel like I'm in this fog of depression that I can't get out of."

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
And you can click any of these to go out and visit the blog

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
from which it was collected. And in that way,

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
you can connect with the authors of these statements

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:05.958
if you feel some degree of empathy.

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:08.958
The next movement is called Montage.

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:11.958
Montage causes all of the feelings that contain photographs

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:14.958
to become extracted and display themselves in a grid.

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:19.958
This grid is then said to represent the picture of the world's feelings

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:20.958
in the last few hours, if you will.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:23.958
Each of these can be clicked and we can blow it up.

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:26.958
We see, "I just feel like I'm not going to have fun

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:30.958
if it's not the both of us." That was from someone in Michigan.

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:36.958
We see, "I feel like I have been at a computer all day."

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:37.958
(Laughter)

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:42.958
These are automatically constructed using the found objects:

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
"I think I feel a little full."

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:47.958
The next movement is called mobs.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
Mobs provides different statistical breakdowns

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:52.958
of the population of the world's feelings in the last few hours.

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
We see that "better" is the most frequent feeling right now,

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:58.958
followed by "good," "bad," "guilty," "right," "down," "sick" and so on.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:00.958
We can also get a gender breakdown.

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
And we see that women are slightly more prolific

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
talking about their emotions in the last few hours than men.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:08.958
We can do an age breakdown, which gives us a histogram

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
of the world's emotional distribution by age.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:14.958
We see people in their twenties are the most prolific,

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
followed by teenagers, and then people in their thirties,

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:17.958
and it dies out very quickly from there.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:22.958
In weather, the feelings assume the physical characteristics

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:23.958
of the weather that they represent,

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
so that the ones collected on a sunny day

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:27.958
swirl around as if they're part of the sun.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
The cloudy ones float along as if they're on a breeze.

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.958
The rainy ones fall down as if they're in a rainstorm,

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:34.958
and the snowy ones kind of flutter to the ground.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:38.958
Finally, location causes the feelings to move to their positions

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
on a world map showing the geographical distribution of feelings.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
Metrics provides more numerical views on the data.

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:46.958
We see that the world is feeling "used"

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:49.958
at 3.3 times the normal level right now.

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
(Laughter)

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:56.958
They're feeling "warm" at 2.9 times the normal level, and so on.

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:57.958
Other views are also available.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
Here are gender, age, weather, location.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.958
The final movement is called Mounds.

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:02.958
It's a bit different from the others.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:06.958
Mounds visualizes the entire dataset as large, gelatinous blobs

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:07.958
which kind of jiggle.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
And if I hold down my cursor, they do a little dance.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
We see "better" is the most frequent feeling, followed by "bad."

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
And then if I go over here, the list begins to scroll,

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
and there are actually thousands of feelings that have been collected.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
You can see the little pink cursor moving along,

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:22.958
representing our position.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:27.958
Here we see people that feel "slipping," "nauseous," "responsible."

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:28.958
There's also a search capability,

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
if you're interested in finding out about a certain population.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
For instance, you could find women who feel "addicted"

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:37.958
in their 20s when it was cloudy in Bangladesh.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:41.958
(Laughter)

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:42.958
But I'll spare you that.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:45.958
So here are some of my favorite montages that have been collected:

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:49.958
"I feel so much of my dad alive in me that there isn't even room for me."

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
"I feel very lonely."

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
"I need to be in some backwoods redneck town

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:59.958
so that I can feel beautiful."

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:03.958
"I feel invisible to you."

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
"I wouldn't hide it if society didn't make me feel like I needed to."

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:15.958
"I feel in love with Carolyn." "I feel so naughty."

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:21.958
"I feel these weirdoes are actually an asset to college life."

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:25.958
(Laughter)

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:26.958
"I love how I feel today."

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
So as you can see, We Feel Fine uses a technique

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:31.958
that I call "passive observation."

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
What I mean by that is that it passively observes people

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:38.958
as they live their lives. It scans the world's blogs

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:39.958
and looks at what people are writing,

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
and these people don't know they're being watched or interviewed.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:43.958
And because of that,

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:46.958
you end up getting very honest, candid, sincere responses

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:47.958
that are often very moving.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
And this is a technique that I usually prefer in my work

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
because people don't know they're being interviewed.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:55.958
They're just living life, and they end up just acting like that.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
Another technique is directly questioning people.

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:00.958
And this is a technique that I explored in a different project,

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:01.958
the Yahoo! Time Capsule,

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:05.958
which was designed to take a fingerprint of the world in 2006.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
It was divided into ten very simple themes --

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
love, anger, sadness and so on --

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
each of which contained a single, very open-ended question

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
put to the world: What do you love? What makes you angry?

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
What makes you sad? What do you believe in? And so on.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
The time capsule was available for one month online,

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:24.958
translated into 10 languages, and this is what it looked like.

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:25.958
It's a spinning globe,

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:28.958
the surface of which is entirely composed of the pictures

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:30.958
and words and drawings of people

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:31.958
that submitted to the time capsule.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
The ten themes radiate out and orbit the time capsule.

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:38.958
You can sift through this data and see what people have submitted.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
This is in response to, What's beautiful? "Miss World."

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
There are two modes to the time capsule.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
There's One World, which presents the spinning globe,

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
and Many Voices, which splits the data out into film strips

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:49.958
and lets you sift through them one by one.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:55.958
So this project was punctuated by a really amazing event,

00:09:55.958 --> 00:10:00.958
which was held in the desert outside Albuquerque in New Mexico

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
at the Jemez Pueblo, where for three consecutive nights,

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
the contents of the capsule were projected onto the sides

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:06.958
of the ancient Red Rock Canyon walls,

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
which stand about 200 feet tall. It was really incredible.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
And we also projected the contents of the time capsule

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:15.958
as binary code using a 35-watt laser into outer space.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
You can see the orange line leaving the desert floor

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
at about a 45 degree angle there. This was amazing

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:24.958
because the first night I looked at all this information

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:27.958
and really started seeing the gaps that I talked about earlier --

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:29.958
the differences in age, gender and wealth and so on.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
But, you know, as I looked at this more and more and more,

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
and saw these images go across the rocks,

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
I realized I was seeing the same archetypal events

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
depicted again and again and again.

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:43.958
You know: weddings, births, funerals, the first car, the first kiss,

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.958
the first camel or horse -- depending on the culture.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:50.958
And it was really moving. And this picture here was taken

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
the final night from a distant cliff about two miles away,

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
where the contents of the capsule were being beamed into space.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
And there was something very moving

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:01.958
about all of this human expression being shot off into the night sky.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
And it started to make me think a lot about the night sky,

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:05.958
and how humans have always used the night sky

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:07.958
to project their great stories.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:10.958
You know, as a child in Vermont, on a farm where I grew up,

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
I would often look up into the dark sky

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
and see the three star belt of Orion, the Hunter.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:17.958
And as an adult, I've been more aware

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:20.958
of the great Greek myths playing out in the sky overhead every night.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
You know, Orion facing the roaring bull.

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
Perseus flying to the rescue of Andromeda.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:28.958
Zeus battling Chronos for control of Mount Olympus.

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
I mean, these are the great tales of the Greeks.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
And it caused me to wonder about our world today.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
And it caused me to wonder specifically,

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
if we could make new constellations today,

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
what would those look like? What would those be?

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:43.958
If we could make new pictures in the sky, what would we draw?

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:44.958
What are the great stories of today?

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:48.958
And those are the questions that inspired my new project,

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
which is debuting here today at TED.

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:51.958
Nobody's seen this yet, publicly.

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
It's called Universe: Revealing Our Modern Mythology.

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
And it uses this metaphor of an interactive night sky.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:02.958
So, it's my great pleasure now to show this to you.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:03.958
So, Universe will open here.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:07.958
And you'll see that it leads with a shifting star field,

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
and there's an Aurora Borealis in the background,

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.958
kind of morphing with color. The color of the Aurora Borealis

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:16.958
can be controlled using this single bar of color at the bottom,

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
and we'll put it down here to red.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:21.958
So you see this kind of -- these stars moving along.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:25.958
Now, these aren't just little points of light, little pixels.

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
Each of those stars actually represents

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:29.958
a specific event in the real world --

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
a quote that was stated by somebody, an image,

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:36.958
a news story, a person, a company. You know,

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
some kind of heroic personality.

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
And you might notice that as the cursor begins

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:45.958
to touch some of these stars, that shapes begin to emerge.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:48.958
We see here there's a little man walking along, or maybe a woman.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:52.958
And we see here a photograph with a head.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
You can start to see words emerging here.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:57.958
And those are

00:12:58.958 --> 00:12:59.958
the constellations of today.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:01.958
And I can turn them all on,

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
and you can see them moving across the sky now.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
This is the universe of 2007, the last two months.

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:09.958
The data from this is global news coverage

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:11.958
from thousands of news sources around the world.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:15.958
It's using the API of a really great company that I work with

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:16.958
in New York, actually, called Daylife.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
And it's kind of the zeitgeist view at this level

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:24.958
of the world's current mythology over the last couple of months.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
So we can see where it's emerging here, like President Ford,

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:31.958
Iraq, Bush. And we can actually isolate just the words --

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
I call them secrets -- and we can cause them to form

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:36.958
an alphabetical list. And we see Anna Nicole Smith

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
playing a big role recently.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:42.958
President Ford -- this is Gerald Ford's funeral.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:45.958
We can actually click anything in Universe

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:46.958
and have it become the center of the universe,

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
and everything else will enter its orbit.

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:51.958
So, we'll click Ford, and now that becomes the center.

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:54.958
And the things that relate to Ford enter its orbit

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:55.958
and swirl around it.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
We can isolate just the photographs, and we now see those.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:00.958
We can click on one of those

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
and have the photograph be the center of the universe.

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:06.958
Now the things that relate to it are swirling around.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:09.958
We can click on this and we see this iconic image

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
of Betty Ford kissing her husband's coffin.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:17.958
In Universe, there's kind of no end. It just goes infinitely,

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:19.958
and you can just kind of click on stuff.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:24.958
This is a photographic representation, called Snapshots.

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:28.958
But we can actually be more specific in defining our universe.

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:29.958
So, if we want to,

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
let's check out what Bill Clinton's universe looks like.

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:36.958
And let's see, in the past week, what he's been up to.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:39.958
So now, we have a new universe, which is just constrained

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:40.958
to all things Bill Clinton.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
We can have his constellations emerge here.

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:45.958
We can pull out his secrets,

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:48.958
and we see that it has a lot to do with candidates,

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:51.958
Hillary, presidential, Barack Obama.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:53.958
We can see the stories

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:56.958
that Bill Clinton is taking part in right now.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
Any of those can be opened up.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
So we see Obama and the Clintons meet in Alabama.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:02.958
You can see that this is an important story;

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:06.958
there are a lot of things in its orbit. If we open this up,

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
we get different perspectives on this story.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
You can click any of those to go out and read the article

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
at the source. This one's from Al Jazeera.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:18.958
We can also see the superstars. These would be the people

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:21.958
that are kind of the looming heroes and heroines

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:24.958
in the universe of Bill Clinton. So there's Bill Clinton, Hillary,

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:28.958
Iraq, George Bush, Barack Obama, Scooter Libby --

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
these are kind of the people of Bill Clinton.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:35.958
We can also see a world map, so this shows us the geographic reach

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:36.958
of Bill Clinton in the last week or so.

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
We can see he's been focused in America

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
because he's been campaigning, probably,

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
but a little bit of action over here in the Middle East.

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:44.958
And then we can also see a timeline.

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:47.958
So we see that he was a bit quiet on Saturday,

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:49.958
but he was back to work on Sunday morning,

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:52.958
and actually been tapering off since then this week.

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:54.958
And it's not limited to just people or dates,

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
but we can actually put in concepts also.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:59.958
So if I put in climate change for all of 2006,

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:02.958
we'll see what that universe looks like.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.958
Here we have our star field. Here we have our shapes.

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:07.958
Here we have our secrets.

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:10.958
So we see again, climate change is large:

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:13.958
Nairobi, global conference, environmental.

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:15.958
And there are also quotes that you can see,

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:17.958
if you're interested in reading about quotes on climate change.

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:18.958
You know, this is really an infinite thing.

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:21.958
The superstars of climate change in 2006:

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:24.958
United States, Britain, China. You know,

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:27.958
these are the towering countries that kind of define this concept.

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:30.958
So this is a piece that demands exploration.

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:34.958
This will be online in several days, probably next Tuesday.

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:39.958
And you'll all be able to use it and kind of explore

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:41.958
what your own personal mythology might be.

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:44.958
You'll notice that in Daylife -- rather, in Universe --

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:46.958
it supports both the notion of a global mythology,

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:49.958
which is represented by something as broad as, say, 2007,

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:51.958

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:55.958
As you search for the things that are important to you in your world,

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:58.958
and then see what the constellations of those might look like.

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:02.958
So it's been a pleasure. Thank you very much.
