the high point of my education.

00:00:51.598 --> 00:00:54.854
From that point on, everything else
was pretty much downhill.

00:00:54.878 --> 00:00:57.814
And it wasn't until later,
as I started making games, that --

00:00:57.838 --> 00:00:59.974
I really actually
think of them more as toys.

00:00:59.998 --> 00:01:01.534
People call me a game designer,

00:01:01.558 --> 00:01:03.814
but I really think
of these things more as toys.

00:01:03.838 --> 00:01:07.194
I started getting very interested
in Maria Montessori and her methods,

00:01:07.218 --> 00:01:08.874
and the way she went about things,

00:01:08.898 --> 00:01:11.234
and the way she thought it
very valuable for kids

00:01:11.258 --> 00:01:12.794
to discover things on their own

00:01:12.818 --> 00:01:14.994
rather than being taught
these things overtly.

00:01:15.018 --> 00:01:18.254
And she would design these toys,
where kids in playing with the toys

00:01:18.278 --> 00:01:20.454
would come to understand
these deep principles

00:01:20.478 --> 00:01:22.054
of life and nature through play.

00:01:22.078 --> 00:01:25.094
And since they discovered this,
it stuck with them so much more,

00:01:25.118 --> 00:01:27.494
and also they would experience
their own failures.

00:01:27.518 --> 00:01:31.014
There was a failure-based aspect
to learning there. It was very important.

00:01:31.038 --> 00:01:32.414
And so, the games that I do,

00:01:32.438 --> 00:01:34.774
I think of really more
as modern Montessori toys.

00:01:34.798 --> 00:01:37.394
And I really kind of want them
to be presented in a way

00:01:37.418 --> 00:01:40.614
to where kids can kind of explore
and discover their own principles.

00:01:40.638 --> 00:01:41.803
So a few years ago,

00:01:41.827 --> 00:01:44.394
I started getting very interested
in the SETI program.

00:01:44.418 --> 00:01:45.715
And that's the way I work.

00:01:45.739 --> 00:01:48.816
I get interested in different subjects,
I dive in, research them,

00:01:48.840 --> 00:01:51.597
and then try to figure out
how to craft a toy around that,

00:01:51.621 --> 00:01:54.598
so that other people can experience
the same sense of discovery

00:01:54.622 --> 00:01:56.661
that I did as I was learning that subject.

00:01:56.685 --> 00:01:58.142
And it led me to astrobiology,

00:01:58.166 --> 00:02:00.223
the study of possible life
in the universe.

00:02:00.247 --> 00:02:01.544
And then Drake's equation,

00:02:01.568 --> 00:02:04.145
looking at the probability
of life arising on planets,

00:02:04.169 --> 00:02:06.786
how long it might last,
how many planets are out there.

00:02:06.810 --> 00:02:09.747
And I started looking
at how interesting Drake's equation was,

00:02:09.771 --> 00:02:12.148
because it spanned
all these different subjects --

00:02:12.172 --> 00:02:16.094
physics, chemistry,
sociology, economics, astronomy.

00:02:16.118 --> 00:02:18.854
And another thing that really
impressed me a long time ago

00:02:18.878 --> 00:02:21.853
was "Powers of Ten,"
Charles and Ray Eames' film.

00:02:21.877 --> 00:02:25.454
And I started putting those two together
and wondering, could I build a toy

00:02:25.478 --> 00:02:28.814
where kids would trip across
all these interesting principles of life,

00:02:28.838 --> 00:02:31.014
as it exists and as it might
go in the future.

00:02:31.038 --> 00:02:33.014
Things where you might trip across things

00:02:33.038 --> 00:02:35.374
like the Copernican principle,
the Fermi paradox,

00:02:35.398 --> 00:02:37.934
the anthropic principle,
the origin of life.

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:41.134
And so I'm going to show you a toy today
that I've been working on,

00:02:41.158 --> 00:02:44.094
that I think of more
as kind of a philosophy toy.

00:02:44.118 --> 00:02:47.494
Playing this toy will bring up
philosophical questions in you.

00:02:47.518 --> 00:02:50.574
The game is "Spore."
I've been working on it for several years.

00:02:50.598 --> 00:02:52.614
It's getting pretty close to finished now.

00:02:52.638 --> 00:02:56.015
It occurs at all these different scales,
from very small to very large.

00:02:56.039 --> 00:02:58.176
I'm going to pop in
at the start of the game.

00:02:58.200 --> 00:03:00.657
And you actually start this game
in a drop of water,

00:03:00.681 --> 00:03:02.698
as a very, very small
single-cell creature,

00:03:02.722 --> 00:03:06.755
and right off the bat you basically
just have to live, survive, reproduce.

00:03:06.779 --> 00:03:09.734
So here we are,
at a very microscopic scale,

00:03:09.758 --> 00:03:11.214
swimming around.

00:03:11.238 --> 00:03:13.614
And I actually realize
that cells don't have eyes,

00:03:13.638 --> 00:03:15.934
but it helps to make it cute.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:19.814
The players are going to play
through every generation of this species,

00:03:19.838 --> 00:03:21.094
and as you play the game,

00:03:21.118 --> 00:03:23.214
the creature is actually
growing bit by bit.

00:03:23.238 --> 00:03:24.814
And as we start growing,

00:03:24.838 --> 00:03:26.894
the camera will
actually start zooming out,

00:03:26.918 --> 00:03:29.134
and things that you see
in the background there

00:03:29.158 --> 00:03:31.334
will start slowly
pulling into the foreground,

00:03:31.358 --> 00:03:34.774
showing you a little bit of what
you'll be interacting with as you grow.

00:03:34.798 --> 00:03:36.934
So as we eat, the camera
starts pulling out,

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:39.934
and then we start interacting
with larger and larger organisms.

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:42.174
We actually play
through many generations here,

00:03:42.198 --> 00:03:43.414
at the cellular scale.

00:03:43.438 --> 00:03:44.854
I'm going to skip ahead here.

00:03:44.878 --> 00:03:46.254
At some point we get larger,

00:03:46.278 --> 00:03:49.243
and we actually get
to a macroevolution scale.

00:03:50.060 --> 00:03:52.934
Now, at this point
we're leaving the water,

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:56.694
and one thing that's kind of important
about this game is that, at every level,

00:03:56.718 --> 00:03:58.974
the player is designing their creature,

00:03:58.998 --> 00:04:00.934
and that's a fundamental aspect of this.

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:03.934
Now, in the evolution game here,
the creature scale,

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:06.534
basically you have to eat,
survive, and then reproduce.

00:04:06.558 --> 00:04:08.374
You know, very Darwinian.

00:04:08.398 --> 00:04:11.374
One thing we noticed with "The Sims,"
a game I did earlier,

00:04:11.398 --> 00:04:13.054
is that players love making stuff.

00:04:13.078 --> 00:04:15.254
When they were able
to make stuff in the game,

00:04:15.278 --> 00:04:17.495
they had a lot of empathy
in connection to it.

00:04:17.519 --> 00:04:19.195
Even if it wasn't as pretty

00:04:19.219 --> 00:04:21.910
as a professional artist
would make for games,

00:04:21.934 --> 00:04:23.151
it really stuck with them

00:04:23.175 --> 00:04:25.632
and they really cared
about what would happen to it.

00:04:25.656 --> 00:04:29.086
At this point, we've left the water,
and now with this little creature --

00:04:29.110 --> 00:04:31.180
we could bring up
the volume a little bit --

00:04:31.204 --> 00:04:33.140
and now we might try to eat.

00:04:33.772 --> 00:04:36.257
We might sneak up
on this little guy over here maybe,

00:04:38.038 --> 00:04:39.238
and try and eat him.

00:04:40.118 --> 00:04:41.334
OK, well, we fight.

00:04:41.358 --> 00:04:42.758
(Creatures grunting)

00:04:44.718 --> 00:04:45.918
OK, we got him.

00:04:47.238 --> 00:04:48.438
Now we get a meal.

00:04:50.302 --> 00:04:52.054
So really, at this part of the game,

00:04:52.078 --> 00:04:54.694
what we're doing is we're
running around and surviving,

00:04:54.718 --> 00:04:56.654
and also getting to the next generation,

00:04:56.678 --> 00:04:59.974
because we're going to play
through every generation of this creature.

00:04:59.998 --> 00:05:01.574
We can mate, so I'm going to see

00:05:01.598 --> 00:05:04.158
if one of these creatures
wants to mate with me. Yeah.

00:05:08.594 --> 00:05:10.614
(Creatures grunting)

00:05:10.638 --> 00:05:14.454
We didn't want to replay
actual evolution with humans and all that,

00:05:14.478 --> 00:05:16.214
because it's almost more interesting

00:05:16.238 --> 00:05:18.494
to look at alternate
possibilities in evolution.

00:05:18.518 --> 00:05:21.774
Evolution is usually presented
as this one path that we took through,

00:05:21.798 --> 00:05:24.454
but really it represents
this huge set of possibilities.

00:05:24.478 --> 00:05:26.374
Now, once we mate, we click on the egg.

00:05:26.398 --> 00:05:28.934
And this is where the game
starts getting interesting,

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.374
because one of the things
we really focused on here

00:05:31.398 --> 00:05:33.654
was giving the players
very high-leverage tools,

00:05:33.678 --> 00:05:37.254
so that for very little effort,
the player can make something very cool.

00:05:37.278 --> 00:05:39.934
And it involves a lot
of intelligence on the tool side.

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:41.534
But basically, this is the editor

00:05:41.558 --> 00:05:43.836
where we're going to design
the next generation.

00:05:43.860 --> 00:05:46.894
So it has a little spine.
I can move around, I can extend.

00:05:46.918 --> 00:05:49.454
I can also inflate or deflate it
with the mouse wheel,

00:05:49.478 --> 00:05:50.814
so you sculpt it like clay.

00:05:50.838 --> 00:05:53.174
We have parts here
that I can put on or pull off.

00:05:53.198 --> 00:05:55.454
The idea is that the player
can basically design

00:05:55.478 --> 00:05:57.494
anything they can think of in this editor,

00:05:57.518 --> 00:05:59.334
and we'll basically bring it to life.

00:05:59.358 --> 00:06:01.614
So I might put some limbs
on the character here.

00:06:01.638 --> 00:06:03.214
I'll inflate them kind of large.

00:06:03.238 --> 00:06:06.198
And in this case
I might decide I'm going to put --

00:06:07.878 --> 00:06:09.598
I'll put mouths on the limbs.

00:06:12.838 --> 00:06:17.054
So pretty much players are encouraged
to be very creative in the game.

00:06:17.078 --> 00:06:21.374
Here, I'll give it one eye in the middle,
maybe scale it up a bit. Point it down.

00:06:21.398 --> 00:06:23.078
And I'll also give it a few legs.

00:06:26.078 --> 00:06:27.294
So in some sense

00:06:27.318 --> 00:06:30.734
we want this to feel like an amplifier
for the player's imagination,

00:06:30.758 --> 00:06:34.494
so that with a very small number of clicks
a player can create something

00:06:34.518 --> 00:06:36.894
that they didn't really think
was possible before.

00:06:36.918 --> 00:06:39.374
This is almost like designing
something like Maya --

00:06:39.398 --> 00:06:40.894
that an eight-year-old can use.

00:06:40.918 --> 00:06:42.334
But really the goal here was,

00:06:42.358 --> 00:06:44.854
within about a minute,
I wanted somebody to replicate

00:06:44.878 --> 00:06:48.134
what typically takes a pictorial artist
several weeks to create.

00:06:48.158 --> 00:06:50.094
OK, now I'll put some hands on it.

00:06:50.118 --> 00:06:53.014
OK, so here I've basically
thrown together a little creature.

00:06:53.038 --> 00:06:56.118
Let me give it a little weapon
on the tail here, so it can fight.

00:06:56.838 --> 00:06:58.454
OK, so that's the complete model.

00:06:58.478 --> 00:07:00.614
Now we can actually
go to the painting phase.

00:07:00.638 --> 00:07:03.134
At this phase, the program
has some understanding

00:07:03.158 --> 00:07:04.774
of the topology of this creature.

00:07:04.798 --> 00:07:07.834
It knows where the backbone is,
where the spine, the limbs are,

00:07:07.858 --> 00:07:10.114
how stripes should run,
how it should be shaded.

00:07:10.138 --> 00:07:12.634
And so we're procedurally
generating the texture map,

00:07:12.658 --> 00:07:15.534
something a texture artist
would take many days to work on.

00:07:15.558 --> 00:07:18.494
And then we can test it out,
and see how it would move around.

00:07:18.518 --> 00:07:22.014
And so at this point the computer
is procedurally animating this creature.

00:07:22.038 --> 00:07:25.534
It's looking at whatever I've designed.
It will actually bring it to life.

00:07:25.558 --> 00:07:27.134
And I can see how it might dance.

00:07:27.158 --> 00:07:28.374
(Laughter)

00:07:28.398 --> 00:07:30.758
How it might show emotions,
how it might fight.

00:07:32.598 --> 00:07:34.574
So it's acting with its two mouths there.

00:07:34.598 --> 00:07:36.454
I can even have it pose for a photo.

00:07:36.478 --> 00:07:37.934
Snap a little photo of it.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:39.934
(Laughter)

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:41.974
So then I bring this back into the game.

00:07:41.998 --> 00:07:45.534
It's born, and I play the next generation
of my creature through evolution.

00:07:45.558 --> 00:07:48.014
Now again, the empathy
that the players have

00:07:48.038 --> 00:07:50.054
when they create
the content is tremendous.

00:07:50.078 --> 00:07:53.854
When players create content in this game,
it's automatically sent up to a server

00:07:53.878 --> 00:07:56.814
and then redistributed
to all the other players transparently.

00:07:56.838 --> 00:07:59.974
So in fact, as I'm interacting
in this world with other creatures,

00:07:59.998 --> 00:08:03.894
these creatures are transparently
coming from other players as they play.

00:08:03.918 --> 00:08:05.574
So the process of playing the game

00:08:05.598 --> 00:08:08.454
is a process of building up
this huge database of content.

00:08:08.478 --> 00:08:11.334
And pretty much everything
you're going to see in this game,

00:08:11.358 --> 00:08:14.014
there's an editor for
that the player can create,

00:08:14.038 --> 00:08:15.637
up through civilization.

00:08:15.661 --> 00:08:18.354
This is my baby. When I eat,
I'll actually start growing.

00:08:18.378 --> 00:08:21.414
This is the next generation.
But I'm going to skip ahead here.

00:08:21.438 --> 00:08:24.774
Normally what would happen is
these creatures would work their way up,

00:08:24.798 --> 00:08:26.254
eventually become intelligent.

00:08:26.278 --> 00:08:29.774
I'd start dealing with tribes, cities
and civilizations of them over time.

00:08:29.798 --> 00:08:32.014
I'm going to skip way ahead
to the space phase.

00:08:32.038 --> 00:08:33.974
Eventually they would go out into space,

00:08:33.998 --> 00:08:37.614
and start colonizing
and exploring the universe.

00:08:37.638 --> 00:08:39.316
Now, really, in some sense,

00:08:39.340 --> 00:08:42.614
I want the players to be building
this world in their imagination,

00:08:42.638 --> 00:08:45.654
and then extracting it from them
with the least amount of pain.

00:08:45.678 --> 00:08:47.814
So that's kind of
what these tools are about.

00:08:47.838 --> 00:08:50.093
How do we make the gameplay,

00:08:50.117 --> 00:08:53.294
you know, basically
the player's imagination amplifier?

00:08:53.318 --> 00:08:56.024
And how do we make
these tools, these editors,

00:08:56.048 --> 00:08:59.054
something that are just as fun
as the game itself?

00:08:59.078 --> 00:09:01.334
So this is the planet
that we've been playing on

00:09:01.358 --> 00:09:03.014
up to this point in the game.

00:09:03.038 --> 00:09:06.814
So far the entire game has been played
on the surface of this little world here.

00:09:06.838 --> 00:09:10.014
At this point we're actually
dealing with a very little toy planet.

00:09:10.038 --> 00:09:12.134
Almost, again,
like the Montessori toy idea.

00:09:12.158 --> 00:09:14.374
What happens if you give
somebody a toy planet,

00:09:14.398 --> 00:09:16.614
and let them play
with a lot of dynamics on it?

00:09:16.638 --> 00:09:19.294
What could they discover?
What might they learn on this?

00:09:19.318 --> 00:09:22.334
This world was actually extracted
from the player's imagination.

00:09:22.358 --> 00:09:24.734
So, this is the planet
that the player evolved on.

00:09:24.758 --> 00:09:28.174
Things like the buildings, the vehicles,
the architecture, civilizations

00:09:28.198 --> 00:09:30.534
were all designed by the player
up to this point.

00:09:30.558 --> 00:09:33.734
So here's a little city with some
of our guys walking around in it.

00:09:33.758 --> 00:09:36.614
And most games put the player
in the role of Luke Skywalker,

00:09:36.638 --> 00:09:38.734
this protagonist
playing through this story.

00:09:38.758 --> 00:09:41.894
This is more about putting the player
in the role of George Lucas.

00:09:41.918 --> 00:09:44.014
I want them, after they've
played this game,

00:09:44.038 --> 00:09:47.254
to have extracted an entire world
that they're now interacting with.

00:09:47.278 --> 00:09:48.494
As we pull down here,

00:09:48.518 --> 00:09:52.054
we still have a whole set of creatures
living on the surface of the planet.

00:09:52.078 --> 00:09:54.094
All these different
dynamics going on here.

00:09:54.118 --> 00:09:57.054
I can look over here, and this is
a little simplified food web

00:09:57.078 --> 00:09:58.774
that's going on with the creatures.

00:09:58.798 --> 00:10:01.654
I can open this up and then scan
what exists on the surface.

00:10:01.678 --> 00:10:05.034
You get some sense of the diversity
of creatures that were brought in.

00:10:05.058 --> 00:10:07.034
Some of these were created by the player,

00:10:07.058 --> 00:10:09.654
others by other players,
automatically sent over here.

00:10:09.678 --> 00:10:12.394
But there's a very simple
calculation of what's required,

00:10:12.418 --> 00:10:15.074
how many plants are required
for the herbivores to live,

00:10:15.098 --> 00:10:17.554
how many herbivores
for the carnivores to eat, etc.,

00:10:17.578 --> 00:10:19.234
that you have to balance actively.

00:10:19.258 --> 00:10:20.474
Also with this phase,

00:10:20.498 --> 00:10:23.274
we're getting more and more
God-like powers for the player,

00:10:23.298 --> 00:10:25.614
and you can experiment
with this planet as a toy.

00:10:25.638 --> 00:10:27.414
So I can come in and I can do things,

00:10:27.438 --> 00:10:29.534
and just treat this planet
as a lump of clay.

00:10:29.558 --> 00:10:32.015
We have very simple
weather systems, simple geology.

00:10:32.039 --> 00:10:35.516
For instance, I could open one of my tools
here and then carve out rivers.

00:10:36.878 --> 00:10:40.094
So this whole thing is kind of
like a big lump of clay, a sculpture.

00:10:40.118 --> 00:10:42.854
I can also play with the dynamics
in this world over time.

00:10:42.878 --> 00:10:44.294
So one of the things I can do

00:10:44.318 --> 00:10:47.694
is start pumping more CO2 gases
into the atmosphere,

00:10:47.718 --> 00:10:49.374
and so that's what I'm doing here.

00:10:49.398 --> 00:10:51.494
There's actually
a little readout down there

00:10:51.518 --> 00:10:54.318
of our planetary atmosphere,
pressure and temperature.

00:10:54.838 --> 00:10:56.814
So as I start pumping in more atmosphere,

00:10:56.838 --> 00:10:59.534
we're going to start pushing up
the greenhouse gases here

00:10:59.558 --> 00:11:00.974
and if you'll start noticing,

00:11:00.998 --> 00:11:03.404
we start seeing
the ocean levels rise over time.

00:11:03.838 --> 00:11:05.894
And our cities
are going to be at risk too,

00:11:05.918 --> 00:11:07.934
because a lot of these are coastal cities.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.974
You can see the ocean levels
are rising now

00:11:09.998 --> 00:11:13.274
and as they encroach upon the cities,
I'll start losing cities here.

00:11:13.298 --> 00:11:16.554
So basically, I want the players
to be able to experiment and explore

00:11:16.578 --> 00:11:18.114
a huge amount of failure space.

00:11:18.138 --> 00:11:19.578
So there goes one city.

00:11:20.425 --> 00:11:22.854
Now, over time, this is
going to heat up the planet.

00:11:22.878 --> 00:11:24.574
So at first what we're going to see

00:11:24.598 --> 00:11:27.134
is a global ocean rise
here on this little toy planet,

00:11:27.158 --> 00:11:29.175
but then over time --
I can speed it up --

00:11:29.199 --> 00:11:31.296
we'll see the heat impact of that as well.

00:11:31.320 --> 00:11:33.223
Not only will it get hotter,

00:11:33.247 --> 00:11:36.564
but at some point it's going to get so hot
the oceans will evaporate.

00:11:36.588 --> 00:11:39.905
They'll go up, and then they'll evaporate,
and that'll be my planet.

00:11:39.929 --> 00:11:41.706
So basically, what we're getting here

00:11:41.730 --> 00:11:44.707
is the sequel to "An Inconvenient Truth,"
in about two minutes,

00:11:44.731 --> 00:11:47.868
and that actually brings up
an interesting point about games.

00:11:47.892 --> 00:11:51.052
Now here, our entire oceans
are evaporating off the surface,

00:11:52.078 --> 00:11:53.614
and as it keeps getting hotter,

00:11:53.638 --> 00:11:57.174
at some point the entire planet
is going to melt down. Here it goes.

00:11:57.198 --> 00:11:59.614
So we're not only
simulating biological dynamics --

00:11:59.638 --> 00:12:00.854
food webs and all that --

00:12:00.878 --> 00:12:03.574
but also geologic, you know,
on a very simple core scale.

00:12:03.598 --> 00:12:05.503
And what's interesting to me about games

00:12:05.527 --> 00:12:08.134
is that I think we can take
a lot of long-term dynamics

00:12:08.158 --> 00:12:11.174
and compress them
into very short-term experiences.

00:12:11.198 --> 00:12:14.094
Because it's so hard for people
to think 50 or 100 years out,

00:12:14.118 --> 00:12:15.734
but when you can give them a toy,

00:12:15.758 --> 00:12:19.094
and they can experience these
long-term dynamics in just a few minutes,

00:12:19.118 --> 00:12:21.454
I think it's an entirely
different point of view,

00:12:21.478 --> 00:12:24.254
where we're actually using the game
to remap our intuition.

00:12:24.278 --> 00:12:25.614
It's almost in the same way

00:12:25.638 --> 00:12:28.374
that a telescope or microscope
recalibrates your eyesight;

00:12:28.398 --> 00:12:31.134
I think computer simulations
can recalibrate your instinct

00:12:31.158 --> 00:12:33.158
across vast scales of both space and time.

00:12:33.182 --> 00:12:34.814
So here's our little solar system,

00:12:34.838 --> 00:12:36.934
as we pull away
from our melted planet here.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:40.014
We actually have a couple
of other planets in this solar system.

00:12:40.038 --> 00:12:41.254
Let's fly to another one.

00:12:41.278 --> 00:12:44.734
We're going to have this unlimited
number of worlds you can explore here.

00:12:44.758 --> 00:12:46.094
As we move into the future,

00:12:46.118 --> 00:12:48.494
and we start going out
into space and doing stuff,

00:12:48.518 --> 00:12:51.014
we're drawing a lot
from things like science fiction.

00:12:51.038 --> 00:12:53.054
And all my favorite science fiction movies

00:12:53.078 --> 00:12:55.254
I want to play out here
as different dynamics.

00:12:55.278 --> 00:12:57.254
This planet actually has some life on it.

00:12:57.278 --> 00:12:59.294
Here it is, some indigenous
life down here.

00:12:59.318 --> 00:13:01.654
One of the tools
I can eventually earn for my UFO

00:13:01.678 --> 00:13:03.374
is a monolith that I can drop down.

00:13:03.398 --> 00:13:05.038
(Laughter)

00:13:05.918 --> 00:13:07.934
Now, as you can see,

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:11.254
these guys are actually
starting to go up and bow to it,

00:13:11.278 --> 00:13:14.294
and over time, once they touch it,
they will become intelligent.

00:13:14.318 --> 00:13:16.414
So I can actually
pick a species on a planet

00:13:16.438 --> 00:13:17.814
and then make them sentient.

00:13:17.838 --> 00:13:19.974
Now they've actually
gone to tribal dynamics.

00:13:19.998 --> 00:13:22.014
And now, because
I'm actually the one here,

00:13:22.038 --> 00:13:23.854
I can get out of the UFO and walk up,

00:13:23.878 --> 00:13:26.974
and they should be worshipping me
at this point as a god.

00:13:26.998 --> 00:13:28.958
At first they're a little freaked out.

00:13:33.494 --> 00:13:35.494
OK, well maybe they're not worshipping me.

00:13:35.518 --> 00:13:36.534
(Laughter)

00:13:36.558 --> 00:13:38.678
I think I'll leave
before they get hostile.

00:13:39.678 --> 00:13:41.894
But we basically want
a diversity of activities

00:13:41.918 --> 00:13:43.574
the players can play through this.

00:13:43.598 --> 00:13:44.854
I want to be able to play

00:13:44.878 --> 00:13:47.574
"The Day the Earth Stood Still,"
"2001: A Space Odyssey,"

00:13:47.598 --> 00:13:49.214
"Star Trek," "War Of the Worlds."

00:13:49.238 --> 00:13:51.214
Now, as we pull away from this world --

00:13:51.238 --> 00:13:53.654
we're going to keep
pulling away from the star now.

00:13:53.678 --> 00:13:56.494
One of the things that always
frustrated me about astronomy

00:13:56.518 --> 00:13:57.734
when I was a kid

00:13:57.758 --> 00:14:00.894
is how it was always presented
so two-dimensionally and so static.

00:14:00.918 --> 00:14:02.614
As we pull away from the star here,

00:14:02.638 --> 00:14:05.134
we're actually going now
out into interstellar space,

00:14:05.158 --> 00:14:08.014
and we're getting a sense
of the space around our home star.

00:14:08.038 --> 00:14:10.734
What I really wanted to do
is to present this, basically,

00:14:10.758 --> 00:14:13.054
as wonderfully 3D as it is actually is.

00:14:13.078 --> 00:14:15.054
And also show the dynamics,

00:14:15.078 --> 00:14:18.774
and a lot of the interesting objects
that you might find, like, in the Hubble,

00:14:18.798 --> 00:14:21.054
at pretty much realistic
frequencies and scales.

00:14:21.078 --> 00:14:23.214
So most people
have no idea of the difference

00:14:23.238 --> 00:14:25.614
between an emission nebula
and a planetary nebula.

00:14:25.638 --> 00:14:26.894
But these are the things

00:14:26.918 --> 00:14:28.974
that we can put
in this little galaxy here.

00:14:28.998 --> 00:14:31.734
So we're flying over here
to what looks like a black hole.

00:14:31.758 --> 00:14:34.454
I want to basically have
the entire zoo of Hubble objects

00:14:34.478 --> 00:14:37.334
that people can interact with
and play with, again, as toys.

00:14:37.358 --> 00:14:38.774
So here's a little black hole

00:14:38.798 --> 00:14:41.118
that we probably
don't want to get too close to.

00:14:42.078 --> 00:14:44.094
But we also have stars and things as well.

00:14:44.118 --> 00:14:47.574
If we pull all the way back,
we start seeing the entire galaxy here,

00:14:47.598 --> 00:14:49.534
kind of slowly in motion.

00:14:49.558 --> 00:14:52.774
Typically, when people present galaxies,

00:14:52.798 --> 00:14:55.481
it's always beautiful photos,
but they're always static.

00:14:55.505 --> 00:14:58.394
And when you bring it forward in time
and start animating it,

00:14:58.418 --> 00:15:01.212
it's amazing what a galaxy
would look like fast forwarded.

00:15:01.236 --> 00:15:03.393
This would be about
a million years a second,

00:15:03.417 --> 00:15:06.014
because you have about
one supernova every century.

00:15:06.038 --> 00:15:08.374
And so you'd have
this wonderful sparkling thing,

00:15:08.398 --> 00:15:09.854
with the disk slowly rotating,

00:15:09.878 --> 00:15:11.974
and this is roughly
what it would look like.

00:15:11.998 --> 00:15:14.994
Part of this is about bringing
the beauty of the natural world

00:15:15.018 --> 00:15:16.874
to somebody in a very imaginative way,

00:15:16.898 --> 00:15:19.234
so that they can start
calibrating their instinct

00:15:19.258 --> 00:15:21.314
across these vast scales
of space and time.

00:15:21.338 --> 00:15:25.574
Chris was wondering what kind of gods
the players would become.

00:15:25.598 --> 00:15:27.054
Because if you think about it,

00:15:27.078 --> 00:15:30.674
you're going to have 15-year-olds,
20-year-olds flying around this universe.

00:15:30.698 --> 00:15:32.154
They might be a nurturing god.

00:15:32.178 --> 00:15:34.274
They might be bootstrapping
life on planets,

00:15:34.298 --> 00:15:36.394
trying to terraform
and spread civilization.

00:15:36.418 --> 00:15:38.654
You might be a vengeful god, conquesting,

00:15:38.678 --> 00:15:42.134
because you actually can do that,
you can attack other intelligent races.

00:15:42.158 --> 00:15:45.180
You might be a networking god,
building alliances,

00:15:45.204 --> 00:15:49.060
or just curious, going around and wanting
to explore as much as you possibly can.

00:15:49.640 --> 00:15:53.385
But basically, the reason
why I make toys like this

00:15:53.409 --> 00:15:55.671
is because I think
if there's one difference

00:15:55.695 --> 00:15:58.414
I could possibly make in the world,

00:15:58.438 --> 00:15:59.814
that I would choose to make,

00:15:59.838 --> 00:16:01.974
it's that I would like
to somehow give people

00:16:01.998 --> 00:16:04.814
just a little bit better calibration
on long-term thinking.

00:16:04.838 --> 00:16:08.174
Because I think most of the problems
that our world is facing right now

00:16:08.198 --> 00:16:10.014
are the result of short-term thinking,

00:16:10.038 --> 00:16:14.214
and the fact that it is so hard for us
to think 50, 100, or 1,000 years out.

00:16:14.238 --> 00:16:17.894
And I think by giving kids toys like this
and letting them replay dynamics,

00:16:17.918 --> 00:16:20.014
very long-term dynamics
over the short term,

00:16:20.038 --> 00:16:22.254
and getting some sense
of what we're doing now,

00:16:22.278 --> 00:16:24.214
what it's going to be like in 100 years,

00:16:24.238 --> 00:16:28.214
I think probably is the most effective
thing I can be doing to help the world.

00:16:28.238 --> 00:16:30.905
And so that's why I think
that toys can change the world.

00:16:30.929 --> 00:16:32.129
Thank you.

title: The  4 a.m. mystery
transcript: This is a recent comic strip from the Los Angeles Times. The punch line? "On the other hand, I don't have to get up at four every single morning to milk my Labrador." This is a recent cover of New York Magazine. Best hospitals where doctors say they would go for cancer treatment, births, strokes, heart disease, hip replacements, 4 a.m. emergencies. And this is a song medley I put together —(Music)Did you ever notice that four in the morning has become some sort of meme or shorthand? It means something like you are awake at the worst possible hour.(Laughter)A time for inconveniences, mishaps, yearnings. A time for plotting to whack the chief of police, like in this classic scene from "The Godfather." Coppola's script describes these guys as, "exhausted in shirt sleeves. It is four in the morning."(Laughter)A time for even grimmer stuff than that, like autopsies and embalmings in Isabel Allende's "The House of the Spirits." After the breathtaking green-haired Rosa is murdered, the doctors preserve her with unguents and morticians' paste. They worked until four o'clock in the morning.A time for even grimmer stuff than that, like in last April's New Yorker magazine. This short fiction piece by Martin Amis starts out, "On September 11, 2001, he opened his eyes at 4 a.m. in Portland, Maine, and Mohamed Atta's last day began." For a time that I find to be the most placid and uneventful hour of the day, four in the morning sure gets an awful lot of bad press —(Laughter)across a lot of different media from a lot of big names. And it made me suspicious. I figured, surely some of the most creative artistic minds in the world, really, aren't all defaulting back to this one easy trope like they invented it, right? Could it be there is something more going on here? Something deliberate, something secret, and who got the four in the morning bad rap ball rolling anyway? I say this guy — Alberto Giacometti, shown here with some of his sculptures on the Swiss 100 franc note. He did it with this famous piece from the New York Museum of Modern Art. Its title — "The Palace at Four in the Morning —(Laughter)1932. Not just the earliest cryptic reference to four in the morning I can find. I believe that this so-called first surrealist sculpture may provide an incredible key to virtually every artistic depiction of four in the morning to follow it. I call this The Giacometti Code, a TED exclusive. No, feel free to follow along on your Blackberries or your iPhones if you've got them.It works a little something like — this is a recent Google search for four in the morning. Results vary, of course. This is pretty typical. The top 10 results yield you four hits for Faron Young's song, "It's Four in the Morning," three hits for Judi Dench's film, "Four in the Morning," one hit for Wislawa Szymborska's poem, "Four in the Morning." But what, you may ask, do a Polish poet, a British Dame, a country music hall of famer all have in common besides this totally excellent Google ranking?Well, let's start with Faron Young — who was born incidentally in 1932.(Laughter)In 1996, he shot himself in the head on December ninth — which incidentally is Judi Dench's birthday.(Laughter)But he didn't die on Dench's birthday. He languished until the following afternoon when he finally succumbed to a supposedly self-inflicted gunshot wound at the age of 64 — which incidentally is how old Alberto Giacometti was when he died.Where was Wislawa Szymborska during all this? She has the world's most absolutely watertight alibi. On that very day, December 10, 1996 while Mr. Four in the Morning, Faron Young, was giving up the ghost in Nashville, Tennessee, Ms. Four in the Morning — or one of them anyway — Wislawa Szymborska was in Stockholm, Sweden, accepting the Nobel Prize for Literature. 100 years to the day after the death of Alfred Nobel himself. Coincidence? No, it's creepy.(Laughter)Coincidence to me has a much simpler metric. That's like me telling you, "Hey, you know the Nobel Prize was established in 1901, which coincidentally is the same year Alberto Giacometti was born?" No, not everything fits so tidily into the paradigm, but that does not mean there's not something going on at the highest possible levels. In fact there are people in this room who may not want me to show you this clip we're about to see.(Laughter)Video: Homer Simpson: We have a tennis court, a swimming pool, a screening room — You mean if I want pork chops, even in the middle of the night, your guy will fry them up?Herbert Powell: Sure, that's what he's paid for. Now do you need towels, laundry, maids?HS: Wait, wait, wait, wait, wait, wait — let me see if I got this straight. It is Christmas Day, 4 a.m. There's a rumble in my stomach.Marge Simpson: Homer, please.Rives: Wait, wait, wait, wait, wait, wait, wait. Let me see if I got this straight, Matt.(Laughter)When Homer Simpson needs to imagine the most remote possible moment of not just the clock, but the whole freaking calendar, he comes up with 0400 on the birthday of the Baby Jesus. And no, I don't know how it works into the whole puzzling scheme of things, but obviously I know a coded message when I see one.(Laughter)I said, I know a coded message when I see one. And folks, you can buy a copy of Bill Clinton's "My Life" from the bookstore here at TED. Parse it cover to cover for whatever hidden references you want. Or you can go to the Random House website where there is this excerpt. And how far down into it you figure we'll have to scroll to get to the golden ticket? Would you believe about a dozen paragraphs? This is page 474 on your paperbacks if you're following along: "Though it was getting better, I still wasn't satisfied with the inaugural address. My speechwriters must have been tearing their hair out because as we worked between one and four in the morning on Inauguration Day, I was still changing it."Sure you were, because you've prepared your entire life for this historic quadrennial event that just sort of sneaks up on you. And then —(Laughter)three paragraphs later we get this little beauty: "We went back to Blair House to look at the speech for the last time. It had gotten a lot better since 4 a.m." Well, how could it have? By his own writing, this man was either asleep, at a prayer meeting with Al and Tipper or learning how to launch a nuclear missile out of a suitcase. What happens to American presidents at 0400 on inauguration day? What happened to William Jefferson Clinton? We might not ever know. And I noticed, he's not exactly around here today to face any tough questions.(Laughter)It could get awkward, right? I mean after all, this whole business happened on his watch. But if he were here —(Laughter)he might remind us, as he does in the wrap-up to his fine autobiography, that on this day Bill Clinton began a journey — a journey that saw him go on to become the first Democrat president elected to two consecutive terms in decades. In generations. The first since this man, Franklin Delano Roosevelt, who began his own unprecedented journey way back at his own first election, way back in a simpler time, way back in 1932 — (Laughter)the year Alberto Giacometti(Laughter)made "The Palace at Four in the Morning." The year, let's remember, that this voice, now departed, first came a-cryin' into this big old crazy world of ours.(Music)(Applause)

(Laughter)

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
your guy will fry them up?

Herbert Powell: Sure, that's what he's paid for.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.958

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958

Marge Simpson: Homer, please.

Rives: Wait, wait, wait, wait, wait, wait, wait.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.958
the most remote possible moment of not just the clock,

but the whole freaking calendar, he comes up with 0400

00:05:57.958 --> 00:05:59.958
on the birthday of the Baby Jesus.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:06.958
into the whole puzzling scheme of things, but obviously

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:10.958
I know a coded message when I see one.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:11.958
(Laughter)

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:15.958
I said, I know a coded message when I see one.

And folks, you can buy a copy of Bill Clinton's "My Life"

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:20.958
from the bookstore here at TED.

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:23.958
Parse it cover to cover for whatever hidden references you want.

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
Or you can go to the Random House website where there is this excerpt.

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
And how far down into it you figure we'll have to scroll

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
to get to the golden ticket?

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
Would you believe about a dozen paragraphs?

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
This is page 474 on your paperbacks if you're following along:

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
"Though it was getting better, I still wasn't satisfied

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
with the inaugural address.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:45.958
My speechwriters must have been tearing their hair out

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958
because as we worked between one and four in the morning

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:52.958
on Inauguration Day, I was still changing it."

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
Sure you were, because you've prepared your entire life

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:59.958
for this historic quadrennial event that just sort of sneaks up on you.

And then --

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
(Laughter)

three paragraphs later we get this little beauty:

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
"We went back to Blair House to look at the speech for the last time.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:13.958
It had gotten a lot better since 4 a.m."

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:15.958
Well, how could it have?

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.958
By his own writing, this man was either asleep,

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:20.958
at a prayer meeting with Al and Tipper or learning how to launch

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:23.958
a nuclear missile out of a suitcase.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:27.958
What happens to American presidents at 0400 on inauguration day?

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
What happened to William Jefferson Clinton?

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
We might not ever know.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:34.958
And I noticed, he's not exactly around here today

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
to face any tough questions.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
(Laughter)

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
It could get awkward, right?

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
I mean after all, this whole business happened on his watch.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
But if he were here --

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:45.958
(Laughter)

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:49.958
he might remind us, as he does in the wrap-up to his fine autobiography,

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:52.958
that on this day Bill Clinton began a journey --

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
a journey that saw him go on to become

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
the first Democrat president elected

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
to two consecutive terms in decades.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
In generations.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
The first since this man, Franklin Delano Roosevelt,

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:07.958
who began his own unprecedented journey

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:10.958
way back at his own first election,

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:17.958
way back in a simpler time, way back in 1932 --

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:19.958
(Laughter)

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:20.958
the year Alberto Giacometti

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:21.958
(Laughter)

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
made "The Palace at Four in the Morning."

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:28.958
The year, let's remember, that this voice, now departed,

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:33.958
first came a-cryin' into this big old crazy world of ours.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:57.958
(Music)

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
(Applause)

title: Visualizing the wonder of a living cell
transcript: I'm a medical illustrator, and I come from a slightly different point of view. I've been watching, since I grew up, the expressions of truth and beauty in the arts and truth and beauty in the sciences. And while these are both wonderful things in their own right — they both have very wonderful things going for them — truth and beauty as ideals that can be looked at by the sciences and by math are almost like the ideal conjoined twins that a scientist would want to date. (Laughter) These are expressions of truth as awe-full things, by meaning they are things you can worship. They are ideals that are powerful. They are irreducible. They are unique. They are useful — sometimes, often a long time after the fact. And you can actually roll some of the pictures now, because I don't want to look at me on the screen.Truth and beauty are things that are often opaque to people who are not in the sciences. They are things that describe beauty in a way that is often only accessible if you understand the language and the syntax of the person who studies the subject in which truth and beauty is expressed. If you look at the math, E=mc squared, if you look at the cosmological constant, where there's an anthropic ideal, where you see that life had to evolve from the numbers that describe the universe — these are things that are really difficult to understand.And what I've tried to do since I had my training as a medical illustrator — since I was taught animation by my father, who was a sculptor and my visual mentor — I wanted to figure out a way to help people understand truth and beauty in the biological sciences by using animation, by using pictures, by telling stories so that the things that are not necessarily evident to people can be brought forth, and can be taught, and can be understood.Students today are often immersed in an environment where what they learn is subjects that have truth and beauty embedded in them, but the way they're taught is compartmentalized and it's drawn down to the point where the truth and beauty are not always evident. It's almost like that old recipe for chicken soup where you boil the chicken until the flavor is just gone. We don't want to do that to our students. So we have an opportunity to really open up education.And I had a telephone call from Robert Lue at Harvard, in the Molecular and Cellular Biology Department, a couple of years ago. He asked me if my team and I would be interested and willing to really change how medical and scientific education is done at Harvard. So we embarked on a project that would explore the cell — that would explore the truth and beauty inherent in molecular and cellular biology so that students could understand a larger picture that they could hang all of these facts on. They could have a mental image of the cell as a large, bustling, hugely complicated city that's occupied by micro-machines.And these micro-machines really are at the heart of life. These micro-machines, which are the envy of nanotechnologists the world over, are self-directed, powerful, precise, accurate devices that are made out of strings of amino acids. And these micro-machines power how a cell moves. They power how a cell replicates. They power our hearts. They power our minds.And so what we wanted to do was to figure out how we could make this story into an animation that would be the centerpiece of BioVisions at Harvard, which is a website that Harvard has for its molecular and cellular biology students that will — in addition to all the textual information, in addition to all the didactic stuff — put everything together visually, so that these students would have an internalized view of what a cell really is in all of its truth and beauty, and be able to study with this view in mind, so that their imaginations would be sparked, so that their passions would be sparked and so that they would be able to go on and use these visions in their head to make new discoveries and to be able to find out, really, how life works.So we set out by looking at how these molecules are put together. We worked with a theme, which is, you've got macrophages that are streaming down a capillary, and they're touching the surface of the capillary wall, and they're picking up information from cells that are on the capillary wall, and they are given this information that there's an inflammation somewhere outside, where they can't see and sense. But they get the information that causes them to stop, causes them to internalize that they need to make all of the various parts that will cause them to change their shape, and try to get out of this capillary and find out what's going on.So these molecular motors — we had to work with the Harvard scientists and databank models of the atomically accurate molecules and figure out how they moved, and figure out what they did. And figure out how to do this in a way that was truthful in that it imparted what was going on, but not so truthful that the compact crowding in a cell would prevent the vista from happening.And so what I'm going to show you is a three-minute Reader's Digest version of the first aspect of this film that we produced. It's an ongoing project that's going to go another four or five years. And I want you to look at this and see the paths that the cell manufactures — these little walking machines, they're called kinesins — that take these huge loads that would challenge an ant in relative size. Run the movie, please.But these machines that power the inside of the cells are really quite amazing, and they really are the basis of all life because all of these machines interact with each other. They pass information to each other. They cause different things to happen inside the cell. And the cell will actually manufacture the parts that it needs on the fly, from information that's brought from the nucleus by molecules that read the genes. No life, from the smallest life to everybody here, would be possible without these little micro-machines. In fact, it would really, in the absence of these machines, have made the attendance here, Chris, really quite sparse. (Laughter) (Music)This is the FedEx delivery guy of the cell. This little guy is called the kinesin, and he pulls a sack that's full of brand new manufactured proteins to wherever it's needed in the cell — whether it's to a membrane, whether it's to an organelle, whether it's to build something or repair something. And each of us has about 100,000 of these things running around, right now, inside each one of your 100 trillion cells. So no matter how lazy you feel, you're not really intrinsically doing nothing. (Laughter)So what I want you to do when you go home is think about this, and think about how powerful our cells are. And think about some of the things that we're learning about cellular mechanics. Once we figure out all that's going on — and believe me, we know almost a percent of what's going on — once we figure out what's going on, we're really going to be able to have a lot of control over what we do with our health, with what we do with future generations, and how long we're going to live. And hopefully we'll be able to use this to discover more truth, and more beauty. (Music)But it's really quite amazing that these cells, these micro-machines, are aware enough of what the cell needs that they do their bidding. They work together. They make the cell do what it needs to do. And their working together helps our bodies — huge entities that they will never see — function properly. Enjoy the rest of the show. Thank you. (Applause)

title: Africa's cheetahs versus hippos
transcript: Well, first of all, let me thank Emeka — as a matter of fact, TED Global — for putting this conference together. This conference is going to rank as the most important in the beginning of the 21st century. Think African governments will put together a conference like this? You think the A.U. will put together a conference like this? Even before they do that they will ask for foreign aid. I would also like to pay homage and honor to the TED Fellows June Arunga, James Shikwati, Andrew, and the other TED Fellows. I call them the Cheetah Generation. The Cheetah Generation is a new breed of Africans who brook no nonsense about corruption. They understand what accountability and democracy is. They're not going to wait for government to do things for them. That's the Cheetah Generation, and Africa's salvation rests on the backs of these Cheetahs. In contrast, of course, we have the Hippo Generation.(Laughter)The Hippo Generation are the ruling elites. They are stuck in their intellectual patch. Complaining about colonialism and imperialism, they wouldn't move one foot. If you ask them to reform the economies, they're not going to reform it because they benefit from the rotten status quo. Now, there are a lot of Africans who are very angry, angry at the condition of Africa. Now, we're talking about a continent that is not poor. It is rich in mineral resources, natural mineral resources. But the mineral wealth of Africa is not being utilized to lift its people out of poverty. That's what makes a lot of Africans very angry. And in a way, Africa is more than a tragedy, in more ways than one. There's another enduring tragedy, and that tragedy is that there are so many people, so many governments, so many organizations who want to help the people in Africa. They don't understand. Now, we're not saying don't help Africa. Helping Africa is noble. But helping Africa has been turned into a theater of the absurd. It's like the blind leading the clueless.(Laughter)There are certain things that we need to recognize. Africa's begging-bowl leaks. Did you know that 40 percent of the wealth created in Africa is not invested here in Africa? It's taken out of Africa. That's what the World Bank says. Look at Africa's begging-bowl. It leaks horribly. There are people who think that we should pour more money, more aid into this bowl which leaks. What are the leakages? Corruption alone costs Africa 148 billion dollars a year. Yes, put that aside. Capital flight out of Africa, 80 billion a year. Put that aside. Let's take food imports. Every year Africa spends 20 billion dollars to import food. Just add that up, all these leakages. That's far more than the 50 billion Tony Blair wants to raise for Africa. Now, back in the 1960s Africa not only fed itself, it also exported food. Not anymore.We know that something has gone fundamentally wrong. You know it, I know it, but let's not waste our time talking about these mistakes because we'll spend all day here. Let's move on, and flip over to the next chapter, and that's what this conference is all about — the next chapter. The next chapter begins with first of all, asking ourselves this fundamental question, "Whom do we want to help in Africa?" There is the people, and then there is the government or leaders. Now, the previous speaker before me, Idris Mohammed, indicated that we've had abysmal leadership in Africa. That characterization, in my view, is even more charitable.(Laughter)I belong to an Internet discussion forum, an African Internet discussion forum, and I asked them, I said, "Since 1960, we've had exactly 204 African heads of state, since 1960." And I asked them to name me just 20 good leaders, just 20 good leaders — you may want to take this leadership challenge yourself. I asked them to name me just 20. Everybody mentioned Nelson Mandela, of course. Kwame Nkrumah, Nyerere, Kenyatta — somebody mentioned Idi Amin.(Laughter)I let that pass.(Laughter)My point is, they couldn't go beyond 15. Even if they had been able to name me 20, what does that tell you? 20 out of 204 means that the vast majority of the African leaders failed their people. And if you look at them, the slate of the post-colonial leaders — an assortment of military fufu heads, Swiss-bank socialists, crocodile liberators, vampire elites, quack revolutionaries.(Applause)Now, this leadership is a far cry from the traditional leaders that Africans have known for centuries. The second false premise that we make when we're trying to help Africa is that sometimes we think that there is something called a government in Africa that cares about its people, serves the interests of the people, and represents the people. There is one particular quote — a Lesotho chief once said that "Here in Lesotho, we've got two problems: rats and the government."(Laughter)What you and I understand as a government doesn't exist in many African countries. In fact, what we call our governments are vampire states. Vampires because they suck the economic vitality out of their people. Government is the problem in Africa. A vampire state is the government — (Applause) — which has been hijacked by a phalanx of bandits and crooks who use the instruments of state power to enrich themselves, their cronies, and tribesmen and exclude everybody else. The richest people in Africa are heads-of-state and ministers, and quite often the chief bandit is the head-of-state himself. Where do they get their money? By creating wealth? No. By raking it off the backs of their suffering people. That's not wealth creation. It's wealth redistribution.The third fundamental issue that we have to recognize is that if we want to help the African people, we must know where the African people are. Take any African economy. An African economy can be broken up into three sectors. There is the modern sector, there is the informal sector and the traditional sector. The modern sector is the abode of the elites. It's the seat of government. In many African countries the modern sector is lost. It's dysfunctional. It is a meretricious fandango of imported systems, which the elites themselves don't understand. That is the source of many of Africa's problems where the struggles for political power emanate and then spill over onto the informal and the traditional sector, claiming innocent lives.Now the modern sector, of course, is where a lot of the development aid and resources went into. More than 80 percent of Ivory Coast's development went into the modern sector. The other sectors, the informal and the traditional sectors, are where you find the majority of the African people, the real people in Africa. That's where you find them. Now, obviously it makes common sense that if you want to help the people, you go where the people are. But that's not what we did. As a matter of fact, we neglected the informal and the traditional sectors. Now, traditional sector is where Africa produces its agriculture, which is one of the reasons why Africa can't feed itself, and that's why it must import food.All right, you cannot develop Africa by ignoring the informal and the traditional sectors. And you can't develop the informal and the traditional sectors without an operational understanding of how these two sectors work. These two sectors, let me describe to you, have their own indigenous institutions. First one is the political system. Traditionally, Africans hate governments. They hate tyranny. If you look into their traditional systems, Africans organize their states in two types. The first one belongs to those ethnic societies who believe that the state was necessarily tyrannous, so they didn't want to have anything to do with any centralized authority. These societies are the Ibo, the Somali, the Kikuyus, for example. They have no chiefs.The other ethnic groups, which did have chiefs, made sure that they surrounded the chiefs with councils upon councils upon councils to prevent them from abusing their power. In Ashanti tradition, for example, the chief cannot make any decision without the concurrence of the council of elders. Without the council the chief can't pass any law, and if the chief doesn't govern according to the will of the people he will be removed. If not, the people will abandon the chief, go somewhere else and set up a new settlement. And even if you look in ancient African empires, they were all organized around one particular principle — the confederacy principle, which is characterized by a great deal of devolution of authority, decentralization of power.Now, this is what I have described to you. This is part of Africa's indigenous political heritage. Now, compare that to the modern systems the ruling elites established on Africa. It is a total far cry. In the economic system in traditional Africa, the means of production is privately owned. It's owned by extended families. You see, in the West, the basic economic and social unit is the individual. The American will say, "I am because I am, and I can damn well do anything I want, anytime." The accent is on the "I." In Africa, the Africans say, "I am, because we are." The "we" connotes community — the extended family system. The extended family system pools its resources together.They own farms. They decide what to do, what to produce. They don't take any orders from their chiefs. They decide what to do. And when they produce their crops, they sell the surplus on marketplaces. When they make a profit it is theirs to keep, not for the chief to sequester it from them. So, in a nutshell, what we had in traditional Africa was a free-market system. There were markets in Africa before the colonialists stepped foot on the continent. Timbuktu was one great big market town. Kano, Salaga — they were all there. Even if you go to West Africa, you notice that market activity in West Africa has always been dominated by women. So, it's quite appropriate that this section is called a marketplace. The market is not alien to Africa.What Africans practiced was a different form of capitalism, but then after independence, all of a sudden, markets, capitalism became a western institution, and the leaders said Africans were ready for socialism. Nonsense. And even then, what kind of socialism did they practice? The socialism that they practiced was a peculiar form of Swiss-bank socialism, which allowed the heads of states and the ministers to rape and plunder Africa's treasuries for deposit in Switzerland. That is not the kind of system Africans had known for centuries. What do we do now? Go back to Africa's indigenous institutions, and this is where we charge the Cheetahs to go into the informal sectors, the traditional sectors. That's where you find the African people.And I'd like to show you a quick little video about the informal sector, about the boat-building that I, myself, tried to mobilize Africans in the Diaspora to invest in. Could you please show that? The men are going fishing in these small boats. Yes, it's an enterprise. This is by a local Ghanaian entrepreneur, using his own capital. He's getting no assistance from the government, and he's building a second, bigger boat. A bigger boat will mean more fish will be caught and landed. It means that he will be able to employ more Ghanaians. It also means that he will be able to generate wealth. And then it will have what economists call external effects on a local economy. All that you need to do, all that the elites need to do, is to move this operation into something that is enclosed so that the operation can be made more efficient.Now, it is not just this informal sector. There is also traditional medicine. 80 percent of Africans still rely on traditional medicine. The modern healthcare sector has totally collapsed. Now, this is an area — I mean, there is a treasure trove of wealth in the traditional medicine area. This is where we need to mobilize Africans, in the Diaspora especially, to invest in this. We also need to mobilize Africans in the Diaspora, not only to go into the traditional sectors, but to go into agriculture and also to instigate change from within. We were able to mobilize Ghanaians in the Diaspora to instigate change in Ghana and bring about democracy in Ghana. And I know that with the Cheetahs, we can take Africa back one village at a time. Thank you very much.(Applause)
