and the prepositions "to" and "from"

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
in a literal, spatial sense.

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
"The messenger went from Paris to Istanbul."

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
You can also say, "Biff went from sick to well."

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.958
He needn't go anywhere. He could have been in bed the whole time,

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:21.958
but it's as if his health is a point in state space

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
that you conceptualize as moving.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
Or, "The meeting went from three to four,"

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:28.958
in which we conceive of time as stretched along a line.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
Likewise, we use "force" to indicate

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
not only physical force,

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
as in, "Rose forced the door to open,"

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
but also interpersonal force,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:41.958
as in, "Rose forced Sadie to go," not necessarily by manhandling her,

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
but by issuing a threat.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
Or, "Rose forced herself to go,"

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
as if there were two entities inside Rose's head,

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
engaged in a tug of a war.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
Second conclusion is that the ability to conceive

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
of a given event in two different ways,

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
such as "cause something to go to someone"

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:00.958
and "causing someone to have something,"

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:04.958
I think is a fundamental feature of human thought,

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
and it's the basis for much human argumentation,

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
in which people don't differ so much on the facts

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
as on how they ought to be construed.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
Just to give you a few examples:

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:16.958
"ending a pregnancy" versus "killing a fetus;"

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:19.958
"a ball of cells" versus "an unborn child;"

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
"invading Iraq" versus "liberating Iraq;"

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:25.958
"redistributing wealth" versus "confiscating earnings."

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
And I think the biggest picture of all

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:30.958
would take seriously the fact

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.958
that so much of our verbiage about abstract events

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
is based on a concrete metaphor

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
and see human intelligence itself

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.958
as consisting of a repertoire of concepts --

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:43.958
such as objects, space, time, causation and intention --

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:47.958
which are useful in a social, knowledge-intensive species,

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:49.958
whose evolution you can well imagine,

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
and a process of metaphorical abstraction

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
that allows us to bleach these concepts

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
of their original conceptual content --

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:00.958
space, time and force --

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
and apply them to new abstract domains,

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
therefore allowing a species that evolved

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
to deal with rocks and tools and animals,

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.958
to conceptualize mathematics, physics, law

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:13.958
and other abstract domains.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
Well, I said I'd talk about two windows on human nature --

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:19.958
the cognitive machinery with which we conceptualize the world,

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
and now I'm going to say a few words about the relationship types

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
that govern human social interaction,

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
again, as reflected in language.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:30.958
And I'll start out with a puzzle, the puzzle of indirect speech acts.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
Now, I'm sure most of you have seen the movie "Fargo."

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
And you might remember the scene in which

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
the kidnapper is pulled over by a police officer,

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
is asked to show his driver's license

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
and holds his wallet out

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:44.958
with a 50-dollar bill extending

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:46.958
at a slight angle out of the wallet.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
And he says, "I was just thinking

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
that maybe we could take care of it here in Fargo,"

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
which everyone, including the audience,

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
interprets as a veiled bribe.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:11:00.958
This kind of indirect speech is rampant in language.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
For example, in polite requests,

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
if someone says, "If you could pass the guacamole,

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
that would be awesome,"

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
we know exactly what he means,

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
even though that's a rather bizarre

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
concept being expressed.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
(Laughter)

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:17.958
"Would you like to come up and see my etchings?"

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
I think most people

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
understand the intent behind that.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
And likewise, if someone says,

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
"Nice store you've got there. It would be a real shame if something happened to it" --

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:28.958
(Laughter) --

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
we understand that as a veiled threat,

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:33.958
rather than a musing of hypothetical possibilities.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958
So the puzzle is, why are bribes,

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
polite requests, solicitations and threats so often veiled?

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
No one's fooled.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
Both parties know exactly what the speaker means,

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
and the speaker knows the listener knows

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
that the speaker knows that the listener knows, etc., etc.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
So what's going on?

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
I think the key idea is that language

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
is a way of negotiating relationships,

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
and human relationships fall into a number of types.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:02.958
There's an influential taxonomy by the anthropologist Alan Fiske,

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:05.958
in which relationships can be categorized, more or less,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
into communality, which works on the principle

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:10.958
"what's mine is thine, what's thine is mine,"

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:14.958
the kind of mindset that operates within a family, for example;

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
dominance, whose principle is "don't mess with me;"

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:21.958
reciprocity, "you scratch my back, I'll scratch yours;"

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:26.958
and sexuality, in the immortal words of Cole Porter, "Let's do it."

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.958
Now, relationship types can be negotiated.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.958
Even though there are default situations

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
in which one of these mindsets can be applied,

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:37.958
they can be stretched and extended.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:40.958
For example, communality applies most naturally

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
within family or friends,

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:44.958
but it can be used to try to transfer

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
the mentality of sharing

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:50.958
to groups that ordinarily would not be disposed to exercise it.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:54.958
For example, in brotherhoods, fraternal organizations,

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:57.958
sororities, locutions like "the family of man,"

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
you try to get people who are not related

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:03.958
to use the relationship type that would ordinarily

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
be appropriate to close kin.

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:08.958
Now, mismatches -- when one person assumes one relationship type,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
and another assumes a different one -- can be awkward.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
If you went over and you helped yourself

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:15.958
to a shrimp off your boss' plate,

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:17.958
for example, that would be an awkward situation.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
Or if a dinner guest after the meal

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:22.958
pulled out his wallet and offered to pay you for the meal,

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
that would be rather awkward as well.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
In less blatant cases,

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
there's still a kind of negotiation that often goes on.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
In the workplace, for example,

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:34.958
there's often a tension over whether an employee

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
can socialize with the boss,

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:38.958
or refer to him or her

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:40.958
on a first-name basis.

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:42.958
If two friends have a

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
reciprocal transaction, like selling a car,

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
it's well known that this can be a source

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
of tension or awkwardness.

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
In dating, the transition

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
from friendship to sex

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
can lead to, notoriously, various forms of awkwardness,

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
and as can sex in the workplace,

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
in which we call the conflict between a

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:03.958
dominant and a sexual relationship "sexual harassment."

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:05.958
Well, what does this have to do with language?

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
Well, language, as a social interaction,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
has to satisfy two conditions.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
You have to convey the actual content --

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
here we get back to the container metaphor.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
You want to express the bribe, the command, the promise,

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:19.958
the solicitation and so on,

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
but you also have to negotiate

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
and maintain the kind of relationship

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
you have with the other person.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.958
The solution, I think, is that we use language at two levels:

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
the literal form signals

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:32.958
the safest relationship with the listener,

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
whereas the implicated content --

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
the reading between the lines that we count on the listener to perform --

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:40.958
allows the listener to derive the interpretation

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:42.958
which is most relevant in context,

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:45.958
which possibly initiates a changed relationship.

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:49.958
The simplest example of this is in the polite request.

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:52.958
If you express your request as a conditional --

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:55.958
"if you could open the window, that would be great" --

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
even though the content is an imperative,

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
the fact that you're not using the imperative voice

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.958
means that you're not acting as if you're in a relationship of dominance,

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
where you could presuppose the compliance of the other person.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
On the other hand, you want the damn guacamole.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:12.958
By expressing it as an if-then statement,

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
you can get the message across

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:18.958
without appearing to boss another person around.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
And in a more subtle way, I think, this works

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
for all of the veiled speech acts

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:24.958
involving plausible deniability:

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
the bribes, threats, propositions,

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:28.958
solicitations and so on.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
One way of thinking about it is to imagine what it would be like

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:33.958
if language -- where it could only be used literally.

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:35.958
And you can think of it in terms of a

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:38.958
game-theoretic payoff matrix.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
Put yourself in the position of the

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:43.958
kidnapper wanting to bribe the officer.

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:45.958
There's a high stakes

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
in the two possibilities

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
of having a dishonest officer or an honest officer.

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:54.958
If you don't bribe the officer,

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
then you will get a traffic ticket --

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.958
or, as is the case of "Fargo," worse --

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.958
whether the honest officer

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:02.958
is honest or dishonest.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:04.958
Nothing ventured, nothing gained.

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:07.958
In that case, the consequences are rather severe.

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:09.958
On the other hand, if you extend the bribe,

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:11.958
if the officer is dishonest,

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:14.958
you get a huge payoff of going free.

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:17.958
If the officer is honest, you get a huge penalty

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:19.958
of being arrested for bribery.

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:21.958
So this is a rather fraught situation.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
On the other hand, with indirect language,

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
if you issue a veiled bribe,

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:27.958
then the dishonest officer

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
could interpret it as a bribe,

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:32.958
in which case you get the payoff of going free.

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:35.958
The honest officer can't hold you to it as being a bribe,

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:38.958
and therefore, you get the nuisance of the traffic ticket.

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:41.958
So you get the best of both worlds.

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:43.958
And a similar analysis, I think,

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:45.958
can apply to the potential awkwardness

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:47.958
of a sexual solicitation,

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:50.958
and other cases where plausible deniability is an asset.

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:52.958
I think this affirms

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:54.958
something that's long been known by diplomats --

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:56.958
namely, that the vagueness of language,

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:59.958
far from being a bug or an imperfection,

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:02.958
actually might be a feature of language,

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:05.958
one that we use to our advantage in social interactions.

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:08.958
So to sum up: language is a collective human creation,

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:10.958
reflecting human nature,

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:12.958
how we conceptualize reality,

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:14.958
how we relate to one another.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:18.958
And then by analyzing the various quirks and complexities of language,

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:21.958
I think we can get a window onto what makes us tick.

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:22.958
Thank you very much.

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:23.958
(Applause)

title: The surprising decline in violence
transcript: Images like this, from the Auschwitz concentration camp, have been seared into our consciousness during the twentieth century and have given us a new understanding of who we are, where we've come from and the times we live in. During the twentieth century, we witnessed the atrocities of Stalin, Hitler, Mao, Pol Pot, Rwanda and other genocides, and even though the twenty-first century is only seven years old, we have already witnessed an ongoing genocide in Darfur and the daily horrors of Iraq. This has led to a common understanding of our situation, namely that modernity has brought us terrible violence, and perhaps that native peoples lived in a state of harmony that we have departed from, to our peril.Here is an example from an op-ed on Thanksgiving, in the Boston Globe a couple of years ago, where the writer wrote, "The Indian life was a difficult one, but there were no employment problems, community harmony was strong, substance abuse unknown, crime nearly non-existent, what warfare there was between tribes was largely ritualistic and seldom resulted in indiscriminate or wholesale slaughter." Now, you're all familiar with this treacle. We teach it to our children. We hear it on television and in storybooks. Now, the original title of this session was, "Everything You Know Is Wrong," and I'm going to present evidence that this particular part of our common understanding is wrong, that, in fact, our ancestors were far more violent than we are, that violence has been in decline for long stretches of time, and that today we are probably living in the most peaceful time in our species' existence.Now, in the decade of Darfur and Iraq, a statement like that might seem somewhere between hallucinatory and obscene. But I'm going to try to convince you that that is the correct picture. The decline of violence is a fractal phenomenon. You can see it over millennia, over centuries, over decades and over years, although there seems to have been a tipping point at the onset of the Age of Reason in the sixteenth century. One sees it all over the world, although not homogeneously. It's especially evident in the West, beginning with England and Holland around the time of the Enlightenment.Let me take you on a journey of several powers of 10 — from the millennium scale to the year scale — to try to persuade you of this. Until 10,000 years ago, all humans lived as hunter-gatherers, without permanent settlements or government. And this is the state that's commonly thought to be one of primordial harmony. But the archaeologist Lawrence Keeley, looking at casualty rates among contemporary hunter-gatherers, which is our best source of evidence about this way of life, has shown a rather different conclusion.Here is a graph that he put together showing the percentage of male deaths due to warfare in a number of foraging, or hunting and gathering societies. The red bars correspond to the likelihood that a man will die at the hands of another man, as opposed to passing away of natural causes, in a variety of foraging societies in the New Guinea Highlands and the Amazon Rainforest. And they range from a rate of almost a 60 percent chance that a man will die at the hands of another man to, in the case of the Gebusi, only a 15 percent chance. The tiny, little blue bar in the lower left-hand corner plots the corresponding statistic from United States and Europe in the twentieth century, and includes all the deaths of both World Wars. If the death rate in tribal warfare had prevailed during the 20th century, there would have been two billion deaths rather than 100 million.Also at the millennium scale, we can look at the way of life of early civilizations such as the ones described in the Bible. And in this supposed source of our moral values, one can read descriptions of what was expected in warfare, such as the following from Numbers 31: "And they warred against the Midianites as the Lord commanded Moses, and they slew all the males. And Moses said unto them, 'Have you saved all the women alive? Now, therefore, kill every male among the little ones and kill every woman that hath known man by lying with him, but all the women children that have not know a man by lying with him keep alive for yourselves.'" In other words, kill the men; kill the children; if you see any virgins, then you can keep them alive so that you can rape them. You can find four or five passages in the Bible of this ilk. Also in the Bible, one sees that the death penalty was the accepted punishment for crimes such as homosexuality, adultery, blasphemy, idolatry, talking back to your parents — (Laughter) — and picking up sticks on the Sabbath. Well, let's click the zoom lens down one order of magnitude, and look at the century scale. Although we don't have statistics for warfare throughout the Middle Ages to modern times, we know just from conventional history — the evidence was under our nose all along that there has been a reduction in socially sanctioned forms of violence.For example, any social history will reveal that mutilation and torture were routine forms of criminal punishment. The kind of infraction today that would give you a fine, in those days would result in your tongue being cut out, your ears being cut off, you being blinded, a hand being chopped off and so on. There were numerous ingenious forms of sadistic capital punishment: burning at the stake, disemboweling, breaking on the wheel, being pulled apart by horses and so on. The death penalty was a sanction for a long list of non-violent crimes: criticizing the king, stealing a loaf of bread. Slavery, of course, was the preferred labor-saving device, and cruelty was a popular form of entertainment. Perhaps the most vivid example was the practice of cat burning, in which a cat was hoisted on a stage and lowered in a sling into a fire, and the spectators shrieked in laughter as the cat, howling in pain, was burned to death.What about one-on-one murder? Well, there, there are good statistics, because many municipalities recorded the cause of death. The criminologist Manuel Eisner scoured all of the historical records across Europe for homicide rates in any village, hamlet, town, county that he could find, and he supplemented them with national data, when nations started keeping statistics. He plotted on a logarithmic scale, going from 100 deaths per 100,000 people per year, which was approximately the rate of homicide in the Middle Ages. And the figure plummets down to less than one homicide per 100,000 people per year in seven or eight European countries. Then, there is a slight uptick in the 1960s. The people who said that rock 'n' roll would lead to the decline of moral values actually had a grain of truth to that. But there was a decline from at least two orders of magnitude in homicide from the Middle Ages to the present, and the elbow occurred in the early sixteenth century.Let's click down now to the decade scale. According to non-governmental organizations that keep such statistics, since 1945, in Europe and the Americas, there has been a steep decline in interstate wars, in deadly ethnic riots or pogroms, and in military coups, even in South America. Worldwide, there's been a steep decline in deaths in interstate wars. The yellow bars here show the number of deaths per war per year from 1950 to the present. And, as you can see, the death rate goes down from 65,000 deaths per conflict per year in the 1950s to less than 2,000 deaths per conflict per year in this decade, as horrific as it is. Even in the year scale, one can see a decline of violence. Since the end of the Cold War, there have been fewer civil wars, fewer genocides — indeed, a 90 percent reduction since post-World War II highs — and even a reversal of the 1960s uptick in homicide and violent crime. This is from the FBI Uniform Crime Statistics. You can see that there is a fairly low rate of violence in the '50s and the '60s, then it soared upward for several decades, and began a precipitous decline, starting in the 1990s, so that it went back to the level that was last enjoyed in 1960. President Clinton, if you're here, thank you. (Laughter)So the question is, why are so many people so wrong about something so important? I think there are a number of reasons. One of them is we have better reporting. The Associated Press is a better chronicler of wars over the surface of the Earth than sixteenth-century monks were. There's a cognitive illusion. We cognitive psychologists know that the easier it is to recall specific instances of something, the higher the probability that you assign to it. Things that we read about in the paper with gory footage burn into memory more than reports of a lot more people dying in their beds of old age. There are dynamics in the opinion and advocacy markets: no one ever attracted observers, advocates and donors by saying things just seem to be getting better and better. (Laughter)There's guilt about our treatment of native peoples in modern intellectual life, and an unwillingness to acknowledge there could be anything good about Western culture. And of course, our change in standards can outpace the change in behavior. One of the reasons violence went down is that people got sick of the carnage and cruelty in their time. That's a process that seems to be continuing, but if it outstrips behavior by the standards of the day, things always look more barbaric than they would have been by historic standards. So today, we get exercised — and rightly so — if a handful of murderers get executed by lethal injection in Texas after a 15-year appeal process. We don't consider that a couple of hundred years ago, they may have been burned at the stake for criticizing the king after a trial that lasted 10 minutes, and indeed, that that would have been repeated over and over again. Today, we look at capital punishment as evidence of how low our behavior can sink, rather than how high our standards have risen.Well, why has violence declined? No one really knows, but I have read four explanations, all of which, I think, have some grain of plausibility. The first is, maybe Thomas Hobbes got it right. He was the one who said that life in a state of nature was "solitary, poor, nasty, brutish and short." Not because, he argued, humans have some primordial thirst for blood or aggressive instinct or territorial imperative, but because of the logic of anarchy. In a state of anarchy, there's a constant temptation to invade your neighbors preemptively, before they invade you. More recently, Thomas Schelling gives the analogy of a homeowner who hears a rustling in the basement. Being a good American, he has a pistol in the nightstand, pulls out his gun, and walks down the stairs. And what does he see but a burglar with a gun in his hand. Now, each one of them is thinking, "I don't really want to kill that guy, but he's about to kill me. Maybe I had better shoot him, before he shoots me, especially since, even if he doesn't want to kill me, he's probably worrying right now that I might kill him before he kills me." And so on. Hunter-gatherer peoples explicitly go through this train of thought, and will often raid their neighbors out of fear of being raided first.Now, one way of dealing with this problem is by deterrence. You don't strike first, but you have a publicly announced policy that you will retaliate savagely if you are invaded. The only thing is that it's liable to having its bluff called, and therefore can only work if it's credible. To make it credible, you must avenge all insults and settle all scores, which leads to the cycles of bloody vendetta. Life becomes an episode of "The Sopranos." Hobbes' solution, the "Leviathan," was that if authority for the legitimate use of violence was vested in a single democratic agency — a leviathan — then such a state can reduce the temptation of attack, because any kind of aggression will be punished, leaving its profitability as zero. That would remove the temptation to invade preemptively, out of fear of them attacking you first. It removes the need for a hair trigger for retaliation to make your deterrent threat credible. And therefore, it would lead to a state of peace. Eisner — the man who plotted the homicide rates that you failed to see in the earlier slide — argued that the timing of the decline of homicide in Europe coincided with the rise of centralized states. So that's a bit of a support for the leviathan theory. Also supporting it is the fact that we today see eruptions of violence in zones of anarchy, in failed states, collapsed empires, frontier regions, mafias, street gangs and so on.The second explanation is that in many times and places, there is a widespread sentiment that life is cheap. In earlier times, when suffering and early death were common in one's own life, one has fewer compunctions about inflicting them on others. And as technology and economic efficiency make life longer and more pleasant, one puts a higher value on life in general. This was an argument from the political scientist James Payne.A third explanation invokes the concept of a nonzero-sum game, and was worked out in the book "Nonzero" by the journalist Robert Wright. Wright points out that in certain circumstances, cooperation or non-violence can benefit both parties in an interaction, such as gains in trade when two parties trade their surpluses and both come out ahead, or when two parties lay down their arms and split the so-called peace dividend that results in them not having to fight the whole time. Wright argues that technology has increased the number of positive-sum games that humans tend to be embroiled in, by allowing the trade of goods, services and ideas over longer distances and among larger groups of people. The result is that other people become more valuable alive than dead, and violence declines for selfish reasons. As Wright put it, "Among the many reasons that I think that we should not bomb the Japanese is that they built my mini-van." (Laughter)The fourth explanation is captured in the title of a book called "The Expanding Circle," by the philosopher Peter Singer, who argues that evolution bequeathed humans with a sense of empathy, an ability to treat other peoples' interests as comparable to one's own. Unfortunately, by default we apply it only to a very narrow circle of friends and family. People outside that circle are treated as sub-human, and can be exploited with impunity. But, over history, the circle has expanded. One can see, in historical record, it expanding from the village, to the clan, to the tribe, to the nation, to other races, to both sexes, and, in Singer's own arguments, something that we should extend to other sentient species. The question is, if this has happened, what has powered that expansion?And there are a number of possibilities, such as increasing circles of reciprocity in the sense that Robert Wright argues for. The logic of the golden rule — the more you think about and interact with other people, the more you realize that it is untenable to privilege your interests over theirs, at least not if you want them to listen to you. You can't say that my interests are special compared to yours, anymore than you can say that the particular spot that I'm standing on is a unique part of the universe because I happen to be standing on it that very minute. It may also be powered by cosmopolitanism, by histories, and journalism, and memoirs, and realistic fiction, and travel, and literacy, which allows you to project yourself into the lives of other people that formerly you may have treated as sub-human, and also to realize the accidental contingency of your own station in life, the sense that "there but for fortune go I."Whatever its causes, the decline of violence, I think, has profound implications. It should force us to ask not just, why is there war? But also, why is there peace? Not just, what are we doing wrong? But also, what have we been doing right? Because we have been doing something right, and it sure would be good to find out what it is. Thank you very much. (Applause).Chris Anderson: I loved that talk. I think a lot of people here in the room would say that that expansion of — that you were talking about, that Peter Singer talks about, is also driven by, just by technology, by greater visibility of the other, and the sense that the world is therefore getting smaller. I mean, is that also a grain of truth?Steven Pinker: Very much. It would fit both in Wright's theory, that it allows us to enjoy the benefits of cooperation over larger and larger circles. But also, I think it helps us imagine what it's like to be someone else. I think when you read these horrific tortures that were common in the Middle Ages, you think, how could they possibly have done it, how could they have not have empathized with the person that they're disemboweling? But clearly, as far as they're concerned, this is just an alien being that does not have feelings akin to their own. Anything, I think, that makes it easier to imagine trading places with someone else means that it increases your moral consideration to that other person.CA: Well, Steve, I would love every news media owner to hear that talk at some point in the next year. I think it's really important. Thank you so much.SP: My pleasure.
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:15.958
Images like this, from the Auschwitz concentration camp,

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:20.958
have been seared into our consciousness during the twentieth century

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:25.958
and have given us a new understanding of who we are,

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:28.958
where we've come from and the times we live in.

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:32.958
During the twentieth century, we witnessed the atrocities

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:37.958
of Stalin, Hitler, Mao, Pol Pot, Rwanda and other genocides,

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:41.958
and even though the twenty-first century is only seven years old,

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:45.958
we have already witnessed an ongoing genocide in Darfur

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:47.958
and the daily horrors of Iraq.

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:51.958
This has led to a common understanding of our situation,

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:55.958
namely that modernity has brought us terrible violence, and perhaps

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:58.958
that native peoples lived in a state of harmony that we have departed from, to our peril.

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:03.958
Here is an example

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:06.958
from an op-ed on Thanksgiving, in the Boston Globe

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:09.958
a couple of years ago, where the writer wrote, "The Indian life

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:13.958
was a difficult one, but there were no employment problems,

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:15.958
community harmony was strong, substance abuse unknown,

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:19.958
crime nearly non-existent, what warfare there was between tribes

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:23.958
was largely ritualistic and seldom resulted in indiscriminate

00:01:23.958 --> 00:01:27.958
or wholesale slaughter." Now, you're all familiar with this treacle.

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:31.958
We teach it to our children. We hear it on television

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:36.958
and in storybooks. Now, the original title of this session

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:39.958
was, "Everything You Know Is Wrong," and I'm going to present evidence

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:42.958
that this particular part of our common understanding is wrong,

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:46.958
that, in fact, our ancestors were far more violent than we are,

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:49.958
that violence has been in decline for long stretches of time,

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:53.958
and that today we are probably living in the most peaceful time in our species' existence.

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:57.958
Now, in the decade of Darfur and Iraq,

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:01.958
a statement like that might seem somewhere between hallucinatory

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:04.958
and obscene. But I'm going to try to convince you

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:10.958
that that is the correct picture. The decline of violence

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:13.958
is a fractal phenomenon. You can see it over millennia,

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:16.958
over centuries, over decades and over years,

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:19.958
although there seems to have been a tipping point at the onset

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:23.958
of the Age of Reason in the sixteenth century. One sees it

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:26.958
all over the world, although not homogeneously.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:29.958
It's especially evident in the West, beginning with England

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
and Holland around the time of the Enlightenment.

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:36.958
Let me take you on a journey of several powers of 10 --

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:39.958
from the millennium scale to the year scale --

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:43.958
to try to persuade you of this. Until 10,000 years ago, all humans

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:46.958
lived as hunter-gatherers, without permanent settlements

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:49.958
or government. And this is the state that's commonly thought

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:54.958
to be one of primordial harmony. But the archaeologist

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:59.958
Lawrence Keeley, looking at casualty rates

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:02.958
among contemporary hunter-gatherers, which is our best source

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:09.958
of evidence about this way of life, has shown a rather different conclusion.

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:11.958
Here is a graph that he put together

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:14.958
showing the percentage of male deaths due to warfare

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:18.958
in a number of foraging, or hunting and gathering societies.

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:25.958
The red bars correspond to the likelihood that a man will die

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:28.958
at the hands of another man, as opposed to passing away

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:32.958
of natural causes, in a variety of foraging societies

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:35.958
in the New Guinea Highlands and the Amazon Rainforest.

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:39.958
And they range from a rate of almost a 60 percent chance that a man will die

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:42.958
at the hands of another man to, in the case of the Gebusi,

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:47.958
only a 15 percent chance. The tiny, little blue bar in the lower

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:50.958
left-hand corner plots the corresponding statistic from United States

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:55.958
and Europe in the twentieth century, and includes all the deaths

00:03:55.958 --> 00:04:00.958
of both World Wars. If the death rate in tribal warfare had prevailed

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:06.958
during the 20th century, there would have been two billion deaths rather than 100 million.

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:09.958
Also at the millennium scale, we can look

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:14.958
at the way of life of early civilizations such as the ones described

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:19.958
in the Bible. And in this supposed source of our moral values,

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:23.958
one can read descriptions of what was expected in warfare,

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:26.958
such as the following from Numbers 31: "And they warred

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:29.958
against the Midianites as the Lord commanded Moses,

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:32.958
and they slew all the males. And Moses said unto them,

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:36.958
'Have you saved all the women alive? Now, therefore, kill every male

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:39.958
among the little ones and kill every woman that hath known man

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:43.958
by lying with him, but all the women children that have not know a man

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.958
by lying with him keep alive for yourselves.'" In other words,

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:51.958
kill the men; kill the children; if you see any virgins,

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:53.958
then you can keep them alive so that you can rape them.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:58.958
You can find four or five passages in the Bible of this ilk.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:01.958
Also in the Bible, one sees that the death penalty

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:06.958
was the accepted punishment for crimes such as homosexuality,

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:10.958
adultery, blasphemy, idolatry, talking back to your parents --

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:14.958
(Laughter) -- and picking up sticks on the Sabbath.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:17.958
Well, let's click the zoom lens

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:20.958
down one order of magnitude, and look at the century scale.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:24.958
Although we don't have statistics for warfare throughout

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:26.958
the Middle Ages to modern times,

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:29.958
we know just from conventional history -- the evidence

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:33.958
was under our nose all along that there has been a reduction

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:36.958
in socially sanctioned forms of violence.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:40.958
For example, any social history will reveal that mutilation and torture

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:43.958
were routine forms of criminal punishment. The kind of infraction

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:47.958
today that would give you a fine, in those days would result in

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:51.958
your tongue being cut out, your ears being cut off, you being blinded,

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
a hand being chopped off and so on.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:57.958
There were numerous ingenious forms of sadistic capital punishment:

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958
burning at the stake, disemboweling, breaking on the wheel,

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
being pulled apart by horses and so on.

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:08.958
The death penalty was a sanction for a long list of non-violent crimes:

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:12.958
criticizing the king, stealing a loaf of bread. Slavery, of course,

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:16.958
was the preferred labor-saving device, and cruelty was

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:20.958
a popular form of entertainment. Perhaps the most vivid example

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:23.958
was the practice of cat burning, in which a cat was hoisted

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
on a stage and lowered in a sling into a fire,

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:31.958
and the spectators shrieked in laughter as the cat, howling in pain,

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:34.958
was burned to death.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
What about one-on-one murder? Well, there, there are good statistics,

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:43.958
because many municipalities recorded the cause of death.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:47.958
The criminologist Manuel Eisner

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
scoured all of the historical records across Europe

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:55.958
for homicide rates in any village, hamlet, town, county

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
that he could find, and he supplemented them

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:00.958
with national data, when nations started keeping statistics.

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:08.958
He plotted on a logarithmic scale, going from 100 deaths

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:14.958
per 100,000 people per year, which was approximately the rate

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:19.958
of homicide in the Middle Ages. And the figure plummets down

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:23.958
to less than one homicide per 100,000 people per year

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:28.958
in seven or eight European countries. Then, there is a slight uptick

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:32.958
in the 1960s. The people who said that rock 'n' roll would lead

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
to the decline of moral values actually had a grain of truth to that.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:39.958
But there was a decline from at least two orders of magnitude

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
in homicide from the Middle Ages to the present,

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:46.958
and the elbow occurred in the early sixteenth century.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
Let's click down now to the decade scale.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
According to non-governmental organizations

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:57.958
that keep such statistics, since 1945, in Europe and the Americas,

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:00.958
there has been a steep decline in interstate wars,

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:05.958
in deadly ethnic riots or pogroms, and in military coups,

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:09.958
even in South America. Worldwide, there's been a steep decline

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:14.958
in deaths in interstate wars. The yellow bars here show the number

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:19.958
of deaths per war per year from 1950 to the present.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:24.958
And, as you can see, the death rate goes down from 65,000 deaths

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:28.958
per conflict per year in the 1950s to less than 2,000 deaths

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:32.958
per conflict per year in this decade, as horrific as it is.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:35.958
Even in the year scale, one can see a decline of violence.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
Since the end of the Cold War, there have been fewer civil wars,

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:45.958
fewer genocides -- indeed, a 90 percent reduction since post-World War II highs --

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:51.958
and even a reversal of the 1960s uptick in homicide and violent crime.

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:55.958
This is from the FBI Uniform Crime Statistics. You can see

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:58.958
that there is a fairly low rate of violence in the '50s and the '60s,

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:03.958
then it soared upward for several decades, and began

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:07.958
a precipitous decline, starting in the 1990s, so that it went back

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:11.958
to the level that was last enjoyed in 1960.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
President Clinton, if you're here, thank you.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
(Laughter)

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:18.958
So the question is, why are so many people so wrong

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:22.958
about something so important? I think there are a number of reasons.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:25.958
One of them is we have better reporting. The Associated Press

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:29.958
is a better chronicler of wars over the surface of the Earth

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:33.958
than sixteenth-century monks were.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:38.958
There's a cognitive illusion. We cognitive psychologists know that the easier it is

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
to recall specific instances of something,

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:44.958
the higher the probability that you assign to it.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
Things that we read about in the paper with gory footage

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:52.958
burn into memory more than reports of a lot more people dying

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:57.958
in their beds of old age. There are dynamics in the opinion

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:03.958
and advocacy markets: no one ever attracted observers, advocates

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:04.958
and donors by saying

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
things just seem to be getting better and better.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:08.958
(Laughter)

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:10.958
There's guilt about our treatment of native peoples

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
in modern intellectual life, and an unwillingness to acknowledge

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
there could be anything good about Western culture.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:21.958
And of course, our change in standards can outpace the change

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
in behavior. One of the reasons violence went down

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:28.958
is that people got sick of the carnage and cruelty in their time.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:31.958
That's a process that seems to be continuing,

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:35.958
but if it outstrips behavior by the standards of the day,

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:38.958
things always look more barbaric than they would have been

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:42.958
by historic standards. So today, we get exercised -- and rightly so --

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:48.958
if a handful of murderers get executed by lethal injection

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:52.958
in Texas after a 15-year appeal process. We don't consider

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
that a couple of hundred years ago, they may have been burned

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:59.958
at the stake for criticizing the king after a trial

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.958
that lasted 10 minutes, and indeed, that that would have been repeated

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:06.958
over and over again. Today, we look at capital punishment

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:10.958
as evidence of how low our behavior can sink,

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
rather than how high our standards have risen.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
Well, why has violence declined? No one really knows,

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:21.958
but I have read four explanations, all of which, I think,

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.958
have some grain of plausibility. The first is, maybe

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:28.958
Thomas Hobbes got it right. He was the one who said

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:33.958
that life in a state of nature was "solitary, poor, nasty, brutish

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:37.958
and short." Not because, he argued,

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:40.958
humans have some primordial thirst for blood

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:43.958
or aggressive instinct or territorial imperative,

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:47.958
but because of the logic of anarchy. In a state of anarchy,

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:51.958
there's a constant temptation to invade your neighbors preemptively,

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:54.958
before they invade you. More recently, Thomas Schelling

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
gives the analogy of a homeowner who hears a rustling

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
in the basement. Being a good American, he has a pistol

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:02.958
in the nightstand, pulls out his gun, and walks down the stairs.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
And what does he see but a burglar with a gun in his hand.

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:07.958
Now, each one of them is thinking,

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:11.958
"I don't really want to kill that guy, but he's about to kill me.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:15.958
Maybe I had better shoot him, before he shoots me,

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
especially since, even if he doesn't want to kill me,

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:20.958
he's probably worrying right now that I might kill him

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
before he kills me." And so on.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:27.958
Hunter-gatherer peoples explicitly go through this train of thought,

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.958
and will often raid their neighbors out of fear of being raided first.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:36.958
Now, one way of dealing with this problem is by deterrence.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:41.958
You don't strike first, but you have a publicly announced policy

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
that you will retaliate savagely if you are invaded.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
The only thing is that it's

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:50.958
liable to having its bluff called, and therefore can only work

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:55.958
if it's credible. To make it credible, you must avenge all insults

00:12:56.958 --> 00:13:00.958
and settle all scores, which leads to the cycles of bloody vendetta.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:05.958
Life becomes an episode of "The Sopranos." Hobbes' solution,

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:09.958
the "Leviathan," was that if authority for the legitimate use

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:14.958
of violence was vested in a single democratic agency -- a leviathan --

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:18.958
then such a state can reduce the temptation of attack,

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:21.958
because any kind of aggression will be punished,

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:26.958
leaving its profitability as zero. That would remove the temptation

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:30.958
to invade preemptively, out of fear of them attacking you first.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:34.958
It removes the need for a hair trigger for retaliation

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:37.958
to make your deterrent threat credible. And therefore, it would lead

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:43.958
to a state of peace. Eisner -- the man who plotted the homicide rates

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:45.958
that you failed to see in the earlier slide --

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:49.958
argued that the timing of the decline of homicide in Europe

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:54.958
coincided with the rise of centralized states.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:57.958
So that's a bit of a support for the leviathan theory.

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:01.958
Also supporting it is the fact that we today see eruptions of violence

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:05.958
in zones of anarchy, in failed states, collapsed empires,

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:09.958
frontier regions, mafias, street gangs and so on.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:14.958
The second explanation is that in many times and places,

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
there is a widespread sentiment that life is cheap.

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:22.958
In earlier times, when suffering and early death were common

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:26.958
in one's own life, one has fewer compunctions about inflicting them

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:30.958
on others. And as technology and economic efficiency make life

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:34.958
longer and more pleasant, one puts a higher value on life in general.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
This was an argument from the political scientist James Payne.

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:42.958
A third explanation invokes the concept of a nonzero-sum game,

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:46.958
and was worked out in the book "Nonzero" by the journalist

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:49.958
Robert Wright. Wright points out that in certain circumstances,

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:53.958
cooperation or non-violence can benefit both parties

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:59.958
in an interaction, such as gains in trade when two parties trade

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:03.958
their surpluses and both come out ahead, or when two parties

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:06.958
lay down their arms and split the so-called peace dividend

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
that results in them not having to fight the whole time.

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
Wright argues that technology has increased the number

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:16.958
of positive-sum games that humans tend to be embroiled in,

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
by allowing the trade of goods, services and ideas

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.958
over longer distances and among larger groups of people.

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:27.958
The result is that other people become more valuable alive than dead,

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:32.958
and violence declines for selfish reasons. As Wright put it,

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:35.958
"Among the many reasons that I think that we should not bomb

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:38.958
the Japanese is that they built my mini-van."

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
(Laughter)

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:44.958
The fourth explanation is captured in the title of a book

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:47.958
called "The Expanding Circle," by the philosopher Peter Singer,

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
who argues that evolution bequeathed humans with a sense

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:56.958
of empathy, an ability to treat other peoples' interests

00:15:56.958 --> 00:16:00.958
as comparable to one's own. Unfortunately, by default

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:04.958
we apply it only to a very narrow circle of friends and family.

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:07.958
People outside that circle are treated as sub-human,

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:11.958
and can be exploited with impunity. But, over history,

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:15.958
the circle has expanded. One can see, in historical record,

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:18.958
it expanding from the village, to the clan, to the tribe,

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:22.958
to the nation, to other races, to both sexes,

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:24.958
and, in Singer's own arguments, something that we should extend

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:29.958
to other sentient species. The question is,

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:32.958
if this has happened, what has powered that expansion?

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:35.958
And there are a number of possibilities, such as increasing circles

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:39.958
of reciprocity in the sense that Robert Wright argues for.

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:44.958
The logic of the golden rule -- the more you think about and interact

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:48.958
with other people, the more you realize that it is untenable

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:52.958
to privilege your interests over theirs,

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:55.958
at least not if you want them to listen to you. You can't say

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:58.958
that my interests are special compared to yours,

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:00.958
anymore than you can say that the particular spot

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:03.958
that I'm standing on is a unique part of the universe

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:06.958
because I happen to be standing on it that very minute.

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:11.958
It may also be powered by cosmopolitanism, by histories,

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:15.958
and journalism, and memoirs, and realistic fiction, and travel,

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:19.958
and literacy, which allows you to project yourself into the lives

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:23.958
of other people that formerly you may have treated as sub-human,

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:27.958
and also to realize the accidental contingency of your own station

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:30.958
in life, the sense that "there but for fortune go I."

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:35.958
Whatever its causes, the decline of violence, I think,

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:39.958
has profound implications. It should force us to ask not just, why

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:43.958
is there war? But also, why is there peace? Not just,

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:47.958
what are we doing wrong? But also, what have we been doing right?

00:17:48.958 --> 00:17:49.958
Because we have been doing something right,

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:52.958
and it sure would be good to find out what it is.

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:53.958
Thank you very much.

00:17:53.958 --> 00:18:04.958
(Applause).

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:08.958
Chris Anderson: I loved that talk. I think a lot of people here in the room would say

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:11.958
that that expansion of -- that you were talking about,

00:18:11.958 --> 00:18:14.958
that Peter Singer talks about, is also driven by, just by technology,

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:18.958
by greater visibility of the other, and the sense that the world

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:21.958
is therefore getting smaller. I mean, is that also a grain of truth?

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:25.958
Steven Pinker: Very much. It would fit both in Wright's theory,

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:29.958
that it allows us to enjoy the benefits of cooperation

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:33.958
over larger and larger circles. But also, I think it helps us

00:18:35.958 --> 00:18:38.958
imagine what it's like to be someone else. I think when you read

00:18:38.958 --> 00:18:41.958
these horrific tortures that were common in the Middle Ages, you think,

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:43.958
how could they possibly have done it,

00:18:43.958 --> 00:18:45.958
how could they have not have empathized with the person

00:18:46.958 --> 00:18:48.958
that they're disemboweling? But clearly,

00:18:49.958 --> 00:18:52.958
as far as they're concerned, this is just an alien being

00:18:52.958 --> 00:18:55.958
that does not have feelings akin to their own. Anything, I think,

00:18:55.958 --> 00:18:57.958
that makes it easier to imagine trading places

00:18:58.958 --> 00:19:01.958
with someone else means that it increases your moral consideration

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:02.958
to that other person.

00:19:02.958 --> 00:19:06.958
CA: Well, Steve, I would love every news media owner to hear that talk

00:19:06.958 --> 00:19:08.958
at some point in the next year. I think it's really important. Thank you so much.

00:19:08.958 --> 00:19:09.958
SP: My pleasure.

title: An Iraq war movie crowd-sourced from soldiers
transcript: Three years ago, I got a phone call, based on an earlier film I had made, with an offer to embed the New Hampshire National Guard. My idea — and literally, I woke up in the middle of the night, and we've all have those moments. You know, you go to sleep — I was excited, with this phone call. I was thinking, I just finished making another film about World War II vets, and I realized I'd gotten to know their stories, and I realized this was a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to tell a warrior's story as it unfolded. So I went to bed that night pretty excited. Not sure of all the details, but excited. It wasn't at four in the morning, but it was closer to midnight. Woke straight up. Wide-awake as could be. And I had this idea: what if I could, in effect, virtually embed, and create a permeable relationship with the soldiers? To tell the story from the inside out, versus the outside in?So, I called back Major Heilshorn, who's the public affairs officer of the New Hampshire National Guard. And he knew me, so I was like, "Greg?" He's like, "Yes, Deborah?" Told him my idea, and you know, he is one of the bravest men in the world, as is General Blair, who, in the end, gave me permission to try this experiment.Within 10 days, I was down at Fort Dix. He gave me my pick of units. I picked one unit — Charlie Company, Third of the 172nd, they're mountain infantry — for two reasons. One, they're infantry. Number two, they were going to be based at LSA Anaconda, so I knew they would have Internet access. The caveat for my access was I had to get the soldiers to volunteer. This was a big thing that I think when Major H told me, I wasn't really totally gathering what that would mean.So what that meant was, when I went down to Fort Dix, I had to hop out in front of 180 guys and tell them of my vision. You can imagine the hailstorm of questions I got. The opening one was, "What the fuck do you know about the National Guard?" I started with the 1607 Massachusetts Bay Colony Pequot Indian Wars. Gave them about a nine minute response, and there we went.So, I'd like to show the clip of the film. It's our trailer, because I know, obviously you guys are busy, many of you may not have had a chance to see it. So, I want to show the trailer, and then I'm going to take apart one scene in detail. If we could roll?(Video) Stephen Pink: This is Sergeant Stephen Pink.Michael Moriarty: Specialist Michael Moriarty.Zack Bazzi: Do I really want to go? Probably not.Soldier: We're not supposed to talk to the media.SP: I'm not the media, dammit!MM: The day is here. Life will change.Voice: The real deal, man! Narrator: You ready? Soldier: Bring it on! Narrator: You ready? Voice 2: Iraq, here we come!ZB: Every soldier eventually wants to go in combat. It's natural instinct.SP: If you let fear get to you, then you're not going to be doing your job.MM: Every single time you go out there, there's attacks. It's unbelievable.ZB: Hey, Nestor, your ass crack is right in my face.Soldiers: IV! Are we on fire? IV! Man down! Man down!MM: Keep going, brother. You wanna play?Michael Moriarty's Wife: It's really hard for him to not have his dad.MM: This little kid is in the middle of a war zone.Stephen Pink's Girlfriend: In the beginning, he's like, "Write something dirty!"George W. Bush: The world's newest democracy.MM: They're shooting at me.SP: You don't put 150,000 troops in there, and say we're there to create democracy.Soldier: We've got a drive through window at Burger King now.SP: We're here to create money.MM: I support George Bush. We're not there for the oil.Jon Baril: The worst thing in my life.SP: Baril, don't look at it, bud.Michael Moriarty's Wife: He's not the same person anymore.MM: I will not go back.Kevin Shangraw: The Iraqi people are who we are there to help — and we just killed one.Soldiers: Sergeant Smith is down! Sergeant Smith is down? There they are! Right there! Fire, fire!JB: It'll be a better country in 20 years, 'cause we were there. I hope.(Applause) Deborah Scranton: Thank you. One of the things I'd like to talk to you about is having a conversation about something that is difficult to talk about. And I'd like to relate an experience I had here at TED. I don't know how many of you might imagine it, but there's actually a TEDster who recently got back from Iraq. Paul? Come on, stand up. This is Paul Anthony. He served — (Applause) — with the Marines, and I want to tell you a little, brief story. We were one of the lucky ones to get in the class with the Sony cameras and the Vista software. Right? And we started talking. People will see my tag, and they'll see "The War Tapes," and then we'll start talking about war.We got in a conversation with some other people in the class, and it went on and on. I mean, we were there for an hour, talking. And it really highlighted something that I would like to ask you guys to think about and hopefully to help with, which is, I think a lot of us are very afraid to have conversations about war, and about politics. And really — because maybe we're going to disagree. Maybe it's going to get uncomfortable. How do we open it up to really be able to have a conversation? And you know, Paul was talking, and he then turned to Constance and said, "You know, I wouldn't have this conversation if she weren't here, because I know she has my back."And I want to say, I was nervous. Because I'm used to doing Q&As. I really related to what James was saying yesterday, because I'm behind the camera. You know, I can answer questions about my movie, but for me to come up and talk for 18 minutes is a really long time. So, I wanted to say, Paul, I'm happy you're here, because I know you have my back.This film was not about the Internet, but it could not have been made without it. The guys' tapes on average took two weeks to get from Iraq to me. In the meantime, the soldiers — we would email and IM. I didn't save all of them, because I didn't realize at the beginning that it would be something that I would want to keep track of. But there were 3,211 emails and IMs and text messages that I was able to save. The reason I quantify that is because we really embarked on this as a mutual journey to really get inside of it. So I wanted to show you a clip, and then I was going tell you a little bit of how it got put together. If we could roll the clip.(Video) SP: Today is sport. [Unclear] Radio: [Unclear] Christian soldiers. SP: We like to give these insurgents a fair chance. So, what we do, we ride with the windows down. Because, you know, we obviously have the advantage. I'm just kidding. We don't fucking ride with the goddam windows down. It's not true. Very unsafe. Whoa.Soldier: Right there.SP: All right, let's get over to that site. Be advised, we're leaving Taji right now. We believe that the blast was right outside the gate of Taji, we're heading to that location now.Soldier: That's a fucking car bomb!Soldier: Motherfuckers!Soldiers: Get your vest on! Hey, get over the fucking — yeah, yeah. Any one-four elements get to the gate!SP: Sheriff one-six, or any one-four elements, we need you at the gate of Taji right now, over.Soldier: I'll walk you through it. (Voices)SP: Stay low. Head over to the right. Get your bag, get your bag! (Screams)SP: It was mass casualties. Probably 20 dead, at least 20 or 30 wounded Iraqis.SP: It just looked like, you know, someone had thrown a quarter through a guy, and it was just like — there was no blood coming from the shrapnel wounds. Everything was cauterized, and it was just like there was a void going through the body. This is the scene north. They just removed a burnt body, or half a body from here. I don't think there was anything left from his abdominal down. This is blood. And you know, you walk, and you hear the pieces of skin. And that's it, that's all that's left. I remember giving three IVs, bandaging several wounded. Soldiers sitting in the corner of a sandbag wall, shaking and screaming. Medics who were terrified and couldn't perform. I later heard that Iraqi casualties were not to be treated in Taji. They can work on the post for pennies, but can't die there. They've got to die outside. If one of those incompetent medical officers told me to stop treatment, I would've slit his throat right there. 21:00 hours, and it's just our squad going through today's events in our heads, whether we want to or not.News Anchor: More violence in Iraq. Twin suicide car bombings killed eight Iraqis and wounded dozens more near a coalition base north of Baghdad.SP: We made the news. I feel exploited and proud at the same time. I've lost all faith in the media — a hapless joke I would much rather laugh at than become a part of. I should really thank God for saving my lucky ass. I'll do that, then I'm gonna jerk off. Because these pages smell like Linds, and there won't be any time for jerking off tomorrow. Another mission at 06:00.DS: Now — (Applause) — thanks. When I said earlier, to try and tell a story from the inside out, versus the outside in — part of what Chris said so eloquently in his introduction — is this melding. It's a new way of trying to make a documentary. When I met the guys, and 10 of them agreed to take cameras — in total, 21 ended up filming. Five soldiers filmed the entire time. There are three featured in the film.The way I learned about Taji was Steve Pink sent me an email, and in it, attached a photo of that burned body out at the car. And the tone from the email was, you know, it had been a very bad day, obviously. And I saw in my IM window that Mike Moriarty was at the base. So, I pinged Mike and I said, "Mike, can you please go get that interview with Pink?" Because the thing that very often is missing is, in the military what they call "hot wash." It's that immediate interview after something immediately happens, you know. And if you let time go by, it kind of softens and smooths the edges. And for me, I really wanted that.So, in order to get the intimacy, to share that experience with you, the guys — the two most popular mounts — there was a camera on the turret, the gun turret, and then on the dashboard of the Humvee. Most of the Humvees, we ended up mounting two cameras in them. So you get to experience that in real time, right? The interview that you see is the one that Mike went and did within 24 hours of that episode happening.Steve Pink reading his journal happened five months after he came home. I knew about that journal, but it was very, very private. And you know, you earn someone's trust, especially in doc filmmaking, through your relationship. So, it wasn't until five months after he was home that he would read that journal.Now, the news footage I put in there to try to show — you know, I think mainstream media tries to do the best they can in the format that they have. But the thing that I know you all have heard a lot of times, American soldiers saying, "Why don't they talk about the good stuff that we do?" OK, this is a perfect example. Pink's squad and another squad spent their entire day outside the wire. They didn't have to go outside the wire. There were not Americans hurt out there. They spent their entire day outside the wire trying to save Iraqi lives — the Iraqis who work on the post. So, when you may hear soldiers complaining, that's what they're talking about, you know? And I think it's such an amazing gift that they would share this as a way of bridging.And when I talk about that polarity I get at so many different Q&As, and people are really opinionated. But it seems like people don't want to hear so much, or listen, or try to have an exchange. And I'm as fiery as the next person, but I really think — you know, different speakers have talked about their concern for the world, and my concern is that we have to have these conversations. And we have to be able to go into scary places where we may, you know, we think we know. But we just have to leave that little bit of openness, to know. There's such a disconnect. And for me, it's trying to bridge that disconnect. I'll share one story. I get — I'm often asked, you know, for me, what have been some of the special moments from having worked on this film. And at screenings, inevitably — you know, as I'm sure all of you obviously do speaking stuff — usually you have people who hang around and want to ask you more questions. And usually, the first questions are, "Oh, what kind of cameras did you use?" Or you know, these things.But there's always a few guys, almost always, who are the last ones. And I've learned over time that those are always the soldiers. And they wait until pretty much everybody's gone. And for me, one of the most profound stories someone shared with me, that then became my story, was — for those of you who haven't seen the film, and it's not a spoiler — it's very common there are a lot of civilian accidents, where people get in front of Humvees and they get killed. In this film, there is a scene where an Iraqi woman is killed. A soldier came up to me and stood, you know really, pretty close, a foot away from me. He's a big guy. And he looked at me, and I smiled, and then I saw the tears start welling up in his eyes. And he wasn't going to blink. And he said, "My gunner was throwing candy." And I knew what he was going to say. The gunner was throwing candy. They used to throw candy to the kids. Kids got too close, very often. And he said, "I killed a child. And I'm a father. I have children. I haven't been able to tell my wife. I'm afraid she's going to think I'm a monster." I hugged him, of course, and I said, you know, "It's going to be OK." And he said, "I'm going to bring her to see your film. And then I'm going to tell her."So when I talk about a disconnect, it's not only for maybe those people who don't know a soldier, which there obviously are. You know, these days, it's not like World War II, where there was a war front and a home front, and everybody seemed involved. You can go for days here and not feel like there's a war going on. And often, I'll hear people say, who maybe know that I did this film, and they say, "Oh, you know, I'm against the war, but I support the soldiers." And I've started to ask them, "Well, that's nice. What are you doing? Are you volunteering at a VA? You go and see anybody? Do you, if you find out your neighbor's been, do you spend some time? Not necessarily ask questions, but see if they want to talk? Do you give money to any of the charities?" You know, obviously, like Dean Kamen's working on that amazing thing, but there's charities where you can sponsor computers for wounded soldiers.I think, I challenge us to say — to operationalize those terms, when we say we support someone, you know? Are you a friend to them? Do you really care? And I would just say it's my hope, and I would ask you guys to please, you know, reach out a hand. And really do give them a hug. Thank you.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:26.958

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:29.958
It's that immediate interview after something immediately happens, you know.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
And if you let time go by,

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.958

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:41.958

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:52.958

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:56.958

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:24.958

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:28.958
you know, I think mainstream media tries to do the best they can

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
in the format that they have.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
American soldiers saying,

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:45.958

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:47.958

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:52.958

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:57.958

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
that's what they're talking about, you know?

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:03.958

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:10.958

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:24.958

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
and my concern is that we have to have these conversations.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:31.958

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
we think we know.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:37.958

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
There's such a disconnect.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:44.958
And for me, it's trying to bridge that disconnect.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
I'll share one story.

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
I get -- I'm often asked, you know, for me,

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:52.958
what have been some of the special moments from having worked on this film.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
And at screenings, inevitably --

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:58.958
you know, as I'm sure all of you obviously do speaking stuff --

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:02.958
usually you have people who hang around and want to ask you more questions.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:04.958
