Somewhere in the Amazon forest is the marginal tree. You cut down that tree, the rain forest collapses as an ecosystem. There's really a tree like that out there. That's really what it comes to. And when that ecosystem collapses, it could take a major ecosystem with it, like our atmosphere. So, what do we do about this? What are the solutions?There is some modeling of ecosystems going on now. The problem with ecosystems is that we understand them so poorly, that we don't know they're really in trouble until it's almost too late. We need to know earlier that they're getting in trouble, and we need to be able to pump possible solutions into models. And with the kind of computing power we have now, there is, as I say, some of this going on, but it needs money. National Science Foundation needs to say — you know, almost all the money that's spent on science in this country comes from the federal government, one way or another. And they get to prioritize, you know? There are people at the National Science Foundation who get to say, this is the most important thing. This is one of the things they ought to be thinking more about.Secondly, we need to create huge biodiversity reserves on the planet, and start moving them around. There's been an experiment for the last four or five years on the Georges Bank, or the Grand Banks off of Newfoundland. It's a no-take fishing zone. They can't fish there for a radius of 200 miles. And an amazing thing has happened: almost all the fish have come back, and they're reproducing like crazy. We're going to have to start doing this around the globe. We're going to have to have no-take zones. We're going to have to say, no more logging in the Amazon for 20 years. Let it recover, before we start logging again. (Applause)Number seven: particle accelerator mishap. You all remember Ted Kaczynski, the Unabomber? One of the things he raved about was that a particle accelerator experiment could go haywire and set off a chain reaction that would destroy the world. A lot of very sober-minded physicists, believe it or not, have had exactly the same thought. This spring — there's a collider at Brookhaven, on Long Island — this spring, it's going to have an experiment in which it creates black holes. They are expecting to create little, tiny black holes. They expect them to evaporate. (Laughter) I hope they're right. (Laughter)Other collider experiments — there's one that's going to take place next summer at CERN — have the possibility of creating something called strangelets, which are kind of like antimatter. Whenever they hit other matter, they destroy it and obliterate it. Most physicists say that the accelerators we have now are not really powerful enough to create black holes and strangelets that we need to worry about, and they're probably right. But, all around the world, in Japan, in Canada, there's talk about this, of reviving this in the United States. We shut one down that was going to be big. But there's talk of building very big accelerators. What can we do about this? What are the solutions?We've got the fox watching the henhouse here. We need to — we need the advice of particle physicists to talk about particle physics and what should be done in particle physics, but we need some outside thinking and watchdogging of what's going on with these experiments.Secondly, we have a natural laboratory surrounding the Earth. We have an electromagnetic field around the Earth, and it's constantly bombarded by high-energy particles, like protons. And in my opinion, we don't spend enough time looking at that natural laboratory and figuring out first what's safe to do on Earth.Number six: biotech disaster. It's one of my favorite ones, because we've done several stories on Bt corn. Bt corn is a corn that creates its own pesticide to kill a corn borer. You may of heard of it — heard it called StarLink, especially when all those taco shells were taken out of the supermarkets about a year and a half ago. This stuff was supposed to only be feed for animals in the United States, and it got into the human food supply, and somebody should've figured out that it would get in the human food supply very easily. But the thing that's alarming is a couple of months ago, in Mexico, where Bt corn and all genetically altered corn is totally illegal, they found Bt corn genes in wild corn plants. Now, corn originated, we think, in Mexico. This is the genetic biodiversity storehouse of corn. This brings back a skepticism that has gone away recently, that superweeds and superpests could spread around the world, from biotechnology, that literally could destroy the world's food supply in very short order.So, what do we do about that? We treat biotechnology with the same scrutiny we apply to nuclear power plants. It's that simple. This is an amazingly unregulated field. When the StarLink disaster happened, there was a battle between the EPA and the FDA over who really had authority, and over what parts of this, and they didn't get it straightened out for months. That's kind of crazy.Number five, one of my favorites: reversal of the Earth's magnetic field. Believe it or not, this happens every few hundred thousand years, and has happened many times in our history. North Pole goes to the South, South Pole goes to the North, and vice versa. But what happens, as this occurs, is that we lose our magnetic field around the Earth over the period of about 100 years, and that means that all these cosmic rays and particles that are to come streaming at us from the sun, that this field protects us from, are — well, basically, we're gonna fry. (Laughter)(Voice: Steve, I have some additional hats downstairs.)SP: So, what can we do about this? Oh, by the way, we're overdue. It's been 780,000 years since this happened. So, it should have happened about 480,000 years ago. Oh, and here's one other thing. Scientists think now our magnetic field may be diminished by about five percent. So, maybe we're in the throes of it. One of the problems of trying to figure out how healthy the Earth is, is that we have — you know, we don't have good weather data from 60 years ago, much less data on things like the ozone layer.So, there's a fairly simple solution to this. There's going to be a lot of cheap rocketry that's going to come online in about six or seven years that gets us into the low atmosphere very cheaply. You know, we can make ozone from car tailpipes. It's not hard: it's just three oxygen atoms. If you brought the entire ozone layer down to the surface of the Earth, it would be the thickness of two pennies, at 14 pounds per square inch. You don't need that much up there. We need to learn how to repair and replenish the Earth's ozone layer. (Applause)Number four: giant solar flares. Solar flares are enormous magnetic outbursts from the Sun that bombard the Earth with high-speed subatomic particles. So far, our atmosphere has done, and our magnetic field has done pretty well protecting us from this. Occasionally, we get a flare from the Sun that causes havoc with communications and so forth, and electricity. But the alarming thing is that astronomers recently have been studying stars that are similar to our Sun, and they've found that a number of them, when they're about the age of our Sun, brighten by a factor of as much as 20. Doesn't last for very long. And they think these are super-flares, millions of times more powerful than any flares we've had from our Sun so far.Obviously, we don't want one of those. (Laughter) There's a flip side to it. In studying stars like our Sun, we've found that they go through periods of diminishment, when their total amount of energy that's expelled from them goes down by maybe one percent. One percent doesn't sound like a lot, but it would cause one hell of an ice age here. So, what can we do about this?(Laughter) Start terraforming Mars. This is one of my favorite subjects. I wrote a story about this in Life magazine in 1993. This is rocket science, but it's not hard rocket science. Everything that we need to make an atmosphere on Mars, and to make a livable planet on Mars, is probably there. And you just, literally, have to send little nuclear factories up there that gobble up the iron oxide on the surface of Mars and spit out the oxygen. The problem is it takes 300 years to terraform Mars, minimum. Really more like 500 years to do it right. There's no reason why we shouldn't start now. (Laughter)Number three — isn't this stuff cool? (Laughter) A new global epidemic. People have been at war with germs ever since there have been people, and from time to time, the germs sure get the upper hand. In 1918, we had a flu epidemic in the United States that killed 20 million people. That was back when the population was around 100 million people. The bubonic plague in Europe, in the Middle Ages, killed one out of four Europeans. AIDS is coming back. Ebola seems to be rearing its head with much too much frequency, and old diseases like cholera are becoming resistant to antibiotics. We've all learned what — the kind of panic that can occur when an old disease rears its head, like anthrax.The worst possibility is that a very simple germ, like staph, for which we have one antibiotic that still works, mutates. And we know staph can do amazing things. A staph cell can be next to a muscle cell in your body and borrow genes from it when antibiotics come, and change and mutate. The danger is that some germ like staph will be — will mutate into something that's really virulent, very contagious, and will sweep through populations before we can do anything about it. That's happened before. About 12,000 years ago, there was a massive wave of mammal extinctions in the Americas, and that is thought to have been a virulent disease. So, what can we do about it?It is nuts. We give antibiotics — (Applause) — every cow, every lamb, every chicken, they get antibiotics every day, all. You know, you go to a restaurant, you eat fish, I got news for you, it's all farmed. You know, you gotta ask when you go to a restaurant if it's a wild fish, cause they're not going to tell you. We're giving away the code. This is like being at war and giving somebody your secret code. We're telling the germs out there how to fight us. We gotta fix that. We gotta outlaw that right away.Secondly, our public health system, as we saw with anthrax, is a real disaster. We have a real, major outbreak of disease in the United States, we are not prepared to cope with it. Now, there is money in the federal budget, next year, to build up the public health service. But I don't think to any extent that it really needs to be done.Number two — my favorite — we meet a rogue black hole. You know, 10 years ago, or 15 years ago, really, you walk into an astronomy convention, and you say, "You know, there's probably a black hole at the center of every galaxy," and they're going to hoot you off the stage. And now, if you went into one of those conventions and you said, "Well, I don't think black holes are out there," they'd hoot you off the stage. Our comprehension of the way the universe works is really — has just gained unbelievably in recent years.We think that there are about 10 million dead stars in the Milky Way alone, our galaxy. And these stars have compressed down to maybe something like 12, 15 miles wide, and they are black holes. And they are gobbling up everything around them, including light, which is why we can't see them. Most of them should be in orbit around something. But galaxies are very violent places, and things can be spun out of orbit. And also, space is incredibly vast. So even if you flung a million of these things out of orbit, the chances that one would actually hit us is fairly remote. But it only has to get close, about a billion miles away, one of these things. About a billion miles away, here's what happens to Earth's orbit: it becomes elliptical instead of circular. And for three months out of the year, the surface temperatures go up to 150 to 180. For three months out of the year, they go to 50 below zero. That won't work too well. What can we do about this? And this is my scariest. (Laughter) I don't have a good answer for this one. Again, we gotta think about being a colonizing race.And finally, number one: biggest danger to life as we know it, I think, a really big asteroid heads for Earth. The important thing to remember here — this is not a question of if, this is a question of when, and how big. In 1908, just a 200-foot piece of a comet exploded over Siberia and flattened forests for maybe 100 miles. It had the effect of about 1,000 Hiroshima bombs. Astronomers estimate that little asteroids like that come about every hundred years. In 1989, a large asteroid passed 400,000 miles away from Earth.Nothing to worry about, right? It passed directly through Earth's orbit. We were in that that spot six hours earlier. A small asteroid, say a half mile wide, would touch off firestorms followed by severe global cooling from the debris kicked up — Carl Sagan's nuclear winter thing. An asteroid five miles wide causes major extinctions. We think the one that got the dinosaurs was about five miles wide. Where are they? There's something called the Kuiper belt, which — some people think Pluto's not a planet, that's where Pluto is, it's in the Kuiper belt. There's also something a little farther out, called the Oort cloud. There are about 100,000 balls of ice and rock — comets, really — out there, that are 50 miles in diameter or more, and they regularly take a little spin, in towards the Sun and pass reasonably close to us. Of more concern, I think, is the asteroids that exist between Mars and Jupiter. The folks at the Sloan Digital Sky Survey told us last fall — they're making the first map of the universe, three-dimensional map of the universe — that there are probably 700,000 asteroids between Mars and Jupiter that are a half a mile big or bigger. So you say, yeah, well, what are really the chances of this happening? Andrew, can you put that chart up?This is a chart that Dr. Clark Chapman at the Southwest Research Institute presented to Congress a few years ago. You'll notice that the chance of an asteroid-slash-comet impact killing you is about one in 20,000, according to the work they've done. Now look at the one right below that. Passenger aircraft crash, one in 20,000. We spend an awful lot of money trying to be sure that we don't die in airplane accidents, and we're not spending hardly anything on this. And yet, this is completely preventable. We finally have, just in the last year, the technology to stop this cold. Could we have the solutions?NASA's spending three million dollars a year, three million bucks — that is like pocket change — to search for asteroids. Because we can actually figure out every asteroid that's out there, and if it might hit Earth, and when it might hit Earth. And they're trying to do that. But it's going to take them 10 years, at spending three million dollars a year, and even then, they claim they'll only have about 80 percent of them catalogued. Comets are a tougher act. We don't really have the technology to predict comet trajectories, or when one with our name on it might arrive. But we would have lots of time, if we see it coming. We really need a dedicated observatory. You'll notice that a lot of comets are named after people you never heard of, amateur astronomers? That's because nobody's looking for them, except amateurs. We need a dedicated observatory that looks for comets.Part two of the solutions: we need to figure out how to blow up an asteroid, or alter its trajectory. Now, a year ago, we did an amazing thing. We sent a probe out to this asteroid belt, called NEAR, Near Earth Asteroid Rendezvous. And these guys orbited a 30 — or no, about a 22-mile long asteroid called Eros. And then, of course, you know, they pulled one of those sneaky NASA things, where they had extra batteries and extra gas aboard and everything, and then, at the last minute, they landed. When the mission was over, they actually landed on the thing. We have landed a rocket ship on an asteroid. It's not a big deal. Now, the trouble with just sending a bomb out for this thing is that you don't have anything to push against in space, because there's no air. A nuclear explosion is just as hot, but we don't really have anything big enough to melt a 22-mile long asteroid, or vaporize it, would be more like it.But we can learn to land on these asteroids that have our name on them and put something like a small ion propulsion motor on it, which would gently, slowly, after a period of time, push it into a different trajectory, which, if we've done our math right, would keep it from hitting Earth. This is just a matter of finding 'em, going there, and doing something about it. I know your head is spinning from all this stuff. Yikes! So many big threats!The thing, I think, to remember, is September 11. We don't want to get caught flat-footed again. We know about this stuff. Science has the power to predict the future in many cases now. Knowledge is power. The worst thing we can do is say, jeez, I got enough to worry about without worrying about an asteroid. (Laughter) That's a mistake that could literally cost us our future. Thank you.
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:15.958
The advances that have taken place in astronomy,

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:22.958
cosmology and biology, in the last 10 years,

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:26.958
are really extraordinary --

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:30.958
to the point where we know more about our universe and how it works

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:36.958
than many of you might imagine.

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:39.958
But there was something else that I've noticed

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:42.958
as those changes were taking place, as people were starting to find out that

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:47.958
hmm ... yeah, there really is a black hole at the center of every galaxy.

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:50.958
The science writers and editors -- I shouldn't say science writers,

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:54.958
I should say people who write about science --

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:56.958
and editors would sit down over a couple of beers,

00:00:56.958 --> 00:01:00.958
after a hard day of work, and start talking about

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:05.958
some of these incredible perceptions about how the universe works.

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:10.958
And they would inevitably end up in what I thought was a very bizarre place,

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:14.958
which is ways the world could end very suddenly.

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:19.958
And that's what I want to talk about today. (Laughter)

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:26.958
Ah, you laugh, you fools. (Laughter)

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:28.958
(Voice: Can we finish up a little early?)

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:33.958
(Laughter) Yeah, we need the time!

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:39.958
Stephen Petranek: At first, it all seemed a little fantastical to me, but after challenging a lot of these ideas,

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:43.958
I began to take a lot of them seriously. And then September 11 happened,

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:45.958
and I thought, ah, God,

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:48.958
I can't go to the TED conference and talk about how the world is going to end.

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:53.958
Nobody wants to hear that. Not after this!

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:57.958
And that got me into a discussion with some other people, other scientists,

00:01:57.958 --> 00:02:01.958
about maybe some other subjects, and one of the guys I talked to,

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:03.958
who was a neuroscientist, said,

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:07.958
"You know, I think there are a lot of solutions to the problems you brought up,"

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:11.958
and reminds me of Michael's talk yesterday

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:15.958
and his mother saying you can't have a solution if you don't have a problem.

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:20.958
So, we went out looking for solutions to ways that the world might end tomorrow,

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:23.958
and lo and behold, we found them.

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:29.958
Which leads me to a videotape of a President Bush

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:31.958
press conference from a couple of weeks ago.

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:33.958
Can we run that, Andrew?

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:37.958
President George W. Bush: Whatever it costs to defend our security,

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:42.958
and whatever it costs to defend our freedom, we must pay it.

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:43.958
SP: I agree with the president.

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:49.958
He wants two trillion dollars to protect us from terrorists next year,

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:55.958
a two-trillion-dollar federal budget, which will land us back into deficit spending real fast.

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:58.958
But terrorists aren't the only threat we face.

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:03.958
There are really serious calamities staring us in the eye

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:05.958
that we're in the same kind of denial about

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:11.958
that we were about terrorism, and what could've happened on September 11.

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:17.958
I would propose, therefore, that if we took 10 billion dollars

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:20.958
from that 2.13 trillion dollar budget --

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:26.958
which is two one hundredths of that budget --

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:30.958
and we doled out a billion dollars to each one of these problems

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:34.958
I'm going to talk to you about, the vast majority could be solved,

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:40.958
and the rest we could deal with. So, I hope you find this both fascinating --

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:43.958
I'm fascinated by this kind of stuff, I gotta admit --

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:49.958
to me these are Richard's cockroaches.

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:55.958
But I also hope, because I think the people in this room can literally change the world,

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:59.958
I hope you take some of this stuff away with you,

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:03.958
and when you have an opportunity to be influential,

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:07.958
that you try to get some heavy-duty money spent on some of these ideas.

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:16.958
So let's start. Number 10: we lose the will to survive.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:19.958
We live in an incredible age of modern medicine.

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:23.958
We are all much healthier than we were 20 years ago.

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:28.958
People around the world are getting better medicine --

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:31.958
but mentally, we're falling apart.

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:33.958
The World Health Organization now estimates

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:39.958
that one out of five people on the planet is clinically depressed.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:44.958
And the World Health Organization also says that depression is the

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:50.958
biggest epidemic that humankind has ever faced.

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:53.958
Soon, genetic breakthroughs and even better medicine

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:59.958
are going to allow us to think of 100 as a normal lifespan.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:07.958
A female child born tomorrow, on average -- median -- will live to age 83.

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:12.958
Our life longevity is going up almost a year for every year that passes.

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:14.958
Now the problem with all of this, getting older,

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:19.958
is that people over 65 are the most likely people to commit suicide.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:21.958
So, what are the solutions?

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:24.958
We don't really have mental health insurance in this country,

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:28.958
and it's -- (Applause) -- it's really a crime.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:32.958
Something like 98 percent of all people with depression,

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:33.958
and I mean really severe depression

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:38.958
-- I have a friend with stunningly severe depression

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:42.958
-- this is a curable disease, with present medicine and present technology.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:46.958
But it is often a combination of talk therapy and pills.

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:51.958
Pills alone don't do it, especially in clinically depressed people.

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:55.958
You ought to be able to go to a psychiatrist or a psychologist,

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:57.958
and put down your 10-dollar copay, and get treated,

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:01.958
just like you do when you got a cut on your arm. It's ridiculous.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:06.958
Secondly, drug companies are not going to develop really sophisticated

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:13.958
psychoactive drugs. We know that most mental illnesses have a biological

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:16.958
component that can be dealt with.

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:19.958
And we know just an amazing amount more about the brain now than we

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:24.958
did 10 years ago. We need a pump-push from the federal government,

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:29.958
through NIH and National Science -- NSF --

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
and places like that to start helping the drug companies

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:35.958
develop some advanced psychoactive drugs.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:40.958
Moving on. Number nine -- don't laugh -- aliens invade Earth.

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:43.958
Ten years ago, you couldn't have found an astronomer --

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:46.958
well, very few astronomers -- in the world who would've told you that

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:50.958
there are any planets anywhere outside our solar system.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:54.958
1995, we found three. The count now is up to 80 --

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:58.958
we're finding about two or three a month.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.958
All of the ones we've found, by the way, are in this little, teeny, tiny corner where we live,

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:07.958
in the Milky Way. There must be millions of planets in the Milky Way,

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
and as Carl Sagan insisted for many years,

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:15.958
and was laughed at for it, there must be billions and billions in the universe.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:19.958
In a few years, NASA is going to launch four or five telescopes out to Jupiter,

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:23.958
where there's less dust, and start looking for Earth-like planets,

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:27.958
which we cannot see with present technology, nor detect.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:35.958
It's becoming obvious that the chance that life does not exist elsewhere in the universe,

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:39.958
and probably fairly close to us, is a fairly remote idea.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:45.958
And the chance that some of it isn't more intelligent than ours is also a remote idea.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
Remember, we've only been an advanced civilization --

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:51.958
an industrial civilization, if you would -- for 200 years.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:54.958
Although every time I go to Pompeii, I'm amazed that they had

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
the equivalent of a McDonald's on every street corner, too.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:08:00.958
So, I don't know how much civilization really has progressed since AD 79,

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:04.958
but there's a great likelihood. I really believe this,

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:09.958
and I don't believe in aliens, and I don't believe there are any aliens on the Earth

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
or anything like that. But there's a likelihood that we will confront a

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:15.958
civilization that is more intelligent than our own.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:19.958
Now, what will happen? What if they come to, you know,

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.958
suck up our oceans for the hydrogen?

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:25.958
And swat us away like flies, the way we swat away flies when we go into

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:28.958
the rainforest and start logging it.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:33.958
We can look at our own history. The late physicist Gerard O'Neill said,

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:36.958
"Advanced Western civilization has had a destructive effect

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:40.958
on all primitive civilizations it has come in contact with,

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:43.958
even in those cases where every attempt was made

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:48.958
to protect and guard the primitive civilization."

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:52.958
If the aliens come visiting, we're the primitive civilization.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:09:01.958
So, what are the solutions to this? (Laughter)

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
Thank God you can all read!

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:11.958
It may seem ridiculous, but we have a really lousy history of anticipating things like this

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
and actually being prepared for them.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:16.958
How much energy and money does it take to actually have a plan

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:21.958
to negotiate with an advanced species?

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:25.958
Secondly -- and you're going to hear more from me about this --

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:28.958
we have to become an outward-looking, space-faring nation.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:29.958
We have got to develop the

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
idea that the Earth doesn't last forever,

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
our sun doesn't last forever.

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:39.958
If we want humanity to last forever, we have to colonize the Milky Way.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:45.958
And that is not something that is beyond comprehension at this point.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
(Applause)

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:52.958
It'll also help us a lot, if we meet an advanced civilization along the way,

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:55.958
if we're trying to be an advanced civilization. Number eight --

00:09:55.958 --> 00:10:01.958
(Voice: Steve, that's what I'm doing after TED.) (Laughter) (Applause)

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
SP: You've got it! You've got the job.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
Number eight: the ecosystem collapses.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:11.958
Last July, in Science, the journal Science,

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
19 oceanographers published a very, very unusual article.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:17.958
It wasn't really a research report; it was a screed.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:20.958
They said, we've been looking at the oceans for a long time now,

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:24.958
and we want to tell you they're not in trouble, they're near collapse.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:30.958
Many other ecosystems on Earth are in real, real danger.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:33.958
We're living in a time of mass extinctions that exceeds the fossil record

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
by a factor of 10,000.

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:41.958
We have lost 25 percent of the unique species in Hawaii in the last 20 years.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:47.958
California is expected to lose 25 percent of its species in the next 40 years.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:51.958
Somewhere in the Amazon forest is the marginal tree.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:55.958
You cut down that tree, the rain forest collapses as an ecosystem.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
There's really a tree like that out there. That's really what it comes to.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:03.958
And when that ecosystem collapses, it could take a major ecosystem with it,

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:10.958
like our atmosphere. So, what do we do about this? What are the solutions?

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:13.958
There is some modeling of ecosystems going on now.

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:18.958
The problem with ecosystems is that we understand them so poorly,

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:22.958
that we don't know they're really in trouble until it's almost too late.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:26.958
We need to know earlier that they're getting in trouble,

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:30.958
and we need to be able to pump possible solutions into models.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:33.958
And with the kind of computing power we have now,

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958
there is, as I say, some of this going on, but it needs money.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
National Science Foundation needs to say -- you know,

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
almost all the money that's spent on science in this country

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
comes from the federal government, one way or another.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
And they get to prioritize, you know?

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:48.958
There are people at the National Science Foundation

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:51.958
who get to say, this is the most important thing.

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
This is one of the things they ought to be thinking more about.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:56.958
Secondly, we need to create huge biodiversity reserves on the planet,

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
and start moving them around.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:02.958
There's been an experiment for the last four or five years on the Georges Bank,

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:06.958
or the Grand Banks off of Newfoundland. It's a no-take fishing zone.

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:09.958
They can't fish there for a radius of 200 miles.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:12.958
And an amazing thing has happened: almost all the fish have come back,

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:16.958
and they're reproducing like crazy. We're going to have to start doing this

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
around the globe. We're going to have to have no-take zones.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:22.958
We're going to have to say, no more logging in the Amazon for 20 years.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
Let it recover, before we start logging again.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:30.958
(Applause)

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:34.958
Number seven: particle accelerator mishap.

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:37.958
You all remember Ted Kaczynski, the Unabomber?

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:41.958
One of the things he raved about was that a particle accelerator experiment

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:46.958
could go haywire and set off a chain reaction that would destroy the world.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.958
A lot of very sober-minded physicists, believe it or not,

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:51.958
have had exactly the same thought.

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:54.958
This spring -- there's a collider at Brookhaven, on Long Island --

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:58.958
this spring, it's going to have an experiment in which it creates black holes.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:02.958
They are expecting to create little, tiny black holes.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:09.958
They expect them to evaporate. (Laughter)

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:12.958
I hope they're right. (Laughter)

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:16.958
Other collider experiments -- there's one that's going to take place next summer

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:20.958
at CERN -- have the possibility of creating something called strangelets,

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:24.958
which are kind of like antimatter. Whenever they hit other matter, they destroy it

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:28.958
and obliterate it. Most physicists say that the accelerators we have now

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:31.958
are not really powerful enough to create black holes and strangelets

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:34.958
that we need to worry about, and they're probably right.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:38.958
But, all around the world, in Japan, in Canada,

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:40.958
there's talk about this, of reviving this in the United States.

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:42.958
We shut one down that was going to be big.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:46.958
But there's talk of building very big accelerators.

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:49.958
What can we do about this? What are the solutions?

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
We've got the fox watching the henhouse here.

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:57.958
We need to -- we need the advice of particle physicists to talk about particle physics

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
and what should be done in particle physics,

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:04.958
but we need some outside thinking and watchdogging

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:07.958
of what's going on with these experiments.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
Secondly, we have a natural laboratory surrounding the Earth.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
We have an electromagnetic field around the Earth,

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:17.958
and it's constantly bombarded by high-energy particles, like protons.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:21.958
And in my opinion, we don't spend enough time

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:28.958
looking at that natural laboratory and figuring out first what's safe to do on Earth.

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:31.958
Number six: biotech disaster.

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:34.958
It's one of my favorite ones, because we've done several stories on Bt corn.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:40.958
Bt corn is a corn that creates its own pesticide to kill a corn borer.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:44.958
You may of heard of it -- heard it called StarLink,

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:48.958
especially when all those taco shells were taken out of the supermarkets

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:50.958
about a year and a half ago.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:54.958
This stuff was supposed to only be feed for animals in the United States,

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:58.958
and it got into the human food supply, and somebody should've figured out

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
that it would get in the human food supply very easily.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:04.958
But the thing that's alarming is a couple of months ago, in Mexico,

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:08.958
where Bt corn and all genetically altered corn is totally illegal,

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:12.958
they found Bt corn genes in wild corn plants.

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:15.958
Now, corn originated, we think, in Mexico.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:20.958
This is the genetic biodiversity storehouse of corn.

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:26.958
This brings back a skepticism that has gone away recently,

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:30.958
that superweeds and superpests could spread around the world,

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:35.958
from biotechnology, that literally could destroy the world's food supply

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:37.958
in very short order.

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:41.958
So, what do we do about that?

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:46.958
We treat biotechnology with the same scrutiny we apply to nuclear power plants.

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:49.958
It's that simple. This is an amazingly unregulated field.

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:52.958
When the StarLink disaster happened, there was a battle between the

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:57.958
EPA and the FDA over who really had authority, and over what parts of this,

00:15:57.958 --> 00:16:01.958
and they didn't get it straightened out for months. That's kind of crazy.

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:06.958
Number five, one of my favorites: reversal of the Earth's magnetic field.

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:09.958
Believe it or not, this happens every few hundred thousand years,

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:11.958
and has happened many times in our history.

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:16.958
North Pole goes to the South, South Pole goes to the North, and vice versa.

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:19.958
But what happens, as this occurs,

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:25.958
is that we lose our magnetic field around the Earth over the period of about 100 years,

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:27.958
and that means that all these cosmic rays and particles

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:30.958
that are to come streaming at us from the sun,

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:43.958
that this field protects us from, are -- well, basically, we're gonna fry. (Laughter)

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:47.958
(Voice: Steve, I have some additional hats downstairs.)

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:51.958
SP: So, what can we do about this? Oh, by the way, we're overdue.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:53.958
It's been 780,000 years since this happened.

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:56.958
So, it should have happened about 480,000 years ago.

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:58.958
Oh, and here's one other thing.

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:06.958
Scientists think now our magnetic field may be diminished by about five percent.

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:10.958
So, maybe we're in the throes of it.

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:14.958
One of the problems of trying to figure out how healthy the Earth is,

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:18.958
is that we have -- you know, we don't have good weather data from 60 years ago,

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:22.958
much less data on things like the ozone layer.

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:26.958
So, there's a fairly simple solution to this.

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:29.958
There's going to be a lot of cheap rocketry that's going to come online

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:31.958
in about six or seven years

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:35.958
that gets us into the low atmosphere very cheaply.

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:38.958
You know, we can make ozone from car tailpipes.

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:41.958
It's not hard: it's just three oxygen atoms.

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:45.958
If you brought the entire ozone layer down to the surface of the Earth,

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:48.958
it would be the thickness of two pennies, at 14 pounds per square inch.

00:17:48.958 --> 00:17:51.958
You don't need that much up there.

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:54.958
We need to learn how to repair and replenish the Earth's ozone layer.

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:58.958
(Applause)

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:01.958
Number four: giant solar flares.

00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:05.958
Solar flares are enormous magnetic outbursts from the Sun

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:09.958
that bombard the Earth with high-speed subatomic particles.

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:12.958
So far, our atmosphere has done, and our magnetic field has done

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:15.958
pretty well protecting us from this.

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:19.958
Occasionally, we get a flare from the Sun that causes havoc

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:23.958
with communications and so forth, and electricity.

00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:26.958
But the alarming thing is that astronomers recently have been studying

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:28.958
stars that are similar to our Sun,

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:32.958
and they've found that a number of them, when they're about the age of our Sun,

00:18:32.958 --> 00:18:37.958
brighten by a factor of as much as 20. Doesn't last for very long.

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:39.958
And they think these are super-flares, millions of times more powerful

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:44.958
than any flares we've had from our Sun so far.

00:18:44.958 --> 00:18:48.958
Obviously, we don't want one of those. (Laughter)

00:18:48.958 --> 00:18:50.958
There's a flip side to it. In studying stars

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:54.958
like our Sun, we've found that they go through periods of diminishment,

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:58.958
when their total amount of energy that's expelled from them

00:18:58.958 --> 00:19:00.958
goes down by maybe one percent.

00:19:00.958 --> 00:19:04.958
One percent doesn't sound like a lot, but it would cause one hell of an ice age here.

00:19:04.958 --> 00:19:06.958
So, what can we do about this?

00:19:06.958 --> 00:19:09.958
(Laughter) Start terraforming Mars. This is one of my favorite subjects.

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:13.958
I wrote a story about this in Life magazine in 1993.

00:19:13.958 --> 00:19:17.958
This is rocket science, but it's not hard rocket science.

00:19:17.958 --> 00:19:20.958
Everything that we need to make an atmosphere on Mars,

00:19:20.958 --> 00:19:24.958
and to make a livable planet on Mars, is probably there.

00:19:24.958 --> 00:19:30.958
And you just, literally, have to send little nuclear factories up there

00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:35.958
that gobble up the iron oxide on the surface of Mars and spit out the oxygen.

00:19:35.958 --> 00:19:39.958
The problem is it takes 300 years to terraform Mars, minimum.

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:42.958
Really more like 500 years to do it right.

00:19:42.958 --> 00:19:46.958
There's no reason why we shouldn't start now. (Laughter)

00:19:46.958 --> 00:19:53.958
Number three -- isn't this stuff cool? (Laughter)

00:19:53.958 --> 00:19:56.958
A new global epidemic. People have been at war with germs

00:19:56.958 --> 00:19:57.958
ever since there have been people,

00:19:57.958 --> 00:20:01.958
and from time to time, the germs sure get the upper hand.

00:20:01.958 --> 00:20:06.958
In 1918, we had a flu epidemic in the United States that killed 20 million people.

00:20:06.958 --> 00:20:10.958
That was back when the population was around 100 million people.

00:20:10.958 --> 00:20:13.958
The bubonic plague in Europe, in the Middle Ages,

00:20:13.958 --> 00:20:17.958
killed one out of four Europeans.

00:20:17.958 --> 00:20:21.958
AIDS is coming back. Ebola seems to be rearing its head

00:20:21.958 --> 00:20:24.958
with much too much frequency,

00:20:24.958 --> 00:20:29.958
and old diseases like cholera are becoming resistant to antibiotics.

00:20:29.958 --> 00:20:31.958
We've all learned what -- the kind of panic that can occur

00:20:31.958 --> 00:20:36.958
when an old disease rears its head, like anthrax.

00:20:36.958 --> 00:20:43.958
The worst possibility is that a very simple germ, like staph,

00:20:43.958 --> 00:20:48.958
for which we have one antibiotic that still works, mutates.

00:20:48.958 --> 00:20:50.958
And we know staph can do amazing things.

00:20:50.958 --> 00:20:55.958
A staph cell can be next to a muscle cell in your body and borrow genes from it

00:20:55.958 --> 00:20:59.958
when antibiotics come, and change and mutate.

00:20:59.958 --> 00:21:01.958
The danger is that some germ like staph will be --

00:21:01.958 --> 00:21:06.958
will mutate into something that's really virulent, very contagious,

00:21:06.958 --> 00:21:10.958
and will sweep through populations before we can do anything about it.

00:21:10.958 --> 00:21:12.958
That's happened before. About 12,000 years ago,

00:21:12.958 --> 00:21:17.958
there was a massive wave of mammal extinctions in the Americas,

00:21:17.958 --> 00:21:20.958
and that is thought to have been a virulent disease.

00:21:20.958 --> 00:21:21.958
So, what can we do about it?

00:21:21.958 --> 00:21:27.958
It is nuts. We give antibiotics -- (Applause) --

00:21:27.958 --> 00:21:32.958
every cow, every lamb, every chicken, they get antibiotics every day, all.

00:21:32.958 --> 00:21:34.958
You know, you go to a restaurant, you eat fish, I got news for you,

00:21:34.958 --> 00:21:38.958
it's all farmed. You know, you gotta ask when you go to a restaurant if it's a wild fish,

00:21:38.958 --> 00:21:41.958
cause they're not going to tell you. We're giving away the code.

00:21:41.958 --> 00:21:44.958
This is like being at war and giving somebody your secret code.

00:21:44.958 --> 00:21:49.958
We're telling the germs out there how to fight us.

00:21:49.958 --> 00:21:51.958
We gotta fix that. We gotta outlaw that right away.

00:21:51.958 --> 00:21:55.958
Secondly, our public health system, as we saw with anthrax, is a real disaster.

00:21:55.958 --> 00:22:01.958
We have a real, major outbreak of disease in the United States,

00:22:01.958 --> 00:22:03.958
we are not prepared to cope with it.

00:22:03.958 --> 00:22:05.958
Now, there is money in the federal budget, next year,

00:22:05.958 --> 00:22:07.958
to build up the public health service.

00:22:07.958 --> 00:22:12.958
But I don't think to any extent that it really needs to be done.

00:22:12.958 --> 00:22:16.958
Number two -- my favorite -- we meet a rogue black hole.

00:22:16.958 --> 00:22:19.958
You know, 10 years ago, or 15 years ago, really,

00:22:19.958 --> 00:22:21.958
you walk into an astronomy convention, and you say,

00:22:21.958 --> 00:22:24.958
"You know, there's probably a black hole at the center of every galaxy,"

00:22:24.958 --> 00:22:26.958
and they're going to hoot you off the stage.

00:22:26.958 --> 00:22:28.958
And now, if you went into one of those conventions and you said,

00:22:28.958 --> 00:22:32.958
"Well, I don't think black holes are out there," they'd hoot you off the stage.

00:22:32.958 --> 00:22:35.958
Our comprehension of the way the universe works is really --

00:22:35.958 --> 00:22:40.958
has just gained unbelievably in recent years.

00:22:40.958 --> 00:22:47.958
We think that there are about 10 million dead stars in the Milky Way alone, our galaxy.

00:22:47.958 --> 00:22:51.958
And these stars have compressed down to maybe something like 12, 15 miles wide,

00:22:51.958 --> 00:22:54.958
and they are black holes. And they are gobbling up everything around them,

00:22:54.958 --> 00:22:59.958
including light, which is why we can't see them.

00:22:59.958 --> 00:23:02.958
Most of them should be in orbit around something.

00:23:02.958 --> 00:23:06.958
But galaxies are very violent places, and things can be spun out of orbit.

00:23:06.958 --> 00:23:09.958
And also, space is incredibly vast.

00:23:09.958 --> 00:23:14.958
So even if you flung a million of these things out of orbit,

00:23:14.958 --> 00:23:17.958
the chances that one would actually hit us is fairly remote.

00:23:17.958 --> 00:23:25.958
But it only has to get close, about a billion miles away, one of these things.

00:23:25.958 --> 00:23:28.958
About a billion miles away, here's what happens to Earth's orbit:

00:23:28.958 --> 00:23:31.958
it becomes elliptical instead of circular.

00:23:31.958 --> 00:23:33.958
And for three months out of the year,

00:23:33.958 --> 00:23:37.958
the surface temperatures go up to 150 to 180.

00:23:37.958 --> 00:23:40.958
For three months out of the year, they go to 50 below zero.

00:23:40.958 --> 00:23:42.958
That won't work too well. What can we do about this?

00:23:42.958 --> 00:23:50.958
And this is my scariest. (Laughter)

00:23:50.958 --> 00:23:55.958
I don't have a good answer for this one.

00:23:55.958 --> 00:23:59.958
Again, we gotta think about being a colonizing race.

00:23:59.958 --> 00:24:04.958
And finally, number one: biggest danger to life as we know it, I think,

00:24:04.958 --> 00:24:07.958
a really big asteroid heads for Earth.

00:24:07.958 --> 00:24:11.958
The important thing to remember here -- this is not a question of if,

00:24:11.958 --> 00:24:15.958
this is a question of when, and how big.

00:24:15.958 --> 00:24:19.958
In 1908, just a 200-foot piece of a comet

00:24:19.958 --> 00:24:23.958
exploded over Siberia and flattened forests for maybe 100 miles.

00:24:23.958 --> 00:24:28.958
It had the effect of about 1,000 Hiroshima bombs.

00:24:28.958 --> 00:24:33.958
Astronomers estimate that little asteroids like that come about every hundred years.

00:24:33.958 --> 00:24:40.958
In 1989, a large asteroid passed 400,000 miles away from Earth.

00:24:40.958 --> 00:24:42.958
Nothing to worry about, right?

00:24:42.958 --> 00:24:52.958
It passed directly through Earth's orbit. We were in that that spot six hours earlier.

00:24:52.958 --> 00:24:56.958
A small asteroid, say a half mile wide, would touch off firestorms

00:24:56.958 --> 00:25:00.958
followed by severe global cooling from the debris kicked up --

00:25:00.958 --> 00:25:02.958
Carl Sagan's nuclear winter thing.

00:25:02.958 --> 00:25:06.958
An asteroid five miles wide causes major extinctions.

00:25:06.958 --> 00:25:09.958
We think the one that got the dinosaurs was about five miles wide.

00:25:09.958 --> 00:25:12.958
Where are they? There's something called the Kuiper belt,

00:25:12.958 --> 00:25:17.958
which -- some people think Pluto's not a planet,

00:25:17.958 --> 00:25:20.958
that's where Pluto is, it's in the Kuiper belt.

00:25:20.958 --> 00:25:22.958
There's also something a little farther out, called the Oort cloud.

00:25:22.958 --> 00:25:28.958
There are about 100,000 balls of ice and rock -- comets, really --

00:25:28.958 --> 00:25:32.958
out there, that are 50 miles in diameter or more,

00:25:32.958 --> 00:25:34.958
and they regularly take a little spin,

00:25:34.958 --> 00:25:40.958
in towards the Sun and pass reasonably close to us.

00:25:40.958 --> 00:25:49.958
Of more concern, I think, is the asteroids that exist between Mars and Jupiter.

00:25:49.958 --> 00:25:52.958
The folks at the Sloan Digital Sky Survey told us last fall --

00:25:52.958 --> 00:25:56.958
they're making the first map of the universe, three-dimensional map of the universe --

00:25:56.958 --> 00:26:01.958
that there are probably 700,000 asteroids between Mars and Jupiter

00:26:01.958 --> 00:26:06.958
that are a half a mile big or bigger.

00:26:06.958 --> 00:26:12.958
So you say, yeah, well, what are really the chances of this happening?

00:26:12.958 --> 00:26:15.958
Andrew, can you put that chart up?

00:26:15.958 --> 00:26:20.958
This is a chart that Dr. Clark Chapman at the Southwest Research Institute

00:26:20.958 --> 00:26:23.958
presented to Congress a few years ago.

00:26:23.958 --> 00:26:27.958
You'll notice that the chance of an asteroid-slash-comet impact killing you

00:26:27.958 --> 00:26:30.958
is about one in 20,000, according to the work they've done.

00:26:30.958 --> 00:26:32.958
Now look at the one right below that.

00:26:32.958 --> 00:26:37.958
Passenger aircraft crash, one in 20,000.

00:26:37.958 --> 00:26:42.958
We spend an awful lot of money trying to be sure that we don't die in airplane accidents,

00:26:42.958 --> 00:26:49.958
and we're not spending hardly anything on this. And yet, this is completely preventable.

00:26:49.958 --> 00:26:53.958
We finally have, just in the last year, the technology to stop this cold.

00:26:53.958 --> 00:26:55.958
Could we have the solutions?

00:26:55.958 --> 00:26:59.958
NASA's spending three million dollars a year, three million bucks --

00:26:59.958 --> 00:27:02.958
that is like pocket change -- to search for asteroids.

00:27:02.958 --> 00:27:07.958
Because we can actually figure out every asteroid that's out there,

00:27:07.958 --> 00:27:10.958
and if it might hit Earth, and when it might hit Earth.

00:27:10.958 --> 00:27:11.958
And they're trying to do that.

00:27:11.958 --> 00:27:15.958
But it's going to take them 10 years, at spending three million dollars a year,

00:27:15.958 --> 00:27:19.958
and even then, they claim they'll only have about 80 percent of them catalogued.

00:27:19.958 --> 00:27:21.958
Comets are a tougher act.

00:27:21.958 --> 00:27:24.958
We don't really have the technology to predict comet trajectories,

00:27:24.958 --> 00:27:27.958
or when one with our name on it might arrive.

00:27:27.958 --> 00:27:30.958
But we would have lots of time, if we see it coming.

00:27:30.958 --> 00:27:33.958
We really need a dedicated observatory.

00:27:33.958 --> 00:27:36.958
You'll notice that a lot of comets are named after people you never heard of,

00:27:36.958 --> 00:27:40.958
amateur astronomers? That's because nobody's looking for them, except amateurs.

00:27:40.958 --> 00:27:44.958
We need a dedicated observatory that looks for comets.

00:27:44.958 --> 00:27:49.958
Part two of the solutions: we need to figure out how to blow up an asteroid,

00:27:49.958 --> 00:27:53.958
or alter its trajectory. Now, a year ago, we did an amazing thing.

00:27:53.958 --> 00:27:55.958
We sent a probe out to this asteroid belt,

00:27:55.958 --> 00:27:58.958
called NEAR, Near Earth Asteroid Rendezvous.

00:27:58.958 --> 00:28:06.958
And these guys orbited a 30 -- or no, about a 22-mile long asteroid called Eros.

00:28:06.958 --> 00:28:09.958
And then, of course, you know, they pulled one of those sneaky NASA things,

00:28:09.958 --> 00:28:12.958
where they had extra batteries and extra gas aboard and everything,

00:28:12.958 --> 00:28:14.958
and then, at the last minute, they landed.

00:28:14.958 --> 00:28:17.958
When the mission was over, they actually landed on the thing.

00:28:17.958 --> 00:28:22.958
We have landed a rocket ship on an asteroid. It's not a big deal.

00:28:22.958 --> 00:28:25.958
Now, the trouble with just sending a bomb out for this thing

00:28:25.958 --> 00:28:29.958
is that you don't have anything to push against in space, because there's no air.

00:28:29.958 --> 00:28:31.958
A nuclear explosion is just as hot,

00:28:31.958 --> 00:28:37.958
but we don't really have anything big enough to melt a 22-mile long asteroid,

00:28:37.958 --> 00:28:39.958
or vaporize it, would be more like it.

00:28:39.958 --> 00:28:44.958
But we can learn to land on these asteroids that have our name on them

00:28:44.958 --> 00:28:48.958
and put something like a small ion propulsion motor on it,

00:28:48.958 --> 00:28:53.958
which would gently, slowly, after a period of time, push it into a different trajectory,

00:28:53.958 --> 00:28:56.958
which, if we've done our math right, would keep it from hitting Earth.

00:28:56.958 --> 00:29:01.958
This is just a matter of finding 'em, going there, and doing something about it.

00:29:01.958 --> 00:29:04.958
I know your head is spinning from all this stuff.

00:29:04.958 --> 00:29:07.958
Yikes! So many big threats!

00:29:07.958 --> 00:29:09.958
The thing, I think, to remember, is September 11.

00:29:09.958 --> 00:29:12.958
We don't want to get caught flat-footed again.

00:29:12.958 --> 00:29:14.958
We know about this stuff.

00:29:14.958 --> 00:29:18.958
Science has the power to predict the future in many cases now.

00:29:18.958 --> 00:29:20.958
Knowledge is power.

00:29:20.958 --> 00:29:25.958
The worst thing we can do is say, jeez, I got enough to worry about

00:29:25.958 --> 00:29:31.958
without worrying about an asteroid. (Laughter)

00:29:31.958 --> 00:29:34.958
That's a mistake that could literally cost us our future.

00:29:34.958 --> 00:29:36.958
Thank you.

title: A flight on solar wings
transcript: I am known best for human-powered flight, but that was just one thing that got me going in the sort of things that I'm working in now. As a youngster, I was very interested in model airplanes, ornithopters, autogyros, helicopters, gliders, power planes, indoor models, outdoor models, everything, which I just thought was a lot of fun, and wondered why most other people didn't share my same enthusiasm with them. And then, navy pilot training, and, after college, I got into sailplane flying, power plane flying, and considered the sailplanes as a sort of hobby and fun, but got tangled up with some great professor types, who convinced me and everybody else in the field that this was a good way to get into really deep science.While this was all going on, I was in the field of weather modification, although getting a Ph.D. in aeronautics. The weather modification subject was getting started, and as a graduate student, I could go around to the various talks that were being given, on a hitchhiker ride to the East Coast, and so on. And everybody would talk to me, but all the professionals in the field hated each other, and they wouldn't communicate. And as a result, I got the absolutely unique background in that field, and started a company, which did more research in weather modification than anybody, and there are a lot of things that I just can't go into. But then, 1971 started AeroVironment, with no employees — then one or two, three, and sort of fumbled along on trying to get interesting projects. We had AirDynamisis, who, like I, did not want to work for aerospace companies on some big, many year project, and so we did our small projects, and the company slowly grew.The thing that is exciting was, in 1976, I suddenly got interested in the human-powered airplane because I'd made a made a loan to a friend of 100,000 dollars, or I guaranteed the money at the bank. He needed them — he needed the money for starting a company. The company did not succeed, and he couldn't pay the money back, and I was the guarantor of the note. So, I had a $100,000 debt, and I noticed that the Kramer prize for human-powered flight, which had then been around for — (Laughter) — 17 years at the time, was 50,000 pounds, which, at the exchange rate, was just about 100,000 dollars.So suddenly, I was interested in human-powered flight — (Laughter) — and did not — the way I approached it, first, thinking about ways to make the planes, was just like they'd been doing in England, and not succeeding, and I gave it up. I figured, nah, there isn't any simple, easy way. But then, got off on a vacation trip, and was studying bird flight, just for the fun of it, and you can watch a bird soaring around in circles, and measure the time, and estimate the bank angle, and immediately, figure out its speed, and the turning radius, and so on, which I could do in the car, as we're driving along on a vacation trip — (Laughter) — with my three sons, young sons, helping me, but ridiculing the whole thing very much.But that began thinking about how birds went around, and then how airplanes would, how hang gliders would fly, and then other planes, and the idea of the Gossamer-Condor-type airplane quickly emerged, was so logical, one should have thought of it in the first place, but one didn't. And it was just, keep the weight down — 70 pounds was all it weighed — but let the size swell up, like a hang glider, but three times the span, three times the cord. You're down to a third of the speed, a third of the power, and a good bicyclist can put out that power, and that worked, and we won the prize a year later.We didn't — a lot of flying, a lot of experiments, a lot of things that didn't work, and ones that did work, and the plane kept getting a little better, a little better. Got a good pilot, Brian Allen, to operate it, and finally, succeeded. But unfortunately, about 65,000 dollars was spent on the project.(Laughter)And there was only about 30 to help retire the debt. But fortunately, Henry Kramer, who put up the prize for — that was a one-mile flight — put up a new prize for flying the English Channel, 21 miles. And he thought it would take another 18 years for somebody to win that. We realized that if you just cleaned up our Gossamer Condor a little bit, the power to fly would be decreased a little bit, and if you decrease the power required a little, the pilot can fly a much longer period of time. And Brian Allen was able, in a miraculous flight, to get the Gossamer Albatross across the English Channel, and we won the 100,000-pound, 200,000-dollar prize for that. And when all expenses were paid, the debt was handled, and everything was fine. It turned out that giving the planes to the museum was worth much more than the debt, so for five years, six years, I only had to pay one third income tax. So, there were good economic reasons for the project, but — (Laughter) —that's not, well, the project was done entirely for economic reasons, and we have not been involved in any human-powered flight since then — (Laughter) — because the prizes are all over. (Laughter) But that sure started me thinking about various things, and immediately, we began making a solar-powered plane because we felt solar power was going to be so important for the country and the world, we didn't want the small funding in the government to be decreased, which is what the government was trying to do with it. And we thought a solar-powered plane wouldn't really make sense, but you could do it and it would get a lot of publicity for solar power and maybe help that field. And that project continued, did succeed, and we then got into other projects in aviation and mechanical things and ground devices.But while this was going on, in 1982, I got a prize from the Lindbergh Foundation — their annual prize — and I had to prepare a paper on it, which collected all my varied thoughts and varied interests over the years. This was the one chance that I had to focus on what I, really, was after, and what was important. And to my surprise, I realized the importance of environmental issues, which Charles Lindbergh devoted the last third of his life to, and preparing that paper did me a lot of good. I thought back about if I was a space traveler, and came and visited Earth every 5,000 years. I wanted to — well, one of the biggest changes is, 200 years ago, we began using coal from underground, which has a lot of pollution, and 100 years ago, began getting gasoline from underground, with a lot of pollution. And gasoline consumption, or production, will reach its limit in about ten years, and then go down, and we wonder what's going to happen with transportation.I wanted to show the slide — this slide, I think, is the most important one any of you will see, ever, because — (Laughter) (Applause) — it shows nature versus humans, and goes from 1850 to 2050. And so, the year 2000, you see there. And this is the weight of all air and land vertebrates. Humans and muskrats and giraffes and birds and so on, are — the red line goes up. That's the humans and livestock and pets portion. The green line goes down. That's the wild nature portion. Humans, livestock and pets are, now, 98 percent of the total world's mass of vertebrates on land and air. And you don't know what the future will hold, but it's not going to get a lower percentage. Ten thousand years ago, the humans and livestock and pets were not even one tenth of one percent and wouldn't even have been visible on such a curve. Now they are 98 percent, and it, I think, shows human domination of the Earth.I give a talk to some remarkable high school students each summer, and ask them, after they've asked me questions, and I give them a talk and so on. Then I ask them questions. What's the population of the Earth? What's the population of the Earth going to be when you're the age of your parents? Which I'd never, really — they had never, really, thought about but, now, they think about it. And then, what population of the Earth would be an equilibrium that could continue on, and be for 2050, 2100, 2150? And they form little groups, all fighting with each other, and when I leave, two hours later, most of them are saying about 2 billion people, and they don't have any clue about how to get down to 2 billion, nor do I, but I think they're right and this is a serious problem.Rachel Carson was thinking of these, and came out with "Silent Spring," way back. "Solar Manifesto" by Hermann Scheer, in Germany, claims all energy on Earth can be derived, for every country, from solar energy and water, and so on. You don't need to dig down for these chemicals, and we can do things much more efficiently. Let's have the next slide. So this just summarizes it. "Over billions of years, on a unique sphere, chance has painted a thin covering of life — complex and probable, wonderful and fragile.Suddenly, we humans, a recently arrived species, no longer subject to the checks and balances inherent in nature, have grown in population, technology and intelligence to a position of terrible power. We, now, wield the paintbrush." We're in charge. It's frightening. And I do a painting every 20 or 25 years. This is the last one. (Laughter) And [it] shows the Earth in a time flag: on the right, in trilobites and dinosaurs and so on; and over the triangle, we now get to civilization and TV and traffic jams and so on. I have no idea of what comes next, so I just used robotic and natural cockroaches as the future, as a little warning. And two weeks after this drawing was done, we actually had our first project contract, at AeroVironment, on robotic cockroaches, which was very frightening to me.(Laughter) (Paper rustling)Well, that'll be all the slides. As time went on, we stopped our environmental programs. We focused more on the really serious energy problems of the future, and we produced products for the company. And we developed the impact car that General Motors made, the EV1, out of — and got the Air Resources Board to have the regulations that stimulated the electric cars, but they've since come apart. And we've done a lot of things, small drone airplanes and so on. I have a Helios. We have the first video.(Video) Narrator: With a wingspan of 247 feet, this makes her larger than a Boeing 747.(Music)Her designers' attention to detail and her construction gives Helios' structure the flexibility and strength to deal with the turbulence encountered in the atmosphere. This enables her to easily ride through the air currents as if she's sliding along on the ocean waves.Paul MacCready: The wings could touch together on top and not break. We think.(Laughter)Narrator: And Helios now begins the process of turning her back to the sun, to maximize the power from her solar array.(Music) As the sky gets darker, and the outside air temperatures drop below minus 100 degrees Fahrenheit, the most environmentally hostile segment of Helios's journey has gone by without notice, except for being recorded by specially designed data acquisition systems and their associated sensors. Approaching a peak radar altitude of 96,863 feet, at 4:12 p.m., Helios is standing on top of 98 percent of the Earth's atmosphere. This is more than 10,000 feet higher than the previous world's altitude record held by the SR-71 Blackbird.(Applause)PM: That plane has many purposes, but it's aimed for communications, and it can fly so slowly that it'll just stay up at 65,000 feet. Eventually, it will be able to have to stay up day, night, day, night, for six months at a time, acting like the synchronous satellite, but only ten miles above the Earth. Let's have the next video. This shows the other end of the spectrum.(Video) Narrator: A tiny airplane, the AV Pointer serves for surveillance. In effect a pair of roving eyeglasses, a cutting-edge example of where miniaturization can lead if the operator is remote from the vehicle. It is convenient to carry, assemble, and launch by hand. Battery-powered, it is silent and rarely noticed. It sends high-resolution video pictures back to the operator. With on-board GPS, it can navigate autonomously, and it is rugged enough to self-land without damage.PM: Okay, and let's have the next.(Applause)That plane is widely used by the military, now, in all their operations. How old were you when you invented that?TM: Oh, 10, 11. (AA: Oh my God.)TM: 12, something like that. (AA: That's amazing.)PM: And Tyler's here to show you the Walkalong.(Applause)TM: All right. As the wind comes up, it has to go over the cliff, so as you walk through the air, it goes around your body, some has to go over you. And so you just keep the glider positioned in that up current. So I can do it — oops, that was going to be a right turn.(Laughter)Okay, this one will be a left turn. Here, but — (Applause) — anyway. (Applause) And that's it, so you can just control it, wherever you want, and it's just hours of fun. And these are no longer in production, so you have real collector's items.(Laughter)And this, we just wanted to show you — if we can get the video running on this, yeah — just an example of a little video surveillance.(Laughter)This was flying around in the party last night, and — (Laughter) — you can see how it just can fly around, and you can spy on anybody you want.(Laughter)And that's it. I was going to bring an airplane, but I was worried about hitting people in here, so I thought this would be a little bit more gentle. And that's it, yeah, just a few inventions. 00:00:13.958 --> 00:00:18.958
I am known best for human-powered flight,

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:23.958
but that was just one thing that got me going

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:27.958
in the sort of things that I'm working in now.

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:33.958
As a youngster, I was very interested in model airplanes,

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:39.958
ornithopters, autogyros, helicopters, gliders, power planes,

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:42.958
indoor models, outdoor models, everything,

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:45.958
which I just thought was a lot of fun,

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:53.958
and wondered why most other people didn't share my same enthusiasm with them.

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:59.958
And then, navy pilot training, and, after college,

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:03.958
I got into sailplane flying, power plane flying,

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:11.958
and considered the sailplanes as a sort of hobby and fun,

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:15.958
but got tangled up with some great professor types,

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:20.958
who convinced me and everybody else in the field

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:25.958
that this was a good way to get into really deep science.

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:31.958
While this was all going on, I was in the field of weather modification,

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:35.958
although getting a Ph.D. in aeronautics.

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:39.958
The weather modification subject was getting started,

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:41.958
and as a graduate student,

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:45.958
I could go around to the various talks that were being given,

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:47.958
on a hitchhiker ride to the East Coast,

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:50.958
and so on. And everybody would talk to me,

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:53.958
but all the professionals in the field hated each other,

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:56.958
and they wouldn't communicate. And as a result,

00:01:56.958 --> 00:02:00.958
I got the absolutely unique background in that field,

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:05.958
and started a company, which did more research

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:09.958
in weather modification than anybody,

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:15.958
and there are a lot of things that I just can't go into.

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:21.958
But then, 1971 started AeroVironment, with no employees --

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:23.958
then one or two, three,

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:27.958
and sort of fumbled along on trying to get interesting projects.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:29.958
We had AirDynamisis,

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:34.958
who, like I, did not want to work for aerospace companies

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:38.958
on some big, many year project,

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:47.958
and so we did our small projects, and the company slowly grew.

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:52.958
The thing that is exciting was, in 1976,

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:57.958
I suddenly got interested in the human-powered airplane

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:01.958
because I'd made a made a loan to a friend of 100,000 dollars,

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:03.958
or I guaranteed the money at the bank.

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:07.958
He needed them -- he needed the money for starting a company.

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:10.958
The company did not succeed, and he couldn't pay the money back,

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:15.958
and I was the guarantor of the note. So, I had a $100,000 debt,

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:21.958
and I noticed that the Kramer prize for human-powered flight,

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:24.958
which had then been around for -- (Laughter) --

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:28.958
17 years at the time, was 50,000 pounds,

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:32.958
which, at the exchange rate, was just about 100,000 dollars.

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:35.958
So suddenly, I was interested in human-powered flight --

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:38.958
(Laughter) --

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:44.958
and did not -- the way I approached it, first,

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
thinking about ways to make the planes,

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:52.958

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:56.958
and I gave it up. I figured, nah, there isn't any simple, easy way.

00:03:56.958 --> 00:04:02.958
But then, got off on a vacation trip, and was studying bird flight,

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:04.958
just for the fun of it,

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:07.958
and you can watch a bird soaring around in circles,

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:11.958
and measure the time, and estimate the bank angle,

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:14.958
and immediately, figure out its speed,

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:17.958
and the turning radius, and so on,

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:22.958
which I could do in the car, as we're driving along on a vacation trip --

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:24.958
(Laughter) --

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:28.958
with my three sons, young sons, helping me,

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:32.958
but ridiculing the whole thing very much.

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:37.958

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:44.958

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:46.958
and then other planes,

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:52.958

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:59.958

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:06.958

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:08.958

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:11.958

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:18.958

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:23.958
