00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:53.958
but they're stiff in the other direction so they capture disparities in the surface.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
Now crabs don't miss footholds, because they normally move on sand --

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:57.958
until they come to our lab.

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
And where they have a problem with this kind of mesh,

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
because they don't have spines.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
The crabs are missing spines, so they have a problem in this kind of rough terrain.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
But of course, we can deal with that

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
because we can produce artificial spines.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:17.958
We can make spines that catch on simulated debris

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
and collapse on removal to easily pull them out.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
We did that by putting these artificial spines on crabs,

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:25.958
as you see here, and then we tested them.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:29.958
Do we really understand that principle of tuning? The answer is, yes!

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:34.958
This is slowed down 20-fold, and the crab just zooms across that simulated debris.

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
(Laughter) (Applause)

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.958
A little better than nature.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:42.958
So to our blueprint, we need to add tuned spines.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:47.958
Now will this help us think about the design of more effective climbing robots?

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:52.958
Well, here's RHex: RHex has trouble on rails -- on smooth rails, as you see here.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:56.958
So why not add a spine? My colleagues did this at U. Penn.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:10:00.958
Dan Koditschek put some steel nails -- very simple version -- on the robot,

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:06.958
and here's RHex, now, going over those steel -- those rails. No problem!

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:07.958
How does it do it?

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
Let's slow it down and you can see the spines in action.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
Watch the leg come around, and you'll see it grab on right there.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:15.958
It couldn't do that before; it would just slip and get stuck and tip over.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:19.958
And watch again, right there -- successful.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:22.958
Now just because we have a distributed foot and spines

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
doesn't mean you can climb vertical surfaces.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
This is really, really difficult.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:29.958
But look at this animal do it!

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:35.958
One of the ones I'm passing around is climbing up this vertical surface that's a smooth metal plate.

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
It's extraordinary how fast it can do it --

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:41.958
but if you slow it down, you see something that's quite extraordinary.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:45.958
It's a secret. The animal effectively climbs by slipping and look --

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:49.958
and doing, actually, terribly, with respect to grabbing on the surface.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
It looks, in fact, like it's swimming up the surface.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:56.958
We can actually model that behavior better as a fluid, if you look at it.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:11:00.958
The distributed foot, actually, is working more like a paddle.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:04.958
The same is true when we looked at this lizard running on fluidized sand.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
Watch its feet.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
It's actually functioning as a paddle

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:14.958
even though it's interacting with a surface that we normally think of as a solid.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:19.958
This is not different from what my former undergraduate discovered

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:23.958
when she figured out how lizards can run on water itself.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:29.958
Can you use this to make a better robot?

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
Martin Buehler did -- who's now at Boston Dynamics --

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:37.958
he took this idea and made RHex to be Aqua RHex.

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
So here's RHex with paddles,

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:44.958
now converted into an incredibly maneuverable swimming robot.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
For rough surfaces, though, animals add claws.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:49.958
And you probably feel them if you grabbed it.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:50.958
Did you touch it?

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:51.958
CA: I did.

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
RF: And they do really well at grabbing onto surfaces with these claws.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:59.958
Mark Cutkosky at Stanford University, one of my collaborators, is an extraordinary engineer

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:02.958
who developed this technique called Shape Deposition Manufacturing,

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:05.958
where he can imbed claws right into an artificial foot.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:10.958
And here's the simple version of a foot for a new robot that I'll show you in a bit.

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.958
So to our blueprint, let's attach claws.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:16.958
Now if we look at animals, though, to be really maneuverable in all surfaces,

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
the animals use hybrid mechanisms

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:22.958
that include claws, and spines, and hairs, and pads, and glue, and capillary adhesion

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:23.958
and a whole bunch of other things.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:25.958
These are all from different insects.

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
There's an ant crawling up a vertical surface.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:28.958
Let's look at that ant.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:34.958
This is the foot of an ant. You see the hairs and the claws and this thing here.

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
This is when its foot's in the air.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:40.958
Watch what happens when the foot goes onto your sandwich.

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
You see what happens?

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:46.958
That pad comes out. And that's where the glue is.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
Here from underneath is an ant foot,

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:56.958
and when the claws don't dig in, that pad automatically comes out without the ant doing anything.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:57.958
It just extrudes.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:02.958
And this was a hard shot to get -- I think this is the shot of the ant foot on the superstrings.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:03.958
So it's pretty tough to do.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:06.958
This is what it looks like close up --

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
here's the ant foot, and there's the glue.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:12.958
And we discovered this glue may be an interesting two-phase mixture.

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
It certainly helps it to hold on.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:18.958
So to our blueprint, we stick on some sticky pads.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:22.958
Now you might think for smooth surfaces we get inspiration here.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:25.958
Now we have something better here.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:28.958
The gecko's a really great example of nanotechnology in nature.

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:30.958
These are its feet.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:34.958
They're -- almost look alien. And the secret, which they stick on with,

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
involves their hairy toes.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:40.958
They can run up a surface at a meter per second,

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
take 30 steps in that one second -- you can hardly see them.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
If we slow it down, they attach their feet at eight milliseconds,

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:49.958
and detach them in 16 milliseconds.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:56.958
And when you watch how they detach it, it is bizarre.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:14:01.958
They peel away from the surface like you'd peel away a piece of tape.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:04.958
Very strange. How do they stick?

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:07.958
If you look at their feet, they have leaf-like structures called linalae

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:08.958
with millions of hairs.

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:11.958
And each hair has the worst case of split ends possible.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:14.958
It has a hundred to a thousand split ends,

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
and that's the secret, because it allows intimate contact.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:21.958
The gecko has a billion of these 200-nanometer-sized split ends.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:26.958
And they don't stick by glue, or they don't work like Velcro, or they don't work with suction.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:30.958
We discovered they work by intermolecular forces alone.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:34.958
So to our blueprint, we split some hairs.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
This has inspired the design of the first self-cleaning dry adhesive --

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
the patent issued, we're happy to say.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:42.958
And here's the simplest version in nature,

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:45.958
and here's my collaborator Ron Fearing's attempt

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:50.958
at an artificial version of this dry adhesive made from polyurethane.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:53.958
And here's the first attempt to have it work on some load.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:56.958
There's enormous interest in this in a variety of different fields.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:59.958
You could think of a thousand possible uses, I'm sure.

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:04.958
Lots of people have, and we're excited about realizing this as a product.

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:06.958
We have imagined products; for example, this one:

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:12.958
we imagined a bio-inspired Band-Aid, where we took the glue off the Band-Aid.

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
We took some hairs from a molting gecko;

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:18.958
put three rolls of them on here, and then made this Band-Aid.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
This is an undergraduate volunteer --

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.958
we have 30,000 undergraduates so we can choose among them --

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
that's actually just a red pen mark.

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:27.958
But it makes an incredible Band-Aid.

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:35.958
It's aerated, it can be peeled off easily, it doesn't cause any irritation, it works underwater.

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:40.958
I think this is an extraordinary example of how curiosity-based research --

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
we just wondered how they climbed up something --

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
can lead to things that you could never imagine.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:49.958
It's just an example of why we need to support curiosity-based research.

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:52.958
Here you are, pulling off the Band-Aid.

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:56.958
So we've redefined, now, what a foot is.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.958
The question is, can we use these secrets, then,

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:01.958
to inspire the design of a better foot, better than one that we see in nature?

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.958
Here's the new project:

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:09.958
we're trying to create the first climbing search-and-rescue robot -- no suction or magnets --

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:12.958
that can only move on limited kinds of surfaces.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:17.958
I call the new robot RiSE, for "Robot in Scansorial Environment" -- that's a climbing environment --

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:21.958
and we have an extraordinary team of biologists and engineers creating this robot.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
And here is RiSE.

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:28.958
It's six-legged and has a tail. Here it is on a fence and a tree.

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:32.958
And here are RiSE's first steps on an incline.

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:35.958
You have the audio? You can hear it go up.

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:41.958
And here it is coming up at you, in its first steps up a wall.

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:46.958
Now it's only using its simplest feet here, so this is very new.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:49.958
But we think we got the dynamics right of the robot.

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:52.958
Mark Cutkosky, though, is taking it a step further.

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:57.958
He's the one able to build this shape-deposition manufactured feet and toes.

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:01.958
The next step is to make compliant toes,

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:03.958
and try to add spines and claws and set it for dry adhesives.

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:06.958
So the idea is to first get the toes and a foot right,

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:09.958
attempt to make that climb, and ultimately put it on the robot.

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:11.958
And that's exactly what he's done.

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:16.958
He's built, in fact, a climbing foot-bot inspired by nature.

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:20.958
And here's Cutkosky's and his amazing students' design.

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:26.958
So these are tuned toes -- there are six of them,

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:35.958
and they use the principles that I just talked about collectively for the blueprint.

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:37.958
So this is not using any suction, any glue,

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:40.958
and it will ultimately, when it's attached to the robot --

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:43.958
it's as biologically inspired as the animal --

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:48.958
hopefully be able to climb any kind of a surface.

00:17:48.958 --> 00:17:53.958
Here you see it, next, going up the side of a building at Stanford.

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:56.958
It's sped up -- again, it's a foot climbing.

00:17:56.958 --> 00:17:58.958
It's not the whole robot yet, we're working on it --

00:17:58.958 --> 00:17:59.958
now you can see how it's attaching.

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:05.958
These tuned structures allow the spines, friction pads and ultimately the adhesive hairs

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:08.958
to grab onto very challenging, difficult surfaces.

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:12.958
And so they were able to get this thing -- this is now sped up 20 times --

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:16.958
can you imagine it trying to go up and rescue somebody at that upper floor? OK?

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:18.958
You can visualize this now; it's not impossible.

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:22.958
It's a very challenging task. But more to come later.

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:26.958
To finish: we've gotten design secrets from nature by looking at how feet are built.

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:29.958
We've learned we should distribute control to smart parts.

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:30.958
Don't put it all in the brain,

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:34.958
but put some of the control in tuned feet, legs and even body.

00:18:34.958 --> 00:18:37.958
That nature uses hybrid solutions, not a single solution, to these problems,

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:40.958
and they're integrated and beautifully robust.

00:18:40.958 --> 00:18:48.958
And third, we believe strongly that we do not want to mimic nature but instead be inspired by biology,

00:18:48.958 --> 00:18:52.958
and use these novel principles with the best engineering solutions that are out there

00:18:52.958 --> 00:18:55.958
to make -- potentially -- something better than nature.

00:18:56.958 --> 00:18:58.958
So there's a clear message:

00:18:58.958 --> 00:19:01.958
whether you care about a fundamental, basic research

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:04.958
of really interesting, bizarre, wonderful animals,

00:19:04.958 --> 00:19:05.958
or you want to build a search-and-rescue robot

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:08.958
that can help you in an earthquake, or to save someone in a fire,

00:19:08.958 --> 00:19:13.958
or you care about medicine, we must preserve nature's designs.

00:19:13.958 --> 00:19:16.958
Otherwise these secrets will be lost forever.

00:19:16.958 --> 00:19:17.958
Thank you.

title: The fractals at the heart of African designs
transcript: I want to start my story in Germany, in 1877, with a mathematician named Georg Cantor. And Cantor decided he was going to take a line and erase the middle third of the line, and then take those two resulting lines and bring them back into the same process, a recursive process. So he starts out with one line, and then two, and then four, and then 16, and so on. And if he does this an infinite number of times, which you can do in mathematics, he ends up with an infinite number of lines, each of which has an infinite number of points in it. So he realized he had a set whose number of elements was larger than infinity. And this blew his mind. Literally. He checked into a sanitarium. (Laughter) And when he came out of the sanitarium, he was convinced that he had been put on earth to found transfinite set theory because the largest set of infinity would be God Himself. He was a very religious man. He was a mathematician on a mission.And other mathematicians did the same sort of thing. A Swedish mathematician, von Koch, decided that instead of subtracting lines, he would add them. And so he came up with this beautiful curve. And there's no particular reason why we have to start with this seed shape; we can use any seed shape we like. And I'll rearrange this and I'll stick this somewhere — down there, OK — and now upon iteration, that seed shape sort of unfolds into a very different looking structure. So these all have the property of self-similarity: the part looks like the whole. It's the same pattern at many different scales.Now, mathematicians thought this was very strange because as you shrink a ruler down, you measure a longer and longer length. And since they went through the iterations an infinite number of times, as the ruler shrinks down to infinity, the length goes to infinity. This made no sense at all, so they consigned these curves to the back of the math books. They said these are pathological curves, and we don't have to discuss them. (Laughter) And that worked for a hundred years.And then in 1977, Benoit Mandelbrot, a French mathematician, realized that if you do computer graphics and used these shapes he called fractals, you get the shapes of nature. You get the human lungs, you get acacia trees, you get ferns, you get these beautiful natural forms. If you take your thumb and your index finger and look right where they meet — go ahead and do that now — — and relax your hand, you'll see a crinkle, and then a wrinkle within the crinkle, and a crinkle within the wrinkle. Right? Your body is covered with fractals. The mathematicians who were saying these were pathologically useless shapes? They were breathing those words with fractal lungs. It's very ironic. And I'll show you a little natural recursion here. Again, we just take these lines and recursively replace them with the whole shape. So here's the second iteration, and the third, fourth and so on.So nature has this self-similar structure. Nature uses self-organizing systems. Now in the 1980s, I happened to notice that if you look at an aerial photograph of an African village, you see fractals. And I thought, "This is fabulous! I wonder why?" And of course I had to go to Africa and ask folks why. So I got a Fulbright scholarship to just travel around Africa for a year asking people why they were building fractals, which is a great job if you can get it. (Laughter)And so I finally got to this city, and I'd done a little fractal model for the city just to see how it would sort of unfold — but when I got there, I got to the palace of the chief, and my French is not very good; I said something like, "I am a mathematician and I would like to stand on your roof." But he was really cool about it, and he took me up there, and we talked about fractals. And he said, "Oh yeah, yeah! We knew about a rectangle within a rectangle, we know all about that." And it turns out the royal insignia has a rectangle within a rectangle within a rectangle, and the path through that palace is actually this spiral here. And as you go through the path, you have to get more and more polite. So they're mapping the social scaling onto the geometric scaling; it's a conscious pattern. It is not unconscious like a termite mound fractal.This is a village in southern Zambia. The Ba-ila built this village about 400 meters in diameter. You have a huge ring. The rings that represent the family enclosures get larger and larger as you go towards the back, and then you have the chief's ring here towards the back and then the chief's immediate family in that ring. So here's a little fractal model for it. Here's one house with the sacred altar, here's the house of houses, the family enclosure, with the humans here where the sacred altar would be, and then here's the village as a whole — a ring of ring of rings with the chief's extended family here, the chief's immediate family here, and here there's a tiny village only this big. Now you might wonder, how can people fit in a tiny village only this big? That's because they're spirit people. It's the ancestors. And of course the spirit people have a little miniature village in their village, right? So it's just like Georg Cantor said, the recursion continues forever.This is in the Mandara mountains, near the Nigerian border in Cameroon, Mokoulek. I saw this diagram drawn by a French architect, and I thought, "Wow! What a beautiful fractal!" So I tried to come up with a seed shape, which, upon iteration, would unfold into this thing. I came up with this structure here. Let's see, first iteration, second, third, fourth. Now, after I did the simulation, I realized the whole village kind of spirals around, just like this, and here's that replicating line — a self-replicating line that unfolds into the fractal. Well, I noticed that line is about where the only square building in the village is at. So, when I got to the village, I said, "Can you take me to the square building? I think something's going on there." And they said, "Well, we can take you there, but you can't go inside because that's the sacred altar, where we do sacrifices every year to keep up those annual cycles of fertility for the fields." And I started to realize that the cycles of fertility were just like the recursive cycles in the geometric algorithm that builds this. And the recursion in some of these villages continues down into very tiny scales.So here's a Nankani village in Mali. And you can see, you go inside the family enclosure — you go inside and here's pots in the fireplace, stacked recursively. Here's calabashes that Issa was just showing us, and they're stacked recursively. Now, the tiniest calabash in here keeps the woman's soul. And when she dies, they have a ceremony where they break this stack called the zalanga and her soul goes off to eternity. Once again, infinity is important.Now, you might ask yourself three questions at this point. Aren't these scaling patterns just universal to all indigenous architecture? And that was actually my original hypothesis. When I first saw those African fractals, I thought, "Wow, so any indigenous group that doesn't have a state society, that sort of hierarchy, must have a kind of bottom-up architecture." But that turns out not to be true.I started collecting aerial photographs of Native American and South Pacific architecture; only the African ones were fractal. And if you think about it, all these different societies have different geometric design themes that they use. So Native Americans use a combination of circular symmetry and fourfold symmetry. You can see on the pottery and the baskets. Here's an aerial photograph of one of the Anasazi ruins; you can see it's circular at the largest scale, but it's rectangular at the smaller scale, right? It is not the same pattern at two different scales.Second, you might ask, "Well, Dr. Eglash, aren't you ignoring the diversity of African cultures?" And three times, the answer is no. First of all, I agree with Mudimbe's wonderful book, "The Invention of Africa," that Africa is an artificial invention of first colonialism, and then oppositional movements. No, because a widely shared design practice doesn't necessarily give you a unity of culture — and it definitely is not "in the DNA." And finally, the fractals have self-similarity — so they're similar to themselves, but they're not necessarily similar to each other — you see very different uses for fractals. It's a shared technology in Africa.And finally, well, isn't this just intuition? It's not really mathematical knowledge. Africans can't possibly really be using fractal geometry, right? It wasn't invented until the 1970s. Well, it's true that some African fractals are, as far as I'm concerned, just pure intuition. So some of these things, I'd wander around the streets of Dakar asking people, "What's the algorithm? What's the rule for making this?" and they'd say, "Well, we just make it that way because it looks pretty, stupid." (Laughter) But sometimes, that's not the case. In some cases, there would actually be algorithms, and very sophisticated algorithms. So in Manghetu sculpture, you'd see this recursive geometry. In Ethiopian crosses, you see this wonderful unfolding of the shape.In Angola, the Chokwe people draw lines in the sand, and it's what the German mathematician Euler called a graph; we now call it an Eulerian path — you can never lift your stylus from the surface and you can never go over the same line twice. But they do it recursively, and they do it with an age-grade system, so the little kids learn this one, and then the older kids learn this one, then the next age-grade initiation, you learn this one. And with each iteration of that algorithm, you learn the iterations of the myth. You learn the next level of knowledge.And finally, all over Africa, you see this board game. It's called Owari in Ghana, where I studied it; it's called Mancala here on the East Coast, Bao in Kenya, Sogo elsewhere. Well, you see self-organizing patterns that spontaneously occur in this board game. And the folks in Ghana knew about these self-organizing patterns and would use them strategically. So this is very conscious knowledge.Here's a wonderful fractal. Anywhere you go in the Sahel, you'll see this windscreen. And of course fences around the world are all Cartesian, all strictly linear. But here in Africa, you've got these nonlinear scaling fences. So I tracked down one of the folks who makes these things, this guy in Mali just outside of Bamako, and I asked him, "How come you're making fractal fences? Because nobody else is." And his answer was very interesting. He said, "Well, if I lived in the jungle, I would only use the long rows of straw because they're very quick and they're very cheap. It doesn't take much time, doesn't take much straw." He said, "but wind and dust goes through pretty easily. Now, the tight rows up at the very top, they really hold out the wind and dust. But it takes a lot of time, and it takes a lot of straw because they're really tight." "Now," he said, "we know from experience that the farther up from the ground you go, the stronger the wind blows." Right? It's just like a cost-benefit analysis. And I measured out the lengths of straw, put it on a log-log plot, got the scaling exponent, and it almost exactly matches the scaling exponent for the relationship between wind speed and height in the wind engineering handbook. So these guys are right on target for a practical use of scaling technology.The most complex example of an algorithmic approach to fractals that I found was actually not in geometry, it was in a symbolic code, and this was Bamana sand divination. And the same divination system is found all over Africa. You can find it on the East Coast as well as the West Coast, and often the symbols are very well preserved, so each of these symbols has four bits — it's a four-bit binary word — you draw these lines in the sand randomly, and then you count off, and if it's an odd number, you put down one stroke, and if it's an even number, you put down two strokes. And they did this very rapidly, and I couldn't understand where they were getting — they only did the randomness four times — I couldn't understand where they were getting the other 12 symbols. And they wouldn't tell me. They said, "No, no, I can't tell you about this." And I said, "Well look, I'll pay you, you can be my teacher, and I'll come each day and pay you." They said, "It's not a matter of money. This is a religious matter."And finally, out of desperation, I said, "Well, let me explain Georg Cantor in 1877." And I started explaining why I was there in Africa, and they got very excited when they saw the Cantor set. And one of them said, "Come here. I think I can help you out here." And so he took me through the initiation ritual for a Bamana priest. And of course, I was only interested in the math, so the whole time, he kept shaking his head going, "You know, I didn't learn it this way." But I had to sleep with a kola nut next to my bed, buried in sand, and give seven coins to seven lepers and so on. And finally, he revealed the truth of the matter. And it turns out it's a pseudo-random number generator using deterministic chaos. When you have a four-bit symbol, you then put it together with another one sideways. So even plus odd gives you odd. Odd plus even gives you odd. Even plus even gives you even. Odd plus odd gives you even. It's addition modulo 2, just like in the parity bit check on your computer. And then you take this symbol, and you put it back in so it's a self-generating diversity of symbols. They're truly using a kind of deterministic chaos in doing this. Now, because it's a binary code, you can actually implement this in hardware — what a fantastic teaching tool that should be in African engineering schools.And the most interesting thing I found out about it was historical. In the 12th century, Hugo of Santalla brought it from Islamic mystics into Spain. And there it entered into the alchemy community as geomancy: divination through the earth. This is a geomantic chart drawn for King Richard II in 1390. Leibniz, the German mathematician, talked about geomancy in his dissertation called "De Combinatoria." And he said, "Well, instead of using one stroke and two strokes, let's use a one and a zero, and we can count by powers of two." Right? Ones and zeros, the binary code. George Boole took Leibniz's binary code and created Boolean algebra, and John von Neumann took Boolean algebra and created the digital computer. So all these little PDAs and laptops — every digital circuit in the world — started in Africa. And I know Brian Eno says there's not enough Africa in computers, but you know, I don't think there's enough African history in Brian Eno. (Laughter) (Applause)So let me end with just a few words about applications that we've found for this. And you can go to our website, the applets are all free; they just run in the browser. Anybody in the world can use them. The National Science Foundation's Broadening Participation in Computing program recently awarded us a grant to make a programmable version of these design tools, so hopefully in three years, anybody'll be able to go on the Web and create their own simulations and their own artifacts. We've focused in the U.S. on African-American students as well as Native American and Latino. We've found statistically significant improvement with children using this software in a mathematics class in comparison with a control group that did not have the software. So it's really very successful teaching children that they have a heritage that's about mathematics, that it's not just about singing and dancing. We've started a pilot program in Ghana. We got a small seed grant, just to see if folks would be willing to work with us on this; we're very excited about the future possibilities for that.We've also been working in design. I didn't put his name up here — my colleague, Kerry, in Kenya, has come up with this great idea for using fractal structure for postal address in villages that have fractal structure, because if you try to impose a grid structure postal system on a fractal village, it doesn't quite fit. Bernard Tschumi at Columbia University has finished using this in a design for a museum of African art. David Hughes at Ohio State University has written a primer on Afrocentric architecture in which he's used some of these fractal structures.And finally, I just wanted to point out that this idea of self-organization, as we heard earlier, it's in the brain. It's in the — it's in Google's search engine. Actually, the reason that Google was such a success is because they were the first ones to take advantage of the self-organizing properties of the web. It's in ecological sustainability. It's in the developmental power of entrepreneurship, the ethical power of democracy. It's also in some bad things. Self-organization is why the AIDS virus is spreading so fast. And if you don't think that capitalism, which is self-organizing, can have destructive effects, you haven't opened your eyes enough. So we need to think about, as was spoken earlier, the traditional African methods for doing self-organization. These are robust algorithms. These are ways of doing self-organization — of doing entrepreneurship — that are gentle, that are egalitarian. So if we want to find a better way of doing that kind of work, we need look only no farther than Africa to find these robust self-organizing algorithms. Thank you.

WEBVTT

00:00:12.958 --> 00:00:15.958
I want to start my story in Germany, in 1877,

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:17.958
with a mathematician named Georg Cantor.

00:00:17.958 --> 00:00:22.958
And Cantor decided he was going to take a line and erase the middle third of the line,

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:27.958
and then take those two resulting lines and bring them back into the same process, a recursive process.

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:29.958
So he starts out with one line, and then two,

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:32.958
and then four, and then 16, and so on.

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:35.958
And if he does this an infinite number of times, which you can do in mathematics,

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:37.958
he ends up with an infinite number of lines,

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:40.958
each of which has an infinite number of points in it.

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:44.958
So he realized he had a set whose number of elements was larger than infinity.

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:47.958
And this blew his mind. Literally. He checked into a sanitarium. (Laughter)

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:49.958
And when he came out of the sanitarium,

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:55.958
he was convinced that he had been put on earth to found transfinite set theory

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:58.958
because the largest set of infinity would be God Himself.

00:00:58.958 --> 00:00:59.958
He was a very religious man.

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:01.958
He was a mathematician on a mission.

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:03.958
And other mathematicians did the same sort of thing.

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:05.958
A Swedish mathematician, von Koch,

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:09.958
decided that instead of subtracting lines, he would add them.

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:11.958
And so he came up with this beautiful curve.

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:14.958
And there's no particular reason why we have to start with this seed shape;

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:18.958
we can use any seed shape we like.

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:22.958
And I'll rearrange this and I'll stick this somewhere -- down there, OK --

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:29.958
and now upon iteration, that seed shape sort of unfolds into a very different looking structure.

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:31.958
So these all have the property of self-similarity:

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:33.958
the part looks like the whole.

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:35.958
It's the same pattern at many different scales.

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:38.958
Now, mathematicians thought this was very strange

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:43.958
because as you shrink a ruler down, you measure a longer and longer length.

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:45.958
And since they went through the iterations an infinite number of times,

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:51.958
as the ruler shrinks down to infinity, the length goes to infinity.

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:52.958
This made no sense at all,

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:55.958
so they consigned these curves to the back of the math books.

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:59.958
They said these are pathological curves, and we don't have to discuss them.

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:00.958
(Laughter)

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:02.958
And that worked for a hundred years.

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:08.958
And then in 1977, Benoit Mandelbrot, a French mathematician,

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:13.958
realized that if you do computer graphics and used these shapes he called fractals,

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:15.958
you get the shapes of nature.

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:19.958
You get the human lungs, you get acacia trees, you get ferns,

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:21.958
you get these beautiful natural forms.

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:25.958
If you take your thumb and your index finger and look right where they meet --

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:27.958
go ahead and do that now --

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:30.958
-- and relax your hand, you'll see a crinkle,

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:33.958
and then a wrinkle within the crinkle, and a crinkle within the wrinkle. Right?

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:35.958
Your body is covered with fractals.

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:38.958
The mathematicians who were saying these were pathologically useless shapes?

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:40.958
They were breathing those words with fractal lungs.

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:44.958
It's very ironic. And I'll show you a little natural recursion here.

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:49.958
Again, we just take these lines and recursively replace them with the whole shape.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:54.958
So here's the second iteration, and the third, fourth and so on.

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:56.958
So nature has this self-similar structure.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:58.958
Nature uses self-organizing systems.

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:01.958
Now in the 1980s, I happened to notice

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:05.958
that if you look at an aerial photograph of an African village, you see fractals.

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:09.958
And I thought, "This is fabulous! I wonder why?"

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:11.958
And of course I had to go to Africa and ask folks why.

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:17.958
So I got a Fulbright scholarship to just travel around Africa for a year

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.958
asking people why they were building fractals,

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
which is a great job if you can get it.

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:22.958
(Laughter)

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:29.958
And so I finally got to this city, and I'd done a little fractal model for the city

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:32.958
just to see how it would sort of unfold --

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:35.958
but when I got there, I got to the palace of the chief,

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:38.958
and my French is not very good; I said something like,

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:41.958
"I am a mathematician and I would like to stand on your roof."

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:44.958
But he was really cool about it, and he took me up there,

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:45.958
and we talked about fractals.

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:48.958
And he said, "Oh yeah, yeah! We knew about a rectangle within a rectangle,

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:50.958
we know all about that."

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:54.958
And it turns out the royal insignia has a rectangle within a rectangle within a rectangle,

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:58.958
and the path through that palace is actually this spiral here.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:02.958
And as you go through the path, you have to get more and more polite.

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:05.958
So they're mapping the social scaling onto the geometric scaling;

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:10.958
it's a conscious pattern. It is not unconscious like a termite mound fractal.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
This is a village in southern Zambia.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:16.958
The Ba-ila built this village about 400 meters in diameter.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.958
You have a huge ring.

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:24.958
The rings that represent the family enclosures get larger and larger as you go towards the back,

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:29.958
and then you have the chief's ring here towards the back

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:32.958
and then the chief's immediate family in that ring.

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:33.958
So here's a little fractal model for it.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:36.958
Here's one house with the sacred altar,

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:39.958
here's the house of houses, the family enclosure,

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:42.958
with the humans here where the sacred altar would be,

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:44.958
and then here's the village as a whole --

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:49.958
a ring of ring of rings with the chief's extended family here, the chief's immediate family here,

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:52.958
and here there's a tiny village only this big.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:56.958
Now you might wonder, how can people fit in a tiny village only this big?

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:59.958
That's because they're spirit people. It's the ancestors.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:04.958
And of course the spirit people have a little miniature village in their village, right?

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:07.958
So it's just like Georg Cantor said, the recursion continues forever.

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:11.958
This is in the Mandara mountains, near the Nigerian border in Cameroon, Mokoulek.

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:14.958
I saw this diagram drawn by a French architect,

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:16.958
and I thought, "Wow! What a beautiful fractal!"

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:22.958
So I tried to come up with a seed shape, which, upon iteration, would unfold into this thing.

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
I came up with this structure here.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:28.958
Let's see, first iteration, second, third, fourth.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:30.958
Now, after I did the simulation,

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:33.958
I realized the whole village kind of spirals around, just like this,

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:39.958
and here's that replicating line -- a self-replicating line that unfolds into the fractal.

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:44.958
Well, I noticed that line is about where the only square building in the village is at.

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:46.958
So, when I got to the village,

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
I said, "Can you take me to the square building?

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
I think something's going on there."

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.958
And they said, "Well, we can take you there, but you can't go inside

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958
because that's the sacred altar, where we do sacrifices every year

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:59.958
to keep up those annual cycles of fertility for the fields."

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
And I started to realize that the cycles of fertility

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:05.958
were just like the recursive cycles in the geometric algorithm that builds this.

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:09.958
And the recursion in some of these villages continues down into very tiny scales.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:11.958
So here's a Nankani village in Mali.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:14.958
And you can see, you go inside the family enclosure --

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:18.958
you go inside and here's pots in the fireplace, stacked recursively.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:22.958
Here's calabashes that Issa was just showing us,

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:24.958
and they're stacked recursively.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:26.958
Now, the tiniest calabash in here keeps the woman's soul.

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
And when she dies, they have a ceremony

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:33.958
where they break this stack called the zalanga and her soul goes off to eternity.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.958
Once again, infinity is important.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:41.958
Now, you might ask yourself three questions at this point.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:45.958
Aren't these scaling patterns just universal to all indigenous architecture?

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
And that was actually my original hypothesis.

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:49.958
When I first saw those African fractals,

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:53.958
I thought, "Wow, so any indigenous group that doesn't have a state society,

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:56.958
that sort of hierarchy, must have a kind of bottom-up architecture."

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:58.958
But that turns out not to be true.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:02.958
I started collecting aerial photographs of Native American and South Pacific architecture;

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
only the African ones were fractal.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:10.958
And if you think about it, all these different societies have different geometric design themes that they use.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:16.958
So Native Americans use a combination of circular symmetry and fourfold symmetry.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
You can see on the pottery and the baskets.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:21.958
Here's an aerial photograph of one of the Anasazi ruins;

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:26.958
you can see it's circular at the largest scale, but it's rectangular at the smaller scale, right?

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:30.958
It is not the same pattern at two different scales.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:31.958
Second, you might ask,

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:34.958
"Well, Dr. Eglash, aren't you ignoring the diversity of African cultures?"

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
And three times, the answer is no.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:41.958
First of all, I agree with Mudimbe's wonderful book, "The Invention of Africa,"

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
that Africa is an artificial invention of first colonialism,

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
and then oppositional movements.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:51.958
No, because a widely shared design practice doesn't necessarily give you a unity of culture --

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:54.958
and it definitely is not "in the DNA."

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
And finally, the fractals have self-similarity --

00:07:56.958 --> 00:08:00.958
so they're similar to themselves, but they're not necessarily similar to each other --

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:02.958
you see very different uses for fractals.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
It's a shared technology in Africa.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
And finally, well, isn't this just intuition?

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
It's not really mathematical knowledge.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
Africans can't possibly really be using fractal geometry, right?

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
It wasn't invented until the 1970s.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:21.958
Well, it's true that some African fractals are, as far as I'm concerned, just pure intuition.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:24.958
So some of these things, I'd wander around the streets of Dakar

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:27.958
asking people, "What's the algorithm? What's the rule for making this?"

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:28.958
and they'd say,

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
"Well, we just make it that way because it looks pretty, stupid." (Laughter)

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
But sometimes, that's not the case.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:39.958
In some cases, there would actually be algorithms, and very sophisticated algorithms.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
So in Manghetu sculpture, you'd see this recursive geometry.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:47.958
In Ethiopian crosses, you see this wonderful unfolding of the shape.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:51.958
In Angola, the Chokwe people draw lines in the sand,

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
and it's what the German mathematician Euler called a graph;

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
we now call it an Eulerian path --

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
you can never lift your stylus from the surface

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
and you can never go over the same line twice.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
But they do it recursively, and they do it with an age-grade system,

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
so the little kids learn this one, and then the older kids learn this one,

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
then the next age-grade initiation, you learn this one.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
And with each iteration of that algorithm,

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
you learn the iterations of the myth.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
You learn the next level of knowledge.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
And finally, all over Africa, you see this board game.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
It's called Owari in Ghana, where I studied it;

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:28.958
it's called Mancala here on the East Coast, Bao in Kenya, Sogo elsewhere.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:33.958
Well, you see self-organizing patterns that spontaneously occur in this board game.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:36.958
And the folks in Ghana knew about these self-organizing patterns

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.958
and would use them strategically.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
So this is very conscious knowledge.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
Here's a wonderful fractal.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:46.958
Anywhere you go in the Sahel, you'll see this windscreen.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:50.958
And of course fences around the world are all Cartesian, all strictly linear.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:54.958
But here in Africa, you've got these nonlinear scaling fences.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
So I tracked down one of the folks who makes these things,

00:09:56.958 --> 00:10:00.958
this guy in Mali just outside of Bamako, and I asked him,

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
"How come you're making fractal fences? Because nobody else is."

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
And his answer was very interesting.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:09.958
He said, "Well, if I lived in the jungle, I would only use the long rows of straw

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
because they're very quick and they're very cheap.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
It doesn't take much time, doesn't take much straw."

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
He said, "but wind and dust goes through pretty easily.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:20.958
Now, the tight rows up at the very top, they really hold out the wind and dust.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:25.958
But it takes a lot of time, and it takes a lot of straw because they're really tight."

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
"Now," he said, "we know from experience

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:32.958
that the farther up from the ground you go, the stronger the wind blows."

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.958
Right? It's just like a cost-benefit analysis.

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
And I measured out the lengths of straw,

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
put it on a log-log plot, got the scaling exponent,

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:44.958
and it almost exactly matches the scaling exponent for the relationship between wind speed and height

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:45.958
in the wind engineering handbook.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:50.958
So these guys are right on target for a practical use of scaling technology.

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:55.958
The most complex example of an algorithmic approach to fractals that I found

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
was actually not in geometry, it was in a symbolic code,

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:00.958
and this was Bamana sand divination.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.958
And the same divination system is found all over Africa.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:08.958
You can find it on the East Coast as well as the West Coast,

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
and often the symbols are very well preserved,

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:16.958
so each of these symbols has four bits -- it's a four-bit binary word --

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:21.958
you draw these lines in the sand randomly, and then you count off,

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
and if it's an odd number, you put down one stroke,

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
and if it's an even number, you put down two strokes.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:28.958
And they did this very rapidly,

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
and I couldn't understand where they were getting --

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
they only did the randomness four times --

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
I couldn't understand where they were getting the other 12 symbols.

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
And they wouldn't tell me.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.958
They said, "No, no, I can't tell you about this."

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
And I said, "Well look, I'll pay you, you can be my teacher,

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
and I'll come each day and pay you."

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
They said, "It's not a matter of money. This is a religious matter."

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:46.958
And finally, out of desperation, I said,

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
"Well, let me explain Georg Cantor in 1877."

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:53.958
And I started explaining why I was there in Africa,

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
and they got very excited when they saw the Cantor set.

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:59.958
And one of them said, "Come here. I think I can help you out here."

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:04.958
And so he took me through the initiation ritual for a Bamana priest.

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
And of course, I was only interested in the math,

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
so the whole time, he kept shaking his head going,

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:09.958
"You know, I didn't learn it this way."

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:13.958
But I had to sleep with a kola nut next to my bed, buried in sand,

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:16.958
and give seven coins to seven lepers and so on.

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:20.958
And finally, he revealed the truth of the matter.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:25.958
And it turns out it's a pseudo-random number generator using deterministic chaos.

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:31.958
When you have a four-bit symbol, you then put it together with another one sideways.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
So even plus odd gives you odd.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
Odd plus even gives you odd.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:38.958
Even plus even gives you even. Odd plus odd gives you even.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:42.958
It's addition modulo 2, just like in the parity bit check on your computer.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:46.958
And then you take this symbol, and you put it back in

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.958
so it's a self-generating diversity of symbols.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:52.958
They're truly using a kind of deterministic chaos in doing this.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
Now, because it's a binary code,

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
you can actually implement this in hardware --

00:12:56.958 --> 00:13:01.958
what a fantastic teaching tool that should be in African engineering schools.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.958
And the most interesting thing I found out about it was historical.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:10.958
In the 12th century, Hugo of Santalla brought it from Islamic mystics into Spain.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:16.958
And there it entered into the alchemy community as geomancy:

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
divination through the earth.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:23.958
This is a geomantic chart drawn for King Richard II in 1390.

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:26.958
Leibniz, the German mathematician,

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:30.958
talked about geomancy in his dissertation called "De Combinatoria."

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:34.958
And he said, "Well, instead of using one stroke and two strokes,

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:38.958
let's use a one and a zero, and we can count by powers of two."

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:40.958
Right? Ones and zeros, the binary code.

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
George Boole took Leibniz's binary code and created Boolean algebra,

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
and John von Neumann took Boolean algebra and created the digital computer.

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:49.958
So all these little PDAs and laptops --

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:52.958
every digital circuit in the world -- started in Africa.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:57.958
And I know Brian Eno says there's not enough Africa in computers,

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:02.958
but you know, I don't think there's enough African history in Brian Eno.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
(Laughter) (Applause)

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:09.958
So let me end with just a few words about applications that we've found for this.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:11.958
And you can go to our website,

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:13.958
the applets are all free; they just run in the browser.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
Anybody in the world can use them.

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:20.958
The National Science Foundation's Broadening Participation in Computing program

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:27.958
recently awarded us a grant to make a programmable version of these design tools,

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
so hopefully in three years, anybody'll be able to go on the Web

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
and create their own simulations and their own artifacts.

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:37.958
We've focused in the U.S. on African-American students as well as Native American and Latino.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:43.958
We've found statistically significant improvement with children using this software in a mathematics class

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
in comparison with a control group that did not have the software.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:52.958
So it's really very successful teaching children that they have a heritage that's about mathematics,

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:56.958
that it's not just about singing and dancing.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:59.958
We've started a pilot program in Ghana.

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:04.958
We got a small seed grant, just to see if folks would be willing to work with us on this;

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
we're very excited about the future possibilities for that.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
We've also been working in design.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:14.958
I didn't put his name up here -- my colleague, Kerry, in Kenya, has come up with this great idea

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:19.958
for using fractal structure for postal address in villages that have fractal structure,

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:23.958
because if you try to impose a grid structure postal system on a fractal village,

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
it doesn't quite fit.

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:30.958
Bernard Tschumi at Columbia University has finished using this in a design for a museum of African art.

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:38.958
David Hughes at Ohio State University has written a primer on Afrocentric architecture

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
in which he's used some of these fractal structures.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:45.958
And finally, I just wanted to point out that this idea of self-organization,

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:47.958
as we heard earlier, it's in the brain.

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:52.958
It's in the -- it's in Google's search engine.

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:54.958
Actually, the reason that Google was such a success

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:58.958
is because they were the first ones to take advantage of the self-organizing properties of the web.

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.958
It's in ecological sustainability.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:02.958
It's in the developmental power of entrepreneurship,

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:04.958
the ethical power of democracy.

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:07.958
It's also in some bad things.

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:10.958
Self-organization is why the AIDS virus is spreading so fast.

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:14.958
And if you don't think that capitalism, which is self-organizing, can have destructive effects,

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:16.958
you haven't opened your eyes enough.

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:20.958
So we need to think about, as was spoken earlier,

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:22.958
the traditional African methods for doing self-organization.

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:24.958
These are robust algorithms.

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:28.958
These are ways of doing self-organization -- of doing entrepreneurship --

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:30.958
that are gentle, that are egalitarian.

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:34.958
So if we want to find a better way of doing that kind of work,

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:39.958
we need look only no farther than Africa to find these robust self-organizing algorithms.

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:40.958
Thank you.

title: Design and destiny
transcript: You will understand nothing with my type of English. It's good for you because you can have a break after all these fantastic people. I must tell you I am like that, not very comfortable, because usually, in life, I think my job is absolutely useless. I mean, I feel useless. Now after Carolyn, and all the other guys, I feel like shit. And definitively, I don't know why I am here, but — you know the nightmare you can have, like you are an impostor, you arrive at the opera, and they push you, "You must sing!" I don't know. (Laughter)So, so, because I have nothing to show, nothing to say, we shall try to speak about something else. We can start, if you want, by understanding — it's just to start, it's not interesting, but — how I work. When somebody comes to me and ask for what I am known, I mean, yes, lemon squeezer, toilet brush, toothpick, beautiful toilet seats, and why not — a toothbrush? I don't try to design the toothbrush. I don't try to say, "Oh, that will be a beautiful object," or something like that. That doesn't interest me.Because there is different types of design. The one, we can call it the cynical design, that means the design invented by Raymond Loewy in the '50s, who said, what is ugly is a bad sale, la laideur se vend mal, which is terrible. It means the design must be just the weapon for marketing, for producer to make product more sexy, like that, they sell more: it's shit, it's obsolete, it's ridiculous. I call that the cynical design.After, there is the narcissistic design: it's a fantastic designer who designs only for other fantastic designers. (Laughter) After, there is people like me, who try to deserve to exist, and who are so ashamed to make this useless job, who try to do it in another way, and they try, I try, to not make the object for the object but for the result, for the profit for the human being, the person who will use it. If we take the toothbrush — I don't think about the toothbrush. I think, "What will be the effect of the brush in the mouth?" And to understand what will be the effect of the toothbrush in the mouth, I must imagine: Who owns this mouth? What is the life of the owner of this mouth? In what society [does] this guy live? What civilization creates this society? What animal species creates this civilization? When I arrive — and I take one minute, I am not so intelligent — when I arrive at the level of animal species, that becomes real interesting.Me, I have strictly no power to change anything. But when I come back, I can understand why I shall not do it, because today to not do it, it's more positive than do it, or how I shall do it. But to come back, where I am at the animal species, there is things to see. There is things to see, there is the big challenge. The big challenge in front of us. Because there is not a human production which exists outside of what I call "the big image." The big image is our story, our poetry, our romanticism. Our poetry is our mutation, our life. We must remember, and we can see that in any book of my son of 10 years old, that life appears four billion years ago, around — four billion point two?Voice offstage: Four point five.Yes, point five, OK, OK, OK! (Laughter) I'm a designer, that's all, of Christmas gifts. And before, there was this soup, called "soupe primordiale," this first soup — bloop bloop bloop — sort of dirty mud, no life, nothing. So then — pshoo-shoo — lightning — pshoo — arrive — pshoo-shoo — makes life — bloop bloop — and that dies. Some million years after — pshoo-shoo, bloop-bloop — ah, wake up! At the end, finally, that succeeds, and life appears. We was so, so stupid. The most stupid bacteria. Even, I think, we copy our way to reproduce, you know what I mean, and something of — oh no, forget it.After, we become a fish; after, we become a frog; after, we become a monkey; after, we become what we are today: a super-monkey, and the fun is, the super-monkey we are today, is at half of the story. Can you imagine? From that stupid bacteria to us, with a microphone, with a computer, with an iPod: four billion years. And we know, and especially Carolyn knows, that when the sun will implode, the earth will burn, explode, I don't know what, and this is scheduled for four, four billion years? Yes, she said, something like that. OK, that means we are at half of the story. Fantastic! It's a beauty! Can you imagine? It's very symbolic. Because the bacteria we was had no idea of what we are today. And today, we have no idea of what we shall be in four billion years. And this territory is fantastic.That is our poetry. That is our beautiful story. It's our romanticism. Mu-ta-tion. We are mutants. And if we don't deeply understand, if we don't integrate that we are mutants, we completely miss the story. Because every generation thinks we are the final one. We have a way to look at Earth like that, you know, "I am the man. The final man. You know, we mutate during four billion years before, but now, because it's me, we stop. Fin. (Laughter) For the end, for the eternity, it is one with a red jacket." Something like that. I am not sure of that. (Laughter) Because that is our intelligence of mutation and things like that. There is so many things to do; it's so fresh.And here is something: nobody is obliged to be a genius, but everybody is obliged to participate. And to participate, for a mutant, there is a minimum of exercise, a minimum of sport. We can say that. The first, if you want — there is so many — but one which is very easy to do, is the duty of vision. I can explain you. I shall try. If you walk like that, it's OK, it's OK, you can walk, but perhaps, because you walk with the eyes like that, you will not see, oh, there is a hole. And you will fall, and you will die. Dangerous.That's why, perhaps, you will try to have this angle of vision. OK, I can see, if I found something, up, up, and they continue, up up up. I raise the angle of vision, but it's still very — selfish, selfish, egoiste — yes, selfish. You, you survive. It's OK. If you raise the level of your eyes a little more you go, "I see you, oh my God you are here, how are you, I can help you, I can design for you a new toothbrush, new toilet brush," something like that. I live in society; I live in community. It's OK. You start to be in the territory of intelligence, we can say. From this level, the more you can raise this angle of view, the more you will be important for the society. The more you will rise, the more you will be important for the civilization. The more you will rise, to see far and high, like that, the more you will be important for the story of our mutation. That means intelligent people are in this angle. That is intelligence. From this to here, that, it's genius. Ptolemy, Eratosthenes, Einstein, things like that. Nobody's obliged to be a genius. It's better, but nobody.Take care, in this training, to be a good mutant. There is some danger, there is some trap. One trap: the vertical. Because at the vertical of us, if you look like that, "Ah! my God, there is God. Ah! God!" God is a trap. God is the answer when we don't know the answer. That means, when your brain is not enough big, when you don't understand, you go, "Ah, it's God, it's God." That's ridiculous. That's why — jump, like that? No, don't jump. Come back. Because, after, there is another trap. If you look like that, you look to the past, or you look inside if you are very flexible, inside yourself. It's called schizophrenia, and you are dead also.That's why every morning, now, because you are a good mutant, you will raise your angle of view. Out, more of the horizontal. You are an intelligence. Never forget — like that, like that. It's very, very, very important. What, what else we can say about that? Why do that? It's because we — if we look from far, we see our line of evolution. This line of evolution is clearly positive. From far, this line looks very smooth, like that. But if you take a lens, like that, this line is ack, ack, ack, ack, ack. Like that. It's made of light and shadow. We can say light is civilization, shadow is barbaria. And it's very important to know where we are. Because some cycle, there is a spot in the cycle, and you have not the same duty in the different parts of the cycle.That means, we can imagine — I don't say it was fantastic, but in the '80s, there was not too much war, like that, it was — we can imagine that the civilization can become civilized. In this case, people like me are acceptable. We can say, "It's luxurious time." We have time to think, we have time to I don't know what, speak about art and things like that. It's OK. We are in the light. But sometimes, like today, we fall, we fall so fast, so fast to shadow, we fall so fast to barbaria. With many, many, many, many face of barbaria. Because it's not, the barbaria we have today, it's perhaps not the barbaria we think. There is different type of barbaria. That's why we must adapt. That means, when barbaria is back, forget the beautiful chairs, forget the beautiful hotel, forget design, even — I'm sorry to say — forget art. Forget all that. There is priority; there is urgency. You must go back to politics, you must go back to radicalization, I'm sorry if that's not very English. You must go back to fight, to battle.That's why today I'm so ashamed to make this job. That's why I am here, to try to do it the best possible. But I know that even I do it the best possible — that's why I'm the best — it's nothing. Because it's not the right time. That's why I say that. I say that, because, I repeat, nothing exist if it's not in the good reason, the reason of our beautiful dream, of this civilization. And because we must all work to finish this story. Because the scenario of this civilization — about love, progress, and things like that — it's OK, but there is so many different, other scenarios of other civilizations. This scenario, of this civilization, was about becoming powerful, intelligent, like this idea we have invented, this concept of God. We are God now. We are. It's almost done. We have just to finish the story. That is very, very important. And when you don't understand really what's happened, you cannot go and fight and work and build and things like that. You go to the future back, back, back, back, like that. And you can fall, and it's very dangerous. No, you must really understand that.Because we have almost finished, I'll repeat this story. And the beauty of this, in perhaps 50 years, 60 years, we can finish completely this civilization, and offer to our children the possibility to invent a new story, a new poetry, a new romanticism. With billions of people who have been born, worked, lived and died before us, these people who have worked so much, we have now bring beautiful things, beautiful gifts, we know so many things. We can say to our children, OK, done, that was our story. That passed. Now you have a duty: invent a new story. Invent a new poetry. The only rule is, we have not to have any idea about the next story. We give you white pages. Invent. We give you the best tools, the best tools, and now, do it. That's why I continue to work, even if it's for toilet brush.
