title: The emergent genius of ant colonies
transcript: I study ants, and that's because I like to think about how organizations work. And in particular, how the simple parts of organizations interact to create the behavior of the whole organization. So, ant colonies are a good example of an organization like that, and there are many others. The web is one. There are many biological systems like that — brains, cells, developing embryos.There are about 10,000 species of ants. They all live in colonies consisting of one or a few queens, and then all the ants you see walking around are sterile female workers. And all ant colonies have in common that there's no central control. Nobody tells anybody what to do. The queen just lays the eggs. There's no management. No ant directs the behavior of any other ant. And I try to figure out how that works. And I've been working for the past 20 years on a population of seed-eating ants in southeastern Arizona.Here's my study site. This is really a picture of ants, and the rabbit just happens to be there. And these ants are called harvester ants because they eat seeds. This is the nest of the mature colony, and there's the nest entrance. And they forage maybe for about 20 meters away, gather up the seeds and bring them back to the nest, and store them. And every year I go there and make a map of my study site. This is just a road. And it's not very big: it's about 250 meters on one side, 400 on the other. And every colony has a name, which is a number, which is painted on a rock. And I go there every year and look for all the colonies that were alive the year before, and figure out which ones have died, and put all the new ones on the map. And by doing this I know how old they all are. And because of that, I've been able to study how their behavior changes as the colony gets older and larger.So I want to tell you about the life cycle of a colony. Ants never make more ants; colonies make more colonies. And they do that by each year sending out the reproductives — those are the ones with wings — on a mating flight. So every year, on the same day — and it's a mystery exactly how that happens — each colony sends out its virgin, unmated queens with wings, and the males, and they all fly to a common place. And they mate. And this shows a recently virgin queen. Here's her wings. And she's in the process of mating with this male, and there's another male on top waiting his turn. Often the queens mate more than once. And after that, the males all die. That's it for them.(Laughter)And then the newly mated queens fly off somewhere, drop their wings, dig a hole and go into that hole and start laying eggs. And they will live for 15 or 20 years, continuing to lay eggs using the sperm from that original mating. So the queen goes down in there. She lays eggs, she feeds the larvae — so an ant starts as an egg, then it's a larva. She feeds the larvae by regurgitating from her fat reserves. Then, as soon as the ants — the first group of ants — emerge, they're larvae. Then they're pupae. Then they come out as adult ants. They go out, they get the food, they dig the nest, and the queen never comes out again.So this is a one-year-old colony — this happens to be 536. There's the nest entrance, there's a pencil for scale. So this is the colony founded by a queen the previous summer. This is a three-year-old colony. There's the nest entrance, there's a pencil for scale. They make a midden, a pile of refuse — mostly the husks of the seeds that they eat. This is a five-year-old colony. This is the nest entrance, here's a pencil for scale. This is about as big as they get, about a meter across. And then this is how colony size and numbers of worker ants changes — so this is about 10,000 worker ants — changes as a function of colony age, in years. So it starts out with zero ants, just the founding queen, and it grows to a size of about 10 or 12 thousand ants when the colony is five. And it stays that size until the queen dies and there's nobody to make more ants, when she's about 15 or 20 years old. And it's when they reach this stable size, in numbers of ants, that they start to reproduce. That is, to send more winged queens and males to that year's mating flight. And I know how colony size changes as a function of colony age because I've dug up colonies of known age and counted all the ants. (Laughter) So that's not the most fun part of this research, although it's interesting.(Laughter)Really the question that I think about with these ants is what I call task allocation. That's not just how is the colony organized, but how does it change what it's doing? How is it that the colony manages to adjust the numbers of workers performing each task as conditions change? So, things happen to an ant colony. When it rains in the summer, it floods in the desert. There's a lot of damage to the nest, and extra ants are needed to clean up that mess. When extra food becomes available — and this is what everybody knows about picnics — then extra ants are allocated to collect the food. So, with nobody telling anybody what to do, how is it that the colony manages to adjust the numbers of workers performing each task? And that's the process that I call task allocation.And in harvester ants, I divide the tasks of the ants I see just outside the nest into these four categories: where an ant is foraging, when it's out along the foraging trail, searching for food or bringing food back. The patrollers — that's supposed to be a magnifying glass — are an interesting group that go out early in the morning before the foragers are active. They somehow choose the direction that the foragers will go, and by coming back — just by making it back — they tell the foragers that it's safe to go out. Then the nest maintenance workers work inside the nest, and I wanted to say that the nests look a lot like Bill Lishman's house. That is, that there are chambers inside, they line the walls of the chambers with moist soil and it dries to a kind of an adobe-like surface in it. It also looks very similar to some of the cave dwellings of the Hopi people that are in that area. And the nest maintenance workers do that inside the nest, and then they come out of the nest carrying bits of dry soil in their mandibles. So you see the nest maintenance workers come out with a bit of sand, put it down, turn around, and go back in. And finally, the midden workers put some kind of territorial chemical in the garbage. So what you see the midden workers doing is making a pile of refuse. On one day, it'll all be here, and then the next day they'll move it over there, and then they'll move it back. So that's what the midden workers do. And these four groups are just the ants outside the nest. So that's only about 25 percent of the colony, and they're the oldest ants.So, an ant starts out somewhere near the queen. And when we dig up nests we find they're about as deep as the colony is wide, so about a meter deep for the big old nests. And then there's another long tunnel and a chamber, where we often find the queen, after eight hours of hacking away at the rock with pickaxes. I don't think that chamber has evolved because of me and my backhoe and my crew of students with pickaxes, but instead because when there's flooding, occasionally the colony has to go down deep. So there's this whole network of chambers. The queen's in there somewhere; she just lays eggs. There's the larvae, and they consume most of the food. And this is true of most ants — that the ants you see walking around don't do much eating. They bring it back and feed it to the larvae. When the foragers come in with food, they just drop it into the upper chamber, and other ants come up from below, get the food, bring it back, husk the seeds, and pile them up. There are nest maintenance workers working throughout the nest. And curiously, and interestingly, it looks as though at any time about half the ants in the colony are just doing nothing. So, despite what it says in the Bible, about, you know, "Look to the ant, thou sluggard," in fact, you could think of those ants as reserves. That is to say, if something happened — and I've never seen anything like this happen, but I've only been looking for 20 years — if something happened, they might all come out if they were needed. But in fact, mostly they're just hanging around in there.And I think it's a very interesting question — what is there about the way the colony is organized that might give some function to a reserve of ants who are doing nothing? And they sort of stand as a buffer in between the ants working deep inside the nest and the ants working outside. And if you mark ants that are working outside, and dig up a colony, you never see them deep down. So what's happening is that the ants work inside the nest when they're younger. They somehow get into this reserve. And then eventually they get recruited to join this exterior workforce. And once they belong to the ants that work outside, they never go back down. Now ants — most ants, including these, don't see very well. They have eyes, they can distinguish between light and dark, but they mostly work by smell. So just to reinforce that what you might have thought about ant queens isn't true — you know, even if the queen did have the intelligence to send chemical messages through this whole network of chambers to tell the ants outside what to do, there is no way that such messages could make it in time to see the shifts in the allocation of workers that we actually see outside the nest. So that's one way that we know the queen isn't directing the behavior of the colony.So when I first set out to work on task allocation, my first question was, "What's the relationship between the ants doing different tasks? Does it matter to the foragers what the nest maintenance workers are doing? Does it matter to the midden workers what the patrollers are doing?" And I was working in the context of a view of ant colonies in which each ant was somehow dedicated to its task from birth and sort of performed independently of the others, knowing its place on the assembly line. And instead I wanted to ask, "How are the different task groups interdependent?"So I did experiments where I changed one thing. So for example, I created more work for the nest maintenance workers by putting out a pile of toothpicks near the nest entrance, early in the morning when the nest maintenance workers are first active. This is what it looks like about 20 minutes later. Here it is about 40 minutes later. And the nest maintenance workers just take all the toothpicks to the outer edge of the nest mound and leave them there. And what I wanted to know was, "OK, here's a situation where extra nest maintenance workers were recruited — is this going to have any effect on the workers performing other tasks?" Then we repeated all those experiments with the ants marked. So here's some blue nest maintenance workers. And lately we've gotten more sophisticated and we have this three-color system. And we can mark them individually so we know which ant is which. We started out with model airplane paint and then we found these wonderful little Japanese markers, and they work really well. And so just to summarize the result, well it turns out that yes, the different tasks are interdependent. So, if I change the numbers performing one task, it changes the numbers performing another. So for example, if I make a mess that the nest maintenance workers have to clean up, then I see fewer ants out foraging. And this was true for all the pair-wise combinations of tasks.And the second result, which was surprising to a lot of people, was that ants actually switch tasks. The same ant doesn't do the same task over and over its whole life. So for example, if I put out extra food, everybody else — the midden workers stop doing midden work and go get the food, they become foragers. The nest maintenance workers become foragers. The patrollers become foragers. But not every transition is possible. And this shows how it works. Like I just said, if there is more food to collect, the patrollers, the midden workers, the nest maintenance workers will all change to forage. If there's more patrolling to do — so I created a disturbance, so extra patrollers were needed — the nest maintenance workers will switch to patrol. But if more nest maintenance work is needed — for example, if I put out a bunch of toothpicks — then nobody will ever switch back to nest maintenance, they have to get nest maintenance workers from inside the nest. So foraging acts as a sink, and the ants inside the nest act as a source. And finally, it looks like each ant is deciding moment to moment whether to be active or not.So, for example, when there's extra nest maintenance work to do, it's not that the foragers switch over. I know that they don't do that. But the foragers somehow decide not to come out. And here was the most intriguing result: the task allocation. This process changes with colony age, and it changes like this. When I do these experiments with older colonies — so ones that are five years or older — they're much more consistent from one time to another and much more homeostatic. The worse things get, the more I hassle them, the more they act like undisturbed colonies. Whereas the young, small colonies — the two-year-old colonies of just 2,000 ants — are much more variable. And the amazing thing about this is that an ant lives only a year. It could be this year, or this year. So, the ants in the older colony that seem to be more stable are not any older than the ants in the younger colony. It's not due to the experience of older, wiser ants. Instead, something about the organization must be changing as the colony gets older. And the obvious thing that's changing is its size.So since I've had this result, I've spent a lot of time trying to figure out what kinds of decision rules — very simple, local, probably olfactory, chemical rules could an ant could be using, since no ant can assess the global situation — that would have the outcome that I see, these predictable dynamics, in who does what task. And it would change as the colony gets larger. And what I've found out is that ants are using a network of antennal contact. So anybody who's ever looked at ants has seen them touch antennae. They smell with their antennae. When one ant touches another, it's smelling it, and it can tell, for example, whether the other ant is a nest mate because ants cover themselves and each other, through grooming, with a layer of grease, which carries a colony-specific odor. And what we're learning is that an ant uses the pattern of its antennal contacts, the rate at which it meets ants of other tasks, in deciding what to do. And so what the message is, is not any message that they transmit from one ant to another, but the pattern. The pattern itself is the message. And I'll tell you a little bit more about that.But first you might be wondering: how is it that an ant can tell, for example, I'm a forager. I expect to meet another forager every so often. But if instead I start to meet a higher number of nest maintenance workers, I'm less likely to forage. So it has to know the difference between a forager and a nest maintenance worker. And we've learned that, in this species — and I suspect in others as well — these hydrocarbons, this layer of grease on the outside of ants, is different as ants perform different tasks. And we've done experiments that show that that's because the longer an ant stays outside, the more these simple hydrocarbons on its surface change, and so they come to smell different by doing different tasks. And they can use that task-specific odor in cuticular hydrocarbons — they can use that in their brief antennal contacts to somehow keep track of the rate at which they're meeting ants of certain tasks. And we've just recently demonstrated this by putting extract of hydrocarbons on little glass beads, and dropping the beads gently down into the nest entrance at the right rate. And it turns out that ants will respond to the right rate of contact with a glass bead with hydrocarbon extract on it, as they would to contact with real ants.So I want now to show you a bit of film — and this will start out, first of all, showing you the nest entrance. So the idea is that ants are coming in and out of the nest entrance. They've gone out to do different tasks, and the rate at which they meet as they come in and out of the nest entrance determines, or influences, each ant's decision about whether to go out, and which task to perform. This is taken through a fiber optics microscope. It's down inside the nest. In the beginning you see the ants just kind of engaging with the fiber optics microscope. But the idea is that the ants are in there, and each ant is experiencing a certain flow of ants past it — a stream of contacts with other ants. And the pattern of these interactions determines whether the ant comes back out, and what it does when it comes back out. You can also see this in the ants just outside the nest entrance like these. Each ant, then, as it comes back in, is contacting other ants. And the ants that are waiting just inside the nest entrance to decide whether to go out on their next trip, are contacting the ants coming in.So, what's interesting about this system is that it's messy. It's variable. It's noisy. And, in particular, in two ways. The first is that the experience of the ant — of each ant — can't be very predictable. Because the rate at which ants come back depends on all the little things that happen to an ant as it goes out and does its task outside. And the second thing is that an ant's ability to assess this pattern must be very crude because no ant can do any sophisticated counting. So, we do a lot of simulation and modeling, and also experimental work, to try to figure out how those two kinds of noise combine to, in the aggregate, produce the predictable behavior of ant colonies.Again, I don't want to say that this kind of haphazard pattern of interactions produces a factory that works with the precision and efficiency of clockwork. In fact, if you watch ants at all, you end up trying to help them because they never seem to be doing anything exactly the way that you think that they ought to be doing it. So it's not really that out of these haphazard contacts, perfection arises. But it works pretty well. Ants have been around for several hundred million years. They cover the earth, except for Antarctica. Something that they're doing is clearly successful enough that this pattern of haphazard contacts, in the aggregate, produces something that allows ants to make a lot more ants. And one of the things that we're studying is how natural selection might be acting now to shape this use of interaction patterns — this network of interaction patterns — to perhaps increase the foraging efficiency of ant colonies.So the one thing, though, that I want you to remember about this is that these patterns of interactions are something that you'd expect to be closely connected to colony size. The simplest idea is that when an ant is in a small colony — and an ant in a large colony can use the same rule, like "I expect to meet another forager every three seconds." But in a small colony, it's likely to meet fewer foragers, just because there are fewer other foragers there to meet. So this is the kind of rule that, as the colony develops and gets older and larger, will produce different behavior in an old colony and a small young one.Thank you.(Applause)

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:21.958
Then the nest maintenance workers work inside the nest,

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:26.958
and I wanted to say that the nests look a lot like Bill Lishman's house.

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
That is, that there are chambers inside,

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:32.958
they line the walls of the chambers with moist soil

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:35.958
and it dries to a kind of an adobe-like surface in it.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:38.958
It also looks very similar to some of the cave dwellings

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
of the Hopi people that are in that area.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:45.958
And the nest maintenance workers do that inside the nest,

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958
and then they come out of the nest carrying bits of dry soil in their mandibles.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:51.958
So you see the nest maintenance workers come out with a bit of sand,

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:53.958
put it down, turn around, and go back in.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:07:01.958
And finally, the midden workers put some kind of territorial chemical in the garbage.

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:04.958
So what you see the midden workers doing is making a pile of refuse.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
On one day, it'll all be here, and then the next day

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
they'll move it over there, and then they'll move it back.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:12.958
So that's what the midden workers do.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:16.958
And these four groups are just the ants outside the nest.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:20.958
So that's only about 25 percent of the colony, and they're the oldest ants.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:23.958
So, an ant starts out somewhere near the queen.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:26.958
And when we dig up nests we find they're about as deep

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:30.958
as the colony is wide, so about a meter deep for the big old nests.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:35.958
And then there's another long tunnel and a chamber, where we often find the queen,

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:39.958
after eight hours of hacking away at the rock with pickaxes.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:43.958
I don't think that chamber has evolved because of me and my backhoe

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
and my crew of students with pickaxes,

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
but instead because when there's flooding,

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
occasionally the colony has to go down deep.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
So there's this whole network of chambers.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:55.958
The queen's in there somewhere; she just lays eggs.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
There's the larvae, and they consume most of the food.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:00.958
And this is true of most ants --

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:02.958
that the ants you see walking around don't do much eating.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
They bring it back and feed it to the larvae.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:09.958
When the foragers come in with food, they just drop it into the upper chamber,

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
and other ants come up from below, get the food,

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:15.958
bring it back, husk the seeds, and pile them up.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
There are nest maintenance workers working throughout the nest.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:23.958
And curiously, and interestingly, it looks as though at any time

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
about half the ants in the colony are just doing nothing.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
So, despite what it says in the Bible,

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:32.958
about, you know, "Look to the ant, thou sluggard,"

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:35.958
in fact, you could think of those ants as reserves.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:38.958
That is to say, if something happened -- and I've never seen anything like this happen,

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
but I've only been looking for 20 years --

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:44.958
if something happened, they might all come out if they were needed.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:46.958
But in fact, mostly they're just hanging around in there.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:48.958
And I think it's a very interesting question --

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.958
what is there about the way the colony is organized

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:58.958
that might give some function to a reserve of ants who are doing nothing?

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:02.958
And they sort of stand as a buffer in between

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:05.958
the ants working deep inside the nest and the ants working outside.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:09.958
And if you mark ants that are working outside, and dig up a colony,

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:11.958
you never see them deep down.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:16.958
So what's happening is that the ants work inside the nest when they're younger.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:18.958
They somehow get into this reserve.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:22.958
And then eventually they get recruited to join this exterior workforce.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:26.958
And once they belong to the ants that work outside, they never go back down.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:30.958
Now ants -- most ants, including these, don't see very well.

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.958
They have eyes, they can distinguish between light and dark,

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
but they mostly work by smell.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:39.958
So just to reinforce that what you might have thought

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.958
about ant queens isn't true --

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:44.958
you know, even if the queen did have the intelligence

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:48.958
to send chemical messages through this whole network of chambers

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:50.958
to tell the ants outside what to do,

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:54.958
there is no way that such messages could make it in time to see

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:59.958
the shifts in the allocation of workers that we actually see outside the nest.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:03.958
So that's one way that we know the queen isn't directing the behavior of the colony.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:07.958
So when I first set out to work on task allocation,

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.958
my first question was, "What's the relationship

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:13.958
between the ants doing different tasks?

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
Does it matter to the foragers what the nest maintenance workers are doing?

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:19.958
Does it matter to the midden workers what the patrollers are doing?"

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:25.958
And I was working in the context of a view of ant colonies in which each ant

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:28.958
was somehow dedicated to its task from birth

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:31.958
and sort of performed independently of the others,

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
knowing its place on the assembly line.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:37.958
And instead I wanted to ask, "How are the different task groups interdependent?"

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
So I did experiments where I changed one thing.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:43.958
So for example, I created more work for the nest maintenance workers

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:47.958
by putting out a pile of toothpicks near the nest entrance,

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:51.958
early in the morning when the nest maintenance workers are first active.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.958
This is what it looks like about 20 minutes later.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
Here it is about 40 minutes later.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
And the nest maintenance workers just take all the toothpicks

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:00.958
to the outer edge of the nest mound and leave them there.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.958
And what I wanted to know was, "OK,

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:06.958
here's a situation where extra nest maintenance workers were recruited --

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:10.958
is this going to have any effect on the workers performing other tasks?"

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:14.958
Then we repeated all those experiments with the ants marked.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
So here's some blue nest maintenance workers.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
And lately we've gotten more sophisticated

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
and we have this three-color system.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.958
And we can mark them individually so we know which ant is which.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:26.958
We started out with model airplane paint

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:28.958
and then we found these wonderful little Japanese markers,

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
and they work really well.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
And so just to summarize the result,

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
well it turns out that yes, the different tasks are interdependent.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
So, if I change the numbers performing one task,

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
it changes the numbers performing another.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
So for example, if I make a mess

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
that the nest maintenance workers have to clean up,

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
then I see fewer ants out foraging.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
And this was true for all the pair-wise combinations of tasks.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:54.958
And the second result, which was surprising to a lot of people,

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
was that ants actually switch tasks.

00:11:56.958 --> 00:12:00.958
The same ant doesn't do the same task over and over its whole life.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
So for example, if I put out extra food, everybody else --

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
the midden workers stop doing midden work and go get the food,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
they become foragers.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
The nest maintenance workers become foragers.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
The patrollers become foragers.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:15.958
But not every transition is possible. And this shows how it works.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:19.958
Like I just said, if there is more food to collect, the patrollers, the midden workers,

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:21.958
the nest maintenance workers will all change to forage.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:23.958
If there's more patrolling to do --

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:27.958
so I created a disturbance, so extra patrollers were needed --

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:29.958
the nest maintenance workers will switch to patrol.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.958
But if more nest maintenance work is needed --

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
for example, if I put out a bunch of toothpicks --

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:37.958
then nobody will ever switch back to nest maintenance,

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:40.958
they have to get nest maintenance workers from inside the nest.

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:46.958
So foraging acts as a sink, and the ants inside the nest act as a source.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:49.958
And finally, it looks like each ant is deciding

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
moment to moment whether to be active or not.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:56.958
So, for example, when there's extra nest maintenance work to do,

00:12:56.958 --> 00:13:00.958
it's not that the foragers switch over. I know that they don't do that.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
But the foragers somehow decide not to come out.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:06.958
And here was the most intriguing result: the task allocation.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:10.958
This process changes with colony age, and it changes like this.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
When I do these experiments with older colonies --

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:15.958
so ones that are five years or older --

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:18.958
they're much more consistent from one time to another

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
and much more homeostatic. The worse things get,

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:23.958
the more I hassle them, the more they act like undisturbed colonies.

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
Whereas the young, small colonies --

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:29.958
the two-year-old colonies of just 2,000 ants -- are much more variable.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:34.958
And the amazing thing about this is that an ant lives only a year.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
It could be this year, or this year.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:40.958
So, the ants in the older colony that seem to be more stable

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
are not any older than the ants in the younger colony.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
It's not due to the experience of older, wiser ants.

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
Instead, something about the organization

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:51.958
must be changing as the colony gets older.

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:54.958
And the obvious thing that's changing is its size.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:14:00.958
So since I've had this result, I've spent a lot of time trying to figure out

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:06.958
what kinds of decision rules -- very simple, local, probably olfactory, chemical

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:11.958
rules could an ant could be using, since no ant can assess the global situation --

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:14.958
that would have the outcome that I see,

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
these predictable dynamics, in who does what task.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
And it would change as the colony gets larger.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:27.958
And what I've found out is that ants are using a network of antennal contact.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:30.958
So anybody who's ever looked at ants has seen them touch antennae.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:32.958
They smell with their antennae.

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
When one ant touches another, it's smelling it,

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:38.958
and it can tell, for example, whether the other ant is a nest mate

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:42.958
because ants cover themselves and each other, through grooming,

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:46.958
with a layer of grease, which carries a colony-specific odor.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:51.958
And what we're learning is that an ant uses the pattern of its antennal contacts,

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:56.958
the rate at which it meets ants of other tasks, in deciding what to do.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:59.958
And so what the message is, is not any message

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:03.958
that they transmit from one ant to another, but the pattern.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
The pattern itself is the message.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
And I'll tell you a little bit more about that.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
But first you might be wondering:

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:14.958
how is it that an ant can tell, for example, I'm a forager.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:16.958
I expect to meet another forager every so often.

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:20.958
But if instead I start to meet a higher number of nest maintenance workers,

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
I'm less likely to forage.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:24.958
So it has to know the difference between

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
a forager and a nest maintenance worker.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:29.958
And we've learned that, in this species --

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:32.958
and I suspect in others as well --

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:36.958
these hydrocarbons, this layer of grease on the outside of ants,

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:39.958
is different as ants perform different tasks.

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:41.958
And we've done experiments that show that

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:43.958
that's because the longer an ant stays outside,

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:47.958
the more these simple hydrocarbons on its surface change,

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:50.958
and so they come to smell different by doing different tasks.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:54.958
And they can use that task-specific odor in cuticular hydrocarbons --

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:58.958
they can use that in their brief antennal contacts to somehow

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:02.958
keep track of the rate at which they're meeting ants of certain tasks.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.958
And we've just recently demonstrated this

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:09.958
by putting extract of hydrocarbons on little glass beads,

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:13.958
and dropping the beads gently down into the nest entrance at the right rate.

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:17.958
And it turns out that ants will respond to the right rate of contact

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:20.958
with a glass bead with hydrocarbon extract on it,

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:23.958
as they would to contact with real ants.

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:28.958
So I want now to show you a bit of film --

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:37.958
and this will start out, first of all, showing you the nest entrance.

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:40.958
So the idea is that ants are coming in and out of the nest entrance.

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:45.958
They've gone out to do different tasks, and the rate at which they meet

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:49.958
as they come in and out of the nest entrance determines, or influences,

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:53.958
each ant's decision about whether to go out, and which task to perform.

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:57.958
This is taken through a fiber optics microscope. It's down inside the nest.

00:16:57.958 --> 00:16:59.958
In the beginning you see the ants

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:01.958
just kind of engaging with the fiber optics microscope.

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:05.958
But the idea is that the ants are in there,

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:10.958
and each ant is experiencing a certain flow of ants past it --

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:13.958
a stream of contacts with other ants.

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:16.958
And the pattern of these interactions determines

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:21.958
whether the ant comes back out, and what it does when it comes back out.

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:28.958
You can also see this in the ants just outside the nest entrance like these.

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:32.958
Each ant, then, as it comes back in, is contacting other ants.

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:35.958
And the ants that are waiting just inside the nest entrance

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:38.958
to decide whether to go out on their next trip,

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:40.958
are contacting the ants coming in.

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:44.958
So, what's interesting about this system is that it's messy.

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:49.958
It's variable. It's noisy. And, in particular, in two ways.

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:54.958
The first is that the experience of the ant -- of each ant -- can't be very predictable.

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:57.958
Because the rate at which ants come back depends on

00:17:57.958 --> 00:18:02.958
all the little things that happen to an ant as it goes out and does its task outside.

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:07.958
And the second thing is that an ant's ability to assess this pattern

00:18:07.958 --> 00:18:13.958
must be very crude because no ant can do any sophisticated counting.

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:18.958
So, we do a lot of simulation and modeling, and also experimental work,

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:24.958
to try to figure out how those two kinds of noise combine to,

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:28.958
in the aggregate, produce the predictable behavior of ant colonies.

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:35.958
Again, I don't want to say that this kind of haphazard pattern of interactions

00:18:35.958 --> 00:18:42.958
produces a factory that works with the precision and efficiency of clockwork.

00:18:42.958 --> 00:18:45.958
In fact, if you watch ants at all, you end up trying to help them

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:47.958
because they never seem to be doing anything

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:50.958
exactly the way that you think that they ought to be doing it.

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:57.958
So it's not really that out of these haphazard contacts, perfection arises.

00:18:57.958 --> 00:18:59.958
But it works pretty well.

00:18:59.958 --> 00:19:02.958
Ants have been around for several hundred million years.

00:19:02.958 --> 00:19:05.958
They cover the earth, except for Antarctica.

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:09.958
Something that they're doing is clearly successful enough

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:12.958
that this pattern of haphazard contacts, in the aggregate,

00:19:12.958 --> 00:19:16.958
produces something that allows ants to make a lot more ants.

00:19:16.958 --> 00:19:19.958
And one of the things that we're studying is how natural selection

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:26.958
might be acting now to shape this use of interaction patterns --

00:19:26.958 --> 00:19:28.958
this network of interaction patterns --

00:19:28.958 --> 00:19:33.958
to perhaps increase the foraging efficiency of ant colonies.

00:19:33.958 --> 00:19:36.958
So the one thing, though, that I want you to remember about this

00:19:36.958 --> 00:19:39.958
is that these patterns of interactions

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:44.958
are something that you'd expect to be closely connected to colony size.

00:19:44.958 --> 00:19:49.958
The simplest idea is that when an ant is in a small colony --

00:19:49.958 --> 00:19:53.958
and an ant in a large colony can use the same rule,

00:19:53.958 --> 00:19:57.958
like "I expect to meet another forager every three seconds."

00:19:57.958 --> 00:20:00.958
But in a small colony, it's likely to meet fewer foragers,

00:20:00.958 --> 00:20:04.958
just because there are fewer other foragers there to meet.

00:20:04.958 --> 00:20:10.958
So this is the kind of rule that, as the colony develops and gets older and larger,

00:20:10.958 --> 00:20:15.958
will produce different behavior in an old colony and a small young one.

00:20:15.958 --> 00:20:17.958
Thank you.

00:20:17.958 --> 00:20:19.958
(Applause)

title: The mystery box
transcript: Here's my thing. Hold on. There I go. Hey. I want to start today — talk about the structure of a polypeptide.(Laughter)I get a lot of people asking me, in terms of "Lost," you know, "What the hell's that island?" You know, it's usually followed by, "No, seriously, what the hell is that island?"Why so many mysteries? What is it about mystery that I seem to be drawn to? And I was thinking about this, what to talk about at TED. When I talked to the kind rep from TED, and I said, "Listen, you know, what should I talk about?" He said, "Don't worry about it. Just be profound."(Laughter)And I took enormous comfort in that. So thank you, if you're here.I was trying to think, what do I talk about? Good question. Why do I do so much stuff that involves mystery? And I started trying to figure it out. And I started thinking about why do I do any of what I do, and I started thinking about my grandfather. I loved my grandfather. Harry Kelvin was his name, my mother's father. He died in 1986. He was an amazing guy. And one of the reasons he was amazing: After World War II, he began an electronics company. He started selling surplus parts, kits, to schools and stuff. So he had this incredible curiosity. As a kid, I saw him come over to me with radios and telephones and all sorts of things. And he'd open them up, he'd unscrew them and reveal the inner workings — which many of us, I'm sure, take for granted. But it's an amazing gift to give a kid. To open up this thing and show how it works and why it works and what it is. He was the ultimate deconstructor, in many ways. And my grandfather was a kind of guy who would not only take things apart, but he got me interested in all sorts of different odd crafts, like, you know, printing, like the letter press. I'm obsessed with printing. I'm obsessed with silk-screening and bookbinding and box making. 00:05:48.238 --> 00:05:51.254
And so I started thinking about "Lost"
and the stuff that we do,

00:05:51.278 --> 00:05:54.774
and I realized, oh my God, mystery boxes
are everywhere in what I do!

00:05:54.798 --> 00:05:57.214
In the creation of "Lost,"
Damon Lindelof and I,

00:05:57.238 --> 00:05:58.654
who created the show with me,

00:05:58.678 --> 00:06:01.814
we were basically tasked
with creating this series

00:06:01.838 --> 00:06:03.534
that we had very little time to do.

00:06:03.558 --> 00:06:05.054
We had 11 and a half weeks

00:06:05.078 --> 00:06:09.854
to write it, cast it, crew it, shoot it,
cut it, post it, turn in a two-hour pilot.

00:06:09.878 --> 00:06:11.254
So it was not a lot of time.

00:06:11.278 --> 00:06:14.054
And that sense of possibility --
what could this thing be?

00:06:14.078 --> 00:06:15.654
There was no time to develop it.

00:06:15.678 --> 00:06:17.614
I'm sure you're all familiar with people

00:06:17.638 --> 00:06:20.374
who tell you what you can't do
and what you should change.

00:06:20.398 --> 00:06:22.894
There was no time for that,
which is kind of amazing.

00:06:22.918 --> 00:06:24.174
And so we did this show,

00:06:24.198 --> 00:06:26.974
and for those of you
who haven't seen it, or don't know it,

00:06:26.998 --> 00:06:29.334
I can show you one
little clip from the pilot,

00:06:29.358 --> 00:06:31.574
just to show you some stuff that we did.

00:06:31.598 --> 00:06:33.318
(Engine roaring)

00:06:40.358 --> 00:06:41.558
(Video) Claire: Help!

00:06:42.318 --> 00:06:44.494
Please help me!

00:06:44.518 --> 00:06:46.598
Help me! Please, help me!

00:06:48.558 --> 00:06:51.334
Jack: Get him out of here!
Get him away from the engine!

00:06:51.358 --> 00:06:52.622
Get him out of here!

00:06:52.646 --> 00:06:58.734
(Engine roaring)

00:06:58.758 --> 00:07:02.094
C: Help me, please!
I'm having contractions!

00:07:02.118 --> 00:07:03.854
J: How many months pregnant are you?

00:07:03.878 --> 00:07:05.334
C: I'm only eight months.

00:07:05.358 --> 00:07:07.174
J: And how far apart are they coming?

00:07:07.198 --> 00:07:09.238
C: I don't know. I think it just happened.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.678
Man: Hey! Hey! Hey, get away from --

00:07:23.358 --> 00:07:25.694
JJ Abrams: 10 years ago,
if we wanted to do that,

00:07:25.718 --> 00:07:27.134
we'd have to kill a stuntman.

00:07:27.158 --> 00:07:32.214
(Laughter)

00:07:32.238 --> 00:07:34.174
It would be harder.

00:07:34.198 --> 00:07:35.534
Take two would be a bitch.

00:07:35.558 --> 00:07:36.814
(Laughter)

00:07:36.838 --> 00:07:39.934
So the amazing thing was,
we were able to do this thing.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:42.814
And part of that was
the amazing availability of technology,

00:07:42.838 --> 00:07:44.254
knowing we could do anything.

00:07:44.278 --> 00:07:46.134
I mean, we could never have done that.

00:07:46.158 --> 00:07:47.894
We might have been able to write it;

00:07:47.918 --> 00:07:50.374
we wouldn't have been able
to depict it like we did.

00:07:50.398 --> 00:07:53.374
So part of the amazing thing for me
is in the creative process,

00:07:53.398 --> 00:07:55.534
technology is mind-blowingly
inspiring to me.

00:07:55.558 --> 00:07:58.814
I realize that that blank page
is a magic box, you know?

00:07:58.838 --> 00:08:01.054
It needs to be filled
with something fantastic.

00:08:01.078 --> 00:08:04.214
I used to have the "Ordinary People"
script that I'd flip through.

00:08:04.238 --> 00:08:06.654
The romance was amazing to me;
it would inspire me.

00:08:06.678 --> 00:08:08.134
I wanted to try and fill pages

00:08:08.158 --> 00:08:11.934
with the same kind of spirit
and thought and emotion

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.174
that that script did.

00:08:13.198 --> 00:08:15.654
So, you know, I love Apple computers.

00:08:15.678 --> 00:08:16.894
I'm obsessed.

00:08:16.918 --> 00:08:19.614
So the Apple computer --
the PowerBook -- this computer,

00:08:19.638 --> 00:08:20.854
it challenges me.

00:08:20.878 --> 00:08:23.734
It basically says, what are you
going to write worthy of me?

00:08:23.758 --> 00:08:25.454
I feel this -- I'm compelled.

00:08:25.478 --> 00:08:26.774
(Laughter)

00:08:26.798 --> 00:08:29.214
And I often am like,
you know, dude, today I'm out.

00:08:29.238 --> 00:08:31.374
I got nothing. You know? So there's that.

00:08:31.398 --> 00:08:32.854
In terms of the content of it,

00:08:32.878 --> 00:08:36.054
you look at stories, you think,
what are stories but mystery boxes?

00:08:36.078 --> 00:08:39.694
There's a fundamental question --
in TV, the first act is called the teaser.

00:08:39.718 --> 00:08:42.054
It's literally the teaser.
It's the big question.

00:08:42.078 --> 00:08:44.694
So you're drawn into it.
Then there's another question.

00:08:44.718 --> 00:08:46.454
And it goes on. Look at "Star Wars."

00:08:46.478 --> 00:08:48.294
The droids meet the mysterious woman.

00:08:48.318 --> 00:08:51.574
Who's that? We don't know. Mystery box!
Then you meet Luke Skywalker.

00:08:51.598 --> 00:08:53.934
He gets the droid,
you see the holographic image.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.774
You learn it's a message.
She wants to find Obi Wan Kenobi.

00:08:56.798 --> 00:08:58.934
He's her only hope.
But who's Obi Wan Kenobi?

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:00.911
Mystery box! So then he meets Ben Kenobi.

00:09:00.935 --> 00:09:03.654
Ben Kenobi is Obi Wan Kenobi.
Holy shit! So it keeps us --

00:09:03.678 --> 00:09:04.694
(Laughter)

00:09:04.718 --> 00:09:06.094
Have you guys not seen that?

00:09:06.118 --> 00:09:07.134
(Laughter)

00:09:07.158 --> 00:09:08.374
It's huge! Anyway --

00:09:08.398 --> 00:09:13.974
So there's this thing with mystery boxes
that I started feeling compelled.

00:09:13.998 --> 00:09:17.574
Then there's the thing of mystery
in terms of imagination --

00:09:17.598 --> 00:09:20.094
the withholding of information.

00:09:20.118 --> 00:09:24.134
You know, doing that intentionally
is much more engaging.

00:09:24.158 --> 00:09:26.094
Whether it's like the shark in "Jaws" --

00:09:26.118 --> 00:09:28.614
if Spielberg's mechanical shark,
Bruce, had worked,

00:09:28.638 --> 00:09:31.814
it would not be remotely as scary;
you would have seen it too much.

00:09:31.838 --> 00:09:34.654
In "Alien", they never
really showed the alien: terrifying!

00:09:34.678 --> 00:09:37.814
Even in a movie like
a romantic comedy, "The Graduate,"

00:09:37.838 --> 00:09:40.174
they're having that date,
and they're in the car,

00:09:40.198 --> 00:09:42.454
and it's loud, and so they put the top up.

00:09:42.478 --> 00:09:44.374
You don't hear anything they're saying!

00:09:44.398 --> 00:09:47.254
You can't hear a word!
But it's the most romantic date ever.

00:09:47.278 --> 00:09:49.334
And you love it because you don't hear it.

00:09:49.358 --> 00:09:52.934
So to me, there's that.
And then, finally, there's this idea --

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:55.214
stretching the paradigm a little bit --

00:09:55.238 --> 00:09:57.494
but the idea of the mystery box.

00:09:57.518 --> 00:10:00.934
Meaning, what you think you're getting,
then what you're really getting.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.054
And it's true in so many
movies and stories.

00:10:03.078 --> 00:10:04.534
Look at "E.T.," for example --

00:10:04.558 --> 00:10:06.694
"E.T." is this unbelievable
movie about what?

00:10:06.718 --> 00:10:08.734
It's about an alien
who meets a kid, right?

00:10:08.758 --> 00:10:10.694
Well, it's not. "E.T." is about divorce.

00:10:10.718 --> 00:10:13.334
"E.T." is about a heartbroken,
divorce-crippled family,

00:10:13.358 --> 00:10:15.614
and ultimately,
this kid who can't find his way.

00:10:15.638 --> 00:10:19.174
"Die Hard," right? Crazy, great, fun,
action-adventure movie in a building.

00:10:19.198 --> 00:10:21.414
It's about a guy
who's on the verge of divorce.

00:10:21.438 --> 00:10:23.654
He's showing up to L.A.,
tail between his legs.

00:10:23.678 --> 00:10:24.894
There are great scenes --

00:10:24.918 --> 00:10:28.054
maybe not the most amazing
dramatic scenes in the history of time,

00:10:28.078 --> 00:10:29.294
but pretty great scenes.

00:10:29.318 --> 00:10:31.654
There's a half an hour
of investment in character

00:10:31.678 --> 00:10:34.054
before you get to the stuff
that you're expecting.

00:10:34.078 --> 00:10:35.894
When you look at a movie like "Jaws,"

00:10:35.918 --> 00:10:38.174
the scene that you expect --
we have the screen?

00:10:38.198 --> 00:10:39.574
These are the kind of scenes

00:10:39.598 --> 00:10:42.054
that you remember and expect from "Jaws."

00:10:42.078 --> 00:10:44.174
And she's being eaten;

00:10:44.198 --> 00:10:45.494
there's a shark.

00:10:45.518 --> 00:10:46.734
(Woman screaming)

00:10:46.758 --> 00:10:49.134
The thing about "Jaws" is,
it's really about a guy

00:10:49.158 --> 00:10:52.694
who is sort of dealing with his place
in the world -- with his masculinity,

00:10:52.718 --> 00:10:56.294
with his family, how he's going to,
you know, make it work in this new town.

00:10:56.318 --> 00:10:58.214
This is one of my favorite scenes ever,

00:10:58.238 --> 00:11:00.974
and this is a scene
that you wouldn't necessarily think of

00:11:00.998 --> 00:11:03.438
when you think of "Jaws."
But it's an amazing scene.

00:11:58.598 --> 00:11:59.798
(Video) Father: C'mere.

00:12:03.398 --> 00:12:04.598
Give us a kiss.

00:12:05.358 --> 00:12:06.558
Son: Why?

00:12:08.638 --> 00:12:09.838
Father: 'Cause I need it.

00:12:10.678 --> 00:12:12.488
JJA: Come on. "Why? 'Cause I need it"?

00:12:12.512 --> 00:12:13.754
Best scene ever, right?

00:12:13.778 --> 00:12:14.794
(Laughter)

00:12:14.818 --> 00:12:16.614
Come on! So you think of "Jaws" --

00:12:16.638 --> 00:12:18.254
so that's the kind of stuff that,

00:12:18.278 --> 00:12:21.214
like, you know --
the investment of character,

00:12:21.238 --> 00:12:24.014
which is the stuff that really
is inside the box, you know?

00:12:24.038 --> 00:12:27.494
It's why when people do sequels,
or rip off movies, you know, of a genre,

00:12:27.518 --> 00:12:29.254
they're ripping off the wrong thing.

00:12:29.278 --> 00:12:31.934
You're not supposed
to rip off the shark or the monster.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:34.814
You know, if you rip something off --
rip off the character.

00:12:34.838 --> 00:12:36.374
Rip off the stuff that matters.

00:12:36.398 --> 00:12:39.374
I mean, look inside yourself
and figure out what is inside you.

00:12:39.398 --> 00:12:41.854
Because ultimately,
the mystery box is all of us.

00:12:41.878 --> 00:12:43.736
So there's that. Then the distribution.

00:12:43.760 --> 00:12:46.574
What's a bigger mystery box
than a movie theater? You know?

00:12:46.598 --> 00:12:49.534
You go to the theater,
you're just so excited to see anything.

00:12:49.558 --> 00:12:52.054
The moment the lights go down
is often the best part.

00:12:52.078 --> 00:12:56.534
And you're full of that amazing --
that feeling of excited anticipation.

00:12:56.558 --> 00:12:58.654
And often, the movie's there
and it's going,

00:12:58.678 --> 00:13:01.854
and then something happens
and you go, "Oh --", and then, "Mmm ..."

00:13:01.878 --> 00:13:04.254
When it's a great movie,
you're along for the ride

00:13:04.278 --> 00:13:06.421
because you're willing
to give yourself to it.

00:13:06.445 --> 00:13:10.254
So to me, whether it's a TV,
an iPod, computer, cell phone --

00:13:10.278 --> 00:13:12.614
It's funny, I'm an --
as I said, Apple fanatic --

00:13:12.638 --> 00:13:14.374
and one day, about a year or so ago,

00:13:14.398 --> 00:13:18.094
I was signing on online in the morning
to watch Steve Jobs' keynote,

00:13:18.118 --> 00:13:19.334
because I always do.

00:13:19.358 --> 00:13:22.494
And he came on,
he was presenting the video iPod,

00:13:22.518 --> 00:13:25.294
and what was on
the enormous iPod behind him?

00:13:25.318 --> 00:13:27.614
"Lost"! I had no idea!

00:13:27.638 --> 00:13:29.974
And I realized, holy shit,
it'd come full circle.

00:13:29.998 --> 00:13:31.951
The inspiration I get from the technology

00:13:31.975 --> 00:13:34.934
is now using the stuff that I do
to sell technology. It's nuts!

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.174
(Laughter)

00:13:36.198 --> 00:13:39.454
I was going to show you a couple
of other things I'm going to skip.

00:13:39.478 --> 00:13:42.654
I'll show you one other thing
that has nothing to do with anything.

00:13:42.678 --> 00:13:45.314
This is something online;
six years ago, they did this.

00:13:45.338 --> 00:13:48.914
This is an online thing done by guys
who had some visual effects experience.

00:13:48.938 --> 00:13:51.114
But the point was,
that they were doing things

00:13:51.138 --> 00:13:54.434
that were using these mystery boxes
that they had -- everyone has now.

00:13:54.458 --> 00:13:57.794
What I've realized is what my grandfather
did for me when I was a kid,

00:13:57.818 --> 00:13:59.614
everyone has access to now.

00:13:59.638 --> 00:14:02.614
You don't need to have my grandfather,
though you wish you had.

00:14:02.638 --> 00:14:03.894
But I have to tell you --

00:14:03.918 --> 00:14:06.414
this is a guy doing stuff
on a Quadra 950 computer --

00:14:06.438 --> 00:14:08.174
the resolution's a little bit low --

00:14:08.198 --> 00:14:10.894
using Infinity software
they stopped making 15 years ago.

00:14:10.918 --> 00:14:12.774
He's doing stuff that looks as amazing

00:14:12.798 --> 00:14:15.974
as stuff I've seen
released from Hollywood.

00:14:15.998 --> 00:14:18.974
The most incredible
sort of mystery, I think,

00:14:18.998 --> 00:14:21.734
is now the question of what comes next.

00:14:21.758 --> 00:14:23.774
Because it is now democratized.

00:14:23.798 --> 00:14:26.294
So now, the creation of media --
it's everywhere.

00:14:26.318 --> 00:14:30.134
The stuff that I was lucky
and begging for to get when I was a kid

00:14:30.158 --> 00:14:31.374
is now ubiquitous.

00:14:31.398 --> 00:14:34.214
And so, there's an amazing sense
of opportunity out there.

00:14:34.238 --> 00:14:37.334
And when I think of the filmmakers
who exist out there now

00:14:37.358 --> 00:14:39.334
who would have been silenced, you know --

00:14:39.358 --> 00:14:41.774
who have been silenced in the past --

00:14:41.798 --> 00:14:43.134
it's a very exciting thing.

00:14:43.158 --> 00:14:46.294
I used to say in classes
and lectures and stuff,

00:14:46.318 --> 00:14:49.054
to someone who wants to write,
"Go! Write! Do your thing."

00:14:49.078 --> 00:14:50.854
It's free, you don't need permission.

00:14:50.878 --> 00:14:54.134
But now I can say, "Go make your movie!"
There's nothing stopping you

00:14:54.158 --> 00:14:56.414
from going out there
and getting the technology.

00:14:56.438 --> 00:14:58.854
You can lease, rent,
buy stuff off the shelf

00:14:58.878 --> 00:15:02.654
that is either as good, or just as good,

00:15:02.678 --> 00:15:06.214
as the stuff that's being used
by the, you know, "legit people."

00:15:06.238 --> 00:15:10.374
No community is best served
when only the elite have control.

00:15:10.398 --> 00:15:12.574
And I feel like
this is an amazing opportunity

00:15:12.598 --> 00:15:14.054
to see what else is out there.

00:15:14.078 --> 00:15:17.294
When I did "Mission: Impossible III,"
we had amazing visual effects.

00:15:17.318 --> 00:15:19.214
ILM did the effects; it was incredible.

00:15:19.238 --> 00:15:20.974
And sort of my dream to be involved.

00:15:20.998 --> 00:15:23.334
And there are a couple
of sequences in the movie,

00:15:23.358 --> 00:15:25.398
like these couple of moments
I'll show you.

00:15:30.478 --> 00:15:31.678
There's that.

00:15:38.438 --> 00:15:39.772
(Video) Luther: Ethan, move!

00:15:44.798 --> 00:15:46.558
(Explosion)

00:15:52.478 --> 00:15:55.334
Obviously, I have an obsession
with big crazy explosions.

00:15:55.358 --> 00:15:58.934
So my favorite visual effect in the movie
is the one I'm about to show you.

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:01.174
It's a scene in which
Tom's character wakes up.

00:16:01.198 --> 00:16:02.454
He's drowsy. He's crazy.

00:16:02.478 --> 00:16:05.134
And the guy wakes up,
and he shoves this gun in his nose

00:16:05.158 --> 00:16:07.294
and shoots this little capsule
into his brain

00:16:07.318 --> 00:16:09.998
that he's going to use later
to kill him, as bad guys do.

00:16:16.198 --> 00:16:17.718
(Video) Brownway: Good morning.

00:16:19.638 --> 00:16:20.894
JJA: OK, now.

00:16:20.918 --> 00:16:22.134
When we shot that scene,

00:16:22.158 --> 00:16:25.214
the actor who had the gun,
an English actor, Eddie Marsan --

00:16:25.238 --> 00:16:26.454
sweetheart, great guy --

00:16:26.478 --> 00:16:29.054
he kept taking the gun
and putting it into Tom's nose,

00:16:29.078 --> 00:16:30.574
and it was hurting Tom's nose.

00:16:30.598 --> 00:16:32.774
And I learned this
very early on in my career:

00:16:32.798 --> 00:16:34.054
Don't hurt Tom's nose.

00:16:34.078 --> 00:16:35.974
(Laughter)

00:16:35.998 --> 00:16:38.094
There are three things
you don't want to do.

00:16:38.118 --> 00:16:39.934
Number two is: Don't hurt Tom's nose.

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:42.654
So Eddie has this gun --
and he's this sweet English guy.

00:16:42.678 --> 00:16:44.814
He's like, "Sorry,
I don't want to hurt you."

00:16:44.838 --> 00:16:46.854
I'm like, "We have to
make this look good."

00:16:46.878 --> 00:16:50.117
And I realized that we had to do something
because it wasn't working.

00:16:50.141 --> 00:16:52.374
And I thought back
to what I would have done

00:16:52.398 --> 00:16:54.814
using the Super 8 camera
that my grandfather got me

00:16:54.838 --> 00:16:56.054
sitting in that room,

00:16:56.078 --> 00:16:58.814
and I realized that hand
didn't have to be Eddie Marsan's.

00:16:58.838 --> 00:17:00.054
It could be Tom's.

00:17:00.078 --> 00:17:02.414
And Tom would know
just how hard to push the gun.

00:17:02.438 --> 00:17:03.654
He wouldn't hurt himself.

00:17:03.678 --> 00:17:07.334
So we took his hand and we painted it
to look a little bit more like Eddie's.

00:17:07.358 --> 00:17:09.214
We put it in Eddie's sleeve,

00:17:09.238 --> 00:17:10.734
and so the hand that you see --

00:17:10.758 --> 00:17:13.934
that's not Eddie's hand, that's Tom's.
So Tom is playing two roles.

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:15.374
(Laughter)

00:17:15.398 --> 00:17:17.214
And he didn't ask for any more money.

00:17:17.238 --> 00:17:18.797
So here, here. Watch it again.

00:17:19.797 --> 00:17:21.293
There he is. He's waking up.

00:17:21.317 --> 00:17:23.438
He's drowsy, been through a lot.

00:17:27.358 --> 00:17:28.934
(Video) Brownway: Good morning.

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:31.094
JJA: Tom's hand. Tom's hand. Tom's hand.

00:17:31.118 --> 00:17:32.334
Anyway.

00:17:32.358 --> 00:17:33.574
So ...

00:17:33.598 --> 00:17:36.974
(Applause)

00:17:36.998 --> 00:17:38.214
Thanks.

00:17:38.238 --> 00:17:40.293
(Applause)

00:17:40.317 --> 00:17:44.934
So you don't need the greatest technology
to do things that can work in movies.

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:48.294
And the mystery box,
in honor of my grandfather, stays closed.

00:17:48.318 --> 00:17:49.534
Thank you.

00:17:49.558 --> 00:17:53.158
(Applause)

title: Underwater astonishments
transcript: We're going to go on a dive to the deep sea, and anyone that's had that lovely opportunity knows that for about two and half hours on the way down, it's a perfectly positively pitch-black world. And we used to see the most mysterious animals out the window that you couldn't describe: these blinking lights — a world of bioluminescence, like fireflies. Dr. Edith Widder — she's now at the Ocean Research and Conservation Association — was able to come up with a camera that could capture some of these incredible animals, and that's what you're seeing here on the screen.That's all bioluminescence. And you see, some of the bioluminescence they use to avoid being eaten, some they use to attract prey, but all of it, from an artistic point of view, is just positively amazing. And a lot of what goes on inside — There's a fish with glowing eyes, pulsating eyes. Some of the colors are designed to hypnotize, these lovely patterns. And then this last one, one of my favorites, this pinwheel design. Just absolutely amazing, every single dive.That's the unknown world, and today we've only explored about 3 percent of what's out there in the ocean. Already we've found the world's highest mountains, the world's deepest valleys, underwater lakes, underwater waterfalls — a lot of that we shared with you from the stage. Cephalopods — head-foots. As a kid I knew them as calamari, mostly.(Laughter)This is an octopus. This is the work of Dr. Roger Hanlon at the Marine Biological Lab, and it's just fascinating how cephalopods can, with their incredible eyes, sense their surroundings, look at light, look at patterns. Here's an octopus moving across the reef, finds a spot to settle down, curls up and then disappears into the background. Tough thing to do.In the next bit, we're going to see a couple squid. Now males, when they fight, if they're really aggressive, they turn white. And these two males are fighting. They do it by bouncing their butts together, which is an interesting concept. Watch the coloration: white on the right, brown on the left. He takes a step back, he's keeping off the other males by splitting his body, and comes up on the other side — Bingo! Now, I'm told that's not not just a squid phenomenon with males, but I don't know.(Laughter)Cuttlefish. I love cuttlefish. This is a Giant Australian Cuttlefish. And there he is, his droopy little eyes up here. But they can do pretty amazing things, too. Here we're going to see one backing into a crevice, and watch his tentacles — he just pulls them in, makes them look just like algae. Disappears right into the background. Positively amazing. Here's two males fighting. Once again, they're smart enough, these cephalopods; they know not to hurt each other. But look at the patterns that they can do with their skin. That's an amazing thing.Here's an octopus. Sometimes they don't want to be seen when they move, because predators can see them. This guy can make himself look like a rock, and, looking at his environment, can actually slide across the bottom, using the waves and the shadows so he can't be seen. His motion blends right into the background — the moving rock trick.So, we're learning lots new from the shallow water. Still exploring the deep, but learning lots from the shallow water. And you see that an octopus would stand out very easily there if you couldn't use your camouflage, use your skin to change color and texture. Here's some algae in the foreground — and an octopus. Ain't that amazing?Now, Roger spooked him, so he took off in a cloud of ink, and when he lands, the octopus says, "Oh, I've been seen. The best thing to do is to get as big as I can get." That big brown makes his eyespot very big. So, he's bluffing. Let's do it backwards. I thought he was joking when he first showed it to me. I thought it was all graphics. So here it is in reverse. Watch the skin color; watch the skin texture. Just an amazing animal, it can change color and texture to match the surroundings. Watch him blend right into this algae. One, two, three.(Applause)And now he's gone, and so am I. Thank you very much.(Applause)
