00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:57.958
And I discovered that while I'd been busy playing business games,

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:02.958
there'd been this incredible revolution in so many areas of interest:

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:08.958
cosmology to psychology to evolutionary psychology to anthropology

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
to ... all this stuff had changed.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:15.958
And the way in which you could think about us as a species

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:19.958
and us as a planet had just changed so much, and it was incredibly exciting.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:21.958
And what was really most exciting --

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:26.958
and I think Richard Wurman discovered this at least 20 years before I did --

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:30.958
was that all this stuff is connected.

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:33.958
It's connected; it all hooks into each other.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
We talk about this a lot,

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:38.958
and I thought about trying to give an example of this. So, just one example:

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:44.958
Madame de Gaulle, the wife of the French president,

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.958
was famously asked once, "What do you most desire?"

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
And she answered, "A penis."

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:55.958
And when you think about it, it's very true:

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:58.958
what we all most desire is a penis --

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:01.958
or "happiness" as we say in English.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:10.958
(Laughter)

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:19.958
And something ... good luck with that one in the Japanese translation room.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
(Laughter)

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:24.958
(Applause)

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:30.958
But something as basic as happiness,

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:33.958
which 20 years ago would have been just something for discussion

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.958
in the church or mosque or synagogue,

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:40.958
today it turns out that there's dozens of TED-like questions

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:43.958
that you can ask about it, which are really interesting.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
You can ask about what causes it biochemically:

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
neuroscience, serotonin, all that stuff.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:52.958
You can ask what are the psychological causes of it:

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
nature? Nurture? Current circumstance?

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
Turns out that the research done on that is absolutely mind-blowing.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:03.958
You can view it as a computing problem, an artificial intelligence problem:

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:05.958
do you need to incorporate

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:10.958
some sort of analog of happiness into a computer brain to make it work properly?

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:14.958
You can view it in sort of geopolitical terms

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:18.958
and say, why is it that a billion people on this planet

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:24.958
are so desperately needy that they have no possibility of happiness,

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
and whereas almost all the rest of them,

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:30.958
regardless of how much money they have -- whether it's two dollars a day or whatever --

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
are almost equally happy on average?

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:40.958
Or you can view it as an evolutionary psychology kind of thing:

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:44.958
did our genes invent this as a kind of trick

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:48.958
to get us to behave in certain ways? The ant's brain, parasitized,

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:51.958
to make us behave in certain ways so that our genes would propagate?

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
Are we the victims of a mass delusion?

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
And so on, and so on.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:59.958
To understand even something as important to us as happiness,

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:02.958
you kind of have to branch off in all these different directions,

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:08.958
and there's nowhere that I've discovered -- other than TED --

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:13.958
where you can ask that many questions in that many different directions.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
And so, it's the profound thing that Richard talks about:

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:20.958
to understand anything, you just need to understand the little bits;

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
a little bit about everything that surrounds it.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
And so, gradually over these three days,

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
you start off kind of trying to figure out,

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:29.958
"Why am I listening to all this irrelevant stuff?"

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
And at the end of the four days,

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:36.958
your brain is humming and you feel energized, alive and excited,

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
and it's because all these different bits have been put together.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
It's the total brain experience, we're going to ...

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
it's the mental equivalent of the full body massage.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:44.958
(Laughter)

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:49.958
Every mental organ addressed. It really is.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:53.958
Enough of the theory, Chris. Tell us what you're actually going to do, all right?

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
So, I will. Here's the vision for TED.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:09:03.958
Number one: do nothing. This thing ain't broke, so I ain't gonna fix it.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
Jeff Bezos kindly remarked to me,

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
"Chris, TED is a really great conference.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
You're going to have to fuck up really badly to make it bad."

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
(Laughter)

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:26.958
So, I gave myself the job title of TED Custodian for a reason,

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:28.958
and I will promise you right here and now

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:32.958
that the core values that make TED special are not going to be interfered with.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:41.958
Truth, curiosity, diversity, no selling, no corporate bullshit,

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.958
no bandwagoning, no platforms.

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:53.958
Just the pursuit of interest, wherever it lies,

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:54.958
across all the disciplines that are represented here.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
That's not going to be changed at all.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
Number two: I am going to put together

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
an incredible line up of speakers for next year.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:08.958
The time scale on which TED operates is just fantastic

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:12.958
after coming out of a magazine business with monthly deadlines.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:14.958
There's a year to do this, and already --

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
I hope to show you a bit later --

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:21.958
there's 25 or so terrific speakers signed up for next year.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
And I'm getting fantastic help from the community;

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:27.958
this is just such a great community. And combined, our contacts

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:33.958
reach pretty much everyone who's interesting in the country, if not the planet.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:35.958
It's true.

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:42.958
Number three: I do want to, if I can, find a way

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
of extending the TED experience throughout the year a little bit.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:50.958
And one key way that we're going to do this is to introduce this book club.

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:56.958
Books kind of saved me in the last couple years,

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:59.958
and that's a gift that I would like to pass on.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:04.958
So, when you sign up for TED2003, every six weeks you'll get a care package

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:07.958
with a book or two and a reason why they're linked to TED.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
They may well be by a TED speaker,

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:12.958
and so we can get the conversation going during the year

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:18.958
and come back next year having had the same intellectual, emotional journey.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
I think it will be great.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:25.958
And then, fourthly: I want to mention the Sapling Foundation,

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
which is the new owner of TED.

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
What Sapling's ownership means is that all of the proceeds of TED

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:36.958
will go towards the causes that Sapling stands for.

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:45.958
And more important, I think, the ideas that are exhibited and realized here

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:50.958
are ideas that the foundation can use, because there's fantastic synergy.

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
Already, just in the last few days,

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
we've had so many people talking about stuff that they care about,

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:57.958
that they're passionate about, that can make a difference in the world,

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:01.958
and the idea of getting this group of people together --

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
some of the causes that we believe in,

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:06.958
the money that this conference can raise and the ideas --

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:11.958
I really believe that that combination will, over time, make a difference.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:12.958
I'm incredibly excited about that.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:21.958
In fact, I don't think, overall, that I've been as excited by anything ever in my life.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:23.958
I'm in this for the long run,

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:28.958
and I would be greatly honored and excited

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
if you'll come on this journey with me.

title: The idea behind Zipcar (and what comes next)
transcript: I'm going to talk about two stories today. One is how we need to use market-based pricing to affect demand and use wireless technologies to dramatically reduce our emissions in the transportation sector. And the other is that there is an incredible opportunity if we choose the right wireless technologies; how we can generate a new engine for economic growth and dramatically reduce C02 in the other sectors.I'm really scared. We need to reduce C02 emissions in ten to fifteen years by 80 percent in order to avert catastrophic effects. And I am astounded that I'm standing here to tell you that. What are catastrophic effects? A three degree centigrade climate change rise that will result in 50 percent species extinction. It's not a movie. This is real life. And I'm really worried, because when people talk about cars — which I know something about — the press and politicians and people in this room are all thinking, "Let's use fuel-efficient cars." If we started today, 10 years from now, at the end of this window of opportunity, those fuel-efficient cars will reduce our fossil fuel needs by four percent. That is not enough.But now I'll talk about some more pleasant things. Here are some ways that we can make some dramatic changes. So, Zipcar is a company that I founded seven years ago, but it's an example of something called car sharing. What Zipcar does is we park cars throughout dense urban areas for members to reserve, by the hour and by the day, instead of using their own car. How does it feel to be a person using a Zipcar? It means that I pay only for what I need. All those hours when a car is sitting idle, I'm not paying for it. It means that I can choose a car exactly for that particular trip. So, here's a woman that reserved MiniMia, and she had her day. I can take a BMW when I'm seeing clients. I can drive my Toyota Element when I'm going to go on that surfing trip.And the other remarkable thing is it's, I think, the highest status of car ownership. Not only do I have a fleet of cars available to me in seven cities around the world that I can have at my beck and call, but heaven forbid I would ever maintain or deal with the repair or have anything to do with it. It's like the car that you always wanted that your mom said that you couldn't have. I get all the good stuff and none of the bad.So, what is the social result of this? The social result is that today's Zipcar has 100,000 members driving 3,000 cars parked in 3,000 parking spaces. Instead of driving 12,000 miles a year, which is what the average city dweller does, they drive 500 miles a year. Are they happy? The company has been doubling in size ever since I founded it, or greater. People adore the company. And it's better, you know? They like it. So, how is it that people went from the 12,000 miles a year to 500 miles? It's because they said, "It's eight to 10 dollars an hour and 65 dollars a day. If I'm going to go buy some ice cream, do I really want to spend eight dollars to go buy the ice cream? Or maybe I'll do without. Maybe I would have bought the ice cream when I did some other errand." So, people really respond very quickly to it, to prices.And the last point I want to make is Zipcar would never be possible without technology. It required that it was completely trivial: that it takes 30 seconds to reserve a car, go get it, drive it. And for me, as a service provider, I would never be able to provide you a car for an hour if the transaction cost was anything. So, without these wireless technologies, this, as a concept, could never happen.So, here's another example. This company is GoLoco — I'm launching it in about three weeks — and I hope to do for ridesharing what I did for car sharing. This will apply to people across all of America. Today, 75 percent of the trips are single-occupancy vehicles, yet 12 percent of trips to work are currently carpool. And I think that we can apply social networks and online payment systems to completely change how people feel about ridesharing and make that trip much more efficient.And so when I think about the future, people will be thinking that sharing the ride with someone is this incredibly great social event out of their day. You know, how did you get to TED? You went with other TEDsters. How fabulous. Why would you ever want to go by yourself in your own car? How did you go food shopping? You went with your neighbor, what a great social time. You know it's going to really transform how we feel about travel, and it will also, I think, enhance our freedom of mobility. Where can I go today and who can I do it with? Those are the types of things that you will look at and feel.And the social benefits: the rate of single-occupancy vehicles is, I told you, 75 percent; I think we can get that down to 50 percent. The demand for parking, of course, is down, congestion and the CO2 emissions. One last piece about this, of course, is that it's enabled by wireless technologies. And it's the cost of driving that's making people want to be able to do this. The average American spends 19 percent of their income on their car, and there's a pressure for them to reduce that cost, yet they have no outlet today.So, the last example of this is congestion pricing, very famously done in London. It's when you charge a premium for people to drive on congested roads. In London, the day they turned the congestion pricing on, there was a 25 percent decrease in congestion overnight, and that's persisted for the four years in which they've been doing congestion pricing. And again, do people like the outcome? Ken Livingstone was reelected. So again, we can see that price plays an enormous role in people's willingness to reduce their driving behavior. We've tripled the miles that we drive since 1970 and doubled them since 1982. There's a huge slack in that system; with the right pricing we can undo that.Congestion pricing is being discussed in every major city around the world and is, again, wirelessly enabled. You weren't going to put tollbooths around the city of London and open and shut those gates. And what congestion pricing is is that it's a technology trial and a psychological trial for something called road pricing. And road pricing is where we're all going to have to go, because today we pay for our maintenance and wear and tear on our cars with gas taxes. And as we get our cars more fuel-efficient, that's going to be reducing the amount of revenue that you get off of those gas taxes, so we need to charge people by the mile that they drive. Whatever happens with congestion pricing and those technologies will be happening with road pricing.Why do we travel too much? Car travel is underpriced and therefore we over-consumed. We need to put this better market feedback. And if we have it, you'll decide how many miles to drive, what mode of travel, where to live and work. And wireless technologies make this real-time loop possible.So, I want to move now to the second part of my story, which is: when are we going to start doing this congestion pricing? Road pricing is coming. When are we going to do it? Are we going to wait 10 to 15 years for this to happen or are we going to finally have this political will to make it happen in the next two years? Because I'm going to say, that is going to be the tool that's going to turn our usage overnight.And what kind of wireless technology are we going to use? This is my big vision. There is a tool that can help us bridge the digital divide, respond to emergencies, get traffic moving, provide a new engine for economic growth and dramatically reduce CO2 emissions in every sector. And this is a moment from "The Graduate." Do you remember this moment? You guys are going to be the handsome young guy and I'm going to be the wise businessman. "I want to say one word to you, just one word." "Yes, sir?" "Are you listening?" "Yes I am." "Ad-hoc peer-to-peer self-configuring wireless networks." (Laughter) These are also called mesh networks. And in a mesh, every device contributes to and expands the network, and I think you might have heard a little bit about it before.I'm going to give you some examples. You'll be hearing later today from Alan Kay. These laptops, when a child opens them up, they communicate with every single child in the classroom, within that school, within that village. And what is the cost of that communication system? Zero dollars a month. Here's another example: in New Orleans, video cameras were mesh-enabled so that they could monitor crime in the downtown French Quarter. When the hurricane happened, the only communication system standing was the mesh network. Volunteers flew in, added a whole bunch of devices, and for the next 12 months, mesh networks were the only wireless that was happening in New Orleans.Another example is in Portsmouth, U.K. They mesh-enabled 300 buses and they speak to these smart terminals. You can look at the terminal and be able to see precisely where your bus is on the street and when it's coming, and you can buy your tickets in real time. Again, all mesh-enabled. Monthly communication cost: zero. So, the beauty of mesh networks: you can have these very low-cost devices. Zero ongoing communication costs. Highly scalable; you can just keep adding them, and as in Katrina, you can keep subtracting them — as long as there's some, we can still communicate. They're resilient; their redundancy is built into this fabulous decentralized design.What are the incredible weaknesses? There isn't anybody in Washington lobbying to make it happen — or in those municipalities, to build out their cities with these wireless networks — because there's zero ongoing communications cost. So, the examples that I gave you are these islands of mesh networks, and networks are interesting only as they are big.How do we create a big network? Are you guys ready again — "The Graduate"? This time you will still play the handsome young thing, but I'll be the sexy woman. These are the next two lines in the movie. "Where did you do it?" "In his car." So you know, when you stick this idea ... (Laughter) where would we expect me, Robin Chase, to be thinking is imagine if we put a mesh-network device in every single car across America. We could have a coast-to-coast, free wireless communication system. I guess I just want you to think about that.And why is this going to happen? Because we're going to do congestion pricing, we are going to do road tolls, gas taxes are going to become road pricing. These things are going to happen. What's the wireless technology we're going to use? Maybe we should use a good one. When are we going to do it? Maybe we shouldn't wait for the 10 or 15 years for this to happen. We should pull it forward.So, I'd like us to launch the wireless Internet interstate wireless mesh system, and require that this network be accessible to everyone, with open standards. Right now in the transportation sector, we're creating these wireless devices — I guess you guys might have Fast Pass here or Easy Lane — that are single-purpose devices in these closed networks. What is the point? We're transferring just a few little data bits when we're doing road controlling, road pricing. We have this incredible excess capacity. So, we can provide the lowest-cost means of going wireless coast-to-coast, we can have resilient nationwide communication systems, we have a new tool for creating efficiencies in all sectors. Imagine what happens when the cost of getting information from anywhere to anywhere is close to zero. What you can do with that tool: we can create an economic engine. Information should be free, and access to information should be free, and we should be charging people for carbon.I think this is a more powerful tool than the Interstate Highway Act, and I think this is as important and world changing to our economy as electrification. And if I had my druthers, we would have an open-source version in addition to open standards. And this open-source version means that it could be — if we did a brilliant job of it — it could be used around the world very quickly. So, going back to one of my earlier thoughts. Imagine if every one of these buses in Lagos was part of the mesh network. When I went this morning to Larry Brilliant's TEDTalk prize — his fabulous networks — imagine if there was an open-source mesh communications device that can be put into those networks, to make all that happen. And we can be doing it if we could just get over the fact that this little slice of things is going to be for free. We could make billions of dollars on top of it, but this one particular slice of communications needs to be open source.So, let's take control of this nightmare: implement a gas tax immediately; transition across the nation to road-tolling with this wireless mesh; require that the mesh be open to all, with open standards; and, of course, use mesh networks. Thank you. (Applause)

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:05.958
they drive 500 miles a year. Are they happy?

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:09.958
The company has been doubling in size ever since I founded it, or greater.

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:14.958
People adore the company. And it's better,

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:16.958
you know? They like it.

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:20.958
So, how is it that people went from the 12,000 miles a year to 500 miles?

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:25.958
It's because they said, "It's eight to 10 dollars an hour and 65 dollars a day.

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:28.958
If I'm going to go buy some ice cream,

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:31.958
do I really want to spend eight dollars to go buy the ice cream? Or maybe I'll do without.

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:34.958
Maybe I would have bought the ice cream when I did some other errand."

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:37.958
So, people really respond very quickly to it, to prices.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:42.958
And the last point I want to make is Zipcar would never be possible without technology.

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:46.958
It required that it was completely trivial: that it takes 30 seconds

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:50.958
to reserve a car, go get it, drive it.

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:52.958
And for me, as a service provider,

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:54.958
I would never be able to provide you a car for an hour

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
if the transaction cost was anything.

00:03:56.958 --> 00:04:01.958
So, without these wireless technologies, this, as a concept, could never happen.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:04.958
So, here's another example. This company is GoLoco --

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:06.958
I'm launching it in about three weeks --

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:10.958
and I hope to do for ridesharing what I did for car sharing.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:13.958
This will apply to people across all of America.

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:16.958
Today, 75 percent of the trips are single-occupancy vehicles,

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:21.958
yet 12 percent of trips to work are currently carpool.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:26.958
And I think that we can apply social networks and online payment systems

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:28.958
to completely change how people feel about ridesharing

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:31.958
and make that trip much more efficient.

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:34.958
And so when I think about the future,

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:37.958
people will be thinking that sharing the ride with someone

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.958
is this incredibly great social event out of their day.

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
You know, how did you get to TED? You went with other TEDsters.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.958
How fabulous. Why would you ever want to go by yourself in your own car?

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:49.958
How did you go food shopping? You went with your neighbor, what a great social time.

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:54.958
You know it's going to really transform how we feel about travel,

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:58.958
and it will also, I think, enhance our freedom of mobility.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:00.958
Where can I go today and who can I do it with?

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:03.958
Those are the types of things that you will look at and feel.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
And the social benefits:

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
the rate of single-occupancy vehicles is, I told you, 75 percent;

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:11.958
I think we can get that down to 50 percent.

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:14.958
The demand for parking, of course, is down, congestion and the CO2 emissions.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:19.958
One last piece about this, of course, is that it's enabled by wireless technologies.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:22.958
And it's the cost of driving that's making people want to be able to do this.

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:26.958
The average American spends 19 percent of their income on their car,

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:33.958
and there's a pressure for them to reduce that cost, yet they have no outlet today.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:38.958
So, the last example of this is congestion pricing, very famously done in London.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:41.958
It's when you charge a premium for people to drive on congested roads.

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
In London, the day they turned the congestion pricing on,

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:48.958
there was a 25 percent decrease in congestion overnight,

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:51.958
and that's persisted for the four years in which they've been doing congestion pricing.

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:55.958
And again, do people like the outcome?

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:58.958
Ken Livingstone was reelected.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:04.958
So again, we can see that price plays an enormous role in people's willingness

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:07.958
to reduce their driving behavior.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:11.958
We've tripled the miles that we drive since 1970 and doubled them since 1982.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:13.958
There's a huge slack in that system;

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:17.958
with the right pricing we can undo that.

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:20.958
Congestion pricing is being discussed in every major city around the world

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
and is, again, wirelessly enabled.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:24.958
You weren't going to put tollbooths around the city of London

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:26.958
and open and shut those gates.

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:31.958
And what congestion pricing is is that it's a technology trial and a psychological trial

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
for something called road pricing.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
And road pricing is where we're all going to have to go,

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
because today we pay for our maintenance

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
and wear and tear on our cars with gas taxes.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:46.958
And as we get our cars more fuel-efficient,

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:50.958
that's going to be reducing the amount of revenue that you get off of those gas taxes,

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:54.958
so we need to charge people by the mile that they drive.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:56.958
Whatever happens with congestion pricing and those technologies

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:59.958
will be happening with road pricing.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.958
Why do we travel too much?

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:04.958
Car travel is underpriced and therefore we over-consumed.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
We need to put this better market feedback.

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
And if we have it, you'll decide how many miles to drive,

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
what mode of travel, where to live and work.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:14.958
And wireless technologies make this real-time loop possible.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
So, I want to move now to the second part of my story,

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:21.958
which is: when are we going to start doing

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:25.958
this congestion pricing? Road pricing is coming.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:26.958
When are we going to do it? Are we going to wait

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:28.958
10 to 15 years for this to happen

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:31.958
or are we going to finally have this political will to make it happen in the next two years?

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:35.958
Because I'm going to say, that is going to be the tool that's going to turn our usage overnight.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:39.958
And what kind of wireless technology are we going to use?

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:42.958
This is my big vision.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:45.958
There is a tool that can help us bridge the digital divide,

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:49.958
respond to emergencies, get traffic moving,

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:52.958
provide a new engine for economic growth

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:58.958
and dramatically reduce CO2 emissions in every sector.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:02.958
And this is a moment from "The Graduate." Do you remember this moment?

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.958
You guys are going to be the handsome young guy

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
and I'm going to be the wise businessman.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
"I want to say one word to you, just one word."

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:16.958
"Yes, sir?" "Are you listening?" "Yes I am."

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:20.958
"Ad-hoc peer-to-peer self-configuring wireless networks."

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:24.958
(Laughter)

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
These are also called mesh networks.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:30.958
And in a mesh, every device contributes to and expands the network,

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:32.958
and I think you might have heard a little bit about it before.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
I'm going to give you some examples.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
You'll be hearing later today from Alan Kay.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
These laptops, when a child opens them up,

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
they communicate with every single child in the classroom,

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:45.958
within that school, within that village.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
And what is the cost of that communication system?

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:50.958
Zero dollars a month.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
Here's another example: in New Orleans,

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
video cameras were mesh-enabled

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
so that they could monitor crime in the downtown French Quarter.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
When the hurricane happened,

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:02.958
the only communication system standing was the mesh network.

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:05.958
Volunteers flew in, added a whole bunch of devices,

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
and for the next 12 months,

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:12.958
mesh networks were the only wireless that was happening in New Orleans.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
Another example is in Portsmouth, U.K.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:18.958
They mesh-enabled 300 buses and they speak to these smart terminals.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
You can look at the terminal

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:24.958
and be able to see precisely where your bus is on the street

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:28.958
and when it's coming, and you can buy your tickets in real time.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:34.958
Again, all mesh-enabled. Monthly communication cost: zero.

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:37.958
So, the beauty of mesh networks:

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
you can have these very low-cost devices.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:42.958
Zero ongoing communication costs. Highly scalable;

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
you can just keep adding them, and as in Katrina,

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:48.958
you can keep subtracting them -- as long as there's some, we can still communicate.

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:52.958
They're resilient; their redundancy is built into this fabulous decentralized design.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
What are the incredible weaknesses?

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:58.958
There isn't anybody in Washington lobbying to make it happen --

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:01.958
or in those municipalities, to build out their cities with these wireless networks --

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
because there's zero ongoing communications cost.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:08.958
So, the examples that I gave you are these islands of mesh networks,

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:12.958
and networks are interesting only as they are big.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:17.958
How do we create a big network?

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:20.958
Are you guys ready again -- "The Graduate"?

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:24.958
This time you will still play the handsome young thing, but I'll be the sexy woman.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
These are the next two lines in the movie.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:31.958
"Where did you do it?" "In his car."

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:36.958
So you know, when you stick this idea ... (Laughter)

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:40.958
where would we expect me, Robin Chase, to be thinking

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
is imagine if we put a mesh-network device

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
in every single car across America.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:51.958
We could have a coast-to-coast, free wireless communication system.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:55.958
I guess I just want you to think about that.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:59.958
And why is this going to happen? Because we're going to do congestion pricing,

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
we are going to do road tolls,

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
gas taxes are going to become road pricing.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
These things are going to happen.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
What's the wireless technology we're going to use?

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:12.958
Maybe we should use a good one. When are we going to do it?

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
Maybe we shouldn't wait for the 10 or 15 years for this to happen.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
We should pull it forward.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:24.958
So, I'd like us to launch the wireless Internet interstate wireless mesh system,

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:29.958
and require that this network be accessible to everyone, with open standards.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:33.958
Right now in the transportation sector, we're creating these wireless devices --

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958
I guess you guys might have Fast Pass here or Easy Lane --

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:40.958
that are single-purpose devices in these closed networks.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:41.958
What is the point?

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
We're transferring just a few little data bits

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
when we're doing road controlling, road pricing.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
We have this incredible excess capacity.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:51.958
So, we can provide the lowest-cost means of going wireless coast-to-coast,

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:54.958
we can have resilient nationwide communication systems,

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:57.958
we have a new tool for creating efficiencies in all sectors.

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
Imagine what happens when the cost of getting information

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:02.958
from anywhere to anywhere is close to zero.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:06.958
What you can do with that tool: we can create an economic engine.

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:09.958
Information should be free, and access to information should be free,

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:13.958
and we should be charging people for carbon.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:16.958
I think this is a more powerful tool than the Interstate Highway Act,

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
and I think this is as important and world changing

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
to our economy as electrification.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
And if I had my druthers,

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:26.958
we would have an open-source version in addition to open standards.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:31.958
And this open-source version means that

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
it could be -- if we did a brilliant job of it --

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:38.958
it could be used around the world very quickly.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:42.958
So, going back to one of my earlier thoughts.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:46.958
Imagine if every one of these buses in Lagos was part of the mesh network.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:51.958
When I went this morning to Larry Brilliant's TEDTalk prize

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.958
-- his fabulous networks --

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
imagine if there was an open-source

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:58.958
mesh communications device that can be put into those networks,

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
to make all that happen.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:04.958
And we can be doing it if we could just get over the fact that

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
this little slice of things is going to be for free.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:09.958
We could make billions of dollars on top of it,

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:14.958
but this one particular slice of communications needs to be open source.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
So, let's take control of this nightmare:

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
implement a gas tax immediately;

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:25.958
transition across the nation to road-tolling with this wireless mesh;

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:29.958
require that the mesh be open to all, with open standards;

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:30.958
and, of course, use mesh networks.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:33.958
Thank you. (Applause)

title: A song of the city
transcript: I hope you'll understand my English. In the mornings it is terrible, and the afternoon is worst. (Laughter) During many years, I made some speeches starting with this saying: "City is not a problem, it's a solution." And more and more, I'm convinced that it's not only a solution for a country, but it's a solution for the problem of climate change.But we have a very pessimistic approach about the cities. I'm working in cities for almost 40 years, and where every mayor is trying to tell me his city is so big, or the other mayors say, "We don't have financial resources," I would like to say from the experience I had: every city in the world can be improved in less than three years. There's no matter of scale. It's not a question of scale, it's not a question of financial resources. Every problem in a city has to have its own equation of co-responsibility and also a design.So to start, I want to introduce some characters from a book I made for teenagers. The best example of quality of life is the turtle because the turtle is an example of living and working together. And when you realize that the casque of the turtle looks like an urban tessitura, and can we imagine, if we cut the casque of the turtle, how sad she's going to be? And that's what we're doing in our cities: living here, working here, having leisure here. And most of the people are leaving the city and living outside of the city.So, the other character is Otto, the automobile. He is invited for a party — he never wants to leave. The chairs are on the tables and still drinking, and he drinks a lot. (Laughter) And he coughs a lot. Very egotistical: he carries only one or two people and he asks always for more infrastructure. Freeways. He's a very demanding person. And on the other hand, Accordion, the friendly bus, he carries 300 people — 275 in Sweden; 300 Brazilians. (Laughter)Speaking about the design: every city has its own design. Curitiba, my city: three million in the metropolitan area, 1,800,000 people in the city itself. Curitiba, Rio: it's like two birds kissing themselves. Oaxaca, San Francisco — it's very easy: Market Street, Van Ness and the waterfront. And every city has its own design. But to make it happen, sometimes you have to propose a scenario and to propose a design — an idea that everyone, or the large majority, will help you to make it happen. And that's the structure of the city of Curitiba.And it's an example of living and working together. And this is where we have more density; it's where we have more public transport. So, this system started in '74. We started with 25,000 passengers a day, now it's 2,200,000 passengers a day. And it took 25 years until another city ... which is Bogota, and they did a very good job. And now there's 83 cities all over the world that they are doing what they call the BRT of Curitiba. And one thing: it's important not for only your own city; every city, besides its normal problems, they have a very important role in being with the whole humanity. That means mostly two main issues — mobility and sustainability — are becoming very important for the cities.And this is an articulated bus, double-articulated. And we are very close to my house. You can come when you are in Curitiba and have a coffee there. And that's the evolution of the system. What in the design that made the difference is the boarding tubes: the boarding tube gives to the bus the same performance as a subway. That's why, I'm trying to say, it's like metro-nizing the bus. This is the design of the bus, and you can pay before entering the bus you're boarding. And for handicapped, they can use this as a normal system.What I'm trying to say is the major contribution on carbon emissions are from the cars — more than 50 percent — so when we depend only on cars, it's ... — that's why when we're talking about sustainability, it's not enough, green buildings. It's not enough, a new materials. It's not enough, new sources of energy. It's the concept of the city, the design of the city, that's also important, too. And also, how to teach the children. I'll speak on this later on.Our idea of mobility is trying to make the connections between all the systems. We started in '83, proposing for the city of Rio how to connect the subway with the bus. The subway was against, of course. And 23 years after, they called us to develop — we're developing this idea. And you can understand how different it's going to be, the image of Rio with the system — one-minute frequency. And it's not Shanghai, it's not being colored during the day, only at night it will look this way.And before you say it's a Norman Foster design, we designed this in '83. And this is the model, how it's going to work. So, it's the same system; the vehicle is different. And that's the model. What I'm trying to say is, I'm not trying to prove which system of transport is better. I'm trying to say we have to combine all the systems, and with one condition: never — if you have a subway, if you have surface systems, if you have any kind of system — never compete in the same space.And coming back to the car, I always used to say that the car is like your mother-in-law: you have to have good relationship with her, but she cannot command your life. So, when the only woman in your life is your mother-in-law, you have a problem. (Laughter) So, all the ideas about how to transform through design — old quarries and open universities and botanic garden — all of it's related to how we teach the children. And the children, we teach during six months how to separate their garbage. And after, the children teach their parents. And now we have 70 percent — since 20 years, it's the highest rate of separation of garbage in the world. Seven zero. (Applause) So teach the children.I would like to say, if we want to have a sustainable world we have to work with everything what's said, but don't forget the cities and the children. I'm working in a museum and also a multi-use city, because you cannot have empty places during 18 hours a day. You should have always a structure of living and working together. Try to understand the sectors in the city that could play different roles during the 24 hours.Another issue is, a city's like our family portrait. We don't rip our family portrait, even if we don't like the nose of our uncle, because this portrait is you. And these are the references that we have in any city. This is the main pedestrian mall; we did it in 72 hours. Yes, you have to be fast. And these are the references from our ethnic contribution. This is the Italian portal, the Ukrainian park, the Polish park, the Japanese square, the German park. All of a sudden, the Soviet Union, they split. And since we have people from Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan, Tajikistan, [unclear], we have to stop the program. (Laughter)Don't forget: creativity starts when you cut a zero from your budget. If you cut two zeros, it's much better. And this is the Wire Opera theater. We did it in two months. Parks — old quarries that they were transformed into parks. Quarries once made the nature, and sometimes we took this and we transformed. And every part can be transformed; every frog can be transformed in a prince.So, in a city, you have to work fast. Planning takes time. And I'm proposing urban acupuncture. That means me, with some focal ideas to help the normal process of planning. And this is an acupuncture note — or I.M. Pei's. Some small ones can make the city better. The smallest park in New York, the most beautiful: 32 meters.So, I want just to end saying that you can always propose new materials — new sustainable materials — but keep in mind that we have to work fast to the end, because we don't have the whole time to plan. And I think creativity, innovation is starting. And we cannot have all the answers. So when you start — and we cannot be so prepotent on having all the answers — it's important starting and having the contribution from people, and they could teach you if you're not in the right track.At the end, I would like if you can help me to sing the sustainable song. OK? Please, allow me just two minutes. You're going to make the music and the rhythm.♫ Toonchi-too! Toonchi-too! Toonchi-too! ♫♫ Toonchi-too! Toonchi-too! Toonchi-too! ♫♫ It's possible! WEBVTT

00:00:12.958 --> 00:00:14.958
I hope you'll understand my English.

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:20.958
In the mornings it is terrible, and the afternoon is worst.

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:23.958
(Laughter)

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:28.958
During many years, I made some speeches starting with this

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:33.958
saying: "City is not a problem, it's a solution."

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:39.958
And more and more, I'm convinced that

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:43.958
it's not only a solution for a country,

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:48.958
but it's a solution for the problem of climate change.

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:55.958
But we have a very pessimistic approach about the cities.

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:59.958
I'm working in cities for almost 40 years,

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:06.958
and where every mayor is trying to tell me his city is so big,

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:12.958
or the other mayors say, "We don't have financial resources,"

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:15.958
I would like to say

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:19.958
from the experience I had: every city in the world

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:27.958
can be improved in less than three years.

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:31.958
There's no matter of scale. It's not a question of scale,

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.958
it's not a question of financial resources.

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:41.958
Every problem in a city has to have its own equation of co-responsibility

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:44.958
and also a design.

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:50.958
So to start, I want to introduce some characters

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:53.958
from a book I made for teenagers.

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:59.958
The best example of quality of life is the turtle

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:06.958
because the turtle is an example of living and working together.

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:11.958
And when you realize that the casque of the turtle

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:16.958
looks like an urban tessitura,

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:25.958
and can we imagine, if we cut the casque of the turtle, how sad she's going to be?

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:27.958
And that's what we're doing in our cities:

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:30.958
living here, working here, having leisure here.

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:34.958
And most of the people are leaving the city

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:37.958
and living outside of the city.

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:43.958
So, the other character is Otto, the automobile.

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:48.958
He is invited for a party -- he never wants to leave.

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:53.958
The chairs are on the tables and still drinking,

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
and he drinks a lot. (Laughter)

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:59.958
And he coughs a lot. Very egotistical:

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:02.958
he carries only one or two people

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:09.958
and he asks always for more infrastructure.

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:11.958
Freeways.

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:14.958
He's a very demanding person.

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:18.958
And on the other hand, Accordion, the friendly bus,

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:21.958
he carries 300 people --

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:32.958
275 in Sweden; 300 Brazilians. (Laughter)

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:37.958
Speaking about the design: every city has its own design.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:41.958
Curitiba, my city: three million in the metropolitan area,

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:46.958
1,800,000 people in the city itself.

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:49.958
Curitiba, Rio: it's like two birds kissing themselves.

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:52.958
Oaxaca, San Francisco -- it's very easy:

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:55.958
Market Street, Van Ness and the waterfront.

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:59.958
And every city has its own design.

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:03.958
But to make it happen, sometimes you have to propose a scenario

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:06.958
and to propose a design --

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:09.958
an idea that everyone, or the large majority,

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:12.958
will help you to make it happen.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:17.958
And that's the structure of the city of Curitiba.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:22.958
And it's an example of living and working together.

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:27.958
And this is where we have more density;

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:30.958
it's where we have more public transport.

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:38.958
So, this system started in '74. We started with 25,000 passengers a day,

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:41.958
now it's 2,200,000 passengers a day.

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:45.958
And it took 25 years until another city ...

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:50.958
which is Bogota, and they did a very good job.

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:55.958
And now there's 83 cities all over the world that they

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:59.958
are doing what they call the BRT of Curitiba.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:06.958
And one thing: it's important not for only your own city;

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:10.958
every city, besides its normal problems,

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.958
they have a very important role

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:16.958
in being with the whole humanity.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:21.958
That means mostly two main issues --

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:26.958
mobility and sustainability -- are becoming very important for the cities.

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:31.958
And this is an articulated bus, double-articulated.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:34.958
And we are very close to my house.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:39.958
You can come when you are in Curitiba and have a coffee there.

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:41.958
And that's the evolution of the system.

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:45.958
What in the design that made the difference

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.958
is the boarding tubes:

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:52.958
the boarding tube gives to the bus the same performance as a subway.

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:57.958
That's why, I'm trying to say,

00:05:57.958 --> 00:05:59.958
it's like metro-nizing the bus.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:05.958
This is the design of the bus,

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
and you can pay before entering the bus you're boarding.

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:16.958
And for handicapped, they can use this as a normal system.

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:19.958
What I'm trying to say is

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:25.958
the major contribution on carbon emissions are from the cars --

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:32.958
more than 50 percent -- so when we depend only on cars, it's ...

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:38.958
-- that's why when we're talking about sustainability,

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
it's not enough, green buildings.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:44.958
It's not enough, a new materials.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:47.958
It's not enough, new sources of energy.

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:51.958
It's the concept of the city, the design of the city,

00:06:51.958 --> 00:07:02.958
that's also important, too. And also, how to teach the children.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:07.958
I'll speak on this later on.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
Our idea of mobility is trying

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:13.958
to make the connections between all the systems.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:18.958
We started in '83, proposing for the city of Rio

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:21.958
how to connect the subway with the bus.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:24.958
The subway was against, of course.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:30.958
And 23 years after, they called us to develop -- we're developing this idea.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:34.958
And you can understand how different it's going to be,

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:37.958
the image of Rio with the system --

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:41.958
one-minute frequency.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:43.958
And it's not Shanghai,

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:47.958
it's not being colored during the day, only at night

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
it will look this way.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:55.958
And before you say it's a Norman Foster design,

00:07:55.958 --> 00:08:00.958
we designed this in '83.

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:01.958
And this is the model,

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:06.958
how it's going to work. So, it's the same system;

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:13.958
the vehicle is different. And that's the model.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
What I'm trying to say is, I'm not trying

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:22.958
to prove which system of transport is better.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:25.958
I'm trying to say we have to combine

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:30.958
all the systems, and with one condition:

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:36.958
never -- if you have a subway, if you have surface systems,

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
if you have any kind of system --

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:44.958
never compete in the same space.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:51.958
And coming back to the car, I always used to say

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:56.958
that the car is like your mother-in-law:

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
you have to have good relationship with her,

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:04.958
but she cannot command your life.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:14.958
So, when the only woman in your life is your mother-in-law,

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:18.958
you have a problem. (Laughter)

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:25.958
So, all the ideas about how to transform through design --

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:32.958
old quarries and open universities and botanic garden --

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:40.958
all of it's related to how we teach the children.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:44.958
And the children, we teach during six months how to separate their garbage.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:49.958
And after, the children teach their parents.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
And now we have 70 percent --

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:58.958
since 20 years, it's the highest rate of separation of garbage in the world.

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
Seven zero.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:05.958
(Applause)

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:08.958
So teach the children.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:14.958
I would like to say, if we want to have a sustainable world

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:18.958
we have to work with everything what's said,

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:23.958
but don't forget the cities and the children.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:27.958
I'm working in a museum and also a multi-use city,

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:32.958
because you cannot have empty places during 18 hours a day.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.958
You should have always

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:39.958
a structure of living and working together.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
Try to understand the sectors in the city

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:48.958
that could play different roles during the 24 hours.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:52.958
Another issue is, a city's like our family portrait.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
We don't rip our family portrait,

00:10:55.958 --> 00:11:00.958
even if we don't like the nose of our uncle,

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.958
because this portrait is you.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:09.958
And these are the references that we have in any city.

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:12.958
This is the main pedestrian mall;

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:17.958
we did it in 72 hours. Yes, you have to be fast.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:23.958
And these are the references from our ethnic contribution.

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
This is the Italian portal,

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:32.958
the Ukrainian park, the Polish park, the Japanese square, the German park.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:36.958
All of a sudden, the Soviet Union, they split.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.958
And since we have people from

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:42.958
Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan, Tajikistan, [unclear],

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
we have to stop the program.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
(Laughter)

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:55.958
Don't forget: creativity starts when you cut a zero from your budget.

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:59.958
If you cut two zeros, it's much better.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:07.958
And this is the Wire Opera theater. We did it in two months.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:11.958
Parks -- old quarries that they were transformed into parks.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:16.958
Quarries once made the nature, and

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:20.958
sometimes we took this and we transformed.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:25.958
And every part can be transformed;

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:31.958
every frog can be transformed in a prince.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:35.958
So, in a city, you have to work fast.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:41.958
Planning takes time. And I'm proposing urban acupuncture.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:49.958
That means me, with some focal ideas to help the normal process of planning.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
And this is an acupuncture note --

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:59.958
or I.M. Pei's. Some small ones

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:02.958
can make the city better.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:07.958
The smallest park in New York, the most beautiful:

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:09.958
32 meters.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
So, I want just to end saying

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:20.958
that you can always propose new materials -- new sustainable materials --

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:24.958
but keep in mind that we have to work fast

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:34.958
to the end, because we don't have the whole time to plan.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:40.958
And I think creativity, innovation is starting.

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:45.958
And we cannot have all the answers.

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:48.958
So when you start --

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:53.958
and we cannot be so prepotent on having all the answers --

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:58.958
it's important starting and having the contribution from people,

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.958
and they could teach you

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:04.958
if you're not in the right track.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:12.958
At the end, I would like if you can help me to sing the sustainable song.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:15.958
OK?
