00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:06.958
We are still Cartesians -- the children of Descartes --

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:11.958
who believe that subjectivity, consciousness, sets us apart;

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
that the world is divided into subjects and objects;

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
that there is nature on one side, culture on another.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:22.958
As soon as you start seeing things from the plant's point of view or the animal's point of view,

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:26.958
you realize that the real literary conceit is that --

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:30.958
is the idea that nature is opposed to culture,

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:34.958
the idea that consciousness is everything --

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:37.958
and that's another very important thing it does.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
Looking at the world from other species' points of view

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:44.958
is a cure for the disease of human self-importance.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:49.958
You suddenly realize that consciousness --

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:53.958
which we value and we consider

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
the crowning achievement of nature,

00:07:55.958 --> 00:08:00.958
human consciousness -- is really just another set of tools for getting along in the world.

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:04.958
And it's kind of natural that we would think it was the best tool.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
But, you know, there's a comedian who said,

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:10.958
"Well, who's telling me that consciousness is so good and so important?

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:12.958
Well, consciousness."

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:16.958
So when you look at the plants, you realize that there are other tools

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
and they're just as interesting.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:22.958
I'll give you two examples, also from the garden:

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:27.958
lima beans. You know what a lima bean does when it's attacked by spider mites?

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:30.958
It releases this volatile chemical that goes out into the world

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.958
and summons another species of mite

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:37.958
that comes in and attacks the spider mite, defending the lima bean.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:43.958
So what plants have -- while we have consciousness, tool making, language,

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
they have biochemistry.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:50.958
And they have perfected that to a degree far beyond what we can imagine.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:55.958
Their complexity, their sophistication, is something to really marvel at,

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
and I think it's really the scandal of the Human Genome Project.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:02.958
You know, we went into it thinking, 40,000 or 50,000 human genes

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:06.958
and we came out with only 23,000.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:14.958
Just to give you grounds for comparison, rice: 35,000 genes.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:17.958
So who's the more sophisticated species?

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:18.958
Well, we're all equally sophisticated.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:21.958
We've been evolving just as long,

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:23.958
just along different paths.

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:32.958
So, cure for self-importance, way to sort of make us feel the Darwinian idea.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:35.958
And that's really what I do as a writer, as a storyteller,

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:42.958
is try to make people feel what we know and tell stories that actually

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:43.958
help us think ecologically.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:45.958
Now, the other use of this is practical.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:47.958
And I'm going to take you to a farm right now,

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:51.958
because I used this idea to develop my understanding of the food system

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:56.958
and what I learned, in fact, is that we are all, now, being manipulated by corn.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:10:01.958
And the talk you heard about ethanol earlier today,

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:06.958
to me, is the final triumph of corn over good sense. (Laughter) (Applause)

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:14.958
It is part of corn's scheme for world domination.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:15.958
(Laughter)

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:19.958
And you will see, the amount of corn planted this year will be up dramatically from last year

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
and there will be that much more habitat

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
because we've decided ethanol is going to help us.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:27.958
So it helped me understand industrial agriculture,

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:29.958
which of course is a Cartesian system.

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:32.958
It's based on this idea that we bend other species to our will

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.958
and that we are in charge, and that we create these factories

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:38.958
and we have these technological inputs and we get the food out of it

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:40.958
or the fuel or whatever we want.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:43.958
Let me take you to a very different kind of farm.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.958
This is a farm in the Shenandoah Valley of Virginia.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
I went looking for a farm where these ideas

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:53.958
about looking at things from the species' point of view are actually implemented,

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
and I found it in a man. The farmer's name is Joel Salatin.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
And I spent a week as an apprentice on his farm,

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:04.958
and I took away from this some of the most hopeful news about our relationship to nature

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:07.958
that I've ever come across in 25 years of writing about nature.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:08.958
And that is this:

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:11.958
the farm is called Polyface, which means ...

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:15.958
the idea is he's got six different species of animals, as well as some plants,

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
growing in this very elaborate symbiotic arrangement.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
It's permaculture, those of you who know a little bit about this,

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:28.958
such that the cows and the pigs and the sheep and the turkeys and the ...

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
what else does he have?

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
All the six different species -- rabbits, actually --

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
are all performing ecological services for one another,

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
such that the manure of one is the lunch for the other

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
and they take care of pests for one another.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:43.958
It's a very elaborate and beautiful dance,

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:46.958
but I'm going to just give you a close-up on one piece of it,

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:52.958
and that is the relationship between his cattle and his chickens, his laying hens.

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:57.958
And I'll show you, if you take this approach, what you get, OK?

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
And this is a lot more than growing food, as you'll see;

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
this is a different way to think about nature

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:05.958
and a way to get away from the zero-sum notion,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
the Cartesian idea that either nature's winning or we're winning,

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:11.958
and that for us to get what we want, nature is diminished.

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
So, one day, cattle in a pen.

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
The only technology involved here is this cheap electric fencing:

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
relatively new, hooked to a car battery;

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:23.958
even I could carry a quarter-acre paddock, set it up in 15 minutes.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:27.958
Cows graze one day. They move, OK?

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:29.958
They graze everything down, intensive grazing.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:31.958
He waits three days,

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:34.958
and then we towed in something called the Eggmobile.

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:37.958
The Eggmobile is a very rickety contraption --

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:40.958
it looks like a prairie schooner made out of boards --

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
but it houses 350 chickens.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:48.958
He tows this into the paddock three days later and opens the gangplank,

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:52.958
turns them down, and 350 hens come streaming down the gangplank --

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
clucking, gossiping as chickens will --

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:58.958
and they make a beeline for the cow patties.

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
And what they're doing is very interesting:

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
they're digging through the cow patties

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:07.958
for the maggots, the grubs, the larvae of flies.

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:09.958
And the reason he's waited three days

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:14.958
is because he knows that on the fourth day or the fifth day, those larvae will hatch

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
and he'll have a huge fly problem.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:22.958
But he waits that long to grow them as big and juicy and tasty as he can

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:25.958
because they are the chickens' favorite form of protein.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:27.958
So the chickens do their kind of little breakdance

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:31.958
and they're pushing around the manure to get at the grubs,

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:34.958
and in the process they're spreading the manure out.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:38.958
Very useful second ecosystem service.

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
And third, while they're in this paddock

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
they are, of course, defecating madly

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:50.958
and their very nitrogenous manure is fertilizing this field.

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
They then move out to the next one,

00:13:52.958 --> 00:14:00.958
and in the course of just a few weeks, the grass just enters this blaze of growth.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
And within four or five weeks, he can do it again.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
He can graze again, he can cut, he can bring in another species,

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:10.958
like the lambs, or he can make hay for the winter.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:14.958
Now, I want you to just look really close up onto what's happened there.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:15.958
So, it's a very productive system.

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
And what I need to tell you is that on 100 acres

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:22.958
he gets 40,000 pounds of beef; 30,000 pounds of pork; 25,000 dozen eggs;

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.958
20,000 broilers; 1,000 turkeys; 1,000 rabbits --

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
an immense amount of food.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
You know, you hear, "Can organic feed the world?"

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:34.958
Well, look how much food you can produce on 100 acres if you do this kind of ...

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
again, give each species what it wants,

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:41.958
let it realize its desires, its physiological distinctiveness.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
Put that in play.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
But look at it from the point of view of the grass, now.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:48.958
What happens to the grass when you do this?

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:54.958
When a ruminant grazes grass, the grass is cut from this height to this height,

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
and it immediately does something very interesting.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:15:00.958
Any one of you who gardens knows that there is something called the root-shoot ratio,

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:04.958
and plants need to keep the root mass

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
in some rough balance with the leaf mass to be happy.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:11.958
So when they lose a lot of leaf mass, they shed roots;

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:14.958
they kind of cauterize them and the roots die.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:17.958
And the species in the soil go to work

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:21.958
basically chewing through those roots, decomposing them --

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:27.958
the earthworms, the fungi, the bacteria -- and the result is new soil.

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:30.958
This is how soil is created.

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:31.958
It's created from the bottom up.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
This is how the prairies were built,

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:35.958
the relationship between bison and grasses.

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:39.958
And what I realized when I understood this --

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:43.958
and if you ask Joel Salatin what he is, he'll tell you he's not a chicken farmer,

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:48.958
he's not a sheep farmer, he's not a cattle rancher; he's a grass farmer,

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:52.958
because grass is really the keystone species of such a system --

00:15:52.958 --> 00:16:01.958
is that, if you think about it, this completely contradicts the tragic idea of nature we hold in our heads,

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:07.958
which is that for us to get what we want, nature is diminished.

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:09.958
More for us, less for nature.

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:14.958
Here, all this food comes off this farm, and at the end of the season

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:20.958
there is actually more soil, more fertility and more biodiversity.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:24.958
It's a remarkably hopeful thing to do.

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:26.958
There are a lot of farmers doing this today.

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:29.958
This is well beyond organic agriculture,

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:32.958
which is still a Cartesian system, more or less.

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:38.958
And what it tells you is that if you begin to take account of other species,

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:45.958
take account of the soil, that even with nothing more than this perspectival idea

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:49.958
-- because there is no technology involved here except for those fences,

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:54.958
which are so cheap they could be all over Africa in no time --

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:58.958
that we can take the food we need from the Earth

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:02.958
and actually heal the Earth in the process.

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:05.958
This is a way to reanimate the world,

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:07.958
and that's what's so exciting about this perspective.

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:11.958
When we really begin to feel Darwin's insights in our bones,

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:16.958
the things we can do with nothing more than these ideas

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:18.958
are something to be very hopeful about.

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:19.958
Thank you very much.

title: The new power of collaboration
transcript: I'm here to enlist you in helping reshape the story about how humans and other critters get things done. Here is the old story — we've already heard a little bit about it: biology is war in which only the fiercest survive; businesses and nations succeed only by defeating, destroying and dominating competition;politics is about your side winning at all costs. But I think we can see the very beginnings of a new story beginning to emerge. It's a narrative spread across a number of different disciplines, in which cooperation, collective action and complex interdependencies play a more important role. And the central, but not all-important, role of competition and survival of the fittest shrinks just a little bit to make room.I started thinking about the relationship between communication, media and collective action when I wrote "Smart Mobs," and I found that when I finished the book, I kept thinking about it. In fact, if you look back, human communication media and the ways in which we organize socially have been co-evolving for quite a long time. Humans have lived for much, much longer than the approximately 10,000 years of settled agricultural civilizationin small family groups. Nomadic hunters bring down rabbits, gathering food. The form of wealth in those days was enough food to stay alive. But at some point, they banded together to hunt bigger game. And we don't know exactly how they did this, although they must have solved some collective action problems; it only makes sense that you can't hunt mastodons while you're fighting with the other groups.And again, we have no way of knowing, but it's clear that a new form of wealth must have emerged. More protein than a hunter's family could eat before it rotted. So that raised a social question that I believe must have driven new social forms. Did the people who ate that mastodon meat owe something to the hunters and their families? And if so, how did they make arrangements? Again, we can't know, but we can be pretty sure that some form of symbolic communication must have been involved.Of course, with agriculture came the first big civilizations, the first cities built of mud and brick, the first empires. And it was the administers of these empires who began hiring people to keep track of the wheat and sheep and wine that was owed and the taxes that was owed on them by making marks; marks on clay in that time.Not too much longer after that, the alphabet was invented. And this powerful tool was really reserved, for thousands of years, for the elite administrators (Laughter) who kept track of accounts for the empires. And then another communication technology enabled new media: the printing press came along, and within decades, millions of people became literate. And from literate populations, new forms of collective action emerged in the spheres of knowledge, religion and politics. We saw scientific revolutions, the Protestant Reformation, constitutional democracies possible where they had not been possible before. Not created by the printing press, but enabled by the collective action that emerges from literacy. And again, new forms of wealth emerged.Now, commerce is ancient. Markets are as old as the crossroads. But capitalism, as we know it, is only a few hundred years old, enabled by cooperative arrangements and technologies, such as the joint-stock ownership company, shared liability insurance, double-entry bookkeeping.Now of course, the enabling technologies are based on the Internet, and in the many-to-many era, every desktop is now a printing press, a broadcasting station, a community or a marketplace. Evolution is speeding up. More recently, that power is untethering and leaping off the desktops, and very, very quickly, we're going to see a significant proportion, if not the majority of the human race, walking around holding, carrying or wearing supercomputers linked at speeds greater than what we consider to be broadband today.Now, when I started looking into collective action, the considerable literature on it is based on what sociologists call "social dilemmas." And there are a couple of mythic narratives of social dilemmas. I'm going to talk briefly about two of them: the prisoner's dilemma and the tragedy of the commons.Now, when I talked about this with Kevin Kelly, he assured me that everybody in this audience pretty much knows the details of the prisoner's dilemma, so I'm just going to go over that very, very quickly. If you have more questions about it, ask Kevin Kelly later. (Laughter)The prisoner's dilemma is actually a story that's overlaid on a mathematical matrix that came out of the game theory in the early years of thinking about nuclear war: two players who couldn't trust each other. Let me just say that every unsecured transaction is a good example of a prisoner's dilemma. Person with the goods, person with the money, because they can't trust each other, are not going to exchange. Neither one wants to be the first one or they're going to get the sucker's payoff, but both lose, of course, because they don't get what they want. If they could only agree, if they could only turn a prisoner's dilemma into a different payoff matrix called an assurance game, they could proceed.Twenty years ago, Robert Axelrod used the prisoner's dilemma as a probe of the biological question: if we are here because our ancestors were such fierce competitors, how does cooperation exist at all? He started a computer tournament for people to submit prisoner's dilemma strategies and discovered, much to his surprise, that a very, very simple strategy won — it won the first tournament, and even after everyone knew it won, it won the second tournament — that's known as tit for tat.Another economic game that may not be as well known as the prisoner's dilemma is the ultimatum game, and it's also a very interesting probe of our assumptions about the way people make economic transactions. Here's how the game is played: there are two players; they've never played the game before, they will not play the game again, they don't know each other, and they are, in fact, in separate rooms. First player is offered a hundred dollars and is asked to propose a split: 50/50, 90/10, whatever that player wants to propose. The second player either accepts the split — both players are paid and the game is over — or rejects the split — neither player is paid and the game is over.Now, the fundamental basis of neoclassical economics would tell you it's irrational to reject a dollar because someone you don't know in another room is going to get 99. Yet in thousands of trials with American and European and Japanese students, a significant percentage would reject any offer that's not close to 50/50. And although they were screened and didn't know about the game and had never played the game before, proposers seemed to innately know this because the average proposal was surprisingly close to 50/50.Now, the interesting part comes in more recently when anthropologists began taking this game to other cultures and discovered, to their surprise, that slash-and-burn agriculturalists in the Amazon or nomadic pastoralists in Central Asia or a dozen different cultures — each had radically different ideas of what is fair. Which suggests that instead of there being an innate sense of fairness, that somehow the basis of our economic transactions can be influenced by our social institutions, whether we know that or not.The other major narrative of social dilemmas is the tragedy of the commons. Garrett Hardin used it to talk about overpopulation in the late 1960s. He used the example of a common grazing area in which each person by simply maximizing their own flock led to overgrazing and the depletion of the resource. He had the rather gloomy conclusion that humans will inevitably despoil any common pool resource in which people cannot be restrained from using it.Now, Elinor Ostrom, a political scientist, in 1990 asked the interesting question that any good scientist should ask, which is: is it really true that humans will always despoil commons? So she went out and looked at what data she could find. She looked at thousands of cases of humans sharing watersheds, forestry resources, fisheries, and discovered that yes, in case after case, humans destroyed the commons that they depended on. But she also found many instances in which people escaped the prisoner's dilemma; in fact, the tragedy of the commons is a multiplayer prisoner's dilemma. And she said that people are only prisoners if they consider themselves to be. They escape by creating institutions for collective action. And she discovered, I think most interestingly, that among those institutions that worked, there were a number of common design principles, and those principles seem to be missing from those institutions that don't work.I'm moving very quickly over a number of disciplines. In biology, the notions of symbiosis, group selection, evolutionary psychology are contested, to be sure. But there is really no longer any major debate over the fact that cooperative arrangements have moved from a peripheral role to a central role in biology, from the level of the cell to the level of the ecology. And again, our notions of individuals as economic beings have been overturned. Rational self-interest is not always the dominating factor. In fact, people will act to punish cheaters, even at a cost to themselves.And most recently, neurophysiological measures have shown that people who punish cheaters in economic games show activity in the reward centers of their brain. Which led one scientist to declare that altruistic punishment may be the glue that holds societies together.Now, I've been talking about how new forms of communication and new media in the past have helped create new economic forms. Commerce is ancient. Markets are very old. Capitalism is fairly recent; socialism emerged as a reaction to that. And yet we see very little talk about how the next form may be emerging. Jim Surowiecki briefly mentioned Yochai Benkler's paper about open source, pointing to a new form of production: peer-to-peer production. I simply want you to keep in mind that if in the past, new forms of cooperation enabled by new technologies create new forms of wealth, we may be moving into yet another economic form that is significantly different from previous ones.Very briefly, let's look at some businesses. IBM, as you know, HP, Sun — some of the most fierce competitors in the IT world are open sourcing their software, are providing portfolios of patents for the commons. Eli Lilly — in, again, the fiercely competitive pharmaceutical world — has created a market for solutions for pharmaceutical problems. Toyota, instead of treating its suppliers as a marketplace, treats them as a network and trains them to produce better, even though they are also training them to produce better for their competitors. Now none of these companies are doing this out of altruism; they're doing it because they're learning that a certain kind of sharing is in their self-interest.Open source production has shown us that world-class software, like Linux and Mozilla, can be created with neither the bureaucratic structure of the firm nor the incentives of the marketplace as we've known them. Google enriches itself by enriching thousands of bloggers through AdSense. Amazon has opened its Application Programming Interface to 60,000 developers, countless Amazon shops. They're enriching others, not out of altruism but as a way of enriching themselves. eBay solved the prisoner's dilemma and created a market where none would have existed by creating a feedback mechanism that turns a prisoner's dilemma game into an assurance game.Instead of, "Neither of us can trust each other, so we have to make suboptimal moves," it's, "You prove to me that you are trustworthy and I will cooperate." Wikipedia has used thousands of volunteers to create a free encyclopedia with a million and a half articles in 200 languages in just a couple of years.We've seen that ThinkCycle has enabled NGOs in developing countries to put up problems to be solved by design students around the world, including something that's being used for tsunami relief right now: it's a mechanism for rehydrating cholera victims that's so simple to use it, illiterates can be trained to use it. BitTorrent turns every downloader into an uploader, making the system more efficient the more it is used.Millions of people have contributed their desktop computers when they're not using them to link together through the Internet into supercomputing collectives that help solve the protein folding problem for medical researchers — that's Folding@home at Stanford — to crack codes, to search for life in outer space.I don't think we know enough yet. I don't think we've even begun to discover what the basic principles are, but I think we can begin to think about them. And I don't have enough time to talk about all of them, but think about self-interest. This is all about self-interest that adds up to more. In El Salvador, both sides that withdrew from their civil war took moves that had been proven to mirror a prisoner's dilemma strategy.In the U.S., in the Philippines, in Kenya, around the world, citizens have self-organized political protests and get out the vote campaigns using mobile devices and SMS. Is an Apollo Project of cooperation possible? A transdisciplinary study of cooperation? I believe that the payoff would be very big. I think we need to begin developing maps of this territory so that we can talk about it across disciplines. And I am not saying that understanding cooperation is going to cause us to be better people — and sometimes people cooperate to do bad things — but I will remind you that a few hundred years ago, people saw their loved ones die from diseases they thought were caused by sin or foreigners or evil spirits.Descartes said we need an entire new way of thinking. When the scientific method provided that new way of thinking and biology showed that microorganisms caused disease, suffering was alleviated. What forms of suffering could be alleviated, what forms of wealth could be created if we knew a little bit more about cooperation? I don't think that this transdisciplinary discourse is automatically going to happen; it's going to require effort. So I enlist you to help me get the cooperation project started. Thank you. (Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.958 --> 00:00:18.958
I'm here to enlist you

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:26.958
in helping reshape the story about how humans and other critters get things done.

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:31.958
Here is the old story -- we've already heard a little bit about it:

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:38.958
biology is war in which only the fiercest survive;

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:46.958
businesses and nations succeed only by defeating,

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:52.958
destroying and dominating competition;

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:59.958
politics is about your side winning at all costs.

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:07.958
But I think we can see the very beginnings of a new story beginning to emerge.

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:14.958
It's a narrative spread across a number of different disciplines,

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:22.958
in which cooperation, collective action and complex interdependencies

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:25.958
play a more important role.

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:34.958
And the central, but not all-important, role of competition and survival of the fittest

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:38.958
shrinks just a little bit to make room.

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:45.958
I started thinking about the relationship between communication, media

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:50.958
and collective action when I wrote "Smart Mobs,"

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:55.958
and I found that when I finished the book, I kept thinking about it.

00:01:55.958 --> 00:02:01.958
In fact, if you look back, human communication media

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:08.958
and the ways in which we organize socially have been co-evolving for quite a long time.

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:12.958
Humans have lived for much, much longer

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:19.958
than the approximately 10,000 years of settled agricultural civilization

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:27.958
in small family groups. Nomadic hunters bring down rabbits, gathering food.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:32.958
The form of wealth in those days was enough food to stay alive.

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:39.958
But at some point, they banded together to hunt bigger game.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:42.958
And we don't know exactly how they did this,

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:47.958
although they must have solved some collective action problems;

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:51.958
it only makes sense that you can't hunt mastodons

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:54.958
while you're fighting with the other groups.

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:56.958
And again, we have no way of knowing,

00:02:56.958 --> 00:03:01.958
but it's clear that a new form of wealth must have emerged.

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:06.958
More protein than a hunter's family could eat before it rotted.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:08.958
So that raised a social question

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:11.958
that I believe must have driven new social forms.

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:16.958
Did the people who ate that mastodon meat owe something

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:18.958
to the hunters and their families?

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:22.958
And if so, how did they make arrangements?

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:25.958
Again, we can't know, but we can be pretty sure that some form of

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:30.958
symbolic communication must have been involved.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:35.958
Of course, with agriculture came the first big civilizations,

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:40.958
the first cities built of mud and brick, the first empires.

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:44.958
And it was the administers of these empires

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:50.958
who began hiring people to keep track of the wheat and sheep and wine that was owed

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:52.958
and the taxes that was owed on them

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:56.958
by making marks; marks on clay in that time.

00:03:56.958 --> 00:04:01.958
Not too much longer after that, the alphabet was invented.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:07.958
And this powerful tool was really reserved, for thousands of years,

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:17.958
for the elite administrators (Laughter) who kept track of accounts for the empires.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:22.958
And then another communication technology enabled new media:

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:27.958
the printing press came along, and within decades,

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
millions of people became literate.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:33.958
And from literate populations,

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:37.958
new forms of collective action emerged in the spheres of knowledge,

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:41.958
religion and politics.

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:46.958
We saw scientific revolutions, the Protestant Reformation,

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:52.958
constitutional democracies possible where they had not been possible before.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:54.958
Not created by the printing press,

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:59.958
but enabled by the collective action that emerges from literacy.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:03.958
And again, new forms of wealth emerged.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:08.958
Now, commerce is ancient. Markets are as old as the crossroads.

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:12.958
But capitalism, as we know it, is only a few hundred years old,

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:17.958
enabled by cooperative arrangements and technologies,

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:20.958
such as the joint-stock ownership company,

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:25.958
shared liability insurance, double-entry bookkeeping.

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:30.958
Now of course, the enabling technologies are based on the Internet,

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:37.958
and in the many-to-many era, every desktop is now a printing press,

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:43.958
a broadcasting station, a community or a marketplace.

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.958
Evolution is speeding up.

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:52.958
More recently, that power is untethering and leaping off the desktops,

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:58.958
and very, very quickly, we're going to see a significant proportion, if not the majority of

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:06.958
the human race, walking around holding, carrying or wearing supercomputers

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
linked at speeds greater

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:13.958
than what we consider to be broadband today.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:16.958
Now, when I started looking into collective action,

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:22.958
the considerable literature on it is based on what sociologists call "social dilemmas."

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:25.958
And there are a couple of mythic narratives of social dilemmas.

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:28.958
I'm going to talk briefly about two of them:

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
the prisoner's dilemma and the tragedy of the commons.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
Now, when I talked about this with Kevin Kelly,

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:37.958
he assured me that everybody in this audience pretty much knows the details

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
of the prisoner's dilemma,

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
so I'm just going to go over that very, very quickly.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:49.958
If you have more questions about it, ask Kevin Kelly later. (Laughter)

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:52.958
The prisoner's dilemma is actually a story that's overlaid

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:56.958
on a mathematical matrix that came out of the game theory

00:06:56.958 --> 00:07:00.958
in the early years of thinking about nuclear war:

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
two players who couldn't trust each other.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:05.958
Let me just say that every unsecured transaction

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:08.958
is a good example of a prisoner's dilemma.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:11.958
Person with the goods, person with the money,

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:15.958
because they can't trust each other, are not going to exchange.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
Neither one wants to be the first one

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
or they're going to get the sucker's payoff,

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:24.958
but both lose, of course, because they don't get what they want.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:28.958
If they could only agree, if they could only turn a prisoner's dilemma into

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:34.958
a different payoff matrix called an assurance game, they could proceed.

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:38.958
Twenty years ago, Robert Axelrod used the prisoner's dilemma

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:43.958
as a probe of the biological question:

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:48.958
if we are here because our ancestors were such fierce competitors,

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
how does cooperation exist at all?

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
He started a computer tournament for

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:57.958
people to submit prisoner's dilemma strategies and discovered,

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:01.958
much to his surprise, that a very, very simple strategy won --

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:05.958
it won the first tournament, and even after everyone knew it won,

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:12.958
it won the second tournament -- that's known as tit for tat.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:18.958
Another economic game that may not be as well known as the prisoner's dilemma

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
is the ultimatum game,

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
and it's also a very interesting probe of

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:28.958
our assumptions about the way people make economic transactions.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
Here's how the game is played: there are two players;

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
they've never played the game before,

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:36.958
they will not play the game again, they don't know each other,

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
and they are, in fact, in separate rooms.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
First player is offered a hundred dollars

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:47.958
and is asked to propose a split: 50/50, 90/10,

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:54.958
whatever that player wants to propose. The second player either accepts the split --

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
both players are paid and the game is over --

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:03.958
or rejects the split -- neither player is paid and the game is over.

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:07.958
Now, the fundamental basis of neoclassical economics

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:11.958
would tell you it's irrational to reject a dollar

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:16.958
because someone you don't know in another room is going to get 99.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:22.958
Yet in thousands of trials with American and European and Japanese students,

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:28.958
a significant percentage would reject any offer that's not close to 50/50.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:33.958
And although they were screened and didn't know about the game

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
and had never played the game before,

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
proposers seemed to innately know this

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:44.958
because the average proposal was surprisingly close to 50/50.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
Now, the interesting part comes in more recently

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:50.958
when anthropologists began taking this game to other cultures

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:53.958
and discovered, to their surprise,

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:57.958
that slash-and-burn agriculturalists in the Amazon

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:02.958
or nomadic pastoralists in Central Asia or a dozen different cultures --

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:07.958
each had radically different ideas of what is fair.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:13.958
Which suggests that instead of there being an innate sense of fairness,

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:16.958
that somehow the basis of our economic

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:22.958
transactions can be influenced by our social institutions,

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
whether we know that or not.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:29.958
The other major narrative of social dilemmas is the tragedy of the commons.

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:35.958
Garrett Hardin used it to talk about overpopulation in the late 1960s.

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:41.958
He used the example of a common grazing area in which each person

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:44.958
by simply maximizing their own flock

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.958
led to overgrazing and the depletion of the resource.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
He had the rather gloomy conclusion that

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:54.958
humans will inevitably despoil any common pool resource

00:10:54.958 --> 00:11:00.958
in which people cannot be restrained from using it.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.958
Now, Elinor Ostrom, a political scientist, in

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:08.958
1990 asked the interesting question that any good scientist should ask,

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:13.958
which is: is it really true that humans will always despoil commons?

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:17.958
So she went out and looked at what data she could find.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:21.958
She looked at thousands of cases of humans sharing watersheds,

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:28.958
forestry resources, fisheries, and discovered that yes, in case after case,

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:32.958
humans destroyed the commons that they depended on.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:39.958
But she also found many instances in which people escaped the prisoner's dilemma;

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:45.958
in fact, the tragedy of the commons is a multiplayer prisoner's dilemma.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:50.958
And she said that people are only prisoners if they consider themselves to be.

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:54.958
They escape by creating institutions for collective action.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:58.958
And she discovered, I think most interestingly,

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
that among those institutions that worked,

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
there were a number of common design

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:06.958
principles, and those principles seem to be

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:10.958
missing from those institutions that don't work.

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
I'm moving very quickly over a number of

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
disciplines. In biology, the notions of symbiosis,

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:21.958
group selection, evolutionary psychology are contested, to be sure.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:26.958
But there is really no longer any major debate over the fact that

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:32.958
cooperative arrangements have moved from a peripheral role to a central role


00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:38.958
in biology, from the level of the cell to the level of the ecology.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:43.958
And again, our notions of individuals as economic beings

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:45.958
have been overturned.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:50.958
Rational self-interest is not always the dominating factor.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:58.958
In fact, people will act to punish cheaters, even at a cost to themselves.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
And most recently, neurophysiological measures

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:06.958
have shown that people who punish cheaters in economic games

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:10.958
show activity in the reward centers of their brain.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:17.958
Which led one scientist to declare that altruistic punishment

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:21.958
may be the glue that holds societies together.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:26.958
Now, I've been talking about how new forms of communication and new media

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:30.958
in the past have helped create new economic forms.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:35.958
Commerce is ancient. Markets are very old. Capitalism is fairly recent;

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:39.958
socialism emerged as a reaction to that.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:45.958
And yet we see very little talk about how the next form may be emerging.

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:50.958
Jim Surowiecki briefly mentioned Yochai Benkler's paper about open source,

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:54.958
pointing to a new form of production: peer-to-peer production.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:14:00.958
I simply want you to keep in mind that if in the past, new forms of cooperation

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:04.958
enabled by new technologies create new forms of wealth,

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:08.958
we may be moving into yet another economic form

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:12.958
that is significantly different from previous ones.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:18.958
Very briefly, let's look at some businesses. IBM, as you know, HP, Sun --

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:24.958
some of the most fierce competitors in the IT world are open sourcing

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:31.958
their software, are providing portfolios of patents for the commons.

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:36.958
Eli Lilly -- in, again, the fiercely competitive pharmaceutical world --

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:42.958
has created a market for solutions for pharmaceutical problems.

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:47.958
Toyota, instead of treating its suppliers as a marketplace,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:51.958
treats them as a network and trains them to produce better,

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:56.958
even though they are also training them to produce better for their competitors.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:15:00.958
Now none of these companies are doing this out of altruism;

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:02.958
they're doing it because they're learning that

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:08.958
a certain kind of sharing is in their self-interest.

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:15.958
Open source production has shown us that world-class software, like Linux and Mozilla,

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:21.958
can be created with neither the bureaucratic structure of the firm

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:27.958
nor the incentives of the marketplace as we've known them.

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:33.958
Google enriches itself by enriching thousands of bloggers through AdSense.

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:37.958
Amazon has opened its Application Programming Interface

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:42.958
to 60,000 developers, countless Amazon shops.

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:48.958
They're enriching others, not out of altruism but as a way of enriching themselves.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:53.958
eBay solved the prisoner's dilemma and created a market

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:57.958
where none would have existed by creating a feedback mechanism

00:15:57.958 --> 00:16:02.958
that turns a prisoner's dilemma game into an assurance game.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:07.958
Instead of, "Neither of us can trust each other, so we have to make suboptimal moves,"

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:13.958
it's, "You prove to me that you are trustworthy and I will cooperate."

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:19.958
Wikipedia has used thousands of volunteers to create a free encyclopedia

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:26.958
with a million and a half articles in 200 languages in just a couple of years.

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:33.958
We've seen that ThinkCycle has enabled NGOs in developing countries

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:39.958
to put up problems to be solved by design students around the world,

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:42.958
including something that's being used for tsunami relief right now:

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:44.958
it's a mechanism for rehydrating

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:47.958
cholera victims that's so simple to use it,

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:50.958
illiterates can be trained to use it.

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:54.958
BitTorrent turns every downloader into an uploader,

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:59.958
making the system more efficient the more it is used.

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:02.958
Millions of people have contributed their desktop computers

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:07.958
when they're not using them to link together through the Internet

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:09.958
into supercomputing collectives

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:13.958
that help solve the protein folding problem for medical researchers --

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:16.958
that's Folding@home at Stanford --

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:21.958
to crack codes, to search for life in outer space.

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:23.958
I don't think we know enough yet.

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:27.958
I don't think we've even begun to discover what the basic principles are,

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:30.958
but I think we can begin to think about them.

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:33.958
And I don't have enough time to talk about all of them,

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:35.958
but think about self-interest.

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:38.958
This is all about self-interest that adds up to more.

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:43.958
In El Salvador, both sides that withdrew from their civil war

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:47.958
took moves that had been proven to mirror a prisoner's dilemma strategy.

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:53.958
In the U.S., in the Philippines, in Kenya, around the world,

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:56.958
citizens have self-organized political protests and

00:17:56.958 --> 00:18:02.958
get out the vote campaigns using mobile devices and SMS.

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:05.958
Is an Apollo Project of cooperation possible?

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:09.958
A transdisciplinary study of cooperation?

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:13.958
I believe that the payoff would be very big.

00:18:13.958 --> 00:18:17.958
I think we need to begin developing maps of this territory

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:19.958
so that we can talk about it across disciplines.

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:23.958
And I am not saying that understanding cooperation 


00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:27.958
is going to cause us to be better people --

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:30.958
and sometimes people cooperate to do bad things --

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:33.958
but I will remind you that a few hundred years ago,

title: The untouchable music of the theremin
transcript: (Music)(Applause)Thank you. Ooh, I'm like, "Phew, phew, calm down. Get back into my body now." (Laughter)Usually when I play out, the first thing that happens is people scream out, "What's she doing?!" I'll play at these rock shows, be on stage standing completely still, and they're like, "What's she doing?! What's she doing?!" And then I'll kind of be like — (Vvvwow!) — and then they're like, "Whoa!" (Laughter)I'm sure you're trying to figure out, "Well, how does this thing work?" Well, what I'm doing is controlling the pitch with my left hand. See, the closer I get to this antenna, the higher the note gets — (Portamento) — and you can get it really low. And with this hand I'm controlling the volume, so the further away my right hand gets, the louder it gets. (Tones) So basically, with both of your hands you're controlling pitch and volume and kind of trying to create the illusion that you're doing separate notes, when really it's continuously going ... (Flourish ... Beep) (Laughter)Sometimes I startle myself: I'll forget that I have it on, and I'll lean over to pick up something, and then it goes like — (Blip) — "Oh!" And it's like a funny sound effect that follows you around if you don't turn the thing off. (Laughter)Maybe we'll go into the next tune, because I totally lost where this is going. We're going to do a song by David Mash called "Listen: the Words Are Gone," and maybe I'll have words come back into me afterwards if I can relax.(Music)(Applause)So, I'm trying to think of some of the questions that are commonly asked; there are so many. And ... Well, I guess I could tell you a little of the history of the theremin. It was invented around the 1920s, and the inventor, Léon Theremin — he also was a musician besides an inventor — he came up with the idea for making the theremin, I think, when he was working on some shortwave radios. And there'd be that sound in the signal — it's like (Screeching) — and he thought, "Oh, what if I could control that sound and turn it into an instrument, because there are pitches in it." And so somehow through developing that, he eventually came to make the theremin the way it is now.And a lot of times, even kids nowadays, they'll make reference to a theremin by going, "Whoo-hoo-hoo-hoo," because in the '50s it was used in the sci-fi horror movies, that sound that's like ... (Woo-hoo-hoo-hoo) (Laughter) It's kind of a funny, goofy sound to do.And sometimes if I have too much coffee, then my vibrato gets out of hand. You're really sensitive to your body and its functions when you're behind this thing. You have to stay so still if you want to have the most control. It reminds me of the balancing act earlier on — what Michael was doing — because you're fighting so hard to keep the balance with what you're playing with and stay in tune, and at the same time you don't want to focus so much on being in tune all the time; you want to be feeling the music.And then also, you're trying to stay very, very, very still because little movements with other parts of your body will affect the pitch, or sometimes if you're holding a low note — (Tone rising out of key) — and breathing will make it ...(Laughter)If I pass out on the next song ... (Laughter)I think of it almost like like a yoga instrument because it makes you so aware of every little crazy thing your body is doing, or just aware of what you don't want it to be doing while you're playing; you don't want to have any sudden movements. And if I go to a club and play a gig, people are like, "Here, have some drinks on us!" And it's like, "Well, I'm about to go on soon; I don't want to be like — (Teetering tones) — you know?"It really does reflect the mood that you're in also, if you're ... it's similar to being a vocalist, except instead of it coming out of your throat, you're controlling it just in the air and you don't really have a point of reference; you're always relying on your ears and adjusting constantly. You just have to always adjust to what's happening and realize you'll have bummer notes come here and there and listen to it, adjust it, and just move on, or else you'll get too tied up and go crazy. Like me.I think we will play another tune now. I'm going to do "Lush Life." It's one of my favorite tunes to play.(Music)(Applause)

title: The story of Project Orion
transcript: I'm a historian. Steve told us about the future of little technology; I'm going to show you some of the past of big technology. This was a project to build a 4,000-ton nuclear bomb-propelled spaceship and go to Saturn and Jupiter. This took place in my childhood, 1957-65. It was deeply classified. I'm going to show you some stuff that not only has not been declassified, but has now been reclassified.(Laughter)If all goes well, next year I'll be back, and I'll have a lot more to show you, and if all doesn't go well, I'll be in jail, like Wen Ho Lee.(Laughter)So, this ship was basically the size of the Marriott Hotel, a little taller and a little bigger. And one of the people who worked on it at the beginning was my father, Freeman, there in the middle. That's me and my sister, Esther, who's a frequent TEDster. I didn't like nuclear bomb-propelled spaceships. I mean, I thought it was a great idea, but I started building kayaks. So we had a few kayaks. Just so you know that I am not Dr. Strangelove.But all the time I was out there doing these strange kayak voyages in odd, beautiful parts of this planet, I always thought in the back of my mind about Project Orion, and how my father and his friends were going to build these big ships. They were actually going to go — Ted Taylor, who led the project, was going to take his children. My father was not going to take his children, that was one of the reasons we sort of had a falling out for a few years.(Laughter)The project began in '57 at General Atomics there, that's right on the coast at La Jolla. Look at that central building right in the middle of the picture. That's the 130-foot diameter library. That is exactly the size of the base of the spaceship. So put that library at the bottom of that ship — that's how big the thing was going to be. It would take two or three thousand bombs. The people who worked on it were a lot of the Los Alamos people who had done the hydrogen bomb work. It was the first project funded by ARPA. That's the contract where ARPA gave the first million dollars to get this thing started. "Spaceship project officially begun. Job waiting for you. Dyson." That's July '58. Two days later, the space traveler's manifesto explaining why — just like we heard yesterday — why we need to go into space: "... trips to satellites of the outer planets. August 20, 1958."These are the statistics of what would be the good places to go and stop. Some of the sizes of the ships, ranging all the way up to ship mass of 8 million tons. So that was the outer extreme. Here was version two: 2,000 bombs. These are five-kiloton yield bombs, about the size of small Volkswagens; it would take 800 to get into orbit. Here we see a 10,000-ton ship will deliver 1,300 tons to Saturn and back — essentially, a five-year trip. Possible departure dates: October 1960 to February 1967. These are trajectories going to Mars. All this was done by hand, with slide rules. The little Orion ship, and what it would take to do what Orion does with chemicals: you have a ship the size of the Empire State Building.NASA had no interest; they tried to kill the project. The people who supported it were the Air Force, which meant that it was all secret. And that's why when you get something declassified, that's what it looks like. Military weapon versions that carried hydrogen bombs that could destroy half the planet. There's another version there that sends retaliatory strikes at the Soviet Union. This is the really secret stuff: how to get directed energy explosions. So you're sending the energy of a nuclear explosion — not like just a stick of dynamite, but you're directing it at the ship. And this is still a very active subject. It's quite dangerous, but I believe it's better to have dangerous things in the open than think you're going to keep them secret.This is what happened at 600 microseconds. The Air Force started to build smaller models and actually started doing this. The guys in La Jolla said, "We've got to get started now." They built a high-explosive propelled model. These are stills from film footage that was saved by someone who was supposed to destroy it but didn't, and kept it in their basement for the last 40 years. So, these are three-pound charges of C4; that's about 10 times what the guy had in his shoes.(Laughter)This is Ed Day putting — So each of these coffee cans has three pounds of C4 in it. They're building a system that ejects these at quarter-second intervals. That's my dad in the sport coat there, holding the briefcase. So, they had a lot of fun doing this. But no children were allowed; my dad could tell me he was building a spaceship and going to go to Saturn, but he could not say anything more about it.So all my life I have wanted to find this stuff out, and spent the last four years tracking these old guys down. These are stills from the video. Jeff Bezos kindly, yesterday, said he'll put this video up on the Amazon site — some little clip of it.(Applause)So, thanks to him. They got quite serious about the engineering of this. The size of that mass, for us, is really large technology in a way we're never going to go back to. If you saw the 1959 — this is what it would feel like in the passenger compartment; that's acceleration profile.(Laughter)And pulse-system yield: we're looking at 20-kiloton yield for an effective thrust of 10 million newtons. Well, here we have a little problem, the radiation doses at the crew station: 700 rads per shot.(Laughter)Fission yields during development: they were hoping to get clean bombs; they didn't. Eyeburn: this is what happens to the people in Miami who are looking up.(Laughter)Personnel compartment noise: that's not too bad; it's very low frequencies, it's basically like these sub-woofers. And now we have ground-hazard assessments when you have a blow-up on the pad. Finally, at the very end in 1964, NASA steps in and says, "OK, we'll support a feasibility study for a small version that could be launched with Saturn Vs in sections and pieced together."So this is what NASA did, getting an eight-man version that would go to Mars. They liked it because the guys could kind of live there and be like, "It's like living in a submarine." This is crew compartment. It switches, so what's upside down is right side up when you go to artificial gravity mode. The scientists were still going to go along; they would take seven astronauts and seven scientists. This is a 20-man version for going to Jupiter: bunks, storm cellars, exercise room. You know, it was going to be a nice, long trip.The Air Force version: here we have a military version. This is the kind of stuff that's not been declassified, just that people managed to sneak home and after, you know, on their deathbed, basically, gave me that. The sort of artist conceptions. These are basically PowerPoint presentations given to the Air Force 40 years ago. Look at the little guys there outside the vehicle. And one part of NASA was interested in it, but the headquarters in NASA, they killed the project. So finally, at the end, we can see the thing followed its sort of design path right up to 1965, and then all those paths came to a halt.Results: none. This project is hereby terminated. So that's the end.All I can say in closing is: we heard yesterday that one of the 10 bad things that could happen to us is an asteroid with our name on it. And one of the bad things that could happen to NASA is if that asteroid shows up with our name on it nine months out, and everybody says, "Well, what are we going to do?" And Orion is really one of the only, if not the only, off-the-shelf technologies that could do something.(Laughter)So I'm going to tell you the good news and the bad news. The good news is that NASA has a small, secret contingency-plan division that is looking at this, trying to keep knowledge of Orion preserved in the event of such a misfortune. Maybe keep a few little bombs of plutonium on the side. That's the good news. The bad news is, when I got in contact with these people to try and get some documents from them, they went crazy because I had all this stuff that they don't have, and NASA purchased 1,759 pages of this stuff from me. So that's the state we're at; it's not very good.(Laughter)(Applause)
