00:02:33.216 --> 00:02:36.094
just like we heard yesterday --
why we need to go into space:

00:02:36.118 --> 00:02:38.285
"... trips to satellites
of the outer planets.

00:02:38.309 --> 00:02:40.029
August 20, 1958."

00:02:40.053 --> 00:02:44.410
These are the statistics of what would be
the good places to go and stop.

00:02:44.434 --> 00:02:45.923
Some of the sizes of the ships,

00:02:45.947 --> 00:02:50.129
ranging all the way up
to ship mass of 8 million tons.

00:02:50.153 --> 00:02:51.586
So that was the outer extreme.

00:02:51.610 --> 00:02:55.471
Here was version two: 2,000 bombs.

00:02:55.495 --> 00:03:00.788
These are five-kiloton yield bombs,
about the size of small Volkswagens;

00:03:00.812 --> 00:03:03.271
it would take 800 to get into orbit.

00:03:03.295 --> 00:03:07.715
Here we see a 10,000-ton ship
will deliver 1,300 tons

00:03:07.739 --> 00:03:10.553
to Saturn and back --
essentially, a five-year trip.

00:03:10.577 --> 00:03:15.458
Possible departure dates:
October 1960 to February 1967.

00:03:15.482 --> 00:03:18.101
These are trajectories going to Mars.

00:03:18.125 --> 00:03:20.243
All this was done by hand,
with slide rules.

00:03:20.267 --> 00:03:21.831
The little Orion ship,

00:03:21.855 --> 00:03:24.707
and what it would take
to do what Orion does with chemicals:

00:03:24.731 --> 00:03:27.268
you have a ship the size
of the Empire State Building.

00:03:27.292 --> 00:03:29.772
NASA had no interest;
they tried to kill the project.

00:03:29.796 --> 00:03:31.995
The people who supported it
were the Air Force,

00:03:32.019 --> 00:03:33.693
which meant that it was all secret.

00:03:33.717 --> 00:03:37.397
And that's why when you get something
declassified, that's what it looks like.

00:03:37.421 --> 00:03:39.937
Military weapon versions
that carried hydrogen bombs

00:03:39.961 --> 00:03:41.642
that could destroy half the planet.

00:03:41.666 --> 00:03:45.490
There's another version there that sends
retaliatory strikes at the Soviet Union.

00:03:45.514 --> 00:03:47.046
This is the really secret stuff:

00:03:47.070 --> 00:03:49.182
how to get directed energy explosions.

00:03:49.206 --> 00:03:51.755
So you're sending the energy
of a nuclear explosion --

00:03:51.779 --> 00:03:55.141
not like just a stick of dynamite,
but you're directing it at the ship.

00:03:55.165 --> 00:03:57.429
And this is still a very active subject.

00:03:57.453 --> 00:03:58.659
It's quite dangerous,

00:03:58.683 --> 00:04:01.636
but I believe it's better to have
dangerous things in the open

00:04:01.660 --> 00:04:03.716
than think you're going
to keep them secret.

00:04:03.740 --> 00:04:05.796
This is what happened
at 600 microseconds.

00:04:05.820 --> 00:04:08.595
The Air Force started
to build smaller models

00:04:08.619 --> 00:04:10.313
and actually started doing this.

00:04:10.337 --> 00:04:13.060
The guys in La Jolla said,
"We've got to get started now."

00:04:13.084 --> 00:04:15.484
They built a high-explosive
propelled model.

00:04:15.508 --> 00:04:19.230
These are stills from
film footage that was saved

00:04:19.254 --> 00:04:21.809
by someone who was supposed
to destroy it but didn't,

00:04:21.833 --> 00:04:24.271
and kept it in their basement
for the last 40 years.

00:04:24.295 --> 00:04:26.211
So, these are three-pound charges of C4;

00:04:26.235 --> 00:04:28.908
that's about 10 times
what the guy had in his shoes.

00:04:28.932 --> 00:04:30.112
(Laughter)

00:04:30.136 --> 00:04:31.558
This is Ed Day putting --

00:04:31.582 --> 00:04:34.831
So each of these coffee cans
has three pounds of C4 in it.

00:04:34.855 --> 00:04:38.991
They're building a system that ejects
these at quarter-second intervals.

00:04:39.015 --> 00:04:42.293
That's my dad in the sport coat there,
holding the briefcase.

00:04:42.317 --> 00:04:44.445
So, they had a lot of fun doing this.

00:04:44.469 --> 00:04:45.954
But no children were allowed;

00:04:45.978 --> 00:04:49.581
my dad could tell me he was building
a spaceship and going to go to Saturn,

00:04:49.605 --> 00:04:51.723
but he could not say
anything more about it.

00:04:51.747 --> 00:04:54.355
So all my life I have wanted
to find this stuff out,

00:04:54.379 --> 00:04:57.331
and spent the last four years
tracking these old guys down.

00:04:57.355 --> 00:04:58.882
These are stills from the video.

00:04:58.906 --> 00:05:01.685
Jeff Bezos kindly, yesterday,
said he'll put this video up

00:05:01.709 --> 00:05:04.101
on the Amazon site --
some little clip of it.

00:05:04.125 --> 00:05:05.133
(Applause)

00:05:05.157 --> 00:05:06.414
So, thanks to him.

00:05:06.438 --> 00:05:09.034
They got quite serious
about the engineering of this.

00:05:09.058 --> 00:05:11.079
The size of that mass, for us,

00:05:11.103 --> 00:05:15.031
is really large technology in a way
we're never going to go back to.

00:05:15.055 --> 00:05:16.809
If you saw the 1959 --

00:05:16.833 --> 00:05:19.693
this is what it would feel
like in the passenger compartment;

00:05:19.717 --> 00:05:21.090
that's acceleration profile.

00:05:21.114 --> 00:05:22.122
(Laughter)

00:05:22.146 --> 00:05:25.999
And pulse-system yield:
we're looking at 20-kiloton yield

00:05:26.023 --> 00:05:28.334
for an effective thrust
of 10 million newtons.

00:05:28.358 --> 00:05:31.995
Well, here we have a little problem,
the radiation doses at the crew station:

00:05:32.019 --> 00:05:34.766
700 rads per shot.

00:05:34.790 --> 00:05:36.497
(Laughter)

00:05:36.521 --> 00:05:38.274
Fission yields during development:

00:05:38.298 --> 00:05:41.604
they were hoping to get
clean bombs; they didn't.

00:05:41.628 --> 00:05:45.884
Eyeburn: this is what happens
to the people in Miami who are looking up.

00:05:45.908 --> 00:05:47.332
(Laughter)

00:05:47.356 --> 00:05:50.911
Personnel compartment noise: that's
not too bad; it's very low frequencies,

00:05:50.935 --> 00:05:52.753
it's basically like these sub-woofers.

00:05:52.777 --> 00:05:56.411
And now we have ground-hazard assessments
when you have a blow-up on the pad.

00:05:56.435 --> 00:05:59.363
Finally, at the very end in 1964,
NASA steps in and says,

00:05:59.387 --> 00:06:02.956
"OK, we'll support a feasibility study
for a small version

00:06:02.980 --> 00:06:07.080
that could be launched with Saturn Vs
in sections and pieced together."

00:06:07.104 --> 00:06:09.129
So this is what NASA did,

00:06:09.153 --> 00:06:14.104
getting an eight-man version
that would go to Mars.

00:06:14.128 --> 00:06:17.324
They liked it because the guys could
kind of live there and be like,

00:06:17.348 --> 00:06:18.974
"It's like living in a submarine."

00:06:18.998 --> 00:06:20.260
This is crew compartment.

00:06:20.284 --> 00:06:22.667
It switches, so what's
upside down is right side up

00:06:22.691 --> 00:06:24.554
when you go to artificial gravity mode.

00:06:24.578 --> 00:06:26.640
The scientists were still
going to go along;

00:06:26.664 --> 00:06:29.189
they would take seven astronauts
and seven scientists.

00:06:29.213 --> 00:06:31.365
This is a 20-man version
for going to Jupiter:

00:06:31.389 --> 00:06:33.161
bunks, storm cellars, exercise room.

00:06:33.185 --> 00:06:35.832
You know, it was going
to be a nice, long trip.

00:06:35.856 --> 00:06:40.045
The Air Force version:
here we have a military version.

00:06:40.069 --> 00:06:42.659
This is the kind of stuff
that's not been declassified,

00:06:42.683 --> 00:06:45.461
just that people managed to sneak
home and after, you know,

00:06:45.485 --> 00:06:48.064
on their deathbed,
basically, gave me that.

00:06:49.032 --> 00:06:50.530
The sort of artist conceptions.

00:06:50.554 --> 00:06:52.736
These are basically
PowerPoint presentations

00:06:52.760 --> 00:06:54.821
given to the Air Force 40 years ago.

00:06:54.845 --> 00:06:58.543
Look at the little guys there
outside the vehicle.

00:06:59.510 --> 00:07:02.478
And one part of NASA was interested in it,

00:07:02.502 --> 00:07:05.465
but the headquarters in NASA,
they killed the project.

00:07:06.626 --> 00:07:09.008
So finally, at the end,

00:07:09.032 --> 00:07:14.249
we can see the thing followed
its sort of design path right up to 1965,

00:07:14.273 --> 00:07:16.224
and then all those paths came to a halt.

00:07:16.248 --> 00:07:17.709
Results: none.

00:07:17.733 --> 00:07:19.737
This project is hereby terminated.

00:07:19.761 --> 00:07:21.639
So that's the end.

00:07:21.663 --> 00:07:23.264
All I can say in closing is:

00:07:23.288 --> 00:07:27.591
we heard yesterday that one of the 10
bad things that could happen to us

00:07:27.615 --> 00:07:30.205
is an asteroid with our name on it.

00:07:30.229 --> 00:07:32.618
And one of the bad things
that could happen to NASA

00:07:32.642 --> 00:07:35.757
is if that asteroid shows up
with our name on it nine months out,

00:07:35.781 --> 00:07:37.376
and everybody says,

00:07:37.400 --> 00:07:38.953
"Well, what are we going to do?"

00:07:38.977 --> 00:07:41.920
And Orion is really one
of the only, if not the only,

00:07:41.944 --> 00:07:46.025
off-the-shelf technologies
that could do something.

00:07:46.049 --> 00:07:47.900
(Laughter)

00:07:47.924 --> 00:07:50.558
So I'm going to tell you
the good news and the bad news.

00:07:50.582 --> 00:07:56.333
The good news is that NASA has a small,
secret contingency-plan division

00:07:56.357 --> 00:08:00.896
that is looking at this, trying
to keep knowledge of Orion preserved

00:08:00.920 --> 00:08:02.968
in the event of such a misfortune.

00:08:02.992 --> 00:08:06.000
Maybe keep a few little
bombs of plutonium on the side.

00:08:06.024 --> 00:08:07.175
That's the good news.

00:08:07.199 --> 00:08:09.826
The bad news is, when I got
in contact with these people

00:08:09.850 --> 00:08:12.937
to try and get some documents
from them, they went crazy

00:08:12.961 --> 00:08:15.308
because I had all this stuff
that they don't have,

00:08:15.332 --> 00:08:20.377
and NASA purchased 1,759 pages
of this stuff from me.

00:08:20.401 --> 00:08:23.084
So that's the state we're at;
it's not very good.

00:08:23.108 --> 00:08:24.370
(Laughter)

00:08:24.394 --> 00:08:26.394
(Applause)

title: Building uniqueness
transcript: So, what I'd like to talk about is something that was very dear to Kahn's heart, which is: how do we discover what is really particular about a project? How do you discover the uniqueness of a project as unique as a person? Because it seems to me that finding this uniqueness has to do with dealing with the whole force of globalization; that the particular is central to finding the uniqueness of place and the uniqueness of a program in a building.And so I'll take you to Wichita, Kansas, where I was asked some years ago to do a science museum on a site, right downtown by the river. And I thought the secret of the site was to make the building of the river, part of the river. Unfortunately, though, the site was separated from the river by McLean Boulevard so I suggested, "Let's reroute McLean," and that gave birth instantly to Friends of McLean Boulevard. (Laughter) And it took six months to reroute it.The first image I showed the building committee was this astronomic observatory of Jantar Mantar in Jaipur because I talked about what makes a building a building of science. And it seemed to me that this structure — complex, rich and yet totally rational: it's an instrument — had something to do with science, and somehow a building for science should be different and unique and speak of that. And so my first sketch after I left was to say, "Let's cut the channel and make an island and make an island building." And I got all excited and came back, and they sort of looked at me in dismay and said, "An island? This used to be an island — Ackerman Island — and we filled in the channel during the Depression to create jobs." (Laughter)And so the process began and they said, "You can't put it all on an island; some of it has to be on the mainland because we don't want to turn our back to the community." And there emerged a design: the galleries sort of forming an island and you could walk through them or on the roof. And there were all kinds of exciting features: you could come in through the landside buildings, walk through the galleries into playgrounds in the landscape. If you were cheap you could walk on top of a bridge to the roof, peek in the exhibits and then get totally seduced, come back and pay the five dollars admission. (Laughter) And the client was happy — well, sort of happy because we were four million dollars over the budget, but essentially happy.But I was still troubled, and I was troubled because I felt this was capricious. It was complex, but there was something capricious about its complexity. It was, what I would say, compositional complexity, and I felt that if I had to fulfill what I talked about — a building for science — there had to be some kind of a generating idea, some kind of a generating geometry. And this gave birth to the idea of having toroidal generating geometry, one with its center deep in the earth for the landside building and a toroid with its center in the sky for the island building. A toroid, for those who don't know, is the surface of a doughnut or, for some of us, a bagel. And out of this idea started spinning off many, many kinds of variations of different plans and possibilities, and then the plan itself evolved in relationship to the exhibits, and you see the intersection of the plan with the toroidal geometry.And finally the building — this is the model. And when there were complaints about budget, I said, "Well, it's worth doing the island because you get twice for your money: reflections." And here's the building as it opened, with a channel overlooking downtown, and as seen from downtown. And the bike route's going right through the building, so those traveling the river would see the exhibits and be drawn to the building. The toroidal geometry made for a very efficient building: every beam in this building is the same radius, all laminated wood. Every wall, every concrete wall is resisting the stresses and supporting the building. Every piece of the building works. These are the galleries with the light coming in through the skylights, and at night, and on opening day.Going back to 1976. (Applause) In 1976, I was asked to design a children's memorial museum in a Holocaust museum in Yad Vashem in Jerusalem, which you see here the campus. I was asked to do a building, and I was given all the artifacts of clothing and drawings. And I felt very troubled. I worked on it for months and I couldn't deal with it because I felt people were coming out of the historic museum, they are totally saturated with information and to see yet another museum with information, it would make them just unable to digest. And so I made a counter-proposal:I said, "No building." There was a cave on the site; we tunnel into the hill, descend through the rock into an underground chamber. There's an anteroom with photographs of children who perished and then you come into a large space. There is a single candle flickering in the center; by an arrangement of reflective glasses, it reflects into infinity in all directions. You walk through the space, a voice reads the names, ages and place of birth of the children. This voice does not repeat for six months. And then you descend to light and to the north and to life.Well, they said, "People won't understand, they'll think it's a discotheque. You can't do that." And they shelved the project. And it sat there for 10 years, and then one day Abe Spiegel from Los Angeles, who had lost his three-year-old son at Auschwitz, came, saw the model, wrote the check and it got built 10 years later.So, many years after that in 1998, I was on one of my monthly trips to Jerusalem and I got a call from the foreign ministry saying, "We've got the Chief Minister of the Punjab here. He is on a state visit. We took him on a visit to Yad Vashem, we took him to the children's memorial; he was extremely moved. He's demanding to meet the architect. Could you come down and meet him in Tel Aviv?" And I went down and Chief Minister Badal said to me, "We Sikhs have suffered a great deal, as you have Jews. I was very moved by what I saw today. We are going to build our national museum to tell the story of our people; we're about to embark on that. I'd like you to come and design it."And so, you know, it's one of those things that you don't take too seriously. But two weeks later, I was in this little town, Anandpur Sahib, outside Chandigarh, the capital of the Punjab, and the temple and also next to it the fortress that the last guru of the Sikhs, Guru Gobind, died in as he wrote the Khalsa, which is their holy scripture. And I got to work and they took me somewhere down there, nine kilometers away from the town and the temple, and said, "That's where we have chosen the location."And I said, "This just doesn't make any sense. The pilgrims come here by the hundreds of thousands — they're not going to get in trucks and buses and go down there. Let's get back to the town and walk to the site." And I recommended they do it right there, on that hill and this hill, and bridge all the way into the town. And, as things are a little easier in India, the site was purchased within a week and we were working. (Laughter)And my proposal was to split the museum into two — the permanent exhibits at one end, the auditorium, library, and changing exhibitions on the other — to flood the valley into a series of water gardens and to link it all to the fort and to the downtown. And the structures rise from the sand cliffs — they're built in concrete and sandstones; the roofs are stainless steel — they are facing south and reflecting light towards the temple itself, pedestrians crisscross from one side to the other. And as you come from the north, it is all masonry growing out of the sand cliffs as you come from the Himalayas and evoking the tradition of the fortress.And then I went away for four months and there was going to be groundbreaking. And I came back and, lo and behold, the little model I'd left behind had been built ten times bigger for public display on site and ... the bridge was built! (Laughter) Within the working drawings! And half a million people gathered for the celebrations; you can see them on the site itself as the foundations are beginning. I was renamed Safdie Singh. And there it is under construction; there are 1,800 workers at work and it will be finished in two years.Back to Yad Vashem three years ago. After all this episode began, Yad Vashem decided to rebuild completely the historic museum because now Washington was built — the Holocaust Museum in Washington — and that museum is so much more comprehensive in terms of information. And Yad Vashem needs to deal with three million visitors a year at this point. They said, "Let's rebuild the museum." But of course, the Sikhs might give you a job on a platter — the Jews make it hard: international competition, phase one, phase two, phase three. (Laughter)And again, I felt kind of uncomfortable with the notion that a building the size of the Washington building — 50,000 square feet — will sit on that fragile hill and that we will go into galleries — rooms with doors and sort of familiar rooms — to tell the story of the Holocaust. And I proposed that we cut through the mountain. That was my first sketch. Just cut the whole museum through the mountain — enter from one side of the mountain, come out on the other side of the mountain — and then bring light through the mountain into the chambers.And here you see the model: a reception building and some underground parking. You cross a bridge, you enter this triangular room, 60 feet high, which cuts right into the hill and extends right through as you go towards the north. And all of it, then, all the galleries are underground, and you see the openings for the light. And at night, just one line of light cuts through the mountain, which is a skylight on top of that triangle. And all the galleries, as you move through them and so on, are below grade. And there are chambers carved in the rock — concrete walls, stone, the natural rock when possible — with the light shafts. This is actually a Spanish quarry, which sort of inspired the kind of spaces that these galleries could be. And then, coming towards the north, it opens up: it bursts out of the mountain into, again, a view of light and of the city and of the Jerusalem hills.I'd like to conclude with a project I've been working on for two months. It's the headquarters for the Institute of Peace in Washington, the U.S. Institute of Peace. The site chosen is across from the Lincoln Memorial; you see it there directly on the Mall. It's the last building on the Mall, on access of the Roosevelt Bridge that comes in from Virginia. That too was a competition, and it is something I'm just beginning to work on.But one recognized the kind of uniqueness of the site. If it were to be anywhere in Washington, it would be an office building, a conference center, a place for negotiating peace and so on — all of which the building is — but by virtue of the choice of putting it on the Mall and by the Lincoln Memorial, this becomes the structure that is the symbol of peace on the Mall. And that was a lot of heat to deal with.The first sketch recognizes that the building is many spaces — spaces where research goes on, conference centers, a public building because it will be a museum devoted to peacemaking — and these are the drawings that we submitted for the competition, the plans showing the spaces which radiate outwards from the entry. You see the structure as, in the sequence of structures on the Mall, very transparent and inviting and looking in. And then as you enter it again, looking in all directions towards the city. And what I felt about that building is that it really was a building that had to do with a lightness of being — to quote Kundera — that it had to do with whiteness, it had to do with a certain dynamic quality and it had to do with optimism. And this is where it is; it's sort of evolving.Studies for the structure of the roof, which demands maybe new materials: how to make it white, how to make it translucent, how to make it glowing, how to make it not capricious. And here studying, in three dimensions, how to give some kind, again, of order, a structure; not something you feel you could just change because you stop the design of that particular process. And so it goes.I'd like to conclude by saying something ... (Applause) I'd like to conclude by relating all of what I've said to the term "beauty." And I know it is not a fashionable term these days, and certainly not fashionable in the discourse of architectural schools, but it seems to me that all this, in one way or the other, is a search for beauty. Beauty in the most profound sense of fit. I have a quote that I like by a morphologist, 1917, Theodore Cook, who said, "Beauty connotes humanity. We call a natural object beautiful because we see that its form expresses fitness, the perfect fulfillment of function." Well, I would have said the perfect fulfillment of purpose. Nevertheless, beauty as the kind of fit; something that tells us that all the forces that have to do with our natural environment have been fulfilled — and our human environment — for that.Twenty years ago, in a conference Richard and I were at together, I wrote a poem, which seems to me to still hold for me today. "He who seeks truth shall find beauty. He who seeks beauty shall find vanity. He who seeks order shall find gratification. He who seeks gratification shall be disappointed. He who considers himself the servant of his fellow beings shall find the joy of self-expression. He who seeks self-expression shall fall into the pit of arrogance. Arrogance is incompatible with nature. Through nature, the nature of the universe and the nature of man, we shall seek truth. If we seek truth, we shall find beauty."Thank you very much. (Applause)

And so my first sketch after I left was to say,

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:06.958
"Let's cut the channel and make an island and make an island building."

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:09.958
And I got all excited and came back, and

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:12.958
they sort of looked at me in dismay and said, "An island?

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:14.958
This used to be an island -- Ackerman Island --

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:17.958
and we filled in the channel during the Depression to create jobs."

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:20.958
(Laughter)

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:23.958
And so the process began and they said,

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:25.958
"You can't put it all on an island;

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:27.958
some of it has to be on the mainland because

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:30.958
we don't want to turn our back to the community."

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:34.958
And there emerged a design: the galleries sort of forming an island

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:37.958
and you could walk through them or on the roof.

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:40.958
And there were all kinds of exciting features:

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:43.958
you could come in through the landside buildings,

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:46.958
walk through the galleries into playgrounds in the landscape.

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:49.958
If you were cheap you could walk on top of a bridge to the roof,

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:53.958
peek in the exhibits and then get totally seduced,

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
come back and pay the five dollars admission.

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.958
(Laughter)

00:02:57.958 --> 00:02:59.958
And the client was happy -- well, sort of happy

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:03.958
because we were four million dollars over the budget, but essentially happy.

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:09.958
But I was still troubled, and I was troubled because I felt this was capricious.

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:14.958
It was complex, but there was something capricious about its complexity.

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:17.958
It was, what I would say, compositional complexity,

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:22.958
and I felt that if I had to fulfill what I talked about --

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:25.958
a building for science -- there had to be some kind of a generating idea,

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:28.958
some kind of a generating geometry.

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:33.958
And this gave birth to the idea of having toroidal generating geometry,

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:37.958
one with its center deep in the earth for the landside building

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:43.958
and a toroid with its center in the sky for the island building.

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:45.958
A toroid, for those who don't know,

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:49.958
is the surface of a doughnut or, for some of us, a bagel.

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:53.958
And out of this idea started spinning off many,

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:58.958
many kinds of variations of different plans and possibilities,

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:02.958
and then the plan itself evolved in relationship to the exhibits,

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:08.958
and you see the intersection of the plan with the toroidal geometry.

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:11.958
And finally the building -- this is the model.

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:13.958
And when there were complaints about budget, I said,

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:18.958
"Well, it's worth doing the island because you get twice for your money: reflections."

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:22.958
And here's the building as it opened,

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:27.958
with a channel overlooking downtown, and as seen from downtown.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:30.958
And the bike route's going right through the building,

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:36.958
so those traveling the river would see the exhibits and be drawn to the building.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:42.958
The toroidal geometry made for a very efficient building:

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:47.958
every beam in this building is the same radius, all laminated wood.

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:53.958
Every wall, every concrete wall is resisting the stresses and supporting the building.

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:56.958
Every piece of the building works.

00:04:56.958 --> 00:05:00.958
These are the galleries with the light coming in through the skylights,

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:05.958
and at night, and on opening day.

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:10.958
Going back to 1976.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:15.958
(Applause)

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:20.958
In 1976, I was asked to design a children's memorial museum

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:24.958
in a Holocaust museum in Yad Vashem in Jerusalem,

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:27.958
which you see here the campus.

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
I was asked to do a building,

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:35.958
and I was given all the artifacts of clothing and drawings.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.958
And I felt very troubled.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
I worked on it for months and I couldn't deal with it

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:42.958
because I felt people were coming out of the historic museum,

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
they are totally saturated with information

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.958
and to see yet another museum with information,

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:52.958
it would make them just unable to digest.

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
And so I made a counter-proposal:

00:05:54.958 --> 00:06:01.958
I said, "No building." There was a cave on the site; we tunnel into the hill,

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:07.958
descend through the rock into an underground chamber.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:11.958
There's an anteroom with photographs of children who perished

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:14.958
and then you come into a large space.

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:19.958
There is a single candle flickering in the center;

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:26.958
by an arrangement of reflective glasses, it reflects into infinity in all directions.

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:31.958
You walk through the space, a voice reads the names,

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
ages and place of birth of the children.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.958
This voice does not repeat for six months.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:41.958
And then you descend to light and to the north and to life.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
Well, they said, "People won't understand,

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
they'll think it's a discotheque. You can't do that."

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:49.958
And they shelved the project. And it sat there for 10 years,

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:53.958
and then one day Abe Spiegel from Los Angeles,

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:56.958
who had lost his three-year-old son at Auschwitz,

00:06:56.958 --> 00:07:00.958
came, saw the model, wrote the check and it got built 10 years later.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:06.958
So, many years after that in 1998,

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:10.958
I was on one of my monthly trips to Jerusalem

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:13.958
and I got a call from the foreign ministry saying,

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:19.958
"We've got the Chief Minister of the Punjab here.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:25.958
He is on a state visit. We took him on a visit to Yad Vashem,

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
we took him to the children's memorial; he was extremely moved.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:31.958
He's demanding to meet the architect. Could you come down and meet him in Tel Aviv?"

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:36.958
And I went down and Chief Minister Badal said to me,

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:41.958
"We Sikhs have suffered a great deal, as you have Jews.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
I was very moved by what I saw today.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:48.958
We are going to build our national museum to tell the story of our people;

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
we're about to embark on that.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
I'd like you to come and design it."

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:58.958
And so, you know, it's one of those things that you don't take too seriously.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:03.958
But two weeks later, I was in this little town, Anandpur Sahib,

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:07.958
outside Chandigarh, the capital of the Punjab,

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:12.958
and the temple and also next to it the fortress

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:17.958
that the last guru of the Sikhs, Guru Gobind, died in

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:22.958
as he wrote the Khalsa, which is their holy scripture.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:27.958
And I got to work and they took me somewhere down there,

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
nine kilometers away from the town and the temple,

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:32.958
and said, "That's where we have chosen the location."

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:36.958
And I said, "This just doesn't make any sense.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
The pilgrims come here by the hundreds of thousands --

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
they're not going to get in trucks and buses and go down there.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:45.958
Let's get back to the town and walk to the site."

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
And I recommended they do it right there, on that hill

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:52.958
and this hill, and bridge all the way into the town.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:58.958
And, as things are a little easier in India, the site was purchased within a week

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:00.958
and we were working.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:01.958
(Laughter)

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:05.958
And my proposal was to split the museum into two --

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:10.958
the permanent exhibits at one end, the auditorium, library,

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
and changing exhibitions on the other --

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:16.958
to flood the valley into a series of water gardens

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:20.958
and to link it all to the fort and to the downtown.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:24.958
And the structures rise from the sand cliffs --

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:29.958
they're built in concrete and sandstones; the roofs are stainless steel --

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:34.958
they are facing south and reflecting light towards the temple itself,

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:37.958
pedestrians crisscross from one side to the other.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:43.958
And as you come from the north, it is all masonry growing out of the sand cliffs

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:49.958
as you come from the Himalayas and evoking the tradition of the fortress.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
And then I went away for four months

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:53.958
and there was going to be groundbreaking.

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
And I came back and, lo and behold, the little model I'd left behind

00:09:56.958 --> 00:10:00.958
had been built ten times bigger for public display on site

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.958
and ... the bridge was built!

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:10.958
(Laughter)

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:12.958
Within the working drawings!

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:17.958
And half a million people gathered for the celebrations;

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:23.958
you can see them on the site itself as the foundations are beginning.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:28.958
I was renamed Safdie Singh. And there it is under construction;

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:33.958
there are 1,800 workers at work and it will be finished in two years.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:38.958
Back to Yad Vashem three years ago. After all this episode began,

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:42.958
Yad Vashem decided to rebuild completely the historic museum

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
because now Washington was built -- the Holocaust Museum in Washington --

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:50.958
and that museum is so much more comprehensive in terms of information.

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:54.958
And Yad Vashem needs to deal with three million visitors a year at this point.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
They said, "Let's rebuild the museum."

00:10:56.958 --> 00:11:00.958
But of course, the Sikhs might give you a job on a platter -- the Jews make it hard:

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:05.958
international competition, phase one, phase two, phase three.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:07.958
(Laughter)

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:11.958
And again, I felt kind of uncomfortable with the notion

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:16.958
that a building the size of the Washington building --

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:20.958
50,000 square feet -- will sit on that fragile hill

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:24.958
and that we will go into galleries -- rooms with doors

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:28.958
and sort of familiar rooms -- to tell the story of the Holocaust.

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:33.958
And I proposed that we cut through the mountain. That was my first sketch.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
Just cut the whole museum through the mountain --

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
enter from one side of the mountain,

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
come out on the other side of the mountain --

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:43.958
and then bring light through the mountain into the chambers.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:46.958
And here you see the model:

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
a reception building and some underground parking.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:55.958
You cross a bridge, you enter this triangular room, 60 feet high,

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:57.958
which cuts right into the hill

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:02.958
and extends right through as you go towards the north.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:05.958
And all of it, then, all the galleries are underground,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
and you see the openings for the light.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:11.958
And at night, just one line of light cuts through the mountain,

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:15.958
which is a skylight on top of that triangle.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:19.958
And all the galleries,

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:22.958
as you move through them and so on, are below grade.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:27.958
And there are chambers carved in the rock --

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:31.958
concrete walls, stone, the natural rock when possible -- with the light shafts.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:37.958
This is actually a Spanish quarry, which sort of inspired

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:40.958
the kind of spaces that these galleries could be.

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:43.958
And then, coming towards the north, it opens up:

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:49.958
it bursts out of the mountain into, again, a view of light and of the city

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
and of the Jerusalem hills.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:59.958
I'd like to conclude with a project I've been working on for two months.

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:05.958
It's the headquarters for the Institute of Peace in Washington,

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
the U.S. Institute of Peace.

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:12.958
The site chosen is across from the Lincoln Memorial;

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:16.958
you see it there directly on the Mall. It's the last building on the Mall,

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:20.958
on access of the Roosevelt Bridge that comes in from Virginia.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:27.958
That too was a competition, and it is something I'm just beginning to work on.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:33.958
But one recognized the kind of uniqueness of the site.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
If it were to be anywhere in Washington,

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:38.958
it would be an office building, a conference center,

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:42.958
a place for negotiating peace and so on -- all of which the building is --

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:46.958
but by virtue of the choice of putting it on the Mall and by the Lincoln Memorial,

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:51.958
this becomes the structure that is the symbol of peace on the Mall.

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:56.958
And that was a lot of heat to deal with.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:14:00.958
The first sketch recognizes that the building is many spaces --

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:05.958
spaces where research goes on, conference centers,

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:09.958
a public building because it will be a museum devoted to peacemaking --

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:13.958
and these are the drawings that we submitted for the competition,

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:18.958
the plans showing the spaces which radiate outwards from the entry.

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:22.958
You see the structure as, in the sequence of structures on the Mall,

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:26.958
very transparent and inviting and looking in.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:31.958
And then as you enter it again, looking in all directions towards the city.

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:35.958
And what I felt about that building is that it really was a building

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:42.958
that had to do with a lightness of being -- to quote Kundera --

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
that it had to do with whiteness,

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:50.958
it had to do with a certain dynamic quality and it had to do with optimism.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:55.958
And this is where it is; it's sort of evolving.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:58.958
Studies for the structure of the roof,

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:02.958
which demands maybe new materials:

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:06.958
how to make it white, how to make it translucent, how to make it glowing,

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
how to make it not capricious.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:14.958
And here studying, in three dimensions,

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:20.958
how to give some kind, again, of order, a structure;

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
not something you feel you could just change

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:25.958
because you stop the design of that particular process.

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
And so it goes.

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
I'd like to conclude by saying something ...

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:46.958
(Applause)

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:52.958
I'd like to conclude by relating all of what I've said to the term "beauty."

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:55.958
And I know it is not a fashionable term these days,

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:59.958
and certainly not fashionable in the discourse of architectural schools,

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:05.958
but it seems to me that all this, in one way or the other, is a search for beauty.

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:08.958
Beauty in the most profound sense of fit.

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:17.958
I have a quote that I like by a morphologist, 1917,

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:21.958
Theodore Cook, who said, "Beauty connotes humanity.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:25.958
We call a natural object beautiful because we see

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:30.958
that its form expresses fitness, the perfect fulfillment of function."

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:34.958
Well, I would have said the perfect fulfillment of purpose.

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:39.958
Nevertheless, beauty as the kind of fit; something that tells us

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:43.958
that all the forces that have to do with our natural environment

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:47.958
have been fulfilled -- and our human environment -- for that.

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:52.958
Twenty years ago, in a conference Richard and I were at together,

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:57.958
I wrote a poem, which seems to me to still hold for me today.

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:04.958
"He who seeks truth shall find beauty. He who seeks beauty shall find vanity.

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:08.958
He who seeks order shall find gratification.

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:12.958
He who seeks gratification shall be disappointed.

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:15.958
He who considers himself the servant of his fellow beings

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:21.958
shall find the joy of self-expression. He who seeks self-expression

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:23.958
shall fall into the pit of arrogance.

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:26.958
Arrogance is incompatible with nature.

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:29.958
Through nature, the nature of the universe and the nature of man,

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:33.958
we shall seek truth. If we seek truth, we shall find beauty."

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:34.958
Thank you very much. (Applause)

In order to do six cups, I must have perfect control

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:09.958
over three with my right hand. (Drum roll)

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:15.958
BF: Also three with his left.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:16.958
DH: Perfect.

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:22.958
(Laughter)

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:28.958
And now, all six cups. Should I do it on the first try

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:31.958
or should I miss once on purpose? (Laughter)

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:33.958
BF: First try? Once on purpose?

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:35.958
(Audience: Once on purpose!)

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:37.958
DH: How about if I try first and then decide?

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:41.958
BF: Good idea. (Laughter) Let's leave that. We'll leave that door open.

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:50.958
(Laughter) (Applause)

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:01.958
DH: He's looking at me.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:05.958
BF: That's all right, he does that. All right.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:08.958
DH: Oh! It's time for Richard's help. (Laughter)

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:10.958
Oh, good. All right.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:13.958
BF: You know, over the years, every year at the conference,

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:17.958
it's kind of become a tradition for us to do something dangerous

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:21.958
with Richard. And we've always done something with the bullwhips

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:24.958
in our act. It's funny, for years I did it with Daniel holding balloons.

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:26.958
And then we thought, "How stupid."

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:29.958
DH: Excuse me, could we work on the design of the microphone?

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:31.958
BF: I think that's the next session.

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:32.958
DH: Next session?

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:36.958
BF: Yeah. And so we've actually found a way to incorporate Richard in this.

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:39.958
He actually assumes more of the danger in this.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:41.958
DH: Please stand up, Richard. (Whip cracks)

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:47.958
Oh, sorry. (Laughter)

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:49.958
DH: Now Richard, please ... (Whip cracks)

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
BF: OK, sorry.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:54.958
DH: Jesus Christ. Richard, please stand in front of me.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:55.958
Richard Wurman: Can I say something?

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:58.958
BF: Sure.

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:00.958
RW: In all past years I've rehearsed with them,

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:02.958
the things that have happened to me --

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:06.958
I have no idea what's going to happen and that's the truth.

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:08.958
DH: All right, please stand here in front ...

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:13.958
God, I hate that. Put your hands out like this, please.

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:18.958
(Laughter)

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:20.958
BF: No, come stay up with him.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:24.958
Dan used to actually hold them but now he's got you for protection.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
It's kind of neat. OK.

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:29.958
(Laughter)

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
DH: Wow, you've been working out.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
BF: No, shut up!

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:37.958
(Laughter)

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:41.958
Having a little bit of Richard time. That's nice, that's good.

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
OK, here we go.

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:44.958
Have him hold your wrist so I can ...

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:46.958
DH: Please hold my wrist, will you. BF: Yeah, hold this a minute.

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:47.958
There you go.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
(Laughter)

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:51.958
OK.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:57.958
OK, hold on.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
RW: Hmmm.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:02.958
(Laughter)

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
DH: First one.

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:07.958
BF: All those mid-year phone calls are coming back to me now, Richard.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:10.958
(Laughter)

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:14.958
DH: So Richard, what were we on the list? Like 1,020?

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:15.958
(Laughter)

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.958
What happened there?

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
BF: I think we were just outside.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
DH: I don't get it. (Applause)

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:25.958
(Laughter)

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:27.958
DH: Sorry. BF: Having some bad flashbacks.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:29.958
RW: Do you want me to hold you or not? DH: Don't hold me that hard.

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
BF: Here we go, I'm taking it. (Balloon pops) (Applause)

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:33.958
DH: One more, one more.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
BF: We've got one more we're going to do.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:36.958
RW: Do I get to hold them?

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
BF: You don't want to hold these, trust me.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
DH: Could you spread your legs a little bit?

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:47.958
(Laughter)

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
BF: Gloria, you want to do it? It's very cool.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:51.958
(Laughter)

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:55.958
(Applause)

00:06:55.958 --> 00:07:03.958
(Laughter)

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:10.958
One more try. Man, I don't want to get too close.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:13.958
(Laughter)

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:15.958
Could you just push that?

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
(Applause)

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:37.958
DH: Wow! Boy!

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:39.958
BF: That's cool. I always wanted to try that.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:43.958
(Laughter)

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
DH: Let's jump this way, though.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:49.958
Now, we risked Richard's life, it's only fair we risk our own lives.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:56.958
So to do that, I will juggle these three razor-sharp sickles.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
And if that wasn't enough, and judging by your response, it's not ...

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
(Laughter)

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
DH: Wow! BF: Hoping for a little more build.

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
DH: True. Barry ...

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
BF: I'm going to run up behind him.

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:08.958
DH: Leap over my shoulder.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
BF: Up and over his shoulders.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
DH: Grab the blades in mid-air, land right there in a pool of blood ...

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
(Laughter)

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
Still juggling. (Laughter)

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:21.958
Impossible, you say?

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
BF: Incredible, you say?

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
DH: Why bother, you say?

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:27.958
BF: Here we go.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:30.958
DH: Just do it juggler boys, you say?

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.958
BF: This guy, this guy invented air.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:34.958
DH: I think so, that's right.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
Even the pencil.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.958
BF: He invented the pencil.

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
DH: All right, we'll do this trick, but please remember

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
it took us over 10 years to perfect.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
BF: Ten years to perfect, which you're about to see.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:48.958
DH: It's not that difficult, we just don't like to practice that much.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:49.958
BF: No, it's a hassle. Traveling too much.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
Actually, we will take a second to prove --

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
this could be fake -- that the blades are indeed razor-sharp.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
DH: Will someone please throw a small farm animal

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
up onto the stage?

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:03.958
(Laughter)

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.958
Or a virgin for a sacrifice?

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
BF: Anything?

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:08.958
DH: Where's Gloria? (Laughter)

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:11.958
BF: No, she's got ... farm animal.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
DH: Do you have a small farm animal?

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
Just trying to play the odds. All right, here we go.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
BF: Over the top, over the top.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
DH: How you feeling, Barry? You feeling all right?

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:20.958
BF: Yeah, it's all right.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:21.958
DH: Do you feel everything's OK? The atmosphere, the ...

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:22.958
BF: Yeah, a little sketchy.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:23.958
DH: Everything up here's OK?

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:24.958
BF: Yeah.

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
DH: Then here we go.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:30.958
BF: This one's a little ... Who's doing the lights? Could you

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.958
point that a little more directly

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:37.958
into my eyeballs? Is that possible? (Laughter) I can still see a little.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:42.958
DH: And turn up the intensity; we're still pink in the middle.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:43.958
We went too far. (Laughter)

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:48.958
BF: Yeah, it's too far. It's too much of a visual.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
The design of the body is a whole different thing.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:53.958
DH: Ready, Barry? BF: Over the top.

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
DH: May we have our jumping music please? (Silence)

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
May we have it a bit louder?

00:09:58.958 --> 00:09:59.958
(Laughter)

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
BF: They're a good crew! Whoa!

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:15.958
DH: Whoa, sorry. All right.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:19.958
BF: We're going on.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
DH: All right, we'll try again.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:27.958
BF: All right? Oh my gosh. Oh.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:29.958
DH: All right, here we go. Sorry about that.

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:31.958
BF: I thought I had the hard part. OK.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
DH: Whenever you're ready.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
BF: There we go!

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
(Applause)

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:49.958
All right, get up! Come on and dance! DH: Dance, come on. BF: Come on and dance!

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
Somebody dance! Come on!

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:57.958
(Applause)

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
Wow, wow, OK, stop.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:03.958
Weird, no one dances. We're two guys doing this. (Laughter)

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
I think that's uncomfortable for everyone.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:06.958
DH: The French judge ...

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:07.958
BF: One more quick thing.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
DH: The French judge gives it a 5.2.

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:15.958
(Laughter)

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:17.958
BF: Well, you know ...

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
DH: There you go ... BF: Oh, yeah. Another one coming in.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:20.958
DH: Tell them about our bio and stuff.

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:22.958
BF: Yeah. In our bio, some of you may have read

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
that we've won two world juggling championships.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
And believe it or not, you don't win juggling champions

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
for doing things with bullwhips or shaker cups.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
We're going to show you right now

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
an excerpt from a routine that we used

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
to wipe out the other juggling team competition.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.958
DH: That's right.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
BF: Good.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:49.958
DH: I know what you're thinking: other juggling teams must really suck.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:53.958
(Laughter)

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
BF: Juggling's got a bad rap.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:05.958
DH: But wait, Barry, there's still one more club lying there by my foot.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
And look, it has a twin!

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:12.958
BF: Shut up. (Laughter)

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
DH: There's still one more by my foot.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
What do you want me to do with it?

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:24.958
BF: Richard you tell him, it's your last year. (Laughter)

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
DH: That's a pretty good setup, Richard.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:28.958
BF: Yeah, it's a good setup. That's a big setup.

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:35.958
DH: You can't get any better than that. All right. What I will do: I will use my panther-like reflexes.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
BF: Nice.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
DH: I got that --

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:46.958
to reach down and grab that club in my grip of steel.

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:49.958
BF: Nice.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
DH: I touched it, Barry. That should be enough.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
BF: It's progress, that's the thing.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:57.958
(Laughter)

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:02.958
DH: How about that? I'll do it again.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:06.958
Oh wait, it's on your side, Barry.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
And it's awfully windy over there.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
BF: It is, it's weird. You wouldn't think

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
it would affect half the stage, but it is. It's weird.

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
Watch this: what I'm going to do is slide the seventh one onto my foot.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
DH: Wow! What a great trick, Barry!

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:24.958
Oh, look how it lies there.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
Oh, Barry, is there nothing you can't do?

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
(Laughter)

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:35.958
You are my hero. You're my Jim Shea, Jr.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:38.958
Too much Olympics.

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
BF: From my foot, I'll attempt to kick the seventh club. Here we go.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:45.958
DH: Where, Barry? Where? Tell us, Barry.

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:49.958
[Unclear] eagerly awaits your next syllable. What will it be?

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
What gem of knowledge?

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:54.958
What pearl of wisdom?

00:13:54.958 --> 00:14:00.958
Do you want to buy a vowel, Barry?

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
Is that your final answer?

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:07.958
BF: All right! You have to turn off the TV from time to time.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:08.958
DH: I do, I do.

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
BF: From my foot, the kick up in the seven.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
DH: We will juggle seven.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
BF: From six to seven. DH: That's a world's record. BF: Really? DH: For us.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:15.958
BF: Yes.

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
DH: Whenever you're ready there, big guy.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:24.958
Put your tongue away, Barry.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.958
BF: Oh, oh, whoa.

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:35.958
(Applause)

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:43.958
DH: Please, please stay seated. Stay seated. Thank you.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
Because now, to make this twice as difficult,

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:47.958
we'll juggle the seven clubs back ...

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
BF: Seven-club juggling.

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
DH: ... to back.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:59.958
BF: Thank you, that's it.

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:19.958
BF: Thank you guys!

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:21.958
DH: Thank you very much!

title: A parable for Kenya
transcript: My name is Joseph, a Member of Parliament in Kenya. Picture a Maasai village, and one evening, government soldiers come, surround the village and ask each elder to bring one boy to school. That's how I went to school — pretty much a government guy pointing a gun and told my father, "You have to make a choice." I walked very comfortably to this missionary school, that was run by an American missionary. The first thing the American missionary gave me was a candy. I had never in my life ever tasted candy. So I said to myself, with all these hundred other boys, this is where I belong.(Laughter) I stayed.When everybody else was dropping out. My family moved; we're nomads. It was a boarding school, I was seven — Every time it closed you had to travel to find them. 40-50 miles, it doesn't matter. You slept in the bush, but you kept going.And I stayed. I don't know why, but I did. All of a sudden I passed the national examination, found myself in a very beautiful high school in Kenya. And I finished high school. And just walking, I found a man who gave me a full scholarship to the United States. My mother still lived in a cow-dung hut, none of my brothers were going to school, and this man told me, "Here, go."I got a scholarship to St. Lawrence University, Upstate New York; finished that. And after that I went to Harvard Graduate School; finished that. Then I worked in DC a little bit: I wrote a book for National Geographic and taught U.S. history. And every time, I kept going back home, listening to their problems — sick people, people with no water, all this stuff — every time I go back to America, I kept thinking about them.Then one day, an elder gave me a story that went like this: long time ago, there was a big war between tribes. This specific tribe was really afraid of this other Luhya tribe. Every time, they sent scouts to make sure no one attacked them. So one day, the scouts came running and told the villagers, "The enemies are coming. Only half an hour away, they'll be here." So people scrambled, took their things and ready to go, move out. But there were two men: one man was blind, one man had no legs — he was born like that. The leader of the chiefs said, "No, sorry. We can't take you. You'll slow us down. We have to flee our women and children, we have to run." And they were left behind, waiting to die.But these two people worked something out. The blind man said, "Look, I'm a very strong man but I can't see." The man with no legs says, "I can see as far as the end of the world, but I can't save myself from a cat, or whatever animals." The blind man went down on his knees like this, and told the man with no legs to go over his back, and stood up. The man on top can see, the blind man can walk. These guys took off, followed the footsteps of the villagers until they found and passed them.So, this was told to me in a setup of elders. And it's a really poor area. I represent Northern Kenya: the most nomadic, remote areas you can even find. And that man told me, "So, here you are. You've got a good education from America, you have a good life in America; what are you going to do for us? We want you to be our eyes, we'll give you the legs. We'll walk you, you lead us."The opportunity came. I was always thinking about that: "What can I do to help my people? Every time you go to an area where for 43 years of independence, we still don't have basic health facilities. A man has to be transported in a wheelbarrow 30 km for a hospital. No clean drinking water.So I said, "I'm going to dedicate myself. I'm leaving America. I'm going to run for office." Last June, I moved from America, ran in July election and won. And I came for them, and that's my goal.Right now I have in place, for the last nine months, a plan that in five years, every nomad will have clean drinking water. We're building dispensaries across that constituency. I'm asking my friends from America to help with bringing nurses or doctors to help us out. I'm trying to improve infrastructure. I'm using the knowledge I received from the United States and from my community to move them forward. I'm trying to develop homegrown solutions to our issues because people from outside can come and help us, but if we don't help ourselves, there's nothing to do.My plan right now as I continue with introducing students to different fields — some become doctors, some lawyers — we want to produce a comprehensive group of people, students who can come back and help us see a community grow that is in the middle of a huge economic recession.As I continue to be a Member of Parliament and as I continue listening to all of you talking about botany, health, democracy, new inventions, I'm hoping that one day in my own little community — which is 26,000 square km, maybe five times Rhode Island — with no roads, we'll be able to become a model to help others develop.Thank you very much.(Applause)

pretty much a government guy
pointing a gun

00:00:26.982 --> 00:00:29.221
and told my father,
"You have to make a choice."

00:00:29.245 --> 00:00:31.934
I walked very comfortably
to this missionary school,

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:33.934
that was run by an American missionary.

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:36.934
The first thing the American missionary
gave me was a candy.

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:38.934
I had never in my life ever tasted candy.

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:41.578
So I said to myself,
with all these hundred other boys,

00:00:41.602 --> 00:00:42.963
this is where I belong.

00:00:42.988 --> 00:00:44.789
(Laughter) I stayed.

00:00:44.814 --> 00:00:46.934
When everybody else was dropping out.

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:48.678
My family moved; we're nomads.

00:00:48.703 --> 00:00:50.655
It was a boarding school, I was seven --

00:00:50.680 --> 00:00:53.368
Every time it closed
you had to travel to find them.

00:00:53.393 --> 00:00:54.934
40-50 miles, it doesn't matter.

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:56.958
You slept in the bush, but you kept going.

00:00:57.477 --> 00:00:59.934
And I stayed. I don't know why, but I did.

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:03.934
All of a sudden I passed
the national examination,

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:06.934
found myself in a very beautiful
high school in Kenya.

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:08.710
And I finished high school.

00:01:08.866 --> 00:01:10.683
And just walking, I found a man

00:01:10.708 --> 00:01:13.307
who gave me a full scholarship
to the United States.

00:01:13.575 --> 00:01:15.592
My mother still lived in a cow-dung hut,

00:01:15.617 --> 00:01:17.639
none of my brothers were going to school,

00:01:17.664 --> 00:01:19.934
and this man told me, "Here, go."

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:20.993
I got a scholarship

00:01:21.017 --> 00:01:23.656
to St. Lawrence University,
Upstate New York;

00:01:23.681 --> 00:01:24.720
finished that.

00:01:25.283 --> 00:01:28.883
And after that I went
to Harvard Graduate School;

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:30.146
finished that.

00:01:30.632 --> 00:01:32.354
Then I worked in DC a little bit:

00:01:32.379 --> 00:01:35.440
I wrote a book for National Geographic
and taught U.S. history.

00:01:35.465 --> 00:01:37.934
And every time, I kept going back home,

00:01:38.115 --> 00:01:39.583
listening to their problems --

00:01:39.608 --> 00:01:42.153
sick people, people
with no water, all this stuff --

00:01:42.178 --> 00:01:43.762
every time I go back to America,

00:01:44.122 --> 00:01:45.573
I kept thinking about them.

00:01:45.598 --> 00:01:48.636
Then one day, an elder gave me
a story that went like this:

00:01:49.323 --> 00:01:53.221
long time ago, there was a big war
between tribes.

00:01:53.482 --> 00:01:56.933
This specific tribe was really afraid
of this other Luhya tribe.

00:01:56.958 --> 00:02:00.040
Every time, they sent scouts
to make sure no one attacked them.

00:02:00.522 --> 00:02:03.485
So one day, the scouts came running
and told the villagers,

00:02:03.510 --> 00:02:06.653
"The enemies are coming.
Only half an hour away, they'll be here."

00:02:06.711 --> 00:02:10.191
So people scrambled, took their things
and ready to go, move out.

00:02:10.537 --> 00:02:12.263
But there were two men:

00:02:12.288 --> 00:02:14.756
one man was blind, one man had no legs

00:02:14.780 --> 00:02:16.084
-- he was born like that.

00:02:16.109 --> 00:02:20.006
The leader of the chiefs said, "No, sorry.
We can't take you. You'll slow us down.

00:02:20.030 --> 00:02:23.520
We have to flee our women
and children, we have to run."

00:02:24.276 --> 00:02:26.666
And they were left behind, waiting to die.

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:29.933
But these two people worked something out.

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:33.101
The blind man said, "Look,
I'm a very strong man but I can't see."

00:02:33.125 --> 00:02:36.411
The man with no legs says,
"I can see as far as the end of the world,

00:02:36.435 --> 00:02:40.934
but I can't save myself
from a cat, or whatever animals."

00:02:41.553 --> 00:02:44.934
The blind man went down
on his knees like this,

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:48.006
and told the man with no legs
to go over his back, and stood up.

00:02:48.338 --> 00:02:50.934
The man on top can see,
the blind man can walk.

00:02:51.749 --> 00:02:54.605
These guys took off, followed
the footsteps of the villagers

00:02:54.630 --> 00:02:56.696
until they found and passed them.

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:02.934
So, this was told to me
in a setup of elders.

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:04.653
And it's a really poor area.

00:03:04.677 --> 00:03:06.132
I represent Northern Kenya:

00:03:06.157 --> 00:03:08.711
the most nomadic, remote areas
you can even find.

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:11.934
And that man told me, "So, here you are.

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:15.450
You've got a good education from America,
you have a good life in America;

00:03:15.926 --> 00:03:17.721
what are you going to do for us?

00:03:19.045 --> 00:03:21.934
We want you to be our eyes,
we'll give you the legs.

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.934
We'll walk you, you lead us."

00:03:24.370 --> 00:03:26.979
The opportunity came.
I was always thinking about that:

00:03:27.004 --> 00:03:28.934
"What can I do to help my people?

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:32.304
Every time you go to an area
where for 43 years of independence,

00:03:32.329 --> 00:03:34.870
we still don't have
basic health facilities.

00:03:34.895 --> 00:03:38.021
A man has to be transported
in a wheelbarrow 30 km for a hospital.

00:03:38.046 --> 00:03:39.331
No clean drinking water.

00:03:39.658 --> 00:03:41.933
So I said, "I'm going to dedicate myself.

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:43.204
I'm leaving America.

00:03:43.529 --> 00:03:45.037
I'm going to run for office."

00:03:45.362 --> 00:03:48.585
Last June, I moved from America,

00:03:49.187 --> 00:03:52.023
ran in July election and won.

00:03:52.561 --> 00:03:55.395
And I came for them,

00:03:56.085 --> 00:03:57.211
and that's my goal.

00:03:57.236 --> 00:03:59.668
Right now I have in place,
for the last nine months,

00:04:00.783 --> 00:04:03.538
a plan that in five years,

00:04:03.998 --> 00:04:06.931
every nomad will have
clean drinking water.

00:04:07.402 --> 00:04:10.378
We're building dispensaries
across that constituency.

00:04:11.448 --> 00:04:13.677
I'm asking my friends from America to help

00:04:13.702 --> 00:04:15.934
with bringing nurses
or doctors to help us out.

00:04:16.249 --> 00:04:18.293
I'm trying to improve infrastructure.

00:04:18.894 --> 00:04:21.609
I'm using the knowledge
I received from the United States

00:04:21.634 --> 00:04:22.680
and from my community

00:04:23.286 --> 00:04:24.686
to move them forward.

00:04:24.711 --> 00:04:28.168
I'm trying to develop
homegrown solutions to our issues

00:04:28.193 --> 00:04:30.758
because people from outside
can come and help us,

00:04:30.783 --> 00:04:33.376
but if we don't help ourselves,
there's nothing to do.

00:04:33.886 --> 00:04:34.973
My plan right now

00:04:34.998 --> 00:04:38.932
as I continue with introducing
students to different fields --

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.807
some become doctors, some lawyers --

00:04:40.832 --> 00:04:43.227
we want to produce
a comprehensive group of people,

00:04:43.252 --> 00:04:46.107
students who can come back
and help us see a community grow

00:04:46.132 --> 00:04:49.440
that is in the middle
of a huge economic recession.

00:04:49.775 --> 00:04:52.567
As I continue to be
a Member of Parliament

00:04:52.592 --> 00:04:55.958
and as I continue listening
to all of you talking about botany,

00:04:55.982 --> 00:04:58.958
health, democracy, new inventions,

00:04:59.437 --> 00:05:01.934
I'm hoping that one day
in my own little community --

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.934
which is 26,000 square km,

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.825
maybe five times Rhode Island --

00:05:06.119 --> 00:05:07.119
with no roads,

00:05:07.608 --> 00:05:11.537
we'll be able to become a model
to help others develop.

00:05:11.561 --> 00:05:12.922
Thank you very much.

00:05:12.946 --> 00:05:13.946
(Applause)

title: Model rocketry
transcript: By day, I'm a venture capitalist. On weekends, I love rockets. I love photography, I love rockets. I'm going to talk about a hobby that can scale and show you photos I've taken over the years with kids like these, that hopefully will grow up to love rocketry and eventually become a Richard Branson or Diamandis. My son designed a rocket that became stable, a golf ball rocket. I thought it was quite an interesting experiment in the principles of rocket science. And it flies straight as an arrow.Baking soda and vinegar. Night shots are beautiful, piercing the Big Dipper and the Milky Way. 2-stage rockets with video cameras on them, onboard computers logging their flights, rocket gliders that fly back to Earth. I use RockSim to simulate flights before they go to see if they'll break supersonic, then fly them with onboard computers to verify performance.To launch the big stuff, you go to the middle of nowhere: Black Rock Desert, where dangerous things happen. The boys and the rockets get bigger. They use motors used on cruise-missile boosters. They rumble the belly and leave even photographers in awe, watching the spectacle. These rockets use experimental motors like nitrous oxide. They use solid propellant most frequently. It's a strange kind of love.RocketMavericks.com with my photos, if you want to learn about this, participate, be a spectator. We had to call it Rocket Mavericks. This one was great, went to 100,000 feet — but didn't quite. Actually, it went 11 feet into solid clay and became a bunker-buster. It had to be dug out.Rockets often spiral out of control if you put too much propellant in them. Here was a drag race. At night you can see what happened in a second; in daytime, we call them land sharks. Sometimes they just explode before your eyes or come down supersonic.(Laughter)To take this shot, I did what I often do, which is go way beyond the pads, where none of the spectators are. And if we can run the video, I'll show you what it took to get this DreamWorks shot.(Video) Voices: Woo-hoo! Yeah. Nice.Steve Jurvetson: They realize the computer failed, they're yelling "Deploy!" (Video) Man: Oh, shit.SJ: This is when they realize everything's gone haywire.(Video) Man: It's going ballistic.SJ: I'll just be quiet.(Video) Woman: No! Come on, come on, come on.SJ: And that's me over there, taking photos the whole way. Things often go wrong. Some people watch this because of a NASCAR-like fascination with things bumping and grinding. Burning the parachute as it fell. That was last weekend. This guy went up, went supersonic, ripped the fin can off. The art sale in the sky. A burning metal hunk coming back. These things dropped down from above all through the weekend of rocket launch after rocket launch. It's a cadence you can't quite imagine. I try to capture the mishaps; it's a challenge in photography when these things take place in a fraction of a second.Why do it? For things like this: Gene from Alabama drives out there with this rocket he's built with X-ray sensors, video cameras, festooned with electronics. He succeeds getting to 100,000 feet, leaving the atmosphere, seeing a thin blue line of space.It is this breathtaking image — success, of course — that motivates us and motivates kids to follow and understand rocket science, understand the importance of physics and math and, in many ways, to have that awe at exploration of the frontiers of the unknown.Thank you.(Applause)
