And when you touch it with your finger, you can actually, then, introduce all the forces on the face of that screen, and that actually has a certain amount of value. Let me see if I can load another disc and show you, quickly, an example. Now, imagine a screen, which is not only touch-sensitive now, it's pressure-sensitive. And it's pressure-sensitive to the forces both in the plane of the screen — X, Y, and Z at least in one direction; we couldn't figure out how to come in the other direction. But let me get rid of the slide, and let's see if this comes on. OK. So there is the pressure-sensitive display in operation. The person's just, if you will, pushing on the screen to make a curve. But this is the interesting part.I want to stop it for a second because the movie is very badly made. And the particular display was built about six years ago, and when we moved from one room to another room, a rather large person sat on it and it got destroyed. So all we have is this record. (Laughter) But imagine that screen having lots of objects on it and the person has touched an object — one of N — like he did there, and then pushed on it. Now, imagine a program where some of those objects are physically heavy and some are light: one is an anvil on a fuzzy rug and the other one is a ping-pong ball on a sheet of glass. And when you touch it, you have to really push very hard to move that anvil across the screen, and yet you touch the ping-pong ball very lightly and it just scoots across the screen. And what you can do — oops, I didn't mean to do that — what you can do is actually feed back to the user the feeling of the physical properties. So again, they don't have to be weight; they could be a general trying to move troops, and he's got to move an aircraft carrier versus a little boat. In fact, they funded it for that very reason.(Laughter)The whole notion, then, is one that at the interface there are physical properties in that transducer — in this case it's pressure and touches — that allow you to present things to the user that you could never present before. So it's not simply looking at the quality or, if you will, the luxury of that interface, but it's actually looking at the idea of presenting things that previously couldn't be presented before. I want to move on to another example, which is one of a different sort, where we're trying to use computer and video disc technology now to come up with a new kind of book. Here, the idea is that you're going to take this book, if you will, and it's going to come alive. You're going to sort of breathe life into it. We are so used to doing monologues. Filmmakers, for example, are the experts in monologue making: you make a film and it has a well-formed beginning, middle and end, and in some sense the art of it is that. And you then say, "There's an opportunity for making conversational movies." Well, what does that mean? And it sort of nibbles at the core of the whole profession and all the assumptions of that medium. So, book writing is the same thing.What I'll show you very quickly is a new kind of book where it is mixed now with ... all sorts of things live in there, but you have to keep a few things in mind. One is that this book knows about itself. Each frame of the movie has information about itself. So it knows, or at least there is computer-readable information in the medium itself. It's just not a static movie frame. That's one thing. The other is that you have to realize that it is a random access medium, and you can, in fact, branch and expand and elaborate and shrink. And here — again, my favorite example — is the cookbook, the "Larousse Gastronomique." And I think I use the example all too often, but it's a great one because there is a classic ending in that little encyclopedia-style cookbook that tells you how to do something like penguin, and you get to the end of the recipe and it says, "Cook until done." Now, that would be, if you will, the top green track, which doesn't mean too much. But you might have to elaborate for me or for somebody who isn't an expert, and say, "Cook at 380 degrees for 45 minutes." And then for a real beginner, you would go down even further and elaborate more — say, "Open the oven, preheat, wait for the light to go out, open the door, don't leave it open too long, put the penguin in and shut the door ..." (Laughter) whatever. And that's a much more elaborate one than you dribble back.That's one kind of use of random access. And the other is where you want to explain the same thing in different ways. If you're in a classroom situation and somebody asks a question, the last thing you do is repeat what you just said. You try and think of a different way of saying the same thing, or if you know the particular student and that student's cognitive style, then you might say it in a way that you think would have a good impedance match with that student. There are all sorts of techniques you will use — and again, this is a different kind of branching. So, what I will show you is ... it's a rather boring book, but I'm afraid sometimes you have to do boring books because your sponsors aren't necessarily interested in fiction and entertainment. And this is a book on how to repair a transmission. Now, I don't even know what vintage the transmission is, but let me just show you very quickly some of it, and we'll move on.(Video) Narrator: And continue to get descriptions for each of these chapters. Nicholas Negroponte: Now, this is his table of contents. Just a picture of the transmission, and as you rub your finger across the transmission it highlights the various parts.Narrator: When I find a chapter that I want to see, I just touch the text and the system will format pages for me to read. The words or phrases that are lit up in red are glossary words, so I can get a different definition by just touching the word, and the definition appears, superimposed over the illustration.NN: This is about the oil pan, or the oil filter and all that. This is relatively important because it sets the page ...Narrator: This is another example of a page with glossary words highlighted in red. I can get a definition of these words just by touching them, and the definition will appear in the illustration corner. I can get back to the illustration, but in this case it's not a single frame, but it's actually a movie of someone coming into the frame and doing the repair that's described in the text. The two-headed slider is a speed control that allows me to watch the movie at various speeds, in forward or reverse. And the movie is displayed as a full frame movie. I can go back to the beginning ... and play the movie at full speed. Here's another step-by-step procedure, only in this case —NN: Okay, this movie is ... Everybody's heard of sound-sync movies — this is text-sync movies, so as the movie plays, the text gets highlighted. We highlight the text as we go through the movie. Repairman: ... Not too far out. Front poles, preferably. Don't loosen them too far. If you loosen them too far, you'll have a big mess. NN: I suspect that some of you might not even understand that language.(Laughter)OK. I'm at the third and last part of this, which I said I would make an attempt to at least give you some examples that may be more directly related to the world of entertainment. And of course, good education has got to be good entertainment, so my first example will be drawn from a very recent experiment that we've been doing — in this case, in Senegal — where we have tried to use personal computers as a pedagogical medium. But not as teaching machines at all; the whole notion is to use this as an instrument where there is a complete reversal of roles — the child is, if you will, the teacher and the machine is the student — and the art of computer programming is a vehicle that sort of approximates thinking about thinking. But teaching kids programming per se is utterly irrelevant. And there are just a few slides I want to go through,but there's a story I'd like to tell. And that was when, before we did this in any developing countries — we're doing it, in fact, in three developing countries right now: Pakistan, Colombia and Senegal — we did it in some pretty rough areas of New York City. And one child, whose name I've forgotten, was about seven or eight years old, absolutely considered mentally handicapped — couldn't read, didn't even make it in the lowest section of the school's classes — and was pretty much not in school, though physically there. But did hang around the, quote, "computer room," where there were quite a few computers, and learned this particular language called Logo — and learned it with great ease and found it a lot of fun, it was very interesting. And one day, by chance, some visitors from the NIE came by in their double-breasted suits looking at this setup, and none of the children who were normally there, except for this one child, were there.He was, and he said, "Let me show you how this works," and they got an absolutely ingenuous, wonderful description of Logo. And the child was just zipping right through it, showing them all sorts of things until they asked him how to do something which he couldn't explain and so he flipped through the manual, found the explanation and typed the command and got it to do what they asked. They were delighted, and by the time it was time to go see the principal, whom they'd actually come to see — not the computer room — they went upstairs and they said, "This is absolutely remarkable! That child was very articulate and showed us and even dealt with the things he couldn't do automatically with that manual. It was just absolutely fantastic."The principal said, "There's a dreadful mistake, because that child can't read. And you obviously have been hoodwinked or you've talked about somebody else." And they all got up and they all went downstairs and the child was still there. And they did something very intelligent: they asked the child, "Can you read?" And the child said, "No, I can't." And then they said, "But wait a minute. You just looked through that manual and you found ... " and he said, "Oh, but that's not reading." And so they said, "Well, what's reading then?" He says, "Well, reading is this junk they give me in little books to read. It's absolutely irrelevant, (Laughter) and I get nothing for it. But here, with a little bit of effort I get a lot of return."And it really meant something to the child. The child read beautifully, it turned out, and was really very competent. So it actually meant something. And that story has many other anecdotes that are similar, but wow. The key to the future of computers in education is right there, and it is: when does it mean something to a child? There is a myth, and it truly is a myth: we believe — and I'm sure a lot of you believe in this room — that it is harder to read and write than it is to learn how to speak. And it's not, but we think speech — "My God, little children pick it up somehow, and by the age of two they're doing a mediocre job, and by three and four they're speaking reasonably well. And yet you've got to go to school to learn how to read, and you have to sit in a classroom and somebody has to teach you. Hence, it must be harder." Well, it's not harder. What the truth is is that speaking has great value to a child; the child can get a great deal by talking to you.Reading and writing is utterly useless. There is no reason for a child to read and write except blind faith, and that it's going to help you. (Laughter) So what happens is you go to school and people say, "Just believe me, you're going to like it. You're going to like reading," and just read and read. On the other hand, you give a kid — a three-year-old kid — a computer and they type a little command and — Poof! — something happens. And all of a sudden ... You may not call that reading and writing, but a certain bit of typing and reading stuff on the screen has a huge payoff, and it's a lot of fun. And in fact, it's a powerful educational instrument. Well, in Senegal we found that this was the traditional classroom: 120 kids — three per desk — one teacher, a little bit of chalk. This student was one of our first students, and it's the girl on the left leaning with her chalkboard, and she came ... within two days — I want to show you the program she wrote, and remember her hairstyle. And that is the program she made.That's what meant something to her, is doing the hair pattern, and actually did it within two days — an hour each day — and found it was, to her, absolutely the most meaningful piece ... But rooted in that, little did she know how much knowledge she was acquiring about geometry and just math and logic and all the rest. And again, I could talk for three hours about this subject. I will come to my last example and then quit. And my last example — as some of my former colleagues, whom I see in the room, can imagine what it will be. Yes, it is. It's our work — that was a while ago, and it still is my favorite project — of teleconferencing. And the reason it remains a favorite project is that we were asked to do a teleconferencing system where you had the following situation: you had five people at five different sites — they were known people — and you had to have these people in teleconference, such that each one was utterly convinced that the other four were physically present. Now, that is sufficiently zany that we would, obviously, jump to the bait, and we did. And the fact that we knew the people — we had to take a page out of the history of Walt Disney — we actually went so far as to build CRTs in the shapes of the people's faces. So if I wanted to call my friend Peter Sprague on the phone, my secretary would get his head out and bring it and set it on the desk,(Laughter)and that would be the TV used for the occasion. And it's uncanny: there's no way I can explain to you the amount of eye contact you get with that physical face projected on a 3D CRT of that sort. The next thing that we had to do is to persuade them that there needed to be spatial correspondence, which is straightforward, but again, it's something that didn't fall naturally out of a telecommunications or computing style of thinking; it was a very, if you will, architectural or spatial concept. And that was to recognize that when you sit around the table, the actual location of the people becomes rather important. And when somebody gets up, in fact, to go answer a phone or use a bathroom or something, the empty seat becomes, if you will, that person. And you point frequently to the empty seat and you say, "He or she wouldn't agree," and the empty chair is that person and the spatiality is crucial. So we said, "Well, these will be on round tables and the order around the table had to be the same, so that at my site, I would be, if you will, real and then at each other's site you'd have these plastic heads. And the plastic heads, sometimes you want to project them. And there are a number of schemes, which I don't want to dwell on,but this is the one that we finally used where we projected onto rear screen material that was molded in the face — literally in the face of the person. And I'll show you one more slide, where this is actually made from something called a solid photograph and is the screen. Now, we track, on the person's head, the head motions — so we transmit with a video the head positions — and so this head moves in about two axes. So if I, all of a sudden, turn to the person to my left and start talking to that person, then at the person to my right's site, he'll see these two plastic heads talking to each other. And then if that person interrupts, then those two heads may turn. And it really is reconstructing, quite accurately, teleconferencing.
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:15.958
In this rather long sort of marathon presentation,

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:17.958
I've tried to break it up into three parts:

00:00:17.958 --> 00:00:22.958
the first being a whole lot of examples on how it can be

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:26.958
a little bit more pleasurable to deal with a computer

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:29.958
and really address the qualities of the human interface.

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:32.958
And these will be some simple design qualities

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:35.958
and they will also be some qualities of, if you will,

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:37.958
the intelligence of interaction.

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:41.958
Then the second part will really just be examples of new technologies --

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:45.958
new media falling very much into that mold.

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:48.958
Again, I will go through them as fast as possible.

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:51.958
And then the last one will be some examples

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:55.958
I've been able to collect, which I think

00:00:55.958 --> 00:01:01.958
illustrate this at least as best I can, in the world of entertainment.

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:07.958
People have this belief -- and I share most of it --

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:11.958
that we will be using the TV screens or their equivalents

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:14.958
for electronic books of the future. But then you think,

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:19.958
"My God! What a terrible image you get when you look at still pictures on TV."

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:21.958
Well, it doesn't have to be terrible.

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:25.958
And that is a slide taken from a TV set

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:29.958
and it was pre-processed to be very sympathetic to the TV medium,

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:32.958
and it absolutely looks beautiful.

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:38.958
Well, what's happened? How did people get into this mess?

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:40.958
Where you are now, all of a sudden,

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:42.958
sitting in front of personal computers

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:46.958
and video text -- teletext systems,

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:49.958
and somewhat horrified by what you see on the screen?

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:52.958
Well, you have to remember that TV was designed

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:55.958
to be looked at eight times the distance of the diagonal.

00:01:55.958 --> 00:02:00.958
So you get a 13-inch, 19-inch, whatever, TV,

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:02.958
and then you should multiply that by eight

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:05.958
and that's the distance you should sit away from the TV set.

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:10.958
Now we've put people 18 inches in front of a TV,

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:15.958
and all the artifacts that none of the original designers expected to be seen,

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:17.958
all of a sudden, are staring you in the face:

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:20.958
the shadow mask, the scan lines, all of that.

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:22.958
And they can be treated very easily;

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:25.958
there are actually ways of getting rid of them,

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:31.958
there are actually ways of just making absolutely beautiful pictures.

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:34.958
I'm talking here a little bit about display technologies.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:37.958
Let me talk about how you might input information.

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:41.958
And my favorite example is always fingers.

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:43.958
I'm very interested in touch-sensitive displays.

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:47.958
High-tech, high-touch. Isn't that what some of you said?

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:54.958
It's certainly a very important medium for input,

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:57.958
and a lot of people think that fingers are a very low-resolution

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:01.958
sort of stylus for inputting to a display.

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:05.958
In fact, they're not: it's really a very, very high-resolution input medium --

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:08.958
you have to just do it twice, you have to touch the screen

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:11.958
and then rotate your finger slightly --

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:14.958
and you can move a cursor with great accuracy.

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:16.958
And so when you see on the market these systems

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:21.958
that have just a few light emitting diodes on the side and are very low resolution,

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:25.958
it's nice that they exist because it still is better than nothing.

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.958
But it, in some sense, misses the point:

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:33.958
namely, that fingers are a very, very high-resolution input medium.

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:35.958
Now, what are some of the other advantages?

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:39.958
Well, the one advantage is that you don't have to pick them up,

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:43.958
and people don't realize how important that is --

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:46.958
not having to pick up your fingers to use them. (Laughter)

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:53.958
When you think for a second of the mouse on Macintosh --

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:57.958
and I will not criticize the mouse too much --

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:01.958
when you're typing -- what you have -- you want to now put something --

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:03.958
first of all, you've got to find the mouse.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:08.958
You have to probably stop. Maybe not come to a grinding halt,

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:11.958
but you've got to sort of find that mouse. Then you find the mouse,

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:13.958
and you're going to have to wiggle it a little bit

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:15.958
to see where the cursor is on the screen.

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
And then when you finally see where it is,

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:19.958
then you've got to move it to get the cursor over there,

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:22.958
and then -- "Bang" -- you've got to hit a button or do whatever.

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:25.958
That's four separate steps versus typing and then touching

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:30.958
and typing and just doing it all in one motion --

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:34.958
or one-and-a-half, depending on how you want to count.

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:36.958
Again, what I'm trying to do is just illustrate

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:40.958
the kinds of problems that I think face the designers

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
of new computer systems and entertainment systems

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.958
and educational systems

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:49.958
from the perspective of the quality of that interface.

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:54.958
And another advantage, of course, of using fingers is you have 10 of them.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:57.958
And we have never known how to do this technically,

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
so this slide is a fake slide.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:02.958
We never succeeded in using ten fingers,

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:05.958
but there are certain things you can do, obviously,

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:10.958
with more than one-finger input, which is rather fascinating.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.958
What we did stumble across was something ...

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:16.958
Again, which is typical of the computer field,

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:21.958
is when you have a bug that you can't get rid of you turn it into a feature.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:23.958
And maybe ... (Laughter)

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:27.958
maybe a mouse is a new kind of bug.

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:31.958
But the bug in our case was in touch-sensitive displays:

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:35.958
we wanted to be able to draw -- you know, rub your finger

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:38.958
across the screen to input continuous points --

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:40.958
and there was just too much friction

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
created between your finger and the glass --

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:46.958
if glass was the substrate, which it usually is.

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:49.958
So we found that that actually was a feature

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:52.958
in the sense you could build a pressure-sensitive display.

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
And when you touch it with your finger,

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:59.958
you can actually, then, introduce all the forces on the face of that screen,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:03.958
and that actually has a certain amount of value.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
Let me see if I can load another disc

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:14.958
and show you, quickly, an example.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:17.958
Now, imagine a screen, which is not only touch-sensitive now,

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
it's pressure-sensitive.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:23.958
And it's pressure-sensitive to the forces both in the plane of the screen --

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
X, Y, and Z at least in one direction;

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:29.958
we couldn't figure out how to come in the other direction.

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:33.958
But let me get rid of the slide,

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:40.958
and let's see if this comes on.

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:44.958
OK. So there is the pressure-sensitive display in operation.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:49.958
The person's just, if you will, pushing on the screen to make a curve.

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:51.958
But this is the interesting part.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:55.958
I want to stop it for a second

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:59.958
because the movie is very badly made.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:02.958
And the particular display was built about six years ago,

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
and when we moved from one room to another room,

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:08.958
a rather large person sat on it and it got destroyed.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:11.958
So all we have is this record. (Laughter)

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:19.958
But imagine that screen having lots of objects on it

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:22.958
and the person has touched an object --

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:27.958
one of N -- like he did there, and then pushed on it.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
Now, imagine a program

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:33.958
where some of those objects are physically heavy and some are light:

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:37.958
one is an anvil on a fuzzy rug

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:41.958
and the other one is a ping-pong ball on a sheet of glass.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:45.958
And when you touch it, you have to really push very hard

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
to move that anvil across the screen,

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
and yet you touch the ping-pong ball very lightly

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
and it just scoots across the screen.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:57.958
And what you can do -- oops, I didn't mean to do that --

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:01.958
what you can do is actually feed back to the user

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
the feeling of the physical properties.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:07.958
So again, they don't have to be weight;

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:10.958
they could be a general trying to move troops,

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:14.958
and he's got to move an aircraft carrier versus a little boat.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:17.958
In fact, they funded it for that very reason.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:21.958
(Laughter)

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:27.958
The whole notion, then, is one that at the interface

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:31.958
there are physical properties in that transducer --

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
in this case it's pressure and touches --

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:37.958
that allow you to present things to the user that you could never present before.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:42.958
So it's not simply looking at the quality or, if you will, the luxury of that interface,

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
but it's actually looking at the idea

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:47.958
of presenting things that previously couldn't be presented before.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:51.958
I want to move on to another example,

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:57.958
which is one of a different sort, where we're trying to use computer

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:02.958
and video disc technology now to come up with a new kind of book.

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:07.958
Here, the idea is that you're going to take this book,

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
if you will, and it's going to come alive.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:12.958
You're going to sort of breathe life into it.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:16.958
We are so used to doing monologues.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:20.958
Filmmakers, for example, are the experts in monologue making:

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
you make a film and it has a well-formed beginning, middle and end,

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:26.958
and in some sense the art of it is that.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:30.958
And you then say, "There's an opportunity

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:34.958
for making conversational movies." Well, what does that mean?

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:40.958
And it sort of nibbles at the core of the whole profession

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
and all the assumptions of that medium.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:45.958
So, book writing is the same thing.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
What I'll show you very quickly is a new kind of book

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:52.958
where it is mixed now with ... all sorts of things live in there,

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:55.958
but you have to keep a few things in mind.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:10:00.958
One is that this book knows about itself.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:06.958
Each frame of the movie has information about itself.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:11.958
So it knows, or at least there is computer-readable information

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:15.958
in the medium itself. It's just not a static movie frame.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
That's one thing. The other is that you have to realize

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:20.958
that it is a random access medium,

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:23.958
and you can, in fact, branch and expand and elaborate and shrink.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:27.958
And here -- again, my favorite example -- is the cookbook,

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
the "Larousse Gastronomique."

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:33.958
And I think I use the example all too often,

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:38.958
but it's a great one because there is a classic ending in that little

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:45.958
encyclopedia-style cookbook that tells you how to do something like penguin,

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:49.958
and you get to the end of the recipe and it says, "Cook until done."

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:54.958
Now, that would be, if you will, the top green track,

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:58.958
which doesn't mean too much. But you might have to elaborate for me

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
or for somebody who isn't an expert, and say,

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
"Cook at 380 degrees for 45 minutes."

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:05.958
And then for a real beginner, you would go down even further

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:09.958
and elaborate more -- say, "Open the oven, preheat, wait for the light to go out,

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:12.958
open the door, don't leave it open too long,

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
put the penguin in and shut the door ..." (Laughter) whatever.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
And that's a much more elaborate one than you dribble back.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:23.958
That's one kind of use of random access.

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:31.958
And the other is where you want to explain the same thing in different ways.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:35.958
If you're in a classroom situation and somebody asks a question,

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
the last thing you do is repeat what you just said.

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:42.958
You try and think of a different way of saying the same thing,

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:47.958
or if you know the particular student and that student's cognitive style,

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
then you might say it in a way that you think

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:52.958
would have a good impedance match with that student.

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:54.958
There are all sorts of techniques you will use --

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:58.958
and again, this is a different kind of branching.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:04.958
So, what I will show you is ... it's a rather boring book,

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:07.958
but I'm afraid sometimes you have to do boring books

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:12.958
because your sponsors aren't necessarily interested in fiction

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:18.958
and entertainment. And this is a book on how to repair a transmission.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:21.958
Now, I don't even know what vintage the transmission is,

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:26.958
but let me just show you very quickly some of it, and we'll move on.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:35.958
(Video) Narrator: And continue to get descriptions for each of these chapters.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
Nicholas Negroponte: Now, this is his table of contents.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:41.958
Just a picture of the transmission, and as you rub your finger across the transmission

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
it highlights the various parts.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
Narrator: When I find a chapter that I want to see,

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:58.958
I just touch the text and the system will format pages for me to read.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:04.958
The words or phrases that are lit up in red are glossary words,

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.958
so I can get a different definition by just touching the word,

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:21.958
and the definition appears, superimposed over the illustration.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:43.958
NN: This is about the oil pan, or the oil filter and all that.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:47.958
This is relatively important because it sets the page ...

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:52.958
Narrator: This is another example of a page with glossary words

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:56.958
highlighted in red.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:59.958
I can get a definition of these words just by touching them,

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:07.958
and the definition will appear in the illustration corner.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:12.958
I can get back to the illustration, but in this case it's not a single frame,

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:15.958
but it's actually a movie of someone coming into the frame and doing the repair

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:18.958
that's described in the text.

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:22.958
The two-headed slider is a speed control that allows me to watch the movie

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.958
at various speeds, in forward or reverse.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:30.958
And the movie is displayed as a full frame movie.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:48.958
I can go back to the beginning ... and play the movie at full speed.

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:50.958
Here's another step-by-step procedure, only in this case --

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:54.958
NN: Okay, this movie is ... Everybody's heard of sound-sync movies --

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:59.958
this is text-sync movies, so as the movie plays, the text gets highlighted.

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:03.958
We highlight the text as we go through the movie.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:07.958
Repairman: ... Not too far out. Front poles, preferably.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:12.958
Don't loosen them too far. If you loosen them too far, you'll have a big mess.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:17.958
NN: I suspect that some of you might not even understand that language.

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:22.958
(Laughter)

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:27.958
OK. I'm at the third and last part of this,

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:31.958
which I said I would make an attempt to at least give you some examples

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:35.958
that may be more directly related to the world of entertainment.

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:40.958
And of course, good education has got to be good entertainment,

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:47.958
so my first example will be drawn from a very recent experiment

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:50.958
that we've been doing -- in this case, in Senegal --

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:55.958
where we have tried to use personal computers

00:15:55.958 --> 00:16:00.958
as a pedagogical medium. But not as teaching machines at all;

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:04.958
the whole notion is to use this as an instrument

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:07.958
where there is a complete reversal of roles --

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:11.958
the child is, if you will, the teacher and the machine is the student --

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:13.958
and the art of computer programming is a vehicle that sort of

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:16.958
approximates thinking about thinking.

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:21.958
But teaching kids programming per se is utterly irrelevant.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:24.958
And there are just a few slides I want to go through,

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:30.958
but there's a story I'd like to tell. And that was when,

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:32.958
before we did this in any developing countries --

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:34.958
we're doing it, in fact, in three developing countries right now:

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:36.958
Pakistan, Colombia and Senegal --

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:41.958
we did it in some pretty rough areas of New York City.

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:46.958
And one child, whose name I've forgotten, was about seven or eight years old,

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:51.958
absolutely considered mentally handicapped --

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:59.958
couldn't read, didn't even make it in the lowest section of the school's classes --

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:02.958
and was pretty much not in school, though physically there.

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:05.958
But did hang around the, quote, "computer room,"

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:07.958
where there were quite a few computers,

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:11.958
and learned this particular language called Logo --

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:14.958
and learned it with great ease and found it a lot of fun,

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:19.958
it was very interesting. And one day, by chance,

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:25.958
some visitors from the NIE came by in their double-breasted suits

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:30.958
looking at this setup, and none of the children who were normally there,

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:34.958
except for this one child, were there.

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:37.958
He was, and he said, "Let me show you how this works,"

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:42.958
and they got an absolutely ingenuous, wonderful description of Logo.

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:46.958
And the child was just zipping right through it, showing them all sorts of things

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:50.958
until they asked him how to do something which he couldn't explain

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:53.958
and so he flipped through the manual, found the explanation

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:55.958
and typed the command and got it to do what they asked.

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:59.958
They were delighted, and by the time it was time to go see the principal,

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:02.958
whom they'd actually come to see -- not the computer room --

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:03.958
they went upstairs and they said,

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:05.958
"This is absolutely remarkable!

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:09.958
That child was very articulate and showed us

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:13.958
and even dealt with the things he couldn't do automatically

00:18:13.958 --> 00:18:17.958
with that manual. It was just absolutely fantastic."

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:20.958
The principal said, "There's a dreadful mistake,

00:18:20.958 --> 00:18:22.958
because that child can't read.

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:24.958
And you obviously have been hoodwinked

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:27.958
or you've talked about somebody else."

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:29.958
And they all got up and they all went downstairs

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:33.958
and the child was still there. And they did something very intelligent:

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:37.958
they asked the child, "Can you read?"

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:40.958
And the child said, "No, I can't."

00:18:40.958 --> 00:18:42.958
And then they said, "But wait a minute. You

00:18:42.958 --> 00:18:45.958
just looked through that manual and you found ... "

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:48.958
and he said, "Oh, but that's not reading."

00:18:48.958 --> 00:18:50.958
And so they said, "Well, what's reading then?"

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:54.958
He says, "Well, reading is this junk they give me in little books to read.

00:18:54.958 --> 00:19:01.958
It's absolutely irrelevant, (Laughter) and I get nothing for it.

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:05.958
But here, with a little bit of effort I get a lot of return."

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:07.958
And it really meant something to the child.

00:19:07.958 --> 00:19:09.958
The child read beautifully, it turned out,

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:13.958
and was really very competent. So it actually meant something.

00:19:13.958 --> 00:19:18.958
And that story has many other anecdotes that are similar,

00:19:18.958 --> 00:19:25.958
but wow. The key to the future of computers in education is right there,

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:28.958
and it is: when does it mean something to a child?

00:19:28.958 --> 00:19:31.958
There is a myth, and it truly is a myth:

00:19:31.958 --> 00:19:34.958
we believe -- and I'm sure a lot of you believe in this room --

00:19:34.958 --> 00:19:39.958
that it is harder to read and write than it is to learn how to speak.

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:45.958
And it's not, but we think speech -- "My God, little children pick it up somehow,

00:19:45.958 --> 00:19:47.958
and by the age of two they're doing a mediocre job,

00:19:47.958 --> 00:19:50.958
and by three and four they're speaking reasonably well.

00:19:50.958 --> 00:19:52.958
And yet you've got to go to school to learn how to read,

00:19:52.958 --> 00:19:55.958
and you have to sit in a classroom and somebody has to teach you.

00:19:55.958 --> 00:19:58.958
Hence, it must be harder." Well, it's not harder.

00:19:58.958 --> 00:20:05.958
What the truth is is that speaking has great value to a child;

00:20:05.958 --> 00:20:08.958
the child can get a great deal by talking to you.

00:20:08.958 --> 00:20:10.958
Reading and writing is utterly useless.

00:20:10.958 --> 00:20:15.958
There is no reason for a child to read and write except blind faith,

00:20:15.958 --> 00:20:18.958
and that it's going to help you. (Laughter)

00:20:18.958 --> 00:20:21.958
So what happens is you go to school and people say,

00:20:21.958 --> 00:20:24.958
"Just believe me, you're going to like it.

00:20:24.958 --> 00:20:27.958
You're going to like reading," and just read and read.

00:20:27.958 --> 00:20:31.958
On the other hand, you give a kid -- a three-year-old kid -- a computer

00:20:31.958 --> 00:20:34.958
and they type a little command and -- Poof! -- something happens.

00:20:34.958 --> 00:20:37.958
And all of a sudden ... You may not call that reading and writing,

00:20:37.958 --> 00:20:40.958
but a certain bit of typing and reading stuff on the screen

00:20:40.958 --> 00:20:43.958
has a huge payoff, and it's a lot of fun.

00:20:43.958 --> 00:20:47.958
And in fact, it's a powerful educational instrument.

00:20:47.958 --> 00:20:52.958
Well, in Senegal we found that this was the traditional classroom:

00:20:52.958 --> 00:20:57.958
120 kids -- three per desk -- one teacher, a little bit of chalk.

00:20:57.958 --> 00:21:00.958
This student was one of our first students,

00:21:00.958 --> 00:21:04.958
and it's the girl on the left leaning with her chalkboard,

00:21:04.958 --> 00:21:07.958
and she came ... within two days --

00:21:07.958 --> 00:21:09.958
I want to show you the program she wrote,

00:21:09.958 --> 00:21:15.958
and remember her hairstyle. And that is the program she made.

00:21:15.958 --> 00:21:19.958
That's what meant something to her, is doing the hair pattern,

00:21:19.958 --> 00:21:24.958
and actually did it within two days -- an hour each day --

00:21:24.958 --> 00:21:26.958
and found it was, to her,

00:21:26.958 --> 00:21:29.958
absolutely the most meaningful piece ...

00:21:29.958 --> 00:21:33.958
But rooted in that, little did she know how much knowledge

00:21:33.958 --> 00:21:35.958
she was acquiring about geometry

00:21:35.958 --> 00:21:38.958
and just math and logic and all the rest.

00:21:38.958 --> 00:21:41.958
And again, I could talk for three hours about this subject.

00:21:41.958 --> 00:21:49.958
I will come to my last example and then quit.

00:21:49.958 --> 00:21:55.958
And my last example -- as some of my former colleagues,

00:21:55.958 --> 00:21:58.958
whom I see in the room, can imagine what it will be.

00:21:58.958 --> 00:22:01.958
Yes, it is. It's our work -- that was a while ago,

00:22:01.958 --> 00:22:05.958
and it still is my favorite project -- of teleconferencing.

00:22:05.958 --> 00:22:07.958
And the reason it remains a favorite project

00:22:07.958 --> 00:22:14.958
is that we were asked to do a teleconferencing system

00:22:14.958 --> 00:22:16.958
where you had the following situation:

00:22:16.958 --> 00:22:21.958
you had five people at five different sites -- they were known people --

00:22:21.958 --> 00:22:26.958
and you had to have these people in teleconference,

00:22:26.958 --> 00:22:29.958
such that each one was utterly convinced

00:22:29.958 --> 00:22:33.958
that the other four were physically present.

00:22:33.958 --> 00:22:37.958
Now, that is sufficiently

00:22:37.958 --> 00:22:42.958
zany that we would, obviously, jump to the bait, and we did.

00:22:42.958 --> 00:22:45.958
And the fact that we knew the people --

00:22:45.958 --> 00:22:48.958
we had to take a page out of the history of Walt Disney --

00:22:48.958 --> 00:22:51.958
we actually went so far as to build CRTs

00:22:51.958 --> 00:22:54.958
in the shapes of the people's faces.

00:22:54.958 --> 00:22:59.958
So if I wanted to call my friend Peter Sprague on the phone,

00:22:59.958 --> 00:23:02.958
my secretary would get his head out and bring it and set it on the desk,

00:23:02.958 --> 00:23:03.958
(Laughter)

00:23:03.958 --> 00:23:08.958
and that would be the TV used for the occasion.

00:23:08.958 --> 00:23:11.958
And it's uncanny: there's no way I can explain to you

00:23:11.958 --> 00:23:15.958
the amount of eye contact you get with that physical face

00:23:15.958 --> 00:23:19.958
projected on a 3D CRT of that sort.

00:23:19.958 --> 00:23:22.958
The next thing that we had to do is to persuade them

00:23:22.958 --> 00:23:26.958
that there needed to be spatial correspondence, which is straightforward,

00:23:26.958 --> 00:23:28.958
but again, it's something that didn't fall naturally

00:23:28.958 --> 00:23:31.958
out of a telecommunications or computing style of thinking;

00:23:31.958 --> 00:23:35.958
it was a very, if you will, architectural or spatial concept.

00:23:35.958 --> 00:23:38.958
And that was to recognize that when you sit around the table,

00:23:38.958 --> 00:23:43.958
the actual location of the people becomes rather important.

00:23:43.958 --> 00:23:46.958
And when somebody gets up, in fact, to go answer a phone

00:23:46.958 --> 00:23:49.958
or use a bathroom or something, the empty seat becomes,

00:23:49.958 --> 00:23:52.958
if you will, that person. And you point frequently to the empty seat

00:23:52.958 --> 00:23:55.958
and you say, "He or she wouldn't agree,"

00:23:55.958 --> 00:24:01.958
and the empty chair is that person and the spatiality is crucial.

00:24:01.958 --> 00:24:04.958
So we said, "Well, these will be on round tables

00:24:04.958 --> 00:24:07.958
and the order around the table had to be the same,

00:24:07.958 --> 00:24:10.958
so that at my site, I would be, if you will, real

00:24:10.958 --> 00:24:15.958
and then at each other's site you'd have these plastic heads.

00:24:15.958 --> 00:24:19.958
And the plastic heads, sometimes you want to project them.

00:24:19.958 --> 00:24:22.958
And there are a number of schemes, which I don't want to dwell on,

00:24:22.958 --> 00:24:24.958
but this is the one that we finally used

00:24:24.958 --> 00:24:28.958
where we projected onto rear screen material

00:24:28.958 --> 00:24:32.958
that was molded in the face -- literally in the face of the person.

00:24:32.958 --> 00:24:36.958
And I'll show you one more slide, where this is actually made

00:24:36.958 --> 00:24:40.958
from something called a solid photograph and is the screen.

00:24:40.958 --> 00:24:43.958
Now, we track, on the person's head, the head motions --

00:24:43.958 --> 00:24:47.958
so we transmit with a video the head positions --

00:24:47.958 --> 00:24:54.958
and so this head moves in about two axes.

00:24:54.958 --> 00:24:59.958
So if I, all of a sudden, turn to the person to my left

00:24:59.958 --> 00:25:04.958
and start talking to that person, then at the person to my right's site,

00:25:04.958 --> 00:25:07.958
he'll see these two plastic heads talking to each other.

00:25:07.958 --> 00:25:12.958
And then if that person interrupts, then those two heads may turn.

00:25:12.958 --> 00:25:17.958
And it really is reconstructing, quite accurately, teleconferencing.

title: My stroke of insight
transcript: I grew up to study the brain because I have a brother who has been diagnosed with a brain disorder, schizophrenia. And as a sister and later, as a scientist, I wanted to understand, why is it that I can take my dreams, I can connect them to my reality, and I can make my dreams come true? What is it about my brother's brain and his schizophrenia that he cannot connect his dreams to a common and shared reality, so they instead become delusion?So I dedicated my career to research into the severe mental illnesses. And I moved from my home state of Indiana to Boston, where I was working in the lab of Dr. Francine Benes, in the Harvard Department of Psychiatry. And in the lab, we were asking the question, "What are the biological differences between the brains of individuals who would be diagnosed as normal control, as compared with the brains of individuals diagnosed with schizophrenia, schizoaffective or bipolar disorder?"So we were essentially mapping the microcircuitry of the brain: which cells are communicating with which cells, with which chemicals, and then in what quantities of those chemicals? So there was a lot of meaning in my life because I was performing this type of research during the day, but then in the evenings and on the weekends, I traveled as an advocate for NAMI, the National Alliance on Mental Illness.But on the morning of December 10, 1996, I woke up to discover that I had a brain disorder of my own. A blood vessel exploded in the left half of my brain. And in the course of four hours, I watched my brain completely deteriorate in its ability to process all information. On the morning of the hemorrhage, I could not walk, talk, read, write or recall any of my life. I essentially became an infant in a woman's body.If you've ever seen a human brain, it's obvious that the two hemispheres are completely separate from one another. And I have brought for you a real human brain.(Groaning, laughter)So this is a real human brain. This is the front of the brain, the back of brain with the spinal cord hanging down, and this is how it would be positioned inside of my head. And when you look at the brain, it's obvious that the two cerebral cortices are completely separate from one another.For those of you who understand computers, our right hemisphere functions like a parallel processor, while our left hemisphere functions like a serial processor. The two hemispheres do communicate with one another through the corpus callosum, which is made up of some 300 million axonal fibers. But other than that, the two hemispheres are completely separate. Because they process information differently, each of our hemispheres think about different things, they care about different things, and, dare I say, they have very different personalities. Excuse me. Thank you. It's been a joy.Assistant: It has been.(Laughter)Our right human hemisphere is all about this present moment. It's all about "right here, right now." Our right hemisphere, it thinks in pictures and it learns kinesthetically through the movement of our bodies. Information, in the form of energy, streams in simultaneously through all of our sensory systems and then it explodes into this enormous collage of what this present moment looks like, what this present moment smells like and tastes like, what it feels like and what it sounds like. I am an energy-being connected to the energy all around me through the consciousness of my right hemisphere. We are energy-beings connected to one another through the consciousness of our right hemispheres as one human family. And right here, right now, we are brothers and sisters on this planet, here to make the world a better place. And in this moment we are perfect, we are whole and we are beautiful.My left hemisphere, our left hemisphere, is a very different place. Our left hemisphere thinks linearly and methodically. Our left hemisphere is all about the past and it's all about the future. Our left hemisphere is designed to take that enormous collage of the present moment and start picking out details, and more details about those details. It then categorizes and organizes all that information, associates it with everything in the past we've ever learned, and projects into the future all of our possibilities. And our left hemisphere thinks in language. It's that ongoing brain chatter that connects me and my internal world to my external world. It's that little voice that says to me, "Hey, you've got to remember to pick up bananas on your way home. I need them in the morning." It's that calculating intelligence that reminds me when I have to do my laundry. But perhaps most important, it's that little voice that says to me, "I am. I am."And as soon as my left hemisphere says to me "I am," I become separate. I become a single solid individual, separate from the energy flow around me and separate from you. And this was the portion of my brain that I lost on the morning of my stroke.On the morning of the stroke, I woke up to a pounding pain behind my left eye. And it was the kind of caustic pain that you get when you bite into ice cream. And it just gripped me — and then it released me. And then it just gripped me — and then it released me. And it was very unusual for me to ever experience any kind of pain, so I thought, "OK, I'll just start my normal routine."So I got up and I jumped onto my cardio glider, which is a full-body, full-exercise machine. And I'm jamming away on this thing, and I'm realizing that my hands look like primitive claws grasping onto the bar. And I thought, "That's very peculiar." And I looked down at my body and I thought, "Whoa, I'm a weird-looking thing." And it was as though my consciousness had shifted away from my normal perception of reality, where I'm the person on the machine having the experience, to some esoteric space where I'm witnessing myself having this experience.And it was all very peculiar, and my headache was just getting worse. So I get off the machine, and I'm walking across my living room floor, and I realize that everything inside of my body has slowed way down. And every step is very rigid and very deliberate. There's no fluidity to my pace, and there's this constriction in my area of perception, so I'm just focused on internal systems. And I'm standing in my bathroom getting ready to step into the shower, and I could actually hear the dialogue inside of my body. I heard a little voice saying, "OK. You muscles, you've got to contract. You muscles, you relax."And then I lost my balance, and I'm propped up against the wall. And I look down at my arm and I realize that I can no longer define the boundaries of my body. I can't define where I begin and where I end, because the atoms and the molecules of my arm blended with the atoms and molecules of the wall. And all I could detect was this energy — energy.And I'm asking myself, "What is wrong with me? What is going on?" And in that moment, my left hemisphere brain chatter went totally silent. Just like someone took a remote control and pushed the mute button. Total silence. And at first I was shocked to find myself inside of a silent mind. But then I was immediately captivated by the magnificence of the energy around me. And because I could no longer identify the boundaries of my body, I felt enormous and expansive. I felt at one with all the energy that was, and it was beautiful there.Then all of a sudden my left hemisphere comes back online and it says to me, "Hey! We've got a problem! We've got to get some help." And I'm going, "Ahh! I've got a problem!"(Laughter)So it's like, "OK, I've got a problem." But then I immediately drifted right back out into the consciousness — and I affectionately refer to this space as La La Land. But it was beautiful there. Imagine what it would be like to be totally disconnected from your brain chatter that connects you to the external world.So here I am in this space, and my job, and any stress related to my job — it was gone. And I felt lighter in my body. And imagine all of the relationships in the external world and any stressors related to any of those — they were gone. And I felt this sense of peacefulness. And imagine what it would feel like to lose 37 years of emotional baggage! (Laughter) Oh! I felt euphoria — euphoria. It was beautiful.And again, my left hemisphere comes online and it says, "Hey! You've got to pay attention. We've got to get help." And I'm thinking, "I've got to get help. I've got to focus." So I get out of the shower and I mechanically dress and I'm walking around my apartment, and I'm thinking, "I've got to get to work. Can I drive?"And in that moment, my right arm went totally paralyzed by my side. Then I realized, "Oh my gosh! I'm having a stroke!" And the next thing my brain says to me is, Wow! This is so cool!(Laughter)This is so cool! How many brain scientists have the opportunity to study their own brain from the inside out?"(Laughter)And then it crosses my mind, "But I'm a very busy woman!"(Laughter)"I don't have time for a stroke!" So I'm like, "OK, I can't stop the stroke from happening, so I'll do this for a week or two, and then I'll get back to my routine. OK. So I've got to call help. I've got to call work." I couldn't remember the number at work, so I remembered, in my office I had a business card with my number. So I go into my business room, I pull out a three-inch stack of business cards. And I'm looking at the card on top and even though I could see clearly in my mind's eye what my business card looked like, I couldn't tell if this was my card or not, because all I could see were pixels. And the pixels of the words blended with the pixels of the background and the pixels of the symbols, and I just couldn't tell. And then I would wait for what I call a wave of clarity. And in that moment, I would be able to reattach to normal reality and I could tell that's not the card... that's not the card. It took me 45 minutes to get one inch down inside of that stack of cards. In the meantime, for 45 minutes, the hemorrhage is getting bigger in my left hemisphere. I do not understand numbers, I do not understand the telephone, but it's the only plan I have.So I take the phone pad and I put it right here. I take the business card, I put it right here, and I'm matching the shape of the squiggles on the card to the shape of the squiggles on the phone pad. But then I would drift back out into La La Land, and not remember when I came back if I'd already dialed those numbers. So I had to wield my paralyzed arm like a stump and cover the numbers as I went along and pushed them, so that as I would come back to normal reality, I'd be able to tell, "Yes, I've already dialed that number."Eventually, the whole number gets dialed and I'm listening to the phone, and my colleague picks up the phone and he says to me, "Woo woo woo woo." (Laughter)(Laughter)And I think to myself, "Oh my gosh, he sounds like a Golden Retriever!"(Laughter)And so I say to him — clear in my mind, I say to him: "This is Jill! I need help!" And what comes out of my voice is, "Woo woo woo woo woo." I'm thinking, "Oh my gosh, I sound like a Golden Retriever." So I couldn't know — I didn't know that I couldn't speak or understand language until I tried. So he recognizes that I need help and he gets me help.And a little while later, I am riding in an ambulance from one hospital across Boston to [Massachusetts] General Hospital. And I curl up into a little fetal ball. And just like a balloon with the last bit of air, just right out of the balloon, I just felt my energy lift and just I felt my spirit surrender.And in that moment, I knew that I was no longer the choreographer of my life. And either the doctors rescue my body and give me a second chance at life, or this was perhaps my moment of transition.When I woke later that afternoon, I was shocked to discover that I was still alive. When I felt my spirit surrender, I said goodbye to my life. And my mind was now suspended between two very opposite planes of reality. Stimulation coming in through my sensory systems felt like pure pain. Light burned my brain like wildfire, and sounds were so loud and chaotic that I could not pick a voice out from the background noise, and I just wanted to escape. Because I could not identify the position of my body in space, I felt enormous and expansive, like a genie just liberated from her bottle. And my spirit soared free, like a great whale gliding through the sea of silent euphoria. Nirvana. I found Nirvana. And I remember thinking, there's no way I would ever be able to squeeze the enormousness of myself back inside this tiny little body.But then I realized, "But I'm still alive! I'm still alive, and I have found Nirvana. And if I have found Nirvana and I'm still alive, then everyone who is alive can find Nirvana." And I pictured a world filled with beautiful, peaceful, compassionate, loving people who knew that they could come to this space at any time. And that they could purposely choose to step to the right of their left hemispheres — and find this peace. And then I realized what a tremendous gift this experience could be, what a stroke of insight this could be to how we live our lives. And it motivated me to recover.Two and a half weeks after the hemorrhage, the surgeons went in, and they removed a blood clot the size of a golf ball that was pushing on my language centers. Here I am with my mama, who is a true angel in my life. It took me eight years to completely recover.So who are we? We are the life-force power of the universe, with manual dexterity and two cognitive minds. And we have the power to choose, moment by moment, who and how we want to be in the world. Right here, right now, I can step into the consciousness of my right hemisphere, where we are. I am the life-force power of the universe. I am the life-force power of the 50 trillion beautiful molecular geniuses that make up my form, at one with all that is. Or, I can choose to step into the consciousness of my left hemisphere, where I become a single individual, a solid. Separate from the flow, separate from you. I am Dr. Jill Bolte Taylor: intellectual, neuroanatomist. These are the "we" inside of me. Which would you choose? Which do you choose? And when? I believe that the more time we spend choosing to run the deep inner-peace circuitry of our right hemispheres, the more peace we will project into the world, and the more peaceful our planet will be. And I thought that was an idea worth spreading.Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.002
I grew up to study the brain

00:00:14.026 --> 00:00:16.440
because I have a brother
who has been diagnosed

00:00:16.464 --> 00:00:19.410
with a brain disorder, schizophrenia.

00:00:19.434 --> 00:00:23.375
And as a sister and later, as a scientist,

00:00:23.399 --> 00:00:27.692
I wanted to understand,
why is it that I can take my dreams,

00:00:27.716 --> 00:00:29.951
I can connect them to my reality,

00:00:29.975 --> 00:00:32.641
and I can make my dreams come true?

00:00:32.665 --> 00:00:36.442
What is it about my brother's brain
and his schizophrenia

00:00:36.466 --> 00:00:41.934
that he cannot connect his dreams
to a common and shared reality,

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:43.958
so they instead become delusion?

00:00:44.331 --> 00:00:49.307
So I dedicated my career to research
into the severe mental illnesses.

00:00:49.331 --> 00:00:52.934
And I moved from my home state
of Indiana to Boston,

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:55.485
where I was working in the lab
of Dr. Francine Benes,

00:00:55.509 --> 00:00:58.776
in the Harvard Department of Psychiatry.

00:00:58.800 --> 00:01:01.934
And in the lab,
we were asking the question,

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:04.808
"What are the biological differences

00:01:04.832 --> 00:01:08.934
between the brains of individuals
who would be diagnosed as normal control,

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:11.628
as compared with the brains of individuals

00:01:11.652 --> 00:01:16.568
diagnosed with schizophrenia,
schizoaffective or bipolar disorder?"

00:01:16.592 --> 00:01:21.083
So we were essentially
mapping the microcircuitry of the brain:

00:01:21.107 --> 00:01:24.209
which cells are communicating
with which cells,

00:01:24.233 --> 00:01:25.767
with which chemicals,

00:01:25.791 --> 00:01:29.140
and then in what quantities
of those chemicals?

00:01:29.164 --> 00:01:31.393
So there was a lot of meaning in my life

00:01:31.417 --> 00:01:34.925
because I was performing
this type of research during the day,

00:01:34.949 --> 00:01:38.051
but then in the evenings
and on the weekends,

00:01:38.075 --> 00:01:43.638
I traveled as an advocate for NAMI,
the National Alliance on Mental Illness.

00:01:43.662 --> 00:01:46.934
But on the morning of December 10, 1996,

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:50.934
I woke up to discover that I had
a brain disorder of my own.

00:01:51.315 --> 00:01:55.858
A blood vessel exploded
in the left half of my brain.

00:01:55.882 --> 00:01:58.052
And in the course of four hours,

00:01:58.076 --> 00:02:01.278
I watched my brain completely deteriorate

00:02:01.302 --> 00:02:04.886
in its ability to process all information.

00:02:04.910 --> 00:02:06.665
On the morning of the hemorrhage,

00:02:06.689 --> 00:02:11.934
I could not walk, talk, read,
write or recall any of my life.

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:15.958
I essentially became
an infant in a woman's body.

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:19.934
If you've ever seen a human brain,

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:23.803
it's obvious that the two hemispheres
are completely separate from one another.

00:02:23.827 --> 00:02:26.347
And I have brought for you
a real human brain.

00:02:28.788 --> 00:02:31.903
(Groaning, laughter)

00:02:36.863 --> 00:02:39.403
So this is a real human brain.

00:02:40.276 --> 00:02:41.934
This is the front of the brain,

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:45.403
the back of brain
with the spinal cord hanging down,

00:02:45.427 --> 00:02:48.854
and this is how it would be
positioned inside of my head.

00:02:49.870 --> 00:02:51.414
And when you look at the brain,

00:02:51.438 --> 00:02:54.447
it's obvious that
the two cerebral cortices

00:02:54.471 --> 00:02:57.161
are completely separate from one another.

00:02:57.657 --> 00:02:59.934
For those of you who understand computers,

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:03.883
our right hemisphere functions
like a parallel processor,

00:03:03.907 --> 00:03:07.637
while our left hemisphere functions
like a serial processor.

00:03:08.180 --> 00:03:11.005
The two hemispheres
do communicate with one another

00:03:11.029 --> 00:03:12.584
through the corpus callosum,

00:03:12.608 --> 00:03:16.802
which is made up of some
300 million axonal fibers.

00:03:16.826 --> 00:03:17.934
But other than that,

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:21.218
the two hemispheres
are completely separate.

00:03:21.242 --> 00:03:24.934
Because they process
information differently,

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:27.934
each of our hemispheres
think about different things,

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:31.522
they care about different things,
and, dare I say,

00:03:31.546 --> 00:03:33.961
they have very different personalities.

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:40.720
Excuse me. Thank you. It's been a joy.

00:03:40.744 --> 00:03:42.044
Assistant: It has been.

00:03:42.068 --> 00:03:44.624
(Laughter)

00:03:45.160 --> 00:03:49.989
Our right human hemisphere
is all about this present moment.

00:03:50.013 --> 00:03:53.934
It's all about "right here, right now."

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:56.934
Our right hemisphere,
it thinks in pictures

00:03:56.958 --> 00:04:00.934
and it learns kinesthetically
through the movement of our bodies.

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:05.934
Information, in the form of energy,
streams in simultaneously

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:07.934
through all of our sensory systems

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:10.934
and then it explodes
into this enormous collage

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:14.934
of what this present moment looks like,

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:17.934
what this present moment
smells like and tastes like,

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:22.934
what it feels like
and what it sounds like.

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:27.934
I am an energy-being connected
to the energy all around me

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:31.481
through the consciousness
of my right hemisphere.

00:04:32.196 --> 00:04:35.814
We are energy-beings
connected to one another

00:04:35.838 --> 00:04:38.609
through the consciousness
of our right hemispheres

00:04:38.633 --> 00:04:40.958
as one human family.

00:04:41.445 --> 00:04:45.482
And right here, right now, we are brothers
and sisters on this planet,

00:04:45.506 --> 00:04:48.934
here to make the world a better place.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:54.958
And in this moment we are perfect,
we are whole and we are beautiful.

00:04:55.958 --> 00:05:00.934
My left hemisphere, our left hemisphere,
is a very different place.

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:05.096
Our left hemisphere
thinks linearly and methodically.

00:05:05.811 --> 00:05:10.934
Our left hemisphere is all about the past
and it's all about the future.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.934
Our left hemisphere is designed to take

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:16.550
that enormous collage
of the present moment

00:05:16.574 --> 00:05:21.624
and start picking out details,
and more details about those details.

00:05:21.648 --> 00:05:26.041
It then categorizes and organizes
all that information,

00:05:26.065 --> 00:05:29.576
associates it with everything
in the past we've ever learned,

00:05:29.600 --> 00:05:33.358
and projects into the future
all of our possibilities.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:37.934
And our left hemisphere
thinks in language.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:42.886
It's that ongoing brain chatter
that connects me and my internal world

00:05:42.910 --> 00:05:44.934
to my external world.

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:47.724
It's that little voice that says to me,

00:05:47.748 --> 00:05:51.536
"Hey, you've got to remember
to pick up bananas on your way home.

00:05:51.560 --> 00:05:52.934
I need them in the morning."

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.856
It's that calculating intelligence

00:05:54.880 --> 00:05:58.699
that reminds me
when I have to do my laundry.

00:05:58.723 --> 00:06:03.552
But perhaps most important,
it's that little voice that says to me,

00:06:03.576 --> 00:06:07.407
"I am. I am."

00:06:07.431 --> 00:06:11.426
And as soon as my left hemisphere
says to me "I am,"

00:06:11.450 --> 00:06:13.064
I become separate.

00:06:13.088 --> 00:06:15.343
I become a single solid individual,

00:06:15.367 --> 00:06:17.662
separate from the energy flow around me

00:06:17.686 --> 00:06:19.518
and separate from you.

00:06:19.542 --> 00:06:24.351
And this was the portion of my brain
that I lost on the morning of my stroke.

00:06:24.375 --> 00:06:27.430
On the morning of the stroke,

00:06:27.454 --> 00:06:31.753
I woke up to a pounding
pain behind my left eye.

00:06:31.777 --> 00:06:36.588
And it was the kind of caustic pain
that you get when you bite into ice cream.

00:06:36.612 --> 00:06:38.457
And it just gripped me --

00:06:38.481 --> 00:06:40.692
and then it released me.

00:06:40.716 --> 00:06:42.827
And then it just gripped me --

00:06:42.851 --> 00:06:44.578
and then it released me.

00:06:44.602 --> 00:06:48.934
And it was very unusual for me
to ever experience any kind of pain,

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:51.530
so I thought, "OK, I'll just start
my normal routine."

00:06:51.554 --> 00:06:53.934
So I got up and I jumped
onto my cardio glider,

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:56.934
which is a full-body,
full-exercise machine.

00:06:58.173 --> 00:07:00.383
And I'm jamming away on this thing,

00:07:00.407 --> 00:07:05.176
and I'm realizing that my hands
look like primitive claws

00:07:05.200 --> 00:07:07.668
grasping onto the bar.

00:07:07.692 --> 00:07:09.683
And I thought, "That's very peculiar."

00:07:09.707 --> 00:07:11.163
And I looked down at my body

00:07:11.187 --> 00:07:14.934
and I thought,
"Whoa, I'm a weird-looking thing."

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.624
And it was as though my consciousness
had shifted away

00:07:17.648 --> 00:07:20.121
from my normal perception of reality,

00:07:20.145 --> 00:07:23.122
where I'm the person on the machine
having the experience,

00:07:23.146 --> 00:07:25.044
to some esoteric space

00:07:25.068 --> 00:07:28.157
where I'm witnessing myself
having this experience.

00:07:28.894 --> 00:07:32.178
And it was all very peculiar,
and my headache was just getting worse.

00:07:32.202 --> 00:07:33.501
So I get off the machine,

00:07:33.525 --> 00:07:35.934
and I'm walking
across my living room floor,

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:40.600
and I realize that everything
inside of my body has slowed way down.

00:07:40.624 --> 00:07:44.060
And every step is very rigid
and very deliberate.

00:07:44.084 --> 00:07:46.933
There's no fluidity to my pace,

00:07:46.957 --> 00:07:49.885
and there's this constriction
in my area of perception,

00:07:49.909 --> 00:07:52.934
so I'm just focused on internal systems.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.489
And I'm standing in my bathroom

00:07:54.513 --> 00:07:56.360
getting ready to step into the shower,

00:07:56.384 --> 00:07:59.133
and I could actually hear
the dialogue inside of my body.

00:07:59.157 --> 00:08:02.934
I heard a little voice saying, "OK.
You muscles, you've got to contract.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.346
You muscles, you relax."

00:08:04.370 --> 00:08:08.504
And then I lost my balance,
and I'm propped up against the wall.

00:08:08.528 --> 00:08:10.473
And I look down at my arm

00:08:10.497 --> 00:08:15.930
and I realize that I can no longer define
the boundaries of my body.

00:08:16.243 --> 00:08:19.742
I can't define where I begin
and where I end,

00:08:19.766 --> 00:08:21.934
because the atoms
and the molecules of my arm

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:25.934
blended with the atoms
and molecules of the wall.

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:29.934
And all I could detect
was this energy -- energy.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:32.101
And I'm asking myself,
"What is wrong with me?

00:08:32.125 --> 00:08:33.904
What is going on?"

00:08:33.928 --> 00:08:39.345
And in that moment, my left hemisphere
brain chatter went totally silent.

00:08:39.719 --> 00:08:43.641
Just like someone took a remote control
and pushed the mute button.

00:08:43.665 --> 00:08:44.934
Total silence.

00:08:45.538 --> 00:08:50.291
And at first I was shocked to find myself
inside of a silent mind.

00:08:50.315 --> 00:08:53.554
But then I was immediately captivated

00:08:53.578 --> 00:08:57.338
by the magnificence
of the energy around me.

00:08:57.362 --> 00:09:01.236
And because I could no longer
identify the boundaries of my body,

00:09:01.260 --> 00:09:04.798
I felt enormous and expansive.

00:09:04.822 --> 00:09:08.147
I felt at one with
all the energy that was,

00:09:08.171 --> 00:09:10.337
and it was beautiful there.

00:09:10.361 --> 00:09:13.203
Then all of a sudden
my left hemisphere comes back online

00:09:13.227 --> 00:09:15.434
and it says to me,
"Hey! We've got a problem!

00:09:15.458 --> 00:09:16.958
We've got to get some help."

00:09:16.982 --> 00:09:19.010
And I'm going, "Ahh! I've got a problem!"

00:09:19.034 --> 00:09:20.561
(Laughter)

00:09:20.585 --> 00:09:22.576
So it's like, "OK, I've got a problem."

00:09:22.600 --> 00:09:27.099
But then I immediately drifted
right back out into the consciousness --

00:09:27.123 --> 00:09:30.958
and I affectionately
refer to this space as La La Land.

00:09:31.751 --> 00:09:33.340
But it was beautiful there.

00:09:33.364 --> 00:09:36.362
Imagine what it would be like to be
totally disconnected

00:09:36.386 --> 00:09:39.934
from your brain chatter that connects you
to the external world.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.800
So here I am in this space,

00:09:41.824 --> 00:09:45.934
and my job, and any stress
related to my job -- it was gone.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:49.275
And I felt lighter in my body.

00:09:49.831 --> 00:09:52.934
And imagine all of the relationships
in the external world

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:55.934
and any stressors related
to any of those -- they were gone.

00:09:56.354 --> 00:09:59.132
And I felt this sense of peacefulness.

00:10:00.259 --> 00:10:02.593
And imagine
what it would feel like to lose

00:10:02.617 --> 00:10:06.355
37 years of emotional baggage!

00:10:06.379 --> 00:10:11.934
(Laughter) Oh! I felt euphoria --

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.809
euphoria.

00:10:13.833 --> 00:10:14.934
It was beautiful.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:17.584
And again, my left hemisphere
comes online and it says,

00:10:17.608 --> 00:10:19.234
"Hey! You've got to pay attention.

00:10:19.258 --> 00:10:20.656
We've got to get help."

00:10:20.680 --> 00:10:23.535
And I'm thinking, "I've got to get help.
I've got to focus."

00:10:23.559 --> 00:10:26.027
So I get out of the shower
and I mechanically dress

00:10:26.051 --> 00:10:27.858
and I'm walking around my apartment,

00:10:27.882 --> 00:10:31.934
and I'm thinking,
"I've got to get to work. Can I drive?"

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.227
And in that moment,

00:10:33.251 --> 00:10:35.593
my right arm went totally
paralyzed by my side.

00:10:35.617 --> 00:10:39.934
Then I realized, "Oh my gosh!
I'm having a stroke!"

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.577
And the next thing my brain says to me is,

00:10:42.601 --> 00:10:44.967
Wow! This is so cool!

00:10:44.991 --> 00:10:46.935
(Laughter)

00:10:46.959 --> 00:10:48.522
This is so cool!

00:10:48.546 --> 00:10:51.101
How many brain scientists
have the opportunity

00:10:51.125 --> 00:10:53.934
to study their own brain
from the inside out?"

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.934
(Laughter)

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:59.934
And then it crosses my mind,
"But I'm a very busy woman!"

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.108
(Laughter)

00:11:01.132 --> 00:11:03.299
"I don't have time for a stroke!"

00:11:03.323 --> 00:11:06.025
So I'm like, "OK, I can't stop
the stroke from happening,

00:11:06.049 --> 00:11:09.934
so I'll do this for a week or two,
and then I'll get back to my routine. OK.

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:12.410
So I've got to call help.
I've got to call work."

00:11:12.434 --> 00:11:14.334
I couldn't remember the number at work,

00:11:14.358 --> 00:11:18.127
so I remembered, in my office
I had a business card with my number.

00:11:18.151 --> 00:11:22.460
So I go into my business room, I pull
out a three-inch stack of business cards.

00:11:22.484 --> 00:11:24.141
And I'm looking at the card on top

00:11:24.165 --> 00:11:27.499
and even though I could see clearly
in my mind's eye

00:11:27.523 --> 00:11:29.234
what my business card looked like,

00:11:29.258 --> 00:11:31.846
I couldn't tell if this
was my card or not,

00:11:31.870 --> 00:11:33.736
because all I could see were pixels.

00:11:33.760 --> 00:11:37.840
