And the pixels of the words
blended with the pixels of the background

00:11:37.864 --> 00:11:41.172
and the pixels of the symbols,
and I just couldn't tell.

00:11:41.196 --> 00:11:44.336
And then I would wait
for what I call a wave of clarity.

00:11:44.360 --> 00:11:48.648
And in that moment, I would be able
to reattach to normal reality

00:11:48.672 --> 00:11:52.822
and I could tell that's not the card...
that's not the card.

00:11:52.846 --> 00:11:58.854
It took me 45 minutes to get one inch
down inside of that stack of cards.

00:11:58.878 --> 00:12:00.752
In the meantime, for 45 minutes,

00:12:00.776 --> 00:12:03.434
the hemorrhage is getting bigger
in my left hemisphere.

00:12:03.458 --> 00:12:06.458
I do not understand numbers,
I do not understand the telephone,

00:12:06.482 --> 00:12:08.034
but it's the only plan I have.

00:12:08.058 --> 00:12:10.743
So I take the phone pad
and I put it right here.

00:12:10.767 --> 00:12:13.149
I take the business card,
I put it right here,

00:12:13.173 --> 00:12:16.934
and I'm matching the shape
of the squiggles on the card

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:20.275
to the shape of the squiggles
on the phone pad.

00:12:20.299 --> 00:12:22.934
But then I would drift back out
into La La Land,

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:26.934
and not remember when I came back
if I'd already dialed those numbers.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:30.934
So I had to wield
my paralyzed arm like a stump

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:34.934
and cover the numbers
as I went along and pushed them,

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:37.648
so that as I would come back
to normal reality,

00:12:37.672 --> 00:12:41.680
I'd be able to tell, "Yes,
I've already dialed that number."

00:12:41.704 --> 00:12:46.044
Eventually, the whole number gets dialed
and I'm listening to the phone,

00:12:46.068 --> 00:12:48.705
and my colleague picks up the phone
and he says to me,

00:12:49.655 --> 00:12:51.298
"Woo woo woo woo." (Laughter)

00:12:51.322 --> 00:12:54.757
(Laughter)

00:12:54.781 --> 00:12:56.631
And I think to myself,

00:12:56.655 --> 00:12:59.694
"Oh my gosh, he sounds
like a Golden Retriever!"

00:12:59.718 --> 00:13:01.345
(Laughter)

00:13:01.369 --> 00:13:04.530
And so I say to him --
clear in my mind, I say to him:

00:13:04.554 --> 00:13:06.196
"This is Jill! I need help!"

00:13:06.220 --> 00:13:09.934
And what comes out of my voice is,
"Woo woo woo woo woo."

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:12.768
I'm thinking, "Oh my gosh,
I sound like a Golden Retriever."

00:13:12.792 --> 00:13:14.713
So I couldn't know -- I didn't know

00:13:14.737 --> 00:13:18.363
that I couldn't speak or understand
language until I tried.

00:13:18.387 --> 00:13:21.767
So he recognizes that I need help
and he gets me help.

00:13:22.069 --> 00:13:25.679
And a little while later,
I am riding in an ambulance

00:13:25.703 --> 00:13:29.258
from one hospital across Boston
to [Massachusetts] General Hospital.

00:13:30.115 --> 00:13:32.448
And I curl up into a little fetal ball.

00:13:33.289 --> 00:13:39.837
And just like a balloon
with the last bit of air,

00:13:39.861 --> 00:13:42.011
just right out of the balloon,

00:13:42.035 --> 00:13:47.273
I just felt my energy lift
and just I felt my spirit surrender.

00:13:47.923 --> 00:13:53.934
And in that moment, I knew that I was
no longer the choreographer of my life.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:58.351
And either the doctors rescue my body
and give me a second chance at life,

00:13:58.375 --> 00:14:02.037
or this was perhaps
my moment of transition.

00:14:06.677 --> 00:14:08.884
When I woke later that afternoon,

00:14:08.908 --> 00:14:12.558
I was shocked to discover
that I was still alive.

00:14:14.003 --> 00:14:18.934
When I felt my spirit surrender,
I said goodbye to my life.

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:21.283
And my mind was now suspended

00:14:21.307 --> 00:14:25.505
between two very opposite
planes of reality.

00:14:25.529 --> 00:14:28.816
Stimulation coming in
through my sensory systems

00:14:28.840 --> 00:14:30.553
felt like pure pain.

00:14:31.116 --> 00:14:34.330
Light burned my brain like wildfire,

00:14:34.354 --> 00:14:37.949
and sounds were so loud and chaotic

00:14:37.973 --> 00:14:42.155
that I could not pick a voice out
from the background noise,

00:14:42.179 --> 00:14:44.147
and I just wanted to escape.

00:14:44.776 --> 00:14:49.920
Because I could not identify the position
of my body in space,

00:14:49.944 --> 00:14:53.761
I felt enormous and expansive,

00:14:53.785 --> 00:14:57.356
like a genie just liberated
from her bottle.

00:14:58.610 --> 00:15:01.284
And my spirit soared free,

00:15:01.308 --> 00:15:06.958
like a great whale gliding
through the sea of silent euphoria.

00:15:08.513 --> 00:15:10.197
Nirvana.

00:15:10.221 --> 00:15:12.641
I found Nirvana.

00:15:14.919 --> 00:15:16.339
And I remember thinking,

00:15:16.363 --> 00:15:20.793
there's no way I would ever be able
to squeeze the enormousness of myself

00:15:20.817 --> 00:15:23.331
back inside this tiny little body.

00:15:25.775 --> 00:15:29.283
But then I realized, "But I'm still alive!

00:15:29.307 --> 00:15:32.410
I'm still alive, and I have found Nirvana.

00:15:32.434 --> 00:15:36.140
And if I have found Nirvana
and I'm still alive,

00:15:36.164 --> 00:15:40.116
then everyone who is alive
can find Nirvana."

00:15:42.386 --> 00:15:43.657
And I pictured a world

00:15:43.681 --> 00:15:49.641
filled with beautiful, peaceful,
compassionate, loving people

00:15:49.665 --> 00:15:53.411
who knew that they could come
to this space at any time.

00:15:54.125 --> 00:15:57.608
And that they could purposely choose

00:15:57.632 --> 00:16:00.425
to step to the right
of their left hemispheres --

00:16:02.029 --> 00:16:03.934
and find this peace.

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:05.181
And then I realized

00:16:05.205 --> 00:16:08.762
what a tremendous gift
this experience could be,

00:16:08.786 --> 00:16:14.681
what a stroke of insight this could be
to how we live our lives.

00:16:16.062 --> 00:16:18.585
And it motivated me to recover.

00:16:21.887 --> 00:16:26.037
Two and a half weeks after the hemorrhage,
the surgeons went in,

00:16:26.061 --> 00:16:28.609
and they removed a blood clot
the size of a golf ball

00:16:28.633 --> 00:16:30.624
that was pushing on my language centers.

00:16:30.648 --> 00:16:32.274
Here I am with my mama,

00:16:32.298 --> 00:16:34.203
who is a true angel in my life.

00:16:35.774 --> 00:16:39.377
It took me eight years
to completely recover.

00:16:40.624 --> 00:16:42.661
So who are we?

00:16:42.685 --> 00:16:47.687
We are the life-force power
of the universe,

00:16:47.711 --> 00:16:52.008
with manual dexterity
and two cognitive minds.

00:16:52.584 --> 00:16:55.885
And we have the power
to choose, moment by moment,

00:16:55.909 --> 00:16:58.897
who and how we want to be in the world.

00:16:59.611 --> 00:17:01.166
Right here, right now,

00:17:01.190 --> 00:17:06.416
I can step into the consciousness
of my right hemisphere, where we are.

00:17:06.440 --> 00:17:09.497
I am the life-force power of the universe.

00:17:09.521 --> 00:17:11.061
I am the life-force power

00:17:11.085 --> 00:17:15.919
of the 50 trillion beautiful
molecular geniuses that make up my form,

00:17:15.943 --> 00:17:18.219
at one with all that is.

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:24.302
Or, I can choose to step into
the consciousness of my left hemisphere,

00:17:24.326 --> 00:17:27.607
where I become
a single individual, a solid.

00:17:27.631 --> 00:17:31.190
Separate from the flow, separate from you.

00:17:31.214 --> 00:17:33.324
I am Dr. Jill Bolte Taylor:

00:17:33.348 --> 00:17:36.177
intellectual, neuroanatomist.

00:17:38.067 --> 00:17:41.847
These are the "we" inside of me.

00:17:43.442 --> 00:17:44.942
Which would you choose?

00:17:47.481 --> 00:17:49.167
Which do you choose?

00:17:50.795 --> 00:17:52.095
And when?

00:17:54.735 --> 00:17:56.934
I believe that the more time we spend

00:17:56.958 --> 00:17:59.935
choosing to run the deep
inner-peace circuitry

00:17:59.959 --> 00:18:02.179
of our right hemispheres,

00:18:02.203 --> 00:18:05.509
the more peace we will project
into the world,

00:18:05.533 --> 00:18:08.065
and the more peaceful our planet will be.

00:18:09.156 --> 00:18:12.223
And I thought that was an idea
worth spreading.

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:14.034
Thank you.

00:18:14.058 --> 00:18:17.058
(Applause)

title: My days as a young rebel
transcript: I'm going to go right into the slides. And all I'm going to try and prove to you with these slides is that I do just very straight stuff. And my ideas are — in my head, anyway — they're very logical and relate to what's going on and problem solving for clients. I either convince clients at the end that I solve their problems, or I really do solve their problems, because usually they seem to like it.Let me go right into the slides. Can you turn off the light? Down. I like to be in the dark. I don't want you to see what I'm doing up here.(Laughter)Anyway, I did this house in Santa Monica, and it got a lot of notoriety. In fact, it appeared in a porno comic book, which is the slide on the right.(Laughter)This is in Venice. I just show it because I want you to know I'm concerned about context. On the left-hand side, I had the context of those little houses, and I tried to build a building that fit into that context. When people take pictures of these buildings out of that context they look really weird, and my premise is that they make a lot more sense when they're photographed or seen in that space. And then, once I deal with the context, I then try to make a place that's comfortable and private and fairly serene, as I hope you'll find that slide on the right.And then I did a law school for Loyola in downtown L.A. I was concerned about making a place for the study of law. And we continue to work with this client. The building on the right at the top is now under construction. The garage on the right — the gray structure — will be torn down, finally, and several small classrooms will be placed along this avenue that we've created, this campus. And it all related to the clients and the students from the very first meeting saying they felt denied a place. They wanted a sense of place. And so the whole idea here was to create that kind of space in downtown, in a neighborhood that was difficult to fit into. And it was my theory, or my point of view, that one didn't upstage the neighborhood — one made accommodations. I tried to be inclusive, to include the buildings in the neighborhood, whether they were buildings I liked or not.In the '60s I started working with paper furniture and made a bunch of stuff that was very successful in Bloomingdale's. We even made flooring, walls and everything, out of cardboard. And the success of it threw me for a loop. I couldn't deal with the success of furniture — I wasn't secure enough as an architect — and so I closed it all up and made furniture that nobody would like.(Laughter)So, nobody would like this. And it was in this, preliminary to these pieces of furniture, that Ricky and I worked on furniture by the slice. And after we failed, I just kept failing.(Laughter)The piece on the left — and that ultimately led to the piece on the right — happened when the kid that was working on this took one of those long strings of stuff and folded it up to put it in the wastebasket. And I put a piece of tape around it, as you see there, and realized you could sit on it, and it had a lot of resilience and strength and so on. So, it was an accidental discovery.I got into fish.(Laughter)I mean, the story I tell is that I got mad at postmodernism — at po-mo — and said that fish were 500 million years earlier than man, and if you're going to go back, we might as well go back to the beginning. And so I started making these funny things. And they started to have a life of their own and got bigger — as the one glass at the Walker. And then, I sliced off the head and the tail and everything and tried to translate what I was learning about the form of the fish and the movement. And a lot of my architectural ideas that came from it — accidental, again — it was an intuitive kind of thing, and I just kept going with it, and made this proposal for a building, which was only a proposal.I did this building in Japan. I was taken out to dinner after the contract for this little restaurant was signed. And I love sake and Kobe and all that stuff. And after I got — I was really drunk — I was asked to do some sketches on napkins.(Laughter)And I made some sketches on napkins — little boxes and Morandi-like things that I used to do. And the client said, "Why no fish?" And so I made a drawing with a fish, and I left Japan. Three weeks later, I received a complete set of drawings saying we'd won the competition.(Laughter)Now, it's hard to do. It's hard to translate a fish form, because they're so beautiful — perfect — into a building or object like this. And Oldenburg, who I work with a little once in a while, told me I couldn't do it, and so that made it even more exciting. But he was right — I couldn't do the tail. I started to get the head OK, but the tail I couldn't do. It was pretty hard. The thing on the right is a snake form, a ziggurat. And I put them together, and you walk between them. It was a dialog with the context again. Now, if you saw a picture of this as it was published in Architectural Record — they didn't show the context, so you would think, "God, what a pushy guy this is." But a friend of mine spent four hours wandering around here looking for this restaurant. Couldn't find it. So ...(Laughter)As for craft and technology and all those things that you've all been talking about, I was thrown for a complete loop. This was built in six months. The way we sent drawings to Japan: we used the magic computer in Michigan that does carved models, and we used to make foam models, which that thing scanned. We made the drawings of the fish and the scales. And when I got there, everything was perfect — except the tail. So, I decided to cut off the head and the tail.And I made the object on the left for my show at the Walker. And it's one of the nicest pieces I've ever made, I think. And then Jay Chiat, a friend and client, asked me to do his headquarters building in L.A. For reasons we don't want to talk about, it got delayed. Toxic waste, I guess, is the key clue to that one. And so we built a temporary building — I'm getting good at temporary — and we put a conference room in that's a fish.And, finally, Jay dragged me to my hometown, Toronto, Canada. And there is a story — it's a real story — about my grandmother buying a carp on Thursday, bringing it home, putting it in the bathtub when I was a kid. I played with it in the evening. When I went to sleep, the next day it wasn't there. And the next night, we had gefilte fish.(Laughter)And so I set up this interior for Jay's offices and I made a pedestal for a sculpture. And he didn't buy a sculpture, so I made one. I went around Toronto and found a bathtub like my grandmother's, and I put the fish in. It was a joke.(Laughter)I play with funny people like [Claes] Oldenburg. We've been friends for a long time. And we've started to work on things. A few years ago, we did a performance piece in Venice, Italy, called "Il Corso del Coltello" — the Swiss Army knife. And most of the imagery is —(Laughter)Claes', but those two little boys are my sons, and they were Claes' assistants in the play. He was the Swiss Army knife. He was a souvenir salesman who always wanted to be a painter, and I was Frankie P. Toronto. P for Palladio. Dressed up like the AT&T building by Claes —(Laughter)with a fish hat. The highlight of the performance was at the end. This beautiful object, the Swiss Army knife, which I get credit for participating in. And I can tell you — it's totally an Oldenburg. I had nothing to do with it. The only thing I did was, I made it possible for them to turn those blades so you could sail this thing in the canal, because I love sailing.(Laughter)We made it into a sailing craft.I've been known to mess with things like chain link fencing. I do it because it's a curious thing in the culture, when things are made in such great quantities, absorbed in such great quantities, and there's so much denial about them. People hate it. And I'm fascinated with that, which, like the paper furniture — it's one of those materials. And I'm always drawn to that. And so I did a lot of dirty things with chain link, which nobody will forgive me for. But Claes made homage to it in the Loyola Law School. And that chain link is really expensive. It's in perspective and everything.And then we did a camp together for children with cancer. And you can see, we started making a building together. Of course, the milk can is his. But we were trying to collide our ideas, to put objects next to each other. Like a Morandi — like the little bottles — composing them like a still life. And it seemed to work as a way to put he and I together.Then Jay Chiat asked me to do this building on this funny lot in Venice, and I started with this three-piece thing, and you entered in the middle. And Jay asked me what I was going to do with the piece in the middle. And he pushed that. And one day I had a — oh, well, the other way. I had the binoculars from Claes, and I put them there, and I could never get rid of them after that. Oldenburg made the binoculars incredible when he sent me the first model of the real proposal. It made my building look sick. And it was this interaction between that kind of, up-the-ante stuff that became pretty interesting. It led to the building on the left. And I still think the Time magazine picture will be of the binoculars, you know, leaving out the — what the hell.I use a lot of metal in my work, and I have a hard time connecting with the craft. The whole thing about my house, the whole use of rough carpentry and everything, was the frustration with the crafts available. I said, "If I can't get the craft that I want, I'll use the craft I can get." There were plenty of models for that, in Rauschenberg and Jasper Johns, and many artists who were making beautiful art and sculpture with junk materials. I went into the metal because it was a way of building a building that was a sculpture. And it was all of one material, and the metal could go on the roof as well as the walls. The metalworkers, for the most part, do ducts behind the ceilings and stuff. I was given an opportunity to design an exhibit for the metalworkers' unions of America and Canada in Washington, and I did it on the condition that they become my partners in the future and help me with all future metal buildings, etc. etc. And it's working very well to have these people, these craftsmen, interested in it. I just tell the stories. It's a way of connecting, at least, with some of those people that are so important to the realization of architecture.The metal continued into a building — Herman Miller, in Sacramento. And it's just a complex of factory buildings. And Herman Miller has this philosophy of having a place — a people place. I mean, it's kind of a trite thing to say, but it is real that they wanted to have a central place where the cafeteria would be, where the people would come and where the people working would interact. So it's out in the middle of nowhere, and you approach it. It's copper and galvanize. I used the galvanize and copper in a very light gauge, so it would buckle. I spent a lot of time undoing Richard Meier's aesthetic. Everybody's trying to get the panels perfect, and I always try to get them sloppy and fuzzy. And they end up looking like stone. This is the central area. There's a ramp.And that little dome in there is a building by Stanley Tigerman. Stanley was instrumental in my getting this job. And when I was awarded the contract I, at the very beginning, asked the client if they would let Stanley do a cameo piece with me. Because these were ideas that we were talking about, building things next to each other, making — it's all about [a] metaphor for a city, maybe. And so Stanley did the little dome thing. And we did it over the phone and by fax. He would send me a fax and show me something. He'd made a building with a dome and he had a little tower. I told him, "No, no, that's too ongepotchket. I don't want the tower." So he came back with a simpler building, but he put some funny details on it, and he moved it closer to my building. And so I decided to put him in a depression. I put him in a hole and made a kind of a hole that he sits in. And so then he put two bridges — this all happened on the fax, going back and forth over a couple of weeks' period. And he put these two bridges with pink guardrails on it. And so then I put this big billboard behind it. And I call it, "David and Goliath." And that's my cafeteria.In Boston, we had that old building on the left. It was a very prominent building off the freeway, and we added a floor and cleaned it up and fixed it up and used the kind of — I thought — the language of the neighborhood, which had these cornices, projecting cornices. Mine got a little exuberant, but I used lead copper, which is a beautiful material, and it turns green in 100 years. Instead of, like, copper in 10 or 15. We redid the side of the building and re-proportioned the windows so it sort of fit into the space. And it surprised both Boston and myself that we got it approved, because they have very strict kind of design guideline, and they wouldn't normally think I would fit them. The detailing was very careful with the lead copper and making panels and fitting it tightly into the fabric of the existing building.In Barcelona, on Las Ramblas for some film festival, I did the Hollywood sign going and coming, made a building out of it, and they built it. I flew in one night and took this picture. But they made it a third smaller than my model without telling me.And then more metal and some chain link in Santa Monica — a little shopping center.And this is a laser laboratory at the University of Iowa, in which the fish comes back as an abstraction in the back. It's the support labs, which, by some coincidence, required no windows. And the shape fit perfectly. I just joined the points. In the curved part there's all the mechanical equipment. That solid wall behind it is a pipe chase — a pipe canyon — and so it was an opportunity that I seized, because I didn't have to have any protruding ducts or vents or things in this form. It gave me an opportunity to make a sculpture out of it.This is a small house somewhere. They've been building it so long I don't remember where it is. It's in the West Valley. And we started with the stream and built the house along the stream — dammed it up to make a lake. These are the models. The reality, with the lake — the workmanship is pretty bad. And it reminded me why I play defensively in things like my house. When you have to do something really cheaply, it's hard to get perfect corners and stuff. That big metal thing is a passage, and in it is — you go downstairs into the living room and then down into the bedroom, which is on the right. It's kind of like a whole built town.I was asked to do a hospital for schizophrenic adolescents at Yale. I thought it was fitting for me to be doing that.This is a house next to a Philip Johnson house in Minnesota. The owners had a dilemma — they asked Philip to do it. He was too busy. He didn't recommend me, by the way.(Laughter)We ended up having to make it a sculpture, because the dilemma was, how do you build a building that doesn't look like the language? Is it going to look like this beautiful estate is sub-divided? Etc. etc. You've got the idea. And so we finally ended up making it. These people are art collectors. And we finally made it so it appears very sculptural from the main house and all the windows are on the other side. And the building is very sculptural as you walk around it. It's made of metal and the brown stuff is Fin-Ply — it's that formed lumber from Finland. We used it at Loyola on the chapel, and it didn't work. I keep trying to make it work. In this case we learned how to detail it.In Cleveland, there's Burnham Mall, on the left. It's never been finished. Going out to the lake, you can see all those new buildings we built. And we had the opportunity to build a building on this site. There's a railroad track. This is the city hall over here somewhere, and the courthouse. And the centerline of the mall goes out. Burnham had designed a railroad station that was never built, and so we followed. Sohio is on the axis here, and we followed the axis, and they're two kind of goalposts. And this is our building, which is a corporate headquarters for an insurance company. We collaborated with Oldenburg and put the newspaper on top, folded. The health club is fastened to the garage with a C-clamp, for Cleveland.(Laughter)You drive down. So it's about a 10-story C-clamp. And all this stuff at the bottom is a museum, and an idea for a very fancy automobile entry. This owner has a pet peeve about bad automobile entries. And this would be a hotel. So, the centerline of this thing — we'd preserve it, and it would start to work with the scale of the new buildings by Pelli and Kohn Pederson Fox, etc., that are underway. It's hard to do high-rise. I feel much more comfortable down here.This is a piece of property in Brentwood. And a long time ago, about '82 or something, after my house — I designed a house for myself that would be a village of several pavilions around a courtyard — and the owner of this lot worked for me and built that actual model on the left. And she came back, I guess wealthier or something — something happened — and asked me to design a house for her on this site. And following that basic idea of the village, we changed it as we got into it. I locked the house into the site by cutting the back end — here you see on the photographs of the site — slicing into it and putting all the bathrooms and dressing rooms like a retaining wall, creating a lower level zone for the master bedroom, which I designed like a kind of a barge, looking like a boat. And that's it, built. The dome was a request from the client. She wanted a dome somewhere in the house. She didn't care where. When you sleep in this bedroom, I hope — I mean, I haven't slept in it yet. I've offered to marry her so I could sleep there, but she said I didn't have to do that. But when you're in that room, you feel like you're on a kind of barge on some kind of lake. And it's very private. The landscape is being built around to create a private garden. And then up above there's a garden on this side of the living room, and one on the other side.These aren't focused very well. I don't know how to do it from here. Focus the one on the right. It's up there. Left — it's my right.Anyway, you enter into a garden with a beautiful grove of trees. That's the living room. Servants' quarters. A guest bedroom, which has this dome with marble on it. And then you enter into the living room and then so on. This is the bedroom. You come down from this level along the stairway, and you enter the bedroom here, going into the lake. And the bed is back in this space, with windows looking out onto the lake. These Stonehenge things were designed to give foreground and to create a greater depth in this shallow lot. The material is lead copper, like in the building in Boston. And so it was an intent to make this small piece of land — it's 100 by 250 — into a kind of an estate by separating these areas and making the living room and dining room into this pavilion with a high space in it. And this happened by accident that I got this right on axis with the dining room table. It looks like I got a Baldessari painting for free. But the idea is, the windows are all placed so you see pieces of the house outside. Eventually this will be screened — these trees will come up — and it will be very private. And you feel like you're in your own kind of village.This is for Michael Eisner — Disney. We're doing some work for him.And this is in Anaheim, California, and it's a freeway building. You go under this bridge at about 65 miles an hour, and there's another bridge here. And you're through this room in a split second, and the building will sort of reflect that. On the backside, it's much more humane — entrance, dining hall, etc. And then this thing here — I'm hoping as you drive by you'll hear the picket fence effect of the sound hitting it. Kind of a fun thing to do.I'm doing a building in Switzerland, Basel, which is an office building for a furniture company. And we struggled with the image. These are the early studies, but they have to sell furniture to normal people, so if I did the building and it was too fancy, then people might say, "Well, the furniture looks OK in his thing, but no, it ain't going to look good in my normal building." So we've made a kind of pragmatic slab in the second phase here, and we've taken the conference facilities and made a villa out of them so that the communal space is very sculptural and separate. And you're looking at it from the offices and you create a kind of interaction between these pieces.This is in Paris, along the Seine. Palais des Sports, the Gare de Lyon over here. The Minister of Finance — the guy that moved from the Louvre — goes in here. There's a new library across the river. And back in here, in this already treed park, we're doing a very dense building called the American Center, which has a theater, apartments, dance school, an art museum, restaurants and all kinds of — it's a very dense program — bookstores, etc. In a very tight, small — this is the ground level. And the French have this extraordinary way of screwing things up by taking a beautiful site and cutting the corner off. They call it the plan coupe. And I struggled with that thing — how to get around the corner.These are the models for it. I showed you the other model, the one — this is the way I organized myself so I could make the drawing — so I understood the problem. I was trying to get around this plan coupe — how do you do it? Apartments, etc. And these are the kind of study models we did. And the one on the left is pretty awful. You can see why I was ready to commit suicide when this one was built. But out of it came finally this resolution, where the elevator piece worked frontally to this, parallel to this street, and also parallel to here. And then this kind of twist, with this balcony and the skirt, kind of like a ballerina lifting her skirt to let you into the foyer. The restaurants here — the apartments and the theater, etc. So it would all be built in stone, in French limestone, except for this metal piece. And it faces into a park. And the idea was to make this express the energy of this. On the side facing the street it's much more normal, except I slipped a few mansards down, so that coming on the point, these housing units made a gesture to the corner. And this will be some kind of high-tech billboard. If any of you guys have any ideas for it, please contact me. I don't know what to do.Jay Chiat is a glutton for punishment, and he hired me to do a house for him in the Hamptons. And it's got a fish. And I keep thinking, "This is going to be the last fish." It's like a drug addict. I say, "I'm not going to do it anymore — I don't want to do it anymore — I'm not going to do it." And then I do it.(Laughter)There it is. But it's the living room. And this piece here is — I don't know what it is. I just added it so that we'd have enough money in the budget so we could take something out.(Applause)This is Euro Disney, and I've worked with all of the guys that presented to you earlier. We've had a lot of fun working together. I think I'm from Mars for them, and they are for me, but somehow we all manage to work together, and I think, productively. So far. This is a shopping thing. You come into the Magic Kingdom and the hotel that Tony Baxter's group is doing out here. And then this is a kind of a shopping mall, with a rodeo and restaurants. And another restaurant. What I did — because of the Paris skies being quite dull, I made a light grid that's perpendicular to the train station, to the route of the train. It looks like it's kind of been there, and then crashed all these simpler forms into it. The light grid will have a light, be lit up at night and give a kind of light ceiling. In Switzerland — Germany, actually — on the Rhine across from Basel, we did a furniture factory and a furniture museum.And I tried to — there's a Nick Grimshaw building over here, there's an Oldenburg sculpture over here — I tried to make a relationship urbanistically. And I don't gave good slides to show — it's just been completed — but this piece here is this building, and these pieces here and here. And as you pass by it's always part — you see it as all of these pieces accrue and become part of an overall neighborhood. It's plaster and just zinc. And you wonder, if this is a museum, what it's going to be like inside? If it's going to be so busy and crazy that you wouldn't show anything, and just wait. I'm so cunning and clever — I made it quiet and wonderful. But on the outside it does scream out at you a bit. It's actually basically three square rooms with a couple of skylights and stuff. And from the building in the back, you see it as an iceberg floating by in the hills. I know I'm over time. See, that skylight goes down and becomes that one. So it's pretty quiet inside.This is the Disney Hall — the concert hall. It's a complicated project. It has a chamber hall. It's related to an existing Chandler Pavilion that was built with a lot of love and tears and caring. And it's not a great building, but I approached it optimistically, that we would make a compositional relationship between us that would strengthen both of us. And the plan of this — it's a concert hall. This is the foyer, which is kind of a garden structure. There's commercial at the ground floor. These are offices, which, really, in the competition, we didn't have to design. But finally, there's a hotel there. These were the kind of relationships made to the Chandler, composing these elevations together and relating them to the buildings that existed — to MOCA, etc.The acoustician in the competition gave us criteria, which led to this compartmentalized scheme, which we found out after the competition would not work at all. But everybody liked these forms and liked the space, and so that's one of the problems of a competition. You have to then try and get that back in some way. And we studied many models. This was our original model. These were the three buildings that were the ideal — the Concertgebouw, Boston and Berlin. Everybody liked the surround. Actually, this is the smallest hall in size, and it has more seats than any of these because it has double balconies. Our client doesn't want balconies, so — and when we met our new acoustician, he told us this was the right shape or this was the right shape. And we tried many shapes, trying to get the energy of the original design within an acoustical, acceptable format. We finally settled on a shape that was the proportion of the Concertgebouw with the sloping outside walls, which the acoustician said were crucial to this and later decided they weren't, but now we have them.(Laughter)And our idea is to make the seating carriage very sculptural and out of wood and like a big boat sitting in this plaster room. That's the idea. And the corners would have skylights and these columns would be structural. And the nice thing about introducing columns is they give you a kind of sense of proscenium from wherever you sit, and create intimacy. Now, this is not a final design — these are just on the way to being — and so I wouldn't take it literally, except the feeling of the space. We studied the acoustics with laser stuff, and they bounce them off this and see where it all works. But you get the sense of the hall in section. Most halls come straight down into a proscenium. In this case we're opening it back up and getting skylights in the four corners. And so it will be quite a different shape.(Laughter)The original building, because it was frog-like, fit nicely on the site and cranked itself well. When you get into a box, it's harder to do it — and here we are, struggling with how to put the hotel in. And this is a teapot I designed for Alessi. I just stuck it on there. But this is how I do work. I do take pieces and bits and look at it and struggle with it and cut it away. And of course it's not going to look like that, but it is the crazy way I tend to work.And then finally, in L.A. I was asked to do a sculpture at the foot of Interstate Bank Tower, the highest building in L.A. Larry Halprin is doing the stairs. And I was asked to do a fish, and so I did a snake.(Laughter)It's a public space, and I made it kind of a garden structure, and you can go in it. It's a kiva, and Larry's putting some water in there, and it works much better than a fish.In Barcelona I was asked to do a fish, and we're working on that, at the foot of a Ritz-Carlton Tower being done by Skidmore, Owings and Merrill. And the Ritz-Carlton Tower is being designed with exposed steel, non-fire proof, much like those old gas tanks. And so we took the language of this exposed steel and used it, perverted it, into the form of the fish, and created a kind of a 19th-century contraption that looks like, that will sit — this is the beach and the harbor out in front, and this is really a shopping center with department stores. And we split these bridges. Originally, this was all solid with a hole in it. We cut them loose and made several bridges and created a kind of a foreground for this hotel. We showed this to the hotel people the other day, and they were terrified and said that nobody would come to the Ritz-Carlton anymore, because of this fish.(Laughter)And finally, I just threw these in — Lou Danziger. I didn't expect Lou Danziger to be here, but this is a building I did for him in 1964, I think. A little studio — and it's sadly for sale. Time goes on.And this is my son working with me on a small fast-food thing. He designed the robot as the cashier, and the head moves, and I did the rest of it. And the food wasn't as good as the stuff, and so it failed. It should have been the other way around — the food should have been good first. It didn't work.Thank you very much.
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:13.958
I'm going to go right into the slides.

00:00:13.958 --> 00:00:15.958
And all I'm going to try and prove to you with these slides

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:18.958
is that I do just very straight stuff.

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:23.958
And my ideas are --

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:26.958
in my head, anyway -- they're very logical

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:32.958
and relate to what's going on and problem solving for clients.

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:39.958
I either convince clients at the end that I solve their problems,

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:41.958
or I really do solve their problems,

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:44.958
because usually they seem to like it.

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:48.958
Let me go right into the slides.

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:53.958
Can you turn off the light? Down.

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:55.958
I like to be in the dark.

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:57.958
I don't want you to see what I'm doing up here.

00:00:57.958 --> 00:00:59.958
(Laughter)

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:02.958
Anyway, I did this house in Santa Monica,

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:05.958
and it got a lot of notoriety.

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:08.958
In fact, it appeared in a porno comic book,

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:11.958
which is the slide on the right.

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:15.958
(Laughter)

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:22.958
This is in Venice.

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:25.958
I just show it because I want you to know

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:27.958
I'm concerned about context.

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:29.958
On the left-hand side,

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:32.958
I had the context of those little houses,

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:35.958
and I tried to build a building that fit into that context.

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:39.958
When people take pictures of these buildings out of that context

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:41.958
they look really weird,

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:44.958
and my premise is that they make a lot more sense

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:49.958
when they're photographed or seen in that space.

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:53.958
And then, once I deal with the context,

00:01:53.958 --> 00:02:00.958
I then try to make a place that's comfortable and private and fairly serene,

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:05.958
as I hope you'll find that slide on the right.

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:11.958
And then I did a law school for Loyola in downtown L.A.

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:15.958
I was concerned about making a place for the study of law.

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:21.958
And we continue to work with this client.

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:26.958
The building on the right at the top is now under construction.

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:32.958
The garage on the right -- the gray structure -- will be torn down,

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:36.958
finally, and several small classrooms will be placed

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:40.958
along this avenue that we've created, this campus.

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:46.958
And it all related to the clients and the students

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:51.958
from the very first meeting saying they felt denied a place.

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:53.958
They wanted a sense of place.

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:57.958
And so the whole idea here was to create that kind of space

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:04.958
in downtown, in a neighborhood that was difficult to fit into.

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:08.958
And it was my theory, or my point of view,

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:13.958
that one didn't upstage the neighborhood --

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:15.958
one made accommodations.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:19.958
I tried to be inclusive, to include the buildings in the neighborhood,

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:23.958
whether they were buildings I liked or not.

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:27.958
In the '60s I started working with paper furniture

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:32.958
and made a bunch of stuff that was very successful in Bloomingdale's.

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:37.958
We even made flooring, walls and everything, out of cardboard.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:41.958
And the success of it threw me for a loop.

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:43.958
I couldn't deal with the success of furniture --

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:45.958
I wasn't secure enough as an architect --

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:50.958
and so I closed it all up and made furniture that nobody would like.

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:55.958
(Laughter)

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:00.958
So, nobody would like this.

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:04.958
And it was in this, preliminary to these pieces of furniture,

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:08.958
that Ricky and I worked on furniture by the slice.

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:12.958
And after we failed, I just kept failing.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:20.958
(Laughter)

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:22.958
The piece on the left --

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:25.958
and that ultimately led to the piece on the right --

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:28.958
happened when the kid that was working on this

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:31.958
took one of those long strings of stuff and folded it up

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:33.958
to put it in the wastebasket.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:36.958
And I put a piece of tape around it,

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:39.958
as you see there, and realized you could sit on it,

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:42.958
and it had a lot of resilience and strength and so on.

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:45.958
So, it was an accidental discovery.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958
I got into fish.

00:04:55.958 --> 00:05:02.958
(Laughter)

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:08.958
I mean, the story I tell is that I got mad at postmodernism -- at po-mo --

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:14.958
and said that fish were 500 million years earlier than man,

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:17.958
and if you're going to go back, we might as well go back to the beginning.

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:23.958
And so I started making these funny things.

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:28.958
And they started to have a life of their own and got bigger --

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
as the one glass at the Walker.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:35.958
And then, I sliced off the head and the tail and everything

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:38.958
and tried to translate what I was learning

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:42.958
about the form of the fish and the movement.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
And a lot of my architectural ideas that came from it --

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.958
accidental, again --

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:52.958
it was an intuitive kind of thing, and I just kept going with it,

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:58.958
and made this proposal for a building, which was only a proposal.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:02.958
I did this building in Japan.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:06.958
I was taken out to dinner after the contract

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
for this little restaurant was signed.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:13.958
And I love sake and Kobe and all that stuff.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:18.958
And after I got -- I was really drunk --

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:23.958
I was asked to do some sketches on napkins.

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:27.958
(Laughter)

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:31.958
And I made some sketches on napkins --

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
little boxes and Morandi-like things that I used to do.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:38.958
And the client said, "Why no fish?"

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:42.958
And so I made a drawing with a fish, and I left Japan.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:45.958
Three weeks later, I received a complete set of drawings

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958
saying we'd won the competition.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:57.958
(Laughter)

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:02.958
Now, it's hard to do. It's hard to translate a fish form,

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
because they're so beautiful -- perfect --

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:08.958
into a building or object like this.

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:13.958
And Oldenburg, who I work with a little once in a while,

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:19.958
told me I couldn't do it, and so that made it even more exciting.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:24.958
But he was right -- I couldn't do the tail.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:28.958
I started to get the head OK, but the tail I couldn't do.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
It was pretty hard.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
The thing on the right is a snake form, a ziggurat.

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
And I put them together, and you walk between them.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:39.958
It was a dialog with the context again.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:42.958
Now, if you saw a picture of this

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:45.958
as it was published in Architectural Record --

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:48.958
they didn't show the context, so you would think,

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:51.958
"God, what a pushy guy this is."

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
But a friend of mine spent four hours wandering around here

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
looking for this restaurant.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
Couldn't find it.

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:58.958
So ...

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:04.958
(Laughter)

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:11.958
As for craft and technology and all those things

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:16.958
that you've all been talking about, I was thrown for a complete loop.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
This was built in six months.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:22.958
The way we sent drawings to Japan:

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:27.958
we used the magic computer in Michigan that does carved models,

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:31.958
and we used to make foam models, which that thing scanned.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
We made the drawings of the fish and the scales.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
And when I got there, everything was perfect --

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:41.958
except the tail.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:45.958
So, I decided to cut off the head and the tail.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:50.958
And I made the object on the left for my show at the Walker.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
And it's one of the nicest pieces I've ever made, I think.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
And then Jay Chiat, a friend and client,

00:08:56.958 --> 00:09:00.958
asked me to do his headquarters building in L.A.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:06.958
For reasons we don't want to talk about, it got delayed.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:11.958
Toxic waste, I guess, is the key clue to that one.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:17.958
And so we built a temporary building -- I'm getting good at temporary --

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
and we put a conference room in that's a fish.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:27.958
And, finally, Jay dragged me to my hometown, Toronto, Canada.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:31.958
And there is a story -- it's a real story -- about my grandmother

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
buying a carp on Thursday, bringing it home,

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
putting it in the bathtub when I was a kid.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
I played with it in the evening.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.958
When I went to sleep, the next day it wasn't there.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
And the next night, we had gefilte fish.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
(Laughter)

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:50.958
And so I set up this interior for Jay's offices

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
and I made a pedestal for a sculpture.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:56.958
And he didn't buy a sculpture, so I made one.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.958
I went around Toronto and found a bathtub like my grandmother's,

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
and I put the fish in.

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
It was a joke.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:10.958
(Laughter)

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:14.958
I play with funny people like [Claes] Oldenburg.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:17.958
We've been friends for a long time.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:22.958
And we've started to work on things.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:26.958
A few years ago, we did a performance piece in Venice, Italy,

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:33.958
called "Il Corso del Coltello" -- the Swiss Army knife.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
And most of the imagery is --

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:39.958
(Laughter)

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
Claes', but those two little boys are my sons,

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:46.958
and they were Claes' assistants in the play.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
He was the Swiss Army knife.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:53.958
He was a souvenir salesman who always wanted to be a painter,

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
and I was Frankie P. Toronto.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
P for Palladio.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:01.958
Dressed up like the AT&T building by Claes --

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
(Laughter)

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:08.958
with a fish hat.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:12.958
The highlight of the performance was at the end.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
This beautiful object, the Swiss Army knife,

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
which I get credit for participating in.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
And I can tell you -- it's totally an Oldenburg.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:22.958
I had nothing to do with it.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.958
The only thing I did was, I made it possible for them

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:28.958
to turn those blades so you could sail this thing in the canal,

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
because I love sailing.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
(Laughter)

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
We made it into a sailing craft.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
I've been known to mess with things like chain link fencing.

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:42.958
I do it because it's a curious thing in the culture,

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
when things are made in such great quantities,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
absorbed in such great quantities,

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
and there's so much denial about them.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
People hate it.

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:55.958
And I'm fascinated with that, which, like the paper furniture --

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:57.958
it's one of those materials.

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
And I'm always drawn to that.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:02.958
And so I did a lot of dirty things with chain link,

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
which nobody will forgive me for.

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:08.958
But Claes made homage to it in the Loyola Law School.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
And that chain link is really expensive.

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
It's in perspective and everything.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:19.958
And then we did a camp together for children with cancer.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:23.958
And you can see, we started making a building together.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:26.958
Of course, the milk can is his.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:28.958
But we were trying to collide our ideas,

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
to put objects next to each other.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:35.958
Like a Morandi -- like the little bottles -- composing them like a still life.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:44.958
And it seemed to work as a way to put he and I together.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:48.958
Then Jay Chiat asked me to do this building

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:54.958
on this funny lot in Venice, and I started with this three-piece thing,

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
and you entered in the middle.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
And Jay asked me what I was going to do with the piece in the middle.

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
And he pushed that.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.958
And one day I had a -- oh, well, the other way.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.958
I had the binoculars from Claes, and I put them there,

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
and I could never get rid of them after that.

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
Oldenburg made the binoculars incredible

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:21.958
when he sent me the first model of the real proposal.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:23.958
It made my building look sick.

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
And it was this interaction between

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:30.958
that kind of, up-the-ante stuff that became pretty interesting.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
It led to the building on the left.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:36.958
And I still think the Time magazine picture will be of the binoculars, you know,

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:42.958
leaving out the -- what the hell.

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
I use a lot of metal in my work,

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:52.958
and I have a hard time connecting with the craft.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
The whole thing about my house,

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
the whole use of rough carpentry and everything,

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.958
was the frustration with the crafts available.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:05.958
I said, "If I can't get the craft that I want,

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
I'll use the craft I can get."

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
There were plenty of models for that,

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
in Rauschenberg and Jasper Johns, and many artists

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:19.958
who were making beautiful art and sculpture with junk materials.

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:22.958
I went into the metal because it was a way of building a building

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:26.958
that was a sculpture.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:28.958
And it was all of one material,

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:31.958
and the metal could go on the roof as well as the walls.

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:34.958
The metalworkers, for the most part,

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
do ducts behind the ceilings and stuff.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:40.958
I was given an opportunity to design an exhibit

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:47.958
for the metalworkers' unions of America and Canada in Washington,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
and I did it on the condition that they become my partners

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:55.958
in the future and help me with all future metal buildings, etc. etc.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
And it's working very well

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:00.958
to have these people, these craftsmen, interested in it.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:02.958
I just tell the stories.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:07.958
It's a way of connecting, at least, with some of those people

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:11.958
that are so important to the realization of architecture.

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:21.958
The metal continued into a building -- Herman Miller, in Sacramento.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:26.958
And it's just a complex of factory buildings.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:31.958
And Herman Miller has this philosophy of having a place --

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
a people place.

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:36.958
I mean, it's kind of a trite thing to say,

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:40.958
but it is real that they wanted to have a central place

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:44.958
where the cafeteria would be, where the people would come

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:48.958
and where the people working would interact.

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:54.958
So it's out in the middle of nowhere, and you approach it.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:57.958
It's copper and galvanize.

00:15:57.958 --> 00:16:00.958
I used the galvanize and copper

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:04.958
in a very light gauge, so it would buckle.

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:09.958
I spent a lot of time undoing Richard Meier's aesthetic.

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:13.958
Everybody's trying to get the panels perfect,

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:17.958
and I always try to get them sloppy and fuzzy.

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:20.958
And they end up looking like stone.

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:22.958
This is the central area.

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:24.958
There's a ramp.

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:27.958
And that little dome in there is a building by Stanley Tigerman.

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:30.958
Stanley was instrumental in my getting this job.

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:34.958
And when I was awarded the contract I, at the very beginning,

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:39.958
asked the client if they would let Stanley do a cameo piece with me.

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:43.958
Because these were ideas that we were talking about,

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:46.958
building things next to each other, making --

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:48.958
it's all about [a] metaphor for a city, maybe.

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:51.958
And so Stanley did the little dome thing.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:53.958
And we did it over the phone and by fax.

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:56.958
He would send me a fax and show me something.

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:59.958
He'd made a building with a dome and he had a little tower.

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:02.958
I told him, "No, no, that's too ongepotchket.

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:04.958
I don't want the tower."

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:10.958
So he came back with a simpler building,

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:16.958
but he put some funny details on it,

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:20.958
and he moved it closer to my building.

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:24.958
And so I decided to put him in a depression.

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:28.958
I put him in a hole and made a kind of a hole that he sits in.

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:32.958
And so then he put two bridges -- this all happened on the fax,

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:34.958
going back and forth over a couple of weeks' period.

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:38.958
And he put these two bridges with pink guardrails on it.

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:41.958
And so then I put this big billboard behind it.

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:44.958
And I call it, "David and Goliath."

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:50.958
And that's my cafeteria.

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:59.958
In Boston, we had that old building on the left.

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:02.958
It was a very prominent building off the freeway,

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:06.958
and we added a floor and cleaned it up and fixed it up

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:11.958
and used the kind of -- I thought -- the language of the neighborhood,

00:18:11.958 --> 00:18:15.958
which had these cornices, projecting cornices.

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:22.958
Mine got a little exuberant, but I used lead copper,

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:27.958
which is a beautiful material, and it turns green in 100 years.

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:31.958
Instead of, like, copper in 10 or 15.

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:35.958
We redid the side of the building

00:18:35.958 --> 00:18:39.958
and re-proportioned the windows so it sort of fit into the space.

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:43.958
And it surprised both Boston and myself that we got it approved,

00:18:43.958 --> 00:18:48.958
because they have very strict kind of design guideline,

00:18:49.958 --> 00:18:54.958
and they wouldn't normally think I would fit them.

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:57.958
The detailing was very careful with the lead copper

00:18:57.958 --> 00:19:03.958
and making panels and fitting it tightly

00:19:03.958 --> 00:19:06.958
into the fabric of the existing building.

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:15.958
In Barcelona, on Las Ramblas for some film festival,

00:19:15.958 --> 00:19:18.958
I did the Hollywood sign going and coming,

00:19:18.958 --> 00:19:21.958
made a building out of it, and they built it.

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:24.958
I flew in one night and took this picture.

00:19:24.958 --> 00:19:29.958
But they made it a third smaller than my model without telling me.

00:19:31.958 --> 00:19:37.958
And then more metal and some chain link in Santa Monica --

00:19:37.958 --> 00:19:39.958
a little shopping center.

00:19:44.958 --> 00:19:48.958
And this is a laser laboratory at the University of Iowa,

00:19:49.958 --> 00:19:53.958
in which the fish comes back as an abstraction in the back.

00:19:53.958 --> 00:20:06.958
It's the support labs, which, by some coincidence, required no windows.

00:20:06.958 --> 00:20:11.958
And the shape fit perfectly.

00:20:11.958 --> 00:20:13.958
I just joined the points.

00:20:13.958 --> 00:20:17.958
In the curved part there's all the mechanical equipment.

00:20:17.958 --> 00:20:22.958
That solid wall behind it is a pipe chase -- a pipe canyon --

00:20:22.958 --> 00:20:25.958
and so it was an opportunity that I seized,

00:20:25.958 --> 00:20:31.958
because I didn't have to have any protruding ducts or vents or things in this form.

00:20:31.958 --> 00:20:33.958
It gave me an opportunity to make a sculpture out of it.

00:20:36.958 --> 00:20:43.958
This is a small house somewhere.

00:20:43.958 --> 00:20:46.958
They've been building it so long I don't remember where it is.

00:20:46.958 --> 00:20:48.958
It's in the West Valley.

00:20:48.958 --> 00:20:51.958
And we started with the stream

00:20:52.958 --> 00:20:56.958
and built the house along the stream -- dammed it up to make a lake.

00:20:57.958 --> 00:20:59.958
These are the models.

00:21:02.958 --> 00:21:04.958
The reality, with the lake --

00:21:05.958 --> 00:21:09.958
the workmanship is pretty bad.

00:21:09.958 --> 00:21:15.958
And it reminded me why I play defensively in things like my house.

00:21:15.958 --> 00:21:19.958
When you have to do something really cheaply,

00:21:19.958 --> 00:21:24.958
it's hard to get perfect corners and stuff.

00:21:35.958 --> 00:21:41.958
That big metal thing is a passage, and in it is --

00:21:41.958 --> 00:21:44.958
you go downstairs into the living room and then down into the bedroom,

00:21:44.958 --> 00:21:46.958
which is on the right.

00:21:52.958 --> 00:21:54.958
It's kind of like a whole built town.

00:21:59.958 --> 00:22:06.958
I was asked to do a hospital for schizophrenic adolescents at Yale.

00:22:06.958 --> 00:22:10.958
I thought it was fitting for me to be doing that.

00:22:15.958 --> 00:22:19.958
This is a house next to a Philip Johnson house in Minnesota.

00:22:21.958 --> 00:22:25.958
The owners had a dilemma -- they asked Philip to do it.

00:22:25.958 --> 00:22:27.958
He was too busy.

00:22:28.958 --> 00:22:31.958
He didn't recommend me, by the way.

00:22:31.958 --> 00:22:33.958
(Laughter)

00:22:33.958 --> 00:22:39.958
We ended up having to make it a sculpture, because the dilemma was,

00:22:39.958 --> 00:22:42.958
how do you build a building that doesn't look like the language?

00:22:42.958 --> 00:22:46.958
Is it going to look like this beautiful estate is sub-divided?

00:22:46.958 --> 00:22:48.958
Etc. etc.

00:22:48.958 --> 00:22:50.958
You've got the idea.

00:22:50.958 --> 00:22:52.958
And so we finally ended up making it.

00:22:52.958 --> 00:22:54.958
These people are art collectors.

00:22:54.958 --> 00:22:58.958
And we finally made it so it appears very sculptural

00:22:58.958 --> 00:23:03.958
from the main house and all the windows are on the other side.

00:23:06.958 --> 00:23:11.958
And the building is very sculptural as you walk around it.

00:23:11.958 --> 00:23:17.958
It's made of metal and the brown stuff is Fin-Ply --

00:23:17.958 --> 00:23:21.958
it's that formed lumber from Finland.

00:23:21.958 --> 00:23:24.958
We used it at Loyola on the chapel, and it didn't work.

00:23:24.958 --> 00:23:26.958
I keep trying to make it work.

00:23:26.958 --> 00:23:29.958
In this case we learned how to detail it.

00:23:32.958 --> 00:23:39.958
In Cleveland, there's Burnham Mall, on the left.

00:23:39.958 --> 00:23:41.958
It's never been finished.

00:23:41.958 --> 00:23:46.958
Going out to the lake, you can see all those new buildings we built.

00:23:46.958 --> 00:23:52.958
And we had the opportunity to build a building on this site.

00:23:52.958 --> 00:23:54.958
There's a railroad track.

00:23:54.958 --> 00:23:59.958
This is the city hall over here somewhere, and the courthouse.

00:23:59.958 --> 00:24:03.958
And the centerline of the mall goes out.

00:24:03.958 --> 00:24:08.958
Burnham had designed a railroad station that was never built,

00:24:08.958 --> 00:24:10.958
and so we followed.

00:24:10.958 --> 00:24:12.958
Sohio is on the axis here,

00:24:12.958 --> 00:24:15.958
and we followed the axis, and they're two kind of goalposts.

00:24:15.958 --> 00:24:17.958
And this is our building,

00:24:17.958 --> 00:24:21.958
which is a corporate headquarters for an insurance company.

00:24:21.958 --> 00:24:26.958
We collaborated with Oldenburg and put the newspaper on top, folded.

00:24:32.958 --> 00:24:36.958
The health club is fastened to the garage

00:24:36.958 --> 00:24:39.958
with a C-clamp, for Cleveland.

00:24:39.958 --> 00:24:41.958
(Laughter)

00:24:41.958 --> 00:24:43.958
You drive down.

00:24:43.958 --> 00:24:46.958
So it's about a 10-story C-clamp.

00:24:46.958 --> 00:24:49.958
And all this stuff at the bottom is a museum,

00:24:49.958 --> 00:24:53.958
and an idea for a very fancy automobile entry.

00:24:53.958 --> 00:24:56.958
This owner has a pet peeve about bad automobile entries.

00:24:57.958 --> 00:24:59.958
And this would be a hotel.

00:24:59.958 --> 00:25:01.958
So, the centerline of this thing -- we'd preserve it,

00:25:01.958 --> 00:25:05.958
and it would start to work with the scale of the new buildings

00:25:05.958 --> 00:25:10.958
by Pelli and Kohn Pederson Fox, etc., that are underway.

00:25:21.958 --> 00:25:23.958
It's hard to do high-rise.

00:25:23.958 --> 00:25:26.958
I feel much more comfortable down here.

00:25:27.958 --> 00:25:30.958
This is a piece of property in Brentwood.

00:25:30.958 --> 00:25:36.958
And a long time ago, about '82 or something, after my house --

00:25:36.958 --> 00:25:39.958
I designed a house for myself

00:25:39.958 --> 00:25:44.958
that would be a village of several pavilions around a courtyard --

00:25:44.958 --> 00:25:49.958
and the owner of this lot worked for me

00:25:49.958 --> 00:25:51.958
and built that actual model on the left.

00:25:51.958 --> 00:25:53.958
And she came back,

00:25:53.958 --> 00:25:57.958
I guess wealthier or something -- something happened --

00:25:57.958 --> 00:26:03.958
and asked me to design a house for her on this site.

00:26:05.958 --> 00:26:10.958
And following that basic idea of the village,

00:26:10.958 --> 00:26:12.958
we changed it as we got into it.

00:26:12.958 --> 00:26:17.958
I locked the house into the site by cutting the back end --

00:26:17.958 --> 00:26:20.958
here you see on the photographs of the site --

00:26:20.958 --> 00:26:24.958
slicing into it and putting all the bathrooms and dressing rooms

00:26:24.958 --> 00:26:29.958
like a retaining wall, creating a lower level zone for the master bedroom,

00:26:29.958 --> 00:26:32.958
which I designed like a kind of a barge,

00:26:32.958 --> 00:26:34.958
looking like a boat.

00:26:36.958 --> 00:26:41.958
And that's it, built.

00:26:43.958 --> 00:26:47.958
The dome was a request from the client.

00:26:47.958 --> 00:26:49.958
She wanted a dome somewhere in the house.

00:26:49.958 --> 00:26:51.958
She didn't care where.

00:26:51.958 --> 00:26:53.958
When you sleep in this bedroom, I hope --

00:26:53.958 --> 00:26:55.958
I mean, I haven't slept in it yet.

00:26:56.958 --> 00:27:00.958
I've offered to marry her so I could sleep there,

00:27:00.958 --> 00:27:08.958
but she said I didn't have to do that.

00:27:08.958 --> 00:27:11.958
But when you're in that room,

00:27:11.958 --> 00:27:15.958
you feel like you're on a kind of barge on some kind of lake.

00:27:15.958 --> 00:27:17.958
And it's very private.

00:27:17.958 --> 00:27:20.958
The landscape is being built around to create a private garden.

00:27:20.958 --> 00:27:25.958
And then up above there's a garden on this side of the living room,

00:27:25.958 --> 00:27:27.958
and one on the other side.

00:27:30.958 --> 00:27:32.958
These aren't focused very well.

00:27:32.958 --> 00:27:36.958
I don't know how to do it from here.

00:27:36.958 --> 00:27:39.958
Focus the one on the right.

00:27:40.958 --> 00:27:42.958
It's up there.

00:27:42.958 --> 00:27:45.958
Left -- it's my right.

00:27:46.958 --> 00:27:52.958
Anyway, you enter into a garden with a beautiful grove of trees.

00:27:52.958 --> 00:27:54.958
That's the living room.

00:27:54.958 --> 00:27:56.958
Servants' quarters.

00:27:56.958 --> 00:28:00.958
A guest bedroom, which has this dome with marble on it.

00:28:00.958 --> 00:28:05.958
And then you enter into the living room and then so on.

00:28:10.958 --> 00:28:12.958
This is the bedroom.

00:28:12.958 --> 00:28:14.958
You come down from this level along the stairway,

00:28:14.958 --> 00:28:17.958
and you enter the bedroom here, going into the lake.

00:28:17.958 --> 00:28:19.958
And the bed is back in this space,

00:28:19.958 --> 00:28:22.958
with windows looking out onto the lake.

00:28:22.958 --> 00:28:27.958
These Stonehenge things were designed to give foreground

00:28:27.958 --> 00:28:31.958
and to create a greater depth in this shallow lot.

00:28:31.958 --> 00:28:36.958
The material is lead copper, like in the building in Boston.

00:28:40.958 --> 00:28:45.958
And so it was an intent to make this small piece of land --

00:28:45.958 --> 00:28:51.958
it's 100 by 250 -- into a kind of an estate by separating these areas

00:28:51.958 --> 00:28:57.958
and making the living room and dining room into this pavilion

00:28:57.958 --> 00:28:59.958
with a high space in it.

00:29:04.958 --> 00:29:07.958
And this happened by accident that I got this right on axis

00:29:07.958 --> 00:29:09.958
with the dining room table.

00:29:11.958 --> 00:29:15.958
It looks like I got a Baldessari painting for free.

00:29:16.958 --> 00:29:18.958
But the idea is, the windows are all placed

00:29:18.958 --> 00:29:22.958
so you see pieces of the house outside.

00:29:22.958 --> 00:29:26.958
Eventually this will be screened -- these trees will come up --

00:29:26.958 --> 00:29:28.958
and it will be very private.

00:29:28.958 --> 00:29:31.958
And you feel like you're in your own kind of village.

00:29:36.958 --> 00:29:41.958
This is for Michael Eisner -- Disney.

00:29:41.958 --> 00:29:44.958
We're doing some work for him.

00:29:44.958 --> 00:29:49.958
And this is in Anaheim, California, and it's a freeway building.

00:29:49.958 --> 00:29:53.958
You go under this bridge at about 65 miles an hour,

00:29:53.958 --> 00:29:55.958
and there's another bridge here.

00:29:55.958 --> 00:29:57.958
And you're through this room in a split second,

00:29:57.958 --> 00:29:59.958
and the building will sort of reflect that.

00:29:59.958 --> 00:30:02.958
On the backside, it's much more humane -- entrance,

00:30:02.958 --> 00:30:04.958
dining hall, etc.

00:30:04.958 --> 00:30:09.958
And then this thing here -- I'm hoping as you drive by you'll hear

00:30:09.958 --> 00:30:12.958
the picket fence effect of the sound hitting it.

00:30:13.958 --> 00:30:17.958
Kind of a fun thing to do.

00:30:19.958 --> 00:30:23.958
I'm doing a building in Switzerland, Basel,

00:30:23.958 --> 00:30:26.958
which is an office building for a furniture company.

00:30:26.958 --> 00:30:29.958
And we struggled with the image.

00:30:29.958 --> 00:30:32.958
These are the early studies, but they have to sell furniture

00:30:32.958 --> 00:30:37.958
to normal people, so if I did the building and it was too fancy,

00:30:37.958 --> 00:30:41.958
then people might say, "Well, the furniture looks OK in his thing,

00:30:41.958 --> 00:30:43.958
but no, it ain't going to look good in my normal building."

00:30:43.958 --> 00:30:47.958
So we've made a kind of pragmatic slab in the second phase here,

00:30:47.958 --> 00:30:51.958
and we've taken the conference facilities and made a villa out of them

00:30:51.958 --> 00:30:55.958
so that the communal space is very sculptural and separate.

00:30:55.958 --> 00:30:59.958
And you're looking at it from the offices and you create a kind of

00:30:59.958 --> 00:31:02.958
interaction between these pieces.

00:31:03.958 --> 00:31:07.958
This is in Paris, along the Seine.

00:31:07.958 --> 00:31:11.958
Palais des Sports, the Gare de Lyon over here.

00:31:11.958 --> 00:31:15.958
The Minister of Finance -- the guy that moved from the Louvre -- goes in here.

00:31:15.958 --> 00:31:18.958
There's a new library across the river.

00:31:18.958 --> 00:31:22.958
And back in here, in this already treed park,

00:31:22.958 --> 00:31:26.958
we're doing a very dense building called the American Center,

00:31:26.958 --> 00:31:33.958
which has a theater, apartments, dance school, an art museum,

00:31:33.958 --> 00:31:37.958
restaurants and all kinds of -- it's a very dense program --

00:31:37.958 --> 00:31:40.958
bookstores, etc.

00:31:40.958 --> 00:31:42.958
In a very tight, small --

00:31:42.958 --> 00:31:45.958
this is the ground level.

00:31:45.958 --> 00:31:48.958
And the French have this extraordinary way of screwing things up

00:31:48.958 --> 00:31:52.958
by taking a beautiful site and cutting the corner off.

00:31:52.958 --> 00:31:54.958
They call it the plan coupe.

00:31:54.958 --> 00:32:00.958
And I struggled with that thing --

00:32:00.958 --> 00:32:02.958
how to get around the corner.

00:32:02.958 --> 00:32:05.958
These are the models for it.

00:32:05.958 --> 00:32:08.958
I showed you the other model, the one --

00:32:13.958 --> 00:32:16.958
this is the way I organized myself so I could make the drawing --

00:32:16.958 --> 00:32:22.958
so I understood the problem.

00:32:22.958 --> 00:32:26.958
I was trying to get around this plan coupe -- how do you do it?

00:32:26.958 --> 00:32:29.958
Apartments, etc.

00:32:29.958 --> 00:32:31.958
And these are the kind of study models we did.

00:32:31.958 --> 00:32:35.958
And the one on the left is pretty awful.

00:32:35.958 --> 00:32:40.958
You can see why I was ready to commit suicide when this one was built.

00:32:40.958 --> 00:32:47.958
But out of it came finally this resolution, where the elevator piece

00:32:47.958 --> 00:32:50.958
worked frontally to this, parallel to this street,

00:32:50.958 --> 00:32:52.958
and also parallel to here.

00:32:52.958 --> 00:32:56.958
And then this kind of twist, with this balcony and the skirt,

00:32:56.958 --> 00:33:02.958
kind of like a ballerina lifting her skirt to let you into the foyer.

00:33:02.958 --> 00:33:05.958
The restaurants here -- the apartments and the theater, etc.

00:33:05.958 --> 00:33:09.958
So it would all be built in stone, in French limestone,

00:33:09.958 --> 00:33:11.958
except for this metal piece.

00:33:11.958 --> 00:33:14.958
And it faces into a park.

00:33:14.958 --> 00:33:19.958
And the idea was to make this express the energy of this.

00:33:22.958 --> 00:33:26.958
On the side facing the street it's much more normal,

00:33:26.958 --> 00:33:32.958
except I slipped a few mansards down, so that coming on the point,

00:33:32.958 --> 00:33:36.958
these housing units made a gesture to the corner.

00:33:45.958 --> 00:33:50.958
And this will be some kind of high-tech billboard.

00:33:50.958 --> 00:33:52.958
If any of you guys have any ideas for it, please contact me.

00:33:52.958 --> 00:33:54.958
I don't know what to do.

00:33:57.958 --> 00:34:00.958
Jay Chiat is a glutton for punishment, and he hired me

00:34:00.958 --> 00:34:02.958
to do a house for him in the Hamptons.

00:34:02.958 --> 00:34:04.958
And it's got a fish.

00:34:04.958 --> 00:34:07.958
And I keep thinking, "This is going to be the last fish."

00:34:07.958 --> 00:34:10.958
It's like a drug addict.

00:34:10.958 --> 00:34:12.958
I say, "I'm not going to do it anymore -- I don't want to do it anymore --

00:34:12.958 --> 00:34:14.958
I'm not going to do it."

00:34:14.958 --> 00:34:16.958
And then I do it.

00:34:16.958 --> 00:34:17.958
(Laughter)

00:34:17.958 --> 00:34:18.958
There it is.

00:34:18.958 --> 00:34:19.958
But it's the living room.

00:34:19.958 --> 00:34:21.958
And this piece here is --

00:34:21.958 --> 00:34:23.958
I don't know what it is.

00:34:23.958 --> 00:34:25.958
I just added it so that we'd have enough money in the budget

00:34:25.958 --> 00:34:28.958
so we could take something out.

00:34:28.958 --> 00:34:36.958
(Applause)

00:34:36.958 --> 00:34:40.958
This is Euro Disney, and I've worked with all of the guys

00:34:40.958 --> 00:34:42.958
that presented to you earlier.

00:34:43.958 --> 00:34:45.958
We've had a lot of fun working together.

00:34:45.958 --> 00:34:49.958
I think I'm from Mars for them, and they are for me,

00:34:49.958 --> 00:34:52.958
but somehow we all manage to work together,

00:34:52.958 --> 00:34:56.958
and I think, productively.

00:34:56.958 --> 00:34:58.958
So far.

00:34:58.958 --> 00:35:01.958
This is a shopping thing.

00:35:01.958 --> 00:35:04.958
You come into the Magic Kingdom

00:35:04.958 --> 00:35:08.958
and the hotel that Tony Baxter's group is doing out here.

00:35:08.958 --> 00:35:11.958
And then this is a kind of a shopping mall,

00:35:11.958 --> 00:35:14.958
with a rodeo and restaurants.

00:35:14.958 --> 00:35:17.958
And another restaurant.

00:35:17.958 --> 00:35:22.958
What I did -- because of the Paris skies being quite dull,

00:35:22.958 --> 00:35:25.958
I made a light grid that's perpendicular to the train station,

00:35:25.958 --> 00:35:27.958
to the route of the train.

00:35:27.958 --> 00:35:30.958
It looks like it's kind of been there,

00:35:30.958 --> 00:35:34.958
and then crashed all these simpler forms into it.

00:35:34.958 --> 00:35:40.958
The light grid will have a light, be lit up at night and give a

00:35:40.958 --> 00:35:43.958
kind of light ceiling.

00:35:51.958 --> 00:35:55.958
In Switzerland -- Germany, actually -- on the Rhine across from Basel,

00:35:55.958 --> 00:35:59.958
we did a furniture factory and a furniture museum.

00:35:59.958 --> 00:36:02.958
