And I tried to -- there's a Nick Grimshaw building over here,

00:36:02.958 --> 00:36:05.958
there's an Oldenburg sculpture over here --

00:36:05.958 --> 00:36:09.958
I tried to make a relationship urbanistically.

00:36:09.958 --> 00:36:12.958
And I don't gave good slides to show -- it's just been completed --

00:36:12.958 --> 00:36:16.958
but this piece here is this building, and these pieces here and here.

00:36:16.958 --> 00:36:21.958
And as you pass by it's always part -- you see it as all of these pieces

00:36:21.958 --> 00:36:26.958
accrue and become part of an overall neighborhood.

00:36:31.958 --> 00:36:34.958
It's plaster and just zinc.

00:36:34.958 --> 00:36:37.958
And you wonder, if this is a museum,

00:36:37.958 --> 00:36:39.958
what it's going to be like inside?

00:36:39.958 --> 00:36:43.958
If it's going to be so busy and crazy that you wouldn't show anything,

00:36:43.958 --> 00:36:45.958
and just wait.

00:36:45.958 --> 00:36:50.958
I'm so cunning and clever -- I made it quiet and wonderful.

00:36:50.958 --> 00:36:55.958
But on the outside it does scream out at you a bit.

00:36:58.958 --> 00:37:03.958
It's actually basically three square rooms

00:37:03.958 --> 00:37:05.958
with a couple of skylights and stuff.

00:37:05.958 --> 00:37:08.958
And from the building in the back, you see it as

00:37:08.958 --> 00:37:11.958
an iceberg floating by in the hills.

00:37:14.958 --> 00:37:17.958
I know I'm over time.

00:37:32.958 --> 00:37:35.958
See, that skylight goes down and becomes that one.

00:37:35.958 --> 00:37:39.958
So it's pretty quiet inside.

00:37:42.958 --> 00:37:46.958
This is the Disney Hall -- the concert hall.

00:37:46.958 --> 00:37:50.958
It's a complicated project.

00:37:50.958 --> 00:37:52.958
It has a chamber hall.

00:37:52.958 --> 00:37:56.958
It's related to an existing Chandler Pavilion that was built

00:37:56.958 --> 00:37:59.958
with a lot of love and tears and caring.

00:37:59.958 --> 00:38:04.958
And it's not a great building, but I approached it optimistically,

00:38:04.958 --> 00:38:11.958
that we would make a compositional relationship between us

00:38:12.958 --> 00:38:15.958
that would strengthen both of us.

00:38:15.958 --> 00:38:17.958
And the plan of this -- it's a concert hall.

00:38:17.958 --> 00:38:20.958
This is the foyer, which is kind of a garden structure.

00:38:20.958 --> 00:38:22.958
There's commercial at the ground floor.

00:38:22.958 --> 00:38:26.958
These are offices, which, really, in the competition,

00:38:26.958 --> 00:38:28.958
we didn't have to design.

00:38:28.958 --> 00:38:32.958
But finally, there's a hotel there.

00:38:32.958 --> 00:38:37.958
These were the kind of relationships made to the Chandler,

00:38:37.958 --> 00:38:41.958
composing these elevations together and relating them

00:38:41.958 --> 00:38:46.958
to the buildings that existed -- to MOCA, etc.

00:38:50.958 --> 00:38:55.958
The acoustician in the competition gave us criteria,

00:38:55.958 --> 00:38:59.958
which led to this compartmentalized scheme,

00:38:59.958 --> 00:39:03.958
which we found out after the competition would not work at all.

00:39:03.958 --> 00:39:08.958
But everybody liked these forms and liked the space,

00:39:08.958 --> 00:39:10.958
and so that's one of the problems of a competition.

00:39:10.958 --> 00:39:16.958
You have to then try and get that back in some way.

00:39:16.958 --> 00:39:20.958
And we studied many models.

00:39:20.958 --> 00:39:22.958
This was our original model.

00:39:22.958 --> 00:39:26.958
These were the three buildings that were the ideal --

00:39:26.958 --> 00:39:29.958
the Concertgebouw, Boston and Berlin.

00:39:29.958 --> 00:39:32.958
Everybody liked the surround.

00:39:32.958 --> 00:39:35.958
Actually, this is the smallest hall in size,

00:39:35.958 --> 00:39:38.958
and it has more seats than any of these

00:39:38.958 --> 00:39:40.958
because it has double balconies.

00:39:40.958 --> 00:39:43.958
Our client doesn't want balconies, so --

00:39:43.958 --> 00:39:45.958
and when we met our new acoustician, he told us

00:39:45.958 --> 00:39:48.958
this was the right shape or this was the right shape.

00:39:48.958 --> 00:39:52.958
And we tried many shapes, trying to get the energy

00:39:52.958 --> 00:40:00.958
of the original design within an acoustical, acceptable format.

00:40:00.958 --> 00:40:02.958
We finally settled on a shape that was

00:40:02.958 --> 00:40:05.958
the proportion of the Concertgebouw

00:40:05.958 --> 00:40:10.958
with the sloping outside walls, which the acoustician said

00:40:10.958 --> 00:40:13.958
were crucial to this and later decided they weren't,

00:40:13.958 --> 00:40:15.958
but now we have them.

00:40:15.958 --> 00:40:17.958
(Laughter)

00:40:17.958 --> 00:40:22.958
And our idea is to make the seating carriage very sculptural

00:40:22.958 --> 00:40:28.958
and out of wood and like a big boat sitting in this plaster room.

00:40:28.958 --> 00:40:30.958
That's the idea.

00:40:30.958 --> 00:40:36.958
And the corners would have skylights

00:40:36.958 --> 00:40:40.958
and these columns would be structural.

00:40:40.958 --> 00:40:43.958
And the nice thing about introducing columns is they give you a

00:40:43.958 --> 00:40:46.958
kind of sense of proscenium from wherever you sit,

00:40:46.958 --> 00:40:48.958
and create intimacy.

00:40:48.958 --> 00:40:53.958
Now, this is not a final design -- these are just on the way to being --

00:40:53.958 --> 00:40:59.958
and so I wouldn't take it literally, except the feeling of the space.

00:40:59.958 --> 00:41:04.958
We studied the acoustics with laser stuff,

00:41:04.958 --> 00:41:07.958
and they bounce them off this and see where it all works.

00:41:07.958 --> 00:41:09.958
But you get the sense of the hall in section.

00:41:09.958 --> 00:41:15.958
Most halls come straight down into a proscenium.

00:41:15.958 --> 00:41:17.958
In this case we're opening it back up

00:41:17.958 --> 00:41:20.958
and getting skylights in the four corners.

00:41:20.958 --> 00:41:23.958
And so it will be quite a different shape.

00:41:27.958 --> 00:41:29.958
(Laughter)

00:41:29.958 --> 00:41:34.958
The original building, because it was frog-like,

00:41:34.958 --> 00:41:37.958
fit nicely on the site and cranked itself well.

00:41:37.958 --> 00:41:40.958
When you get into a box, it's harder to do it -- and here we are,

00:41:40.958 --> 00:41:42.958
struggling with how to put the hotel in.

00:41:42.958 --> 00:41:45.958
And this is a teapot I designed for Alessi.

00:41:45.958 --> 00:41:48.958
I just stuck it on there.

00:41:48.958 --> 00:41:53.958
But this is how I do work. I do take pieces and bits and look at it

00:41:53.958 --> 00:41:55.958
and struggle with it and cut it away.

00:41:55.958 --> 00:41:57.958
And of course it's not going to look like that,

00:41:57.958 --> 00:42:02.958
but it is the crazy way I tend to work.

00:42:02.958 --> 00:42:05.958
And then finally, in L.A. I was asked to do a sculpture

00:42:05.958 --> 00:42:11.958
at the foot of Interstate Bank Tower, the highest building in L.A.

00:42:11.958 --> 00:42:14.958
Larry Halprin is doing the stairs.

00:42:14.958 --> 00:42:18.958
And I was asked to do a fish, and so I did a snake.

00:42:18.958 --> 00:42:19.958
(Laughter)

00:42:19.958 --> 00:42:22.958
It's a public space, and I made it kind of a garden structure,

00:42:22.958 --> 00:42:24.958
and you can go in it.

00:42:24.958 --> 00:42:27.958
It's a kiva, and Larry's putting some water in there,

00:42:27.958 --> 00:42:30.958
and it works much better than a fish.

00:42:30.958 --> 00:42:35.958
In Barcelona I was asked to do a fish, and we're working on that,

00:42:35.958 --> 00:42:38.958
at the foot of a Ritz-Carlton Tower being done by

00:42:38.958 --> 00:42:40.958
Skidmore, Owings and Merrill.

00:42:40.958 --> 00:42:43.958
And the Ritz-Carlton Tower is being designed with exposed steel,

00:42:43.958 --> 00:42:47.958
non-fire proof, much like those old gas tanks.

00:42:47.958 --> 00:42:53.958
And so we took the language of this exposed steel and used it,

00:42:53.958 --> 00:43:01.958
perverted it, into the form of the fish, and created a kind of

00:43:01.958 --> 00:43:06.958
a 19th-century contraption that looks like, that will sit --

00:43:06.958 --> 00:43:08.958
this is the beach and the harbor out in front,

00:43:08.958 --> 00:43:12.958
and this is really a shopping center with department stores.

00:43:12.958 --> 00:43:14.958
And we split these bridges.

00:43:14.958 --> 00:43:16.958
Originally, this was all solid with a hole in it.

00:43:16.958 --> 00:43:21.958
We cut them loose and made several bridges and created a kind of

00:43:21.958 --> 00:43:23.958
a foreground for this hotel.

00:43:23.958 --> 00:43:26.958
We showed this to the hotel people the other day,

00:43:26.958 --> 00:43:31.958
and they were terrified and said that nobody would come

00:43:31.958 --> 00:43:36.958
to the Ritz-Carlton anymore, because of this fish.

00:43:36.958 --> 00:43:39.958
(Laughter)

00:43:45.958 --> 00:43:47.958
And finally, I just threw these in -- Lou Danziger.

00:43:47.958 --> 00:43:49.958
I didn't expect Lou Danziger to be here,

00:43:49.958 --> 00:43:53.958
but this is a building I did for him in 1964, I think.

00:43:53.958 --> 00:43:57.958
A little studio -- and it's sadly for sale.

00:43:57.958 --> 00:43:59.958
Time goes on.

00:43:59.958 --> 00:44:06.958
And this is my son working with me on a small fast-food thing.

00:44:06.958 --> 00:44:09.958
He designed the robot as the cashier, and the head moves,

00:44:09.958 --> 00:44:11.958
and I did the rest of it.

00:44:11.958 --> 00:44:15.958
And the food wasn't as good as the stuff, and so it failed.

00:44:15.958 --> 00:44:16.958
It should have been the other way around --

00:44:16.958 --> 00:44:18.958
the food should have been good first.

00:44:18.958 --> 00:44:19.958
It didn't work.

00:44:19.958 --> 00:44:20.958
Thank you very much.

title: My wish: Once Upon a School
transcript: Thank you so much everyone from TED, and Chris and Amy in particular. I cannot believe I'm here. I have not slept in weeks. Neil and I were sitting there comparing how little we've slept in anticipation for this. I've never been so nervous — and I do this when I'm nervous, I just realized. (Laughter) So, I'm going to talk about sort of what we did at this organization called 826 Valencia, and then I'm going to talk about how we all might join in and do similar things.Back in about 2000, I was living in Brooklyn, I was trying to finish my first book, I was wandering around dazed every day because I wrote from 12 a.m. to 5 a.m. So I would walk around in a daze during the day. I had no mental acuity to speak of during the day, but I had flexible hours. In the Brooklyn neighborhood that I lived in, Park Slope, there are a lot of writers — it's like a very high per capita ratio of writers to normal people. Meanwhile, I had grown up around a lot of teachers. My mom was a teacher, my sister became a teacher and after college so many of my friends went into teaching. And so I was always hearing them talk about their lives and how inspiring they were, and they were really sort of the most hard-working and constantly inspiring people I knew.But I knew so many of the things they were up against, so many of the struggles they were dealing with. And one of them was that so many of my friends that were teaching in city schools were having trouble with their students keeping up at grade level, in their reading and writing in particular. Now, so many of these students had come from households where English isn't spoken in the home, where a lot of them have different special needs, learning disabilities. And of course they're working in schools which sometimes and very often are under-funded. And so they would talk to me about this and say, "You know, what we really need is just more people, more bodies, more one-on-one attention, more hours, more expertise from people that have skills in English and can work with these students one-on-one."Now, I would say, "Well, why don't you just work with them one-on-one?" And they would say, "Well, we have five classes of 30 to 40 students each. This can lead up to 150, 180, 200 students a day. How can we possibly give each student even one hour a week of one-on-one attention?" You'd have to greatly multiply the workweek and clone the teachers. And so we started talking about this. And at the same time, I thought about this massive group of people I knew: writers, editors, journalists, graduate students, assistant professors, you name it. All these people that had sort of flexible daily hours and an interest in the English word — I hope to have an interest in the English language, but I'm not speaking it well right now. (Laughter) I'm trying. That clock has got me. But everyone that I knew had an interest in the primacy of the written word in terms of nurturing a democracy, nurturing an enlightened life. And so they had, you know, their time and their interest, but at the same time there wasn't a conduit that I knew of in my community to bring these two communities together.So when I moved back to San Francisco, we rented this building. And the idea was to put McSweeney's — McSweeney's Quarterly, that we published twice or three times a year, and a few other magazines — we were going to move it into an office for the first time. It used to be in my kitchen in Brooklyn. We were going to move it into an office, and we were going to actually share space with a tutoring center. So we thought, "We'll have all these writers and editors and everybody — sort of a writing community — coming into the office every day anyway, why don't we just open up the front of the building for students to come in there after school, get extra help on their written homework, so you have basically no border between these two communities?" So the idea was that we would be working on whatever we're working on, at 2:30 p.m. the students flow in and you put down what you're doing, or you trade, or you work a little bit later or whatever it is. You give those hours in the afternoon to the students in the neighborhood.So, we had this place, we rented it, the landlord was all for it. We did this mural, that's a Chris Ware mural, that basically explains the entire history of the printed word, in mural form — it takes a long time to digest and you have to stand in the middle of the road. So we rented this space. And everything was great except the landlord said, "Well, the space is zoned for retail; you have to come up with something. You've gotta sell something. You can't just have a tutoring center." So we thought, "Ha ha! Really!" And we couldn't think of anything necessarily to sell, but we did all the necessary research. It used to be a weight room, so there were rubber floors below, acoustic tile ceilings and fluorescent lights. We took all that down, and we found beautiful wooden floors, whitewashed beams and it had the look — while we were renovating this place, somebody said, "You know, it really kind of looks like the hull of a ship." And we looked around and somebody else said, "Well, you should sell supplies to the working buccaneer." (Laughter)And so this is what we did. So it made everybody laugh, and we said, "There's a point to that. Let's sell pirate supplies." This is the pirate supply store. You see, this is sort of a sketch I did on a napkin. A great carpenter built all this stuff and you see, we made it look sort of pirate supply-like. Here you see planks sold by the foot and we have supplies to combat scurvy. We have the peg legs there, that are all handmade and fitted to you. Up at the top, you see the eyepatch display, which is the black column there for everyday use for your eyepatch, and then you have the pastel and other colors for stepping out at night — special occasions, bar mitzvahs and whatever.So we opened this place. And this is a vat that we fill with treasures that students dig in. This is replacement eyes in case you lose one. These are some signs that we have all over the place: "Practical Joking with Pirates." While you're reading the sign, we pull a rope behind the counter and eight mop heads drop on your head. That was just my one thing — I said we had to have something that drops on people's heads. It became mop heads. And this is the fish theater, which is just a saltwater tank with three seats, and then right behind it we set up this space, which was the tutoring center. So right there is the tutoring center, and then behind the curtain were the McSweeney's offices, where all of us would be working on the magazine and book editing and things like that.The kids would come in — or we thought they would come in. I should back up. We set the place up, we opened up, we spent months and months renovating this place. We had tables, chairs, computers, everything. I went to a dot-com auction at a Holiday Inn in Palo Alto and I bought 11 G4s with a stroke of a paddle. Anyway, we bought 'em, we set everything up and then we waited. It was started with about 12 of my friends, people that I had known for years that were writers in the neighborhood. And we sat. And at 2:30 p.m. we put a sandwich board out on the front sidewalk and it just said, "Free Tutoring for Your English-Related and Writing-Related Needs — Just Come In, It's All Free." And we thought, "Oh, they're going to storm the gates, they're gonna love it." And they didn't. And so we waited, we sat at the tables, we waited and waited. And everybody was becoming very discouraged because it was weeks and weeks that we waited, really, where nobody came in.And then somebody alerted us to the fact that maybe there was a trust gap, because we were operating behind a pirate supply store. (Laughter) We never put it together, you know? And so then, around that time, I persuaded a woman named Nineveh Caligari, a longtime San Francisco educator — she was teaching in Mexico City, she had all the experience necessary, knew everything about education, was connected with all the teachers and community members in the neighborhood — I convinced her to move up from Mexico City where she was teaching. She took over as executive director. Immediately, she made the inroads with the teachers and the parents and the students and everything, and so suddenly it was actually full every day.And what we were trying to offer every day was one-on-one attention. The goal was to have a one-to-one ratio with every one of these students. You know, it's been proven that 35 to 40 hours a year with one-on-one attention, a student can get one grade level higher. And so most of these students, English is not spoken in the home. They come there, many times their parents — you can't see it, but there's a church pew that I bought in a Berkeley auction right there — the parents will sometimes watch while their kids are being tutored. So that was the basis of it, was one-on-one attention. And we found ourselves full every day with kids. If you're on Valencia Street within those few blocks at around 2 p.m., 2:30 p.m., you will get run over, often, by the kids and their big backpacks, or whatever, actually running to this space,which is very strange, because it's school, in a way. But there was something psychological happening there that was just a little bit different. And the other thing was, there was no stigma. Kids weren't going into the "Center-for-Kids-That-Need-More-Help," or something like that. It was 826 Valencia. First of all, it was a pirate supply store, which is insane. And then secondly, there's a publishing company in the back. And so our interns were actually working at the same tables very often, and shoulder-to-shoulder, computer-next-to-computer with the students.And so it became a tutoring center — publishing center, is what we called it — and a writing center. They go in, and they might be working with a high school student actually working on a novel — because we had very gifted kids, too. So there's no stigma. They're all working next to each other. It's all a creative endeavor. They're seeing adults. They're modeling their behavior. These adults, they're working in their field. They can lean over, ask a question of one of these adults and it all sort of feeds on each other. There's a lot of cross-pollination. The only problem, especially for the adults working at McSweeney's who hadn't necessarily bought into all of this when they signed up, was that there was just the one bathroom. (Laughter) With like 60 kids a day, this is a problem.But you know, there's something about the kids finishing their homework in a given day, working one-on-one, getting all this attention — they go home, they're finished. They don't stall. They don't do their homework in front of the TV. They're allowed to go home at 5:30 p.m., enjoy their family, enjoy other hobbies, get outside, play. And that makes a happy family. A bunch of happy families in a neighborhood is a happy community. A bunch of happy communities tied together is a happy city and a happy world. So the key to it all is homework! (Laughter) (Applause) There you have it, you know — one-on-one attention.So we started off with about 12 volunteers, and then we had about 50, and then a couple hundred. And we now have 1,400 volunteers on our roster. And we make it incredibly easy to volunteer. The key thing is, even if you only have a couple of hours a month, those two hours shoulder-to-shoulder, next to one student, concentrated attention, shining this beam of light on their work, on their thoughts and their self-expression, is going to be absolutely transformative, because so many of the students have not had that ever before. So we said, "Even if you have two hours one Sunday every six months, it doesn't matter. That's going to be enough." So that's partly why the tutor corps grew so fast.Then we said, "Well, what are we going to do with the space during the day, because it has to be used before 2:30 p.m.?" So we started bringing in classes during the day. So every day, there's a field trip where they together create a book — you can see it being typed up above. This is one of the classes getting way too excited about writing. You just point a camera at a class, and it always looks like this. So this is one of the books that they do. Notice the title of the book, "The Book That Was Never Checked Out: Titanic." And the first line of that book is, "Once there was a book named Cindy that was about the Titanic." So, meanwhile, there's an adult in the back typing this up, taking it completely seriously, which blows their mind.So then we still had more tutors to use. This is a shot of just some of the tutors during one of the events. The teachers that we work with — and everything is different to teachers — they tell us what to do. We went in there thinking, "We're ultimately, completely malleable. You're going to tell us. The neighborhood's going to tell us, the parents are going to tell us. The teachers are going to tell us how we're most useful."So then they said, "Why don't you come into the schools? Because what about the students that wouldn't come to you, necessarily, who don't have really active parents that are bringing them in, or aren't close enough?" So then we started saying, "Well, we've got 1,400 people on our tutor roster. Let's just put out the word." A teacher will say, "I need 12 tutors for the next five Sundays. We're working on our college essays. Send them in." So we put that out on the wire: 1,400 tutors. Whoever can make it signs up. They go in about a half an hour before the class. The teacher tells them what to do, how to do it, what their training is, what their project is so far. They work under the teacher's guide, and it's all in one big room. And that's actually the brunt of what we do is, people going straight from their workplace, straight from home, straight into the classroom and working directly with the students. So then we're able to work with thousands and thousands of more students. Then another school said, "Well, what if we just give you a classroom and you can staff it all day?"So this is the Everett Middle School Writers' Room, where we decorated it in buccaneer style. It's right off the library. And there we serve all 529 kids in this middle school. This is their newspaper, the "Straight-Up News," that has an ongoing column from Mayor Gavin Newsom in both languages — English and Spanish. So then one day Isabel Allende wrote to us and said, "Hey, why don't you assign a book with high school students? I want them to write about how to achieve peace in a violent world." And so we went into Thurgood Marshall High School, which is a school that we had worked with on some other things, and we gave that assignment to the students. And we said, "Isabel Allende is going to read all your essays at the end. She's going to publish them in a book. She's going to sponsor the printing of this book in paperback form. It's going to be available in all the bookstores in the Bay Area and throughout the world, on Amazon and you name it." So these kids worked harder than they've ever worked on anything in their lives, because there was that outside audience, there was Isabel Allende on the other end. I think we had about 170 tutors that worked on this book with them and so this worked out incredibly well. We had a big party at the end. This is a book that you can find anywhere. So that led to a series of these. You can see Amy Tan sponsored the next one, "I Might Get Somewhere." And this became an ongoing thing. More and more books.Now we're sort of addicted to the book thing. The kids will work harder than they've ever worked in their life if they know it's going to be permanent, know it's going to be on a shelf, know that nobody can diminish what they've thought and said, that we've honored their words, honored their thoughts with hundreds of hours of five drafts, six drafts — all this attention that we give to their thoughts. And once they achieve that level, once they've written at that level, they can never go back. It's absolutely transformative. And so then they're all sold in the store. This is near the planks. We sell all the student books. Where else would you put them, right? So we sell 'em, and then something weird had been happening with the stores. The store, actually — even though we started out as just a gag — the store actually made money. So it was paying the rent. And maybe this is just a San Francisco thing — I don't know, I don't want to judge. But people would come in — and this was before the pirate movies and everything! It was making a lot of money. Not a lot of money, but it was paying the rent, paying a full-time staff member there. There's the ocean maps you can see on the left.And it became a gateway to the community. People would come in and say, "What the —? What is this?" I don't want to swear on the web. (Laughter) Is that a rule? I don't know. They would say, "What is this?" And people would come in and learn more about it. And then right beyond — there's usually a little chain there — right beyond, they would see the kids being tutored. This is a field trip going on. And so they would be shopping, and they might be more likely to buy some lard, or millet for their parrot, or, you know, a hook, or hook protector for nighttime, all of these things we sell. So the store actually did really well. But it brought in so many people — teachers, donors, volunteers, everybody — because it was street level. It was open to the public. It wasn't a non-profit buried, you know, on the 30th floor of some building downtown. It was right in the neighborhood that it was serving, and it was open all the time to the public. So, it became this sort of weird, happy accident.So all the people I used to know in Brooklyn, they said, "Well, why don't we have a place like that here?" And a lot of them had been former educators or would-be educators, so they combined with a lot of local designers, local writers, and they just took the idea independently and they did their own thing. They didn't want to sell pirate supplies. They didn't think that that was going to work there. So, knowing the crime-fighting community in New York, they opened the Brooklyn Superhero Supply Company. This is Sam Potts' great design that did this. And this was to make it look sort of like one of those keysmith's shops that has to have every service they've ever offered, you know, all over there. So they opened this place. Inside, it's like a Costco for superheroes — all the supplies in kind of basic form. These are all handmade. These are all sort of repurposed other products, or whatever. All the packaging is done by Sam Potts.So then you have the villain containment unit, where kids put their parents. You have the office. This is a little vault — you have to put your product in there, it goes up an electric lift and then the guy behind the counter tells you that you have to recite the vow of heroism, which you do, if you want to buy anything. And it limits, really, their sales. Personally, I think it's a problem. Because they have to do it hand on heart and everything. These are some of the products. These are all handmade. This is a secret identity kit. If you want to take on the identity of Sharon Boone, one American female marketing executive from Hoboken, New Jersey. It's a full dossier on everything you would need to know about Sharon Boone. So, this is the capery where you get fitted for your cape, and then you walk up these three steel-graded steps and then we turn on three hydraulic fans from every side and then you can see the cape in action. There's nothing worse than, you know, getting up there and the cape is bunching up or something like that. So then, the secret door — this is one of the shelves you don't see when you walk in, but it slowly opens. You can see it there in the middle next to all the grappling hooks. It opens and then this is the tutoring center in the back. (Applause) So you can see the full effect!But this is — I just want to emphasize — locally funded, locally built. All the designers, all of the builders, everybody was local, all the time was pro-bono. I just came and visited and said, "Yes, you guys are doing great," or whatever. That was it. You can see the time in all five boroughs of New York in the back. (Laughter) (Applause) So this is the space during tutoring hours. It's very busy. Same principles: one-on-one attention, complete devotion to the students' work and a boundless optimism and sort of a possibility of creativity and ideas. And this switch is flicked in their heads when they walk through those 18 feet of this bizarre store, right? So it's school, but it's not school. It's clearly not school, even though they're working shoulder-to-shoulder on tables, pencils and papers, whatever.This is one of the students, Khaled Hamdan. You can read this quote. Addicted to video games and TV. Couldn't concentrate at home. Came in. Got this concentrated attention. And he couldn't escape it. So, soon enough, he was writing. He would finish his homework early — got really addicted to finishing his homework early. It's an addictive thing to sort of be done with it, and to have it checked, and to know he's going to achieve the next thing and be prepared for school the next day. So he got hooked on that, and then he started doing other things. He's now been published in five books. He co-wrote a mockumentary about failed superheroes called "Super-Has-Beens." He wrote a series on "Penguin Balboa," which is a fighting — a boxing — penguin. And then he read aloud just a few weeks ago to 500 people at Symphony Space, at a benefit for 826 New York. So he's there every day. He's evangelical about it. He brings his cousins in now. There's four family members that come in every day.So, I'll go through really quickly. This is L.A., The Echo Park Time Travel Mart: "Whenever You Are, We're Already Then." (Laughter) This is sort of a 7-Eleven for time travelers. So you see everything: it's exactly as a 7-Eleven would be. Leeches. Mammoth chunks. They even have their own Slurpee machine: "Out of Order. Come Back Yesterday." (Laughter) (Applause)Anyway. So I'm going to jump ahead. These are spaces that are only affiliated with us, doing this same thing: Word St. in Pittsfield, Massachusetts; Ink Spot in Cincinnati; Youth Speaks, San Francisco, California, which inspired us; Studio St. Louis in St. Louis; Austin Bat Cave in Austin; Fighting Words in Dublin, Ireland, started by Roddy Doyle, this will be open in April. Now I'm going to the TED Wish — is that okay?All right, I've got a minute. So, the TED Wish: I wish that you — you personally and every creative individual and organization you know — will find a way to directly engage with a public school in your area and that you'll then tell the story of how you got involved, so that within a year we have a thousand examples — a thousand! — of transformative partnerships. Profound leaps forward! And these can be things that maybe you're already doing. I know that so many people in this room are already doing really interesting things. I know that for a fact. So, tell us these stories and inspire others on the website.We created a website. I'm going to switch to "we," and not "I," hope: We hope that the attendees of this conference will usher in a new era of participation in our public schools. We hope that you will take the lead in partnering your innovative spirit and expertise with that of innovative educators in your community. Always let the teachers lead the way. They will tell you how to be useful. I hope that you'll step in and help out. There are a million ways. You can walk up to your local school and consult with the teachers. They'll always tell you how to help. So, this is with Hot Studio in San Francisco, they did this phenomenal job. This website is already up, it's already got a bunch of stories, a lot of ideas. It's called "Once Upon a School," which is a great title, I think. This site will document every story, every project that comes out of this conference and around the world. So you go to the website, you see a bunch of ideas you can be inspired by and then you add your own projects once you get started. Hot Studio did a great job in a very tight deadline. So, visit the site. If you have any questions, you can ask this guy, who's our director of national programs. He'll be on the phone. You email him, he'll answer any question you possibly want. And he'll get you inspired and get you going and guide you through the process so that you can affect change.And it can be fun! That's the point of this talk — it needn't be sterile. It needn't be bureaucratically untenable. You can do and use the skills that you have. The schools need you. The teachers need you. Students and parents need you. They need your actual person: your physical personhood and your open minds and open ears and boundless compassion, sitting next to them, listening and nodding and asking questions for hours at a time. Some of these kids just don't plain know how good they are: how smart and how much they have to say. You can tell them. You can shine that light on them, one human interaction at a time. So we hope you'll join us. Thank you so much.
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:16.958
Thank you so much everyone from TED, and Chris and Amy in particular.

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:18.958
I cannot believe I'm here.

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:20.958
I have not slept in weeks.

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:23.958
Neil and I were sitting there comparing how little we've slept

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:26.958
in anticipation for this. I've never been so nervous --

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:29.958
and I do this when I'm nervous, I just realized. (Laughter)

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:34.958
So, I'm going to talk about sort of what we did at this organization

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:36.958
called 826 Valencia, and then I'm going to talk

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:39.958
about how we all might join in and do similar things.

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:43.958
Back in about 2000, I was living in Brooklyn,

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:46.958
I was trying to finish my first book,

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:48.958
I was wandering around dazed every day

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:50.958
because I wrote from 12 a.m. to 5 a.m.

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:53.958
So I would walk around in a daze during the day.

00:00:53.958 --> 00:01:01.958
I had no mental acuity to speak of during the day, but I had flexible hours.

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:04.958
In the Brooklyn neighborhood that I lived in, Park Slope,

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:06.958
there are a lot of writers --

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:08.958
it's like a very high per capita ratio

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:10.958
of writers to normal people.

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:15.958
Meanwhile, I had grown up around a lot of teachers.

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:17.958
My mom was a teacher, my sister became a teacher

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:21.958
and after college so many of my friends went into teaching.

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:24.958
And so I was always hearing them talk about their lives

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:26.958
and how inspiring they were,

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:28.958
and they were really sort of the most hard-working

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:30.958
and constantly inspiring people I knew.

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:33.958
But I knew so many of the things they were up against,

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:36.958
so many of the struggles they were dealing with.

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:39.958
And one of them was that so many of my friends

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:42.958
that were teaching in city schools were having trouble

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:45.958
with their students keeping up at grade level,

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:48.958
in their reading and writing in particular.

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:50.958
Now, so many of these students had come from households

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:52.958
where English isn't spoken in the home,

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:56.958
where a lot of them have different special needs,

00:01:56.958 --> 00:02:00.958
learning disabilities. And of course they're working in schools

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:03.958
which sometimes and very often are under-funded.

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:05.958
And so they would talk to me about this and say,

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:07.958
"You know, what we really need is just more people,

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:10.958
more bodies, more one-on-one attention,

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:13.958
more hours, more expertise from people

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:18.958
that have skills in English and can work with these students one-on-one."

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:21.958
Now, I would say, "Well, why don't you just work with them one-on-one?"

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:25.958
And they would say, "Well, we have five classes of 30 to 40 students each.

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:29.958
This can lead up to 150, 180, 200 students a day.

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:32.958
How can we possibly give each student

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:36.958
even one hour a week of one-on-one attention?"

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:40.958
You'd have to greatly multiply the workweek and clone the teachers.

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:43.958
And so we started talking about this.

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:45.958
And at the same time,

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:47.958
I thought about this massive group of people I knew:

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:51.958
writers, editors, journalists, graduate students,

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:53.958
assistant professors, you name it.

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:56.958
All these people that had sort of flexible daily hours

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:58.958
and an interest in the English word --

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:03.958
I hope to have an interest in the English language,

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:06.958
but I'm not speaking it well right now. (Laughter)

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:10.958
I'm trying. That clock has got me.

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:15.958
But everyone that I knew had an interest in the primacy of the written word

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:19.958
in terms of nurturing a democracy, nurturing an enlightened life.

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:22.958
And so they had, you know, their time

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:25.958
and their interest, but at the same time

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:29.958
there wasn't a conduit that I knew of in my community

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:31.958
to bring these two communities together.

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:35.958
So when I moved back to San Francisco, we rented this building.

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:39.958
And the idea was to put McSweeney's --

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:41.958
McSweeney's Quarterly, that we published twice or three times a year,

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:43.958
and a few other magazines --

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:46.958
we were going to move it into an office for the first time.

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:48.958
It used to be in my kitchen in Brooklyn.

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:50.958
We were going to move it into an office,

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:53.958
and we were going to actually share space with a tutoring center.

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:56.958
So we thought, "We'll have all these writers and editors and everybody --

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:59.958
sort of a writing community -- coming into the office every day anyway,

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:01.958
why don't we just open up

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:03.958
the front of the building for students to come in there after school,

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:05.958
get extra help on their written homework,

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:09.958
so you have basically no border between these two communities?"

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:13.958
So the idea was that we would be

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:15.958
working on whatever we're working on,

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
at 2:30 p.m. the students flow in and you put down what you're doing,

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:20.958
or you trade, or you work a little bit later or whatever it is.

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:22.958
You give those hours in the afternoon

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:24.958
to the students in the neighborhood.

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:26.958
So, we had this place, we rented it,

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:28.958
the landlord was all for it. We did this mural,

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:32.958
that's a Chris Ware mural, that basically explains the entire history

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
of the printed word, in mural form -- it takes a long time

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:38.958
to digest and you have to stand in the middle of the road.

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
So we rented this space.

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
And everything was great except the landlord said,

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
"Well, the space is zoned for retail; you have to come up with something.

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:47.958
You've gotta sell something.

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:49.958
You can't just have a tutoring center."

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
So we thought, "Ha ha! Really!"

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:54.958
And we couldn't think of anything necessarily to sell,

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
but we did all the necessary research.

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:59.958
It used to be a weight room, so there were rubber floors below,

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:02.958
acoustic tile ceilings and fluorescent lights.

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:05.958
We took all that down, and we found beautiful wooden floors,

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:09.958
whitewashed beams and it had the look --

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
while we were renovating this place, somebody said,

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:13.958
"You know, it really kind of looks like the hull of a ship."

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:17.958
And we looked around and somebody else said,

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:20.958
"Well, you should sell supplies to the working buccaneer." (Laughter)

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:25.958
And so this is what we did. So it made everybody laugh,

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:28.958
and we said, "There's a point to that.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:33.958
Let's sell pirate supplies." This is the pirate supply store.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:37.958
You see, this is sort of a sketch I did on a napkin.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:40.958
A great carpenter built all this stuff and you see,

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:43.958
we made it look sort of pirate supply-like.

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.958
Here you see planks sold by the foot

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:49.958
and we have supplies to combat scurvy.

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:54.958
We have the peg legs there, that are all handmade and fitted to you.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
Up at the top, you see the eyepatch display,

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:00.958
which is the black column there for everyday use

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:04.958
for your eyepatch, and then you have the pastel

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958
and other colors for stepping out at night --

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:10.958
special occasions, bar mitzvahs and whatever.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:16.958
So we opened this place. And this is a vat

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
that we fill with treasures that students dig in.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:22.958
This is replacement eyes in case you lose one.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:25.958
These are some signs that we have all over the place:

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:28.958
"Practical Joking with Pirates."

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
While you're reading the sign, we pull a rope behind the counter

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:35.958
and eight mop heads drop on your head.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:39.958
That was just my one thing -- I said we had to have something that drops on people's heads.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:44.958
It became mop heads. And this is the fish theater,

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:47.958
which is just a saltwater tank with three seats,

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:53.958
and then right behind it we set up this space,

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.958
which was the tutoring center.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
So right there is the tutoring center,

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
and then behind the curtain were the McSweeney's offices,

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:02.958
where all of us would be working on the magazine and book editing and things like that.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
The kids would come in --

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
or we thought they would come in. I should back up.

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:11.958
We set the place up, we opened up, we spent months and months

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:13.958
renovating this place.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:16.958
We had tables, chairs, computers, everything.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:20.958
I went to a dot-com auction at a Holiday Inn in Palo Alto

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:25.958
and I bought 11 G4s with a stroke of a paddle.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:32.958
Anyway, we bought 'em, we set everything up and then we waited.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:34.958
It was started with about 12 of my friends,

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:37.958
people that I had known for years that were writers in the neighborhood.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:41.958
And we sat. And at 2:30 p.m. we put a sandwich board out on the front sidewalk

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
and it just said, "Free Tutoring for Your English-Related

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
and Writing-Related Needs -- Just Come In, It's All Free."

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
And we thought, "Oh, they're going to storm the gates,

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.958
they're gonna love it." And they didn't.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
And so we waited, we sat at the tables, we waited and waited.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
And everybody was becoming very discouraged

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:00.958
because it was weeks and weeks that we waited, really, where nobody came in.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:06.958
And then somebody alerted us to the fact

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
that maybe there was a trust gap,

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:15.958
because we were operating behind a pirate supply store. (Laughter)

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
We never put it together, you know?

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:28.958
And so then, around that time, I persuaded a woman named Nineveh Caligari,

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
a longtime San Francisco educator --

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:32.958
she was teaching in Mexico City,

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
she had all the experience necessary,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
knew everything about education,

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.958
was connected with all the teachers and community members in the neighborhood --

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
I convinced her to move up from Mexico City where she was teaching.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
She took over as executive director.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:45.958
Immediately, she made the inroads with the teachers

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
and the parents and the students and everything,

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
and so suddenly it was actually full every day.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
And what we were trying to offer every day

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
was one-on-one attention.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
The goal was to have a one-to-one ratio with every one of these students.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
You know, it's been proven

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
that 35 to 40 hours a year with one-on-one attention,

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
a student can get one grade level higher.

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:06.958
And so most of these students, English is not spoken in the home.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
They come there, many times their parents --

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
you can't see it, but there's a church pew

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
that I bought in a Berkeley auction right there --

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
the parents will sometimes watch while their kids are being tutored.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
So that was the basis of it,

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
was one-on-one attention.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
And we found ourselves full every day with kids.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:26.958
If you're on Valencia Street within those few blocks at around 2 p.m.,

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.958
2:30 p.m., you will get run over, often,

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
by the kids and their big backpacks, or whatever, actually running to this space,

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:36.958
which is very strange, because it's school, in a way.

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:40.958
But there was something psychological happening there

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
that was just a little bit different.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
And the other thing was, there was no stigma.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
Kids weren't going into the "Center-for-Kids-That-Need-More-Help,"

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:50.958
or something like that. It was 826 Valencia.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:53.958
First of all, it was a pirate supply store, which is insane.

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:57.958
And then secondly, there's a publishing company in the back.

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
And so our interns were actually working

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
at the same tables very often,

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
and shoulder-to-shoulder, computer-next-to-computer with the students.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
And so it became a tutoring center --

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:08.958
publishing center, is what we called it --

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:10.958
and a writing center.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:12.958
They go in, and they might be working with a high school student

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:15.958
actually working on a novel -- because we had very gifted kids, too.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
So there's no stigma.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
They're all working next to each other. It's all a creative endeavor.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
They're seeing adults. They're modeling their behavior.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
These adults, they're working in their field.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:27.958
They can lean over, ask a question of one of these adults

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
and it all sort of feeds on each other.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
There's a lot of cross-pollination. The only problem,

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.958
especially for the adults working at McSweeney's

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:38.958
who hadn't necessarily bought into all of this when they signed up,

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:41.958
was that there was just the one bathroom. (Laughter)

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
With like 60 kids a day, this is a problem.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
But you know, there's something about the kids finishing their homework

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
in a given day, working one-on-one, getting all this attention --

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
they go home, they're finished. They don't stall.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
They don't do their homework in front of the TV.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
They're allowed to go home at 5:30 p.m., enjoy their family,

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:01.958
enjoy other hobbies, get outside, play.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
And that makes a happy family.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:06.958
A bunch of happy families in a neighborhood is a happy community.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:09.958
A bunch of happy communities tied together is a happy city and a happy world.

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
So the key to it all is homework! (Laughter) (Applause)

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:18.958
There you have it, you know -- one-on-one attention.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
So we started off with about 12 volunteers,

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:22.958
and then we had about 50,

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
and then a couple hundred.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
And we now have 1,400 volunteers on our roster.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
And we make it incredibly easy to volunteer.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
The key thing is, even if you only have a couple of hours a month,

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
those two hours shoulder-to-shoulder,

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
next to one student, concentrated attention,

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
shining this beam of light on their work,

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
on their thoughts and their self-expression,

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
is going to be absolutely transformative,

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:47.958
because so many of the students have not had that ever before.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:51.958
So we said, "Even if you have two hours one Sunday every six months,

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
it doesn't matter. That's going to be enough."

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
So that's partly why the tutor corps grew so fast.

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:57.958
Then we said, "Well, what are we

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
going to do with the space during the day,

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
because it has to be used before 2:30 p.m.?"

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
So we started bringing in classes during the day.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:06.958
So every day, there's a field trip where they together create a book --

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
you can see it being typed up above.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:13.958
This is one of the classes getting way too excited about writing.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
You just point a camera at a class,

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
and it always looks like this.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:20.958
So this is one of the books that they do.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
Notice the title of the book,

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:26.958
"The Book That Was Never Checked Out: Titanic."

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:33.958
And the first line of that book is, "Once there was a book named Cindy

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:36.958
that was about the Titanic."

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:39.958
So, meanwhile, there's an adult in the back typing this up,

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:42.958
taking it completely seriously, which blows their mind.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:45.958
So then we still had more tutors to use.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:49.958
This is a shot of just some of the tutors during one of the events.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:51.958
The teachers that we work with --

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:54.958
and everything is different to teachers -- they tell us what to do.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
We went in there thinking,

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:57.958
"We're ultimately, completely malleable. You're going to tell us.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
The neighborhood's going to tell us, the parents are going to tell us.

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
The teachers are going to tell us how we're most useful."

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.958
So then they said, "Why don't you come into the schools?

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.958
Because what about the students that wouldn't come to you,

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
necessarily, who don't have really active parents that are bringing them in,

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
or aren't close enough?" So then we started saying,

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:15.958
"Well, we've got 1,400 people on our tutor roster.

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:17.958
Let's just put out the word." A teacher will say,

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
"I need 12 tutors for the next five Sundays.

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:23.958
We're working on our college essays. Send them in."

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
So we put that out on the wire: 1,400 tutors.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:28.958
Whoever can make it signs up. They go in about a half an hour before the class.

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:30.958
The teacher tells them what to do,

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
how to do it, what their training is, what their project is so far.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:34.958
They work under the teacher's guide,

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
and it's all in one big room.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:38.958
And that's actually the brunt of what we do is,

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:40.958
people going straight from their workplace, straight from home,

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:42.958
straight into the classroom and

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
working directly with the students.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:48.958
So then we're able to work with thousands and thousands of more students.

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
Then another school said, "Well, what if we

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:53.958
just give you a classroom and you can staff it all day?"

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:56.958
So this is the Everett Middle School Writers' Room,

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
where we decorated it in buccaneer style.

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
It's right off the library. And there we serve

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
all 529 kids in this middle school.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
This is their newspaper, the "Straight-Up News,"

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:08.958
that has an ongoing column from Mayor Gavin Newsom

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:11.958
in both languages -- English and Spanish.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:16.958
So then one day Isabel Allende wrote to us and said,

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:19.958
"Hey, why don't you assign a book with high school students?

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:23.958
I want them to write about how to achieve peace in a violent world."

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
And so we went into Thurgood Marshall High School,

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.958
which is a school that we had worked with on some other things,

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:31.958
and we gave that assignment to the students.

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:34.958
And we said, "Isabel Allende is going to read all your essays at the end.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.958
She's going to publish them in a book.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:38.958
She's going to sponsor the printing of this book in paperback form.

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:40.958
It's going to be available in all the bookstores in the Bay Area

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:43.958
and throughout the world, on Amazon and you name it."

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
So these kids worked harder

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:47.958
than they've ever worked on anything in their lives,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
because there was that outside audience,

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:52.958
there was Isabel Allende on the other end.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:56.958
I think we had about 170 tutors that worked on this book with them

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
and so this worked out incredibly well.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
We had a big party at the end.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.958
This is a book that you can find anywhere. So that led to a series of these.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
You can see Amy Tan sponsored the next one,

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
"I Might Get Somewhere."

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:10.958
And this became an ongoing thing. More and more books.

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:13.958
Now we're sort of addicted to the book thing.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:16.958
The kids will work harder than they've ever worked in their life

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:18.958
if they know it's going to be permanent,

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
know it's going to be on a shelf,

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.958
know that nobody can diminish what they've thought and said,

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
that we've honored their words, honored their thoughts

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:27.958
with hundreds of hours of five drafts, six drafts --

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:29.958
all this attention that we give to their thoughts.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:34.958
And once they achieve that level, once they've written at that level,

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
they can never go back.

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
It's absolutely transformative.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
And so then they're all sold in the store. This is near the planks.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
We sell all the student books.

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
Where else would you put them, right?

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
So we sell 'em, and then something weird had been happening

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
with the stores. The store, actually --

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:56.958
even though we started out as just a gag -- the store actually made money.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.958
So it was paying the rent.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:02.958
And maybe this is just a San Francisco thing --

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:04.958
I don't know, I don't want to judge.

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:06.958
But people would come in --

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
and this was before the pirate movies and everything!

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:11.958
It was making a lot of money. Not a lot of money,

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:13.958
but it was paying the rent, paying a full-time staff member there.

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:15.958
There's the ocean maps you can see on the left.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:19.958
And it became a gateway to the community.

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:21.958
People would come in and say, "What the --?

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:25.958
What is this?" I don't want to swear on the web. (Laughter)

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:30.958
Is that a rule? I don't know.

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:33.958
They would say, "What is this?"

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:37.958
And people would come in and learn more about it.

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:40.958
And then right beyond -- there's usually a little chain there --

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:42.958
right beyond, they would see the kids being tutored.

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:44.958
This is a field trip going on. And so they would be shopping,

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:46.958
and they might be more likely to buy some lard,

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:49.958
or millet for their parrot, or, you know, a hook,

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:52.958
or hook protector for nighttime, all of these things we sell.

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:55.958
So the store actually did really well.

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:57.958
But it brought in so many people --

00:16:57.958 --> 00:16:58.958
teachers, donors, volunteers, everybody --

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:00.958
because it was street level. It was open to the public.

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:02.958
It wasn't a non-profit buried, you know, on the 30th floor

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:05.958
of some building downtown. It was right in the neighborhood

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:08.958
that it was serving, and it was open all the time to the public.

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:11.958
So, it became this sort of weird, happy accident.

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:13.958
So all the people I used to know in Brooklyn, they said,

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:15.958
"Well, why don't we have a place like that here?"

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:17.958
And a lot of them had been former educators

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:19.958
or would-be educators, so they combined

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:21.958
with a lot of local designers, local writers,

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:23.958
and they just took the idea independently

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:25.958
and they did their own thing.

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:27.958
They didn't want to sell pirate supplies.

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:30.958
They didn't think that that was going to work there.

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:33.958
So, knowing the crime-fighting community in New York,

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:36.958
they opened the Brooklyn Superhero Supply Company.

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:39.958
This is Sam Potts' great design that did this.

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:41.958
And this was to make it look sort of like one of those

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:43.958
keysmith's shops that has to have every service

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:46.958
they've ever offered, you know, all over there.

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:48.958
So they opened this place. Inside, it's like a Costco

00:17:48.958 --> 00:17:52.958
for superheroes -- all the supplies in kind of basic form.

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:54.958
These are all handmade.

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:57.958
These are all sort of repurposed other products, or whatever.

00:17:57.958 --> 00:17:59.958
All the packaging is done by Sam Potts.

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:02.958
So then you have the villain containment unit,

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:04.958
where kids put their parents. You have the office.

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:08.958
This is a little vault -- you have to put your product in there,

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:10.958
it goes up an electric lift

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:12.958
and then the guy behind the counter tells you

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:15.958
that you have to recite the vow of heroism,

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:19.958
which you do, if you want to buy anything. And it limits, really, their sales.

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:21.958
Personally, I think it's a problem.

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:23.958
Because they have to do it hand on heart and everything.

00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:29.958
These are some of the products. These are all handmade.

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:31.958
This is a secret identity kit.

00:18:31.958 --> 00:18:33.958
If you want to take on the identity of Sharon Boone,

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:35.958
one American female marketing executive

00:18:35.958 --> 00:18:37.958
from Hoboken, New Jersey. It's a full dossier

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:39.958
on everything you would need to know about Sharon Boone.

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:44.958
So, this is the capery where you get fitted for your cape,

00:18:44.958 --> 00:18:46.958
and then you walk up these three steel-graded steps

00:18:46.958 --> 00:18:49.958
and then we turn on three hydraulic fans

00:18:49.958 --> 00:18:52.958
from every side and then you can see the cape in action.

00:18:52.958 --> 00:18:54.958
There's nothing worse than, you know,

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:58.958
getting up there and the cape is bunching up or something like that.

00:18:59.958 --> 00:19:02.958
So then, the secret door --

00:19:02.958 --> 00:19:04.958
this is one of the shelves you don't see

00:19:04.958 --> 00:19:06.958
when you walk in, but it slowly opens.

00:19:06.958 --> 00:19:08.958
You can see it there in the middle next to all the grappling hooks.

00:19:08.958 --> 00:19:11.958
It opens and then this is the tutoring center in the back. (Applause)

00:19:11.958 --> 00:19:12.958
So you can see the full effect!

00:19:17.958 --> 00:19:20.958
But this is -- I just want to emphasize --

00:19:20.958 --> 00:19:22.958
locally funded, locally built.

00:19:22.958 --> 00:19:24.958
All the designers, all of the builders,

00:19:24.958 --> 00:19:26.958
everybody was local, all the time was pro-bono.

00:19:26.958 --> 00:19:28.958
I just came and visited and said, "Yes, you guys are doing great,"

00:19:28.958 --> 00:19:30.958
or whatever. That was it. You can see the time

00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:32.958
in all five boroughs of New York in the back. (Laughter) (Applause)

00:19:36.958 --> 00:19:39.958
So this is the space during tutoring hours.

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:42.958
It's very busy. Same principles: one-on-one attention,

00:19:42.958 --> 00:19:44.958
complete devotion to the students' work

00:19:44.958 --> 00:19:47.958
and a boundless optimism and sort of a possibility

00:19:47.958 --> 00:19:49.958
of creativity and ideas.

00:19:49.958 --> 00:19:51.958
And this switch is flicked in their heads

00:19:51.958 --> 00:19:54.958
when they walk through those 18 feet of this bizarre store, right?

00:19:54.958 --> 00:19:56.958
So it's school, but it's not school.

00:19:56.958 --> 00:19:58.958
It's clearly not school, even though

00:19:58.958 --> 00:20:00.958
they're working shoulder-to-shoulder on tables, pencils and papers, whatever.

00:20:00.958 --> 00:20:02.958
This is one of the students, Khaled Hamdan.

00:20:02.958 --> 00:20:04.958
You can read this quote.

00:20:04.958 --> 00:20:06.958
Addicted to video games and TV. Couldn't concentrate at home.

00:20:06.958 --> 00:20:09.958
Came in. Got this concentrated attention.

00:20:09.958 --> 00:20:11.958
And he couldn't escape it.

00:20:11.958 --> 00:20:15.958
So, soon enough, he was writing. He would finish his homework early --

00:20:15.958 --> 00:20:17.958
got really addicted to finishing his homework early.

00:20:17.958 --> 00:20:20.958
It's an addictive thing to sort of be done with it,

00:20:20.958 --> 00:20:22.958
and to have it checked, and to know he's going to achieve

00:20:22.958 --> 00:20:24.958
the next thing and be prepared for school the next day.

00:20:24.958 --> 00:20:26.958
So he got hooked on that, and then he started doing other things.

00:20:26.958 --> 00:20:28.958
He's now been published in five books.

00:20:28.958 --> 00:20:30.958
He co-wrote a mockumentary about failed superheroes

00:20:30.958 --> 00:20:34.958
called "Super-Has-Beens."

00:20:34.958 --> 00:20:37.958
He wrote a series on "Penguin Balboa,"

00:20:37.958 --> 00:20:40.958
which is a fighting -- a boxing -- penguin.

00:20:40.958 --> 00:20:45.958
And then he read aloud just a few weeks ago to 500 people at Symphony Space,

00:20:45.958 --> 00:20:48.958
at a benefit for 826 New York. So he's there every day.

00:20:48.958 --> 00:20:51.958
He's evangelical about it. He brings his cousins in now.

00:20:51.958 --> 00:20:54.958
There's four family members that come in every day.

00:20:54.958 --> 00:20:56.958
So, I'll go through really quickly.

00:20:56.958 --> 00:20:59.958
This is L.A., The Echo Park Time Travel Mart:

00:20:59.958 --> 00:21:01.958
"Whenever You Are, We're Already Then." (Laughter)

00:21:04.958 --> 00:21:07.958
This is sort of a 7-Eleven for time travelers.

00:21:07.958 --> 00:21:10.958
So you see everything: it's exactly as a 7-Eleven would be.

00:21:10.958 --> 00:21:15.958
Leeches. Mammoth chunks. They even have their own Slurpee machine:

00:21:15.958 --> 00:21:18.958
"Out of Order. Come Back Yesterday." (Laughter) (Applause)

00:21:25.958 --> 00:21:28.958
Anyway. So I'm going to jump ahead.

00:21:28.958 --> 00:21:31.958
These are spaces that are only affiliated with us,

00:21:31.958 --> 00:21:34.958
doing this same thing: Word St. in Pittsfield, Massachusetts;

00:21:34.958 --> 00:21:36.958
Ink Spot in Cincinnati; Youth Speaks, San Francisco, California,

00:21:36.958 --> 00:21:39.958
which inspired us; Studio St. Louis in St. Louis;

00:21:39.958 --> 00:21:42.958
Austin Bat Cave in Austin;

00:21:42.958 --> 00:21:45.958
Fighting Words in Dublin, Ireland, started by Roddy Doyle,

00:21:45.958 --> 00:21:47.958
this will be open in April.

00:21:47.958 --> 00:21:51.958
Now I'm going to the TED Wish -- is that okay?

00:21:51.958 --> 00:21:54.958
All right, I've got a minute. So, the TED Wish:

00:21:54.958 --> 00:21:57.958
I wish that you -- you personally and every creative individual

00:21:57.958 --> 00:21:59.958
and organization you know -- will find a way

00:21:59.958 --> 00:22:02.958
to directly engage with a public school in your area

00:22:02.958 --> 00:22:05.958
and that you'll then tell the story of how you got involved,

00:22:05.958 --> 00:22:07.958
so that within a year we have a thousand examples --

00:22:07.958 --> 00:22:09.958
a thousand! -- of transformative partnerships.

00:22:09.958 --> 00:22:11.958
Profound leaps forward!

00:22:11.958 --> 00:22:13.958
And these can be things that maybe you're already doing.

00:22:13.958 --> 00:22:15.958
I know that so many people in this room

00:22:15.958 --> 00:22:17.958
are already doing really interesting things.

00:22:17.958 --> 00:22:21.958
I know that for a fact. So, tell us these stories and inspire others on the website.

00:22:21.958 --> 00:22:23.958
We created a website.

00:22:23.958 --> 00:22:26.958
I'm going to switch to "we," and not "I," hope:

00:22:26.958 --> 00:22:29.958
We hope that the attendees of this conference will usher in

00:22:29.958 --> 00:22:31.958
a new era of participation in our public schools.

00:22:31.958 --> 00:22:33.958
We hope that you will take the lead

00:22:33.958 --> 00:22:35.958
in partnering your innovative spirit and expertise

00:22:35.958 --> 00:22:38.958
with that of innovative educators in your community.

00:22:38.958 --> 00:22:40.958
Always let the teachers lead the way.

00:22:40.958 --> 00:22:44.958
They will tell you how to be useful. I hope that you'll step in and help out.

00:22:44.958 --> 00:22:46.958
There are a million ways.

00:22:46.958 --> 00:22:47.958
You can walk up to your local school

00:22:47.958 --> 00:22:50.958
and consult with the teachers. They'll always tell you how to help.

00:22:50.958 --> 00:22:53.958
So, this is with Hot Studio in San Francisco,

00:22:53.958 --> 00:22:54.958
they did this phenomenal job.

00:22:54.958 --> 00:22:57.958
This website is already up, it's already got a bunch of stories,

00:22:57.958 --> 00:23:00.958
a lot of ideas. It's called "Once Upon a School,"

00:23:00.958 --> 00:23:01.958
which is a great title, I think.

00:23:01.958 --> 00:23:03.958
This site will document every story, every project that comes

00:23:03.958 --> 00:23:07.958
out of this conference and around the world. So you go to the website,

00:23:07.958 --> 00:23:09.958
you see a bunch of ideas you can be inspired by

00:23:09.958 --> 00:23:11.958
and then you add your own projects once you get started.

00:23:12.958 --> 00:23:16.958
Hot Studio did a great job in a very tight deadline. So, visit the site.

00:23:16.958 --> 00:23:19.958
If you have any questions, you can ask this guy,

00:23:19.958 --> 00:23:22.958
who's our director of national programs. He'll be on the phone.

00:23:22.958 --> 00:23:24.958
You email him, he'll answer any question you possibly want.

00:23:24.958 --> 00:23:27.958
And he'll get you inspired and get you going

00:23:27.958 --> 00:23:30.958
and guide you through the process so that you can affect change.

00:23:30.958 --> 00:23:32.958
And it can be fun! That's the point of this talk --

00:23:32.958 --> 00:23:39.958
it needn't be sterile. It needn't be bureaucratically untenable.

00:23:39.958 --> 00:23:43.958
You can do and use the skills that you have.

00:23:43.958 --> 00:23:45.958
The schools need you. The teachers need you.

00:23:45.958 --> 00:23:48.958
Students and parents need you. They need your actual person:

00:23:48.958 --> 00:23:50.958
your physical personhood and your open minds

00:23:50.958 --> 00:23:53.958
and open ears and boundless compassion,

00:23:53.958 --> 00:23:55.958
sitting next to them, listening and nodding

00:23:55.958 --> 00:23:58.958
and asking questions for hours at a time.

00:23:58.958 --> 00:24:02.958
Some of these kids just don't plain know how good they are:

00:24:02.958 --> 00:24:05.958
how smart and how much they have to say.

00:24:05.958 --> 00:24:08.958
You can tell them. You can shine that light on them,

00:24:08.958 --> 00:24:12.958
one human interaction at a time. So we hope you'll join us.

00:24:12.958 --> 00:24:14.958
Thank you so much.

title: My wish: The Charter for Compassion
transcript: Well, this is such an honor. And it's wonderful to be in the presence of an organization that is really making a difference in the world. And I'm intensely grateful for the opportunity to speak to you today.And I'm also rather surprised, because when I look back on my life the last thing I ever wanted to do was write, or be in any way involved in religion. After I left my convent, I'd finished with religion, frankly. I thought that was it. And for 13 years I kept clear of it. I wanted to be an English literature professor. And I certainly didn't even want to be a writer, particularly. But then I suffered a series of career catastrophes, one after the other, and finally found myself in television. (Laughter) I said that to Bill Moyers, and he said, "Oh, we take anybody." (Laughter)And I was doing some rather controversial religious programs. This went down very well in the U.K., where religion is extremely unpopular. And so, for once, for the only time in my life, I was finally in the mainstream. But I got sent to Jerusalem to make a film about early Christianity. And there, for the first time, I encountered the other religious traditions: Judaism and Islam, the sister religions of Christianity. And while I found I knew nothing about these faiths at all — despite my own intensely religious background, I'd seen Judaism only as a kind of prelude to Christianity, and I knew nothing about Islam at all.But in that city, that tortured city, where you see the three faiths jostling so uneasily together, you also become aware of the profound connection between them. And it has been the study of other religious traditions that brought me back to a sense of what religion can be, and actually enabled me to look at my own faith in a different light.And I found some astonishing things in the course of my study that had never occurred to me. Frankly, in the days when I thought I'd had it with religion, I just found the whole thing absolutely incredible. These doctrines seemed unproven, abstract. And to my astonishment, when I began seriously studying other traditions, I began to realize that belief — which we make such a fuss about today — is only a very recent religious enthusiasm that surfaced only in the West, in about the 17th century. The word "belief" itself originally meant to love, to prize, to hold dear. In the 17th century, it narrowed its focus, for reasons that I'm exploring in a book I'm writing at the moment, to include — to mean an intellectual assent to a set of propositions, a credo. "I believe:" it did not mean, "I accept certain creedal articles of faith." It meant: "I commit myself. I engage myself." Indeed, some of the world traditions think very little of religious orthodoxy. In the Quran, religious opinion — religious orthodoxy — is dismissed as "zanna:" self-indulgent guesswork about matters that nobody can be certain of one way or the other, but which makes people quarrelsome and stupidly sectarian. (Laughter)So if religion is not about believing things, what is it about? What I've found, across the board, is that religion is about behaving differently.
