Instead of deciding whether or not you believe in God, first you do something. You behave in a committed way, and then you begin to understand the truths of religion. And religious doctrines are meant to be summons to action; you only understand them when you put them into practice.Now, pride of place in this practice is given to compassion. And it is an arresting fact that right across the board, in every single one of the major world faiths, compassion — the ability to feel with the other in the way we've been thinking about this evening — is not only the test of any true religiosity, it is also what will bring us into the presence of what Jews, Christians and Muslims call "God" or the "Divine." It is compassion, says the Buddha, which brings you to Nirvana. Why? Because in compassion, when we feel with the other, we dethrone ourselves from the center of our world and we put another person there. And once we get rid of ego, then we're ready to see the Divine.And in particular, every single one of the major world traditions has highlighted — has said — and put at the core of their tradition what's become known as the Golden Rule. First propounded by Confucius five centuries before Christ: "Do not do to others what you would not like them to do to you." That, he said, was the central thread which ran through all his teaching and that his disciples should put into practice all day and every day. And it was — the Golden Rule would bring them to the transcendent value that he called "ren," human-heartedness, which was a transcendent experience in itself.And this is absolutely crucial to the monotheisms, too. There's a famous story about the great rabbi, Hillel, the older contemporary of Jesus. A pagan came to him and offered to convert to Judaism if the rabbi could recite the whole of Jewish teaching while he stood on one leg. Hillel stood on one leg and said, "That which is hateful to you, do not do to your neighbor. That is the Torah. The rest is commentary. Go and study it." (Laughter)And "go and study it" was what he meant. He said, "In your exegesis, you must make it clear that every single verse of the Torah is a commentary, a gloss upon the Golden Rule." The great Rabbi Meir said that any interpretation of Scripture which led to hatred and disdain, or contempt of other people — any people whatsoever — was illegitimate.Saint Augustine made exactly the same point. Scripture, he says, "teaches nothing but charity, and we must not leave an interpretation of Scripture until we have found a compassionate interpretation of it." And this struggle to find compassion in some of these rather rebarbative texts is a good dress rehearsal for doing the same in ordinary life. (Applause)But now look at our world. And we are living in a world that is — where religion has been hijacked. Where terrorists cite Quranic verses to justify their atrocities. Where instead of taking Jesus' words, "Love your enemies. Don't judge others," we have the spectacle of Christians endlessly judging other people, endlessly using Scripture as a way of arguing with other people, putting other people down. Throughout the ages, religion has been used to oppress others, and this is because of human ego, human greed. We have a talent as a species for messing up wonderful things.So the traditions also insisted — and this is an important point, I think — that you could not and must not confine your compassion to your own group: your own nation, your own co-religionists, your own fellow countrymen. You must have what one of the Chinese sages called "jian ai": concern for everybody. Love your enemies. Honor the stranger. We formed you, says the Quran, into tribes and nations so that you may know one another.And this, again — this universal outreach — is getting subdued in the strident use of religion — abuse of religion — for nefarious gains. Now, I've lost count of the number of taxi drivers who, when I say to them what I do for a living, inform me that religion has been the cause of all the major world wars in history. Wrong. The causes of our present woes are political.But, make no mistake about it, religion is a kind of fault line, and when a conflict gets ingrained in a region, religion can get sucked in and become part of the problem. Our modernity has been exceedingly violent. Between 1914 and 1945, 70 million people died in Europe alone as a result of armed conflict. And so many of our institutions, even football, which used to be a pleasant pastime, now causes riots where people even die. And it's not surprising that religion, too, has been affected by this violent ethos.There's also a great deal, I think, of religious illiteracy around. People seem to think, now equate religious faith with believing things. As though that — we call religious people often believers, as though that were the main thing that they do. And very often, secondary goals get pushed into the first place, in place of compassion and the Golden Rule. Because the Golden Rule is difficult. I sometimes — when I'm speaking to congregations about compassion, I sometimes see a mutinous expression crossing some of their faces because a lot of religious people prefer to be right, rather than compassionate. (Laughter)Now — but that's not the whole story. Since September the 11th, when my work on Islam suddenly propelled me into public life, in a way that I'd never imagined, I've been able to sort of go all over the world, and finding, everywhere I go, a yearning for change. I've just come back from Pakistan, where literally thousands of people came to my lectures, because they were yearning, first of all, to hear a friendly Western voice. And especially the young people were coming. And were asking me — the young people were saying, "What can we do? What can we do to change things?" And my hosts in Pakistan said, "Look, don't be too polite to us. Tell us where we're going wrong. Let's talk together about where religion is failing."Because it seems to me that with — our current situation is so serious at the moment that any ideology that doesn't promote a sense of global understanding and global appreciation of each other is failing the test of the time. And religion, with its wide following ... Here in the United States, people may be being religious in a different way, as a report has just shown — but they still want to be religious. It's only Western Europe that has retained its secularism, which is now beginning to look rather endearingly old-fashioned.But people want to be religious, and religion should be made to be a force for harmony in the world, which it can and should be — because of the Golden Rule. "Do not do to others what you would not have them do to you": an ethos that should now be applied globally. We should not treat other nations as we would not wish to be treated ourselves.And these — whatever our wretched beliefs — is a religious matter, it's a spiritual matter. It's a profound moral matter that engages and should engage us all. And as I say, there is a hunger for change out there. Here in the United States, I think you see it in this election campaign: a longing for change. And people in churches all over and mosques all over this continent after September the 11th, coming together locally to create networks of understanding. With the mosque, with the synagogue, saying, "We must start to speak to one another." I think it's time that we moved beyond the idea of toleration and move toward appreciation of the other.I'd — there's one story I'd just like to mention. This comes from "The Iliad." But it tells you what this spirituality should be. You know the story of "The Iliad," the 10-year war between Greece and Troy. In one incident, Achilles, the famous warrior of Greece, takes his troops out of the war, and the whole war effort suffers. And in the course of the ensuing muddle, his beloved friend, Patroclus, is killed — and killed in single combat by one of the Trojan princes, Hector. And Achilles goes mad with grief and rage and revenge, and he mutilates the body. He kills Hector, he mutilates his body and then he refuses to give the body back for burial to the family, which means that, in Greek ethos, Hector's soul will wander eternally, lost. And then one night, Priam, king of Troy, an old man, comes into the Greek camp incognito, makes his way to Achilles' tent to ask for the body of his son. And everybody is shocked when the old man takes off his head covering and shows himself. And Achilles looks at him and thinks of his father. And he starts to weep. And Priam looks at the man who has murdered so many of his sons, and he, too, starts to weep. And the sound of their weeping filled the house. The Greeks believed that weeping together created a bond between people. And then Achilles takes the body of Hector, he hands it very tenderly to the father, and the two men look at each other, and see each other as divine.That is the ethos found, too, in all the religions. It's what is meant by overcoming the horror that we feel when we are under threat of our enemies, and beginning to appreciate the other. It's of great importance that the word for "holy" in Hebrew, applied to God, is "Kadosh": separate, other. And it is often, perhaps, the very otherness of our enemies which can give us intimations of that utterly mysterious transcendence which is God.And now, here's my wish: I wish that you would help with the creation, launch and propagation of a Charter for Compassion, crafted by a group of inspirational thinkers from the three Abrahamic traditions of Judaism, Christianity and Islam, and based on the fundamental principle of the Golden Rule. We need to create a movement among all these people that I meet in my travels — you probably meet, too — who want to join up, in some way, and reclaim their faith, which they feel, as I say, has been hijacked. We need to empower people to remember the compassionate ethos, and to give guidelines. This Charter would not be a massive document. I'd like to see it — to give guidelines as to how to interpret the Scriptures, these texts that are being abused. Remember what the rabbis and what Augustine said about how Scripture should be governed by the principle of charity. Let's get back to that. And the idea, too, of Jews, Christians and Muslims — these traditions now so often at loggerheads — working together to create a document which we hope will be signed by a thousand, at least, of major religious leaders from all the traditions of the world.And you are the people. I'm just a solitary scholar. Despite the idea that I love a good time, which I was rather amazed to see coming up on me — I actually spend a great deal of time alone, studying, and I'm not very — you're the people with media knowledge to explain to me how we can get this to everybody, everybody on the planet. I've had some preliminary talks, and Archbishop Desmond Tutu, for example, is very happy to give his name to this, as is Imam Feisal Rauf, the Imam in New York City. Also, I would be working with the Alliance of Civilizations at the United Nations. I was part of that United Nations initiative called the Alliance of Civilizations, which was asked by Kofi Annan to diagnose the causes of extremism, and to give practical guidelines to member states about how to avoid the escalation of further extremism.And the Alliance has told me that they are very happy to work with it. The importance of this is that this is — I can see some of you starting to look worried, because you think it's a slow and cumbersome body — but what the United Nations can do is give us some neutrality, so that this isn't seen as a Western or a Christian initiative, but that it's coming, as it were, from the United Nations, from the world — who would help with the sort of bureaucracy of this.And so I do urge you to join me in making — in this charter — to building this charter, launching it and propagating it so that it becomes — I'd like to see it in every college, every church, every mosque, every synagogue in the world, so that people can look at their tradition, reclaim it, and make religion a source of peace in the world, which it can and should be. Thank you very much. (Applause)

Indeed, some of the world traditions think very little of religious orthodoxy.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:04.958
In the Quran, religious opinion -- religious orthodoxy -- is dismissed as "zanna:"

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:10.958
self-indulgent guesswork about matters that nobody can be certain of one way or the other,

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:13.958
but which makes people quarrelsome and stupidly sectarian. (Laughter)

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:20.958
So if religion is not about believing things, what is it about?

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:25.958
What I've found, across the board, is that religion is about behaving differently.

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:31.958
Instead of deciding whether or not you believe in God, first you do something.

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:32.958
You behave in a committed way,

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:36.958
and then you begin to understand the truths of religion.

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:43.958
And religious doctrines are meant to be summons to action;

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:47.958
you only understand them when you put them into practice.

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:55.958
Now, pride of place in this practice is given to compassion.

00:04:55.958 --> 00:05:00.958
And it is an arresting fact that right across the board,

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:04.958
in every single one of the major world faiths, compassion --

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:09.958
the ability to feel with the other in the way we've been thinking about this evening --

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:17.958
is not only the test of any true religiosity, it is also what will bring us

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:22.958
into the presence of what Jews, Christians and Muslims call "God" or the "Divine."

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:28.958
It is compassion, says the Buddha, which brings you to Nirvana.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:32.958
Why? Because in compassion, when we feel with the other,

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:37.958
we dethrone ourselves from the center of our world and we put

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:45.958
another person there. And once we get rid of ego, then we're ready to see the Divine.

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:53.958
And in particular, every single one of the major world traditions has highlighted -- has said --

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:58.958
and put at the core of their tradition what's become known as the Golden Rule.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:02.958
First propounded by Confucius five centuries before Christ:

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:06.958
"Do not do to others what you would not like them to do to you."

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:10.958
That, he said, was the central thread which ran through all his teaching

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:15.958
and that his disciples should put into practice all day and every day.

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:20.958
And it was -- the Golden Rule would bring them to the transcendent value that he called "ren,"

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:26.958
human-heartedness, which was a transcendent experience in itself.

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:31.958
And this is absolutely crucial to the monotheisms, too.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.958
There's a famous story about the great rabbi, Hillel, the older contemporary of Jesus.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:41.958
A pagan came to him and offered to convert to Judaism if the rabbi could

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:44.958
recite the whole of Jewish teaching while he stood on one leg.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:48.958
Hillel stood on one leg and said, "That which is hateful to you,

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:53.958
do not do to your neighbor. That is the Torah. The rest is commentary.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.958
Go and study it." (Laughter)

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:59.958
And "go and study it" was what he meant.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:03.958
He said, "In your exegesis, you must make it clear

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:10.958
that every single verse of the Torah is a commentary, a gloss upon the Golden Rule."

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:18.958
The great Rabbi Meir said that any interpretation of Scripture which

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:23.958
led to hatred and disdain, or contempt of other people --

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:26.958
any people whatsoever -- was illegitimate.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958
Saint Augustine made exactly the same point.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:35.958
Scripture, he says, "teaches nothing but charity, and we must not leave

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:42.958
an interpretation of Scripture until we have found a compassionate interpretation of it."

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:48.958
And this struggle to find compassion in some of these rather rebarbative texts

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:54.958
is a good dress rehearsal for doing the same in ordinary life. (Applause)

00:07:54.958 --> 00:08:01.958
But now look at our world. And we are living in a world that is --

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:12.958
where religion has been hijacked. Where terrorists cite Quranic verses to justify their atrocities.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:19.958
Where instead of taking Jesus' words, "Love your enemies.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:26.958
Don't judge others," we have the spectacle of Christians endlessly judging other people,

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:32.958
endlessly using Scripture as a way of arguing with other people,

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:40.958
putting other people down. Throughout the ages, religion has been used to oppress others,

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:44.958
and this is because of human ego, human greed.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:49.958
We have a talent as a species for messing up wonderful things.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:56.958
So the traditions also insisted -- and this is an important point, I think --

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
that you could not and must not confine your compassion

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:06.958
to your own group: your own nation, your own co-religionists,

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:11.958
your own fellow countrymen. You must have what one of the Chinese sages called "jian ai":

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:17.958
concern for everybody. Love your enemies. Honor the stranger.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:23.958
We formed you, says the Quran, into tribes and nations so that you may know one another.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:33.958
And this, again -- this universal outreach -- is getting subdued in the strident use of religion --

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:39.958
abuse of religion -- for nefarious gains.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:43.958
Now, I've lost count of the number of taxi drivers who,

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:48.958
when I say to them what I do for a living, inform me that religion

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:52.958
has been the cause of all the major world wars in history. Wrong.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:57.958
The causes of our present woes are political.

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:03.958
But, make no mistake about it, religion is a kind of fault line,

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:12.958
and when a conflict gets ingrained in a region, religion can get sucked in

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:17.958
and become part of the problem. Our modernity has been exceedingly violent.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:27.958
Between 1914 and 1945, 70 million people died in Europe alone as a result of armed conflict.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:36.958
And so many of our institutions, even football, which used to be a pleasant pastime,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:41.958
now causes riots where people even die.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:48.958
And it's not surprising that religion, too, has been affected by this violent ethos.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:54.958
There's also a great deal, I think, of religious illiteracy around.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:11:01.958
People seem to think, now equate religious faith with believing things.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:06.958
As though that -- we call religious people often believers,

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:13.958
as though that were the main thing that they do. And very often, secondary goals

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:19.958
get pushed into the first place, in place of compassion and the Golden Rule.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:25.958
Because the Golden Rule is difficult. I sometimes -- when I'm speaking to

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:29.958
congregations about compassion, I sometimes see

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:36.958
a mutinous expression crossing some of their faces because

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:42.958
a lot of religious people prefer to be right, rather than compassionate. (Laughter)

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:46.958
Now -- but that's not the whole story.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:52.958
Since September the 11th, when my work on Islam suddenly propelled me

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:59.958
into public life, in a way that I'd never imagined, I've been able to sort of go all over the world,

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:05.958
and finding, everywhere I go, a yearning for change.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:13.958
I've just come back from Pakistan, where literally thousands of people came to my lectures,

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:17.958
because they were yearning, first of all, to hear a friendly Western voice.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:24.958
And especially the young people were coming. And were asking me --

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:29.958
the young people were saying, "What can we do? What can we do to change things?"

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:36.958
And my hosts in Pakistan said, "Look, don't be too polite to us.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:42.958
Tell us where we're going wrong. Let's talk together about where religion is failing."

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:49.958
Because it seems to me that with -- our current situation is so serious

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:58.958
at the moment that any ideology that doesn't promote a sense of global understanding

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:04.958
and global appreciation of each other is failing the test of the time.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:10.958
And religion, with its wide following ... Here in the United States,

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:16.958
people may be being religious in a different way, as a report has just shown --

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:24.958
but they still want to be religious. It's only Western Europe that has retained its secularism,

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
which is now beginning to look rather endearingly old-fashioned.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:34.958
But people want to be religious, and religion should be made

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:39.958
to be a force for harmony in the world, which it can and should be --

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:42.958
because of the Golden Rule.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:46.958
"Do not do to others what you would not have them do to you":

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:49.958
an ethos that should now be applied globally.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:56.958
We should not treat other nations as we would not wish to be treated ourselves.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:14:04.958
And these -- whatever our wretched beliefs -- is a religious matter, it's a spiritual matter.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:09.958
It's a profound moral matter that engages and should engage us all.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:13.958
And as I say, there is a hunger for change out there.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:19.958
Here in the United States, I think you see it in this election campaign: a longing for change.

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:29.958
And people in churches all over and mosques all over this continent after September the 11th,

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:35.958
coming together locally to create networks of understanding.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:40.958
With the mosque, with the synagogue, saying, "We must start to speak to one another."

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:51.958
I think it's time that we moved beyond the idea of toleration and move toward appreciation of the other.

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:56.958
I'd -- there's one story I'd just like to mention.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:15:02.958
This comes from "The Iliad." But it tells you what this spirituality should be.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:07.958
You know the story of "The Iliad," the 10-year war between Greece and Troy.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:12.958
In one incident, Achilles, the famous warrior of Greece, takes his troops out of the war,

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:18.958
and the whole war effort suffers. And in the course of the ensuing muddle,

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:24.958
his beloved friend, Patroclus, is killed -- and killed in single combat

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:29.958
by one of the Trojan princes, Hector. And Achilles goes mad with grief and rage and revenge,

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:38.958
and he mutilates the body. He kills Hector, he mutilates his body

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:43.958
and then he refuses to give the body back for burial to the family,

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:50.958
which means that, in Greek ethos, Hector's soul will wander eternally, lost.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:54.958
And then one night, Priam, king of Troy, an old man,

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:59.958
comes into the Greek camp incognito, makes his way to Achilles' tent

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:02.958
to ask for the body of his son.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:09.958
And everybody is shocked when the old man takes off his head covering and shows himself.

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:15.958
And Achilles looks at him and thinks of his father. And he starts to weep.

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:21.958
And Priam looks at the man who has murdered so many of his sons,

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:26.958
and he, too, starts to weep. And the sound of their weeping filled the house.

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:31.958
The Greeks believed that weeping together created a bond between people.

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:39.958
And then Achilles takes the body of Hector, he hands it very tenderly to the father,

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:43.958
and the two men look at each other, and see each other as divine.

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:50.958
That is the ethos found, too, in all the religions.

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:58.958
It's what is meant by overcoming the horror that we feel when we are under threat of our enemies,

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:01.958
and beginning to appreciate the other.

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:10.958
It's of great importance that the word for "holy" in Hebrew, applied to God, is "Kadosh": separate, other.

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:16.958
And it is often, perhaps, the very otherness of our enemies which can

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:21.958
give us intimations of that utterly mysterious transcendence which is God.

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:25.958
And now, here's my wish:

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:31.958
I wish that you would help with the creation,

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:37.958
launch and propagation of a Charter for Compassion,

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:43.958
crafted by a group of inspirational thinkers from

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:47.958
the three Abrahamic traditions of Judaism, Christianity and Islam,

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:52.958
and based on the fundamental principle of the Golden Rule.

00:17:52.958 --> 00:18:00.958
We need to create a movement among all these people that I meet in my travels --

00:18:00.958 --> 00:18:04.958
you probably meet, too -- who want to join up, in some way,

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:09.958
and reclaim their faith, which they feel, as I say, has been hijacked.

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:15.958
We need to empower people to remember the compassionate ethos,

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:19.958
and to give guidelines. This Charter would not be a massive document.

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:27.958
I'd like to see it -- to give guidelines as to how to interpret the Scriptures,

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:33.958
these texts that are being abused. Remember what the rabbis and what Augustine

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:36.958
said about how Scripture should be governed by the principle of charity.

00:18:36.958 --> 00:18:42.958
Let's get back to that. And the idea, too, of Jews, Christians and Muslims --

00:18:42.958 --> 00:18:47.958
these traditions now so often at loggerheads -- working together to

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:54.958
create a document which we hope will be signed by a thousand, at least,

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:58.958
of major religious leaders from all the traditions of the world.

00:18:58.958 --> 00:19:02.958
And you are the people. I'm just a solitary scholar.

00:19:02.958 --> 00:19:08.958
Despite the idea that I love a good time, which I was rather amazed to see coming up on me

00:19:08.958 --> 00:19:14.958
-- I actually spend a great deal of time alone, studying, and I'm not very --

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:21.958
you're the people with media knowledge to explain to me how we can get this to everybody,

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:25.958
everybody on the planet. I've had some preliminary talks,

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:28.958
and Archbishop Desmond Tutu, for example,

00:19:28.958 --> 00:19:38.958
is very happy to give his name to this, as is Imam Feisal Rauf, the Imam in New York City.

00:19:38.958 --> 00:19:46.958
Also, I would be working with the Alliance of Civilizations at the United Nations.

00:19:46.958 --> 00:19:54.958
I was part of that United Nations initiative called the Alliance of Civilizations,

00:19:54.958 --> 00:20:00.958
which was asked by Kofi Annan to diagnose the causes of extremism,

00:20:00.958 --> 00:20:09.958
and to give practical guidelines to member states about how to avoid the escalation of further extremism.

00:20:09.958 --> 00:20:13.958
And the Alliance has told me that they are very happy to work with it.

00:20:13.958 --> 00:20:19.958
The importance of this is that this is -- I can see some of you starting to look worried,

00:20:19.958 --> 00:20:22.958
because you think it's a slow and cumbersome body --

00:20:22.958 --> 00:20:25.958
but what the United Nations can do is give us some neutrality,

00:20:25.958 --> 00:20:31.958
so that this isn't seen as a Western or a Christian initiative, but that it's coming,

00:20:31.958 --> 00:20:34.958
as it were, from the United Nations, from the world --

00:20:34.958 --> 00:20:40.958
who would help with the sort of bureaucracy of this.

00:20:40.958 --> 00:20:46.958
And so I do urge you to join me in making -- in this charter --

00:20:46.958 --> 00:20:54.958
to building this charter, launching it and propagating it so that it becomes --

00:20:54.958 --> 00:21:03.958
I'd like to see it in every college, every church, every mosque, every synagogue in the world,

00:21:03.958 --> 00:21:12.958
so that people can look at their tradition, reclaim it, and make religion a source of peace in the world,

00:21:12.958 --> 00:21:17.958
which it can and should be. Thank you very much. (Applause)

title: My wish: Find the next Einstein in Africa
transcript: It was an incredible surprise to me to find out that there was actually an organization that cared about both parts of my life. Because, basically, I work as a theoretical physicist. I develop and test models of the Big Bang, using observational data. And I've been moonlighting for the last five years helping with a project in Africa. And, I get a lot of flak for this at Cambridge. People wonder, you know, "How do you have time to do this?" And so on. And so it was simply astonishing to me to find an organization that actually appreciated both those sides.So I thought I'd start off by just telling you a little bit about myself and why I lead this schizophrenic life. Well, I was born in South Africa and my parents were imprisoned for resisting the racist regime. When they were released, we left and we went as refugees to Kenya and Tanzania. Both were very young countries then, and full of hope for the future.We had an amazing childhood. We didn't have any money, but we were outdoors most of the time. We had fantastic friends and we saw the wonders of the world, like Kilimanjaro, Serengeti and the Olduvai Gorge. Well, then we moved to London for high school. And after that — there's nothing much to say about that. It was rather dull. But I came back to Africa at the age of 17, as a volunteer teacher to Lesotho, which is a tiny country, surrounded at that time by apartheid South Africa.Well, 80 percent of the men in Lesotho worked in the mines over the border, in brutal conditions. Nevertheless, I — as I'm sure — as a rather irritating young, white man coming into their village, I was welcomed with incredible hospitality and warmth. But the kids were the best part. The kids were amazing: extremely eager and often very bright. And I'm just going to tell you one story, which got through to me.I used to try to take the kids outside as often as possible, to try to connect the academic stuff with the real world. And they weren't used to that. But I took them outside one day and I said, "I want you to estimate the height of the building." And I expected them to put a ruler next to the wall, size it up with a finger, and make an estimate of the height. But there was one little boy, very small for his age. He was the son of one of the poorest families in the village. And he wasn't doing that. He was scribbling with chalk on the pavement. And so, I said — I was annoyed — I said, "What are you doing? I want you to estimate the height of the building." He said, "OK. I measured the height of a brick. I counted the number of bricks and now I'm multiplying." Well — (Laughter) — I hadn't thought of that one.And many experiences like this happened to me. Another one is that I met a miner. He was home on his three-month leave from the mines. Sitting next to him one day, he said, "There's only one thing that I really loved at school. And you know what it was? Shakespeare." And he recited some to me. And these and many similar experiences convinced me that there are just tons of bright kids in Africa — inventive kids, intellectual kids — and starved of opportunity. And if Africa is going to get fixed, it's by them, not by us. Well, after — (Applause) — that's the truth.Well, after Lesotho, I traveled across Africa before returning to England — so gray and depressing, in comparison. And I went to Cambridge. And there, I fell for theoretical physics. Well, I'm not going to explain this equation, but theoretical physics is really an amazing subject. We can write down all the laws of physics we know in one line. And, admittedly, it's in a very shorthand notation. And it contains 18 free parameters, OK, which we have to fit to the data.So it's not the final story, but it's an incredibly powerful summary of everything we know about nature at the most basic level. And apart from a few very important loose ends, which you've heard about here — like dark energy and dark matter — this equation describes, seems to describe everything about the universe and what's in it.But there's one big puzzle remaining, and this was most succinctly put to me by my primary school math teacher in Tanzania, who's a wonderful Scottish lady who I still stay in touch with. And she's now in her 80s. And when I try to explain my work to her, she waved away all the details, and she said, "Neil, there's only one question that really matters. What banged?" (Laughter) "Everyone talks about the Big Bang. What banged?"And she's right. It's a question we've all been avoiding. The standard explanation is that the universe somehow sprang into existence, full of a strange kind of energy — inflationary energy — which blew it up. But the puzzle of why the universe emerged in that peculiar state is completely unsolved. Now, I worked on that theory for a while, with Stephen Hawking and others. But then I began to explore another alternative. The alternative is that the Big Bang wasn't the beginning. Perhaps the universe existed before the bang, and the bang was just a violent event in a pre-existing universe.Well, this possibility is actually suggested by the latest theories, the unified theories, which try to explain all those 18 free parameters in a single framework, which will hopefully predict all of them. And I'll just share a cartoon of this idea here. It's all I can convey. According to these theories, there are extra dimensions of space, not just the three we're familiar with, but at every point in the room there are more dimensions. And in particular, there's one rather strange one, in the most elegant unified theories we have. The strange one looks likes this: that we live in a three-dimensional world. We live in one of these worlds, and I can only show it as a sheet, but it's really three-dimensional.And a tiny distance away, there's another sheet, also three-dimensional, and they're separated by a gap. The gap is very tiny, and I've blown it up so you can see it. But it's really a tiny fraction of the size of an atomic nucleus. I won't go into the details of why we think the universe is like this, but it comes out of the math and trying to explain the physics that we know. Well, I got interested in this because it seemed to me that it was an obvious question. Which is, what happens if these two, three-dimensional worlds should actually collide? And if they collide, it would look a lot like the Big Bang. But it's slightly different than in the conventional picture. The conventional picture of the Big Bang is a point. Everything comes out of a point; you have infinite density. And all the equations break down. No hope of describing that.In this picture, you'll notice, the bang is extended. It's not a point. The density of matter is finite, and we have a chance of a consistent set of equations that can describe the whole process. So, to cut a long story short, we've explored this alternative. We've shown that it can fit all of the data that we have about the formation of galaxies, the fluctuations in the microwave background. Furthermore, there's an experimental way to tell this theory, apart from the inflationary explanation that I told you before. It involves gravitational waves.And in this scenario, not only was the Big Bang not the beginning, as you can see from the picture, it can happen over and over again. It may be that we live in an endless universe, both in space and in time. And there've been bangs in the past, and there will be bangs in the future. And maybe we live in an endless universe. Well, making and testing models of the universe is, for me, the best way I have of enjoying and appreciating the universe. We need to make the best mathematical models we can, the most consistent ones. And then we scrutinize them, logically and with data. And we try to convince ourselves — we really try to convince ourselves they're wrong. That's progress: when we prove things wrong. And gradually, we hopefully move closer and closer to understanding the world.As I pursued my career, something was always gnawing away inside me. What about Africa? What about those kids I'd left behind? Instead of developing, as we'd all hoped in the '60s, things had gotten worse. Africa was gripped by poverty, disease and war. This is very graphically shown by the Worldmapper website and project. And so the idea is to represent each country on a map, but scale the area according to some quantity.So here's just the standard area map of the world. By the way, Africa is very large. And the next map now shows Africa's GDP in 1960, around the time of independence for many African states. Now, this is 1990, and then 2002. And here's a projection for 2015. Big changes are happening in the world, but they're not helping Africa.What about Africa's population? The population isn't out of proportion to its area, but Africa leads the world in deaths from often preventable causes: malnutrition, simple infections and birth complications. Then there's HIV/AIDS. And then there are deaths from war. OK, currently there are 45,000 people a month dying in the Congo, as a consequence of the war there over coltan and diamonds and other things. It's still going on.What about Africa's capacity to do something about these problems? Well, here's the number of physicians in Africa. Here's the number of people in higher education. And here — most shocking to me — the number of scientific research papers coming out of Africa. It just doesn't exist scientifically. And this was very eloquently argued at TED Africa: that all of the aid that's been given has completely failed to put Africa onto its own two feet.Well, the transition to democracy in South Africa in 1994 was literally a dream come true for many of us. My parents were both elected to the first parliament, alongside Nelson and Winnie Mandela. They were the only other couple. And in 2001, I took a research leave to visit them. And while I was busy working — I was working on these colliding worlds, in the day. But I learned that there was a desperate shortage of skills, especially mathematical skills, in industry, in government, in education.The ability to make and test models has become essential, not only to every single area of science today, but also to modern society itself. And if you don't have math, you're not going to enter the modern age. So I had an idea. And the idea was very simple. The idea was to set up an African Institute for Mathematical Sciences, or AIMS. And let's recruit students from the whole of Africa, bring them together with lecturers from all over the world, and we'll try to give them a fantastic education.Well, as a Cambridge professor, I had many contacts. And to my astonishment, they backed me 100 percent. They said, "Go and do it, and we'll come and lecture." And I knew it would be amazing fun to bring brilliant students from these countries — where they don't have any opportunities — together with the best lecturers in the world — who I knew would come, because of the interest in Africa — and put them together and just let the sparks fly. So we bought a derelict hotel near Cape Town. It's an 80-room Art Deco hotel from the 1920s. The area was kind of seedy, so we got an 80-room hotel for 100,000 dollars. It's a beautiful building. We decided we would refurbish it and then put out the word: we're going to start the best math institute in Africa in this hotel.Well, the new South Africa is a very exciting country. And those of you who haven't been there, you should go. It's very, very interesting what's happening. And we recruited wonderful staff, highly motivated staff. The other thing that's happened, which was good for us, is the Internet. Even though the Internet is very expensive all over Africa, there are Internet cafes everywhere. And bright young Africans are desperate to join the global community, to be successful — and they're very ambitious. They want to be the next Einstein.And so when word came out that AIMS was opening, it spread very quickly via e-mail and our website. And we got lots of applicants. Well, we designed AIMS as a 24-hour learning environment, and it was fantastic to start a university from the beginning. You have to rethink, what is the university for? And that's really exciting. So we designed it to have interactive teaching. No droning on at the chalkboard. We emphasize problem-solving, working in groups, every student discovering and maximizing their own potential and not chasing grades.Everyone lives together in this hotel — lecturers and students — and it's not surprising at all to find an impromptu tutorial at 1 a.m. The students don't usually leave the computer lab till 2 or 3 a.m. And then they're up again at eight in the morning. Lectures, problem-solving and so on. It's an extraordinary place. We especially emphasize areas of great relevance to Africa's development, because, in those areas, scientists working in Africa will have a competitive advantage. They'll publish, be invited to conferences. They'll do well. They'll have successful careers.And AIMS has done extremely well. Here is a list of last year's graduates, graduated in June, and what they're currently doing — 48 of them. And where they are is indicated over here. And where they've gone. So these are all postgraduate students. And they've all gone on to master's and Ph.D. degrees in excellent places. Five students can be educated at AIMS for the cost of educating one in the U.S. or Europe. But more important, the pan-African student body is a continual source of strength, pride and commitment to Africa. We illustrate AIMS' progress by coloring in the countries of Africa.So here you can see behind this list. When a county is colored yellow, we've received an application; orange, we've accepted an application; and green, a student has graduated. So here is where we were after the first graduation in 2004. And we set ourselves a goal of turning the continent green. So there's 2005, -6, -7, -8. (Applause) We're well on the way to achieving our initial goal.We had some of the students filmed at home before they came to AIMS. And I'll just show you one. Tendai Mugwagwa: My name is Tendai Mugwagwa. I have a Bachelor of Science with an education degree. I will be attending AIMS. My understanding of the course is that it covers quite a lot. You know, from physics to medicine, in particular, epidemiology and also mathematical modeling. Neil Turok: So Tendai came to AIMS and did very well. And I'll let her take it from there.TM: My name is Tendai Mugwagwa and I was a student at AIMS in 2003 and 2004. After leaving AIMS, I went on to do a master's in applied mathematics at the University of Cape Town in South Africa. After that, I came to the Netherlands where I'm now doing a Ph.D. in theoretical immunology.Professor: Tendai is working very independently. She communicates well with the immunologists at the hospital. So all in all I have a very good Ph.D. student from South Africa. So I'm happy she's here.NT: Another student in the first year of AIMS was Shehu. And he's shown here with his favorite high school teacher. And then entering university in northern Nigeria. And after AIMS, Shehu wanted to do high-energy physics, and he came to Cambridge. He's about to finish his Ph.D., and he was filmed recently with someone you all know.Shehu: And from there we will be able to, hopefully, make better predictions and then we compare it to the graph and also make some predictions.Stephen Hawking: That is nice.NT: Here are the current students at AIMS. There are 53 of them from 20 different countries, including 20 women. So now I'm going to get to my TED business. Well, we had a party. This is Africa — we have good parties in Africa. And last month, they threw a surprise party for me. Here's somebody you've seen already. (Applause) I want to point out a few other exceptional people in this picture. So, we were having a party, as you can see they're completely eclipsing me at this point. This is Ezra. She's from Darfur. She's a physicist, and somehow stays smiling, in spite of everything going on back home. But she wants to continue in physics, and she's doing extremely well. This is Lydia. Lydia is the first ever woman to graduate in mathematics in the Central African Republic. And she's now at AIMS. (Applause)So now let me get to our TED wish. Well, it's not my TED wish; it's our wish, as you've already gathered. And our wish has two parts: one is a dream and the other's a plan. OK. Our TED dream is that the next Einstein will be African. (Applause) In striving for the heights of creative genius, we want to give thousands of people the motivation, the encouragement and the courage to obtain the high-level skills they need to help Africa. Among them will be not only brilliant scientists — I'm sure of that from what we've seen at AIMS — they'll also be the African Gates, Brins and Pages of the future.Well, I said we also have a plan. And our plan is quite simple. AIMS is now a proven model. And what we need to do is to replicate it. We want to roll out 15 AIMS centers in the next five years, all over Africa. Each will have a pan-African student body, but specialize in a different area of science. We want to use science to overcome the national and cultural barriers, as it does at AIMS. And we want to add elements to the curriculum. We want to add entrepreneurship and policy skills.The expanded AIMS will be a coherent pan-African institution, and its graduates will form a powerful network, working together for peace and progress across the continent. Over the last year, we've been visiting sites in Africa, looking at potential sites for new AIMS centers. And here are the ones we've selected. And each of these centers has a strong local team, each is in a beautiful place, an interesting place, which international lecturers will be happy to visit. And our partners across Africa are extremely enthusiastic about this. Everyone wants an AIMS center in their country.And last November, the conference of all the African ministers of science and technology, held in Mombasa, called for a comprehensive plan to roll out AIMS. So we have political support right across the continent. It won't be easy. At every site there will be huge challenges. Local scientists must play leading roles and governments must be persuaded to buy in. Conditions are very difficult, but we cannot afford to compromise on those principles which made AIMS work.And we summarize them this way: the institutes have got to be relevant, innovative, cost-effective and high quality. Why? Because we want Africa to be rich. Easy to remember the basic rules we need. So, just in ending, let me say the only people who can fix Africa are talented young Africans. By unlocking and nurturing their creative potential, we can create a step change in Africa's future. Over time, they will contribute to African development and to science in ways we can only imagine. Thank you. (Applause)

WEBVTT

00:00:12.958 --> 00:00:15.958
It was an incredible surprise to me

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:21.958
to find out that there was actually an organization that cared about both parts of my life.

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:22.958
Because, basically,

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:24.958
I work as a theoretical physicist.

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:27.958
I develop and test models of the Big Bang,

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:30.958
using observational data.

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:33.958
And I've been moonlighting for the last five years

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:36.958
helping with a project in Africa.

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:40.958
And, I get a lot of flak for this at Cambridge.

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:44.958
People wonder, you know, "How do you have time to do this?" And so on.

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:47.958
And so it was simply astonishing to me

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:51.958
to find an organization that actually appreciated both those sides.

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:54.958
So I thought I'd start off by just telling you a little bit about myself

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:58.958
and why I lead this schizophrenic life.

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:03.958
Well, I was born in South Africa and my parents were imprisoned

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:05.958
for resisting the racist regime.

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:12.958
When they were released, we left and we went as refugees to Kenya and Tanzania.

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:14.958
Both were very young countries then,

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:17.958
and full of hope for the future.

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:19.958
We had an amazing childhood. We didn't have any money,

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:22.958
but we were outdoors most of the time.

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:27.958
We had fantastic friends and we saw the wonders of the world,

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:33.958
like Kilimanjaro, Serengeti and the Olduvai Gorge.

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:35.958
Well, then we moved to London for high school.

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:40.958
And after that -- there's nothing much to say about that.

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:44.958
It was rather dull. But I came back to Africa

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:48.958
at the age of 17, as a volunteer teacher

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:51.958
to Lesotho, which is a tiny country,

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:56.958
surrounded at that time by apartheid South Africa.

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:59.958
Well, 80 percent of the men in Lesotho

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:03.958
worked in the mines over the border,

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:06.958
in brutal conditions.

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:12.958
Nevertheless, I -- as I'm sure -- as a rather irritating young, white man

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:18.958
coming into their village, I was welcomed with incredible hospitality and warmth.

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
But the kids were the best part.

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:25.958
The kids were amazing: extremely eager and often very bright.

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:27.958
And I'm just going to tell you one story,

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:30.958
which got through to me.

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
I used to try to take the kids outside as often as possible,

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:37.958
to try to connect the academic stuff with the real world.

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:40.958
And they weren't used to that.

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:42.958
But I took them outside one day and I said,

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:45.958
"I want you to estimate the height of the building."

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:48.958
And I expected them to put a ruler next to the wall,

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:53.958
size it up with a finger, and make an estimate of the height.

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:57.958
But there was one little boy, very small for his age.

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:00.958
He was the son of one of the poorest families in the village.

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:05.958
And he wasn't doing that. He was scribbling with chalk on the pavement.

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:08.958
And so, I said -- I was annoyed -- I said, "What are you doing?

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:10.958
I want you to estimate the height of the building."

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:13.958
He said, "OK. I measured the height of a brick.

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:18.958
I counted the number of bricks and now I'm multiplying."

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:23.958
Well -- (Laughter) -- I hadn't thought of that one.

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:27.958
And many experiences like this happened to me.

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:35.958
Another one is that I met a miner. He was home on his three-month leave from the mines.

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:41.958
Sitting next to him one day, he said, "There's only one thing that I really loved at school.

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:48.958
And you know what it was? Shakespeare." And he recited some to me.

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:52.958
And these and many similar experiences convinced me

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:56.958
that there are just tons of bright kids in Africa

00:03:56.958 --> 00:04:00.958
-- inventive kids, intellectual kids --

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:01.958
and starved of opportunity.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:07.958
And if Africa is going to get fixed, it's by them, not by us.

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:13.958
Well, after -- (Applause) -- that's the truth.

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:16.958
Well, after Lesotho, I traveled across Africa

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.958
before returning to England

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:22.958
-- so gray and depressing, in comparison.

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:29.958
And I went to Cambridge. And there, I fell for theoretical physics.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:31.958
Well, I'm not going to explain this equation,

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:35.958
but theoretical physics is really an amazing subject.

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:41.958
We can write down all the laws of physics we know in one line.

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:46.958
And, admittedly, it's in a very shorthand notation.

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:50.958
And it contains 18 free parameters,

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:53.958
OK, which we have to fit to the data.

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:55.958
So it's not the final story,

00:04:55.958 --> 00:05:00.958
but it's an incredibly powerful summary of everything we know

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:04.958
about nature at the most basic level.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:08.958
And apart from a few very important loose ends, which you've heard about here --

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:11.958
like dark energy and dark matter --

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:13.958
this equation describes,

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:18.958
seems to describe everything about the universe and what's in it.

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:20.958
But there's one big puzzle remaining,

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:25.958
and this was most succinctly put to me by my primary school math teacher in

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:28.958
Tanzania, who's a wonderful Scottish lady

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.958
who I still stay in touch with.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
And she's now in her 80s.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:38.958
And when I try to explain my work to her, she waved away all the details, and she said,

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:43.958
"Neil, there's only one question that really matters.

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:47.958
What banged?" (Laughter)

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:52.958
"Everyone talks about the Big Bang. What banged?"

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:57.958
And she's right. It's a question we've all been avoiding.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:02.958
The standard explanation is that the universe somehow sprang into existence,

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
full of a strange kind of energy

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:09.958
-- inflationary energy -- which blew it up.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:13.958
But the puzzle of why the universe emerged in that peculiar state

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:17.958
is completely unsolved.

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:21.958
Now, I worked on that theory for a while, with Stephen Hawking and others.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:24.958
But then I began to explore another alternative.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:27.958
The alternative is that the Big Bang wasn't the beginning.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:30.958
Perhaps the universe existed before the bang,

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:35.958
and the bang was just a violent event in a pre-existing universe.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:38.958
Well, this possibility is actually suggested

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
by the latest theories, the unified theories,

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:44.958
which try to explain all those 18 free parameters

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:51.958
in a single framework, which will hopefully predict all of them.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:54.958
And I'll just share a cartoon of this idea here.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:57.958
It's all I can convey. According to these theories,

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:00.958
there are extra dimensions of space, not just the three we're familiar with,

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:04.958
but at every point in the room there are more dimensions.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
And in particular, there's one rather strange one,

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:09.958
in the most elegant unified theories we have.

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:11.958
The strange one looks likes this:

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
that we live in a three-dimensional world.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:18.958
We live in one of these worlds, and I can only show it as a sheet,

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:21.958
but it's really three-dimensional.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:25.958
And a tiny distance away, there's another sheet,

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
also three-dimensional, and they're separated by a gap.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:30.958
The gap is very tiny, and I've blown it up so you can see it.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:35.958
But it's really a tiny fraction of the size of an atomic nucleus.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:38.958
I won't go into the details of why we think the universe is like this,

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:42.958
but it comes out of the math and trying to explain the physics that we know.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:46.958
Well, I got interested in this because it seemed to me that it was an obvious question.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:49.958
Which is, what happens if these two, three-dimensional worlds

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:52.958
should actually collide?

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
And if they collide, it would look a lot like the Big Bang.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
But it's slightly different than in the conventional picture.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
The conventional picture of the Big Bang is a point.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
Everything comes out of a point;

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:07.958
you have infinite density. And all the equations break down.

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
No hope of describing that.

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
In this picture, you'll notice,

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
the bang is extended. It's not a point.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
The density of matter is finite, and we have a chance

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:21.958
of a consistent set of equations that can describe the whole process.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:24.958
So, to cut a long story short, we've explored this alternative.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
We've shown that it can fit

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:30.958
all of the data that we have about the formation of galaxies,

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.958
the fluctuations in the microwave background.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
Furthermore, there's an experimental way

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:42.958
to tell this theory, apart from the inflationary explanation that I told you before.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:45.958
It involves gravitational waves.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
And in this scenario, not only was the Big Bang not the beginning,

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.958
as you can see from the picture,

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
it can happen over and over again.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
It may be that we live in an endless universe,

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:57.958
both in space and in time.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:03.958
And there've been bangs in the past, and there will be bangs in the future.

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:07.958
And maybe we live in an endless universe.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:12.958
Well, making and testing models of the universe

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:19.958
is, for me, the best way I have of enjoying and appreciating the universe.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
We need to make the best mathematical models we can,

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:23.958
the most consistent ones.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:27.958
And then we scrutinize them, logically and with data.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:30.958
And we try to convince ourselves --

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.958
we really try to convince ourselves they're wrong.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:35.958
That's progress: when we prove things wrong.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:41.958
And gradually, we hopefully move closer and closer to understanding the world.

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:46.958
As I pursued my career, something was always gnawing away inside me.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
What about Africa?

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:54.958
What about those kids I'd left behind?

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
Instead of developing, as we'd all hoped in the '60s,

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
things had gotten worse.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:03.958
Africa was gripped by poverty, disease and war.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:09.958
This is very graphically shown by the Worldmapper website and project.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
And so the idea is to represent each country

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:18.958
on a map, but scale the area according to some quantity.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
So here's just the standard area map of the world.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
By the way, Africa is very large.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:27.958
And the next map now shows Africa's GDP in 1960,

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:32.958
around the time of independence for many African states.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:42.958
Now, this is 1990, and then 2002. And here's a projection for 2015.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:44.958
Big changes are happening in the world,

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.958
but they're not helping Africa.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:51.958
What about Africa's population? The population isn't out of proportion to its area,

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:56.958
but Africa leads the world in deaths from often preventable causes:

00:10:56.958 --> 00:11:03.958
malnutrition, simple infections and birth complications.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:08.958
Then there's HIV/AIDS. And then there are deaths from war.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:13.958
OK, currently there are 45,000 people a month dying in the Congo,

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
as a consequence of the war

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:19.958
there over coltan and diamonds and other things.

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:23.958
It's still going on.

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:26.958
What about Africa's capacity to do something about these problems?

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:31.958
Well, here's the number of physicians in Africa.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:36.958
Here's the number of people in higher education.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.958
And here -- most shocking to me --

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:42.958
the number of scientific research papers coming out of Africa.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:47.958
It just doesn't exist scientifically.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:50.958
And this was very eloquently argued at TED Africa:

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
that all of the aid that's been given

00:11:52.958 --> 00:12:00.958
has completely failed to put Africa onto its own two feet.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
Well, the transition to democracy in South Africa in 1994

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:07.958
was literally a dream come true for many of us.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:10.958
My parents were both elected to the first parliament,

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:15.958
alongside Nelson and Winnie Mandela. They were the only other couple.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:19.958
And in 2001, I took a research leave to visit them.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:26.958
And while I was busy working -- I was working on these colliding worlds, in the day.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.958
But I learned that there was a desperate shortage of skills,

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:37.958
especially mathematical skills, in industry, in government, in education.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:41.958
The ability to make and test models has become essential,

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
not only to every single area of science today,

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:48.958
but also to modern society itself.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:54.958
And if you don't have math, you're not going to enter the modern age.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:57.958
So I had an idea. And the idea was very simple.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:03.958
The idea was to set up an African Institute for Mathematical Sciences, or AIMS.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:07.958
And let's recruit students from the whole of Africa,

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:11.958
bring them together with lecturers from all over the world,

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:16.958
and we'll try to give them a fantastic education.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
Well, as a Cambridge professor, I had many contacts.

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:22.958
And to my astonishment, they backed me 100 percent.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
They said, "Go and do it,

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:28.958
and we'll come and lecture."

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:32.958
And I knew it would be amazing fun to bring brilliant students

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:36.958
from these countries -- where they don't have any opportunities -- together

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:38.958
with the best lecturers in the world --

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
who I knew would come, because of the interest in Africa --

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:48.958
and put them together and just let the sparks fly.

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:52.958
So we bought a derelict hotel near Cape Town.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
It's an 80-room Art Deco hotel from the 1920s.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:14:01.958
The area was kind of seedy, so we got an 80-room hotel for 100,000 dollars.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:05.958
It's a beautiful building. We decided we would refurbish it

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
and then put out the word:

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:11.958
we're going to start the best math institute in Africa

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:12.958
in this hotel.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:15.958
Well, the new South Africa is a very exciting country.

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:18.958
And those of you who haven't been there, you should go.

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:21.958
It's very, very interesting what's happening.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:24.958
And we recruited wonderful staff,

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:26.958
highly motivated staff.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:30.958
The other thing that's happened, which was good for us, is the Internet.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:33.958
Even though the Internet is very expensive all over Africa,

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
there are Internet cafes everywhere.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:40.958
And bright young Africans are desperate to join the global community,

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:43.958
to be successful -- and they're very ambitious.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:47.958
They want to be the next Einstein.

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:52.958
And so when word came out that AIMS was opening,

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:56.958
it spread very quickly via e-mail and our website.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
And we got lots of applicants.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
Well, we designed AIMS as a 24-hour learning environment,

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:05.958
and it was fantastic to start a university from the beginning.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:09.958
You have to rethink, what is the university for?

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
And that's really exciting.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:14.958
So we designed it to have interactive teaching.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:18.958
No droning on at the chalkboard.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:22.958
We emphasize problem-solving, working in groups,

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:26.958
every student discovering and maximizing their own potential

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:29.958
and not chasing grades.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
Everyone lives together in this hotel -- lecturers and students --

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:37.958
and it's not surprising at all to find an impromptu tutorial at 1 a.m.

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:41.958
The students don't usually leave the computer lab till 2 or 3 a.m.

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:43.958
And then they're up again at eight in the morning.

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:50.958
Lectures, problem-solving and so on. It's an extraordinary place.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:55.958
We especially emphasize areas of great relevance to Africa's development,

00:15:55.958 --> 00:16:01.958
because, in those areas, scientists working in Africa will have a competitive advantage.

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.958
They'll publish, be invited to conferences.

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:09.958
They'll do well. They'll have successful careers.

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:11.958
And AIMS has done extremely well.

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:15.958
Here is a list of last year's graduates, graduated in June,

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:18.958
and what they're currently doing -- 48 of them.

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:22.958
And where they are is indicated over here.

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:26.958
And where they've gone. So these are all postgraduate students.

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:33.958
And they've all gone on to master's and Ph.D. degrees in excellent places.

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:35.958
Five students can be educated at AIMS

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:39.958
for the cost of educating one in the U.S. or Europe.

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:42.958
But more important, the pan-African student body

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:48.958
is a continual source of strength, pride and commitment to Africa.

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:53.958
We illustrate AIMS' progress by coloring in the countries of Africa.

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:55.958
So here you can see behind this list.

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:59.958
When a county is colored yellow, we've received an application;

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:04.958
orange, we've accepted an application; and green,

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:06.958
a student has graduated.

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:10.958
So here is where we were after the first graduation in 2004.

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:14.958
And we set ourselves a goal of turning the continent green.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:18.958
So there's 2005, -6, -7, -8.

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:28.958
(Applause)

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:32.958
We're well on the way to achieving our initial goal.

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:36.958
We had some of the students filmed at home before they came to AIMS.

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:39.958
And I'll just show you one.

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:43.958
Tendai Mugwagwa: My name is Tendai Mugwagwa.

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:46.958
I have a Bachelor of Science with an education degree.

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:48.958
I will be attending AIMS.

00:17:48.958 --> 00:17:52.958
My understanding of the course is that it covers quite a lot.

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:56.958
You know, from physics to medicine,

00:17:56.958 --> 00:18:02.958
in particular, epidemiology and also mathematical modeling.

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:07.958
Neil Turok: So Tendai came to AIMS and did very well.

00:18:07.958 --> 00:18:11.958
And I'll let her take it from there.

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:17.958
TM: My name is Tendai Mugwagwa

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:21.958
and I was a student at AIMS in 2003 and 2004.

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:26.958
After leaving AIMS, I went on to do a master's in applied mathematics

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:29.958
at the University of Cape Town in South Africa.

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:31.958
After that, I came to the Netherlands

00:18:31.958 --> 00:18:34.958
where I'm now doing a Ph.D. in theoretical immunology.

00:18:34.958 --> 00:18:37.958
Professor: Tendai is working very independently.

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:41.958
She communicates well with the immunologists at the hospital.

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:45.958
So all in all I have a very good Ph.D. student from South Africa.

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:48.958
So I'm happy she's here.

00:18:48.958 --> 00:18:52.958
NT: Another student in the first year of AIMS was Shehu.

00:18:52.958 --> 00:18:57.958
And he's shown here with his favorite high school teacher.

00:18:57.958 --> 00:19:03.958
And then entering university in northern Nigeria.

00:19:03.958 --> 00:19:08.958
And after AIMS, Shehu wanted to do high-energy physics,

00:19:08.958 --> 00:19:10.958
and he came to Cambridge.

00:19:10.958 --> 00:19:13.958
He's about to finish his Ph.D.,

00:19:13.958 --> 00:19:17.958
and he was filmed recently with someone you all know.

00:19:17.958 --> 00:19:19.958
Shehu: And from there we will be able to,

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:22.958
hopefully, make better predictions and then we compare it

00:19:22.958 --> 00:19:27.958
to the graph and also make some predictions.

00:19:27.958 --> 00:19:30.958
Stephen Hawking: That is nice.

00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:33.958
NT: Here are the current students at AIMS. There are 53 of them

00:19:33.958 --> 00:19:37.958
from 20 different countries, including 20 women.

00:19:37.958 --> 00:19:40.958
So now I'm going to get to my TED business.

00:19:40.958 --> 00:19:43.958
Well, we had a party. This is Africa --

00:19:43.958 --> 00:19:47.958
we have good parties in Africa. And last month, they threw a surprise party for me.

00:19:47.958 --> 00:19:49.958
Here's somebody you've seen already.

00:19:49.958 --> 00:20:13.958
(Applause)

00:20:13.958 --> 00:20:17.958
I want to point out a few other exceptional people in this picture.

00:20:17.958 --> 00:20:18.958
So, we were having a party,

00:20:18.958 --> 00:20:22.958
as you can see they're completely eclipsing me at this point.

00:20:22.958 --> 00:20:25.958
This is Ezra. She's from Darfur.

00:20:25.958 --> 00:20:29.958
She's a physicist, and somehow stays smiling,

00:20:29.958 --> 00:20:31.958
in spite of everything going on back home.

00:20:31.958 --> 00:20:35.958
But she wants to continue in physics, and she's doing extremely well.

00:20:35.958 --> 00:20:39.958
This is Lydia. Lydia is the first ever woman

00:20:39.958 --> 00:20:42.958
to graduate in mathematics in the Central African Republic.

00:20:42.958 --> 00:20:47.958
And she's now at AIMS. (Applause)

00:20:48.958 --> 00:20:52.958
So now let me get to our TED wish.

00:20:52.958 --> 00:20:57.958
Well, it's not my TED wish; it's our wish, as you've already gathered.

00:20:57.958 --> 00:21:00.958
And our wish has two parts:

00:21:00.958 --> 00:21:05.958
one is a dream and the other's a plan. OK.

00:21:05.958 --> 00:21:21.958
Our TED dream is that the next Einstein will be African. (Applause)

00:21:24.958 --> 00:21:25.958
In striving for the heights of creative genius,

00:21:25.958 --> 00:21:30.958
we want to give thousands of people the motivation,

00:21:30.958 --> 00:21:32.958
the encouragement and the courage

00:21:32.958 --> 00:21:37.958
to obtain the high-level skills they need to help Africa.

00:21:37.958 --> 00:21:40.958
Among them will be not only brilliant scientists --

00:21:40.958 --> 00:21:43.958
I'm sure of that from what we've seen at AIMS --

00:21:43.958 --> 00:21:49.958
they'll also be the African Gates, Brins and Pages of the future.

00:21:49.958 --> 00:21:53.958
Well, I said we also have a plan. And our plan is quite simple.

00:21:53.958 --> 00:21:55.958
AIMS is now a proven model.

00:21:55.958 --> 00:21:59.958
And what we need to do is to replicate it.

00:21:59.958 --> 00:22:03.958
We want to roll out 15 AIMS centers in the next five years, all over Africa.

00:22:03.958 --> 00:22:08.958
Each will have a pan-African student body,

00:22:08.958 --> 00:22:10.958
but specialize in a different area of science.

00:22:10.958 --> 00:22:15.958
We want to use science to overcome the national and cultural barriers,

00:22:15.958 --> 00:22:16.958
as it does at AIMS.

00:22:16.958 --> 00:22:18.958
And we want to add elements to the curriculum.

00:22:18.958 --> 00:22:23.958
We want to add entrepreneurship and policy skills.

00:22:23.958 --> 00:22:26.958
The expanded AIMS will be a coherent pan-African institution,

00:22:26.958 --> 00:22:30.958
and its graduates will form a powerful network,

00:22:30.958 --> 00:22:36.958
working together for peace and progress across the continent.

00:22:36.958 --> 00:22:38.958
Over the last year,

00:22:38.958 --> 00:22:40.958
we've been visiting sites in Africa,

00:22:40.958 --> 00:22:43.958
looking at potential sites for new AIMS centers.

00:22:43.958 --> 00:22:45.958
And here are the ones we've selected.

00:22:45.958 --> 00:22:49.958
And each of these centers has a strong local team,

00:22:49.958 --> 00:22:51.958
each is in a beautiful place, an interesting place,

00:22:51.958 --> 00:22:54.958
which international lecturers will be happy to visit.

00:22:54.958 --> 00:22:59.958
And our partners across Africa are extremely enthusiastic about this.

00:22:59.958 --> 00:23:03.958
Everyone wants an AIMS center in their country.

00:23:03.958 --> 00:23:05.958
And last November,

00:23:05.958 --> 00:23:09.958
the conference of all the African ministers of science and technology,

00:23:09.958 --> 00:23:14.958
held in Mombasa, called for a comprehensive plan to roll out AIMS.

00:23:14.958 --> 00:23:17.958
So we have political support right across the continent.

00:23:17.958 --> 00:23:20.958
It won't be easy.

00:23:20.958 --> 00:23:22.958
At every site there will be huge challenges.

00:23:22.958 --> 00:23:25.958
Local scientists must play leading roles

00:23:25.958 --> 00:23:29.958
and governments must be persuaded to buy in.

00:23:29.958 --> 00:23:31.958
Conditions are very difficult,

00:23:31.958 --> 00:23:38.958
but we cannot afford to compromise on those principles which made AIMS work.

00:23:38.958 --> 00:23:40.958
And we summarize them this way:

00:23:40.958 --> 00:23:43.958
the institutes have got to be relevant, innovative,

00:23:43.958 --> 00:23:45.958
cost-effective and high quality. Why?

00:23:45.958 --> 00:23:48.958
Because we want Africa to be rich.

00:23:48.958 --> 00:23:55.958
Easy to remember the basic rules we need.

00:23:55.958 --> 00:23:58.958
So, just in ending, let me say the only people who can fix Africa

00:23:58.958 --> 00:24:01.958
are talented young Africans.

00:24:01.958 --> 00:24:04.958
