By unlocking and nurturing their creative potential,

00:24:04.958 --> 00:24:08.958
we can create a step change in Africa's future.

00:24:08.958 --> 00:24:12.958
Over time, they will contribute to African development

00:24:12.958 --> 00:24:15.958
and to science in ways we can only imagine.

00:24:15.958 --> 00:24:17.958
Thank you.

00:24:17.958 --> 00:24:38.958
(Applause)

title: My green agenda for architecture
transcript: As an architect you design for the present, with an awareness of the past, for a future which is essentially unknown. The green agenda is probably the most important agenda and issue of the day. And I'd like to share some experience over the last 40 years — we celebrate our fortieth anniversary this year — and to explore and to touch on some observations about the nature of sustainability. How far you can anticipate, what follows from it, what are the threats, what are the possibilities, the challenges, the opportunities? I think that — I've said in the past, many, many years ago, before anybody even invented the concept of a green agenda, that it wasn't about fashion — it was about survival.But what I never said, and what I'm really going to make the point is, that really, green is cool. I mean, all the projects which have, in some way, been inspired by that agenda are about a celebratory lifestyle, in a way celebrating the places and the spaces which determine the quality of life. I rarely actually quote anything, so I'm going to try and find a piece of paper if I can, [in] which somebody, at the end of last year, ventured the thought about what for that individual, as a kind of important observer, analyst, writer — a guy called Thomas Friedman, who wrote in the Herald Tribune, about 2006. He said, "I think the most important thing to happen in 2006 was that living and thinking green hit Main Street. We reached a tipping point this year where living, acting, designing, investing and manufacturing green came to be understood by a critical mass of citizens, entrepreneurs and officials as the most patriotic, capitalistic, geo-political and competitive thing they could do. Hence my motto: green is the new red, white and blue."And I asked myself, in a way, looking back, "When did that kind of awareness of the planet and its fragility first appear?" And I think it was July 20, 1969, when, for the first time, man could look back at planet Earth. And, in a way, it was Buckminster Fuller who coined that phrase. And before the kind of collapse of the communist system, I was privileged to meet a lot of cosmonauts in Space City and other places in Russia. And interestingly, as I think back, they were the first true environmentalists. They were filled with a kind of pioneering passion, fired about the problems of the Aral Sea. And at that period it was — in a way, a number of things were happening. Buckminster Fuller was the kind of green guru — again, a word that had not been coined. He was a design scientist, if you like, a poet, but he foresaw all the things that are happening now. It's another subject. It's another conversation. You can go back to his writings: it's quite extraordinary. It was at that time, with an awareness fired by Bucky's prophecies, his concerns as a citizen, as a kind of citizen of the planet, that influenced my thinking and what we were doing at that time.And it's a number of projects. I select this one because it was 1973, and it was a master plan for one of the Canary Islands. And this probably coincided with the time when you had the planet Earth's sourcebook, and you had the hippie movement. And there are some of those qualities in this drawing, which seeks to sum up the recommendations. And all the components are there which are now in common parlance, in our vocabulary, you know, 30-odd years later: wind energy, recycling, biomass, solar cells. And in parallel at that time, there was a very kind of exclusive design club. People who were really design conscious were inspired by the work of Dieter Rams, and the objects that he would create for the company called Braun. This is going back the mid-'50s, '60s. And despite Bucky's prophecies that everything would be miniaturized and technology would make an incredible style — access to comfort, to amenities — it was very, very difficult to imagine that everything that we see in this image, would be very, very stylishly packaged. And that, and more besides, would be in the palm of your hand.And I think that that digital revolution now is coming to the point where, as the virtual world, which brings so many people together here, finally connects with the physical world, there is the reality that that has become humanized, so that digital world has all the friendliness, all the immediacy, the orientation of the analog world. Probably summed up in a way by the stylish or alternative available here, as we generously had gifted at lunchtime, the [unclear], which is a further kind of development — and again, inspired by the incredible sort of sensual feel. A very, very beautiful object. So, something which in [the] '50s, '60s was very exclusive has now become, interestingly, quite inclusive. And the reference to the iPod as iconic, and in a way evocative of performance, delivery — quite interesting that [in] the beginning of the year 2007, the Financial Times commented that the Detroit companies envy the halo effect that Toyota has gained from the Prius as the hybrid, energy-conscious vehicle, which rivals the iPod as an iconic product.And I think it's very tempting to, in a way, seduce ourselves — as architects, or anybody involved with the design process — that the answer to our problems lies with buildings. Buildings are important, but they're only a component of a much bigger picture. In other words, as I might seek to demonstrate, if you could achieve the impossible, the equivalent of perpetual motion, you could design a carbon-free house, for example. That would be the answer. Unfortunately, it's not the answer. It's only the beginning of the problem. You cannot separate the buildings out from the infrastructure of cites and the mobility of transit. For example, if, in that Bucky-inspired phrase, we draw back and we look at planet Earth, and we take a kind of typical, industrialized society, then the energy consumed would be split between the buildings, 44 percent, transport, 34 percent, and industry. But again, that only shows part of the picture. If you looked at the buildings together with the associated transport, in other words, the transport of people, which is 26 percent, then 70 percent of the energy consumption is influenced by the way that our cites and infrastructure work together.So the problems of sustainability cannot be separated from the nature of the cities, of which the buildings are a part. For example, if you take, and you make a comparison between a recent kind of city, what I'll call, simplistically, a North American city — and Detroit is not a bad example, it is very car dependent. The city goes out in annular rings, consuming more and more green space, and more and more roads, and more and more energy in the transport of people between the city center — which again, the city center, as it becomes deprived of the living and just becomes commercial, again becomes dead. If you compared Detroit with a city of a Northern European example — and Munich is not a bad example of that, with the greater dependence on walking and cycling — then a city which is really only twice as dense, is only using one-tenth of the energy. In other words, you take these comparable examples and the energy leap is enormous.So basically, if you wanted to generalize, you can demonstrate that as the density increases along the bottom there, that the energy consumed reduces dramatically. Of course you can't separate this out from issues like social diversity, mass transit, the ability to be able to walk a convenient distance, the quality of civic spaces. But again, you can see Detroit, in yellow at the top, extraordinary consumption, down below Copenhagen. And Copenhagen, although it's a dense city, is not dense compared with the really dense cities. In the year 2000, a rather interesting thing happened. You had for the first time mega-cities, [of] 5 million or more, which were occurring in the developing world. And now, out of typically 46 cities, 33 of those mega-cities are in the developing world. So you have to ask yourself — the environmental impact of, for example, China or India. If you take China, and you just take Beijing, you can see on that traffic system, and the pollution associated with the consumption of energy as the cars expand at the price of the bicycles. In other words, if you put onto the roads, as is currently happening, 1,000 new cars every day — statistically, it's the biggest booming auto market in the world — and the half a billion bicycles serving one and a third billion people are reducing.And that urbanization is extraordinary, accelerated pace. So, if we think of the transition in our society of the movement from the land to the cities, which took 200 years, then that same process is happening in 20 years. In other words, it is accelerating by a factor of 10. And quite interestingly, over something like a 60-year period, we're seeing the doubling in life expectancy, over that period where the urbanization has trebled. If I pull back from that global picture, and I look at the implication over a similar period of time in terms of the technology — which, as a tool, is a tool for designers, and I cite our own experience as a company, and I just illustrate that by a small selection of projects — then how do you measure that change of technology? How does it affect the design of buildings? And particularly, how can it lead to the creation of buildings which consume less energy, create less pollution and are more socially responsible?That story, in terms of buildings, started in the late '60s, early '70s. The one example I take is a corporate headquarters for a company called Willis and Faber, in a small market town in the northeast of England, commuting distance with London. And here, the first thing you can see is that this building, the roof is a very warm kind of overcoat blanket, a kind of insulating garden, which is also about the celebration of public space. In other words, for this community, they have this garden in the sky. So the humanistic ideal is very, very strong in all this work, encapsulated perhaps by one of my early sketches here, where you can see greenery, you can see sunlight, you have a connection with nature. And nature is part of the generator, the driver for this building. And symbolically, the colors of the interior are green and yellow. It has facilities like swimming pools, it has flextime, it has a social heart, a space, you have contact with nature. Now this was 1973.In 2001, this building received an award. And the award was about a celebration for a building which had been in use over a long period of time. And the people who'd created it came back: the project managers, the company chairmen then. And they were saying, you know, "The architects, Norman was always going on about designing for the future, and you know, it didn't seem to cost us any more. So we humored him, we kept him happy." The image at the top, what it doesn't — if you look at it in detail, really what it is saying is you can wire this building. This building was wired for change. So, in 1975, the image there is of typewriters. And when the photograph was taken, it's word processors. And what they were saying on this occasion was that our competitors had to build new buildings for the new technology. We were fortunate, because in a way our building was future-proofed. It anticipated change, even though those changes were not known. Round about that design period leading up to this building, I did a sketch, which we pulled out of the archive recently. And I was saying, and I wrote, "But we don't have the time, and we really don't have the immediate expertise at a technical level."In other words, we didn't have the technology to do what would be really interesting on that building. And that would be to create a kind of three-dimensional bubble — a really interesting overcoat that would naturally ventilate, would breathe and would seriously reduce the energy loads. Notwithstanding the fact that the building, as a green building, is very much a pioneering building. And if I fast-forward in time, what is interesting is that the technology is now available and celebratory. The library of the Free University, which opened last year, is an example of that. And again, the transition from one of the many thousands of sketches and computer images to the reality. And a combination of devices here, the kind of heavy mass concrete of these book stacks, and the way in which that is enclosed by this skin, which enables the building to be ventilated, to consume dramatically less energy, and where it's really working with the forces of nature.And what is interesting is that this is hugely popular by the people who use it. Again, coming back to that thing about the lifestyle, and in a way, the ecological agenda is very much at one with the spirit. So it's not a kind of sacrifice, quite the reverse. I think it's a great — it's a celebration. And you can measure the performance, in terms of energy consumption, of that building against a typical library. If I show another aspect of that technology then, in a completely different context — this apartment building in the Alps in Switzerland. Prefabricated from the most traditional of materials, but that material — because of the technology, the computing ability, the ability to prefabricate, make high-performance components out of timber — very much at the cutting edge. And just to give a sort of glimpse of that technology, the ability to plot points in the sky and to transmit, to transfer that information now, directly into the factory.So if you cross the border — just across the border — a small factory in Germany, and here you can see the guy with his computer screen, and those points in space are communicated. And on the left are the cutting machines, which then, in the factory, enable those individual pieces to be fabricated and plus or minus very, very few millimeters, to be slotted together on site. And then interestingly, that building to then be clad in the oldest technology, which is the kind of hand-cut shingles. One quarter of a million of them applied by hand as the final finish. And again, the way in which that works as a building, for those of us who can enjoy the spaces, to live and visit there. If I made the leap into these new technologies, then how did we — what happened before that? I mean, you know, what was life like before the mobile phone, the things that you take for granted?Well, obviously the building still happened. I mean, this is a glimpse of the interior of our Hong Kong bank of 1979, which opened in 1985, with the ability to be able to reflect sunlight deep into the heart of this space here. And in the absence of computers, you have to physically model. So for example, we would put models under an artificial sky. For wind tunnels, we would literally put them in a wind tunnel and blast air, and the many kilometers of cable and so on. And the turning point was probably, in our terms, when we had the first computer. And that was at the time that we sought to redesign, reinvent the airport. This is Terminal Four at Heathrow, typical of any terminal — big, heavy roof, blocking out the sunlight, lots of machinery, big pipes, whirring machinery.And Stansted, the green alternative, which uses natural light, is a friendly place: you know where you are, you can relate to the outside. And for a large part of its cycle, not needing electric light — electric light, which in turn creates more heat, which creates more cooling loads and so on. And at that particular point in time, this was one of the few solitary computers. And that's a little image of the tree of Stansted. Not going back very far in time, 1990, that's our office. And if you looked very closely, you'd see that people were drawing with pencils, and they were pushing, you know, big rulers and triangles. It's not that long ago, 17 years, and here we are now. I mean, major transformation.Going back in time, there was a lady called Valerie Larkin, and in 1987, she had all our information on one disk. Now, every week, we have the equivalent of 84 million disks, which record our archival information on past, current and future projects. That reaches 21 kilometers into the sky. This is the view you would get, if you looked down on that. But meanwhile, as you know, wonderful protagonists like Al Gore are noting the inexorable rise in temperature, set in the context of that, interestingly, those buildings which are celebratory and very, very relevant to this place.Our Reichstag project, which has a very familiar agenda, I'm sure, as a public place where we sought to, in a way, through a process of advocacy, reinterpret the relationship between society and politicians, public space. And maybe its hidden agenda, an energy manifesto — something that would be free, completely free of fuel as we know it. So it would be totally renewable. And again, the humanistic sketch, the translation into the public space, but this very, very much a part of the ecology. But here, not having to model it for real. Obviously the wind tunnel had a place, but the ability now with the computer to explore, to plan, to see how that would work in terms of the forces of nature: natural ventilation, to be able to model the chamber below, and to look at biomass. A combination of biomass, aquifers, burning vegetable oil — a process that, quite interestingly, was developed in Eastern Germany, at the time of its dependence on the Soviet Bloc.So really, retranslating that technology and developing something which was so clean, it was virtually pollution-free. You can measure it again. You can compare how that building, in terms of its emission in tons of carbon dioxide per year — at the time that we took that project, over 7,000 tons — what it would have been with natural gas and finally, with the vegetable oil, 450 tons. I mean, a 94 percent reduction — virtually clean. We can see the same processes at work in terms of the Commerce Bank — its dependence on natural ventilation, the way that you can model those gardens, the way they spiral around. But again, very much about the lifestyle, the quality — something that would be more enjoyable as a place to work. And again, we can measure the reduction in terms of energy consumption.There is an evolution here between the projects, and Swiss Re again develops that a little bit further — the project in the city in London. And this sequence shows the buildup of that model. But what it shows first, which I think is quite interesting, is that here you see the circle, you see the public space around it. What are the other ways of putting the same amount of space on the site? If, for example, you seek to do a building which goes right to the edge of the pavement, it's the same amount of space. And finally, you profile this, you cut grooves into it. The grooves become the kind of green lungs which give views, which give light, ventilation, make the building fresher. And you enclose that with something that also is central to its appearance, which is a mesh of triangulated structures — again, in a long connection evocative of some of those works of Buckminster Fuller, and the way in which triangulation can increase performance and also give that building its sense of identity.And here, if we look at a detail of the way that the building opens up and breathes into those atria, the way in which now, with a computer, we can model the forces, we can see the high pressure, the low pressure, the way in which the building behaves rather like an aircraft wing. So it also has the ability, all the time, regardless of the direction of the wind, to be able to make the building fresh and efficient. And unlike conventional buildings, the top of the building is celebratory. It's a viewing place for people, not machinery. And the base of the building is again about public space. Comparing it with a typical building, what happens if we seek to use such design strategies in terms of really large-scale thinking? And I'm just going to give two images out of a kind of company research project.It's been well known that the Dead Sea is dying. The level is dropping, rather like the Aral Sea. And the Dead Sea is obviously much lower than the oceans and seas around it. So there has been a project which rescues the Dead Sea by creating a pipeline, a pipe, sometimes above the surface, sometimes buried, that will redress that, and will feed from the Gulf of Aqaba into the Dead Sea. And our translation of that, using a lot of the thinking built up over the 40 years, is to say, what if that, instead of being just a pipe, what if it is a lifeline? What if it is the equivalent, depending on where you are, of the Grand Canal, in terms of tourists, habitation, desalination, agriculture? In other words, water is the lifeblood.And if you just go back to the previous image, and you look at this area of volatility and hostility, that a unifying design idea as a humanitarian gesture could have the affect of bringing all those warring factions together in a united cause, in terms of something that would be genuinely green and productive in the widest sense. Infrastructure at that large scale is also inseparable from communication. And whether that communication is the virtual world or it is the physical world, then it's absolutely central to society. And how do we make more legible in this growing world, especially in some of the places that I'm talking about — China, for example, which in the next ten years will create 400 new airports. Now what form do they take? How do you make them more friendly at that scale?Hong Kong I refer to as a kind of analog experience in a digital age, because you always have a point of reference. So what happens when we take that and you expand that further into the Chinese society? And what is interesting is that that produces in a way perhaps the ultimate mega-building. It is physically the largest project on the planet at the moment. 250 — excuse me, 50,000 people working 24 hours, seven days. Larger by 17 percent than every terminal put together at Heathrow — built — plus the new, un-built Terminal Five. And the challenge here is a building that will be green, that is compact despite its size and is about the human experience of travel, is about friendly, is coming back to that starting point, is very, very much about the lifestyle. And perhaps these, in the end, as celebratory spaces.As Hubert was talking over lunch, as we sort of engaged in conversation, talked about this, talked about cities. Hubert was saying, absolutely correctly, "These are the new cathedrals." And in a way, one aspect of this conversation was triggered on New Year's Eve, when I was talking about the Olympic agenda in China in terms of its green ambitions and aspirations. And I was voicing the thought that — it just crossed my mind that New Year's Eve, a sort of symbolic turning point as we move from 2006 to 2007 — that maybe, you know, the future was the most powerful, innovative sort of nation. The way in which somebody like Kennedy inspirationally could say, "We put a man on the moon."You know, who is going to say that we cracked this thing of the dependence on fossil fuels, with all that being held to ransom by rogue regimes, and so on. And that's a concerted platform. It's more than one device, you know, it's renewable. And I voiced the thought that maybe at the turn of the year, I thought that the inspiration was more likely to come from those other, larger countries out there — the Chinas, the Indias, the Asian-Pacific tigers. Thank you very much.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:18.958
As an architect you design for the present,

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:21.958
with an awareness of the past,

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:28.958
for a future which is essentially unknown.

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:32.958
The green agenda is probably the most important agenda

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:35.958
and issue of the day.

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:39.958
And I'd like to share some experience

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:44.958
over the last 40 years -- we celebrate our fortieth anniversary this year --

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:50.958
and to explore and to touch on some observations

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:54.958
about the nature of sustainability.

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:57.958
How far you can anticipate, what follows from it,

00:00:57.958 --> 00:00:59.958
what are the threats, what are the possibilities,

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:02.958
the challenges, the opportunities?

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:06.958
I think that -- I've said in the past, many, many years ago,

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:12.958
before anybody even invented the concept of a green agenda,

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:18.958
that it wasn't about fashion -- it was about survival.

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:23.958
But what I never said, and what I'm really going to make the point is,

00:01:23.958 --> 00:01:26.958
that really, green is cool.

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:31.958
I mean, all the projects which have, in some way, been inspired

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:36.958
by that agenda are about a celebratory lifestyle,

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:41.958
in a way celebrating the places and the spaces

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:44.958
which determine the quality of life.

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:48.958
I rarely actually quote anything,

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:52.958
so I'm going to try and find a piece of paper if I can,

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:58.958
[in] which somebody, at the end of last year, ventured the thought

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:03.958
about what for that individual, as a kind of important observer,

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:07.958
analyst, writer -- a guy called Thomas Friedman,

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:13.958
who wrote in the Herald Tribune, about 2006.

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:16.958
He said,

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:19.958
"I think the most important thing to happen in 2006

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:24.958
was that living and thinking green hit Main Street.

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:27.958
We reached a tipping point this year

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:32.958
where living, acting, designing, investing and manufacturing green

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:34.958
came to be understood by a critical mass

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:37.958
of citizens, entrepreneurs and officials

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:40.958
as the most patriotic, capitalistic, geo-political

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:43.958
and competitive thing they could do.

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:49.958
Hence my motto: green is the new red, white and blue."

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:53.958
And I asked myself, in a way, looking back,

00:02:53.958 --> 00:03:03.958
"When did that kind of awareness of the planet and its fragility first appear?"

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:07.958
And I think it was July 20, 1969,

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:13.958
when, for the first time, man could look back at planet Earth.

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:19.958
And, in a way, it was Buckminster Fuller who coined that phrase.

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:25.958
And before the kind of collapse of the communist system,

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:28.958
I was privileged to meet a lot of cosmonauts

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
in Space City and other places in Russia.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:33.958
And interestingly, as I think back,

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:37.958
they were the first true environmentalists.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:42.958
They were filled with a kind of pioneering passion,

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:45.958
fired about the problems of the Aral Sea.

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:48.958
And at that period it was --

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:50.958
in a way, a number of things were happening.

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:55.958
Buckminster Fuller was the kind of green guru --

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
again, a word that had not been coined.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:01.958
He was a design scientist, if you like, a poet,

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:05.958
but he foresaw all the things that are happening now.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:08.958
It's another subject. It's another conversation.

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:13.958
You can go back to his writings: it's quite extraordinary.

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:18.958
It was at that time, with an awareness

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:23.958
fired by Bucky's prophecies, his concerns

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:28.958
as a citizen, as a kind of citizen of the planet,

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:32.958
that influenced my thinking and what we were doing at that time.

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:35.958
And it's a number of projects.

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:41.958
I select this one because it was 1973, and it was a master plan

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:43.958
for one of the Canary Islands.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:47.958
And this probably coincided with the time

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:50.958
when you had the planet Earth's sourcebook,

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:52.958
and you had the hippie movement.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:56.958
And there are some of those qualities in this drawing,

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:59.958
which seeks to sum up the recommendations.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:02.958
And all the components are there which are now

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:05.958
in common parlance, in our vocabulary,

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
you know, 30-odd years later:

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:13.958
wind energy, recycling, biomass, solar cells.

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:17.958
And in parallel at that time, there was

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:22.958
a very kind of exclusive design club.

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:25.958
People who were really design conscious

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:28.958
were inspired by the work of Dieter Rams,

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.958
and the objects that he would create

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
for the company called Braun.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:36.958
This is going back the mid-'50s, '60s.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:39.958
And despite Bucky's prophecies

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:42.958
that everything would be miniaturized

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:45.958
and technology would make an incredible style --

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:49.958
access to comfort, to amenities --

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:52.958
it was very, very difficult to imagine

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
that everything that we see in this image,

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
would be very, very stylishly packaged.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:00.958
And that, and more besides, would be in the palm of your hand.

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:04.958
And I think that that digital revolution

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:07.958
now is coming to the point

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:13.958
where, as the virtual world, which brings so many people together here,

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
finally connects with the physical world,

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:21.958
there is the reality that that has become humanized,

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:25.958
so that digital world has all the friendliness,

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:29.958
all the immediacy, the orientation of the analog world.

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:31.958
Probably summed up in a way

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:35.958
by the stylish or alternative available here,

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:39.958
as we generously had gifted at lunchtime,

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:43.958
the [unclear], which is a further kind of development --

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:47.958
and again, inspired by the incredible sort of sensual feel.

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:49.958
A very, very beautiful object.

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:54.958
So, something which in [the] '50s, '60s was very exclusive

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:57.958
has now become, interestingly, quite inclusive.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:01.958
And the reference to the iPod as iconic,

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:06.958
and in a way evocative of performance, delivery --

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:09.958
quite interesting that [in] the beginning of the year 2007,

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:13.958
the Financial Times commented that the Detroit companies

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:16.958
envy the halo effect that Toyota has gained

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:21.958
from the Prius as the hybrid, energy-conscious vehicle,

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
which rivals the iPod as an iconic product.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:28.958
And I think it's very tempting to, in a way, seduce ourselves --

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:31.958
as architects, or anybody involved with the design process --

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:35.958
that the answer to our problems lies with buildings.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
Buildings are important, but

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
they're only a component of a much bigger picture.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
In other words, as I might seek to demonstrate,

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
if you could achieve the impossible,

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
the equivalent of perpetual motion,

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:51.958
you could design a carbon-free house, for example.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:52.958
That would be the answer.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
Unfortunately, it's not the answer.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
It's only the beginning of the problem.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
You cannot separate the buildings out

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:00.958
from the infrastructure of cites

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:02.958
and the mobility of transit.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:08.958
For example, if, in that Bucky-inspired phrase, we draw back

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
and we look at planet Earth,

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
and we take a kind of typical, industrialized society,

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
then the energy consumed would be split

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:22.958
between the buildings, 44 percent, transport, 34 percent, and industry.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
But again, that only shows part of the picture.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:29.958
If you looked at the buildings together with the associated transport,

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:34.958
in other words, the transport of people, which is 26 percent,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
then 70 percent of the energy consumption

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:43.958
is influenced by the way that our cites and infrastructure work together.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:46.958
So the problems of sustainability

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
cannot be separated from the nature of the cities,

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.958
of which the buildings are a part.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:56.958
For example, if you take, and you make a comparison

00:08:56.958 --> 00:09:00.958
between a recent kind of city,

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:03.958
what I'll call, simplistically, a North American city --

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:08.958
and Detroit is not a bad example, it is very car dependent.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:11.958
The city goes out in annular rings,

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
consuming more and more green space,

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:17.958
and more and more roads, and more and more energy

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:21.958
in the transport of people between the city center --

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:24.958
which again, the city center, as it becomes deprived

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:29.958
of the living and just becomes commercial, again becomes dead.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:35.958
If you compared Detroit with a city of a Northern European example --

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:39.958
and Munich is not a bad example of that,

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:44.958
with the greater dependence on walking and cycling --

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:50.958
then a city which is really only twice as dense,

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:54.958
is only using one-tenth of the energy.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
In other words, you take these comparable examples

00:09:56.958 --> 00:10:00.958
and the energy leap is enormous.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:06.958
So basically, if you wanted to generalize, you can demonstrate

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:11.958
that as the density increases along the bottom there,

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:15.958
that the energy consumed reduces dramatically.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
Of course you can't separate this out from issues like

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.958
social diversity, mass transit,

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:25.958
the ability to be able to walk a convenient distance,

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
the quality of civic spaces.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:32.958
But again, you can see Detroit, in yellow at the top,

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.958
extraordinary consumption, down below Copenhagen.

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
And Copenhagen, although it's a dense city,

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:42.958
is not dense compared with the really dense cities.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:47.958
In the year 2000, a rather interesting thing happened.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:51.958
You had for the first time mega-cities, [of] 5 million or more,

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:55.958
which were occurring in the developing world.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:58.958
And now, out of typically 46 cities,

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:03.958
33 of those mega-cities are in the developing world.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:07.958
So you have to ask yourself -- the environmental impact of,

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
for example, China or India.

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:14.958
If you take China, and you just take Beijing,

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
you can see on that traffic system,

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:23.958
and the pollution associated with the consumption of energy

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:30.958
as the cars expand at the price of the bicycles.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:35.958
In other words, if you put onto the roads, as is currently happening,

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:39.958
1,000 new cars every day --

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:45.958
statistically, it's the biggest booming auto market in the world --

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:53.958
and the half a billion bicycles serving one and a third billion people are reducing.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:12:00.958
And that urbanization is extraordinary, accelerated pace.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:07.958
So, if we think of the transition in our society

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:12.958
of the movement from the land to the cities, which took 200 years,

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:17.958
then that same process is happening in 20 years.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:22.958
In other words, it is accelerating by a factor of 10.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:30.958
And quite interestingly, over something like a 60-year period,

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.958
we're seeing the doubling in life expectancy,

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:39.958
over that period where the urbanization has trebled.

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:42.958
If I pull back from that global picture,

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:46.958
and I look at the implication over a similar period of time

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:50.958
in terms of the technology -- which, as a tool,

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
is a tool for designers,

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:56.958
and I cite our own experience as a company,

00:12:56.958 --> 00:13:01.958
and I just illustrate that by a small selection of projects --

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:06.958
then how do you measure that change of technology?

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:09.958
How does it affect the design of buildings?

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:12.958
And particularly, how can it lead

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:16.958
to the creation of buildings which consume less energy,

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:21.958
create less pollution and are more socially responsible?

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:27.958
That story, in terms of buildings, started in the late '60s, early '70s.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
The one example I take is a corporate headquarters

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:33.958
for a company called Willis and Faber,

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:40.958
in a small market town in the northeast of England,

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
commuting distance with London.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:45.958
And here, the first thing you can see

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:50.958
is that this building, the roof is a very warm kind of

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:53.958
overcoat blanket, a kind of insulating garden,

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:57.958
which is also about the celebration of public space.

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:01.958
In other words, for this community, they have this garden in the sky.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:06.958
So the humanistic ideal is very, very strong in all this work,

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:11.958
encapsulated perhaps by one of my early sketches here,

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:14.958
where you can see greenery, you can see sunlight,

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
you have a connection with nature.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:21.958
And nature is part of the generator, the driver for this building.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:25.958
And symbolically, the colors of the interior are green and yellow.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:29.958
It has facilities like swimming pools, it has flextime,

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:34.958
it has a social heart, a space, you have contact with nature.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
Now this was 1973.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:41.958
In 2001, this building received an award.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:44.958
And the award was about a celebration for a building

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:48.958
which had been in use over a long period of time.

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:51.958
And the people who'd created it came back:

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:55.958
the project managers, the company chairmen then.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:56.958
And they were saying, you know,

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:59.958
"The architects, Norman was always going on about

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
designing for the future, and you know,

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
it didn't seem to cost us any more.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:07.958
So we humored him, we kept him happy."

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
The image at the top,

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
what it doesn't -- if you look at it in detail,

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:15.958
really what it is saying is you can wire this building.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:19.958
This building was wired for change.

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:23.958
So, in 1975, the image there is of typewriters.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:28.958
And when the photograph was taken, it's word processors.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:32.958
And what they were saying on this occasion was that our competitors

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:36.958
had to build new buildings for the new technology.

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
We were fortunate,

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
because in a way our building was future-proofed.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:46.958
It anticipated change, even though those changes were not known.

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:50.958
Round about that design period leading up to this building,

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:55.958
I did a sketch, which we pulled out of the archive recently.

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:59.958
And I was saying, and I wrote, "But we don't have the time,

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:02.958
and we really don't have the immediate expertise

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:03.958
at a technical level."

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:05.958
In other words, we didn't have the technology

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:09.958
to do what would be really interesting on that building.

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:13.958
And that would be to create a kind of three-dimensional bubble --

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:18.958
a really interesting overcoat that would naturally ventilate,

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:23.958
would breathe and would seriously reduce the energy loads.

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:26.958
Notwithstanding the fact that the building, as a green building,

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:28.958
is very much a pioneering building.

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:31.958
And if I fast-forward in time, what is interesting

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:36.958
is that the technology is now available and celebratory.

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:42.958
The library of the Free University, which opened last year,

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:44.958
is an example of that.

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:48.958
And again, the transition from one of the many thousands

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:52.958
of sketches and computer images to the reality.

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:54.958
And a combination of devices here,

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:58.958
the kind of heavy mass concrete of these book stacks,

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:04.958
and the way in which that is enclosed by this skin,

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:08.958
which enables the building to be ventilated,

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:11.958
to consume dramatically less energy,

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:14.958
and where it's really working with the forces of nature.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:20.958
And what is interesting is that this is hugely popular

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:22.958
by the people who use it.

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:25.958
Again, coming back to that thing about the lifestyle,

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:34.958
and in a way, the ecological agenda is very much at one with the spirit.

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:37.958
So it's not a kind of sacrifice, quite the reverse.

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:40.958
I think it's a great -- it's a celebration.

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:44.958
And you can measure the performance,

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:47.958
in terms of energy consumption, of that building

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:50.958
against a typical library.

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:53.958
If I show another aspect of that technology

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:57.958
then, in a completely different context --

00:17:57.958 --> 00:18:02.958
this apartment building in the Alps in Switzerland.

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:05.958
Prefabricated from the most traditional of materials,

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:10.958
but that material -- because of the technology, the computing ability,

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:14.958
the ability to prefabricate, make high-performance components

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:18.958
out of timber -- very much at the cutting edge.

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:21.958
And just to give a sort of glimpse of that technology,

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:29.958
the ability to plot points in the sky

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:36.958
and to transmit, to transfer that information

00:18:36.958 --> 00:18:41.958
now, directly into the factory.

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:44.958
So if you cross the border -- just across the border --

00:18:44.958 --> 00:18:50.958
a small factory in Germany, and here you can see the guy with his computer screen,

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:54.958
and those points in space are communicated.

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:57.958
And on the left are the cutting machines,

00:18:57.958 --> 00:18:59.958
which then, in the factory,

00:18:59.958 --> 00:19:03.958
enable those individual pieces to be fabricated

00:19:03.958 --> 00:19:06.958
and plus or minus very, very few millimeters,

00:19:06.958 --> 00:19:09.958
to be slotted together on site.

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:15.958
And then interestingly, that building to then be clad

00:19:15.958 --> 00:19:21.958
in the oldest technology, which is the kind of hand-cut shingles.

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:28.958
One quarter of a million of them applied by hand as the final finish.

00:19:28.958 --> 00:19:32.958
And again, the way in which that works as a building,

00:19:32.958 --> 00:19:36.958
for those of us who can enjoy the spaces,

00:19:36.958 --> 00:19:39.958
to live and visit there.

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:43.958
If I made the leap into these new technologies,

00:19:43.958 --> 00:19:46.958
then how did we -- what happened before that?

00:19:46.958 --> 00:19:52.958
I mean, you know, what was life like before the mobile phone,

00:19:52.958 --> 00:19:55.958
the things that you take for granted?

00:19:55.958 --> 00:19:57.958
Well, obviously the building still happened.

00:19:57.958 --> 00:20:05.958
I mean, this is a glimpse of the interior of our Hong Kong bank of 1979,

00:20:05.958 --> 00:20:10.958
which opened in 1985, with the ability to be able to reflect sunlight

00:20:10.958 --> 00:20:13.958
deep into the heart of this space here.

00:20:13.958 --> 00:20:17.958
And in the absence of computers, you have to physically model.

00:20:17.958 --> 00:20:24.958
So for example, we would put models under an artificial sky.

00:20:24.958 --> 00:20:26.958
For wind tunnels, we would literally put them

00:20:26.958 --> 00:20:29.958
in a wind tunnel and blast air,

00:20:29.958 --> 00:20:33.958
and the many kilometers of cable and so on.

00:20:33.958 --> 00:20:37.958
And the turning point was probably, in our terms,

00:20:37.958 --> 00:20:41.958
when we had the first computer.

00:20:41.958 --> 00:20:45.958
And that was at the time that we sought

00:20:45.958 --> 00:20:49.958
to redesign, reinvent the airport.

00:20:49.958 --> 00:20:54.958
This is Terminal Four at Heathrow, typical of any terminal --

00:20:54.958 --> 00:20:56.958
big, heavy roof, blocking out the sunlight,

00:20:56.958 --> 00:21:01.958
lots of machinery, big pipes, whirring machinery.

00:21:01.958 --> 00:21:06.958
And Stansted, the green alternative,

00:21:06.958 --> 00:21:08.958
which uses natural light, is a friendly place:

00:21:08.958 --> 00:21:12.958
you know where you are, you can relate to the outside.

00:21:12.958 --> 00:21:16.958
And for a large part of its cycle, not needing electric light --

00:21:16.958 --> 00:21:19.958
electric light, which in turn creates more heat,

00:21:19.958 --> 00:21:21.958
which creates more cooling loads and so on.

00:21:21.958 --> 00:21:24.958
And at that particular point in time,

00:21:24.958 --> 00:21:28.958
this was one of the few solitary computers.

00:21:28.958 --> 00:21:34.958
And that's a little image of the tree of Stansted.

00:21:34.958 --> 00:21:37.958
Not going back very far in time, 1990,

00:21:37.958 --> 00:21:40.958
that's our office.

00:21:40.958 --> 00:21:43.958
And if you looked very closely, you'd see

00:21:43.958 --> 00:21:45.958
that people were drawing with pencils,

00:21:45.958 --> 00:21:49.958
and they were pushing, you know, big rulers and triangles.

00:21:49.958 --> 00:21:53.958
It's not that long ago, 17 years, and here we are now.

00:21:53.958 --> 00:21:55.958
I mean, major transformation.

00:21:56.958 --> 00:22:00.958
Going back in time, there was a lady called Valerie Larkin,

00:22:00.958 --> 00:22:07.958
and in 1987, she had all our information on one disk.

00:22:07.958 --> 00:22:16.958
Now, every week, we have the equivalent of 84 million disks,

00:22:16.958 --> 00:22:19.958
which record our archival information

00:22:19.958 --> 00:22:22.958
on past, current and future projects.

00:22:22.958 --> 00:22:26.958
That reaches 21 kilometers into the sky.

00:22:26.958 --> 00:22:29.958
This is the view you would get, if you looked down on that.

00:22:29.958 --> 00:22:31.958
But meanwhile, as you know,

00:22:31.958 --> 00:22:35.958
wonderful protagonists like Al Gore

00:22:35.958 --> 00:22:41.958
are noting the inexorable rise in temperature,

00:22:41.958 --> 00:22:44.958
set in the context of that,

00:22:44.958 --> 00:22:46.958
interestingly, those buildings which are celebratory

00:22:46.958 --> 00:22:50.958
and very, very relevant to this place.

00:22:50.958 --> 00:22:52.958
Our Reichstag project,

00:22:53.958 --> 00:22:57.958
which has a very familiar agenda, I'm sure,

00:22:57.958 --> 00:23:03.958
as a public place where we sought to, in a way,

00:23:03.958 --> 00:23:06.958
through a process of advocacy,

00:23:06.958 --> 00:23:11.958
reinterpret the relationship between society and politicians,

00:23:11.958 --> 00:23:16.958
public space. And maybe its hidden agenda, an energy manifesto --

00:23:16.958 --> 00:23:19.958
something that would be free, completely free

00:23:19.958 --> 00:23:22.958
of fuel as we know it.

00:23:22.958 --> 00:23:24.958
So it would be totally renewable.

00:23:24.958 --> 00:23:29.958
And again, the humanistic sketch, the translation into the public space,

00:23:29.958 --> 00:23:32.958
but this very, very much a part of the ecology.

00:23:32.958 --> 00:23:36.958
But here, not having to model it for real.

00:23:36.958 --> 00:23:39.958
Obviously the wind tunnel had a place,

00:23:39.958 --> 00:23:41.958
but the ability now with the computer

00:23:41.958 --> 00:23:45.958
to explore, to plan, to see how that would work

00:23:45.958 --> 00:23:47.958
in terms of the forces of nature:

00:23:47.958 --> 00:23:51.958
natural ventilation, to be able to model the chamber below,

00:23:51.958 --> 00:23:54.958
and to look at biomass.

00:23:54.958 --> 00:24:01.958
A combination of biomass, aquifers, burning vegetable oil --

00:24:01.958 --> 00:24:05.958
a process that, quite interestingly, was developed

00:24:05.958 --> 00:24:09.958
in Eastern Germany, at the time of its

00:24:09.958 --> 00:24:11.958
dependence on the Soviet Bloc.

00:24:11.958 --> 00:24:15.958
So really, retranslating that technology and developing something

00:24:15.958 --> 00:24:19.958
which was so clean, it was virtually pollution-free.

00:24:19.958 --> 00:24:20.958
You can measure it again.

00:24:20.958 --> 00:24:24.958
You can compare how that building, in terms of its emission

00:24:24.958 --> 00:24:26.958
in tons of carbon dioxide per year --

00:24:26.958 --> 00:24:30.958
at the time that we took that project, over 7,000 tons --

00:24:30.958 --> 00:24:31.958
what it would have been with natural gas

00:24:31.958 --> 00:24:34.958
and finally, with the vegetable oil, 450 tons.

00:24:34.958 --> 00:24:37.958
I mean, a 94 percent reduction -- virtually clean.

00:24:37.958 --> 00:24:39.958
We can see the same processes at work

00:24:39.958 --> 00:24:41.958
in terms of the Commerce Bank --

00:24:41.958 --> 00:24:43.958
its dependence on natural ventilation,

00:24:43.958 --> 00:24:45.958
the way that you can model those gardens,

00:24:45.958 --> 00:24:47.958
the way they spiral around.

00:24:47.958 --> 00:24:51.958
But again, very much about the lifestyle, the quality --

00:24:51.958 --> 00:24:55.958
something that would be more enjoyable as a place to work.

00:24:55.958 --> 00:24:57.958
And again, we can measure the reduction

00:24:57.958 --> 00:25:01.958
in terms of energy consumption.

00:25:01.958 --> 00:25:03.958
There is an evolution here between the projects,

00:25:03.958 --> 00:25:08.958
and Swiss Re again develops that a little bit further --

00:25:08.958 --> 00:25:10.958
the project in the city in London.

00:25:10.958 --> 00:25:14.958
And this sequence shows the buildup of that model.

00:25:14.958 --> 00:25:17.958
But what it shows first, which I think is quite interesting,

00:25:17.958 --> 00:25:22.958
is that here you see the circle, you see the public space around it.

00:25:22.958 --> 00:25:24.958
What are the other ways of putting

00:25:24.958 --> 00:25:27.958
the same amount of space on the site?

00:25:27.958 --> 00:25:31.958
If, for example, you seek to do a building

00:25:31.958 --> 00:25:36.958
which goes right to the edge of the pavement,

00:25:36.958 --> 00:25:39.958
it's the same amount of space.

00:25:39.958 --> 00:25:44.958
And finally, you profile this, you cut grooves into it.

00:25:44.958 --> 00:25:47.958
The grooves become the kind of green lungs

00:25:47.958 --> 00:25:51.958
which give views, which give light, ventilation,

00:25:51.958 --> 00:25:53.958
make the building fresher.

00:25:53.958 --> 00:25:56.958
And you enclose that with something that also

00:25:56.958 --> 00:25:59.958
is central to its appearance,

00:25:59.958 --> 00:26:03.958
which is a mesh of triangulated structures --

00:26:03.958 --> 00:26:06.958
again, in a long connection evocative of

00:26:06.958 --> 00:26:09.958
some of those works of Buckminster Fuller,

00:26:09.958 --> 00:26:13.958
and the way in which triangulation can increase performance

00:26:13.958 --> 00:26:18.958
and also give that building its sense of identity.

00:26:18.958 --> 00:26:21.958
And here, if we look at a detail of the way

00:26:21.958 --> 00:26:24.958
that the building opens up and breathes into those atria,

00:26:24.958 --> 00:26:29.958
the way in which now, with a computer, we can model the forces,

00:26:29.958 --> 00:26:32.958
we can see the high pressure, the low pressure,

00:26:32.958 --> 00:26:36.958
the way in which the building behaves rather like an aircraft wing.

00:26:36.958 --> 00:26:39.958
So it also has the ability, all the time,

00:26:39.958 --> 00:26:41.958
regardless of the direction of the wind,

00:26:41.958 --> 00:26:46.958
to be able to make the building fresh and efficient.

00:26:46.958 --> 00:26:49.958
And unlike conventional buildings,

00:26:49.958 --> 00:26:51.958
the top of the building is celebratory.

00:26:51.958 --> 00:26:54.958
It's a viewing place for people, not machinery.

00:26:54.958 --> 00:26:58.958
And the base of the building is again about public space.

00:26:58.958 --> 00:27:00.958
Comparing it with a typical building,

00:27:00.958 --> 00:27:05.958
what happens if we seek to use such design strategies

00:27:05.958 --> 00:27:09.958
in terms of really large-scale thinking?

00:27:09.958 --> 00:27:11.958
And I'm just going to give two images

00:27:11.958 --> 00:27:17.958
out of a kind of company research project.

00:27:17.958 --> 00:27:23.958
It's been well known that the Dead Sea is dying.

00:27:23.958 --> 00:27:27.958
The level is dropping, rather like the Aral Sea.

00:27:27.958 --> 00:27:31.958
And the Dead Sea is obviously much lower

00:27:31.958 --> 00:27:35.958
than the oceans and seas around it.

00:27:35.958 --> 00:27:39.958
So there has been a project which rescues the Dead Sea

00:27:39.958 --> 00:27:43.958
by creating a pipeline, a pipe,

00:27:43.958 --> 00:27:46.958
sometimes above the surface, sometimes buried,

00:27:46.958 --> 00:27:52.958
that will redress that, and will feed from the Gulf of Aqaba

00:27:52.958 --> 00:27:54.958
into the Dead Sea.

00:27:54.958 --> 00:27:55.958
And our translation of that,

00:27:55.958 --> 00:28:00.958
using a lot of the thinking built up over the 40 years, is to say,

00:28:00.958 --> 00:28:03.958
what if that, instead of being just a pipe,

00:28:03.958 --> 00:28:05.958
what if it is a lifeline?

00:28:05.958 --> 00:28:09.958
What if it is the equivalent, depending on where you are,

00:28:09.958 --> 00:28:11.958
of the Grand Canal,

00:28:11.958 --> 00:28:16.958
in terms of tourists, habitation, desalination, agriculture?

00:28:16.958 --> 00:28:18.958
In other words, water is the lifeblood.

00:28:18.958 --> 00:28:21.958
And if you just go back to the previous image,

00:28:21.958 --> 00:28:25.958
and you look at this area of volatility and hostility,

00:28:25.958 --> 00:28:31.958
that a unifying design idea as a humanitarian gesture

00:28:31.958 --> 00:28:35.958
could have the affect of bringing all those warring factions together

00:28:35.958 --> 00:28:39.958
in a united cause, in terms of something that would be

00:28:39.958 --> 00:28:45.958
genuinely green and productive in the widest sense.

00:28:45.958 --> 00:28:47.958
Infrastructure at that large scale is also

00:28:47.958 --> 00:28:52.958
inseparable from communication.

00:28:52.958 --> 00:28:55.958
And whether that communication is the virtual world

00:28:55.958 --> 00:28:56.958
or it is the physical world,

00:28:56.958 --> 00:28:59.958
then it's absolutely central to society.

00:28:59.958 --> 00:29:04.958
And how do we make more legible in this growing world,

00:29:04.958 --> 00:29:08.958
especially in some of the places that I'm talking about --

00:29:08.958 --> 00:29:10.958
China, for example, which in the next ten years

00:29:10.958 --> 00:29:14.958
will create 400 new airports.

00:29:14.958 --> 00:29:16.958
Now what form do they take?

00:29:16.958 --> 00:29:19.958
How do you make them more friendly at that scale?

00:29:19.958 --> 00:29:26.958
Hong Kong I refer to as a kind of analog experience in a digital age,

00:29:26.958 --> 00:29:28.958
because you always have a point of reference.

00:29:28.958 --> 00:29:34.958
So what happens when we take that and you expand that further

00:29:34.958 --> 00:29:38.958
into the Chinese society?

00:29:38.958 --> 00:29:42.958
And what is interesting is that that produces in a way

00:29:42.958 --> 00:29:44.958
perhaps the ultimate mega-building.

00:29:44.958 --> 00:29:48.958
It is physically the largest project on the planet at the moment.

00:29:48.958 --> 00:29:54.958
250 -- excuse me, 50,000 people working 24 hours, seven days.

00:29:54.958 --> 00:29:58.958
Larger by 17 percent than every terminal put together

00:29:58.958 --> 00:30:03.958
at Heathrow -- built -- plus the new, un-built Terminal Five.

00:30:03.958 --> 00:30:07.958
And the challenge here is a building that will be green,

00:30:07.958 --> 00:30:10.958
that is compact despite its size

00:30:10.958 --> 00:30:15.958
and is about the human experience of travel,

00:30:15.958 --> 00:30:20.958
is about friendly, is coming back to that starting point,

00:30:20.958 --> 00:30:22.958
is very, very much about the lifestyle.

00:30:22.958 --> 00:30:28.958
And perhaps these, in the end, as celebratory spaces.

00:30:28.958 --> 00:30:30.958
As Hubert was talking over lunch,

00:30:30.958 --> 00:30:32.958
as we sort of engaged in conversation,

00:30:32.958 --> 00:30:34.958
talked about this, talked about cities.

00:30:34.958 --> 00:30:39.958
Hubert was saying, absolutely correctly, "These are the new cathedrals."

00:30:39.958 --> 00:30:43.958
And in a way, one aspect of this conversation

00:30:43.958 --> 00:30:47.958
was triggered on New Year's Eve,

00:30:47.958 --> 00:30:55.958
when I was talking about the Olympic agenda in China

00:30:55.958 --> 00:31:00.958
in terms of its green ambitions and aspirations.

00:31:00.958 --> 00:31:02.958
And I was voicing the thought that --

00:31:02.958 --> 00:31:04.958
it just crossed my mind that New Year's Eve,

00:31:04.958 --> 00:31:10.958
a sort of symbolic turning point as we move from 2006 to 2007 --

00:31:10.958 --> 00:31:12.958
that maybe, you know, the future was

00:31:12.958 --> 00:31:16.958
the most powerful, innovative sort of nation.

00:31:16.958 --> 00:31:19.958
The way in which somebody like Kennedy inspirationally could say,

00:31:19.958 --> 00:31:20.958
"We put a man on the moon."

00:31:20.958 --> 00:31:22.958
You know, who is going to say

00:31:22.958 --> 00:31:27.958
that we cracked this thing of the dependence on fossil fuels,

00:31:27.958 --> 00:31:31.958
with all that being held to ransom by rogue regimes, and so on.

00:31:31.958 --> 00:31:33.958
And that's a concerted platform.

00:31:33.958 --> 00:31:36.958
It's more than one device, you know, it's renewable.

00:31:36.958 --> 00:31:40.958
And I voiced the thought that maybe at the turn of the year,

00:31:40.958 --> 00:31:42.958
I thought that the inspiration was more likely

00:31:42.958 --> 00:31:44.958
to come from those other, larger countries out there --

00:31:44.958 --> 00:31:48.958
the Chinas, the Indias, the Asian-Pacific tigers.

00:31:48.958 --> 00:31:50.958
Thank you very much.

00:31:50.958 --> 00:31:51.958
(Applause)

title: A look inside the brain in real time
transcript: Hi. I'm going to ask you to raise your arms and wave back, just the way I am — kind of a royal wave. You can mimic what you can see. You can program the hundreds of muscles in your arm. Soon, you'll be able to look inside your brain and program, control the hundreds of brain areas that you see there. I'm going to tell you about that technology.People have wanted to look inside the human mind, the human brain, for thousands of years. Well, coming out of the research labs just now, for our generation, is the possibility to do that. People envision this as being very difficult. You had to take a spaceship, shrink it down, inject it into the bloodstream. It was terribly dangerous. (Laughter) You could be attacked by white blood cells in the arteries. But now, we have a real technology to do this.We're going to fly into my colleague Peter's brain. We're going to do it non-invasively using MRI. We don't have to inject anything. We don't need radiation. We will be able to fly into the anatomy of Peter's brain — literally, fly into his body — but more importantly, we can look into his mind. When Peter moves his arm, that yellow spot you see there is the interface to the functioning of Peter's mind taking place. Now you've seen before that with electrodes you can control robotic arms, that brain imaging and scanners can show you the insides of brains. What's new is that that process has typically taken days or months of analysis. We've collapsed that through technology to milliseconds, and that allows us to let Peter to look at his brain in real time as he's inside the scanner. He can look at these 65,000 points of activation per second. If he can see this pattern in his own brain, he can learn how to control it.There have been three ways to try to impact the brain: the therapist's couch, pills and the knife. This is a fourth alternative that you are soon going to have. We all know that as we form thoughts, they form deep channels in our minds and in our brains. Chronic pain is an example. If you burn yourself, you pull your hand away. But if you're still in pain in six months' or six years' time, it's because these circuits are producing pain that's no longer helping you. If we can look at the activation in the brain that's producing the pain, we can form 3D models and watch in real time the brain process information, and then we can select the areas that produce the pain. So put your arms back up and flex your bicep.Now imagine that you will soon be able to look inside your brain and select brain areas to do that same thing. What you're seeing here is, we've selected the pathways in the brain of a chronic pain patient. This may shock you, but we're literally reading this person's brain in real time. They're watching their own brain activation, and they're controlling the pathway that produces their pain. They're learning to flex this system that releases their own endogenous opiates. As they do it, in the upper left is a display that's yoked to their brain activation of their own pain being controlled. When they control their brain, they can control their pain. This is an investigational technology, but, in clinical trials, we're seeing a 44 to 64 percent decrease in chronic pain patients.This is not "The Matrix." You can only do this to yourself. You take control. I've seen inside my brain. You will too, soon. When you do, what do you want to control? You will be able to look at all the aspects that make you yourself, all your experiences. These are some of the areas we're working on today that I don't have time to go into in detail. But I want to leave with you the big question. We are the first generation that's going to be able to enter into, using this technology, the human mind and brain. Where will we take it?
