00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:18.958
I have given the slide show that I gave here two years ago about 2,000 times.

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:23.958
I'm giving a short slide show this morning

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:26.958
that I'm giving for the very first time, so --

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:31.958
well it's -- I don't want or need to raise the bar,

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:32.958
I'm actually trying to lower the bar.

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:37.958
Because I've cobbled this together

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:42.958
to try to meet the challenge of this session.

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:47.958
And I was reminded by Karen Armstrong's fantastic presentation

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:53.958
that religion really properly understood

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:56.958
is not about belief, but about behavior.

00:00:56.958 --> 00:01:00.958
Perhaps we should say the same thing about optimism.

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:04.958
How dare we be optimistic?

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:12.958
Optimism is sometimes characterized as a belief, an intellectual posture.

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:15.958
As Mahatma Gandhi famously said,

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:18.958
"You must become the change you wish to see in the world."

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:20.958
And the outcome about which

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:25.958
we wish to be optimistic is not going to be created

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:30.958
by the belief alone, except to the extent that the belief

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:36.958
brings about new behavior. But the word "behavior"

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:40.958
is also, I think, sometimes misunderstood in this context.

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:43.958
I'm a big advocate of changing

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:46.958
the lightbulbs and buying hybrids,

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:50.958
and Tipper and I put 33 solar panels on our house,

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:55.958
and dug the geothermal wells, and did all of that other stuff.

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:59.958
But, as important as it is to change the lightbulbs,

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:01.958
it is more important to change the laws.

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:07.958
And when we change our behavior in our daily lives,

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:10.958
we sometimes leave out the citizenship part

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:17.958
and the democracy part. In order to be optimistic about this,

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:23.958
we have to become incredibly active as citizens in our democracy.

00:02:23.958 --> 00:02:25.958
In order to solve the climate crisis,

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:28.958
we have to solve the democracy crisis.

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
And we have one.

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:35.958
I have been trying to tell this story for a long time.

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:39.958
I was reminded of that recently, by a woman

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:42.958
who walked past the table I was sitting at,

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:46.958
just staring at me as she walked past. She was in her 70s,

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:50.958
looked like she had a kind face. I thought nothing of it

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:53.958
until I saw from the corner of my eye

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
she was walking from the opposite direction,

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:59.958
also just staring at me. And so I said, "How do you do?"

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:02.958
And she said, "You know, if you dyed your hair black,

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:07.958
you would look just like Al Gore." (Laughter)

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:14.958
Many years ago, when I was a young congressman,

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:18.958
I spent an awful lot of time dealing with the challenge

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:21.958
of nuclear arms control -- the nuclear arms race.

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:24.958
And the military historians taught me,

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:29.958
during that quest, that military conflicts are typically

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:34.958
put into three categories: local battles,

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:39.958
regional or theater wars, and the rare but all-important

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:44.958
global, world war -- strategic conflicts.

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:49.958
And each level of conflict requires a different allocation of resources,

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:51.958
a different approach,

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:55.958
a different organizational model.

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:59.958
Environmental challenges fall into the same three categories,

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:00.958
and most of what we think about

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:03.958
are local environmental problems: air pollution, water pollution,

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:07.958
hazardous waste dumps. But there are also

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:10.958
regional environmental problems, like acid rain

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:14.958
from the Midwest to the Northeast, and from Western Europe

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:18.958
to the Arctic, and from the Midwest

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:21.958
out the Mississippi into the dead zone of the Gulf of Mexico.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:23.958
And there are lots of those. But the climate crisis

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
is the rare but all-important

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:28.958
global, or strategic, conflict.

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:33.958
Everything is affected. And we have to organize our response

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:39.958
appropriately. We need a worldwide, global mobilization

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:42.958
for renewable energy, conservation, efficiency

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:45.958
and a global transition to a low-carbon economy.

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:49.958
We have work to do. And we can mobilize resources

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:53.958
and political will. But the political will

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:56.958
has to be mobilized, in order to mobilize the resources.

00:04:56.958 --> 00:05:01.958
Let me show you these slides here.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:08.958
I thought I would start with the logo. What's missing here,

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
of course, is the North Polar ice cap.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:17.958
Greenland remains. Twenty-eight years ago, this is what the

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:21.958
polar ice cap -- the North Polar ice cap -- looked like

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:25.958
at the end of the summer, at the fall equinox.

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:29.958
This last fall, I went to the Snow and Ice Data Center

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:32.958
in Boulder, Colorado, and talked to the researchers

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:36.958
here in Monterey at the Naval Postgraduate Laboratory.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:40.958
This is what's happened in the last 28 years.

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:45.958
To put it in perspective, 2005 was the previous record.

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.958
Here's what happened last fall

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:51.958
that has really unnerved the researchers.

00:05:51.958 --> 00:06:03.958
The North Polar ice cap is the same size geographically --

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:04.958
doesn't look quite the same size --

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:08.958
but it is exactly the same size as the United States,

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:11.958
minus an area roughly equal to the state of Arizona.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:14.958
The amount that disappeared in 2005

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:18.958
was equivalent to everything east of the Mississippi.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:22.958
The extra amount that disappeared last fall

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:25.958
was equivalent to this much. It comes back in the winter,

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:29.958
but not as permanent ice, as thin ice --

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:35.958
vulnerable. The amount remaining could be completely gone

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:36.958
in summer in as little as five years.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:41.958
That puts a lot of pressure on Greenland.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:48.958
Already, around the Arctic Circle --

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:54.958
this is a famous village in Alaska. This is a town

00:06:54.958 --> 00:07:03.958
in Newfoundland. Antarctica. Latest studies from NASA.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:06.958
The amount of a moderate-to-severe snow melting

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:10.958
of an area equivalent to the size of California.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:13.958
"They were the best of times,

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:16.958
they were the worst of times": the most famous opening sentence

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:19.958
in English literature. I want to share briefly

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:22.958
a tale of two planets. Earth and Venus

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
are exactly the same size. Earth's diameter

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:30.958
is about 400 kilometers larger, but essentially the same size.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
They have exactly the same amount of carbon.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:37.958
But the difference is, on Earth, most of the carbon

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
has been leeched over time out of the atmosphere,

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:44.958
deposited in the ground as coal, oil,

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
natural gas, etc. On Venus, most of it

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:52.958
is in the atmosphere. The difference is that our temperature

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:55.958
is 59 degrees on average. On Venus,

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:59.958
it's 855. This is relevant to our current strategy

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
of taking as much carbon out of the ground as quickly as possible,

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:02.958
and putting it into the atmosphere.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
It's not because Venus is slightly closer to the Sun.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
It's three times hotter than Mercury,

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
which is right next to the Sun. Now, briefly,

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
here's an image you've seen, as one of the only old images,

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:19.958
but I show it because I want to briefly give you CSI: Climate.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:25.958
The global scientific community says:

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:29.958
man-made global warming pollution, put into the atmosphere,

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
thickening this, is trapping more of the outgoing infrared.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:32.958
You all know that. At the last

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:36.958
IPCC summary, the scientists wanted to say,

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
"How certain are you?" They wanted to answer that "99 percent."

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
The Chinese objected, and so the compromise was

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
"more than 90 percent."

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:46.958
Now, the skeptics say, "Oh, wait a minute,

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:50.958
this could be variations in this energy

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
coming in from the sun." If that were true,

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:57.958
the stratosphere would be heated as well as the

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
lower atmosphere, if it's more coming in.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:03.958
If it's more being trapped on the way out, then you would

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:09.958
expect it to be warmer here and cooler here. Here is the lower atmosphere.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:12.958
Here's the stratosphere: cooler.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:13.958
CSI: Climate.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:20.958
Now, here's the good news. Sixty-eight percent of Americans now believe

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
that human activity is responsible

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:28.958
for global warming. Sixty-nine percent believe that the Earth is heating up

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:31.958
in a significant way. There has been progress,

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:38.958
but here is the key: when given a list

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:47.958
of challenges to confront, global warming is still listed at near the bottom.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:50.958
What is missing is a sense of urgency.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:55.958
If you agree with the factual analysis,

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:58.958
but you don't feel the sense of urgency,

00:09:58.958 --> 00:09:59.958
where does that leave you?

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
Well, the Alliance for Climate Protection, which I head

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:06.958
in conjunction with Current TV -- who did this pro bono --

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:10.958
did a worldwide contest to do commercials on how to communicate this.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:12.958
This is the winner.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:06.958
NBC -- I'll show all of the networks here -- the top journalists

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:10.958
for NBC asked 956 questions in 2007

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:13.958
of the presidential candidates: two of them were about

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:20.958
the climate crisis. ABC: 844 questions, two about the climate crisis.

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:30.958
Fox: two. CNN: two. CBS: zero.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:34.958
From laughs to tears -- this is one of the older

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:35.958
tobacco commercials.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.958
So here's what we're doing.

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:48.958
This is gasoline consumption in all of these countries. And us.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:54.958
But it's not just the developed nations.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:58.958
The developing countries are now following us

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
and accelerating their pace. And actually,

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
their cumulative emissions this year are the equivalent

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:06.958
to where we were in 1965. And they're catching up

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:10.958
very dramatically. The total concentrations:

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:16.958
by 2025, they will be essentially where we were in 1985.

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:21.958
If the wealthy countries were completely missing

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:24.958
from the picture, we would still have this crisis.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:28.958
But we have given to the developing countries

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
the technologies and the ways of thinking

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:36.958
that are creating the crisis. This is in Bolivia --

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:39.958
over thirty years.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:02.958
This is peak fishing in a few seconds. The '60s.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:11.958
'70s. '80s. '90s. We have to stop this. And the good news is that we can.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:15.958
We have the technologies.

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:20.958
We have to have a unified view of how to go about this:

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:24.958
the struggle against poverty in the world

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:28.958
and the challenge of cutting wealthy country emissions,

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:32.958
all has a single, very simple solution.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:36.958
People say, "What's the solution?" Here it is.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:42.958
Put a price on carbon. We need a CO2 tax, revenue neutral,

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:50.958
to replace taxation on employment, which was invented by Bismarck --

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:51.958
and some things have changed

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:52.958
since the 19th century.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:59.958
In the poor world, we have to integrate the responses

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:03.958
to poverty with the solutions to the climate crisis.

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:06.958
Plans to fight poverty in Uganda

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:10.958
are mooted, if we do not solve the climate crisis.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:18.958
But responses can actually make a huge difference

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:23.958
in the poor countries. This is a proposal

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:27.958
that has been talked about a lot in Europe.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:31.958
This was from Nature magazine. These are concentrating

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:38.958
solar, renewable energy plants, linked in a so-called "supergrid"

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:41.958
to supply all of the electrical power

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:49.958
to Europe, largely from developing countries -- high-voltage DC currents.

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:52.958
This is not pie in the sky; this can be done.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:55.958
We need to do it for our own economy.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:58.958
The latest figures show that the old model

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:02.958
is not working. There are a lot of great investments

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:06.958
that you can make. If you are investing in tar sands

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:12.958
or shale oil, then you have a portfolio

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:16.958
that is crammed with sub-prime carbon assets.

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:20.958
And it is based on an old model.

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.958
Junkies find veins in their toes when the ones

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:28.958
in their arms and their legs collapse. Developing tar sands

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:34.958
and coal shale is the equivalent. Here are just a few of the investments

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:37.958
that I personally think make sense.

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:40.958
I have a stake in these, so I'll have a disclaimer there.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:43.958
But geothermal, concentrating solar,

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:49.958
advanced photovoltaics, efficiency and conservation.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:53.958
You've seen this slide before, but there's a change.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:57.958
The only two countries that didn't ratify

00:15:57.958 --> 00:16:02.958
-- and now there's only one. Australia had an election.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.958
And there was a campaign in Australia

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:10.958
that involved television and Internet and radio commercials

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:12.958
to lift the sense of urgency for the people there.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:16.958
And we trained 250 people to give the slide show

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:21.958
in every town and village and city in Australia.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
Lot of other things contributed to it,

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:26.958
but the new Prime Minister announced that

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:30.958
his very first priority would be to change Australia's position

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:35.958
on Kyoto, and he has. Now, they came to an awareness

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:39.958
partly because of the horrible drought that they have had.

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:43.958
This is Lake Lanier. My friend Heidi Cullen

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:47.958
said that if we gave droughts names the way we give hurricanes names,

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:50.958
we'd call the one in the southeast now Katrina,

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:52.958
and we would say it's headed toward Atlanta.

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:56.958
We can't wait for the kind of drought

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:58.958
Australia had to change our political culture.

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:07.958
Here's more good news. The cities supporting Kyoto in the U.S.

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:10.958
are up to 780 -- and I thought I saw one go by there,

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:16.958
just to localize this -- which is good news.

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:22.958
Now, to close, we heard a couple of days ago

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:31.958
about the value of making individual heroism so commonplace

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:34.958
that it becomes banal or routine.

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:43.958
What we need is another hero generation. Those of us who are alive

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:45.958
in the United States of America

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:47.958
today especially, but also the rest of the world,

00:17:48.958 --> 00:17:53.958
have to somehow understand that history

00:17:53.958 --> 00:18:03.958
has presented us with a choice -- just as Jill [Bolte] Taylor was figuring out

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:08.958
how to save her life while she was distracted

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:12.958
by the amazing experience that she was going through.

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:15.958
We now have a culture of distraction.

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:20.958
But we have a planetary emergency.

00:18:20.958 --> 00:18:24.958
And we have to find a way to create,

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:30.958
in the generation of those alive today, a sense of generational mission.

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:33.958
I wish I could find the words to convey this.

00:18:36.958 --> 00:18:38.958
This was another hero generation

00:18:38.958 --> 00:18:41.958
that brought democracy to the planet.

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:48.958
Another that ended slavery. And that gave women the right to vote.

00:18:48.958 --> 00:18:55.958
We can do this. Don't tell me that we don't have the capacity to do it.

00:18:55.958 --> 00:18:59.958
If we had just one week's worth of what we spend on the Iraq War,

00:18:59.958 --> 00:19:02.958
we could be well on the way to solving this challenge.

00:19:02.958 --> 00:19:06.958
We have the capacity to do it.

00:19:12.958 --> 00:19:25.958
One final point: I'm optimistic, because I believe

00:19:25.958 --> 00:19:29.958
we have the capacity, at moments of great challenge,

00:19:29.958 --> 00:19:35.958
to set aside the causes of distraction and rise to the challenge

00:19:35.958 --> 00:19:38.958
that history is presenting to us.

00:19:40.958 --> 00:19:52.958
Sometimes I hear people respond to the disturbing facts of the climate crisis

00:19:52.958 --> 00:19:54.958
by saying, "Oh, this is so terrible.

00:19:54.958 --> 00:20:00.958
What a burden we have." I would like to ask you

00:20:00.958 --> 00:20:04.958
to reframe that. How many generations

00:20:04.958 --> 00:20:09.958
in all of human history have had the opportunity

00:20:09.958 --> 00:20:18.958
to rise to a challenge that is worthy of our best efforts?

00:20:18.958 --> 00:20:24.958
A challenge that can pull from us

00:20:24.958 --> 00:20:32.958
more than we knew we could do? I think we ought to approach

00:20:32.958 --> 00:20:36.958
this challenge with a sense of profound joy

00:20:36.958 --> 00:20:41.958
and gratitude that we are the generation

00:20:41.958 --> 00:20:45.958
about which, a thousand years from now,

00:20:45.958 --> 00:20:54.958
philharmonic orchestras and poets and singers will celebrate

00:20:54.958 --> 00:21:01.958
by saying, they were the ones that found it within themselves

00:21:01.958 --> 00:21:06.958
to solve this crisis and lay the basis

00:21:06.958 --> 00:21:08.958
for a bright and optimistic human future.

00:21:08.958 --> 00:21:11.958
Let's do that. Thank you very much.

00:21:35.958 --> 00:21:41.958
Chris Anderson: For so many people at TED, there is deep pain

00:21:41.958 --> 00:21:43.958
that basically a design issue

00:21:43.958 --> 00:21:45.958
on a voting form --

00:21:45.958 --> 00:21:49.958
one bad design issue meant that your voice wasn't being heard

00:21:49.958 --> 00:21:50.958
like that in the last eight years in a position

00:21:50.958 --> 00:21:52.958
where you could make these things come true.

00:21:52.958 --> 00:21:54.958
That hurts.

00:21:54.958 --> 00:22:01.958
Al Gore: You have no idea. (Laughter)

00:22:04.958 --> 00:22:05.958
CA: When you look at what the leading candidates

00:22:05.958 --> 00:22:07.958
in your own party are doing now -- I mean, there's --

00:22:07.958 --> 00:22:12.958
are you excited by their plans on global warming?

00:22:21.958 --> 00:22:25.958
AG: The answer to the question is hard for me

00:22:25.958 --> 00:22:29.958
because, on the one hand, I think that

00:22:29.958 --> 00:22:33.958
we should feel really great about the fact

00:22:34.958 --> 00:22:40.958
that the Republican nominee -- certain nominee --

00:22:40.958 --> 00:22:44.958
John McCain, and both of the finalists

00:22:44.958 --> 00:22:49.958
for the Democratic nomination -- all three have a very different

00:22:49.958 --> 00:22:51.958
and forward-leaning position

00:22:51.958 --> 00:22:56.958
on the climate crisis. All three have offered leadership,

00:22:56.958 --> 00:23:00.958
and all three are very different from the approach taken

00:23:00.958 --> 00:23:03.958
by the current administration. And I think

00:23:03.958 --> 00:23:07.958
that all three have also been responsible in

00:23:07.958 --> 00:23:18.958
putting forward plans and proposals. But the campaign dialogue that --

00:23:18.958 --> 00:23:19.958
as illustrated by the questions --

00:23:19.958 --> 00:23:20.958
that was put together by the

00:23:20.958 --> 00:23:23.958
League of Conservation Voters, by the way, the analysis of all the questions --

00:23:23.958 --> 00:23:25.958
and, by the way, the debates have all been

00:23:27.958 --> 00:23:29.958
sponsored by something that goes by the Orwellian label,

00:23:29.958 --> 00:23:33.958
"Clean Coal." Has anybody noticed that?

00:23:33.958 --> 00:23:37.958
Every single debate has been sponsored by "Clean Coal."

00:23:37.958 --> 00:23:39.958
"Now, even lower emissions!"

00:23:39.958 --> 00:23:43.958
The richness and fullness of the dialogue

00:23:43.958 --> 00:23:46.958
in our democracy has not laid the basis

00:23:46.958 --> 00:23:50.958
for the kind of bold initiative that is really needed.

00:23:50.958 --> 00:23:53.958
So they're saying the right things and they may --

00:23:53.958 --> 00:23:56.958
whichever of them is elected -- may do the right thing,

00:23:56.958 --> 00:24:00.958
but let me tell you: when I came back from Kyoto

00:24:00.958 --> 00:24:07.958
in 1997, with a feeling of great happiness

00:24:07.958 --> 00:24:09.958
that we'd gotten that breakthrough there,

00:24:09.958 --> 00:24:11.958
and then confronted the United States Senate,

00:24:11.958 --> 00:24:15.958
only one out of 100 senators was willing to vote

00:24:15.958 --> 00:24:22.958
to confirm, to ratify that treaty. Whatever the candidates say

00:24:22.958 --> 00:24:27.958
has to be laid alongside what the people say.

00:24:27.958 --> 00:24:31.958
This challenge is part of the fabric

00:24:31.958 --> 00:24:33.958
of our whole civilization.

00:24:33.958 --> 00:24:36.958
CO2 is the exhaling breath of our civilization, literally.

00:24:37.958 --> 00:24:40.958
And now we mechanized that process. Changing that pattern

00:24:40.958 --> 00:24:47.958
requires a scope, a scale, a speed of change

00:24:47.958 --> 00:24:50.958
that is beyond what we have done in the past.

00:24:50.958 --> 00:24:52.958
So that's why I began by saying,

00:24:52.958 --> 00:24:58.958
be optimistic in what you do, but be an active citizen.

00:24:59.958 --> 00:25:01.958
Demand -- change the light bulbs,

00:25:01.958 --> 00:25:04.958
but change the laws. Change the global treaties.

00:25:04.958 --> 00:25:10.958
We have to speak up. We have to solve this democracy -- this --

00:25:11.958 --> 00:25:17.958
We have sclerosis in our democracy. And we have to change that.

00:25:18.958 --> 00:25:19.958
Use the Internet. Go on the Internet.

00:25:19.958 --> 00:25:23.958
Connect with people. Become very active as citizens.

00:25:23.958 --> 00:25:25.958
Have a moratorium -- we shouldn't

00:25:25.958 --> 00:25:27.958
have any new coal-fired generating plants

00:25:27.958 --> 00:25:32.958
that aren't able to capture and store CO2, which means we have to

00:25:32.958 --> 00:25:34.958
quickly build these renewable sources.

00:25:34.958 --> 00:25:38.958
Now, nobody is talking on that scale. But I do believe

00:25:38.958 --> 00:25:42.958
that between now and November, it is possible.

00:25:42.958 --> 00:25:43.958
This Alliance for Climate Protection

00:25:44.958 --> 00:25:47.958
is going to launch a nationwide campaign --

00:25:47.958 --> 00:25:50.958
grassroots mobilization, television ads, Internet ads,

00:25:50.958 --> 00:25:53.958
radio, newspaper -- with partnerships with everybody

00:25:53.958 --> 00:25:56.958
from the Girl Scouts to the hunters and fishermen.

00:25:56.958 --> 00:26:00.958
We need help. We need help.

00:26:00.958 --> 00:26:04.958
CA: In terms of your own personal role going forward,

00:26:04.958 --> 00:26:06.958
Al, is there something more than that

00:26:06.958 --> 00:26:07.958
you would like to be doing?

00:26:07.958 --> 00:26:15.958
AG: I have prayed that I would be able to find the answer

00:26:15.958 --> 00:26:20.958
to that question. What can I do?

00:26:20.958 --> 00:26:24.958
Buckminster Fuller once wrote, "If the future

00:26:24.958 --> 00:26:29.958
of all human civilization depended on me, what would I do?

00:26:29.958 --> 00:26:34.958
How would I be?" It does depend on all of us,

00:26:34.958 --> 00:26:36.958
but again, not just with the light bulbs.

00:26:36.958 --> 00:26:44.958
We, most of us here, are Americans. We have a democracy.

00:26:44.958 --> 00:26:50.958
We can change things, but we have to actively change.

00:26:50.958 --> 00:26:55.958
What's needed really is a higher level of consciousness.

00:26:55.958 --> 00:26:57.958
And that's hard to --

00:26:57.958 --> 00:27:01.958
that's hard to create -- but it is coming.

00:27:01.958 --> 00:27:04.958
There's an old African proverb that some of you know

00:27:04.958 --> 00:27:08.958
that says, "If you want to go quickly, go alone;

00:27:08.958 --> 00:27:16.958
if you want to go far, go together." We have to go far, quickly.

00:27:16.958 --> 00:27:20.958
So we have to have a change in consciousness.

00:27:20.958 --> 00:27:24.958
A change in commitment. A new sense of urgency.

00:27:24.958 --> 00:27:27.958
A new appreciation for the privilege

00:27:27.958 --> 00:27:30.958
that we have of undertaking this challenge.

00:27:30.958 --> 00:27:34.958
CA: Al Gore, thank you so much for coming to TED.

00:27:34.958 --> 00:27:38.958
AG: Thank you. Thank you very much.

title: Free or cheap Wii Remote hacks
transcript: So, as researchers, something that we often do is use immense resources to achieve certain capabilities, or achieve certain goals. And this is essential to the progress of science, or exploration of what is possible. But it creates this unfortunate situation where a tiny, tiny fraction of the world can actually participate in this exploration or can benefit from that technology. Something that motivates me, and gets me really excited about my research, is when I see simple opportunities to drastically change that distribution and make the technology accessible to a much wider percentage of the population.I'm going to show you two videos that have gotten a lot of attention that I think embody this philosophy. And they actually use the Nintendo Wii Remote. For those of you who aren't familiar with this device, it's a $40 video game controller. And it's mostly advertised for its motion-sensing capabilities: so you can swing a tennis racket, or hit a baseball bat. But what actually interests me a lot more is the fact that in the tip of each controller is a relatively high-performing infrared camera. And I'm going to show you two demos of why this is useful.So here, I have my computer set up with the projector, and I have a Wii Remote sitting on top of it. And, for example, if you're in a school that doesn't have a lot money, probably a lot of schools, or if you're in an office environment, and you want an interactive whiteboard, normally these cost about two to three thousand dollars. So I'm going to show you how to create one with a Wii Remote. Now, this requires another piece of hardware, which is this infrared pen. You can probably make this yourself for about five dollars with a quick trip to the Radio Shack. It's got a battery, a button and an infrared LED — you guys can't see it — but it turns on whenever I push the button. Now, what this means is that if I run this piece of software, the camera sees the infrared dot, and I can register the location of the camera pixels to the projector pixels. And now this is like an interactive whiteboard surface.(Applause)So for about $50 of hardware, you can have your own whiteboard. This is Adobe Photoshop.(Applause)Thank you.(Laughter)The software for this I've actually put on my website and have let people download it for free. In the three months this project has been public, it's been downloaded over half a million times. So teachers and students all around the world are already using this.(Applause)Although it does do it for 50 dollars, there are some limitations of this approach. You get about 80 percent of the way there, for one percent of the cost. Another nice thing is that a camera can see multiple dots, so this is actually a multi-touch, interactive whiteboard system as well.(Applause)For the second demo, I have this Wii Remote that's actually next to the TV. So it's pointing away from the display, rather than pointing at the display. And why this is interesting is that if you put on, say, a pair of safety glasses, that have two infrared dots in them, they are going to give the computer an approximation of your head location. And why this is interesting is I have this sort of application running on the computer monitor, which has a 3D room, with some targets floating in it. And you can see that it looks like a 3D room. kind of like a video game, it sort of looks 3D, but for the most part, the image looks pretty flat, and bound to the surface of the screen. But if we turn on head tracking — the computer can change the image that's on the screen and make it respond to the head movements. So let's switch back to that.(Laughter)(Applause)So this has actually been a little bit startling to the game-development community.(Laughter)Because this is about 10 dollars of additional hardware if you already have a Nintendo Wii. So I'm looking forward to seeing some games, and actually Louis Castle, that's him down there, last week announced that Electronic Arts, one of the largest game publishers, is releasing a game in May that has a little Easter egg feature for supporting this type of head tracking. And that's from less than five months from a prototype in my lab to a major commercial product.(Applause)Thank you.(Applause)But actually, to me, what's almost more interesting than either of these two projects is how people actually found out about them. YouTube has really changed the way, or changed the speed, in which a single individual can actually spread an idea around the world. I'm doing some research in my lab with a video camera, and within the first week, a million people had seen this work, and literally within days, engineers, teachers and students from around the world were already posting their own YouTube videos of them using my system or derivatives of this work. So I hope to see more of that in the future, and hope online video distribution to be embraced by the research community.So thank you very much.(Applause)

For the second demo,

00:03:02.205 --> 00:03:04.829
I have this Wii Remote
that's actually next to the TV.

00:03:04.853 --> 00:03:09.053
So it's pointing away from the display,
rather than pointing at the display.

00:03:09.077 --> 00:03:11.340
And why this is interesting

00:03:11.364 --> 00:03:15.078
is that if you put on, say,
a pair of safety glasses,

00:03:15.102 --> 00:03:16.916
that have two infrared dots in them,

00:03:16.940 --> 00:03:22.193
they are going to give the computer
an approximation of your head location.

00:03:22.217 --> 00:03:23.519
And why this is interesting

00:03:23.543 --> 00:03:26.686
is I have this sort of application
running on the computer monitor,

00:03:26.710 --> 00:03:29.242
which has a 3D room,
with some targets floating in it.

00:03:29.266 --> 00:03:31.505
And you can see that it
looks like a 3D room.

00:03:31.529 --> 00:03:34.876
kind of like a video game,
it sort of looks 3D,

00:03:34.900 --> 00:03:37.367
but for the most part,
the image looks pretty flat,

00:03:37.391 --> 00:03:39.249
and bound to the surface of the screen.

00:03:39.273 --> 00:03:41.373
But if we turn on head tracking --

00:03:44.678 --> 00:03:47.463
the computer can change
the image that's on the screen

00:03:47.487 --> 00:03:49.503
and make it respond to the head movements.

00:03:49.527 --> 00:03:50.908
So let's switch back to that.

00:03:50.932 --> 00:03:53.934
(Laughter)

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:56.822
(Applause)

00:04:04.603 --> 00:04:07.822
So this has actually
been a little bit startling

00:04:07.846 --> 00:04:09.480
to the game-development community.

00:04:09.504 --> 00:04:11.326
(Laughter)

00:04:11.350 --> 00:04:14.206
Because this is about 10 dollars
of additional hardware

00:04:14.230 --> 00:04:16.089
if you already have a Nintendo Wii.

00:04:16.113 --> 00:04:18.398
So I'm looking forward
to seeing some games,

00:04:18.422 --> 00:04:20.917
and actually Louis Castle,
that's him down there,

00:04:20.941 --> 00:04:24.580
last week announced that Electronic Arts,
one of the largest game publishers,

00:04:24.604 --> 00:04:27.605
is releasing a game in May
that has a little Easter egg feature

00:04:27.629 --> 00:04:29.922
for supporting this type of head tracking.

00:04:29.946 --> 00:04:31.872
And that's from less than five months

00:04:31.896 --> 00:04:35.022
from a prototype in my lab
to a major commercial product.

00:04:35.046 --> 00:04:40.539
(Applause)

00:04:40.563 --> 00:04:41.792
Thank you.

00:04:41.816 --> 00:04:44.055
(Applause)

00:04:44.079 --> 00:04:46.478
But actually, to me,
what's almost more interesting

00:04:46.502 --> 00:04:48.074
than either of these two projects

00:04:48.098 --> 00:04:50.393
is how people actually
found out about them.

00:04:50.417 --> 00:04:53.957
YouTube has really changed the way,
or changed the speed,

00:04:53.981 --> 00:04:55.315
in which a single individual

00:04:55.339 --> 00:04:57.566
can actually spread
an idea around the world.

00:04:57.590 --> 00:05:00.590
I'm doing some research
in my lab with a video camera,

00:05:00.614 --> 00:05:03.567
and within the first week,
a million people had seen this work,

00:05:03.591 --> 00:05:07.182
and literally within days,
engineers, teachers and students

00:05:07.206 --> 00:05:10.397
from around the world were already
posting their own YouTube videos

00:05:10.421 --> 00:05:13.781
of them using my system
or derivatives of this work.

00:05:13.805 --> 00:05:16.345
So I hope to see more
of that in the future,

00:05:16.369 --> 00:05:19.941
and hope online video distribution
to be embraced by the research community.

00:05:19.965 --> 00:05:21.218
So thank you very much.

00:05:21.242 --> 00:05:24.731
(Applause)

title: Inventing instruments that unlock new music
transcript: The first idea I'd like to suggest is that we all love music a great deal. It means a lot to us. But music is even more powerful if you don't just listen to it, but you make it yourself. So, that's my first idea. And we all know about the Mozart effect — the idea that's been around for the last five to 10 years — that just by listening to music or by playing music to your baby [in utero], that it'll raise our IQ points 10, 20, 30 percent.Great idea, but it doesn't work at all. So, you can't just listen to music, you have to make it somehow. And I'd add to that, that it's not just making it, but everybody, each of us, everybody in the world has the power to create and be part of music in a very dynamic way, and that's one of the main parts of my work. So, with the MIT Media Lab, for quite a while now, we've been engaged in a field called active music. What are all the possible ways that we can think of to get everybody in the middle of a musical experience, not just listening, but making music?And we started by making instruments for some of the world's greatest performers — we call these hyperinstruments — for Yo-Yo Ma, Peter Gabriel, Prince, orchestras, rock bands. Instruments where they're all kinds of sensors built right into the instrument, so the instrument knows how it's being played. And just by changing the interpretation and the feeling, I can turn my cello into a voice, or into a whole orchestra, or into something that nobody has ever heard before.When we started making these, I started thinking, why can't we make wonderful instruments like that for everybody, people who aren't fantastic Yo-Yo Mas or Princes? So, we've made a whole series of instruments. One of the largest collections is called the Brain Opera. It's a whole orchestra of about 100 instruments, all designed for anybody to play using natural skill. So, you can play a video game, drive through a piece of music, use your body gesture to control huge masses of sound, touch a special surface to make melodies, use your voice to make a whole aura. And when we make the Brain Opera, we invite the public to come in, to try these instruments and then collaborate with us to help make each performance of the Brain Opera. We toured that for a long time. It is now permanently in Vienna, where we built a museum around it.And that led to something which you probably do know. Guitar Hero came out of our lab, and my two teenage daughters and most of the students at the MIT Media Lab are proof that if you make the right kind of interface, people are really interested in being in the middle of a piece of music, and playing it over and over and over again.So, the model works, but it's only the tip of the iceberg, because my second idea is that it's not enough just to want to make music in something like Guitar Hero. And music is very fun, but it's also transformative. It's very, very important. Music can change your life, more than almost anything. It can change the way you communicate with others, it can change your body, it can change your mind. So, we're trying to go to the next step of how you build on top of something like Guitar Hero. We are very involved in education. We have a long-term project called Toy Symphony, where we make all kinds of instruments that are also addictive, but for little kids, so the kids will fall in love with making music, want to spend their time doing it, and then will demand to know how it works, how to make more, how to create. So, we make squeezy instruments, like these Music Shapers that measure the electricity in your fingers, Beatbugs that let you tap in rhythms — they gather your rhythm, and like hot potato, you send your rhythm to your friends, who then have to imitate or respond to what your doing — and a software package called Hyperscore, which lets anybody use lines and color to make quite sophisticated music. Extremely easy to use, but once you use it, you can go quite deep — music in any style. And then, by pressing a button, it turns into music notation so that live musicians can play your pieces.We've had good enough, really, very powerful effects with kids around the world, and now people of all ages, using Hyperscore. So, we've gotten more and more interested in using these kinds of creative activities in a much broader context, for all kinds of people who don't usually have the opportunity to make music. So, one of the growing fields that we're working on at the Media Lab right now is music, mind and health. A lot of you have probably seen Oliver Sacks' wonderful new book called "Musicophilia". It's on sale in the bookstore. It's a great book. If you haven't seen it, it's worth reading. He's a pianist himself, and he details his whole career of looking at and observing incredibly powerful effects that music has had on peoples' lives in unusual situations.So we know, for instance, that music is almost always the last thing that people with advanced Alzheimer's can still respond to. Maybe many of you have noticed this with loved ones, you can find somebody who can't recognize their face in the mirror, or can't tell anyone in their family, but you can still find a shard of music that that person will jump out of the chair and start singing. And with that you can bring back parts of people's memories and personalities. Music is the best way to restore speech to people who have lost it through strokes, movement to people with Parkinson's disease. It's very powerful for depression, schizophrenia, many, many things.So, we're working on understanding those underlying principles and then building activities which will let music really improve people's health. And we do this in many ways. We work with many different hospitals. One of them is right near Boston, called Tewksbury Hospital. It's a long-term state hospital, where several years ago we started working with Hyperscore and patients with physical and mental disabilities. This has become a central part of the treatment at Tewksbury hospital, so everybody there clamors to work on musical activities. It's the activity that seems to accelerate people's treatment the most and it also brings the entire hospital together as a kind of musical community. I wanted to show you a quick video of some of this work before I go on. Video: They're manipulating each other's rhythms. It's a real experience, not only to learn how to play and listen to rhythms, but to train your musical memory and playing music in a group. To get their hands on music, to shape it themselves, change it, to experiment with it, to make their own music. So Hyperscore lets you start from scratch very quickly. Everybody can experience music in a profound way, we just have to make different tools.The third idea I want to share with you is that music, paradoxically, I think even more than words, is one of the very best ways we have of showing who we really are. I love giving talks, although strangely I feel more nervous giving talks than playing music. If I were here playing cello, or playing on a synth, or sharing my music with you, I'd be able to show things about myself that I can't tell you in words, more personal things, perhaps deeper things.I think that's true for many of us, and I want to give you two examples of how music is one of the most powerful interfaces we have, from ourselves to the outside world. The first is a really crazy project that we're building right now, called Death and the Powers. And it's a big opera, one of the larger opera projects going on in the world right now. And it's about a man, rich, successful, powerful, who wants to live forever. So, he figures out a way to download himself into his environment, actually into a series of books. So this guy wants to live forever, he downloads himself into his environment. The main singer disappears at the beginning of the opera and the entire stage becomes the main character. It becomes his legacy.And the opera is about what we can share, what we can pass on to others, to the people we love, and what we can't. Every object in the opera comes alive and is a gigantic music instrument, like this chandelier. It takes up the whole stage. It looks like a chandelier, but it's actually a robotic music instrument. So, as you can see in this prototype, gigantic piano strings, each string is controlled with a little robotic element — either little bows that stroke the strings, propellers that tickle the strings, acoustic signals that vibrate the strings. We also have an army of robots on stage. These robots are the kind of the intermediary between the main character, Simon Powers, and his family. There are a whole series of them, kind of like a Greek chorus. They observe the action. We've designed these square robots that we're testing right now at MIT called OperaBots. These OperaBots follow my music. They follow the characters. They're smart enough, we hope, not to bump into each other. They go off on their own. And then they can also, when you snap, line up exactly the way you'd like to. Even though they're cubes, they actually have a lot of personality.The largest set piece in the opera is called The System. It's a series of books. Every single book is robotic, so they all move, they all make sound, and when you put them all together, they turn into these walls, which have the gesture and the personality of Simon Powers. So he's disappeared, but the whole physical environment becomes this person. This is how he's chosen to represent himself. The books also have high-packed LEDs on the spines. So it's all display. And here's the great baritone James Maddalena as he enters The System. This is a sneak preview. This premieres in Monaco — it's in September 2009. If by any chance you can't make it, another idea with this project — here's this guy building his legacy through this very unusual form, through music and through the environment. But we're also making this available both online and in public spaces, as a way of each of us to use music and images from our lives to make our own legacy or to make a legacy of someone we love. So instead of being grand opera, this opera will turn into what we're thinking of as personal opera.And, if you're going to make a personal opera, what about a personal instrument? Everything I've shown you so far — whether it's a hyper-cello for Yo-Yo Ma or squeezy toy for a child — the instruments stayed the same and are valuable for a certain class of person: a virtuoso, a child. But what if I could make an instrument that could be adapted to the way I personally behave, to the way my hands work, to what I do very skillfully, perhaps, to what I don't do so skillfully? I think that this is the future of interface, it's the future of music, the future of instruments.And I'd like now to invite two very special people on the stage, so that I can give you an example of what personal instruments might be like. So, can you give a hand to Adam Boulanger, Ph.D. student from the MIT Media Lab, and Dan Ellsey. Dan, thanks to TED and to Bombardier Flexjet, Dan is here with us today all the way from Tewksbury. He's a resident at Tewksbury Hospital. This is by far the farthest he's strayed from Tewksbury Hospital, I can tell you that, because he's motivated to meet with you today and show you his own music. So, first of all, Dan, do you want to say hi to everyone and tell everyone who you are?Dan Ellsey: Hello. My name is Dan Ellsey. I am 34 years old and I have cerebral palsy. I have always loved music and I am excited to be able to conduct my own music with this new software.Tod Machover: And we're really excited to have you here, really Dan. (Applause)So we met Dan about three years ago, three and a half years ago, when we started working at Tewksbury. Everybody we met there was fantastic, did fantastic music. Dan had never made music before, and it turned out he was really fantastic at it. He's a born composer. He's very shy, too. So, turned out he's a fantastic composer, and over the last few years has been a constant collaborator of ours. He has made many, many pieces. He makes his own CDs. Actually, he is quite well known in the Boston area — mentors people at the hospital and children, locally, in how to make their own music. And I'll let Adam tell you. So, Adam is a Ph.D. student at MIT, an expert in music technology and medicine. And Adam and Dan have become close collaborators. What Adam's been working on for this last period is not only how to have Dan be able easily to make his own pieces, but how he can perform his piece using this kind of personal instrument. So, you want to say a little bit about how you guys work?Adam Boulanger: Yes. So, Tod and I entered into a discussion following the Tewksbury work and it was really about how Dan is an expressive person, and he's an intelligent and creative person. And it's in his face, it's in his breathing, it's in his eyes. How come he can't perform one of his pieces of music? That's our responsibility, and it doesn't make sense.So we started developing a technology that will allow him with nuance, with precision, with control, and despite his physical disability, to be able to do that, to be able to perform his piece of music. So, the process and the technology — basically, first we needed an engineering solution. So, you know, we have a FireWire camera, it looked at an infrared pointer. We went with the type of gesture metaphor that Dan was already used to with his speaking controller. And this was actually the least interesting part of the work, you know, the design process. We needed an input; we needed continuous tracking; in the software, we look at the types of shapes he's making.But, then was the really interesting aspect of the work, following the engineering part, where, basically, we're coding over Dan's shoulder at the hospital extensively to figure out, you know, how does Dan move? What's useful to him as an expressive motion? You know, what's his metaphor for performance? What types of things does he find important to control and convey in a piece of music? So all the parameter fitting, and really the technology was stretched at that point to fit just Dan. And, you know, I think this is a perspective shift. It's not that our technologies — they provide access, they allow us to create pieces of creative work. But what about expression? What about that moment when an artist delivers that piece of work? You know, do our technologies allow us to express? Do they provide structure for us to do that? And, you know, that's a personal relationship to expression that is lacking in the technological sphere. So, you know, with Dan, we needed a new design process, a new engineering process to sort of discover his movement and his path to expression that allow him to perform. And so that's what we'll do today.TM: So let's do it. So Dan do you want to tell everyone about what you're going to play now?DE: This is "My Eagle Song." TM: So Dan is going to play a piece of his, called "My Eagle Song". In fact, this is the score for Dan's piece, completely composed by Dan in Hyperscore. So he can use his infrared tracker to go directly into Hyperscore. He's incredibly fast at it, too, faster than I am, in fact.(Laughter)TM: He's really modest, too. So he can go in Hyperscore. You start out by making melodies and rhythms. He can place those exactly where he wants. Each one gets a color. He goes back into the composition window, draws the lines, places everything the way he wants to. Looking at the Hyperscore, you can see it also, you can see where the sections are, something might continue for a while, change, get really crazy and then end up with a big bang at the end.So that's the way he made his piece, and as Adam says, we then figured out the best way to have him perform his piece. It's going to be looked at by this camera, analyze his movements, it's going to let Dan bring out all the different aspects of his music that he wants to. And you're also going to notice a visual on the screen. We asked one of our students to look at what the camera is measuring. But instead of making it very literal, showing you exactly the camera tracing, we turned it into a graphic that shows you the basic movement, and shows the way it's being analyzed.I think it gives an understanding of how we're picking out movement from what Dan's doing, but I think it will also show you, if you look at that movement, that when Dan makes music, his motions are very purposeful, very precise, very disciplined and they're also very beautiful. So, in hearing this piece, as I mentioned before, the most important thing is the music's great, and it'll show you who Dan is. So, are we ready Adam?AB: Yeah.TM: OK, now Dan will play his piece "My Eagle Song" for you. (Applause)TM: Bravo. (Applause)
