00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:21.958
that people with advanced Alzheimer's can still respond to.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:23.958
Maybe many of you have noticed this with loved ones,

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
you can find somebody who can't recognize their face in the mirror,

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:28.958
or can't tell anyone in their family, but you can still find a shard of music

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:32.958
that that person will jump out of the chair and start singing. And with that

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
you can bring back parts of people's memories and personalities.

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:38.958
Music is the best way to restore speech to people who have lost it through strokes,

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
movement to people with Parkinson's disease.

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:44.958
It's very powerful for depression, schizophrenia, many, many things.

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:46.958
So, we're working on understanding those underlying principles

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:50.958
and then building activities which will let music really improve people's health.

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:53.958
And we do this in many ways. We work with many different hospitals.

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:56.958
One of them is right near Boston, called Tewksbury Hospital.

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
It's a long-term state hospital, where several years ago

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:02.958
we started working with Hyperscore and patients with physical and mental disabilities.

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:06.958
This has become a central part of the treatment at Tewksbury hospital,

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:10.958
so everybody there clamors to work on musical activities.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:14.958
It's the activity that seems to accelerate people's treatment the most

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:18.958
and it also brings the entire hospital together as a kind of musical community.

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:22.958
I wanted to show you a quick video of some of this work before I go on.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
Video: They're manipulating each other's rhythms.

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:09.958
It's a real experience, not only to learn how to play and listen to rhythms,

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:14.958
but to train your musical memory and playing music in a group.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:18.958
To get their hands on music, to shape it themselves, change it,

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:20.958
to experiment with it, to make their own music.

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:24.958
So Hyperscore lets you start from scratch very quickly.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
Everybody can experience music in a profound way,

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
we just have to make different tools.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:58.958
The third idea I want to share with you is that music, paradoxically,

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.958
I think even more than words, is one of the very best ways we have

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:05.958
of showing who we really are. I love giving talks, although

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
strangely I feel more nervous giving talks than playing music.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
If I were here playing cello, or playing on a synth, or sharing my music with you,

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:15.958
I'd be able to show things about myself that I can't tell you in words,

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
more personal things, perhaps deeper things.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:21.958
I think that's true for many of us, and I want to give you two examples

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:24.958
of how music is one of the most powerful interfaces we have,

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
from ourselves to the outside world.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:30.958
The first is a really crazy project that we're building right now, called

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
Death and the Powers. And it's a big opera,

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:36.958
one of the larger opera projects going on in the world right now.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:41.958
And it's about a man, rich, successful, powerful, who wants to live forever.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:43.958
So, he figures out a way to download himself into his environment,

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:46.958
actually into a series of books.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:49.958
So this guy wants to live forever, he downloads himself into his environment.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:53.958
The main singer disappears at the beginning of the opera

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:57.958
and the entire stage becomes the main character. It becomes his legacy.

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:00.958
And the opera is about what we can share, what we can pass on to others,

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:02.958
to the people we love, and what we can't.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:06.958
Every object in the opera comes alive and is a gigantic music instrument,

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:09.958
like this chandelier. It takes up the whole stage. It looks like a chandelier,

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
but it's actually a robotic music instrument.

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:15.958
So, as you can see in this prototype, gigantic piano strings,

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
each string is controlled with a little robotic element --

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:23.958
either little bows that stroke the strings, propellers that tickle the strings,

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:28.958
acoustic signals that vibrate the strings. We also have an army of robots on stage.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:32.958
These robots are the kind of the intermediary between the main character, Simon Powers,

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:36.958
and his family. There are a whole series of them, kind of like a Greek chorus.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:41.958
They observe the action. We've designed these square robots that we're testing right now

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:44.958
at MIT called OperaBots. These OperaBots follow my music.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:47.958
They follow the characters. They're smart enough, we hope,

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:50.958
not to bump into each other. They go off on their own.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:56.958
And then they can also, when you snap, line up exactly the way you'd like to.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
Even though they're cubes, they actually have a lot of personality.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:09.958
The largest set piece in the opera is called The System. It's a series of books.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:13.958
Every single book is robotic, so they all move, they all make sound,

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:17.958
and when you put them all together, they turn into these walls,

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:22.958
which have the gesture and the personality of Simon Powers. So he's disappeared,

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:25.958
but the whole physical environment becomes this person.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:28.958
This is how he's chosen to represent himself.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:35.958
The books also have high-packed LEDs on the spines. So it's all display.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:39.958
And here's the great baritone James Maddalena as he enters The System.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:40.958
This is a sneak preview.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:09.958
This premieres in Monaco -- it's in September 2009. If by any chance you can't make it,

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
another idea with this project -- here's this guy building his legacy

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:16.958
through this very unusual form, through music and through the environment.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:20.958
But we're also making this available both online and in public spaces,

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:24.958
as a way of each of us to use music and images from our lives

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:27.958
to make our own legacy or to make a legacy of someone we love.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
So instead of being grand opera, this opera will turn into what we're

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
thinking of as personal opera.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
And, if you're going to make a personal opera, what about a personal instrument?

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
Everything I've shown you so far -- whether it's a hyper-cello for Yo-Yo Ma

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:42.958
or squeezy toy for a child -- the instruments stayed the same and are valuable

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:45.958
for a certain class of person: a virtuoso, a child.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
But what if I could make an instrument that could be adapted

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:52.958
to the way I personally behave, to the way my hands work,

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
to what I do very skillfully, perhaps, to what I don't do so skillfully?

00:10:55.958 --> 00:11:00.958
I think that this is the future of interface, it's the future of music, the future of instruments.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.958
And I'd like now to invite two very special people on the stage,

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:09.958
so that I can give you an example of what personal instruments might be like.

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:14.958
So, can you give a hand to Adam Boulanger, Ph.D. student from

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:21.958
the MIT Media Lab, and Dan Ellsey. Dan,

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:28.958
thanks to TED and to Bombardier Flexjet, Dan is here with us today

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:32.958
all the way from Tewksbury. He's a resident at Tewksbury Hospital.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:36.958
This is by far the farthest he's strayed from Tewksbury Hospital, I can tell you that,

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:41.958
because he's motivated to meet with you today and show you his own music.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:45.958
So, first of all, Dan, do you want to say hi to everyone and tell everyone who you are?

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:58.958
Dan Ellsey: Hello. My name is Dan Ellsey. I am 34 years old and I have cerebral palsy.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:04.958
I have always loved music and I am excited to be able to conduct

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
my own music with this new software.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:19.958
Tod Machover: And we're really excited to have you here, really Dan. (Applause)

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:22.958
So we met Dan about three years ago, three and a half years ago,

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:27.958
when we started working at Tewksbury. Everybody we met there was fantastic,

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:32.958
did fantastic music. Dan had never made music before, and it turned out

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:39.958
he was really fantastic at it. He's a born composer.

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:42.958
He's very shy, too.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:46.958
So, turned out he's a fantastic composer, and over the last few years has been

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:49.958
a constant collaborator of ours. He has made many, many pieces.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
He makes his own CDs. Actually, he is quite well known in the Boston area --

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:56.958
mentors people at the hospital and children, locally, in how to make their own music.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:13:01.958
And I'll let Adam tell you. So, Adam is a Ph.D. student at MIT, an expert in music

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:06.958
technology and medicine. And Adam and Dan have become close collaborators.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:10.958
What Adam's been working on for this last period is not only how to have Dan

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
be able easily to make his own pieces,

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
but how he can perform his piece using this kind of personal instrument.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
So, you want to say a little bit about how you guys work?

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:21.958
Adam Boulanger: Yes. So, Tod and I entered into a discussion

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:25.958
following the Tewksbury work and it was really about how Dan is an expressive

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:30.958
person, and he's an intelligent and creative person. And it's in his face,

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:33.958
it's in his breathing, it's in his eyes. How come he can't perform

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:37.958
one of his pieces of music? That's our responsibility, and it doesn't make sense.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:40.958
So we started developing a technology that will allow him with nuance,

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:45.958
with precision, with control, and despite his physical disability, to be able to do that,

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:48.958
to be able to perform his piece of music.

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
So, the process and the technology --

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:53.958
basically, first we needed an engineering solution. So, you know,

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:56.958
we have a FireWire camera, it looked at an infrared pointer.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:14:00.958
We went with the type of gesture metaphor that Dan was already used to

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:04.958
with his speaking controller.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:07.958
And this was actually the least interesting part of the work, you know,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
the design process. We needed an input; we needed continuous tracking;

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
in the software, we look at the types of shapes he's making.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:17.958
But, then was the really interesting aspect of the work, following the engineering part,

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
where, basically, we're coding over Dan's shoulder at the hospital

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
extensively to figure out, you know, how does Dan move?

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
What's useful to him as an expressive motion?

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.958
You know, what's his metaphor for performance?

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
What types of things does he find

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:32.958
important to control and convey in a piece of music?

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:36.958
So all the parameter fitting, and really the technology

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:39.958
was stretched at that point to fit just Dan.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:45.958
And, you know, I think this is a perspective shift. It's not that our technologies --

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:49.958
they provide access, they allow us to create pieces of creative work.

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:52.958
But what about expression? What about that moment when an artist delivers

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:56.958
that piece of work? You know, do our technologies allow us to express?

00:14:56.958 --> 00:15:00.958
Do they provide structure for us to do that? And, you know, that's a personal relationship

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:04.958
to expression that is lacking in the technological sphere. So, you know,

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:07.958
with Dan, we needed a new design process, a new engineering process

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:12.958
to sort of discover his movement and his path to expression that allow him to perform.

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
And so that's what we'll do today.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:16.958
TM: So let's do it. So Dan do you want to tell everyone

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:18.958
about what you're going to play now?

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
DE: This is "My Eagle Song."

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:31.958
TM: So Dan is going to play a piece of his, called "My Eagle Song".

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:33.958
In fact, this is the score for Dan's piece,

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:36.958
completely composed by Dan in Hyperscore.

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:41.958
So he can use his infrared tracker to go directly into Hyperscore.

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:44.958
He's incredibly fast at it, too, faster than I am, in fact.

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:46.958
(Laughter)

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
TM: He's really modest, too.

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:57.958
So he can go in Hyperscore. You start out by making melodies and rhythms.

00:15:57.958 --> 00:15:59.958
He can place those exactly where he wants.

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:02.958
Each one gets a color. He goes back into the composition window,

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:07.958
draws the lines, places everything the way he wants to. Looking at the Hyperscore,

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:10.958
you can see it also, you can see where the sections are,

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:15.958
something might continue for a while, change, get really crazy and then end

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:18.958
up with a big bang at the end.

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:21.958
So that's the way he made his piece, and as Adam says,

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:28.958
we then figured out the best way to have him perform his piece.

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:31.958
It's going to be looked at by this camera, analyze his movements,

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:35.958
it's going to let Dan bring out all the different aspects of his music that he wants to.

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:38.958
And you're also going to notice a visual on the screen.

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:44.958
We asked one of our students to look at what the camera is measuring.

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:47.958
But instead of making it very literal, showing you exactly

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:52.958
the camera tracing, we turned it into a graphic that shows you the basic

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:56.958
movement, and shows the way it's being analyzed.

00:16:56.958 --> 00:17:00.958
I think it gives an understanding of how we're picking out movement from what

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:04.958
Dan's doing, but I think it will also show you, if you look at that movement,

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:11.958
that when Dan makes music, his motions are very purposeful, very precise,

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:14.958
very disciplined and they're also very beautiful.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:19.958
So, in hearing this piece, as I mentioned before, the most important thing is

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:22.958
the music's great, and it'll show you who Dan is.

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:24.958
So, are we ready Adam?

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:26.958
AB: Yeah.

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:30.958
TM: OK, now Dan will play his piece "My Eagle Song" for you.

00:19:54.958 --> 00:20:18.958
(Applause)

00:20:18.958 --> 00:20:20.958
TM: Bravo.

00:20:20.958 --> 00:20:29.958
(Applause)

title: The new open-source economics
transcript: One of the problems of writing, and working, and looking at the Internet is that it's very hard to separate fashion from deep change. And so, to start helping that, I want to take us back to 1835. In 1835, James Gordon Bennett founded the first mass-circulation newspaper in New York City. And it cost about 500 dollars to start it, which was about the equivalent of 10,000 dollars of today. By 15 years later, by 1850, doing the same thing — starting what was experienced as a mass—circulation daily paper — would come to cost two and a half million dollars. 10,000, two and a half million, 15 years. That's the critical change that is being inverted by the Net. And that's what I want to talk about today, and how that relates to the emergence of social production.Starting with newspapers, what we saw was high cost as an initial requirement for making information, knowledge and culture, which led to a stark bifurcation between producers — who had to be able to raise financial capital, just like any other industrial organization — and passive consumers that could choose from a certain set of things that this industrial model could produce. Now, the term "information society," "information economy," for a very long time has been used as the thing that comes after the industrial revolution. But in fact, for purposes of understanding what's happening today, that's wrong. Because for 150 years, we've had an information economy. It's just been industrial, which means those who were producing had to have a way of raising money to pay those two and a half million dollars, and later, more for the telegraph, and the radio transmitter, and the television, and eventually the mainframe. And that meant they were market based, or they were government owned, depending on what kind of system they were in. And this characterized and anchored the way information and knowledge were produced for the next 150 years.Now, let me tell you a different story. Around June 2002, the world of supercomputers had a bombshell. The Japanese had, for the first time, created the fastest supercomputer — the NEC Earth Simulator — taking the primary from the U.S., and about two years later — this, by the way, is measuring the trillion floating-point operations per second that the computer's capable of running — sigh of relief: IBM [Blue Gene] has just edged ahead of the NEC Earth Simulator. All of this completely ignores the fact that throughout this period, there's another supercomputer running in the world — SETI@home. Four and a half million users around the world, contributing their leftover computer cycles, whenever their computer isn't working, by running a screen saver, and together sharing their resources to create a massive supercomputer that NASA harnesses to analyze the data coming from radio telescopes.What this picture suggests to us is that we've got a radical change in the way information production and exchange is capitalized. Not that it's become less capital intensive — that there's less money that's required — but that the ownership of this capital, the way the capitalization happens, is radically distributed. Each of us, in these advanced economies, has one of these, or something rather like it — a computer. They're not radically different from routers inside the middle of the network. And computation, storage and communications capacity are in the hands of practically every connected person — and these are the basic physical capital means necessary for producing information, knowledge and culture, in the hands of something like 600 million to a billion people around the planet.What this means is that for the first time since the industrial revolution, the most important means, the most important components of the core economic activities — remember, we are in an information economy — of the most advanced economies, and there more than anywhere else, are in the hands of the population at large. This is completely different than what we've seen since the industrial revolution. So we've got communications and computation capacity in the hands of the entire population, and we've got human creativity, human wisdom, human experience — the other major experience, the other major input — which unlike simple labor — stand here turning this lever all day long — is not something that's the same or fungible among people. Any one of you who has taken someone else's job, or tried to give yours to someone else, no matter how detailed the manual, you cannot transmit what you know, what you will intuit under a certain set of circumstances. In that we're unique, and each of us holds this critical input into production as we hold this machine.What's the effect of this? So, the story that most people know is the story of free or open source software. This is market share of Apache Web server — one of the critical applications in Web-based communications. In 1995, two groups of people said, "Wow, this is really important, the Web! We need a much better Web server!" One was a motley collection of volunteers who just decided, you know, we really need this, we should write one, and what are we going to do with what — well, we're gonna share it! And other people will be able to develop it. The other was Microsoft.Now, if I told you that 10 years later, the motley crew of people, who didn't control anything that they produced, acquired 20 percent of the market and was the red line, it would be amazing! Right? Think of it in minivans. A group of automobile engineers on their weekends are competing with Toyota. Right? But, in fact, of course, the story is it's the 70 percent, including the major e-commerce site — 70 percent of a critical application on which Web-based communications and applications work is produced in this form, in direct competition with Microsoft. Not in a side issue — in a central strategic decision to try to capture a component of the Net. Software has done this in a way that's been very visible, because it's measurable. But the thing to see is that this actually happens throughout the Web.So, NASA, at some point, did an experiment where they took images of Mars that they were mapping, and they said, instead of having three or four fully trained Ph.D.s doing this all the time, let's break it up into small components, put it up on the Web, and see if people, using a very simple interface, will actually spend five minutes here, 10 minutes there, clicking. After six months, 85,000 people used this to generate mapping at a faster rate than the images were coming in, which was, quote, "practically indistinguishable from the markings of a fully-trained Ph.D.," once you showed it to a number of people and computed the average.Now, if you have a little girl, and she goes and writes to — well, not so little, medium little — tries to do research on Barbie. And she'll come to Encarta, one of the main online encyclopedias. This is what you'll find out about Barbie. This is it, there's nothing more to the definition, including, "manufacturers" — plural — "now more commonly produce ethnically diverse dolls, like this black Barbie." Which is vastly better than what you'll find in the encyclopedia.com, which is Barbie, Klaus. (Laughter) On the other hand, if they go to Wikipedia, they'll find a genuine article — and I won't talk a lot about Wikipedia, because Jimmy Wales is here — but roughly equivalent to what you would find in the Britannica, differently written, including the controversies over body image and commercialization, the claims about the way in which she's a good role model, etc.Another portion is not only how content is produced, but how relevance is produced. The claim to fame of Yahoo! was, we hire people to look — originally, not anymore — we hire people to look at websites and tell you — if they're in the index, they're good. This, on the other hand, is what 60,000 passionate volunteers produce in the Open Directory Project, each one willing to spend an hour or two on something they really care about, to say, this is good. So, this is the Open Directory Project, with 60,000 volunteers, each one spending a little bit of time, as opposed to a few hundred fully paid employees. No one owns it, no one owns the output, it's free for anyone to use and it's the output of people acting out of social and psychological motivations to do something interesting.This is not only outside of businesses. When you think of what is the critical innovation of Google, the critical innovation is outsourcing the one most important thing — the decision about what's relevant — to the community of the Web as a whole, doing whatever they want to do: so, page rank. The critical innovation here is instead of our engineers, or our people saying which is the most relevant, we're going to go out and count what you, people out there on the Web, for whatever reason — vanity, pleasure — produced links, and tied to each other. We're going to count those, and count them up. And again, here, you see Barbie.com, but also, very quickly, Adiosbarbie.com, the body image for every size. A contested cultural object, which you won't find anywhere soon on Overture, which is the classic market-based mechanism: whoever pays the most is highest on the list.So, all of that is in the creation of content, of relevance, basic human expression. But remember, the computers were also physical. Just physical materials — our PCs — we share them together. We also see this in wireless. It used to be wireless was one person owned the license, they transmitted in an area, and it had to be decided whether they would be licensed or based on property. What we're seeing now is that computers and radios are becoming so sophisticated that we're developing algorithms to let people own machines, like Wi-Fi devices, and overlay them with a sharing protocol that would allow a community like this to build its own wireless broadband network simply from the simple principle: When I'm listening, when I'm not using, I can help you transfer your messages; and when you're not using, you'll help me transfer yours. And this is not an idealized version. These are working models that at least in some places in the United States are being implemented, at least for public security.If in 1999 I told you, let's build a data storage and retrieval system. It's got to store terabytes. It's got to be available 24 hours a day, seven days a week. It's got to be available from anywhere in the world. It has to support over 100 million users at any given moment. It's got to be robust to attack, including closing the main index, injecting malicious files, armed seizure of some major nodes. You'd say that would take years. It would take millions. But of course, what I'm describing is P2P file sharing. Right? We always think of it as stealing music, but fundamentally, it's a distributed data storage and retrieval system, where people, for very obvious reasons, are willing to share their bandwidth and their storage to create something.So, essentially what we're seeing is the emergence of a fourth transactional framework. It used to be that there were two primary dimensions along which you could divide things. They could be market based, or non-market based; they could be decentralized, or centralized. The price system was a market-based and decentralized system. If things worked better because you actually had somebody organizing them, you had firms, if you wanted to be in the market — or you had governments or sometimes larger non-profits in the non-market. It was too expensive to have decentralized social production, to have decentralized action in society. That was not about society itself. That was, in fact, economic.But what we're seeing now is the emergence of this fourth system of social sharing and exchange. Not that it's the first time that we do nice things to each other, or for each other, as social beings. We do it all the time. It's that it's the first time that it's having major economic impact. What characterizes them is decentralized authority. You don't have to ask permission, as you do in a property-based system. May I do this? It's open for anyone to create and innovate and share, if they want to, by themselves or with others, because property is one mechanism of coordination. But it's not the only one.Instead, what we see are social frameworks for all of the critical things that we use property and contract in the market: information flows to decide what are interesting problems; who's available and good for something; motivation structures — remember, money isn't always the best motivator. If you leave a $50 check after dinner with friends, you don't increase the probability of being invited back. And if dinner isn't entirely obvious, think of sex. (Laughter)It also requires certain new organizational approaches. And in particular, what we've seen is task organization. You have to hire people who know what they're doing. You have to hire them to spend a lot of time. Now, take the same problem, chunk it into little modules, and motivations become trivial. Five minutes, instead of watching TV? Five minutes I'll spend just because it's interesting. Just because it's fun. Just because it gives me a certain sense of meaning, or, in places that are more involved, like Wikipedia, gives me a certain set of social relations.So, a new social phenomenon is emerging. It's creating, and it's most visible when we see it as a new form of competition. Peer-to-peer networks assaulting the recording industry; free and open source software taking market share from Microsoft; Skype potentially threatening traditional telecoms; Wikipedia competing with online encyclopedias. But it's also a new source of opportunities for businesses. As you see a new set of social relations and behaviors emerging, you have new opportunities. Some of them are toolmakers. Instead of building well-behaved appliances — things that you know what they'll do in advance — you begin to build more open tools. There's a new set of values, a new set of things people value. You build platforms for self-expression and collaboration. Like Wikipedia, like the Open Directory Project, you're beginning to build platforms, and you see that as a model. And you see surfers, people who see this happening, and in some sense build it into a supply chain, which is a very curious one. Right?You have a belief: stuff will flow out of connected human beings. That'll give me something I can use, and I'm going to contract with someone. I will deliver something based on what happens. It's very scary — that's what Google does, essentially. That's what IBM does in software services, and they've done reasonably well.So, social production is a real fact, not a fad. It is the critical long-term shift caused by the Internet. Social relations and exchange become significantly more important than they ever were as an economic phenomenon. In some contexts, it's even more efficient because of the quality of the information, the ability to find the best person, the lower transaction costs. It's sustainable and growing fast.But — and this is the dark lining — it is threatened by — in the same way that it threatens — the incumbent industrial systems. So next time you open the paper, and you see an intellectual property decision, a telecoms decision, it's not about something small and technical. It is about the future of the freedom to be as social beings with each other, and the way information, knowledge and culture will be produced. Because it is in this context that we see a battle over how easy or hard it will be for the industrial information economy to simply go on as it goes, or for the new model of production to begin to develop alongside that industrial model, and change the way we begin to see the world and report what it is that we see. Thank you.

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
One of the problems of writing, and working, and looking at the Internet

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:21.958
is that it's very hard to separate fashion from deep change.

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:25.958
And so, to start helping that, I want to take us back to 1835.

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:32.958
In 1835, James Gordon Bennett founded the first mass-circulation newspaper

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.958
in New York City.

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:37.958
And it cost about 500 dollars to start it,

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:41.958
which was about the equivalent of 10,000 dollars of today.

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:45.958
By 15 years later, by 1850, doing the same thing

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:48.958
-- starting what was experienced as a mass--circulation daily paper

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:52.958
-- would come to cost two and a half million dollars.

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:55.958
10,000, two and a half million, 15 years.

00:00:55.958 --> 00:01:02.958
That's the critical change that is being inverted by the Net.

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:05.958
And that's what I want to talk about today,

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:08.958
and how that relates to the emergence of social production.

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:16.958
Starting with newspapers, what we saw was high cost as an initial requirement

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:22.958
for making information, knowledge and culture, which led to a stark bifurcation

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:26.958
between producers -- who had to be able to raise financial capital,

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:30.958
just like any other industrial organization --

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:33.958
and passive consumers that could choose from a certain set of

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:38.958
things that this industrial model could produce.

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:41.958
Now, the term "information society," "information economy,"

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:45.958
for a very long time has been used as the thing that comes after

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:51.958
the industrial revolution. But in fact, for purposes of understanding what's happening

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:57.958
today, that's wrong. Because for 150 years, we've had an information economy.

00:01:57.958 --> 00:01:59.958
It's just been industrial,

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:03.958
which means those who were producing had to have a way of raising money

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:07.958
to pay those two and a half million dollars, and later, more for the telegraph,

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:12.958
and the radio transmitter, and the television, and eventually the mainframe.

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:15.958
And that meant they were market based, or they were government owned,

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:20.958
depending on what kind of system they were in. And this characterized and anchored

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:27.958
the way information and knowledge were produced for the next 150 years.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:32.958
Now, let me tell you a different story. Around June 2002,

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:36.958
the world of supercomputers had a bombshell.

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:40.958
The Japanese had, for the first time, created the fastest supercomputer --

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:43.958
the NEC Earth Simulator -- taking the primary from the U.S.,

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:47.958
and about two years later -- this, by the way, is measuring the trillion floating-point

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:51.958
operations per second that the computer's capable of running --

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:57.958
sigh of relief: IBM [Blue Gene] has just edged ahead of the NEC Earth Simulator.

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:01.958
All of this completely ignores the fact that throughout this period,

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:05.958
there's another supercomputer running in the world -- SETI@home.

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:09.958
Four and a half million users around the world, contributing their

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:13.958
leftover computer cycles, whenever their computer isn't working,

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:20.958
by running a screen saver, and together sharing their resources to create

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:25.958
a massive supercomputer that NASA harnesses to analyze the data

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:29.958
coming from radio telescopes.

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:36.958
What this picture suggests to us is that we've got a radical change in the way

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:40.958
information production and exchange is capitalized. Not that it's become

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:43.958
less capital intensive -- that there's less money that's required

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:48.958
-- but that the ownership of this capital, the way the capitalization happens,

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:53.958
is radically distributed. Each of us, in these advanced economies,

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:58.958
has one of these, or something rather like it -- a computer.

00:03:58.958 --> 00:04:03.958
They're not radically different from routers inside the middle of the network.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:08.958
And computation, storage and communications capacity are in the hands of

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:14.958
practically every connected person -- and these are the basic physical

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:19.958
capital means necessary for producing information, knowledge and culture,

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:25.958
in the hands of something like 600 million to a billion people around the planet.

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:31.958
What this means is that for the first time since the industrial revolution,

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:37.958
the most important means, the most important components of the core

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:41.958
economic activities -- remember, we are in an information economy

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:46.958
-- of the most advanced economies, and there more than anywhere else,

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:50.958
are in the hands of the population at large. This is completely different than what we've

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:55.958
seen since the industrial revolution. So we've got communications and computation

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:58.958
capacity in the hands of the entire population,

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:03.958
and we've got human creativity, human wisdom, human experience

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:06.958
-- the other major experience, the other major input --

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:11.958
which unlike simple labor -- stand here turning this lever all day long --

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:14.958
is not something that's the same or fungible among people.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:17.958
Any one of you who has taken someone else's job, or tried to give yours

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:23.958
to someone else, no matter how detailed the manual, you cannot transmit

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:28.958
what you know, what you will intuit under a certain set of circumstances.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:32.958
In that we're unique, and each of us holds this critical input

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:36.958
into production as we hold this machine.

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:41.958
What's the effect of this? So, the story that most people know

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:45.958
is the story of free or open source software.

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.958
This is market share of Apache Web server

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:54.958
-- one of the critical applications in Web-based communications.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:58.958
In 1995, two groups of people said,

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:02.958
"Wow, this is really important, the Web! We need a much better Web server!"

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:06.958
One was a motley collection of volunteers who just decided,

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:08.958
you know, we really need this, we should write one,

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:11.958
and what are we going to do with what --

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:13.958
well, we're gonna share it! And other people will be able to develop it.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
The other was Microsoft.

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:20.958
Now, if I told you that 10 years later, the motley crew of people, who didn't control

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:23.958
anything that they produced, acquired 20 percent of the market

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
and was the red line, it would be amazing! Right?

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:29.958
Think of it in minivans. A group of automobile

00:06:29.958 --> 00:06:34.958
engineers on their weekends are competing with Toyota. Right?

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
But, in fact, of course, the story is it's the 70 percent,

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:42.958
including the major e-commerce site -- 70 percent of a critical application

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:48.958
on which Web-based communications and applications work is produced in this form, in

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:52.958
direct competition with Microsoft. Not in a side issue --

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:59.958
in a central strategic decision to try to capture a component of the Net.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:04.958
Software has done this in a way that's been very visible, because

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:10.958
it's measurable. But the thing to see is that this actually happens throughout the Web.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:16.958
So, NASA, at some point, did an experiment where they took images of Mars

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:20.958
that they were mapping, and they said, instead of having three or four

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:25.958
fully trained Ph.D.s doing this all the time, let's break it up into small components,

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:29.958
put it up on the Web, and see if people, using a very simple interface,

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
will actually spend five minutes here,

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:35.958
10 minutes there, clicking. After six months,

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:40.958
85,000 people used this to generate mapping at a

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:44.958
faster rate than the images were coming in, which was, quote,

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:48.958
"practically indistinguishable from the markings of a fully-trained Ph.D.,"

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:55.958
once you showed it to a number of people and computed the average.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
Now, if you have a little girl, and she goes and writes to

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:02.958
-- well, not so little, medium little -- tries to do research on Barbie.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:06.958
And she'll come to Encarta, one of the main online encyclopedias.

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:12.958
This is what you'll find out about Barbie. This is it, there's nothing more to the definition,

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:16.958
including, "manufacturers" -- plural -- "now more commonly produce

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:20.958
ethnically diverse dolls, like this black Barbie." Which is vastly better

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
than what you'll find in the encyclopedia.com,

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:27.958
which is Barbie, Klaus. (Laughter)

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:32.958
On the other hand, if they go to Wikipedia, they'll find a genuine article

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:35.958
-- and I won't talk a lot about Wikipedia, because Jimmy Wales is here --

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:41.958
but roughly equivalent to what you would find in the Britannica, differently written,

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:45.958
including the controversies over body image and commercialization,

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:53.958
the claims about the way in which she's a good role model, etc.

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:57.958
Another portion is not only how content is produced, but how relevance is produced.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:01.958
The claim to fame of Yahoo! was, we hire people to look -- originally, not anymore

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:06.958
-- we hire people to look at websites and tell you --

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:10.958
if they're in the index, they're good. This, on the other hand, is what 60,000

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:14.958
passionate volunteers produce in the Open Directory Project,

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:19.958
each one willing to spend an hour or two on something they really care about,

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:25.958
to say, this is good. So, this is the Open Directory Project, with 60,000 volunteers,

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:28.958
each one spending a little bit of time, as opposed to a few hundred

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:33.958
fully paid employees. No one owns it, no one owns the output,

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:38.958
it's free for anyone to use and it's the output of people acting out of social

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:42.958
and psychological motivations to do something interesting.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:48.958
This is not only outside of businesses. When you think of what is the critical innovation

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:53.958
of Google, the critical innovation is outsourcing the one most important thing --

00:09:53.958 --> 00:10:00.958
the decision about what's relevant -- to the community of the Web as a whole,

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.958
doing whatever they want to do: so, page rank.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:09.958
The critical innovation here is instead of our engineers, or our people saying

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
which is the most relevant, we're going to go out and count what you,

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:16.958
people out there on the Web, for whatever reason -- vanity, pleasure --

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:22.958
produced links, and tied to each other. We're going to count those, and count them up.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:26.958
And again, here, you see Barbie.com, but also, very quickly,

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:31.958
Adiosbarbie.com, the body image for every size. A contested cultural object,

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:35.958
which you won't find anywhere soon on Overture, which is the classic

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:40.958
market-based mechanism: whoever pays the most is highest on the list.

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:45.958
So, all of that is in the creation of content, of relevance, basic human expression.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:49.958
But remember, the computers were also physical. Just physical materials

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:53.958
-- our PCs -- we share them together. We also see this in wireless.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:59.958
It used to be wireless was one person owned the license, they transmitted in an

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:04.958
area, and it had to be decided whether they would be licensed or based on property.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:09.958
What we're seeing now is that computers and radios are becoming so sophisticated

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:15.958
that we're developing algorithms to let people own machines, like Wi-Fi devices,

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:20.958
and overlay them with a sharing protocol that would allow a community like this

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:26.958
to build its own wireless broadband network simply from the simple principle:

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:32.958
When I'm listening, when I'm not using, I can help you transfer your messages;

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
and when you're not using, you'll help me transfer yours.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:40.958
And this is not an idealized version. These are working models that at least in some

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:47.958
places in the United States are being implemented, at least for public security.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:53.958
If in 1999 I told you, let's build a data storage and retrieval system.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:56.958
It's got to store terabytes. It's got to be available 24 hours a day,

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
seven days a week. It's got to be available from anywhere in the world.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:03.958
It has to support over 100 million users at any given moment. It's got to

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:08.958
be robust to attack, including closing the main index, injecting malicious files,

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:13.958

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:20.958
It would take millions. But of course, what I'm describing is P2P file sharing.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:23.958
Right? We always think of it as stealing music, but fundamentally,

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:27.958
it's a distributed data storage and retrieval system, where people,

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:31.958

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:34.958

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:38.958
So, essentially what we're seeing is the emergence of a fourth transactional

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:44.958
framework. It used to be that there were two primary dimensions along which

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:47.958
you could divide things. They could be market based, or non-market based;

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:49.958
they could be decentralized, or centralized.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
The price system was a market-based and decentralized system.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:56.958
If things worked better because you actually had somebody organizing them,

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
you had firms, if you wanted to be in the market -- or you had governments

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:02.958

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:07.958
It was too expensive to have decentralized social production,

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:14.958

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
That was, in fact, economic.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:20.958

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:21.958
of social sharing and exchange.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:26.958
Not that it's the first time that we do nice things to each other, or for each other,

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:30.958
as social beings. We do it all the time.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:34.958
It's that it's the first time that it's having major economic impact.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:39.958
What characterizes them is decentralized authority.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:42.958

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:48.958

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:52.958
if they want to, by themselves or with others,

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
because property is one mechanism of coordination.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:56.958
But it's not the only one.

00:13:56.958 --> 00:14:01.958
Instead, what we see are social frameworks for all of the critical things that we use

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:04.958
property and contract in the market: information flows to decide what are

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:08.958
interesting problems; who's available and good for something;

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:12.958
motivation structures -- remember, money isn't always the best motivator.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:16.958
If you leave a $50 check after dinner with friends,

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:20.958
you don't increase the probability of being invited back.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:26.958
And if dinner isn't entirely obvious, think of sex. (Laughter)

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
It also requires certain new organizational approaches.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:33.958
And in particular, what we've seen is task organization.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
You have to hire people who know what they're doing.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:38.958
You have to hire them to spend a lot of time.

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:40.958
Now, take the same problem,

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:44.958
chunk it into little modules, and motivations become trivial.

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:46.958
Five minutes, instead of watching TV?

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:50.958
Five minutes I'll spend just because it's interesting. Just because it's fun.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:54.958
Just because it gives me a certain sense of meaning, or, in places that are more

00:14:54.958 --> 00:15:00.958
involved, like Wikipedia, gives me a certain set of social relations.

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:04.958
So, a new social phenomenon is emerging.

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:09.958
It's creating, and it's most visible when we see it as a new form of competition.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:12.958
Peer-to-peer networks assaulting the recording industry;

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:16.958
free and open source software taking market share from Microsoft;

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:20.958
Skype potentially threatening traditional telecoms;

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.958
Wikipedia competing with online encyclopedias.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:26.958
But it's also a new source of opportunities for businesses.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:32.958
As you see a new set of social relations and behaviors emerging,

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:36.958
you have new opportunities. Some of them are toolmakers.

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:39.958
Instead of building well-behaved appliances

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:41.958
-- things that you know what they'll do in advance --

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:44.958
you begin to build more open tools. There's a new set of values,

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:47.958
a new set of things people value.

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:51.958
You build platforms for self-expression and collaboration.

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:55.958
Like Wikipedia, like the Open Directory Project,

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:58.958
you're beginning to build platforms, and you see that as a model.

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:02.958
And you see surfers, people who see this happening, and in some sense

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:07.958
build it into a supply chain, which is a very curious one. Right?

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:10.958
You have a belief: stuff will flow out of connected human beings.

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:13.958
That'll give me something I can use, and I'm going to contract with someone.

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:17.958
I will deliver something based on what happens. It's very scary

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:19.958
-- that's what Google does, essentially.

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:23.958
That's what IBM does in software services, and they've done reasonably well.

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:27.958
So, social production is a real fact, not a fad.

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:31.958
It is the critical long-term shift caused by the Internet.

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:38.958
Social relations and exchange become significantly more important than they ever

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:42.958
were as an economic phenomenon. In some contexts, it's even more efficient

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:47.958
because of the quality of the information, the ability to find the best person,

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:51.958
the lower transaction costs. It's sustainable and growing fast.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:57.958
But -- and this is the dark lining -- it is threatened by

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:01.958
-- in the same way that it threatens -- the incumbent industrial systems.

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:06.958
So next time you open the paper, and you see an intellectual property decision,

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:12.958
a telecoms decision, it's not about something small and technical.

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:18.958
It is about the future of the freedom to be as social beings with each other,

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:23.958
and the way information, knowledge and culture will be produced.

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:30.958
Because it is in this context that we see a battle over how easy or hard it will be

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:34.958
for the industrial information economy to simply go on as it goes,

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:40.958
or for the new model of production to begin to develop alongside that industrial model,

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:45.958
and change the way we begin to see the world and report what it is that we see.

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:46.958
Thank you.

title: World-class health care
transcript: It is interesting that in the United States, the most significant health-care budget goes to cardiovascular disease care, whether it's private or public. There's no comparison at all. In Africa — where it is a major killer — it is totally ignored.And that situation cannot be right. We must do something about it. A health status of a nation parallels development of that nation. 17 million people die every year from heart disease. 32 million heart attacks and strokes occur. Most of this is in developing countries, and the majority is in Africa. 85 percent of global disease burden for cardiovascular disease is in developing countries — not in the West — and yet 90 percent of the resources are in the West.Who is at risk? People like you. It's not just the Africans that should be concerned about that. All friends of Africa, that will have reason to be in Africa at some point in time, should be very concerned about this deplorable situation. Has anyone here wondered what will happen if you go back to your room at night, and you start getting chest pains, shortness of breath, sweating? You're having a heart attack. What are you going to do? Will you fly back to the U.S., Germany, Europe? No, you will die. 50 percent will die within 24 hours, if not treated.This is what's going on. In a look at the map of the U.S. — the graph here, 10 million people here, 10 million here. By the time you get to 50, it's almost no one left in Nigeria — life expectancy is 47. It's not because some people don't survive childhood illnesses — they do — but they do not survive after the time that they reach about 45 years old and 50 years old. And those are the times they're most productive. Those are the times that they should be contributing to Africa's development. But they're not there. The best way to spiral into a cycle of poverty is to kill the parents. If you cannot secure the parents, you cannot guarantee the security of the African child.What are the risk factors? It's very well known. I'm not going to spend a lot of time on those. These are just for information: hypertension, diabetes, obesity, lack of exercise. The usual suspects. Right here in Tanzania, 30 percent of individuals have hypertension. 20 percent are getting treated. Only less than one percent are adequately treated. If we can treat hypertension alone in Africa, we'll save 250,000 lives a year. That's quite significant!Easy to treat. Look at the situation in Mauritius. In eight short years — we're here talking about HIV, malaria, which is all good. We cannot make the mistakes we've made with malaria and HIV. In eight short years, non-communicable diseases will become the leading causes of death in Africa.That is something to keep in mind. We can't deal with it with situations like this. This is a typical African hospital. We can't depend on the elites — they go to USA, Germany, U.K. for treatment. Unbelievable. You can't depend on foreign aid alone. Here is the situation: countries are turning inwards. Post-9/11, [the] United States has had a lot of trouble to deal with, their own internal issues. So, they spend their money trying to fix those problems. You can't rightly — it's not their responsibility, it is my responsibility. I have to take care of my own problems. If they help, that's good! But that is not my expectation. These worsening indices of health care or health studies in Africa demand a new look. We cannot keep on doing things the way we've always done them. If they have not worked, we have to look for alternative solutions.I'm here to talk to you about solutions. This has been — what has been a difficult sign to some of us. Several years ago, we started thinking about it. Everyone knows the problem. No one knows what the solutions are. We decided that we needed to put our money where our mouth is. Everyone is ready to throw in money, in terms of free money aid to developing countries. Talk about sustainable investment, no one is interested. You can't raise money. I have done businesses in healthcare in the United States — I live in Nashville, Tennessee, health care capital of America. [It's] very easy to raise money for health-care ventures. But start telling them, you know, we're going to try to do it in Nigeria — everyone runs away. That is totally wrong. Those of you in the audience here, if you want to help Africa, invest money in sustainable development.Let me lead you through a day in the life of the Heart Institute, so you get a glimpse of what we do, and I'll talk a little bit more about it. What we have done is to show that high-quality health care, comparable to the best anywhere in the world, can be done in a developing country environment. We have 25 positions right now — all of them trained, board certified in the USA, Canada or Britain. We have every modality that can be done in Vanderbilt, Cleveland Clinic — everywhere in the U.S. — and we do it for about 10 percent of the cost that you will need to do those things in the United States. (Applause)Additionally, we have a policy that no one is ever turned away because of ability to pay. We take care of everyone. (Applause) Whether you have one dollar, two dollars — it doesn't matter. And I will tell you how we're able to do it.We make sure that we select our equipment properly. We go for modular units. Units that have multi-modality functions have modular components. Easy to repair, and because of that, we do not take things that are not durable and cannot last. We emphasize training, and we make sure that this process is regenerative. Very soon we will all be dead and gone, but the problems will stay, unless we have people taking over from where we stopped.We made sure that we produced some things ourselves. We do not buy unit doses of radiopharmaceuticals. We get the generators from the companies. We manufacture them in-house, ourselves. That keeps the costs down. So, for a radiopharmaceutical in the U.S. — that you'll get a unit dose for 250 dollars — when we're finished manufacturing it in-house, we come at a price of about two dollars. (Applause)We recognize that the only way to bridge the gap between the rich and poor countries is through education and technology. All these problems we're talking about — if we bring development, they will all disappear. Technology is a great equalizer. How do we make it work? It's been proved: self-care is cost-effective. It extends opportunity to the rural centers, and we can use expertise in a very smart way.This is the way our centers are set up. We currently have three locations in the Caribbean, and we're planning a fourth one. And we have now decided to go into Africa. We will be doing the West African Heart Institute in Port Harcourt, Nigeria. That project will be starting within the next few months. We hope to open in 2008-09. And we will do other centers. This model can be adapted to every disease process. All the units, all the centers, are linked through a switched hub to a central server, and all the images are populated to review stations. And we designed this telemedicine solution. It's proprietary to us, and we are happy to share what we have learned with anyone who is interested in doing it. You can still be profitable.We make sure that the telemedicine platform gives access to expert medical specialists anywhere in the world, just by a click of the button. I'll lead you through, to see how this happens. This is at the Heart Institute. The doctors from anywhere can log in. I can call you in Switzerland and say, "Listen, go into our system. Look at Mrs. Jones. Look at the study, tell me what you think." They'll give me that information, and we'll make the care of the patient better. The patient doesn't have to travel. He doesn't have to experience the anxiety of not knowing because of limited expertise.We also use [an] electronic medical record system. I'm happy to say that the things we have implemented — 80 percent of U.S. practices do not have them, and yet the technology is there. But you know, they have that luxury. Because if you can't get it in Nashville, you can travel to Birmingham, two hours away, and you'll get it. If you can't get it in Cleveland, you can go to Cincinnati. We don't have that luxury, so we have to make it happen. When we do it, we will put the cost of care down. And we'll extend it to the rural centers and make it affordable. And everyone will get the care they deserve.It cannot just be technology, we recognize that. Prevention must be part of the solution — we emphasize that. But, you know, you have to tell people what can be done. It's not possible to tell people to do what is going to be expensive, and they go home and can't do it. They need to be alive, they need to feed. We recommend exercise as the most effective, simple, easy thing to do. We have had walks every year — every March, April. We form people into groups and make them go into challenges. Which group loses the most weight, we give them prizes. Which groups record more walking distance by pedometer, we give them prizes. We do this constantly. We encourage them to bring children. That way we start exposing the children from very early on, on what these issues are. Because once they learn it,they will stay with it. In doing this we have created at least 100 skilled jobs in Jamaica alone, and these are physicians with expertise and special training. We have taken care of over 1,000 indigent patients that could have died, including four free pacemakers in patients with complete heart block. For those that understand cardiology, complete heart block means certain death. If you don't get this pacemaker, you will be dead. So we are pleased with that.Indirectly, we have saved the government of Jamaica five million dollars from people that would have gone to Miami or Atlanta for care. And we've hopefully saved a lot of lives. By the end of this year, we would have contributed over one million dollars in indigent care. In the first four months, it's been 340,000 dollars, averaging 85,000 dollars a month. The government will not do that, because they have competing needs. They need to put resources elsewhere. But we can still do it. People say, "How can you do that?" This is how we can do that. At least 4,000 rich Jamaicans that were heading to Miami for treatment have self-confessed that they did not go to Miami because of the Heart Institute of the Caribbean. And, if they went to Miami, they will spend significantly more — eight to 10 times more. And they feel happy spending it at home, getting the same quality of care. And for that money — for every one patient that has the money to pay, it gives us an opportunity to take care of at least four people that do not have the resources to pay. (Applause)For this to work, this progress must be sustainable. So, we emphasize training. Training is critical. We have gone further: we have formed a relationship with the University of Technology, Jamaica, where I now have an appointment. And we are starting a biomedical engineering program, so that we will train people locally, who can repair that equipment. That way we're not going to deal with obsolescence and all those kinds of issues. We're also starting ancillary health-care technology training programs — training people in echocardiography, cardiac ultrasound, those kinds of things. Now, with that kind of training, it gives people motivation. Because now they will get a bachelors degree in medical imaging and all that kind of stuff. In the process, I want you to just hear from the trainees themselves what it has meant for them.(Video) Dr. Jason Topping: My name is Jason Topping. I'm a senior resident in anesthesia in intensive care at the University Hospital of the West Indies. I came to the Heart Institute in 2006, as part of my elective in my anesthesia and intensive care program. I spent three months at the Heart Institute. There's been no doubt around my colleagues about the utility of the training I received here, and I think there's been an increased interest now in — particularly in echocardiography and its use in our setting.Sharon Lazarus: I am an echocardiographer at the Heart Institute of the Caribbean, since the past two years. I received training at this institution. I think this aspect of training in cardiology that the Heart Institute of the Caribbean has introduced in Jamaica is very important in terms of diagnosing cardiac diseases.Ernest Madu: The lesson in this is that it can be done, and it can be sustained, and you can make it possible for everyone. Who are we to decide that poor people cannot get the best care? When have you been appointed to play God? It is not my decision. My job is to make sure that every person, no matter what fate has assigned to you, will have the opportunity to get the best quality health care in life. Next stop is West African Heart Institute, that we are going to be doing in Port Harcourt, Nigeria, as I said before. We will do other centers across West Africa. We will extend the same system into other areas, like dialysis treatment. And anyone who is interested in doing it in any health care situation, we will be happy to assist you and tell you how we've done it,and how you can do it. If we do this, we can change the face of health care in Africa. Africa has been good to us; it is time for us to give back to Africa. I am going. Those who want to come, I welcome you to come along with me. Thank you. (Applause)
