unless we have people taking over from where we stopped.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
We made sure that we produced some things ourselves.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.958
We do not buy unit doses of radiopharmaceuticals.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.958
We get the generators from the companies.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:57.958
We manufacture them in-house, ourselves. That keeps the costs down.

00:07:57.958 --> 00:08:00.958
So, for a radiopharmaceutical in the U.S. --

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:03.958
that you'll get a unit dose for 250 dollars --

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
when we're finished manufacturing it in-house,

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
we come at a price of about two dollars.

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:11.958
(Applause)

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:14.958
We recognize that the only way to bridge the gap

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:17.958
between the rich and poor countries

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
is through education and technology.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
All these problems we're talking about --

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:25.958
if we bring development, they will all disappear.

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:30.958
Technology is a great equalizer. How do we make it work?

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:32.958
It's been proved: self-care is cost-effective.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:36.958
It extends opportunity to the rural centers,

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
and we can use expertise in a very smart way.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.958
This is the way our centers are set up.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:45.958
We currently have three locations in the Caribbean,

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
and we're planning a fourth one.

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:50.958
And we have now decided to go into Africa.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
We will be doing the West African Heart Institute

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
in Port Harcourt, Nigeria. That project will be starting

00:08:56.958 --> 00:09:00.958
within the next few months. We hope to open in 2008-09.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
And we will do other centers.

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:06.958
This model can be adapted to every disease process.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
All the units, all the centers, are linked

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:12.958
through a switched hub to a central server,

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
and all the images are populated to review stations.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:20.958
And we designed this telemedicine solution. It's proprietary to us,

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
and we are happy to share what we have learned with anyone

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:28.958
who is interested in doing it. You can still be profitable.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:34.958
We make sure that the telemedicine platform gives access

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:38.958
to expert medical specialists anywhere in the world,

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
just by a click of the button.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:43.958
I'll lead you through, to see how this happens.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:47.958
This is at the Heart Institute. The doctors from anywhere can log in.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:51.958
I can call you in Switzerland and say, "Listen, go into our system.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:55.958
Look at Mrs. Jones. Look at the study, tell me what you think."

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:57.958
They'll give me that information,

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:00.958
and we'll make the care of the patient better.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
The patient doesn't have to travel.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
He doesn't have to experience the anxiety of not knowing

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:09.958
because of limited expertise.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
We also use [an] electronic medical record system.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:16.958
I'm happy to say that the things we have implemented --

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:23.958
80 percent of U.S. practices do not have them, and yet the technology is there.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:24.958
But you know, they have that luxury.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:29.958
Because if you can't get it in Nashville, you can travel to Birmingham,

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:32.958
two hours away, and you'll get it. If you can't get it in Cleveland,

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.958
you can go to Cincinnati. We don't have that luxury,

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
so we have to make it happen.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:41.958
When we do it, we will put the cost of care down.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:45.958
And we'll extend it to the rural centers and make it affordable.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
And everyone will get the care they deserve.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:52.958
It cannot just be technology, we recognize that.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:56.958
Prevention must be part of the solution -- we emphasize that.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:11:00.958
But, you know, you have to tell people what can be done.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.958
It's not possible to tell people to do what is going to be expensive,

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:06.958
and they go home and can't do it.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
They need to be alive, they need to feed.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:14.958
We recommend exercise as the most effective, simple, easy thing to do.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:18.958
We have had walks every year -- every March, April.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:23.958
We form people into groups and make them go into challenges.

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:26.958
Which group loses the most weight, we give them prizes.

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:30.958
Which groups record more walking distance by pedometer,

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:33.958
we give them prizes. We do this constantly.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
We encourage them to bring children.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
That way we start exposing the children from very early on,

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:42.958
on what these issues are. Because once they learn it,

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:46.958
they will stay with it. In doing this we have created

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.958
at least 100 skilled jobs in Jamaica alone,

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:53.958
and these are physicians with expertise and special training.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:57.958
We have taken care of over 1,000 indigent patients that could have died,

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
including four free pacemakers in patients

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:03.958
with complete heart block. For those that understand cardiology,

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:06.958
complete heart block means certain death.

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:09.958
If you don't get this pacemaker, you will be dead.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:10.958
So we are pleased with that.

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:14.958
Indirectly, we have saved the government of Jamaica five million dollars

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:19.958
from people that would have gone to Miami or Atlanta for care.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:22.958
And we've hopefully saved a lot of lives.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:27.958
By the end of this year, we would have contributed over one million dollars

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:31.958
in indigent care. In the first four months, it's been 340,000 dollars,

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:37.958
averaging 85,000 dollars a month. The government will not do that,

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:38.958
because they have competing needs.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:41.958
They need to put resources elsewhere. But we can still do it.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:46.958
People say, "How can you do that?" This is how we can do that.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:51.958
At least 4,000 rich Jamaicans that were heading to Miami for treatment

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:56.958
have self-confessed that they did not go to Miami

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:58.958
because of the Heart Institute of the Caribbean.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:03.958
And, if they went to Miami, they will spend significantly more --

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:08.958
eight to 10 times more. And they feel happy spending it at home,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:09.958
getting the same quality of care.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:15.958
And for that money -- for every one patient that has the money to pay,

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:18.958
it gives us an opportunity to take care of at least four people

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:21.958
that do not have the resources to pay.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:26.958
(Applause)

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:29.958
For this to work, this progress must be sustainable.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:32.958
So, we emphasize training. Training is critical.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:36.958
We have gone further: we have formed a relationship

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:39.958
with the University of Technology, Jamaica,

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:40.958
where I now have an appointment.

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
And we are starting a biomedical engineering program,

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:48.958
so that we will train people locally, who can repair that equipment.

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:52.958
That way we're not going to deal with obsolescence and all those kinds of issues.

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:57.958
We're also starting ancillary health-care technology training programs --

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:01.958
training people in echocardiography, cardiac ultrasound,

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:04.958
those kinds of things. Now, with that kind of training,

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
it gives people motivation.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:09.958
Because now they will get a bachelors degree in medical imaging

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:15.958
and all that kind of stuff. In the process, I want you to just hear

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:19.958
from the trainees themselves what it has meant for them.

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:20.958
(Video) Dr. Jason Topping: My name is Jason Topping.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
I'm a senior resident in anesthesia in intensive care

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
at the University Hospital of the West Indies.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
I came to the Heart Institute in 2006,

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:34.958
as part of my elective in my anesthesia and intensive care program.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
I spent three months at the Heart Institute.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
There's been no doubt around my colleagues

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:42.958
about the utility of the training I received here,

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:47.958
and I think there's been an increased interest now in --

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:51.958
particularly in echocardiography and its use in our setting.

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:56.958
Sharon Lazarus: I am an echocardiographer at the Heart Institute of the Caribbean,

00:14:56.958 --> 00:15:01.958
since the past two years. I received training at this institution.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:06.958
I think this aspect of training in cardiology

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:10.958
that the Heart Institute of the Caribbean has introduced in Jamaica

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:19.958
is very important in terms of diagnosing cardiac diseases.

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:24.958
Ernest Madu: The lesson in this is that it can be done, and it can be sustained,

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:28.958
and you can make it possible for everyone.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:32.958
Who are we to decide that poor people cannot get the best care?

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:36.958
When have you been appointed to play God?

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:41.958
It is not my decision. My job is to make sure that every person,

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:46.958
no matter what fate has assigned to you, will have the opportunity

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:49.958
to get the best quality health care in life.

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:53.958
Next stop is West African Heart Institute,

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:56.958
that we are going to be doing in Port Harcourt, Nigeria,

00:15:56.958 --> 00:16:00.958
as I said before. We will do other centers across West Africa.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:05.958
We will extend the same system into other areas,

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:06.958
like dialysis treatment.

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:10.958
And anyone who is interested in doing it in any health care situation,

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:15.958
we will be happy to assist you and tell you how we've done it,

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:19.958
and how you can do it. If we do this,

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:23.958
we can change the face of health care in Africa.

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:27.958
Africa has been good to us; it is time for us to give back to Africa.

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:30.958
I am going. Those who want to come,

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:32.958
I welcome you to come along with me.

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:34.958
Thank you.

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:38.958
(Applause)

title: Where does creativity hide?
transcript: The Value of Nothing: Out of Nothing Comes Something. That was an essay I wrote when I was 11 years old and I got a B+. (Laughter) What I'm going to talk about: nothing out of something, and how we create. And I'm gonna try and do that within the 18-minute time span that we were told to stay within, and to follow the TED commandments: that is, actually, something that creates a near-death experience, but near-death is good for creativity. (Laughter) OK.So, I also want to explain, because Dave Eggers said he was going to heckle me if I said anything that was a lie, or not true to universal creativity. And I've done it this way for half the audience, who is scientific. When I say we, I don't mean you, necessarily; I mean me, and my right brain, my left brain and the one that's in between that is the censor and tells me what I'm saying is wrong. And I'm going do that also by looking at what I think is part of my creative process, which includes a number of things that happened, actually — the nothing started even earlier than the moment in which I'm creating something new. And that includes nature, and nurture, and what I refer to as nightmares.Now in the nature area, we look at whether or not we are innately equipped with something, perhaps in our brains, some abnormal chromosome that causes this muse-like effect. And some people would say that we're born with it in some other means. And others, like my mother, would say that I get my material from past lives. Some people would also say that creativity may be a function of some other neurological quirk — van Gogh syndrome — that you have a little bit of, you know, psychosis, or depression. I do have to say, somebody — I read recently that van Gogh wasn't really necessarily psychotic, that he might have had temporal lobe seizures, and that might have caused his spurt of creativity, and I don't — I suppose it does something in some part of your brain. And I will mention that I actually developed temporal lobe seizures a number of years ago, but it was during the time I was writing my last book, and some people say that book is quite different.I think that part of it also begins with a sense of identity crisis: you know, who am I, why am I this particular person, why am I not black like everybody else? And sometimes you're equipped with skills, but they may not be the kind of skills that enable creativity. I used to draw. I thought I would be an artist. And I had a miniature poodle. And it wasn't bad, but it wasn't really creative. Because all I could really do was represent in a very one-on-one way. And I have a sense that I probably copied this from a book. And then, I also wasn't really shining in a certain area that I wanted to be, and you know, you look at those scores, and it wasn't bad, but it was not certainly predictive that I would one day make my living out of the artful arrangement of words.Also, one of the principles of creativity is to have a little childhood trauma. And I had the usual kind that I think a lot of people had, and that is that, you know, I had expectations placed on me. That figure right there, by the way, figure right there was a toy given to me when I was but nine years old, and it was to help me become a doctor from a very early age. I have some ones that were long lasting: from the age of five to 15, this was supposed to be my side occupation, and it led to a sense of failure.But actually, there was something quite real in my life that happened when I was about 14. And it was discovered that my brother, in 1967, and then my father, six months later, had brain tumors. And my mother believed that something had gone wrong, and she was gonna find out what it was, and she was gonna fix it. My father was a Baptist minister, and he believed in miracles, and that God's will would take care of that. But, of course, they ended up dying, six months apart. And after that, my mother believed that it was fate, or curses — she went looking through all the reasons in the universe why this would have happened. Everything except randomness. She did not believe in randomness. There was a reason for everything. And one of the reasons, she thought, was that her mother, who had died when she was very young, was angry at her. And so, I had this notion of death all around me, because my mother also believed that I would be next, and she would be next. And when you are faced with the prospect of death very soon, you begin to think very much about everything. You become very creative, in a survival sense.And this, then, led to my big questions. And they're the same ones that I have today. And they are: why do things happen, and how do things happen? And the one my mother asked: how do I make things happen? It's a wonderful way to look at these questions, when you write a story. Because, after all, in that framework, between page one and 300, you have to answer this question of why things happen, how things happen, in what order they happen. What are the influences? How do I, as the narrator, as the writer, also influence that? And it's also one that, I think, many of our scientists have been asking. It's a kind of cosmology, and I have to develop a cosmology of my own universe, as the creator of that universe.And you see, there's a lot of back and forth in trying to make that happen, trying to figure it out — years and years, oftentimes. So, when I look at creativity, I also think that it is this sense or this inability to repress, my looking at associations in practically anything in life. And I got a lot of them during what's been going on throughout this conference, almost everything that's been going on.And so I'm going to use, as the metaphor, this association: quantum mechanics, which I really don't understand, but I'm still gonna use it as the process for explaining how it is the metaphor. So, in quantum mechanics, of course, you have dark energy and dark matter. And it's the same thing in looking at these questions of how things happen. There's a lot of unknown, and you often don't know what it is except by its absence. But when you make those associations, you want them to come together in a kind of synergy in the story, and what you're finding is what matters. The meaning. And that's what I look for in my work, a personal meaning.There is also the uncertainty principle, which is part of quantum mechanics, as I understand it. (Laughter) And this happens constantly in the writing. And there's the terrible and dreaded observer effect, in which you're looking for something, and you know, things are happening simultaneously, and you're looking at it in a different way, and you're trying to really look for the about-ness, or what is this story about. And if you try too hard, then you will only write the about. You won't discover anything. And what you were supposed to find, what you hoped to find in some serendipitous way, is no longer there. Now, I don't want to ignore the other side of what happens in our universe, like many of our scientists have. And so, I am going to just throw in string theory here, and just say that creative people are multidimensional, and there are 11 levels, I think, of anxiety. (Laughter) And they all operate at the same time.There is also a big question of ambiguity. And I would link that to something called the cosmological constant. And you don't know what is operating, but something is operating there. And ambiguity, to me, is very uncomfortable in my life, and I have it. Moral ambiguity. It is constantly there. And, just as an example, this is one that recently came to me. It was something I read in an editorial by a woman who was talking about the war in Iraq. And she said, "Save a man from drowning, you are responsible to him for life." A very famous Chinese saying, she said. And that means because we went into Iraq, we should stay there until things were solved. You know, maybe even 100 years. So, there was another one that I came across, and it's "saving fish from drowning." And it's what Buddhist fishermen say, because they're not supposed to kill anything. And they also have to make a living, and people need to be fed. So their way of rationalizing that is they are saving the fish from drowning, and unfortunately, in the process the fish die.Now, what's encapsulated in both these drowning metaphors — actually, one of them is my mother's interpretation, and it is a famous Chinese saying, because she said it to me: "save a man from drowning, you are responsible to him for life." And it was a warning — don't get involved in other people's business, or you're going to get stuck. OK. I think if somebody really was drowning, she'd save them. But, both of these sayings — saving a fish from drowning, or saving a man from drowning — to me they had to do with intentions.And all of us in life, when we see a situation, we have a response. And then we have intentions. There's an ambiguity of what that should be that we should do, and then we do something. And the results of that may not match what our intentions had been. Maybe things go wrong. And so, after that, what are our responsibilities? What are we supposed to do? Do we stay in for life, or do we do something else and justify and say, well, my intentions were good, and therefore I cannot be held responsible for all of it? That is the ambiguity in my life that really disturbed me, and led me to write a book called "Saving Fish From Drowning."I saw examples of that. Once I identified this question, it was all over the place. I got these hints everywhere. And then, in a way, I knew that they had always been there. And then writing, that's what happens. I get these hints, these clues, and I realize that they've been obvious, and yet they have not been. And what I need, in effect, is a focus. And when I have the question, it is a focus. And all these things that seem to be flotsam and jetsam in life actually go through that question, and what happens is those particular things become relevant. And it seems like it's happening all the time. You think there's a sort of coincidence going on, a serendipity, in which you're getting all this help from the universe. And it may also be explained that now you have a focus. And you are noticing it more often.But you apply this. You begin to look at things having to do with your tensions. Your brother, who's fallen in trouble, do you take care of him? Why or why not? It may be something that is perhaps more serious — as I said, human rights in Burma. I was thinking that I shouldn't go because somebody said, if I did, it would show that I approved of the military regime there. And then, after a while, I had to ask myself, "Why do we take on knowledge, why do we take on assumptions that other people have given us?" And it was the same thing that I felt when I was growing up, and was hearing these rules of moral conduct from my father, who was a Baptist minister. So I decided that I would go to Burma for my own intentions, and still didn't know that if I went there, what the result of that would be, if I wrote a book — and I just would have to face that later, when the time came.We are all concerned with things that we see in the world that we are aware of. We come to this point and say, what do I as an individual do? Not all of us can go to Africa, or work at hospitals, so what do we do, if we have this moral response, this feeling? Also, I think one of the biggest things we are all looking at, and we talked about today, is genocide. This leads to this question. When I look at all these things that are morally ambiguous and uncomfortable, and I consider what my intentions should be, I realize it goes back to this identity question that I had when I was a child — and why am I here, and what is the meaning of my life, and what is my place in the universe?It seems so obvious, and yet it is not. We all hate moral ambiguity in some sense, and yet it is also absolutely necessary. In writing a story, it is the place where I begin. Sometimes I get help from the universe, it seems. My mother would say it was the ghost of my grandmother from the very first book, because it seemed I knew things I was not supposed to know. Instead of writing that the grandmother died accidentally, from an overdose of opium, while having too much of a good time, I actually put down in the story that the woman killed herself, and that actually was the way it happened. And my mother decided that that information must have come from my grandmother.There are also things, quite uncanny, which bring me information that will help me in the writing of the book. In this case, I was writing a story that included some kind of detail, period of history, a certain location. And I needed to find something historically that would match that. And I took down this book, and I — first page that I flipped it to was exactly the setting, and the time period, and the kind of character I needed — was the Taiping rebellion, happening in the area near Guilin, outside of that, and a character who thought he was the son of God.You wonder, are these things random chance? Well, what is random? What is chance? What is luck? What are things that you get from the universe that you can't really explain? And that goes into the story, too. These are the things I constantly think about from day to day. Especially when good things happen, and, in particular, when bad things happen. But I do think there's a kind of serendipity, and I do want to know what those elements are, so I can thank them, and also try to find them in my life. Because, again, I think that when I am aware of them, more of them happen.Another chance encounter is when I went to a place — I just was with some friends, and we drove randomly to a different place, and we ended up in this non-tourist location, a beautiful village, pristine. And we walked three valleys beyond, and the third valley, there was something quite mysterious and ominous, a discomfort I felt. And then I knew that had to be [the] setting of my book. And in writing one of the scenes, it happened in that third valley. For some reason I wrote about cairns — stacks of rocks — that a man was building. And I didn't know exactly why I had it, but it was so vivid. I got stuck, and a friend, when she asked if I would go for a walk with her dogs, that I said, sure. And about 45 minutes later, walking along the beach, I came across this. And it was a man, a Chinese man, and he was stacking these things, not with glue, not with anything. And I asked him, "How is it possible to do this?" And he said, "Well, I guess with everything in life, there's a place of balance." And this was exactly the meaning of my story at that point. I had so many examples — I have so many instances like this, when I'm writing a story, and I cannot explain it. Is it because I had the filter that I have such a strong coincidence in writing about these things? Or is it a kind of serendipity that we cannot explain, like the cosmological constant?A big thing that I also think about is accidents. And as I said, my mother did not believe in randomness. What is the nature of accidents? And how are we going to assign what the responsibility and the causes are, outside of a court of law? I was able to see that in a firsthand way, when I went to beautiful Dong village, in Guizhou, the poorest province of China. And I saw this beautiful place. I knew I wanted to come back. And I had a chance to do that, when National Geographic asked me if I wanted to write anything about China. And I said yes, about this village of singing people, singing minority. And they agreed, and between the time I saw this place and the next time I went, there was a terrible accident. A man, an old man, fell asleep, and his quilt dropped in a pan of fire that kept him warm. 60 homes were destroyed, and 40 were damaged. Responsibility was assigned to the family. The man's sons were banished to live three kilometers away, in a cowshed. And, of course, as Westerners, we say, "Well, it was an accident. That's not fair. It's the son, not the father."When I go on a story, I have to let go of those kinds of beliefs. It takes a while, but I have to let go of them and just go there, and be there. And so I was there on three occasions, different seasons. And I began to sense something different about the history, and what had happened before, and the nature of life in a very poor village, and what you find as your joys, and your rituals, your traditions, your links with other families. And I saw how this had a kind of justice, in its responsibility. I was able to find out also about the ceremony that they were using, a ceremony they hadn't used in about 29 years. And it was to send some men — a Feng Shui master sent men down to the underworld on ghost horses. Now you, as Westerners, and I, as Westerners, would say well, that's superstition. But after being there for a while, and seeing the amazing things that happened, you begin to wonder whose beliefs are those that are in operation in the world, determining how things happen.So I remained with them, and the more I wrote that story, the more I got into those beliefs, and I think that's important for me — to take on the beliefs, because that is where the story is real, and that is where I'm gonna find the answers to how I feel about certain questions that I have in life. Years go by, of course, and the writing, it doesn't happen instantly, as I'm trying to convey it to you here at TED. The book comes and it goes. When it arrives, it is no longer my book. It is in the hands of readers, and they interpret it differently. But I go back to this question of, how do I create something out of nothing? And how do I create my own life?And I think it is by questioning, and saying to myself that there are no absolute truths. I believe in specifics, the specifics of story, and the past, the specifics of that past, and what is happening in the story at that point. I also believe that in thinking about things — my thinking about luck, and fate, and coincidences and accidents, God's will, and the synchrony of mysterious forces — I will come to some notion of what that is, how we create. I have to think of my role. Where I am in the universe, and did somebody intend for me to be that way, or is it just something I came up with? And I also can find that by imagining fully, and becoming what is imagined — and yet is in that real world, the fictional world. And that is how I find particles of truth, not the absolute truth, or the whole truth. And they have to be in all possibilities, including those I never considered before.So, there are never complete answers. Or rather, if there is an answer, it is to remind myself that there is uncertainty in everything, and that is good, because then I will discover something new. And if there is a partial answer, a more complete answer from me, it is to simply imagine. And to imagine is to put myself in that story, until there was only — there is a transparency between me and the story that I am creating.And that's how I've discovered that if I feel what is in the story — in one story — then I come the closest, I think, to knowing what compassion is, to feeling that compassion. Because for everything, in that question of how things happen, it has to do with the feeling. I have to become the story in order to understand a lot of that. We've come to the end of the talk, and I will reveal what is in the bag, and it is the muse, and it is the things that transform in our lives, that are wonderful and stay with us. There she is. Thank you very much! (Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:15.958
The Value of Nothing: Out of Nothing Comes Something.

00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:19.958
That was an essay I wrote when I was 11 years old

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:21.958
and I got a B+. (Laughter)

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:25.958
What I'm going to talk about: nothing out of something, and how we create.

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:27.958
And I'm gonna try and do that within

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:32.958
the 18-minute time span that we were told to stay within,

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.958
and to follow the TED commandments:

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:37.958
that is, actually, something that creates

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:39.958
a near-death experience,

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:41.958
but near-death is good for creativity.

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:45.958
(Laughter) OK.

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:47.958
So, I also want to explain,

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:50.958
because Dave Eggers said he was going to heckle me

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:55.958
if I said anything that was a lie, or not true to universal creativity.

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:58.958
And I've done it this way for half the audience, who is scientific.

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:02.958
When I say we, I don't mean you, necessarily;

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:05.958
I mean me, and my right brain, my left brain

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:07.958
and the one that's in between that is the censor

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:09.958
and tells me what I'm saying is wrong.

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:12.958
And I'm going do that also by looking at

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:15.958
what I think is part of my creative process,

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:18.958
which includes a number of things that happened, actually --

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:21.958
the nothing started even earlier than the moment

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:24.958
in which I'm creating something new.

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:29.958
And that includes nature, and nurture,

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:32.958
and what I refer to as nightmares.

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:36.958
Now in the nature area, we look at whether or not

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:39.958
we are innately equipped with something, perhaps

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:42.958
in our brains, some abnormal chromosome

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:46.958
that causes this muse-like effect.

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:52.958
And some people would say that we're born with it in some other means.

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:54.958
And others, like my mother,

00:01:54.958 --> 00:02:00.958
would say that I get my material from past lives.

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:03.958
Some people would also say that creativity

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:08.958
may be a function of some other neurological quirk --

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:13.958
van Gogh syndrome -- that you have a little bit of, you know, psychosis, or depression.

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:16.958
I do have to say, somebody -- I read recently

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:19.958
that van Gogh wasn't really necessarily psychotic,

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:21.958
that he might have had temporal lobe seizures,

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:25.958
and that might have caused his spurt of creativity, and I don't --

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:28.958
I suppose it does something in some part of your brain.

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
And I will mention that I actually developed

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:34.958
temporal lobe seizures a number of years ago,

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:37.958
but it was during the time I was writing my last book,

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:41.958
and some people say that book is quite different.

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:46.958
I think that part of it also begins with a sense of identity crisis:

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:50.958
you know, who am I, why am I this particular person,

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:55.958
why am I not black like everybody else?

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.958
And sometimes you're equipped with skills,

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:01.958
but they may not be the kind of skills that enable creativity.

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:04.958
I used to draw. I thought I would be an artist.

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:06.958
And I had a miniature poodle.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:08.958
And it wasn't bad, but it wasn't really creative.

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:13.958
Because all I could really do was represent in a very one-on-one way.

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:17.958
And I have a sense that I probably copied this from a book.

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:23.958
And then, I also wasn't really shining in a certain area that I wanted to be,

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:27.958
and you know, you look at those scores, and it wasn't bad,

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:31.958
but it was not certainly predictive that I would one day make

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:35.958
my living out of the artful arrangement of words.

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:41.958
Also, one of the principles of creativity is to have a little childhood trauma.

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:45.958
And I had the usual kind that I think a lot of people had,

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:49.958
and that is that, you know, I had expectations placed on me.

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:52.958
That figure right there, by the way,

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:57.958
figure right there was a toy given to me when I was but nine years old,

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:02.958
and it was to help me become a doctor from a very early age.

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:07.958
I have some ones that were long lasting: from the age of five to 15,

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:10.958
this was supposed to be my side occupation,

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:13.958
and it led to a sense of failure.

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:16.958
But actually, there was something quite real in my life

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.958
that happened when I was about 14.

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:23.958
And it was discovered that my brother, in 1967, and then my father,

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
six months later, had brain tumors.

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:30.958
And my mother believed that something had gone wrong,

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:33.958
and she was gonna find out what it was, and she was gonna fix it.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:37.958
My father was a Baptist minister, and he believed in miracles,

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.958
and that God's will would take care of that.

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:43.958
But, of course, they ended up dying, six months apart.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:47.958
And after that, my mother believed that it was fate, or curses

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:50.958
-- she went looking through all the reasons in the universe

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:52.958
why this would have happened.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:57.958
Everything except randomness. She did not believe in randomness.

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
There was a reason for everything.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
And one of the reasons, she thought, was that her mother,

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:06.958
who had died when she was very young, was angry at her.

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
And so, I had this notion of death all around me,

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:14.958
because my mother also believed that I would be next, and she would be next.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:17.958
And when you are faced with the prospect of death very soon,

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:22.958
you begin to think very much about everything.

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:26.958
You become very creative, in a survival sense.

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:30.958
And this, then, led to my big questions.

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:33.958
And they're the same ones that I have today.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:38.958
And they are: why do things happen, and how do things happen?

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:45.958
And the one my mother asked: how do I make things happen?

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:50.958
It's a wonderful way to look at these questions, when you write a story.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:56.958
Because, after all, in that framework, between page one and 300,

00:05:56.958 --> 00:06:00.958
you have to answer this question of why things happen, how things happen,

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:03.958
in what order they happen. What are the influences?

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:07.958
How do I, as the narrator, as the writer, also influence that?

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:11.958
And it's also one that, I think, many of our scientists have been asking.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:17.958
It's a kind of cosmology, and I have to develop a cosmology of my own universe,

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
as the creator of that universe.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:23.958
And you see, there's a lot of back and forth

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
in trying to make that happen, trying to figure it out

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:30.958
-- years and years, oftentimes.

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:37.958
So, when I look at creativity, I also think that it is this sense or this inability

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:41.958
to repress, my looking at associations in practically anything in life.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:45.958
And I got a lot of them during what's been going on

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958
throughout this conference,

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
almost everything that's been going on.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:54.958
And so I'm going to use, as the metaphor, this association:

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:58.958
quantum mechanics, which I really don't understand,

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
but I'm still gonna use it as the process

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:04.958
for explaining how it is the metaphor.

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:11.958
So, in quantum mechanics, of course, you have dark energy and dark matter.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:15.958
And it's the same thing in looking at these questions of how things happen.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:21.958
There's a lot of unknown, and you often don't know what it is except by its absence.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
But when you make those associations,

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:27.958
you want them to come together in a kind of synergy in the story,

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:31.958
and what you're finding is what matters. The meaning.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:35.958
And that's what I look for in my work, a personal meaning.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:40.958
There is also the uncertainty principle, which is part of quantum mechanics,

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
as I understand it. (Laughter)

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:46.958
And this happens constantly in the writing.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:49.958
And there's the terrible and dreaded observer effect,

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958
in which you're looking for something, and

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:54.958
you know, things are happening simultaneously,

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
and you're looking at it in a different way,

00:07:56.958 --> 00:08:00.958
and you're trying to really look for the about-ness,

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:04.958
or what is this story about. And if you try too hard,

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:07.958
then you will only write the about.

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:10.958
You won't discover anything.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:12.958
And what you were supposed to find,

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:15.958
what you hoped to find in some serendipitous way,

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:18.958
is no longer there.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
Now, I don't want to ignore

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
the other side of what happens in our universe,

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
like many of our scientists have.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:29.958
And so, I am going to just throw in string theory here,

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:32.958
and just say that creative people are multidimensional,

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:36.958
and there are 11 levels, I think, of anxiety.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:40.958
(Laughter) And they all operate at the same time.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:43.958
There is also a big question of ambiguity.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:49.958
And I would link that to something called the cosmological constant.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
And you don't know what is operating, but something is operating there.

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:55.958
And ambiguity, to me, is very uncomfortable

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:58.958
in my life, and I have it. Moral ambiguity.

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:02.958
It is constantly there. And, just as an example,

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:05.958
this is one that recently came to me.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
It was something I read in an editorial by a woman

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:11.958
who was talking about the war in Iraq. And she said,

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:14.958
"Save a man from drowning, you are responsible to him for life."

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:17.958
A very famous Chinese saying, she said.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:21.958
And that means because we went into Iraq, we should stay there

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:25.958
until things were solved. You know, maybe even 100 years.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:30.958
So, there was another one that I came across,

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.958
and it's "saving fish from drowning."

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
And it's what Buddhist fishermen say,

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
because they're not supposed to kill anything.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
And they also have to make a living, and people need to be fed.

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:45.958
So their way of rationalizing that is they are saving the fish from drowning,

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
and unfortunately, in the process the fish die.

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:53.958
Now, what's encapsulated in both these drowning metaphors

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
-- actually, one of them is my mother's interpretation,

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.958
and it is a famous Chinese saying, because she said it to me:

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
"save a man from drowning, you are responsible to him for life."

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:06.958
And it was a warning -- don't get involved in other people's business,

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:08.958
or you're going to get stuck.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:12.958
OK. I think if somebody really was drowning, she'd save them.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:16.958
But, both of these sayings -- saving a fish from drowning,

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:20.958
or saving a man from drowning -- to me they had to do with intentions.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:25.958
And all of us in life, when we see a situation, we have a response.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
And then we have intentions.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:32.958
There's an ambiguity of what that should be that we should do,

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
and then we do something.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
And the results of that may not match what our intentions had been.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:42.958
Maybe things go wrong. And so, after that, what are our responsibilities?

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
What are we supposed to do?

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:46.958
Do we stay in for life,

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:51.958
or do we do something else and justify and say, well, my intentions were good,

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:57.958
and therefore I cannot be held responsible for all of it?

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
That is the ambiguity in my life

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:03.958
that really disturbed me, and led me to write a book called

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
"Saving Fish From Drowning."

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:12.958
I saw examples of that. Once I identified this question, it was all over the place.

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
I got these hints everywhere.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
And then, in a way, I knew that they had always been there.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:20.958
And then writing, that's what happens. I get these hints, these clues,

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:27.958
and I realize that they've been obvious, and yet they have not been.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:31.958
And what I need, in effect, is a focus.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
And when I have the question, it is a focus.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:38.958
And all these things that seem to be flotsam and jetsam in life actually go through

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:43.958
that question, and what happens is those particular things become relevant.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
And it seems like it's happening all the time.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
You think there's a sort of coincidence going on, a serendipity,

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:51.958
in which you're getting all this help from the universe.

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:54.958
And it may also be explained that now you have a focus.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:58.958
And you are noticing it more often.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
But you apply this.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:04.958
You begin to look at things having to do with your tensions.

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:07.958
Your brother, who's fallen in trouble, do you take care of him?

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
Why or why not?

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:13.958
It may be something that is perhaps more serious

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:16.958
-- as I said, human rights in Burma.

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:20.958
I was thinking that I shouldn't go because somebody said, if I did, it would show

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:23.958
that I approved of the military regime there.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:26.958
And then, after a while, I had to ask myself,

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:28.958
"Why do we take on knowledge, why do we take on assumptions

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.958
that other people have given us?"

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:34.958
And it was the same thing that I felt when I was growing up,

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:39.958
and was hearing these rules of moral conduct from my father,

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
who was a Baptist minister.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:46.958
So I decided that I would go to Burma for my own intentions,

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:49.958
and still didn't know that if I went there,

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
what the result of that would be, if I wrote a book --

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:56.958
and I just would have to face that later, when the time came.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:13:01.958
We are all concerned with things that we see in the world that we are aware of.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:06.958
We come to this point and say, what do I as an individual do?

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:10.958
Not all of us can go to Africa, or work at hospitals,

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:17.958
so what do we do, if we have this moral response, this feeling?

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
Also, I think one of the biggest things we are all looking at,

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:23.958
and we talked about today, is genocide.

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:26.958
This leads to this question.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:31.958
When I look at all these things that are morally ambiguous and uncomfortable,

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
and I consider what my intentions should be,

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:38.958
I realize it goes back to this identity question that I had when I was a child

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
-- and why am I here, and what is the meaning of my life,

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
and what is my place in the universe?

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
It seems so obvious, and yet it is not.

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:51.958
We all hate moral ambiguity in some sense,

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:55.958
and yet it is also absolutely necessary.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:59.958
In writing a story, it is the place where I begin.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:03.958
Sometimes I get help from the universe, it seems.

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:06.958
My mother would say it was the ghost of my grandmother from the very first book,

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:09.958
because it seemed I knew things I was not supposed to know.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
Instead of writing that the grandmother died accidentally,

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:15.958
from an overdose of opium, while having too much of a good time,

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:20.958
I actually put down in the story that the woman killed herself,

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
and that actually was the way it happened.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:27.958
And my mother decided that that information must have come from my grandmother.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:30.958
There are also things, quite uncanny,

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:34.958
which bring me information that will help me in the writing of the book.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:36.958
In this case, I was writing a story

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:40.958
that included some kind of detail, period of history, a certain location.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:43.958
And I needed to find something historically that would match that.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
And I took down this book, and I --

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:51.958
first page that I flipped it to was exactly the setting, and the time period,

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
and the kind of character I needed -- was the Taiping rebellion,

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:58.958
happening in the area near Guilin, outside of that,

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
and a character who thought he was the son of God.

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:04.958
You wonder, are these things random chance?

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:08.958
Well, what is random? What is chance? What is luck?

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:12.958
What are things that you get from the universe that you can't really explain?

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
And that goes into the story, too.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:17.958
These are the things I constantly think about from day to day.

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:19.958
Especially when good things happen,

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:23.958
and, in particular, when bad things happen.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
But I do think there's a kind of serendipity,

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:28.958
and I do want to know what those elements are,

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:33.958
so I can thank them, and also try to find them in my life.

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:37.958
Because, again, I think that when I am aware of them, more of them happen.

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:41.958
Another chance encounter is when I went to a place

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:45.958
-- I just was with some friends, and we drove randomly to a different place,

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:49.958
and we ended up in this non-tourist location,

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
a beautiful village, pristine.

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:53.958
And we walked three valleys beyond,

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:56.958
and the third valley, there was something quite mysterious and ominous,

00:15:56.958 --> 00:16:02.958
a discomfort I felt. And then I knew that had to be [the] setting of my book.

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:05.958
And in writing one of the scenes, it happened in that third valley.

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:12.958
For some reason I wrote about cairns -- stacks of rocks -- that a man was building.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
And I didn't know exactly why I had it, but it was so vivid.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:20.958
I got stuck, and a friend, when she asked if I would go for a walk with her dogs,

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:23.958
that I said, sure. And about 45 minutes later,

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:27.958
walking along the beach, I came across this.

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
And it was a man, a Chinese man,

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:32.958
and he was stacking these things, not with glue, not with anything.

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:35.958
And I asked him, "How is it possible to do this?"

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:39.958
And he said, "Well, I guess with everything in life, there's a place of balance."

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:44.958
And this was exactly the meaning of my story at that point.

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:49.958
I had so many examples -- I have so many instances like this, when I'm writing a story,

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:51.958
and I cannot explain it.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:55.958
Is it because I had the filter that I have such a strong coincidence

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:58.958
in writing about these things?

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:05.958
Or is it a kind of serendipity that we cannot explain, like the cosmological constant?

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:08.958
A big thing that I also think about is accidents.

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:11.958
And as I said, my mother did not believe in randomness.

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:13.958
What is the nature of accidents?

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:17.958
And how are we going to assign what the responsibility and the causes are,

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:20.958
outside of a court of law?

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:23.958
I was able to see that in a firsthand way,

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:29.958
when I went to beautiful Dong village, in Guizhou, the poorest province of China.

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:31.958
And I saw this beautiful place. I knew I wanted to come back.

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:34.958
And I had a chance to do that, when National Geographic asked me

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:36.958
if I wanted to write anything about China.

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:41.958
And I said yes, about this village of singing people, singing minority.

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:46.958
And they agreed, and between the time I saw this place and the next time I went,

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:50.958
there was a terrible accident. A man, an old man, fell asleep,

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:53.958
and his quilt dropped in a pan of fire that kept him warm.

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:59.958
60 homes were destroyed, and 40 were damaged.

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:01.958
Responsibility was assigned to the family.

00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:05.958
The man's sons were banished to live three kilometers away, in a cowshed.

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:09.958
And, of course, as Westerners, we say, "Well, it was an accident. That's not fair.

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:11.958
It's the son, not the father."

00:18:11.958 --> 00:18:17.958
When I go on a story, I have to let go of those kinds of beliefs.

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:21.958
It takes a while, but I have to let go of them and just go there, and be there.

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:24.958
And so I was there on three occasions, different seasons.

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:28.958
And I began to sense something different about the history,

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:32.958
and what had happened before, and the nature of life in a very poor village,

00:18:32.958 --> 00:18:35.958
and what you find as your joys, and your rituals, your traditions, your links

00:18:35.958 --> 00:18:45.958
with other families. And I saw how this had a kind of justice, in its responsibility.

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:50.958
I was able to find out also about the ceremony that they were using,

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:58.958
a ceremony they hadn't used in about 29 years. And it was to send some men

00:18:58.958 --> 00:19:02.958
-- a Feng Shui master sent men down to the underworld on ghost horses.

00:19:02.958 --> 00:19:05.958
Now you, as Westerners, and I, as Westerners,

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:08.958
would say well, that's superstition. But after being there for a while,

00:19:08.958 --> 00:19:11.958
and seeing the amazing things that happened,

00:19:11.958 --> 00:19:16.958
you begin to wonder whose beliefs are those that are in operation in the world,

00:19:16.958 --> 00:19:19.958
determining how things happen.

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:22.958
So I remained with them, and the more I wrote that story,

00:19:22.958 --> 00:19:26.958
the more I got into those beliefs, and I think that's important for me

00:19:26.958 --> 00:19:29.958
-- to take on the beliefs, because that is where the story is real,

00:19:29.958 --> 00:19:31.958
and that is where I'm gonna find the answers

00:19:31.958 --> 00:19:36.958
to how I feel about certain questions that I have in life.

00:19:36.958 --> 00:19:39.958
Years go by, of course, and the writing, it doesn't happen instantly,

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:43.958
as I'm trying to convey it to you here at TED.

00:19:43.958 --> 00:19:48.958
The book comes and it goes. When it arrives, it is no longer my book.

00:19:48.958 --> 00:19:52.958
It is in the hands of readers, and they interpret it differently.

00:19:52.958 --> 00:19:58.958
But I go back to this question of, how do I create something out of nothing?

00:19:58.958 --> 00:20:01.958
And how do I create my own life?

00:20:01.958 --> 00:20:03.958
And I think it is by questioning,

00:20:03.958 --> 00:20:08.958
and saying to myself that there are no absolute truths.

00:20:08.958 --> 00:20:12.958
I believe in specifics, the specifics of story,

00:20:12.958 --> 00:20:15.958
and the past, the specifics of that past,

00:20:15.958 --> 00:20:19.958
and what is happening in the story at that point.

00:20:19.958 --> 00:20:22.958
I also believe that in thinking about things --

00:20:22.958 --> 00:20:26.958
my thinking about luck, and fate, and coincidences and accidents,

00:20:26.958 --> 00:20:30.958
God's will, and the synchrony of mysterious forces --

00:20:30.958 --> 00:20:36.958
I will come to some notion of what that is, how we create.

00:20:36.958 --> 00:20:40.958
I have to think of my role. Where I am in the universe,

00:20:40.958 --> 00:20:45.958
and did somebody intend for me to be that way, or is it just something I came up with?

00:20:45.958 --> 00:20:53.958
And I also can find that by imagining fully, and becoming what is imagined --

00:20:53.958 --> 00:20:56.958
and yet is in that real world, the fictional world.

00:20:56.958 --> 00:21:04.958
And that is how I find particles of truth, not the absolute truth, or the whole truth.

00:21:04.958 --> 00:21:06.958
And they have to be in all possibilities,

00:21:06.958 --> 00:21:09.958
including those I never considered before.

00:21:09.958 --> 00:21:12.958
So, there are never complete answers.

00:21:12.958 --> 00:21:17.958
Or rather, if there is an answer, it is to remind

00:21:17.958 --> 00:21:21.958
myself that there is uncertainty in everything,

00:21:21.958 --> 00:21:26.958
and that is good, because then I will discover something new.

00:21:26.958 --> 00:21:30.958
And if there is a partial answer, a more complete answer from me,

00:21:30.958 --> 00:21:33.958
it is to simply imagine.

00:21:33.958 --> 00:21:37.958
And to imagine is to put myself in that story,

00:21:37.958 --> 00:21:43.958
until there was only -- there is a transparency between me and the story that I am creating.

00:21:43.958 --> 00:21:49.958
And that's how I've discovered that if I feel what is in the story

00:21:49.958 --> 00:21:55.958
-- in one story -- then I come the closest, I think,

00:21:55.958 --> 00:21:59.958
to knowing what compassion is, to feeling that compassion.

00:21:59.958 --> 00:22:01.958
Because for everything,

00:22:01.958 --> 00:22:05.958
in that question of how things happen, it has to do with the feeling.

00:22:05.958 --> 00:22:11.958
I have to become the story in order to understand a lot of that.

00:22:11.958 --> 00:22:13.958
We've come to the end of the talk,

00:22:13.958 --> 00:22:17.958
and I will reveal what is in the bag, and it is the muse,

00:22:17.958 --> 00:22:20.958
and it is the things that transform in our lives,

00:22:20.958 --> 00:22:30.958
that are wonderful and stay with us.

00:22:30.958 --> 00:22:31.958
There she is.

00:22:31.958 --> 00:22:33.958
Thank you very much!

00:22:33.958 --> 00:22:39.958
(Applause)
